3108 ACT II SCENE 1
3109 Paris The KING'S palace
3110 Flourish of cornets Enter the KING with divers young LORDS taking leave
3111 for the Florentine war BERTRAM and PAROLLES ATTENDANTS
3112 KING Farewell young lords these warlike principles
3113 Do not throw from you And you my lords farewell
3114 Share the advice betwixt you if both gain all
3115 The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis receiv'd
3116 And is enough for both
3117 FIRST LORD 'Tis our hope sir
3118 After wellent'red soldiers to return
3119 And find your Grace in health
3120 KING No no it cannot be and yet my heart
3121 Will not confess he owes the malady
3122 That doth my life besiege Farewell young lords
3123 Whether I live or die be you the sons
3124 Of worthy Frenchmen let higher Italy
3125 Those bated that inherit but the fall
3126 Of the last monarchysee that you come
3127 Not to woo honour but to wed it when
3128 The bravest questant shrinks find what you seek
3129 That fame may cry you aloud I say farewell
3130 SECOND LORD Health at your bidding serve your Majesty
3131 KING Those girls of Italy take heed of them
3132 They say our French lack language to deny
3133 If they demand beware of being captives
3134 Before you serve
3135 BOTH Our hearts receive your warnings
3136 KING Farewell [To ATTENDANTS] Come hither to me
3137 The KING retires attended
3138 FIRST LORD O my sweet lord that you will stay behind us
3139 PAROLLES 'Tis not his fault the spark
3140 SECOND LORD O 'tis brave wars
3141 PAROLLES Most admirable I have seen those wars
3142 BERTRAM I am commanded here and kept a coil with
3143 'Too young and next year and Tis too early'
3144 PAROLLES An thy mind stand to 't boy steal away bravely
3145 BERTRAM I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock
3146 Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry
3147 Till honour be bought up and no sword worn
3148 But one to dance with By heaven I'll steal away
3149 FIRST LORD There's honour in the theft
3150 PAROLLES Commit it Count
3151 SECOND LORD I am your accessary and so farewell
3152 BERTRAM I grow to you and our parting is a tortur'd body
3153 FIRST LORD Farewell Captain
3154 SECOND LORD Sweet Monsieur Parolles
3155 PAROLLES Noble heroes my sword and yours are kin Good sparks and
3156 lustrous a word good metals you shall find in the regiment of
3157 the Spinii one Captain Spurio with his cicatrice an emblem of
3158 war here on his sinister cheek it was this very sword
3159 entrench'd it Say to him I live and observe his reports for me
3160 FIRST LORD We shall noble Captain
3161 PAROLLES Mars dote on you for his novices Exeunt LORDS
3162 What will ye do
3163 Reenter the KING
3164 BERTRAM Stay the King
3165 PAROLLES Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords you have
3166 restrain'd yourself within the list of too cold an adieu Be more
3167 expressive to them for they wear themselves in the cap of the
3168 time there do muster true gait eat speak and move under the
3169 influence of the most receiv'd star and though the devil lead
3170 the measure such are to be followed After them and take a more
3171 dilated farewell
3172 BERTRAM And I will do so
3173 PAROLLES Worthy fellows and like to prove most sinewy swordmen
3174 Exeunt BERTRAM and PAROLLES
3175 Enter LAFEU
3176 LAFEU [Kneeling] Pardon my lord for me and for my tidings
3177 KING I'll fee thee to stand up
3178 LAFEU Then here's a man stands that has brought his pardon
3179 I would you had kneel'd my lord to ask me mercy
3180 And that at my bidding you could so stand up
3181 KING I would I had so I had broke thy pate
3182 And ask'd thee mercy for't
3183 LAFEU Good faith across
3184 But my good lord 'tis thus will you be cur'd
3185 Of your infirmity
3186 KING No
3187 LAFEU O will you eat
3188 No grapes my royal fox Yes but you will
3189 My noble grapes an if my royal fox
3190 Could reach them I have seen a medicine
3191 That's able to breathe life into a stone
3192 Quicken a rock and make you dance canary
3193 With spritely fire and motion whose simple touch
3194 Is powerful to araise King Pepin nay
3195 To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand
3196 And write to her a loveline
3197 KING What her is this
3198 LAFEU Why Doctor She My lord there's one arriv'd
3199 If you will see her Now by my faith and honour
3200 If seriously I may convey my thoughts
3201 In this my light deliverance I have spoke
3202 With one that in her sex her years profession
3203 Wisdom and constancy hath amaz'd me more
3204 Than I dare blame my weakness Will you see her
3205 For that is her demand and know her business
3206 That done laugh well at me
3207 KING Now good Lafeu
3208 Bring in the admiration that we with the
3209 May spend our wonder too or take off thine
3210 By wond'ring how thou took'st it
3211 LAFEU Nay I'll fit you
3212 And not be all day neither Exit LAFEU
3213 KING Thus he his special nothing ever prologues
3214 Reenter LAFEU with HELENA
3215 LAFEU Nay come your ways
3216 KING This haste hath wings indeed
3217 LAFEU Nay come your ways
3218 This is his Majesty say your mind to him
3219 A traitor you do look like but such traitors
3220 His Majesty seldom fears I am Cressid's uncle
3221 That dare leave two together Fare you well Exit
3222 KING Now fair one does your business follow us
3223 HELENA Ay my good lord
3224 Gerard de Narbon was my father
3225 In what he did profess well found
3226 KING I knew him
3227 HELENA The rather will I spare my praises towards him
3228 Knowing him is enough On's bed of death
3229 Many receipts he gave me chiefly one
3230 Which as the dearest issue of his practice
3231 And of his old experience th only darling
3232 He bade me store up as a triple eye
3233 Safer than mine own two more dear I have so
3234 And hearing your high Majesty is touch'd
3235 With that malignant cause wherein the honour
3236 Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power
3237 I come to tender it and my appliance
3238 With all bound humbleness
3239 KING We thank you maiden
3240 But may not be so credulous of cure
3241 When our most learned doctors leave us and
3242 The congregated college have concluded
3243 That labouring art can never ransom nature
3244 From her inaidable estateI say we must not
3245 So stain our judgment or corrupt our hope
3246 To prostitute our pastcure malady
3247 To empirics or to dissever so
3248 Our great self and our credit to esteem
3249 A senseless help when help past sense we deem
3250 HELENA My duty then shall pay me for my pains
3251 I will no more enforce mine office on you
3252 Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
3253 A modest one to bear me back again
3254 KING I cannot give thee less to be call'd grateful
3255 Thou thought'st to help me and such thanks I give
3256 As one near death to those that wish him live
3257 But what at full I know thou know'st no part
3258 I knowing all my peril thou no art
3259 HELENA What I can do can do no hurt to try
3260 Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy
3261 He that of greatest works is finisher
3262 Oft does them by the weakest minister
3263 So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown
3264 When judges have been babes Great floods have flown
3265 From simple sources and great seas have dried
3266 When miracles have by the greatest been denied
3267 Oft expectation fails and most oft there
3268 Where most it promises and oft it hits
3269 Where hope is coldest and despair most fits
3270 KING I must not hear thee Fare thee well kind maid
3271 Thy pains not us'd must by thyself be paid
3272 Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward
3273 HELENA Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd
3274 It is not so with Him that all things knows
3275 As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows
3276 But most it is presumption in us when
3277 The help of heaven we count the act of men
3278 Dear sir to my endeavours give consent
3279 Of heaven not me make an experiment
3280 I am not an impostor that proclaim
3281 Myself against the level of mine aim
3282 But know I think and think I know most sure
3283 My art is not past power nor you past cure
3284 KING Art thou so confident Within what space
3285 Hop'st thou my cure
3286 HELENA The greatest Grace lending grace
3287 Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
3288 Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring
3289 Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
3290 Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp
3291 Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass
3292 Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass
3293 What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly
3294 Health shall live free and sickness freely die
3295 KING Upon thy certainty and confidence
3296 What dar'st thou venture
3297 HELENA Tax of impudence
3298 A strumpet's boldness a divulged shame
3299 Traduc'd by odious ballads my maiden's name
3300 Sear'd otherwise ne worse of worstextended
3301 With vilest torture let my life be ended
3302 KING Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
3303 His powerful sound within an organ weak
3304 And what impossibility would slay
3305 In common sense sense saves another way
3306 Thy life is dear for all that life can rate
3307 Worth name of life in thee hath estimate
3308 Youth beauty wisdom courage all
3309 That happiness and prime can happy call
3310 Thou this to hazard needs must intimate
3311 Skill infinite or monstrous desperate
3312 Sweet practiser thy physic I will try
3313 That ministers thine own death if I die
3314 HELENA If I break time or flinch in property
3315 Of what I spoke unpitied let me die
3316 And well deserv'd Not helping death's my fee
3317 But if I help what do you promise me
3318 KING Make thy demand
3319 HELENA But will you make it even
3320 KING Ay by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven
3321 HELENA Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
3322 What husband in thy power I will command
3323 Exempted be from me the arrogance
3324 To choose from forth the royal blood of France
3325 My low and humble name to propagate
3326 With any branch or image of thy state
3327 But such a one thy vassal whom I know
3328 Is free for me to ask thee to bestow
3329 KING Here is my hand the premises observ'd
3330 Thy will by my performance shall be serv'd
3331 So make the choice of thy own time for I
3332 Thy resolv'd patient on thee still rely
3333 More should I question thee and more I must
3334 Though more to know could not be more to trust
3335 From whence thou cam'st how tended on But rest
3336 Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest
3337 Give me some help here ho If thou proceed
3338 As high as word my deed shall match thy deed
3339 [Flourish Exeunt]
3340 ACT II SCENE 2
3341 Rousillon The COUNT'S palace
3342 Enter COUNTESS and CLOWN
3343 COUNTESS Come on sir I shall now put you to the height of your
3344 breeding
3345 CLOWN I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught I know my
3346 business is but to the court
3347 COUNTESS To the court Why what place make you special when you
3348 put off that with such contempt But to the court
3349 CLOWN Truly madam if God have lent a man any manners he may
3350 easily put it off at court He that cannot make a leg put off's
3351 cap kiss his hand and say nothing has neither leg hands lip
3352 nor cap and indeed such a fellow to say precisely were not for
3353 the court but for me I have an answer will serve all men
3354 COUNTESS Marry that's a bountiful answer that fits all questions
3355 CLOWN It is like a barber's chair that fits all buttocksthe pin
3356 buttock the quatch buttock the brawn buttock or any buttock
3357 COUNTESS Will your answer serve fit to all questions
3358 CLOWN As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney as your
3359 French crown for your taffety punk as Tib's rush for Tom's
3360 forefinger as a pancake for Shrove Tuesday a morris for Mayday
3361 as the nail to his hole the cuckold to his horn as a scolding
3362 quean to a wrangling knave as the nun's lip to the friar's
3363 mouth nay as the pudding to his skin
3364 COUNTESS Have you I say an answer of such fitness for all
3365 questions
3366 CLOWN From below your duke to beneath your constable it will fit
3367 any question
3368 COUNTESS It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit
3369 all demands
3370 CLOWN But a trifle neither in good faith if the learned should
3371 speak truth of it Here it is and all that belongs to't Ask me
3372 if I am a courtier it shall do you no harm to learn
3373 COUNTESS To be young again if we could I will be a fool in
3374 question hoping to be the wiser by your answer I pray you sir
3375 are you a courtier
3376 CLOWN O Lord sirThere's a simple putting off More more a
3377 hundred of them
3378 COUNTESS Sir I am a poor friend of yours that loves you
3379 CLOWN O Lord sirThick thick spare not me
3380 COUNTESS I think sir you can eat none of this homely meat
3381 CLOWN O Lord sirNay put me to't I warrant you
3382 COUNTESS You were lately whipp'd sir as I think
3383 CLOWN O Lord sirSpare not me
3384 COUNTESS Do you cry 'O Lord sir at your whipping and 'spare
3385 not me Indeed your 'O Lord sir is very sequent to your
3386 whipping You would answer very well to a whipping if you were
3387 but bound to't
3388 CLOWN I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my 'O Lord sir I see
3389 thing's may serve long but not serve ever
3390 COUNTESS I play the noble housewife with the time
3391 To entertain it so merrily with a fool
3392 CLOWN O Lord sirWhy there't serves well again
3393 COUNTESS An end sir To your business give Helen this
3394 And urge her to a present answer back
3395 Commend me to my kinsmen and my son This is not much
3396 CLOWN Not much commendation to them
3397 COUNTESS Not much employment for you You understand me
3398 CLOWN Most fruitfully I am there before my legs
3399 COUNTESS Haste you again Exeunt
3400 ACT II SCENE 3
3401 Paris The KING'S palace
3402 Enter BERTRAM LAFEU and PAROLLES
3403 LAFEU They say miracles are past and we have our philosophical
3404 persons to make modern and familiar things supernatural and
3405 causeless Hence is it that we make trifles of terrors
3406 ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge when we should submit
3407 ourselves to an unknown fear
3408 PAROLLES Why 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot
3409 out in our latter times
3410 BERTRAM And so 'tis
3411 LAFEU To be relinquish'd of the artists
3412 PAROLLES So I sayboth of Galen and Paracelsus
3413 LAFEU Of all the learned and authentic fellows
3414 PAROLLES Right so I say
3415 LAFEU That gave him out incurable
3416 PAROLLES Why there 'tis so say I too
3417 LAFEU Not to be help'd
3418 PAROLLES Right as 'twere a man assur'd of a
3419 LAFEU Uncertain life and sure death
3420 PAROLLES Just you say well so would I have said
3421 LAFEU I may truly say it is a novelty to the world
3422 PAROLLES It is indeed If you will have it in showing you shall
3423 read it in whatdoyecall't here
3424 LAFEU [Reading the ballad title] 'A Showing of a Heavenly
3425 Effect in an Earthly Actor'
3426 PAROLLES That's it I would have said the very same
3427 LAFEU Why your dolphin is not lustier 'Fore me I speak in
3428 respect
3429 PAROLLES Nay 'tis strange 'tis very strange that is the brief
3430 and the tedious of it and he's of a most facinerious spirit that
3431 will not acknowledge it to be the
3432 LAFEU Very hand of heaven
3433 PAROLLES Ay so I say
3434 LAFEU In a most weak
3435 PAROLLES And debile minister great power great transcendence
3436 which should indeed give us a further use to be made than alone
3437 the recov'ry of the King as to be
3438 LAFEU Generally thankful
3439 Enter KING HELENA and ATTENDANTS
3440 PAROLLES I would have said it you say well Here comes the King
3441 LAFEU Lustig as the Dutchman says I'll like a maid the better
3442 whilst I have a tooth in my head Why he's able to lead her a
3443 coranto
3444 PAROLLES Mort du vinaigre Is not this Helen
3445 LAFEU 'Fore God I think so
3446 KING Go call before me all the lords in court
3447 Exit an ATTENDANT
3448 Sit my preserver by thy patient's side
3449 And with this healthful hand whose banish'd sense
3450 Thou has repeal'd a second time receive
3451 The confirmation of my promis'd gift
3452 Which but attends thy naming
3453 Enter three or four LORDS
3454 Fair maid send forth thine eye This youthful parcel
3455 Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing
3456 O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice
3457 I have to use Thy frank election make
3458 Thou hast power to choose and they none to forsake
3459 HELENA To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress
3460 Fall when love please Marry to each but one
3461 LAFEU I'd give bay Curtal and his furniture
3462 My mouth no more were broken than these boys'
3463 And writ as little beard
3464 KING Peruse them well
3465 Not one of those but had a noble father
3466 HELENA Gentlemen
3467 Heaven hath through me restor'd the King to health
3468 ALL We understand it and thank heaven for you
3469 HELENA I am a simple maid and therein wealthiest
3470 That I protest I simply am a maid
3471 Please it your Majesty I have done already
3472 The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me
3473 'We blush that thou shouldst choose but be refused
3474 Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever
3475 We'll ne'er come there again'
3476 KING Make choice and see
3477 Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me
3478 HELENA Now Dian from thy altar do I fly
3479 And to imperial Love that god most high
3480 Do my sighs stream Sir will you hear my suit
3481 FIRST LORD And grant it
3482 HELENA Thanks sir all the rest is mute
3483 LAFEU I had rather be in this choice than throw amesace for my
3484 life
3485 HELENA The honour sir that flames in your fair eyes
3486 Before I speak too threat'ningly replies
3487 Love make your fortunes twenty times above
3488 Her that so wishes and her humble love
3489 SECOND LORD No better if you please
3490 HELENA My wish receive
3491 Which great Love grant and so I take my leave
3492 LAFEU Do all they deny her An they were sons of mine I'd have
3493 them whipt or I would send them to th Turk to make eunuchs of
3494 HELENA Be not afraid that I your hand should take
3495 I'll never do you wrong for your own sake
3496 Blessing upon your vows and in your bed
3497 Find fairer fortune if you ever wed
3498 LAFEU These boys are boys of ice they'll none have her
3499 Sure they are bastards to the English the French ne'er got 'em
3500 HELENA You are too young too happy and too good
3501 To make yourself a son out of my blood
3502 FOURTH LORD Fair one I think not so
3503 LAFEU There's one grape yet I am sure thy father drunk winebut
3504 if thou be'st not an ass I am a youth of fourteen I have known
3505 thee already
3506 HELENA [To BERTRAM] I dare not say I take you but I give
3507 Me and my service ever whilst I live
3508 Into your guiding power This is the man
3509 KING Why then young Bertram take her she's thy wife
3510 BERTRAM My wife my liege I shall beseech your Highness
3511 In such a business give me leave to use
3512 The help of mine own eyes
3513 KING Know'st thou not Bertram
3514 What she has done for me
3515 BERTRAM Yes my good lord
3516 But never hope to know why I should marry her
3517 KING Thou know'st she has rais'd me from my sickly bed
3518 BERTRAM But follows it my lord to bring me down
3519 Must answer for your raising I know her well
3520 She had her breeding at my father's charge
3521 A poor physician's daughter my wife Disdain
3522 Rather corrupt me ever
3523 KING 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her the which
3524 I can build up Strange is it that our bloods
3525 Of colour weight and heat pour'd all together
3526 Would quite confound distinction yet stand off
3527 In differences so mighty If she be
3528 All that is virtuoussave what thou dislik'st
3529 A poor physician's daughterthou dislik'st
3530 Of virtue for the name but do not so
3531 From lowest place when virtuous things proceed
3532 The place is dignified by the doer's deed
3533 Where great additions swell's and virtue none
3534 It is a dropsied honour Good alone
3535 Is good without a name Vileness is so
3536 The property by what it is should go
3537 Not by the title She is young wise fair
3538 In these to nature she's immediate heir
3539 And these breed honour That is honour's scorn
3540 Which challenges itself as honour's born
3541 And is not like the sire Honours thrive
3542 When rather from our acts we them derive
3543 Than our foregoers The mere word's a slave
3544 Debauch'd on every tomb on every grave
3545 A lying trophy and as oft is dumb
3546 Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb
3547 Of honour'd bones indeed What should be said
3548 If thou canst like this creature as a maid
3549 I can create the rest Virtue and she
3550 Is her own dower honour and wealth from me
3551 BERTRAM I cannot love her nor will strive to do 't
3552 KING Thou wrong'st thyself if thou shouldst strive to choose
3553 HELENA That you are well restor'd my lord I'm glad
3554 Let the rest go
3555 KING My honour's at the stake which to defeat
3556 I must produce my power Here take her hand
3557 Proud scornful boy unworthy this good gift
3558 That dost in vile misprision shackle up
3559 My love and her desert that canst not dream
3560 We poising us in her defective scale
3561 Shall weigh thee to the beam that wilt not know
3562 It is in us to plant thine honour where
3563 We please to have it grow Check thy contempt
3564 Obey our will which travails in thy good
3565 Believe not thy disdain but presently
3566 Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
3567 Which both thy duty owes and our power claims
3568 Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
3569 Into the staggers and the careless lapse
3570 Of youth and ignorance both my revenge and hate
3571 Loosing upon thee in the name of justice
3572 Without all terms of pity Speak thine answer
3573 BERTRAM Pardon my gracious lord for I submit
3574 My fancy to your eyes When I consider
3575 What great creation and what dole of honour
3576 Flies where you bid it I find that she which late
3577 Was in my nobler thoughts most base is now
3578 The praised of the King who so ennobled
3579 Is as 'twere born so
3580 KING Take her by the hand
3581 And tell her she is thine to whom I promise
3582 A counterpoise if not to thy estate
3583 A balance more replete
3584 BERTRAM I take her hand
3585 KING Good fortune and the favour of the King
3586 Smile upon this contract whose ceremony
3587 Shall seem expedient on the nowborn brief
3588 And be perform'd tonight The solemn feast
3589 Shall more attend upon the coming space
3590 Expecting absent friends As thou lov'st her
3591 Thy love's to me religious else does err
3592 Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES who stay behind
3593 commenting of this wedding
3594 LAFEU Do you hear monsieur A word with you
3595 PAROLLES Your pleasure sir
3596 LAFEU Your lord and master did well to make his recantation
3597 PAROLLES Recantation My Lord my master
3598 LAFEU Ay is it not a language I speak
3599 PAROLLES A most harsh one and not to be understood without bloody
3600 succeeding My master
3601 LAFEU Are you companion to the Count Rousillon
3602 PAROLLES To any count to all counts to what is man
3603 LAFEU To what is count's man count's master is of another style
3604 PAROLLES You are too old sir let it satisfy you you are too
3605 old
3606 LAFEU I must tell thee sirrah I write man to which title age
3607 cannot bring thee
3608 PAROLLES What I dare too well do I dare not do
3609 LAFEU I did think thee for two ordinaries to be a pretty wise
3610 fellow thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel it might
3611 pass Yet the scarfs and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly
3612 dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burden I
3613 have now found thee when I lose thee again I care not yet art
3614 thou good for nothing but taking up and that thou'rt scarce
3615 worth
3616 PAROLLES Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee
3617 LAFEU Do not plunge thyself too far in anger lest thou hasten thy
3618 trial which ifLord have mercy on thee for a hen So my good
3619 window of lattice fare thee well thy casement I need not open
3620 for I look through thee Give me thy hand
3621 PAROLLES My lord you give me most egregious indignity
3622 LAFEU Ay with all my heart and thou art worthy of it
3623 PAROLLES I have not my lord deserv'd it
3624 LAFEU Yes good faith ev'ry dram of it and I will not bate thee
3625 a scruple
3626 PAROLLES Well I shall be wiser
3627 LAFEU Ev'n as soon as thou canst for thou hast to pull at a smack
3628 o th contrary If ever thou be'st bound in thy scarf and
3629 beaten thou shalt find what it is to be proud of thy bondage I
3630 have a desire to hold my acquaintance with thee or rather my
3631 knowledge that I may say in the default 'He is a man I know'
3632 PAROLLES My lord you do me most insupportable vexation
3633 LAFEU I would it were hell pains for thy sake and my poor doing
3634 eternal for doing I am past as I will by thee in what motion
3635 age will give me leave Exit
3636 PAROLLES Well thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off me
3637 scurvy old filthy scurvy lord Well I must be patient there
3638 is no fettering of authority I'll beat him by my life if I can
3639 meet him with any convenience an he were double and double a
3640 lord I'll have no more pity of his age than I would have of
3641 I'll beat him and if I could but meet him again
3642 Reenter LAFEU
3643 LAFEU Sirrah your lord and master's married there's news for
3644 you you have a new mistress
3645 PAROLLES I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make some
3646 reservation of your wrongs He is my good lord whom I serve
3647 above is my master
3648 LAFEU Who God
3649 PAROLLES Ay sir
3650 LAFEU The devil it is that's thy master Why dost thou garter up
3651 thy arms o this fashion Dost make hose of thy sleeves Do other
3652 servants so Thou wert best set thy lower part where thy nose
3653 stands By mine honour if I were but two hours younger I'd beat
3654 thee Methink'st thou art a general offence and every man should
3655 beat thee I think thou wast created for men to breathe
3656 themselves upon thee
3657 PAROLLES This is hard and undeserved measure my lord
3658 LAFEU Go to sir you were beaten in Italy for picking a kernel
3659 out of a pomegranate you are a vagabond and no true traveller
3660 you are more saucy with lords and honourable personages than the
3661 commission of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry You are
3662 not worth another word else I'd call you knave I leave you
3663 Exit
3664 Enter BERTRAM
3665 PAROLLES Good very good it is so then Good very good let it
3666 be conceal'd awhile
3667 BERTRAM Undone and forfeited to cares for ever
3668 PAROLLES What's the matter sweetheart
3669 BERTRAM Although before the solemn priest I have sworn
3670 I will not bed her
3671 PAROLLES What what sweetheart
3672 BERTRAM O my Parolles they have married me
3673 I'll to the Tuscan wars and never bed her
3674 PAROLLES France is a doghole and it no more merits
3675 The tread of a man's foot To th wars
3676 BERTRAM There's letters from my mother what th import is I know
3677 not yet
3678 PAROLLES Ay that would be known To th wars my boy to th'
3679 wars
3680 He wears his honour in a box unseen
3681 That hugs his kickywicky here at home
3682 Spending his manly marrow in her arms
3683 Which should sustain the bound and high curvet
3684 Of Mars's fiery steed To other regions
3685 France is a stable we that dwell in't jades
3686 Therefore to th war
3687 BERTRAM It shall be so I'll send her to my house
3688 Acquaint my mother with my hate to her
3689 And wherefore I am fled write to the King
3690 That which I durst not speak His present gift
3691 Shall furnish me to those Italian fields
3692 Where noble fellows strike War is no strife
3693 To the dark house and the detested wife
3694 PAROLLES Will this capriccio hold in thee art sure
3695 BERTRAM Go with me to my chamber and advise me
3696 I'll send her straight away Tomorrow
3697 I'll to the wars she to her single sorrow
3698 PAROLLES Why these balls bound there's noise in it 'Tis hard
3699 A young man married is a man that's marr'd
3700 Therefore away and leave her bravely go
3701 The King has done you wrong but hush 'tis so Exeunt
3702 ACT II SCENE 4
3703 Paris The KING'S palace
3704 Enter HELENA and CLOWN
3705 HELENA My mother greets me kindly is she well
3706 CLOWN She is not well but yet she has her health she's very
3707 merry but yet she is not well But thanks be given she's very
3708 well and wants nothing i th world but yet she is not well
3709 HELENA If she be very well what does she ail that she's not very
3710 well
3711 CLOWN Truly she's very well indeed but for two things
3712 HELENA What two things
3713 CLOWN One that she's not in heaven whither God send her quickly
3714 The other that she's in earth from whence God send her quickly
3715 Enter PAROLLES
3716 PAROLLES Bless you my fortunate lady
3717 HELENA I hope sir I have your good will to have mine own good
3718 fortunes
3719 PAROLLES You had my prayers to lead them on and to keep them on
3720 have them still O my knave how does my old lady
3721 CLOWN So that you had her wrinkles and I her money I would she
3722 did as you say
3723 PAROLLES Why I say nothing
3724 CLOWN Marry you are the wiser man for many a man's tongue shakes
3725 out his master's undoing To say nothing to do nothing to know
3726 nothing and to have nothing is to be a great part of your
3727 title which is within a very little of nothing
3728 PAROLLES Away th'art a knave
3729 CLOWN You should have said sir 'Before a knave th'art a knave'
3730 that's 'Before me th'art a knave This had been truth sir
3731 PAROLLES Go to thou art a witty fool I have found thee
3732 CLOWN Did you find me in yourself sir or were you taught to find
3733 me The search sir was profitable and much fool may you find
3734 in you even to the world's pleasure and the increase of
3735 laughter
3736 PAROLLES A good knave i faith and well fed
3737 Madam my lord will go away tonight
3738 A very serious business calls on him
3739 The great prerogative and rite of love
3740 Which as your due time claims he does acknowledge
3741 But puts it off to a compell'd restraint
3742 Whose want and whose delay is strew'd with sweets
3743 Which they distil now in the curbed time
3744 To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy
3745 And pleasure drown the brim
3746 HELENA What's his else
3747 PAROLLES That you will take your instant leave o th King
3748 And make this haste as your own good proceeding
3749 Strength'ned with what apology you think
3750 May make it probable need
3751 HELENA What more commands he
3752 PAROLLES That having this obtain'd you presently
3753 Attend his further pleasure
3754 HELENA In everything I wait upon his will
3755 PAROLLES I shall report it so
3756 HELENA I pray you Exit PAROLLES
3757 Come sirrah Exeunt
3758 ACT II SCENE 5
3759 Paris The KING'S palace
3760 Enter LAFEU and BERTRAM
3761 LAFEU But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier
3762 BERTRAM Yes my lord and of very valiant approof
3763 LAFEU You have it from his own deliverance
3764 BERTRAM And by other warranted testimony
3765 LAFEU Then my dial goes not true I took this lark for a bunting
3766 BERTRAM I do assure you my lord he is very great in knowledge
3767 and accordingly valiant
3768 LAFEU I have then sinn'd against his experience and transgress'd
3769 against his valour and my state that way is dangerous since I
3770 cannot yet find in my heart to repent Here he comes I pray you
3771 make us friends I will pursue the amity
3772 Enter PAROLLES
3773 PAROLLES [To BERTRAM] These things shall be done sir
3774 LAFEU Pray you sir who's his tailor
3775 PAROLLES Sir
3776 LAFEU O I know him well Ay sir he sir 's a good workman a
3777 very good tailor
3778 BERTRAM [Aside to PAROLLES] Is she gone to the King
3779 PAROLLES She is
3780 BERTRAM Will she away tonight
3781 PAROLLES As you'll have her
3782 BERTRAM I have writ my letters casketed my treasure
3783 Given order for our horses and tonight
3784 When I should take possession of the bride
3785 End ere I do begin
3786 LAFEU A good traveller is something at the latter end of a dinner
3787 but one that lies threethirds and uses a known truth to pass a
3788 thousand nothings with should be once heard and thrice beaten
3789 God save you Captain
3790 BERTRAM Is there any unkindness between my lord and you monsieur
3791 PAROLLES I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord's
3792 displeasure
3793 LAFEU You have made shift to run into 't boots and spurs and all
3794 like him that leapt into the custard and out of it you'll run
3795 again rather than suffer question for your residence
3796 BERTRAM It may be you have mistaken him my lord
3797 LAFEU And shall do so ever though I took him at's prayers
3798 Fare you well my lord and believe this of me there can be no
3799 kernal in this light nut the soul of this man is his clothes
3800 trust him not in matter of heavy consequence I have kept of them
3801 tame and know their natures Farewell monsieur I have spoken
3802 better of you than you have or will to deserve at my hand but we
3803 must do good against evil Exit
3804 PAROLLES An idle lord I swear
3805 BERTRAM I think so
3806 PAROLLES Why do you not know him
3807 BERTRAM Yes I do know him well and common speech
3808 Gives him a worthy pass Here comes my clog
3809 Enter HELENA
3810 HELENA I have sir as I was commanded from you
3811 Spoke with the King and have procur'd his leave
3812 For present parting only he desires
3813 Some private speech with you
3814 BERTRAM I shall obey his will
3815 You must not marvel Helen at my course
3816 Which holds not colour with the time nor does
3817 The ministration and required office
3818 On my particular Prepar'd I was not
3819 For such a business therefore am I found
3820 So much unsettled This drives me to entreat you
3821 That presently you take your way for home
3822 And rather muse than ask why I entreat you
3823 For my respects are better than they seem
3824 And my appointments have in them a need
3825 Greater than shows itself at the first view
3826 To you that know them not This to my mother
3827 [Giving a letter]
3828 'Twill be two days ere I shall see you so
3829 I leave you to your wisdom
3830 HELENA Sir I can nothing say
3831 But that I am your most obedient servant
3832 BERTRAM Come come no more of that
3833 HELENA And ever shall
3834 With true observance seek to eke out that
3835 Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd
3836 To equal my great fortune
3837 BERTRAM Let that go
3838 My haste is very great Farewell hie home
3839 HELENA Pray sir your pardon
3840 BERTRAM Well what would you say
3841 HELENA I am not worthy of the wealth I owe
3842 Nor dare I say 'tis mine and yet it is
3843 But like a timorous thief most fain would steal
3844 What law does vouch mine own
3845 BERTRAM What would you have
3846 HELENA Something and scarce so much nothing indeed
3847 I would not tell you what I would my lord
3848 Faith yes
3849 Strangers and foes do sunder and not kiss
3850 BERTRAM I pray you stay not but in haste to horse
3851 HELENA I shall not break your bidding good my lord
3852 BERTRAM Where are my other men monsieur
3853 Farewell Exit HELENA
3854 Go thou toward home where I will never come
3855 Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum
3856 Away and for our flight
3857 PAROLLES Bravely coragio Exeunt

3866 ACT III SCENE 1
3867 Florence The DUKE's palace
3868 Flourish Enter the DUKE OF FLORENCE attended two
3869 FRENCH LORDS with a TROOP OF SOLDIERS
3870 DUKE So that from point to point now have you hear
3871 The fundamental reasons of this war
3872 Whose great decision hath much blood let forth
3873 And more thirsts after
3874 FIRST LORD Holy seems the quarrel
3875 Upon your Grace's part black and fearful
3876 On the opposer
3877 DUKE Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
3878 Would in so just a business shut his bosom
3879 Against our borrowing prayers
3880 SECOND LORD Good my lord
3881 The reasons of our state I cannot yield
3882 But like a common and an outward man
3883 That the great figure of a council frames
3884 By selfunable motion therefore dare not
3885 Say what I think of it since I have found
3886 Myself in my incertain grounds to fail
3887 As often as I guess'd
3888 DUKE Be it his pleasure
3889 FIRST LORD But I am sure the younger of our nature
3890 That surfeit on their ease will day by day
3891 Come here for physic
3892 DUKE Welcome shall they be
3893 And all the honours that can fly from us
3894 Shall on them settle You know your places well
3895 When better fall for your avails they fell
3896 Tomorrow to th field Flourish Exeunt
3897 ACT III SCENE 2
3898 Rousillon The COUNT'S palace
3899 Enter COUNTESS and CLOWN
3900 COUNTESS It hath happen'd all as I would have had it save that he
3901 comes not along with her
3902 CLOWN By my troth I take my young lord to be a very melancholy
3903 man
3904 COUNTESS By what observance I pray you
3905 CLOWN Why he will look upon his boot and sing mend the ruff and
3906 sing ask questions and sing pick his teeth and sing I know a
3907 man that had this trick of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a
3908 song
3909 COUNTESS Let me see what he writes and when he means to come
3910 [Opening a letter]
3911 CLOWN I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court Our old ling
3912 and our Isbels o th country are nothing like your old ling and
3913 your Isbels o th court The brains of my Cupid's knock'd out
3914 and I begin to love as an old man loves money with no stomach
3915 COUNTESS What have we here
3916 CLOWN E'en that you have there Exit
3917 COUNTESS [Reads] 'I have sent you a daughterinlaw she hath
3918 recovered the King and undone me I have wedded her not bedded
3919 her and sworn to make the not eternal You shall hear I am run
3920 away know it before the report come If there be breadth enough
3921 in the world I will hold a long distance My duty to you
3922 Your unfortunate son
3923 BERTRAM'
3924 This is not well rash and unbridled boy
3925 To fly the favours of so good a king
3926 To pluck his indignation on thy head
3927 By the misprizing of a maid too virtuous
3928 For the contempt of empire
3929 Reenter CLOWN
3930 CLOWN O madam yonder is heavy news within between two soldiers
3931 and my young lady
3932 COUNTESS What is the matter
3933 CLOWN Nay there is some comfort in the news some comfort your
3934 son will not be kill'd so soon as I thought he would
3935 COUNTESS Why should he be kill'd
3936 CLOWN So say I madam if he run away as I hear he does the
3937 danger is in standing to 't that's the loss of men though it be
3938 the getting of children Here they come will tell you more For my
3939 part I only hear your son was run away Exit
3940 Enter HELENA and the two FRENCH GENTLEMEN
3941 SECOND GENTLEMAN Save you good madam
3942 HELENA Madam my lord is gone for ever gone
3943 FIRST GENTLEMAN Do not say so
3944 COUNTESS Think upon patience Pray you gentlemen
3945 I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief
3946 That the first face of neither on the start
3947 Can woman me unto 't Where is my son I pray you
3948 FIRST GENTLEMAN Madam he's gone to serve the Duke of Florence
3949 We met him thitherward for thence we came
3950 And after some dispatch in hand at court
3951 Thither we bend again
3952 HELENA Look on this letter madam here's my passport
3953 [Reads] 'When thou canst get the ring upon my finger which
3954 never shall come off and show me a child begotten of thy body
3955 that I am father to then call me husband but in such a then I
3956 write a never
3957 This is a dreadful sentence
3958 COUNTESS Brought you this letter gentlemen
3959 FIRST GENTLEMAN Ay madam
3960 And for the contents sake are sorry for our pains
3961 COUNTESS I prithee lady have a better cheer
3962 If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine
3963 Thou robb'st me of a moiety He was my son
3964 But I do wash his name out of my blood
3965 And thou art all my child Towards Florence is he
3966 FIRST GENTLEMAN Ay madam
3967 COUNTESS And to be a soldier
3968 FIRST GENTLEMAN Such is his noble purpose and believe 't
3969 The Duke will lay upon him all the honour
3970 That good convenience claims
3971 COUNTESS Return you thither
3972 SECOND GENTLEMAN Ay madam with the swiftest wing of speed
3973 HELENA [Reads] 'Till I have no wife I have nothing in France'
3974 'Tis bitter
3975 COUNTESS Find you that there
3976 HELENA Ay madam
3977 SECOND GENTLEMAN 'Tis but the boldness of his hand haply which
3978 his heart was not consenting to
3979 COUNTESS Nothing in France until he have no wife
3980 There's nothing here that is too good for him
3981 But only she and she deserves a lord
3982 That twenty such rude boys might tend upon
3983 And call her hourly mistress Who was with him
3984 SECOND GENTLEMAN A servant only and a gentleman
3985 Which I have sometime known
3986 COUNTESS Parolles was it not
3987 SECOND GENTLEMAN Ay my good lady he
3988 COUNTESS A very tainted fellow and full of wickedness
3989 My son corrupts a wellderived nature
3990 With his inducement
3991 SECOND GENTLEMAN Indeed good lady
3992 The fellow has a deal of that too much
3993 Which holds him much to have
3994 COUNTESS Y'are welcome gentlemen
3995 I will entreat you when you see my son
3996 To tell him that his sword can never win
3997 The honour that he loses More I'll entreat you
3998 Written to bear along
3999 FIRST GENTLEMAN We serve you madam
4000 In that and all your worthiest affairs
4001 COUNTESS Not so but as we change our courtesies
4002 Will you draw near Exeunt COUNTESS and GENTLEMEN
4003 HELENA 'Till I have no wife I have nothing in France'
4004 Nothing in France until he has no wife
4005 Thou shalt have none Rousillon none in France
4006 Then hast thou all again Poor lord is't
4007 That chase thee from thy country and expose
4008 Those tender limbs of thine to the event
4009 Of the nonsparing war And is it I
4010 That drive thee from the sportive court where thou
4011 Wast shot at with fair eyes to be the mark
4012 Of smoky muskets O you leaden messengers
4013 That ride upon the violent speed of fire
4014 Fly with false aim move the stillpiecing air
4015 That sings with piercing do not touch my lord
4016 Whoever shoots at him I set him there
4017 Whoever charges on his forward breast
4018 I am the caitiff that do hold him to't
4019 And though I kill him not I am the cause
4020 His death was so effected Better 'twere
4021 I met the ravin lion when he roar'd
4022 With sharp constraint of hunger better 'twere
4023 That all the miseries which nature owes
4024 Were mine at once No come thou home Rousillon
4025 Whence honour but of danger wins a scar
4026 As oft it loses all I will be gone
4027 My being here it is that holds thee hence
4028 Shall I stay here to do 't No no although
4029 The air of paradise did fan the house
4030 And angels offic'd all I will be gone
4031 That pitiful rumour may report my flight
4032 To consolate thine ear Come night end day
4033 For with the dark poor thief I'll steal away Exit
4034 ACT III SCENE 3
4035 Florence Before the DUKE's palace
4036 Flourish Enter the DUKE OF FLORENCE BERTRAM PAROLLES SOLDIERS
4037 drum and trumpets
4038 DUKE The General of our Horse thou art and we
4039 Great in our hope lay our best love and credence
4040 Upon thy promising fortune
4041 BERTRAM Sir it is
4042 A charge too heavy for my strength but yet
4043 We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
4044 To th extreme edge of hazard
4045 DUKE Then go thou forth
4046 And Fortune play upon thy prosperous helm
4047 As thy auspicious mistress
4048 BERTRAM This very day
4049 Great Mars I put myself into thy file
4050 Make me but like my thoughts and I shall prove
4051 A lover of thy drum hater of love Exeunt
4052 ACT III SCENE 4
4053 Rousillon The COUNT'S palace
4054 Enter COUNTESS and STEWARD
4055 COUNTESS Alas and would you take the letter of her
4056 Might you not know she would do as she has done
4057 By sending me a letter Read it again
4058 STEWARD [Reads] 'I am Saint Jaques pilgrim thither gone
4059 Ambitious love hath so in me offended
4060 That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon
4061 With sainted vow my faults to have amended
4062 Write write that from the bloody course of war
4063 My dearest master your dear son may hie
4064 Bless him at home in peace whilst I from far
4065 His name with zealous fervour sanctify
4066 His taken labours bid him me forgive
4067 I his despiteful Juno sent him forth
4068 From courtly friends with camping foes to live
4069 Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth
4070 He is too good and fair for death and me
4071 Whom I myself embrace to set him free'
4072 COUNTESS Ah what sharp stings are in her mildest words
4073 Rinaldo you did never lack advice so much
4074 As letting her pass so had I spoke with her
4075 I could have well diverted her intents
4076 Which thus she hath prevented
4077 STEWARD Pardon me madam
4078 If I had given you this at overnight
4079 She might have been o'er ta'en and yet she writes
4080 Pursuit would be but vain
4081 COUNTESS What angel shall
4082 Bless this unworthy husband He cannot thrive
4083 Unless her prayers whom heaven delights to hear
4084 And loves to grant reprieve him from the wrath
4085 Of greatest justice Write write Rinaldo
4086 To this unworthy husband of his wife
4087 Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
4088 That he does weigh too light My greatest grief
4089 Though little he do feel it set down sharply
4090 Dispatch the most convenient messenger
4091 When haply he shall hear that she is gone
4092 He will return and hope I may that she
4093 Hearing so much will speed her foot again
4094 Led hither by pure love Which of them both
4095 Is dearest to me I have no skill in sense
4096 To make distinction Provide this messenger
4097 My heart is heavy and mine age is weak
4098 Grief would have tears and sorrow bids me speak Exeunt
4099 ACT III SCENE 5
4100 Without the walls of Florence
4101 A tucket afar off Enter an old WIDOW OF FLORENCE her daughter DIANA
4102 VIOLENTA and MARIANA with other CITIZENS
4103 WIDOW Nay come for if they do approach the city we shall lose
4104 all the sight
4105 DIANA They say the French count has done most honourable service
4106 WIDOW It is reported that he has taken their great'st commander
4107 and that with his own hand he slew the Duke's brother [Tucket]
4108 We have lost our labour they are gone a contrary way Hark you
4109 may know by their trumpets
4110 MARIANA Come let's return again and suffice ourselves with the
4111 report of it Well Diana take heed of this French earl the
4112 honour of a maid is her name and no legacy is so rich as
4113 honesty
4114 WIDOW I have told my neighbour how you have been solicited by a
4115 gentleman his companion
4116 MARIANA I know that knave hang him one Parolles a filthy
4117 officer he is in those suggestions for the young earl Beware of
4118 them Diana their promises enticements oaths tokens and all
4119 these engines of lust are not the things they go under many a
4120 maid hath been seduced by them and the misery is example that
4121 so terrible shows in the wreck of maidenhood cannot for all that
4122 dissuade succession but that they are limed with the twigs that
4123 threatens them I hope I need not to advise you further but I
4124 hope your own grace will keep you where you are though there
4125 were no further danger known but the modesty which is so lost
4126 DIANA You shall not need to fear me
4127 Enter HELENA in the dress of a pilgrim
4128 WIDOW I hope so Look here comes a pilgrim I know she will lie
4129 at my house thither they send one another I'll question her
4130 God save you pilgrim Whither are bound
4131 HELENA To Saint Jaques le Grand
4132 Where do the palmers lodge I do beseech you
4133 WIDOW At the Saint Francis here beside the port
4134 HELENA Is this the way
4135 [A march afar]
4136 WIDOW Ay marry is't Hark you They come this way
4137 If you will tarry holy pilgrim
4138 But till the troops come by
4139 I will conduct you where you shall be lodg'd
4140 The rather for I think I know your hostess
4141 As ample as myself
4142 HELENA Is it yourself
4143 WIDOW If you shall please so pilgrim
4144 HELENA I thank you and will stay upon your leisure
4145 WIDOW You came I think from France
4146 HELENA I did so
4147 WIDOW Here you shall see a countryman of yours
4148 That has done worthy service
4149 HELENA His name I pray you
4150 DIANA The Count Rousillon Know you such a one
4151 HELENA But by the ear that hears most nobly of him
4152 His face I know not
4153 DIANA What some'er he is
4154 He's bravely taken here He stole from France
4155 As 'tis reported for the King had married him
4156 Against his liking Think you it is so
4157 HELENA Ay surely mere the truth I know his lady
4158 DIANA There is a gentleman that serves the Count
4159 Reports but coarsely of her
4160 HELENA What's his name
4161 DIANA Monsieur Parolles
4162 HELENA O I believe with him
4163 In argument of praise or to the worth
4164 Of the great Count himself she is too mean
4165 To have her name repeated all her deserving
4166 Is a reserved honesty and that
4167 I have not heard examin'd
4168 DIANA Alas poor lady
4169 'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
4170 Of a detesting lord
4171 WIDOW I sweet good creature wheresoe'er she is
4172 Her heart weighs sadly This young maid might do her
4173 A shrewd turn if she pleas'd
4174 HELENA How do you mean
4175 May be the amorous Count solicits her
4176 In the unlawful purpose
4177 WIDOW He does indeed
4178 And brokes with all that can in such a suit
4179 Corrupt the tender honour of a maid
4180 But she is arm'd for him and keeps her guard
4181 In honestest defence
4182 Enter with drum and colours BERTRAM PAROLLES and the
4183 whole ARMY
4184 MARIANA The gods forbid else
4185 WIDOW So now they come
4186 That is Antonio the Duke's eldest son
4187 That Escalus
4188 HELENA Which is the Frenchman
4189 DIANA He
4190 That with the plume 'tis a most gallant fellow
4191 I would he lov'd his wife if he were honester
4192 He were much goodlier Is't not a handsome gentleman
4193 HELENA I like him well
4194 DIANA 'Tis pity he is not honest Yond's that same knave
4195 That leads him to these places were I his lady
4196 I would poison that vile rascal
4197 HELENA Which is he
4198 DIANA That jackanapes with scarfs Why is he melancholy
4199 HELENA Perchance he's hurt i th battle
4200 PAROLLES Lose our drum well
4201 MARIANA He's shrewdly vex'd at something
4202 Look he has spied us
4203 WIDOW Marry hang you
4204 MARIANA And your courtesy for a ringcarrier
4205 Exeunt BERTRAM PAROLLES and ARMY
4206 WIDOW The troop is past Come pilgrim I will bring you
4207 Where you shall host Of enjoin'd penitents
4208 There's four or five to great Saint Jaques bound
4209 Already at my house
4210 HELENA I humbly thank you
4211 Please it this matron and this gentle maid
4212 To eat with us tonight the charge and thanking
4213 Shall be for me and to requite you further
4214 I will bestow some precepts of this virgin
4215 Worthy the note
4216 BOTH We'll take your offer kindly Exeunt
4217 ACT III SCENE 6
4218 Camp before Florence
4219 Enter BERTRAM and the two FRENCH LORDS
4220 SECOND LORD Nay good my lord put him to't let him have his way
4221 FIRST LORD If your lordship find him not a hiding hold me no more
4222 in your respect
4223 SECOND LORD On my life my lord a bubble
4224 BERTRAM Do you think I am so far deceived in him
4225 SECOND LORD Believe it my lord in mine own direct knowledge
4226 without any malice but to speak of him as my kinsman he's a
4227 most notable coward an infinite and endless liar an hourly
4228 promisebreaker the owner of no one good quality worthy your
4229 lordship's entertainment
4230 FIRST LORD It were fit you knew him lest reposing too far in his
4231 virtue which he hath not he might at some great and trusty
4232 business in a main danger fail you
4233 BERTRAM I would I knew in what particular action to try him
4234 FIRST LORD None better than to let him fetch off his drum which
4235 you hear him so confidently undertake to do
4236 SECOND LORD I with a troop of Florentines will suddenly surprise
4237 him such I will have whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy
4238 We will bind and hoodwink him so that he shall suppose no other
4239 but that he is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries when
4240 we bring him to our own tents Be but your lordship present at
4241 his examination if he do not for the promise of his life and in
4242 the highest compulsion of base fear offer to betray you and
4243 deliver all the intelligence in his power against you and that
4244 with the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath never trust my
4245 judgment in anything
4246 FIRST LORD O for the love of laughter let him fetch his drum he
4247 says he has a stratagem for't When your lordship sees the bottom
4248 of his success in't and to what metal this counterfeit lump of
4249 ore will be melted if you give him not John Drum's
4250 entertainment your inclining cannot be removed Here he comes
4251 Enter PAROLLES
4252 SECOND LORD O for the love of laughter hinder not the honour of
4253 his design let him fetch off his drum in any hand
4254 BERTRAM How now monsieur This drum sticks sorely in your
4255 disposition
4256 FIRST LORD A pox on 't let it go 'tis but a drum
4257 PAROLLES But a drum Is't but a drum A drum so lost There was
4258 excellent command to charge in with our horse upon our own
4259 wings and to rend our own soldiers
4260 FIRST LORD That was not to be blam'd in the command of the
4261 service it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself could not
4262 have prevented if he had been there to command
4263 BERTRAM Well we cannot greatly condemn our success
4264 Some dishonour we had in the loss of that drum but it is not to
4265 be recovered
4266 PAROLLES It might have been recovered
4267 BERTRAM It might but it is not now
4268 PAROLLES It is to be recovered But that the merit of service is
4269 seldom attributed to the true and exact performer I would have
4270 that drum or another or 'hic jacet'
4271 BERTRAM Why if you have a stomach to't monsieur If you think
4272 your mystery in stratagem can bring this instrument of honour
4273 again into his native quarter be magnanimous in the enterprise
4274 and go on I will grace the attempt for a worthy exploit If you
4275 speed well in it the Duke shall both speak of it and extend to
4276 you what further becomes his greatness even to the utmost
4277 syllable of our worthiness
4278 PAROLLES By the hand of a soldier I will undertake it
4279 BERTRAM But you must not now slumber in it
4280 PAROLLES I'll about it this evening and I will presently pen
4281 down my dilemmas encourage myself in my certainty put myself
4282 into my mortal preparation and by midnight look to hear further
4283 from me
4284 BERTRAM May I be bold to acquaint his Grace you are gone about it
4285 PAROLLES I know not what the success will be my lord but the
4286 attempt I vow
4287 BERTRAM I know th art valiant and to the of thy soldiership
4288 will subscribe for thee Farewell
4289 PAROLLES I love not many words Exit
4290 SECOND LORD No more than a fish loves water Is not this a strange
4291 fellow my lord that so confidently seems to undertake this
4292 business which he knows is not to be done damns himself to do
4293 and dares better be damn'd than to do 't
4294 FIRST LORD You do not know him my lord as we do Certain it is
4295 that he will steal himself into a man's favour and for a week
4296 escape a great deal of discoveries but when you find him out
4297 you have him ever after
4298 BERTRAM Why do you think he will make no deed at all of this that
4299 so seriously he does address himself unto
4300 SECOND LORD None in the world but return with an invention and
4301 clap upon you two or three probable lies But we have almost
4302 emboss'd him You shall see his fall tonight for indeed he is
4303 not for your lordship's respect
4304 FIRST LORD We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case him
4305 He was first smok'd by the old Lord Lafeu When his disguise and
4306 he is parted tell me what a sprat you shall find him which you
4307 shall see this very night
4308 SECOND LORD I must go look my twigs he shall be caught
4309 BERTRAM Your brother he shall go along with me
4310 SECOND LORD As't please your lordship I'll leave you Exit
4311 BERTRAM Now will I lead you to the house and show you
4312 The lass I spoke of
4313 FIRST LORD But you say she's honest
4314 BERTRAM That's all the fault I spoke with her but once
4315 And found her wondrous cold but I sent to her
4316 By this same coxcomb that we have i th wind
4317 Tokens and letters which she did resend
4318 And this is all I have done She's a fair creature
4319 Will you go see her
4320 FIRST LORD With all my heart my lord Exeunt
4321 ACT III SCENE 7
4322 Florence The WIDOW'S house
4323 Enter HELENA and WIDOW
4324 HELENA If you misdoubt me that I am not she
4325 I know not how I shall assure you further
4326 But I shall lose the grounds I work upon
4327 WIDOW Though my estate be fall'n I was well born
4328 Nothing acquainted with these businesses
4329 And would not put my reputation now
4330 In any staining act
4331 HELENA Nor would I wish you
4332 FIRST give me trust the Count he is my husband
4333 And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken
4334 Is so from word to word and then you cannot
4335 By the good aid that I of you shall borrow
4336 Err in bestowing it
4337 WIDOW I should believe you
4338 For you have show'd me that which well approves
4339 Y'are great in fortune
4340 HELENA Take this purse of gold
4341 And let me buy your friendly help thus far
4342 Which I will overpay and pay again
4343 When I have found it The Count he woos your daughter
4344 Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty
4345 Resolv'd to carry her Let her in fine consent
4346 As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it
4347 Now his important blood will nought deny
4348 That she'll demand A ring the County wears
4349 That downward hath succeeded in his house
4350 From son to son some four or five descents
4351 Since the first father wore it This ring he holds
4352 In most rich choice yet in his idle fire
4353 To buy his will it would not seem too dear
4354 Howe'er repented after
4355 WIDOW Now I see
4356 The bottom of your purpose
4357 HELENA You see it lawful then It is no more
4358 But that your daughter ere she seems as won
4359 Desires this ring appoints him an encounter
4360 In fine delivers me to fill the time
4361 Herself most chastely absent After this
4362 To marry her I'll add three thousand crowns
4363 To what is pass'd already
4364 WIDOW I have yielded
4365 Instruct my daughter how she shall persever
4366 That time and place with this deceit so lawful
4367 May prove coherent Every night he comes
4368 With musics of all sorts and songs compos'd
4369 To her unworthiness It nothing steads us
4370 To chide him from our eaves for he persists
4371 As if his life lay on 't
4372 HELENA Why then tonight
4373 Let us assay our plot which if it speed
4374 Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed
4375 And lawful meaning in a lawful act
4376 Where both not sin and yet a sinful fact
4377 But let's about it Exeunt
