4386 ACT IV SCENE 1
4387 Without the Florentine camp
4388 Enter SECOND FRENCH LORD with five or six other SOLDIERS in ambush
4389 SECOND LORD He can come no other way but by this hedgecorner
4390 When you sally upon him speak what terrible language you will
4391 though you understand it not yourselves no matter for we must
4392 not seem to understand him unless some one among us whom we
4393 must produce for an interpreter
4394 FIRST SOLDIER Good captain let me be th interpreter
4395 SECOND LORD Art not acquainted with him Knows he not thy voice
4396 FIRST SOLDIER No sir I warrant you
4397 SECOND LORD But what linseywoolsey has thou to speak to us again
4398 FIRST SOLDIER E'en such as you speak to me
4399 SECOND LORD He must think us some band of strangers i th'
4400 adversary's entertainment Now he hath a smack of all
4401 neighbouring languages therefore we must every one be a man of
4402 his own fancy not to know what we speak one to another so we
4403 seem to know is to know straight our purpose choughs language
4404 gabble enough and good enough As for you interpreter you must
4405 seem very politic But couch ho here he comes to beguile two
4406 hours in a sleep and then to return and swear the lies he forges
4407 Enter PAROLLES
4408 PAROLLES Ten o'clock Within these three hours 'twill be time
4409 enough to go home What shall I say I have done It must be a
4410 very plausive invention that carries it They begin to smoke me
4411 and disgraces have of late knock'd to often at my door I find my
4412 tongue is too foolhardy but my heart hath the fear of Mars
4413 before it and of his creatures not daring the reports of my
4414 tongue
4415 SECOND LORD This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was
4416 guilty of
4417 PAROLLES What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery
4418 of this drum being not ignorant of the impossibility and
4419 knowing I had no such purpose I must give myself some hurts and
4420 say I got them in exploit Yet slight ones will not carry it
4421 They will say 'Came you off with so little And great ones I
4422 dare not give Wherefore what's the instance Tongue I must put
4423 you into a butterwoman's mouth and buy myself another of
4424 Bajazet's mule if you prattle me into these perils
4425 SECOND LORD Is it possible he should know what he is and be that
4426 he is
4427 PAROLLES I would the cutting of my garments would serve the turn
4428 or the breaking of my Spanish sword
4429 SECOND LORD We cannot afford you so
4430 PAROLLES Or the baring of my beard and to say it was in
4431 stratagem
4432 SECOND LORD 'Twould not do
4433 PAROLLES Or to drown my clothes and say I was stripp'd
4434 SECOND LORD Hardly serve
4435 PAROLLES Though I swore I leap'd from the window of the citadel
4436 SECOND LORD How deep
4437 PAROLLES Thirty fathom
4438 SECOND LORD Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed
4439 PAROLLES I would I had any drum of the enemy's I would swear I
4440 recover'd it
4441 SECOND LORD You shall hear one anon [Alarum within]
4442 PAROLLES A drum now of the enemy's
4443 SECOND LORD Throca movousus cargo cargo cargo
4444 ALL Cargo cargo cargo villianda par corbo cargo
4445 PAROLLES O ransom ransom Do not hide mine eyes
4446 [They blindfold him]
4447 FIRST SOLDIER Boskos thromuldo boskos
4448 PAROLLES I know you are the Muskos regiment
4449 And I shall lose my life for want of language
4450 If there be here German or Dane Low Dutch
4451 Italian or French let him speak to me
4452 I'll discover that which shall undo the Florentine
4453 FIRST SOLDIER Boskos vauvado I understand thee and can speak thy
4454 tongue Kerelybonto sir betake thee to thy faith for
4455 seventeen poniards are at thy bosom
4456 PAROLLES O
4457 FIRST SOLDIER O pray pray pray Manka revania dulche
4458 SECOND LORD Oscorbidulchos volivorco
4459 FIRST SOLDIER The General is content to spare thee yet
4460 And hoodwink'd as thou art will lead thee on
4461 To gather from thee Haply thou mayst inform
4462 Something to save thy life
4463 PAROLLES O let me live
4464 And all the secrets of our camp I'll show
4465 Their force their purposes Nay I'll speak that
4466 Which you will wonder at
4467 FIRST SOLDIER But wilt thou faithfully
4468 PAROLLES If I do not damn me
4469 FIRST SOLDIER Acordo linta
4470 Come on thou art granted space
4471 Exit PAROLLES guarded A short alarum within
4472 SECOND LORD Go tell the Count Rousillon and my brother
4473 We have caught the woodcock and will keep him muffled
4474 Till we do hear from them
4475 SECOND SOLDIER Captain I will
4476 SECOND LORD 'A will betray us all unto ourselves
4477 Inform on that
4478 SECOND SOLDIER So I will sir
4479 SECOND LORD Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd
4480 Exeunt
4481 ACT IV SCENE 2
4482 Florence The WIDOW'S house
4483 Enter BERTRAM and DIANA
4484 BERTRAM They told me that your name was Fontibell
4485 DIANA No my good lord Diana
4486 BERTRAM Titled goddess
4487 And worth it with addition But fair soul
4488 In your fine frame hath love no quality
4489 If the quick fire of youth light not your mind
4490 You are no maiden but a monument
4491 When you are dead you should be such a one
4492 As you are now for you are cold and stern
4493 And now you should be as your mother was
4494 When your sweet self was got
4495 DIANA She then was honest
4496 BERTRAM So should you be
4497 DIANA No
4498 My mother did but duty such my lord
4499 As you owe to your wife
4500 BERTRAM No more o'that
4501 I prithee do not strive against my vows
4502 I was compell'd to her but I love the
4503 By love's own sweet constraint and will for ever
4504 Do thee all rights of service
4505 DIANA Ay so you serve us
4506 Till we serve you but when you have our roses
4507 You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves
4508 And mock us with our bareness
4509 BERTRAM How have I sworn
4510 DIANA 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth
4511 But the plain single vow that is vow'd true
4512 What is not holy that we swear not by
4513 But take the High'st to witness Then pray you tell me
4514 If I should swear by Jove's great attributes
4515 I lov'd you dearly would you believe my oaths
4516 When I did love you ill This has no holding
4517 To swear by him whom I protest to love
4518 That I will work against him Therefore your oaths
4519 Are words and poor conditions but unseal'd
4520 At least in my opinion
4521 BERTRAM Change it change it
4522 Be not so holycruel Love is holy
4523 And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts
4524 That you do charge men with Stand no more off
4525 But give thyself unto my sick desires
4526 Who then recovers Say thou art mine and ever
4527 My love as it begins shall so persever
4528 DIANA I see that men make ropes in such a scarre
4529 That we'll forsake ourselves Give me that ring
4530 BERTRAM I'll lend it thee my dear but have no power
4531 To give it from me
4532 DIANA Will you not my lord
4533 BERTRAM It is an honour 'longing to our house
4534 Bequeathed down from many ancestors
4535 Which were the greatest obloquy i th world
4536 In me to lose
4537 DIANA Mine honour's such a ring
4538 My chastity's the jewel of our house
4539 Bequeathed down from many ancestors
4540 Which were the greatest obloquy i th world
4541 In me to lose Thus your own proper wisdom
4542 Brings in the champion Honour on my part
4543 Against your vain assault
4544 BERTRAM Here take my ring
4545 My house mine honour yea my life be thine
4546 And I'll be bid by thee
4547 DIANA When midnight comes knock at my chamber window
4548 I'll order take my mother shall not hear
4549 Now will I charge you in the band of truth
4550 When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed
4551 Remain there but an hour nor speak to me
4552 My reasons are most strong and you shall know them
4553 When back again this ring shall be deliver'd
4554 And on your finger in the night I'll put
4555 Another ring that what in time proceeds
4556 May token to the future our past deeds
4557 Adieu till then then fail not You have won
4558 A wife of me though there my hope be done
4559 BERTRAM A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee
4560 Exit
4561 DIANA For which live long to thank both heaven and me
4562 You may so in the end
4563 My mother told me just how he would woo
4564 As if she sat in's heart she says all men
4565 Have the like oaths He had sworn to marry me
4566 When his wife's dead therefore I'll lie with him
4567 When I am buried Since Frenchmen are so braid
4568 Marry that will I live and die a maid
4569 Only in this disguise I think't no sin
4570 To cozen him that would unjustly win Exit
4571 ACT IV SCENE 3
4572 The Florentine camp
4573 Enter the two FRENCH LORDS and two or three SOLDIERS
4574 SECOND LORD You have not given him his mother's letter
4575 FIRST LORD I have deliv'red it an hour since There is something
4576 in't that stings his nature for on the reading it he chang'd
4577 almost into another man
4578 SECOND LORD He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking off
4579 so good a wife and so sweet a lady
4580 FIRST LORD Especially he hath incurred the everlasting displeasure
4581 of the King who had even tun'd his bounty to sing happiness to
4582 him I will tell you a thing but you shall let it dwell darkly
4583 with you
4584 SECOND LORD When you have spoken it 'tis dead and I am the grave
4585 of it
4586 FIRST LORD He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in Florence
4587 of a most chaste renown and this night he fleshes his will in
4588 the spoil of her honour He hath given her his monumental ring
4589 and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition
4590 SECOND LORD Now God delay our rebellion As we are ourselves
4591 what things are we
4592 FIRST LORD Merely our own traitors And as in the common course of
4593 all treasons we still see them reveal themselves till they attain
4594 to their abhorr'd ends so he that in this action contrives
4595 against his own nobility in his proper stream o'erflows
4596 himself
4597 SECOND LORD Is it not meant damnable in us to be trumpeters of our
4598 unlawful intents We shall not then have his company tonight
4599 FIRST LORD Not till after midnight for he is dieted to his hour
4600 SECOND LORD That approaches apace I would gladly have him see his
4601 company anatomiz'd that he might take a measure of his own
4602 judgments wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit
4603 FIRST LORD We will not meddle with him till he come for his
4604 presence must be the whip of the other
4605 SECOND LORD In the meantime what hear you of these wars
4606 FIRST LORD I hear there is an overture of peace
4607 SECOND LORD Nay I assure you a peace concluded
4608 FIRST LORD What will Count Rousillon do then Will he travel
4609 higher or return again into France
4610 SECOND LORD I perceive by this demand you are not altogether
4611 of his counsel
4612 FIRST LORD Let it be forbid sir So should I be a great deal
4613 of his act
4614 SECOND LORD Sir his wife some two months since fled from his
4615 house Her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand
4616 which holy undertaking with most austere sanctimony she
4617 accomplish'd and there residing the tenderness of her nature
4618 became as a prey to her grief in fine made a groan of her last
4619 breath and now she sings in heaven
4620 FIRST LORD How is this justified
4621 SECOND LORD The stronger part of it by her own letters which
4622 makes her story true even to the point of her death Her death
4623 itself which could not be her office to say is come was
4624 faithfully confirm'd by the rector of the place
4625 FIRST LORD Hath the Count all this intelligence
4626 SECOND LORD Ay and the particular confirmations point from
4627 point to the full arming of the verity
4628 FIRST LORD I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this
4629 SECOND LORD How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our
4630 losses
4631 FIRST LORD And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in
4632 tears The great dignity that his valour hath here acquir'd for
4633 him shall at home be encount'red with a shame as ample
4634 SECOND LORD The web of our life is of a mingled yarn good and ill
4635 together Our virtues would be proud if our faults whipt them
4636 not and our crimes would despair if they were not cherish'd by
4637 our virtues
4638 Enter a MESSENGER
4639 How now Where's your master
4640 SERVANT He met the Duke in the street sir of whom he hath taken
4641 a solemn leave His lordship will next morning for France The
4642 Duke hath offered him letters of commendations to the King
4643 SECOND LORD They shall be no more than needful there if they were
4644 more than they can commend
4645 FIRST LORD They cannot be too sweet for the King's tartness
4646 Here's his lordship now
4647 Enter BERTRAM
4648 How now my lord is't not after midnight
4649 BERTRAM I have tonight dispatch'd sixteen businesses a month's
4650 length apiece by an abstract of success I have congied with the
4651 Duke done my adieu with his nearest buried a wife mourn'd for
4652 her writ to my lady mother I am returning entertain'd my
4653 convoy and between these main parcels of dispatch effected many
4654 nicer needs The last was the greatest but that I have not ended
4655 yet
4656 SECOND LORD If the business be of any difficulty and this morning
4657 your departure hence it requires haste of your lordship
4658 BERTRAM I mean the business is not ended as fearing to hear of it
4659 hereafter But shall we have this dialogue between the Fool and
4660 the Soldier Come bring forth this counterfeit module has
4661 deceiv'd me like a doublemeaning prophesier
4662 SECOND LORD Bring him forth [Exeunt SOLDIERS] Has sat i th'
4663 stocks all night poor gallant knave
4664 BERTRAM No matter his heels have deserv'd it in usurping his
4665 spurs so long How does he carry himself
4666 SECOND LORD I have told your lordship already the stocks carry
4667 him But to answer you as you would be understood he weeps like
4668 a wench that had shed her milk he hath confess'd himself to
4669 Morgan whom he supposes to be a friar from the time of his
4670 remembrance to this very instant disaster of his setting i th'
4671 stocks And what think you he hath confess'd
4672 BERTRAM Nothing of me has 'a
4673 SECOND LORD His confession is taken and it shall be read to his
4674 face if your lordship be in't as I believe you are you must
4675 have the patience to hear it
4676 Enter PAROLLES guarded and
4677 FIRST SOLDIER as interpreter
4678 BERTRAM A plague upon him muffled He can say nothing of me
4679 SECOND LORD Hush hush Hoodman comes Portotartarossa
4680 FIRST SOLDIER He calls for the tortures What will you say without
4681 'em
4682 PAROLLES I will confess what I know without constraint if ye
4683 pinch me like a pasty I can say no more
4684 FIRST SOLDIER Bosko chimurcho
4685 SECOND LORD Boblibindo chicurmurco
4686 FIRST SOLDIER YOU are a merciful general Our General bids you
4687 answer to what I shall ask you out of a note
4688 PAROLLES And truly as I hope to live
4689 FIRST SOLDIER 'First demand of him how many horse the Duke is
4690 strong What say you to that
4691 PAROLLES Five or six thousand but very weak and unserviceable
4692 The troops are all scattered and the commanders very poor
4693 rogues upon my reputation and credit and as I hope to live
4694 FIRST SOLDIER Shall I set down your answer so
4695 PAROLLES Do I'll take the sacrament on 't how and which way you
4696 will
4697 BERTRAM All's one to him What a pastsaving slave is this
4698 SECOND LORD Y'are deceiv'd my lord this is Monsieur Parolles
4699 the gallant militaristthat was his own phrasethat had the whole
4700 theoric of war in the knot of his scarf and the practice in the
4701 chape of his dagger
4702 FIRST LORD I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword
4703 clean nor believe he can have everything in him by wearing his
4704 apparel neatly
4705 FIRST SOLDIER Well that's set down
4706 PAROLLES 'Five or six thousand horse I saidI will say true 'or
4707 thereabouts set down for I'll speak truth
4708 SECOND LORD He's very near the truth in this
4709 BERTRAM But I con him no thanks for't in the nature he delivers it
4710 PAROLLES 'Poor rogues I pray you say
4711 FIRST SOLDIER Well that's set down
4712 PAROLLES I humbly thank you sir A truth's a truththe rogues are
4713 marvellous poor
4714 FIRST SOLDIER 'Demand of him of what strength they are afoot'
4715 What say you to that
4716 PAROLLES By my troth sir if I were to live this present hour I
4717 will tell true Let me see Spurio a hundred and fifty
4718 Sebastian so many Corambus so many Jaques so many Guiltian
4719 Cosmo Lodowick and Gratii two hundred fifty each mine own
4720 company Chitopher Vaumond Bentii two hundred fifty each so
4721 that the musterfile rotten and sound upon my life amounts not
4722 to fifteen thousand poll half of the which dare not shake the
4723 snow from off their cassocks lest they shake themselves to
4724 pieces
4725 BERTRAM What shall be done to him
4726 SECOND LORD Nothing but let him have thanks Demand of him my
4727 condition and what credit I have with the Duke
4728 FIRST SOLDIER Well that's set down 'You shall demand of him
4729 whether one Captain Dumain be i th camp a Frenchman what his
4730 reputation is with the Duke what his valour honesty expertness
4731 in wars or whether he thinks it were not possible with
4732 wellweighing sums of gold to corrupt him to a revolt What say
4733 you to this What do you know of it
4734 PAROLLES I beseech you let me answer to the particular of the
4735 inter'gatories Demand them singly
4736 FIRST SOLDIER Do you know this Captain Dumain
4737 PAROLLES I know him 'a was a botcher's prentice in Paris from
4738 whence he was whipt for getting the shrieve's fool with childa
4739 dumb innocent that could not say him nay
4740 BERTRAM Nay by your leave hold your hands though I know his
4741 brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls
4742 FIRST SOLDIER Well is this captain in the Duke of Florence's
4743 camp
4744 PAROLLES Upon my knowledge he is and lousy
4745 SECOND LORD Nay look not so upon me we shall hear of your
4746 lordship anon
4747 FIRST SOLDIER What is his reputation with the Duke
4748 PAROLLES The Duke knows him for no other but a poor officer of
4749 mine and writ to me this other day to turn him out o th band
4750 I think I have his letter in my pocket
4751 FIRST SOLDIER Marry we'll search
4752 PAROLLES In good sadness I do not know either it is there or it
4753 is upon a file with the Duke's other letters in my tent
4754 FIRST SOLDIER Here 'tis here's a paper Shall I read it to you
4755 PAROLLES I do not know if it be it or no
4756 BERTRAM Our interpreter does it well
4757 SECOND LORD Excellently
4758 FIRST SOLDIER [Reads] 'Dian the Count's a fool and full of
4759 gold'
4760 PAROLLES That is not the Duke's letter sir that is an
4761 advertisement to a proper maid in Florence one Diana to take
4762 heed of the allurement of one Count Rousillon a foolish idle
4763 boy but for all that very ruttish I pray you sir put it up
4764 again
4765 FIRST SOLDIER Nay I'll read it first by your favour
4766 PAROLLES My meaning in't I protest was very honest in the behalf
4767 of the maid for I knew the young Count to be a dangerous and
4768 lascivious boy who is a whale to virginity and devours up all
4769 the fry it finds
4770 BERTRAM Damnable bothsides rogue
4771 FIRST SOLDIER [Reads]
4772 'When he swears oaths bid him drop gold and take it
4773 After he scores he never pays the score
4774 Half won is match well made match and well make it
4775 He ne'er pays afterdebts take it before
4776 And say a soldier Dian told thee this
4777 Men are to mell with boys are not to kiss
4778 For count of this the Count's a fool I know it
4779 Who pays before but not when he does owe it
4780 Thine as he vow'd to thee in thine ear
4781 PAROLLES'
4782 BERTRAM He shall be whipt through the army with this rhyme in's
4783 forehead
4784 FIRST LORD This is your devoted friend sir the manifold
4785 linguist and the amnipotent soldier
4786 BERTRAM I could endure anything before but a cat and now he's a
4787 cat to me
4788 FIRST SOLDIER I perceive sir by our General's looks we shall be
4789 fain to hang you
4790 PAROLLES My life sir in any case Not that I am afraid to die
4791 but that my offences being many I would repent out the
4792 remainder of nature Let me live sir in a dungeon i th'
4793 stocks or anywhere so I may live
4794 FIRST SOLDIER We'll see what may be done so you confess freely
4795 therefore once more to this Captain Dumain you have answer'd to
4796 his reputation with the Duke and to his valour what is his
4797 honesty
4798 PAROLLES He will steal sir an egg out of a cloister for rapes
4799 and ravishments he parallels Nessus He professes not keeping of
4800 oaths in breaking 'em he is stronger than Hercules He will lie
4801 sir with such volubility that you would think truth were a fool
4802 Drunkenness is his best virtue for he will be swinedrunk and
4803 in his sleep he does little harm save to his bedclothes about
4804 him but they know his conditions and lay him in straw I have
4805 but little more to say sir of his honesty He has everything
4806 that an honest man should not have what an honest man should
4807 have he has nothing
4808 SECOND LORD I begin to love him for this
4809 BERTRAM For this description of thine honesty A pox upon him For
4810 me he's more and more a cat
4811 FIRST SOLDIER What say you to his expertness in war
4812 PAROLLES Faith sir has led the drum before the English
4813 tragediansto belie him I will notand more of his soldiership
4814 I know not except in that country he had the honour to be the
4815 officer at a place there called Mileend to instruct for the
4816 doubling of filesI would do the man what honour I canbut of
4817 this I am not certain
4818 SECOND LORD He hath outvillain'd villainy so far that the rarity
4819 redeems him
4820 BERTRAM A pox on him he's a cat still
4821 FIRST SOLDIER His qualities being at this poor price I need not
4822 to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt
4823 PAROLLES Sir for a cardecue he will sell the feesimple of his
4824 salvation the inheritance of it and cut th entail from all
4825 remainders and a perpetual succession for it perpetually
4826 FIRST SOLDIER What's his brother the other Captain Dumain
4827 FIRST LORD Why does he ask him of me
4828 FIRST SOLDIER What's he
4829 PAROLLES E'en a crow o th same nest not altogether so great as
4830 the first in goodness but greater a great deal in evil He
4831 excels his brother for a coward yet his brother is reputed one
4832 of the best that is In a retreat he outruns any lackey marry
4833 in coming on he has the cramp
4834 FIRST SOLDIER If your life be saved will you undertake to betray
4835 the Florentine
4836 PAROLLES Ay and the Captain of his Horse Count Rousillon
4837 FIRST SOLDIER I'll whisper with the General and know his
4838 pleasure
4839 PAROLLES [Aside] I'll no more drumming A plague of all drums
4840 Only to seem to deserve well and to beguile the supposition of
4841 that lascivious young boy the Count have I run into this danger
4842 Yet who would have suspected an ambush where I was taken
4843 FIRST SOLDIER There is no remedy sir but you must die
4844 The General says you that have so traitorously discover'd the
4845 secrets of your army and made such pestiferous reports of men
4846 very nobly held can serve the world for no honest use therefore
4847 you must die Come headsman of with his head
4848 PAROLLES O Lord sir let me live or let me see my death
4849 FIRST SOLDIER That shall you and take your leave of all your
4850 friends [Unmuffling him] So look about you know you any here
4851 BERTRAM Good morrow noble Captain
4852 FIRST LORD God bless you Captain Parolles
4853 SECOND LORD God save you noble Captain
4854 FIRST LORD Captain what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu I am
4855 for France
4856 SECOND LORD Good Captain will you give me a copy of the sonnet
4857 you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon An I were not
4858 a very coward I'd compel it of you but fare you well
4859 Exeunt BERTRAM and LORDS
4860 FIRST SOLDIER You are undone Captain all but your scarf that
4861 has a knot on 't yet
4862 PAROLLES Who cannot be crush'd with a plot
4863 FIRST SOLDIER If you could find out a country where but women were
4864 that had received so much shame you might begin an impudent
4865 nation Fare ye well sir I am for France too we shall speak of
4866 you there Exit with SOLDIERS
4867 PAROLLES Yet am I thankful If my heart were great
4868 'Twould burst at this Captain I'll be no more
4869 But I will eat and drink and sleep as soft
4870 As captain shall Simply the thing I am
4871 Shall make me live Who knows himself a braggart
4872 Let him fear this for it will come to pass
4873 That every braggart shall be found an ass
4874 Rust sword cool blushes and Parolles live
4875 Safest in shame Being fool'd by fool'ry thrive
4876 There's place and means for every man alive
4877 I'll after them Exit
4878 ACT IV SCENE 4
4879 The WIDOW'S house
4880 Enter HELENA WIDOW and DIANA
4881 HELENA That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you
4882 One of the greatest in the Christian world
4883 Shall be my surety fore whose throne 'tis needful
4884 Ere I can perfect mine intents to kneel
4885 Time was I did him a desired office
4886 Dear almost as his life which gratitude
4887 Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth
4888 And answer 'Thanks I duly am inform'd
4889 His Grace is at Marseilles to which place
4890 We have convenient convoy You must know
4891 I am supposed dead The army breaking
4892 My husband hies him home where heaven aiding
4893 And by the leave of my good lord the King
4894 We'll be before our welcome
4895 WIDOW Gentle madam
4896 You never had a servant to whose trust
4897 Your business was more welcome
4898 HELENA Nor you mistress
4899 Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour
4900 To recompense your love Doubt not but heaven
4901 Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower
4902 As it hath fated her to be my motive
4903 And helper to a husband But O strange men
4904 That can such sweet use make of what they hate
4905 When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts
4906 Defiles the pitchy night So lust doth play
4907 With what it loathes for that which is away
4908 But more of this hereafter You Diana
4909 Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
4910 Something in my behalf
4911 DIANA Let death and honesty
4912 Go with your impositions I am yours
4913 Upon your will to suffer
4914 HELENA Yet I pray you
4915 But with the word the time will bring on summer
4916 When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns
4917 And be as sweet as sharp We must away
4918 Our waggon is prepar'd and time revives us
4919 All's Well that Ends Well Still the fine's the crown
4920 Whate'er the course the end is the renown Exeunt
4921 ACT IV SCENE 5
4922 Rousillon The COUNT'S palace
4923 Enter COUNTESS LAFEU and CLOWN
4924 LAFEU No no no son was misled with a snipttaffeta fellow
4925 there whose villainous saffron would have made all the unbak'd
4926 and doughy youth of a nation in his colour Your daughterinlaw
4927 had been alive at this hour and your son here at home more
4928 advanc'd by the King than by that redtail'd humblebee I speak
4929 of
4930 COUNTESS I would I had not known him It was the death of the most
4931 virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had praise for creating If
4932 she had partaken of my flesh and cost me the dearest groans of a
4933 mother I could not have owed her a more rooted love
4934 LAFEU 'Twas a good lady 'twas a good lady We may pick a thousand
4935 sallets ere we light on such another herb
4936 CLOWN Indeed sir she was the sweetmarjoram of the sallet or
4937 rather the herb of grace
4938 LAFEU They are not salletherbs you knave they are noseherbs
4939 CLOWN I am no great Nebuchadnezzar sir I have not much skill in
4940 grass
4941 LAFEU Whether dost thou profess thyselfa knave or a fool
4942 CLOWN A fool sir at a woman's service and a knave at a man's
4943 LAFEU Your distinction
4944 CLOWN I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service
4945 LAFEU So you were a knave at his service indeed
4946 CLOWN And I would give his wife my bauble sir to do her service
4947 LAFEU I will subscribe for thee thou art both knave and fool
4948 CLOWN At your service
4949 LAFEU No no no
4950 CLOWN Why sir if I cannot serve you I can serve as great a
4951 prince as you are
4952 LAFEU Who's that A Frenchman
4953 CLOWN Faith sir 'a has an English name but his fisnomy is more
4954 hotter in France than there
4955 LAFEU What prince is that
4956 CLOWN The Black Prince sir alias the Prince of Darkness alias
4957 the devil
4958 LAFEU Hold thee there's my purse I give thee not this to suggest
4959 thee from thy master thou talk'st of serve him still
4960 CLOWN I am a woodland fellow sir that always loved a great fire
4961 and the master I speak of ever keeps a good fire But sure he
4962 is the prince of the world let his nobility remain in's court I
4963 am for the house with the narrow gate which I take to be too
4964 little for pomp to enter Some that humble themselves may but
4965 the many will be too chill and tender and they'll be for the
4966 flow'ry way that leads to the broad gate and the great fire
4967 LAFEU Go thy ways I begin to be aweary of thee and I tell thee
4968 so before because I would not fall out with thee Go thy ways
4969 let my horses be well look'd to without any tricks
4970 CLOWN If I put any tricks upon 'em sir they shall be jades'
4971 tricks which are their own right by the law of nature
4972 Exit
4973 LAFEU A shrewd knave and an unhappy
4974 COUNTESS So 'a is My lord that's gone made himself much sport
4975 out of him By his authority he remains here which he thinks is
4976 a patent for his sauciness and indeed he has no pace but runs
4977 where he will
4978 LAFEU I like him well 'tis not amiss And I was about to tell
4979 you since I heard of the good lady's death and that my lord
4980 your son was upon his return home I moved the King my master to
4981 speak in the behalf of my daughter which in the minority of
4982 them both his Majesty out of a selfgracious remembrance did
4983 first propose His Highness hath promis'd me to do it and to
4984 stop up the displeasure he hath conceived against your son there
4985 is no fitter matter How does your ladyship like it
4986 COUNTESS With very much content my lord and I wish it happily
4987 effected
4988 LAFEU His Highness comes post from Marseilles of as able body as
4989 when he number'd thirty 'a will be here tomorrow or I am
4990 deceiv'd by him that in such intelligence hath seldom fail'd
4991 COUNTESS It rejoices me that I hope I shall see him ere I die
4992 I have letters that my son will be here tonight I shall beseech
4993 your lordship to remain with me tal they meet together
4994 LAFEU Madam I was thinking with what manners I might safely be
4995 admitted
4996 COUNTESS You need but plead your honourable privilege
4997 LAFEU Lady of that I have made a bold charter but I thank my
4998 God it holds yet
4999 Reenter CLOWN
5000 CLOWN O madam yonder's my lord your son with a patch of velvet
5001 on's face whether there be a scar under 't or no the velvet
5002 knows but 'tis a goodly patch of velvet His left cheek is a
5003 cheek of two pile and a half but his right cheek is worn bare
5004 LAFEU A scar nobly got or a noble scar is a good liv'ry of
5005 honour so belike is that
5006 CLOWN But it is your carbonado'd face
5007 LAFEU Let us go see your son I pray you
5008 I long to talk with the young noble soldier
5009 CLOWN Faith there's a dozen of 'em with delicate fine hats and
5010 most courteous feathers which bow the head and nod at every man
5011 Exeunt

5020 ACT V SCENE 1
5021 Marseilles A street
5022 Enter HELENA WIDOW and DIANA with two ATTENDANTS
5023 HELENA But this exceeding posting day and night
5024 Must wear your spirits low we cannot help it
5025 But since you have made the days and nights as one
5026 To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs
5027 Be bold you do so grow in my requital
5028 As nothing can unroot you
5029 Enter a GENTLEMAN
5030 In happy time
5031 This man may help me to his Majesty's ear
5032 If he would spend his power God save you sir
5033 GENTLEMAN And you
5034 HELENA Sir I have seen you in the court of France
5035 GENTLEMAN I have been sometimes there
5036 HELENA I do presume sir that you are not fall'n
5037 From the report that goes upon your goodness
5038 And therefore goaded with most sharp occasions
5039 Which lay nice manners by I put you to
5040 The use of your own virtues for the which
5041 I shall continue thankful
5042 GENTLEMAN What's your will
5043 HELENA That it will please you
5044 To give this poor petition to the King
5045 And aid me with that store of power you have
5046 To come into his presence
5047 GENTLEMAN The King's not here
5048 HELENA Not here sir
5049 GENTLEMAN Not indeed
5050 He hence remov'd last night and with more haste
5051 Than is his use
5052 WIDOW Lord how we lose our pains
5053 HELENA All's Well That Ends Well yet
5054 Though time seem so adverse and means unfit
5055 I do beseech you whither is he gone
5056 GENTLEMAN Marry as I take it to Rousillon
5057 Whither I am going
5058 HELENA I do beseech you sir
5059 Since you are like to see the King before me
5060 Commend the paper to his gracious hand
5061 Which I presume shall render you no blame
5062 But rather make you thank your pains for it
5063 I will come after you with what good speed
5064 Our means will make us means
5065 GENTLEMAN This I'll do for you
5066 HELENA And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd
5067 Whate'er falls more We must to horse again
5068 Go go provide Exeunt
5069 ACT V SCENE 2
5070 Rousillon The inner court of the COUNT'S palace
5071 Enter CLOWN and PAROLLES
5072 PAROLLES Good Monsieur Lavache give my Lord Lafeu this letter I
5073 have ere now sir been better known to you when I have held
5074 familiarity with fresher clothes but I am now sir muddied in
5075 Fortune's mood and smell somewhat strong of her strong
5076 displeasure
5077 CLOWN Truly Fortune's displeasure is but sluttish if it smell
5078 so strongly as thou speak'st of I will henceforth eat no fish
5079 of Fortune's butt'ring Prithee allow the wind
5080 PAROLLES Nay you need not to stop your nose sir I spake but by
5081 a metaphor
5082 CLOWN Indeed sir if your metaphor stink I will stop my nose or
5083 against any man's metaphor Prithee get thee further
5084 PAROLLES Pray you sir deliver me this paper
5085 CLOWN Foh prithee stand away A paper from Fortune's closestool
5086 to give to a nobleman Look here he comes himself
5087 Enter LAFEU
5088 Here is a pur of Fortune's sir or of Fortune's cat but not
5089 a muskcat that has fall'n into the unclean fishpond of her
5090 displeasure and as he says is muddied withal Pray you sir
5091 use the carp as you may for he looks like a poor decayed
5092 ingenious foolish rascally knave I do pity his distress
5093 in my similes of comfort and leave him to your lordship
5094 Exit
5095 PAROLLES My lord I am a man whom Fortune hath cruelly scratch'd
5096 LAFEU And what would you have me to do 'Tis too late to pare her
5097 nails now Wherein have you played the knave with Fortune that
5098 she should scratch you who of herself is a good lady and would
5099 not have knaves thrive long under her There's a cardecue for
5100 you Let the justices make you and Fortune friends I am for
5101 other business
5102 PAROLLES I beseech your honour to hear me one single word
5103 LAFEU You beg a single penny more come you shall ha't save your
5104 word
5105 PAROLLES My name my good lord is Parolles
5106 LAFEU You beg more than word then Cox my passion give me your
5107 hand How does your drum
5108 PAROLLES O my good lord you were the first that found me
5109 LAFEU Was I in sooth And I was the first that lost thee
5110 PAROLLES It lies in you my lord to bring me in some grace for
5111 you did bring me out
5112 LAFEU Out upon thee knave Dost thou put upon me at once both the
5113 office of God and the devil One brings the in grace and the
5114 other brings thee out [Trumpets sound] The King's coming I
5115 know by his trumpets Sirrah inquire further after me I had
5116 talk of you last night Though you are a fool and a knave you
5117 shall eat Go to follow
5118 PAROLLES I praise God for you Exeunt
5119 ACT V SCENE 3
5120 Rousillon The COUNT'S palace
5121 Flourish Enter KING COUNTESS LAFEU the two FRENCH LORDS with ATTENDANTS
5122 KING We lost a jewel of her and our esteem
5123 Was made much poorer by it but your son
5124 As mad in folly lack'd the sense to know
5125 Her estimation home
5126 COUNTESS 'Tis past my liege
5127 And I beseech your Majesty to make it
5128 Natural rebellion done i th blaze of youth
5129 When oil and fire too strong for reason's force
5130 O'erbears it and burns on
5131 KING My honour'd lady
5132 I have forgiven and forgotten all
5133 Though my revenges were high bent upon him
5134 And watch'd the time to shoot
5135 LAFEU This I must say
5136 But first I beg my pardon the young lord
5137 Did to his Majesty his mother and his lady
5138 Offence of mighty note but to himself
5139 The greatest wrong of all He lost a wife
5140 Whose beauty did astonish the survey
5141 Of richest eyes whose words all ears took captive
5142 Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve
5143 Humbly call'd mistress
5144 KING Praising what is lost
5145 Makes the remembrance dear Well call him hither
5146 We are reconcil'd and the first view shall kill
5147 All repetition Let him not ask our pardon
5148 The nature of his great offence is dead
5149 And deeper than oblivion do we bury
5150 Th incensing relics of it let him approach
5151 A stranger no offender and inform him
5152 So 'tis our will he should
5153 GENTLEMAN I shall my liege Exit GENTLEMAN
5154 KING What says he to your daughter Have you spoke
5155 LAFEU All that he is hath reference to your Highness
5156 KING Then shall we have a match I have letters sent me
5157 That sets him high in fame
5158 Enter BERTRAM
5159 LAFEU He looks well on 't
5160 KING I am not a day of season
5161 For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail
5162 In me at once But to the brightest beams
5163 Distracted clouds give way so stand thou forth
5164 The time is fair again
5165 BERTRAM My highrepented blames
5166 Dear sovereign pardon to me
5167 KING All is whole
5168 Not one word more of the consumed time
5169 Let's take the instant by the forward top
5170 For we are old and on our quick'st decrees
5171 Th inaudible and noiseless foot of Time
5172 Steals ere we can effect them You remember
5173 The daughter of this lord
5174 BERTRAM Admiringly my liege At first
5175 I stuck my choice upon her ere my heart
5176 Durst make too bold herald of my tongue
5177 Where the impression of mine eye infixing
5178 Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me
5179 Which warp'd the line of every other favour
5180 Scorn'd a fair colour or express'd it stol'n
5181 Extended or contracted all proportions
5182 To a most hideous object Thence it came
5183 That she whom all men prais'd and whom myself
5184 Since I have lost have lov'd was in mine eye
5185 The dust that did offend it
5186 KING Well excus'd
5187 That thou didst love her strikes some scores away
5188 From the great compt but love that comes too late
5189 Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried
5190 To the great sender turns a sour offence
5191 Crying 'That's good that's gone Our rash faults
5192 Make trivial price of serious things we have
5193 Not knowing them until we know their grave
5194 Oft our displeasures to ourselves unjust
5195 Destroy our friends and after weep their dust
5196 Our own love waking cries to see what's done
5197 While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon
5198 Be this sweet Helen's knell And now forget her
5199 Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin
5200 The main consents are had and here we'll stay
5201 To see our widower's second marriageday
5202 COUNTESS Which better than the first O dear heaven bless
5203 Or ere they meet in me O nature cesse
5204 LAFEU Come on my son in whom my house's name
5205 Must be digested give a favour from you
5206 To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter
5207 That she may quickly come
5208 [BERTRAM gives a ring]
5209 By my old beard
5210 And ev'ry hair that's on 't Helen that's dead
5211 Was a sweet creature such a ring as this
5212 The last that e'er I took her leave at court
5213 I saw upon her finger
5214 BERTRAM Hers it was not
5215 KING Now pray you let me see it for mine eye
5216 While I was speaking oft was fasten'd to't
5217 This ring was mine and when I gave it Helen
5218 I bade her if her fortunes ever stood
5219 Necessitied to help that by this token
5220 I would relieve her Had you that craft to reave her
5221 Of what should stead her most
5222 BERTRAM My gracious sovereign
5223 Howe'er it pleases you to take it so
5224 The ring was never hers
5225 COUNTESS Son on my life
5226 I have seen her wear it and she reckon'd it
5227 At her life's rate
5228 LAFEU I am sure I saw her wear it
5229 BERTRAM You are deceiv'd my lord she never saw it
5230 In Florence was it from a casement thrown me
5231 Wrapp'd in a paper which contain'd the name
5232 Of her that threw it Noble she was and thought
5233 I stood engag'd but when I had subscrib'd
5234 To mine own fortune and inform'd her fully
5235 I could not answer in that course of honour
5236 As she had made the overture she ceas'd
5237 In heavy satisfaction and would never
5238 Receive the ring again
5239 KING Plutus himself
5240 That knows the tinct and multiplying med'cine
5241 Hath not in nature's mystery more science
5242 Than I have in this ring 'Twas mine 'twas Helen's
5243 Whoever gave it you Then if you know
5244 That you are well acquainted with yourself
5245 Confess 'twas hers and by what rough enforcement
5246 You got it from her She call'd the saints to surety
5247 That she would never put it from her finger
5248 Unless she gave it to yourself in bed
5249 Where you have never come or sent it us
5250 Upon her great disaster
5251 BERTRAM She never saw it
5252 KING Thou speak'st it falsely as I love mine honour
5253 And mak'st conjectural fears to come into me
5254 Which I would fain shut out If it should prove
5255 That thou art so inhuman 'twill not prove so
5256 And yet I know not thou didst hate her deadly
5257 And she is dead which nothing but to close
5258 Her eyes myself could win me to believe
5259 More than to see this ring Take him away
5260 [GUARDS seize BERTRAM]
5261 My forepast proofs howe'er the matter fall
5262 Shall tax my fears of little vanity
5263 Having vainly fear'd too little Away with him
5264 We'll sift this matter further
5265 BERTRAM If you shall prove
5266 This ring was ever hers you shall as easy
5267 Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence
5268 Where she yet never was Exit guarded
5269 KING I am wrapp'd in dismal thinkings
5270 Enter a GENTLEMAN
5271 GENTLEMAN Gracious sovereign
5272 Whether I have been to blame or no I know not
5273 Here's a petition from a Florentine
5274 Who hath for four or five removes come short
5275 To tender it herself I undertook it
5276 Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and speech
5277 Of the poor suppliant who by this I know
5278 Is here attending her business looks in her
5279 With an importing visage and she told me
5280 In a sweet verbal brief it did concern
5281 Your Highness with herself
5282 KING [Reads the letter] 'Upon his many protestations to marry me
5283 when his wife was dead I blush to say it he won me Now is the
5284 Count Rousillon a widower his vows are forfeited to me and my
5285 honour's paid to him He stole from Florence taking no leave
5286 and I follow him to his country for justice Grant it me O King
5287 in you it best lies otherwise a seducer flourishes and a poor
5288 maid is undone
5289 DIANA CAPILET'
5290 LAFEU I will buy me a soninlaw in a fair and toll for this
5291 I'll none of him
5292 KING The heavens have thought well on thee Lafeu
5293 To bring forth this discov'ry Seek these suitors
5294 Go speedily and bring again the Count
5295 Exeunt ATTENDANTS
5296 I am afeard the life of Helen lady
5297 Was foully snatch'd
5298 COUNTESS Now justice on the doers
5299 Enter BERTRAM guarded
5300 KING I wonder sir sith wives are monsters to you
5301 And that you fly them as you swear them lordship
5302 Yet you desire to marry
5303 Enter WIDOW and DIANA
5304 What woman's that
5305 DIANA I am my lord a wretched Florentine
5306 Derived from the ancient Capilet
5307 My suit as I do understand you know
5308 And therefore know how far I may be pitied
5309 WIDOW I am her mother sir whose age and honour
5310 Both suffer under this complaint we bring
5311 And both shall cease without your remedy
5312 KING Come hither Count do you know these women
5313 BERTRAM My lord I neither can nor will deny
5314 But that I know them Do they charge me further
5315 DIANA Why do you look so strange upon your wife
5316 BERTRAM She's none of mine my lord
5317 DIANA If you shall marry
5318 You give away this hand and that is mine
5319 You give away heaven's vows and those are mine
5320 You give away myself which is known mine
5321 For I by vow am so embodied yours
5322 That she which marries you must marry me
5323 Either both or none
5324 LAFEU [To BERTRAM] Your reputation comes too short for
5325 my daughter you are no husband for her
5326 BERTRAM My lord this is a fond and desp'rate creature
5327 Whom sometime I have laugh'd with Let your Highness
5328 Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour
5329 Than for to think that I would sink it here
5330 KING Sir for my thoughts you have them ill to friend
5331 Till your deeds gain them Fairer prove your honour
5332 Than in my thought it lies
5333 DIANA Good my lord
5334 Ask him upon his oath if he does think
5335 He had not my virginity
5336 KING What say'st thou to her
5337 BERTRAM She's impudent my lord
5338 And was a common gamester to the camp
5339 DIANA He does me wrong my lord if I were so
5340 He might have bought me at a common price
5341 Do not believe him o behold this ring
5342 Whose high respect and rich validity
5343 Did lack a parallel yet for all that
5344 He gave it to a commoner o th camp
5345 If I be one
5346 COUNTESS He blushes and 'tis it
5347 Of six preceding ancestors that gem
5348 Conferr'd by testament to th sequent issue
5349 Hath it been ow'd and worn This is his wife
5350 That ring's a thousand proofs
5351 KING Methought you said
5352 You saw one here in court could witness it
5353 DIANA I did my lord but loath am to produce
5354 So bad an instrument his name's Parolles
5355 LAFEU I saw the man today if man he be
5356 KING Find him and bring him hither Exit an ATTENDANT
5357 BERTRAM What of him
5358 He's quoted for a most perfidious slave
5359 With all the spots o th world tax'd and debauch'd
5360 Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth
5361 Am I or that or this for what he'll utter
5362 That will speak anything
5363 KING She hath that ring of yours
5364 BERTRAM I think she has Certain it is I lik'd her
5365 And boarded her i th wanton way of youth
5366 She knew her distance and did angle for me
5367 Madding my eagerness with her restraint
5368 As all impediments in fancy's course
5369 Are motives of more fancy and in fine
5370 Her infinite cunning with her modern grace
5371 Subdu'd me to her rate She got the ring
5372 And I had that which any inferior might
5373 At marketprice have bought
5374 DIANA I must be patient
5375 You that have turn'd off a first so noble wife
5376 May justly diet me I pray you yet
5377 Since you lack virtue I will lose a husband
5378 Send for your ring I will return it home
5379 And give me mine again
5380 BERTRAM I have it not
5381 KING What ring was yours I pray you
5382 DIANA Sir much like
5383 The same upon your finger
5384 KING Know you this ring This ring was his of late
5385 DIANA And this was it I gave him being abed
5386 KING The story then goes false you threw it him
5387 Out of a casement
5388 DIANA I have spoke the truth
5389 Enter PAROLLES
5390 BERTRAM My lord I do confess the ring was hers
5391 KING You boggle shrewdly every feather starts you
5392 Is this the man you speak of
5393 DIANA Ay my lord
5394 KING Tell me sirrahbut tell me true I charge you
5395 Not fearing the displeasure of your master
5396 Which on your just proceeding I'll keep off
5397 By him and by this woman here what know you
5398 PAROLLES So please your Majesty my master hath been an honourable
5399 gentleman tricks he hath had in him which gentlemen have
5400 KING Come come to th purpose Did he love this woman
5401 PAROLLES Faith sir he did love her but how
5402 KING How I pray you
5403 PAROLLES He did love her sir as a gentleman loves a woman
5404 KING How is that
5405 PAROLLES He lov'd her sir and lov'd her not
5406 KING As thou art a knave and no knave
5407 What an equivocal companion is this
5408 PAROLLES I am a poor man and at your Majesty's command
5409 LAFEU He's a good drum my lord but a naughty orator
5410 DIANA Do you know he promis'd me marriage
5411 PAROLLES Faith I know more than I'll speak
5412 KING But wilt thou not speak all thou know'st
5413 PAROLLES Yes so please your Majesty I did go between them as I
5414 said but more than that he loved herfor indeed he was mad for
5415 her and talk'd of Satan and of Limbo and of Furies and I know
5416 not what Yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I
5417 knew of their going to bed and of other motions as promising
5418 her marriage and things which would derive me ill will to speak
5419 of therefore I will not speak what I know
5420 KING Thou hast spoken all already unless thou canst say they are
5421 married but thou art too fine in thy evidence therefore stand
5422 aside
5423 This ring you say was yours
5424 DIANA Ay my good lord
5425 KING Where did you buy it Or who gave it you
5426 DIANA It was not given me nor I did not buy it
5427 KING Who lent it you
5428 DIANA It was not lent me neither
5429 KING Where did you find it then
5430 DIANA I found it not
5431 KING If it were yours by none of all these ways
5432 How could you give it him
5433 DIANA I never gave it him
5434 LAFEU This woman's an easy glove my lord she goes of and on at
5435 pleasure
5436 KING This ring was mine I gave it his first wife
5437 DIANA It might be yours or hers for aught I know
5438 KING Take her away I do not like her now
5439 To prison with her And away with him
5440 Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring
5441 Thou diest within this hour
5442 DIANA I'll never tell you
5443 KING Take her away
5444 DIANA I'll put in bail my liege
5445 KING I think thee now some common customer
5446 DIANA By Jove if ever I knew man 'twas you
5447 KING Wherefore hast thou accus'd him all this while
5448 DIANA Because he's guilty and he is not guilty
5449 He knows I am no maid and he'll swear to't
5450 I'll swear I am a maid and he knows not
5451 Great King I am no strumpet by my life
5452 I am either maid or else this old man's wife
5453 [Pointing to LAFEU]
5454 KING She does abuse our ears to prison with her
5455 DIANA Good mother fetch my bail Stay royal sir
5456 Exit WIDOW
5457 The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for
5458 And he shall surety me But for this lord
5459 Who hath abus'd me as he knows himself
5460 Though yet he never harm'd me here I quit him
5461 He knows himself my bed he hath defil'd
5462 And at that time he got his wife with child
5463 Dead though she be she feels her young one kick
5464 So there's my riddle one that's dead is quick
5465 And now behold the meaning
5466 Reenter WIDOW with HELENA
5467 KING Is there no exorcist
5468 Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes
5469 Is't real that I see
5470 HELENA No my good lord
5471 'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see
5472 The name and not the thing
5473 BERTRAM Both both o pardon
5474 HELENA O my good lord when I was like this maid
5475 I found you wondrous kind There is your ring
5476 And look you here's your letter This it says
5477 'When from my finger you can get this ring
5478 And are by me with child etc This is done
5479 Will you be mine now you are doubly won
5480 BERTRAM If she my liege can make me know this clearly
5481 I'll love her dearly ever ever dearly
5482 HELENA If it appear not plain and prove untrue
5483 Deadly divorce step between me and you
5484 O my dear mother do I see you living
5485 LAFEU Mine eyes smell onions I shall weep anon [To PAROLLES]
5486 Good Tom Drum lend me a handkercher So I
5487 thank thee Wait on me home I'll make sport with thee
5488 let thy curtsies alone they are scurvy ones
5489 KING Let us from point to point this story know
5490 To make the even truth in pleasure flow
5491 [To DIANA] If thou beest yet a fresh uncropped flower
5492 Choose thou thy husband and I'll pay thy dower
5493 For I can guess that by thy honest aid
5494 Thou kept'st a wife herself thyself a maid
5495 Of that and all the progress more and less
5496 Resolvedly more leisure shall express
5497 All yet seems well and if it end so meet
5498 The bitter past more welcome is the sweet [Flourish]
5499 EPILOGUE
5500 EPILOGUE
5501 KING The King's a beggar now the play is done
5502 All is well ended if this suit be won
5503 That you express content which we will pay
5504 With strife to please you day exceeding day
5505 Ours be your patience then and yours our parts
5506 Your gentle hands lend us and take our hearts
5507 Exeunt omnes
5508 THE END

5517 1607
5518 THE TRAGEDY OF ANTONY AND CLEOPATRA
5519 by William Shakespeare

5523 M AEMILIUS LEPIDUS
