9385 1601
9386 AS YOU LIKE IT
9387 by William Shakespeare
9388 DRAMATIS PERSONAE
9389 DUKE living in exile
9390 FREDERICK his brother and usurper of his dominions
9391 AMIENS lord attending on the banished Duke
9392 JAQUES
9393 LE BEAU a courtier attending upon Frederick
9394 CHARLES wrestler to Frederick
9395 OLIVER son of Sir Rowland de Boys
9396 JAQUES
9397 ORLANDO
9398 ADAM servant to Oliver
9399 DENNIS
9400 TOUCHSTONE the court jester
9401 SIR OLIVER MARTEXT a vicar
9402 CORIN shepherd
9403 SILVIUS
9404 WILLIAM a country fellow in love with Audrey
9405 A person representing HYMEN
9406 ROSALIND daughter to the banished Duke
9407 CELIA daughter to Frederick
9408 PHEBE a shepherdes
9409 AUDREY a country wench
9410 Lords Pages Foresters and Attendants
9411 <<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
9412 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
9413 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
9414 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
9415 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS

9419 SCENE
9420 OLIVER'S house FREDERICK'S court and the Forest of Arden
9421 ACT I SCENE I
9422 Orchard of OLIVER'S house
9423 Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
9424 ORLANDO As I remember Adam it was upon this fashion bequeathed
9425 me by will but poor a thousand crowns and as thou say'st
9426 charged my brother on his blessing to breed me well and there
9427 begins my sadness My brother Jaques he keeps at school and
9428 report speaks goldenly of his profit For my part he keeps me
9429 rustically at home or to speak more properly stays me here at
9430 home unkept for call you that keeping for a gentleman of my
9431 birth that differs not from the stalling of an ox His horses are
9432 bred better for besides that they are fair with their feeding
9433 they are taught their manage and to that end riders dearly
9434 hir'd but I his brother gain nothing under him but growth for
9435 the which his animals on his dunghills are as much bound to him
9436 as I Besides this nothing that he so plentifully gives me the
9437 something that nature gave me his countenance seems to take from
9438 me He lets me feed with his hinds bars me the place of a
9439 brother and as much as in him lies mines my gentility with my
9440 education This is it Adam that grieves me and the spirit of
9441 my father which I think is within me begins to mutiny against
9442 this servitude I will no longer endure it though yet I know no
9443 wise remedy how to avoid it
9444 Enter OLIVER
9445 ADAM Yonder comes my master your brother
9446 ORLANDO Go apart Adam and thou shalt hear how he will shake me
9447 up [ADAM retires]
9448 OLIVER Now sir what make you here
9449 ORLANDO Nothing I am not taught to make any thing
9450 OLIVER What mar you then sir
9451 ORLANDO Marry sir I am helping you to mar that which God made a
9452 poor unworthy brother of yours with idleness
9453 OLIVER Marry sir be better employed and be nought awhile
9454 ORLANDO Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them What
9455 prodigal portion have I spent that I should come to such penury
9456 OLIVER Know you where you are sir
9457 ORLANDO O sir very well here in your orchard
9458 OLIVER Know you before whom sir
9459 ORLANDO Ay better than him I am before knows me I know you are
9460 my eldest brother and in the gentle condition of blood you
9461 should so know me The courtesy of nations allows you my better
9462 in that you are the firstborn but the same tradition takes not
9463 away my blood were there twenty brothers betwixt us I have as
9464 much of my father in me as you albeit I confess your coming
9465 before me is nearer to his reverence
9466 OLIVER What boy [Strikes him]
9467 ORLANDO Come come elder brother you are too young in this
9468 OLIVER Wilt thou lay hands on me villain
9469 ORLANDO I am no villain I am the youngest son of Sir Rowland de
9470 Boys He was my father and he is thrice a villain that says such
9471 a father begot villains Wert thou not my brother I would not
9472 take this hand from thy throat till this other had pull'd out thy
9473 tongue for saying so Thou has rail'd on thyself
9474 ADAM [Coming forward] Sweet masters be patient for your father's
9475 remembrance be at accord
9476 OLIVER Let me go I say
9477 ORLANDO I will not till I please you shall hear me My father
9478 charg'd you in his will to give me good education you have
9479 train'd me like a peasant obscuring and hiding from me all
9480 gentlemanlike qualities The spirit of my father grows strong in
9481 me and I will no longer endure it therefore allow me such
9482 exercises as may become a gentleman or give me the poor
9483 allottery my father left me by testament with that I will go buy
9484 my fortunes
9485 OLIVER And what wilt thou do Beg when that is spent Well sir
9486 get you in I will not long be troubled with you you shall have
9487 some part of your will I pray you leave me
9488 ORLANDO I no further offend you than becomes me for my good
9489 OLIVER Get you with him you old dog
9490 ADAM Is 'old dog my reward Most true I have lost my teeth in
9491 your service God be with my old master He would not have spoke
9492 such a word
9493 Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM
9494 OLIVER Is it even so Begin you to grow upon me I will physic
9495 your rankness and yet give no thousand crowns neither Holla
9496 Dennis
9497 Enter DENNIS
9498 DENNIS Calls your worship
9499 OLIVER not Charles the Duke's wrestler here to speak with me
9500 DENNIS So please you he is here at the door and importunes access
9501 to you
9502 OLIVER Call him in [Exit DENNIS] 'Twill be a good way and
9503 tomorrow the wrestling is
9504 Enter CHARLES
9505 CHARLES Good morrow to your worship
9506 OLIVER Good Monsieur Charles What's the new news at the new
9507 court
9508 CHARLES There's no news at the court sir but the old news that
9509 is the old Duke is banished by his younger brother the new Duke
9510 and three or four loving lords have put themselves into voluntary
9511 exile with him whose lands and revenues enrich the new Duke
9512 therefore he gives them good leave to wander
9513 OLIVER Can you tell if Rosalind the Duke's daughter be banished
9514 with her father
9515 CHARLES O no for the Duke's daughter her cousin so loves her
9516 being ever from their cradles bred together that she would have
9517 followed her exile or have died to stay behind her She is at
9518 the court and no less beloved of her uncle than his own
9519 daughter and never two ladies loved as they do
9520 OLIVER Where will the old Duke live
9521 CHARLES They say he is already in the Forest of Arden and a many
9522 merry men with him and there they live like the old Robin Hood
9523 of England They say many young gentlemen flock to him every day
9524 and fleet the time carelessly as they did in the golden world
9525 OLIVER What you wrestle tomorrow before the new Duke
9526 CHARLES Marry do I sir and I came to acquaint you with a
9527 matter I am given sir secretly to understand that your younger
9528 brother Orlando hath a disposition to come in disguis'd against
9529 me to try a fall Tomorrow sir I wrestle for my credit and he
9530 that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well
9531 Your brother is but young and tender and for your love I would
9532 be loath to foil him as I must for my own honour if he come
9533 in therefore out of my love to you I came hither to acquaint
9534 you withal that either you might stay him from his intendment
9535 or brook such disgrace well as he shall run into in that it is
9536 thing of his own search and altogether against my will
9537 OLIVER Charles I thank thee for thy love to me which thou shalt
9538 find I will most kindly requite I had myself notice of my
9539 brother's purpose herein and have by underhand means laboured to
9540 dissuade him from it but he is resolute I'll tell thee
9541 Charles it is the stubbornest young fellow of France full of
9542 ambition an envious emulator of every man's good parts a secret
9543 and villainous contriver against me his natural brother
9544 Therefore use thy discretion I had as lief thou didst break his
9545 neck as his finger And thou wert best look to't for if thou
9546 dost him any slight disgrace or if he do not mightily grace
9547 himself on thee he will practise against thee by poison entrap
9548 thee by some treacherous device and never leave thee till he
9549 hath ta'en thy life by some indirect means or other for I
9550 assure thee and almost with tears I speak it there is not one
9551 so young and so villainous this day living I speak but brotherly
9552 of him but should I anatomize him to thee as he is I must blush
9553 and weep and thou must look pale and wonder
9554 CHARLES I am heartily glad I came hither to you If he come
9555 tomorrow I'll give him his payment If ever he go alone again
9556 I'll never wrestle for prize more And so God keep your worship
9557 Exit
9558 OLIVER Farewell good Charles Now will I stir this gamester I
9559 hope I shall see an end of him for my soul yet I know not why
9560 hates nothing more than he Yet he's gentle never school'd and
9561 yet learned full of noble device of all sorts enchantingly
9562 beloved and indeed so much in the heart of the world and
9563 especially of my own people who best know him that I am
9564 altogether misprised But it shall not be so long this wrestler
9565 shall clear all Nothing remains but that I kindle the boy
9566 thither which now I'll go about Exit
9567 <<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
9568 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
9569 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
9570 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
9571 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
9572 PERSONAL USE ONLY AND 2 ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
9573 COMMERCIALLY PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
9574 SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP>>
9575 SCENE II
9576 A lawn before the DUKE'S palace
9577 Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
9578 CELIA I pray thee Rosalind sweet my coz be merry
9579 ROSALIND Dear Celia I show more mirth than I am mistress of and
9580 would you yet I were merrier Unless you could teach me to forget
9581 a banished father you must not learn me how to remember any
9582 extraordinary pleasure
9583 CELIA Herein I see thou lov'st me not with the full weight that I
9584 love thee If my uncle thy banished father had banished thy
9585 uncle the Duke my father so thou hadst been still with me I
9586 could have taught my love to take thy father for mine so wouldst
9587 thou if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously temper'd
9588 as mine is to thee
9589 ROSALIND Well I will forget the condition of my estate to
9590 rejoice in yours
9591 CELIA You know my father hath no child but I nor none is like to
9592 have and truly when he dies thou shalt be his heir for what
9593 he hath taken away from thy father perforce I will render thee
9594 again in affection By mine honour I will and when I break that
9595 oath let me turn monster therefore my sweet Rose my dear
9596 Rose be merry
9597 ROSALIND From henceforth I will coz and devise sports
9598 Let me see what think you of falling in love
9599 CELIA Marry I prithee do to make sport withal but love no man
9600 in good earnest nor no further in sport neither than with safety
9601 of a pure blush thou mayst in honour come off again
9602 ROSALIND What shall be our sport then
9603 CELIA Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her
9604 wheel that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally
9605 ROSALIND I would we could do so for her benefits are mightily
9606 misplaced and the bountiful blind woman doth most mistake in her
9607 gifts to women
9608 CELIA 'Tis true for those that she makes fair she scarce makes
9609 honest and those that she makes honest she makes very
9610 illfavouredly
9611 ROSALIND Nay now thou goest from Fortune's office to Nature's
9612 Fortune reigns in gifts of the world not in the lineaments of
9613 Nature
9614 Enter TOUCHSTONE
9615 CELIA No when Nature hath made a fair creature may she not by
9616 Fortune fall into the fire Though Nature hath given us wit to
9617 flout at Fortune hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off
9618 the argument
9619 ROSALIND Indeed there is Fortune too hard for Nature when
9620 Fortune makes Nature's natural the cutteroff of Nature's wit
9621 CELIA Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither but
9622 Nature's who perceiveth our natural wits too dull to reason of
9623 such goddesses and hath sent this natural for our whetstone for
9624 always the dullness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits How
9625 now wit Whither wander you
9626 TOUCHSTONE Mistress you must come away to your father
9627 CELIA Were you made the messenger
9628 TOUCHSTONE No by mine honour but I was bid to come for you
9629 ROSALIND Where learned you that oath fool
9630 TOUCHSTONE Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they were
9631 good pancakes and swore by his honour the mustard was naught
9632 Now I'll stand to it the pancakes were naught and the mustard
9633 was good and yet was not the knight forsworn
9634 CELIA How prove you that in the great heap of your knowledge
9635 ROSALIND Ay marry now unmuzzle your wisdom
9636 TOUCHSTONE Stand you both forth now stroke your chins and swear
9637 by your beards that I am a knave
9638 CELIA By our beards if we had them thou art
9639 TOUCHSTONE By my knavery if I had it then I were But if you
9640 swear by that that not you are not forsworn no more was this
9641 knight swearing by his honour for he never had any or if he
9642 had he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancackes or
9643 that mustard
9644 CELIA Prithee who is't that thou mean'st
9645 TOUCHSTONE One that old Frederick your father loves
9646 CELIA My father's love is enough to honour him Enough speak no
9647 more of him you'll be whipt for taxation one of these days
9648 TOUCHSTONE The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what wise
9649 men do foolishly
9650 CELIA By my troth thou sayest true for since the little wit that
9651 fools have was silenced the little foolery that wise men have
9652 makes a great show Here comes Monsieur Le Beau
9653 Enter LE BEAU
9654 ROSALIND With his mouth full of news
9655 CELIA Which he will put on us as pigeons feed their young
9656 ROSALIND Then shall we be newscramm'd
9657 CELIA All the better we shall be the more marketable Bon jour
9658 Monsieur Le Beau What's the news
9659 LE BEAU Fair Princess you have lost much good sport
9660 CELIA Sport of what colour
9661 LE BEAU What colour madam How shall I answer you
9662 ROSALIND As wit and fortune will
9663 TOUCHSTONE Or as the Destinies decrees
9664 CELIA Well said that was laid on with a trowel
9665 TOUCHSTONE Nay if I keep not my rank
9666 ROSALIND Thou losest thy old smell
9667 LE BEAU You amaze me ladies I would have told you of good
9668 wrestling which you have lost the sight of
9669 ROSALIND Yet tell us the manner of the wrestling
9670 LE BEAU I will tell you the beginning and if it please your
9671 ladyships you may see the end for the best is yet to do and
9672 here where you are they are coming to perform it
9673 CELIA Well the beginning that is dead and buried
9674 LE BEAU There comes an old man and his three sons
9675 CELIA I could match this beginning with an old tale
9676 LE BEAU Three proper young men of excellent growth and presence
9677 ROSALIND With bills on their necks 'Be it known unto all men by
9678 these presents'
9679 LE BEAU The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles the Duke's
9680 wrestler which Charles in a moment threw him and broke three of
9681 his ribs that there is little hope of life in him So he serv'd
9682 the second and so the third Yonder they lie the poor old man
9683 their father making such pitiful dole over them that all the
9684 beholders take his part with weeping
9685 ROSALIND Alas
9686 TOUCHSTONE But what is the sport monsieur that the ladies have
9687 lost
9688 LE BEAU Why this that I speak of
9689 TOUCHSTONE Thus men may grow wiser every day It is the first time
9690 that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies
9691 CELIA Or I I promise thee
9692 ROSALIND But is there any else longs to see this broken music in
9693 his sides Is there yet another dotes upon ribbreaking Shall we
9694 see this wrestling cousin
9695 LE BEAU You must if you stay here for here is the place
9696 appointed for the wrestling and they are ready to perform it
9697 CELIA Yonder sure they are coming Let us now stay and see it
9698 Flourish Enter DUKE FREDERICK LORDS ORLANDO
9699 CHARLES and ATTENDANTS
9700 FREDERICK Come on since the youth will not be entreated his own
9701 peril on his forwardness
9702 ROSALIND Is yonder the man
9703 LE BEAU Even he madam
9704 CELIA Alas he is too young yet he looks successfully
9705 FREDERICK How now daughter and cousin Are you crept hither to
9706 see the wrestling
9707 ROSALIND Ay my liege so please you give us leave
9708 FREDERICK You will take little delight in it I can tell you
9709 there is such odds in the man In pity of the challenger's youth
9710 I would fain dissuade him but he will not be entreated Speak to
9711 him ladies see if you can move him
9712 CELIA Call him hither good Monsieur Le Beau
9713 FREDERICK Do so I'll not be by
9714 [DUKE FREDERICK goes apart]
9715 LE BEAU Monsieur the Challenger the Princess calls for you
9716 ORLANDO I attend them with all respect and duty
9717 ROSALIND Young man have you challeng'd Charles the wrestler
9718 ORLANDO No fair Princess he is the general challenger I come
9719 but in as others do to try with him the strength of my youth
9720 CELIA Young gentleman your spirits are too bold for your years
9721 You have seen cruel proof of this man's strength if you saw
9722 yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment the
9723 fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal
9724 enterprise We pray you for your own sake to embrace your own
9725 safety and give over this attempt
9726 ROSALIND Do young sir your reputation shall not therefore be
9727 misprised we will make it our suit to the Duke that the
9728 wrestling might not go forward
9729 ORLANDO I beseech you punish me not with your hard thoughts
9730 wherein I confess me much guilty to deny so fair and excellent
9731 ladies any thing But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go
9732 with me to my trial wherein if I be foil'd there is but one
9733 sham'd that was never gracious if kill'd but one dead that is
9734 willing to be so I shall do my friends no wrong for I have none
9735 to lament me the world no injury for in it I have nothing only
9736 in the world I fill up a place which may be better supplied when
9737 I have made it empty
9738 ROSALIND The little strength that I have I would it were with
9739 you
9740 CELIA And mine to eke out hers
9741 ROSALIND Fare you well Pray heaven I be deceiv'd in you
9742 CELIA Your heart's desires be with you
9743 CHARLES Come where is this young gallant that is so desirous to
9744 lie with his mother earth
9745 ORLANDO Ready sir but his will hath in it a more modest working
9746 FREDERICK You shall try but one fall
9747 CHARLES No I warrant your Grace you shall not entreat him to a
9748 second that have so mightily persuaded him from a first
9749 ORLANDO You mean to mock me after you should not have mock'd me
9750 before but come your ways
9751 ROSALIND Now Hercules be thy speed young man
9752 CELIA I would I were invisible to catch the strong fellow by the
9753 leg [They wrestle]
9754 ROSALIND O excellent young man
9755 CELIA If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye I can tell who should
9756 down
9757 [CHARLES is thrown Shout]
9758 FREDERICK No more no more
9759 ORLANDO Yes I beseech your Grace I am not yet well breath'd
9760 FREDERICK How dost thou Charles
9761 LE BEAU He cannot speak my lord
9762 FREDERICK Bear him away What is thy name young man
9763 ORLANDO Orlando my liege the youngest son of Sir Rowland de
9764 Boys
9765 FREDERICK I would thou hadst been son to some man else
9766 The world esteem'd thy father honourable
9767 But I did find him still mine enemy
9768 Thou shouldst have better pleas'd me with this deed
9769 Hadst thou descended from another house
9770 But fare thee well thou art a gallant youth
9771 I would thou hadst told me of another father
9772 Exeunt DUKE train and LE BEAU
9773 CELIA Were I my father coz would I do this
9774 ORLANDO I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son
9775 His youngest son and would not change that calling
9776 To be adopted heir to Frederick
9777 ROSALIND My father lov'd Sir Rowland as his soul
9778 And all the world was of my father's mind
9779 Had I before known this young man his son
9780 I should have given him tears unto entreaties
9781 Ere he should thus have ventur'd
9782 CELIA Gentle cousin
9783 Let us go thank him and encourage him
9784 My father's rough and envious disposition
9785 Sticks me at heart Sir you have well deserv'd
9786 If you do keep your promises in love
9787 But justly as you have exceeded all promise
9788 Your mistress shall be happy
9789 ROSALIND Gentleman [Giving him a chain from her neck]
9790 Wear this for me one out of suits with fortune
9791 That could give more but that her hand lacks means
9792 Shall we go coz
9793 CELIA Ay Fare you well fair gentleman
9794 ORLANDO Can I not say 'I thank you My better parts
9795 Are all thrown down and that which here stands up
9796 Is but a quintain a mere lifeless block
9797 ROSALIND He calls us back My pride fell with my fortunes
9798 I'll ask him what he would Did you call sir
9799 Sir you have wrestled well and overthrown
9800 More than your enemies
9801 CELIA Will you go coz
9802 ROSALIND Have with you Fare you well
9803 Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA
9804 ORLANDO What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue
9805 I cannot speak to her yet she urg'd conference
9806 O poor Orlando thou art overthrown
9807 Or Charles or something weaker masters thee
9808 Reenter LE BEAU
9809 LE BEAU Good sir I do in friendship counsel you
9810 To leave this place Albeit you have deserv'd
9811 High commendation true applause and love
9812 Yet such is now the Duke's condition
9813 That he misconstrues all that you have done
9814 The Duke is humorous what he is indeed
9815 More suits you to conceive than I to speak of
9816 ORLANDO I thank you sir and pray you tell me this
9817 Which of the two was daughter of the Duke
9818 That here was at the wrestling
9819 LE BEAU Neither his daughter if we judge by manners
9820 But yet indeed the smaller is his daughter
9821 The other is daughter to the banish'd Duke
9822 And here detain'd by her usurping uncle
9823 To keep his daughter company whose loves
9824 Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters
9825 But I can tell you that of late this Duke
9826 Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece
9827 Grounded upon no other argument
9828 But that the people praise her for her virtues
9829 And pity her for her good father's sake
9830 And on my life his malice 'gainst the lady
9831 Will suddenly break forth Sir fare you well
9832 Hereafter in a better world than this
9833 I shall desire more love and knowledge of you
9834 ORLANDO I rest much bounden to you fare you well
9835 Exit LE BEAU
9836 Thus must I from the smoke into the smother
9837 From tyrant Duke unto a tyrant brother
9838 But heavenly Rosalind Exit
9839 SCENE III
9840 The DUKE's palace
9841 Enter CELIA and ROSALIND
9842 CELIA Why cousin why Rosalind Cupid have mercy
9843 Not a word
9844 ROSALIND Not one to throw at a dog
9845 CELIA No thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs
9846 throw some of them at me come lame me with reasons
9847 ROSALIND Then there were two cousins laid up when the one should
9848 be lam'd with reasons and the other mad without any
9849 CELIA But is all this for your father
9850 ROSALIND No some of it is for my child's father O how full of
9851 briers is this workingday world
9852 CELIA They are but burs cousin thrown upon thee in holiday
9853 foolery if we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats
9854 will catch them
9855 ROSALIND I could shake them off my coat these burs are in my
9856 heart
9857 CELIA Hem them away
9858 ROSALIND I would try if I could cry 'hem and have him
9859 CELIA Come come wrestle with thy affections
9860 ROSALIND O they take the part of a better wrestler than myself
9861 CELIA O a good wish upon you You will try in time in despite of
9862 a fall But turning these jests out of service let us talk in
9863 good earnest Is it possible on such a sudden you should fall
9864 into so strong a liking with old Sir Rowland's youngest son
9865 ROSALIND The Duke my father lov'd his father dearly
9866 CELIA Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly
9867 By this kind of chase I should hate him for my father hated his
9868 father dearly yet I hate not Orlando
9869 ROSALIND No faith hate him not for my sake
9870 CELIA Why should I not Doth he not deserve well
9871 Enter DUKE FREDERICK with LORDS
9872 ROSALIND Let me love him for that and do you love him because I
9873 do Look here comes the Duke
9874 CELIA With his eyes full of anger
9875 FREDERICK Mistress dispatch you with your safest haste
9876 And get you from our court
9877 ROSALIND Me uncle
9878 FREDERICK You cousin
9879 Within these ten days if that thou beest found
9880 So near our public court as twenty miles
9881 Thou diest for it
9882 ROSALIND I do beseech your Grace
9883 Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me
9884 If with myself I hold intelligence
9885 Or have acquaintance with mine own desires
9886 If that I do not dream or be not frantic
9887 As I do trust I am not then dear uncle
9888 Never so much as in a thought unborn
9889 Did I offend your Highness
9890 FREDERICK Thus do all traitors
9891 If their purgation did consist in words
9892 They are as innocent as grace itself
9893 Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not
9894 ROSALIND Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor
9895 Tell me whereon the likelihood depends
9896 FREDERICK Thou art thy father's daughter there's enough
9897 ROSALIND SO was I when your Highness took his dukedom
9898 So was I when your Highness banish'd him
9899 Treason is not inherited my lord
9900 Or if we did derive it from our friends
9901 What's that to me My father was no traitor
9902 Then good my liege mistake me not so much
9903 To think my poverty is treacherous
9904 CELIA Dear sovereign hear me speak
9905 FREDERICK Ay Celia we stay'd her for your sake
9906 Else had she with her father rang'd along
9907 CELIA I did not then entreat to have her stay
9908 It was your pleasure and your own remorse
9909 I was too young that time to value her
9910 But now I know her If she be a traitor
9911 Why so am I we still have slept together
9912 Rose at an instant learn'd play'd eat together
9913 And wheresoe'er we went like Juno's swans
9914 Still we went coupled and inseparable
9915 FREDERICK She is too subtle for thee and her smoothness
9916 Her very silence and her patience
9917 Speak to the people and they pity her
9918 Thou art a fool She robs thee of thy name
9919 And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous
9920 When she is gone Then open not thy lips
9921 Firm and irrevocable is my doom
9922 Which I have pass'd upon her she is banish'd
9923 CELIA Pronounce that sentence then on me my liege
9924 I cannot live out of her company
9925 FREDERICK You are a fool You niece provide yourself
9926 If you outstay the time upon mine honour
9927 And in the greatness of my word you die
9928 Exeunt DUKE and LORDS
9929 CELIA O my poor Rosalind Whither wilt thou go
9930 Wilt thou change fathers I will give thee mine
9931 I charge thee be not thou more griev'd than I am
9932 ROSALIND I have more cause
9933 CELIA Thou hast not cousin
9934 Prithee be cheerful Know'st thou not the Duke
9935 Hath banish'd me his daughter
9936 ROSALIND That he hath not
9937 CELIA No hath not Rosalind lacks then the love
9938 Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one
9939 Shall we be sund'red Shall we part sweet girl
9940 No let my father seek another heir
9941 Therefore devise with me how we may fly
9942 Whither to go and what to bear with us
9943 And do not seek to take your charge upon you
9944 To bear your griefs yourself and leave me out
9945 For by this heaven now at our sorrows pale
9946 Say what thou canst I'll go along with thee
9947 ROSALIND Why whither shall we go
9948 CELIA To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden
9949 ROSALIND Alas what danger will it be to us
9950 Maids as we are to travel forth so far
9951 Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold
9952 CELIA I'll put myself in poor and mean attire
9953 And with a kind of umber smirch my face
9954 The like do you so shall we pass along
9955 And never stir assailants
9956 ROSALIND Were it not better
9957 Because that I am more than common tall
9958 That I did suit me all points like a man
9959 A gallant curtleaxe upon my thigh
9960 A boar spear in my hand and in my heart
9961 Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will
9962 We'll have a swashing and a martial outside
9963 As many other mannish cowards have
9964 That do outface it with their semblances
9965 CELIA What shall I call thee when thou art a man
9966 ROSALIND I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page
9967 And therefore look you call me Ganymede
9968 But what will you be call'd
9969 CELIA Something that hath a reference to my state
9970 No longer Celia but Aliena
9971 ROSALIND But cousin what if we assay'd to steal
9972 The clownish fool out of your father's court
9973 Would he not be a comfort to our travel
9974 CELIA He'll go along o'er the wide world with me
9975 Leave me alone to woo him Let's away
9976 And get our jewels and our wealth together
9977 Devise the fittest time and safest way
9978 To hide us from pursuit that will be made
9979 After my flight Now go we in content
9980 To liberty and not to banishment Exeunt
