9989 ACT II SCENE I
9990 The Forest of Arden
9991 Enter DUKE SENIOR AMIENS and two or three LORDS like foresters
9992 DUKE SENIOR Now my comates and brothers in exile
9993 Hath not old custom made this life more sweet
9994 Than that of painted pomp Are not these woods
9995 More free from peril than the envious court
9996 Here feel we not the penalty of Adam
9997 The seasons difference as the icy fang
9998 And churlish chiding of the winter's wind
9999 Which when it bites and blows upon my body
10000 Even till I shrink with cold I smile and say
10001 'This is no flattery these are counsellors
10002 That feelingly persuade me what I am'
10003 Sweet are the uses of adversity
10004 Which like the toad ugly and venomous
10005 Wears yet a precious jewel in his head
10006 And this our life exempt from public haunt
10007 Finds tongues in trees books in the running brooks
10008 Sermons in stones and good in everything
10009 I would not change it
10010 AMIENS Happy is your Grace
10011 That can translate the stubbornness of fortune
10012 Into so quiet and so sweet a style
10013 DUKE SENIOR Come shall we go and kill us venison
10014 And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools
10015 Being native burghers of this desert city
10016 Should in their own confines with forked heads
10017 Have their round haunches gor'd
10018 FIRST LORD Indeed my lord
10019 The melancholy Jaques grieves at that
10020 And in that kind swears you do more usurp
10021 Than doth your brother that hath banish'd you
10022 Today my Lord of Amiens and myself
10023 Did steal behind him as he lay along
10024 Under an oak whose antique root peeps out
10025 Upon the brook that brawls along this wood
10026 To the which place a poor sequest'red stag
10027 That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt
10028 Did come to languish and indeed my lord
10029 The wretched animal heav'd forth such groans
10030 That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
10031 Almost to bursting and the big round tears
10032 Cours'd one another down his innocent nose
10033 In piteous chase and thus the hairy fool
10034 Much marked of the melancholy Jaques
10035 Stood on th extremest verge of the swift brook
10036 Augmenting it with tears
10037 DUKE SENIOR But what said Jaques
10038 Did he not moralize this spectacle
10039 FIRST LORD O yes into a thousand similes
10040 First for his weeping into the needless stream
10041 'Poor deer quoth he 'thou mak'st a testament
10042 As worldlings do giving thy sum of more
10043 To that which had too much Then being there alone
10044 Left and abandoned of his velvet friends
10045 ''Tis right quoth he 'thus misery doth part
10046 The flux of company Anon a careless herd
10047 Full of the pasture jumps along by him
10048 And never stays to greet him 'Ay quoth Jaques
10049 'Sweep on you fat and greasy citizens
10050 'Tis just the fashion Wherefore do you look
10051 Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there'
10052 Thus most invectively he pierceth through
10053 The body of the country city court
10054 Yea and of this our life swearing that we
10055 Are mere usurpers tyrants and what's worse
10056 To fright the animals and to kill them up
10057 In their assign'd and native dwellingplace
10058 DUKE SENIOR And did you leave him in this contemplation
10059 SECOND LORD We did my lord weeping and commenting
10060 Upon the sobbing deer
10061 DUKE SENIOR Show me the place
10062 I love to cope him in these sullen fits
10063 For then he's full of matter
10064 FIRST LORD I'll bring you to him straight Exeunt
10065 SCENE II
10066 The DUKE'S palace
10067 Enter DUKE FREDERICK with LORDS
10068 FREDERICK Can it be possible that no man saw them
10069 It cannot be some villains of my court
10070 Are of consent and sufferance in this
10071 FIRST LORD I cannot hear of any that did see her
10072 The ladies her attendants of her chamber
10073 Saw her abed and in the morning early
10074 They found the bed untreasur'd of their mistress
10075 SECOND LORD My lord the roynish clown at whom so oft
10076 Your Grace was wont to laugh is also missing
10077 Hisperia the Princess gentlewoman
10078 Confesses that she secretly o'erheard
10079 Your daughter and her cousin much commend
10080 The parts and graces of the wrestler
10081 That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles
10082 And she believes wherever they are gone
10083 That youth is surely in their company
10084 FREDERICK Send to his brother fetch that gallant hither
10085 If he be absent bring his brother to me
10086 I'll make him find him Do this suddenly
10087 And let not search and inquisition quail
10088 To bring again these foolish runaways Exeunt
10089 SCENE III
10090 Before OLIVER'S house
10091 Enter ORLANDO and ADAM meeting
10092 ORLANDO Who's there
10093 ADAM What my young master O my gentle master
10094 O my sweet master O you memory
10095 Of old Sir Rowland Why what make you here
10096 Why are you virtuous Why do people love you
10097 And wherefore are you gentle strong and valiant
10098 Why would you be so fond to overcome
10099 The bonny prizer of the humorous Duke
10100 Your praise is come too swiftly home before you
10101 Know you not master to some kind of men
10102 Their graces serve them but as enemies
10103 No more do yours Your virtues gentle master
10104 Are sanctified and holy traitors to you
10105 O what a world is this when what is comely
10106 Envenoms him that bears it
10107 ORLANDO Why what's the matter
10108 ADAM O unhappy youth
10109 Come not within these doors within this roof
10110 The enemy of all your graces lives
10111 Your brother no no brother yet the son
10112 Yet not the son I will not call him son
10113 Of him I was about to call his father
10114 Hath heard your praises and this night he means
10115 To burn the lodging where you use to lie
10116 And you within it If he fail of that
10117 He will have other means to cut you off
10118 I overheard him and his practices
10119 This is no place this house is but a butchery
10120 Abhor it fear it do not enter it
10121 ORLANDO Why whither Adam wouldst thou have me go
10122 ADAM No matter whither so you come not here
10123 ORLANDO What wouldst thou have me go and beg my food
10124 Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce
10125 A thievish living on the common road
10126 This I must do or know not what to do
10127 Yet this I will not do do how I can
10128 I rather will subject me to the malice
10129 Of a diverted blood and bloody brother
10130 ADAM But do not so I have five hundred crowns
10131 The thrifty hire I sav'd under your father
10132 Which I did store to be my fosternurse
10133 When service should in my old limbs lie lame
10134 And unregarded age in corners thrown
10135 Take that and He that doth the ravens feed
10136 Yea providently caters for the sparrow
10137 Be comfort to my age Here is the gold
10138 All this I give you Let me be your servant
10139 Though I look old yet I am strong and lusty
10140 For in my youth I never did apply
10141 Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood
10142 Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo
10143 The means of weakness and debility
10144 Therefore my age is as a lusty winter
10145 Frosty but kindly Let me go with you
10146 I'll do the service of a younger man
10147 In all your business and necessities
10148 ORLANDO O good old man how well in thee appears
10149 The constant service of the antique world
10150 When service sweat for duty not for meed
10151 Thou art not for the fashion of these times
10152 Where none will sweat but for promotion
10153 And having that do choke their service up
10154 Even with the having it is not so with thee
10155 But poor old man thou prun'st a rotten tree
10156 That cannot so much as a blossom yield
10157 In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry
10158 But come thy ways we'll go along together
10159 And ere we have thy youthful wages spent
10160 We'll light upon some settled low content
10161 ADAM Master go on and I will follow the
10162 To the last gasp with truth and loyalty
10163 From seventeen years till now almost fourscore
10164 Here lived I but now live here no more
10165 At seventeen years many their fortunes seek
10166 But at fourscore it is too late a week
10167 Yet fortune cannot recompense me better
10168 Than to die well and not my master's debtor Exeunt
10169 SCENE IV
10170 The Forest of Arden
10171 Enter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE CELIA for ALIENA and CLOWN alias TOUCHSTONE
10172 ROSALIND O Jupiter how weary are my spirits
10173 TOUCHSTONE I Care not for my spirits if my legs were not weary
10174 ROSALIND I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's apparel
10175 and to cry like a woman but I must comfort the weaker vessel as
10176 doublet and hose ought to show itself courageous to petticoat
10177 therefore courage good Aliena
10178 CELIA I pray you bear with me I cannot go no further
10179 TOUCHSTONE For my part I had rather bear with you than bear you
10180 yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you for I think you
10181 have no money in your purse
10182 ROSALIND Well this is the Forest of Arden
10183 TOUCHSTONE Ay now am I in Arden the more fool I when I was at
10184 home I was in a better place but travellers must be content
10185 Enter CORIN and SILVIUS
10186 ROSALIND Ay be so good Touchstone Look you who comes here a
10187 young man and an old in solemn talk
10188 CORIN That is the way to make her scorn you still
10189 SILVIUS O Corin that thou knew'st how I do love her
10190 CORIN I partly guess for I have lov'd ere now
10191 SILVIUS No Corin being old thou canst not guess
10192 Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover
10193 As ever sigh'd upon a midnight pillow
10194 But if thy love were ever like to mine
10195 As sure I think did never man love so
10196 How many actions most ridiculous
10197 Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy
10198 CORIN Into a thousand that I have forgotten
10199 SILVIUS O thou didst then never love so heartily
10200 If thou rememb'rest not the slightest folly
10201 That ever love did make thee run into
10202 Thou hast not lov'd
10203 Or if thou hast not sat as I do now
10204 Wearing thy hearer in thy mistress praise
10205 Thou hast not lov'd
10206 Or if thou hast not broke from company
10207 Abruptly as my passion now makes me
10208 Thou hast not lov'd
10209 O Phebe Phebe Phebe Exit Silvius
10210 ROSALIND Alas poor shepherd searching of thy wound
10211 I have by hard adventure found mine own
10212 TOUCHSTONE And I mine I remember when I was in love I broke my
10213 sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming anight to
10214 Jane Smile and I remember the kissing of her batler and the
10215 cow's dugs that her pretty chopt hands had milk'd and I remember
10216 the wooing of peascod instead of her from whom I took two cods
10217 and giving her them again said with weeping tears 'Wear these
10218 for my sake We that are true lovers run into strange capers
10219 but as all is mortal in nature so is all nature in love mortal
10220 in folly
10221 ROSALIND Thou speak'st wiser than thou art ware of
10222 TOUCHSTONE Nay I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break
10223 my shins against it
10224 ROSALIND Jove Jove this shepherd's passion
10225 Is much upon my fashion
10226 TOUCHSTONE And mine but it grows something stale with me
10227 CELIA I pray you one of you question yond man
10228 If he for gold will give us any food
10229 I faint almost to death
10230 TOUCHSTONE Holla you clown
10231 ROSALIND Peace fool he's not thy Ensman
10232 CORIN Who calls
10233 TOUCHSTONE Your betters sir
10234 CORIN Else are they very wretched
10235 ROSALIND Peace I say Good even to you friend
10236 CORIN And to you gentle sir and to you all
10237 ROSALIND I prithee shepherd if that love or gold
10238 Can in this desert place buy entertainment
10239 Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed
10240 Here's a young maid with travel much oppress'd
10241 And faints for succour
10242 CORIN Fair sir I pity her
10243 And wish for her sake more than for mine own
10244 My fortunes were more able to relieve her
10245 But I am shepherd to another man
10246 And do not shear the fleeces that I graze
10247 My master is of churlish disposition
10248 And little recks to find the way to heaven
10249 By doing deeds of hospitality
10250 Besides his cote his flocks and bounds of feed
10251 Are now on sale and at our sheepcote now
10252 By reason of his absence there is nothing
10253 That you will feed on but what is come see
10254 And in my voice most welcome shall you be
10255 ROSALIND What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture
10256 CORIN That young swain that you saw here but erewhile
10257 That little cares for buying any thing
10258 ROSALIND I pray thee if it stand with honesty
10259 Buy thou the cottage pasture and the flock
10260 And thou shalt have to pay for it of us
10261 CELIA And we will mend thy wages I like this place
10262 And willingly could waste my time in it
10263 CORIN Assuredly the thing is to be sold
10264 Go with me if you like upon report
10265 The soil the profit and this kind of life
10266 I will your very faithful feeder be
10267 And buy it with your gold right suddenly Exeunt
10268 SCENE V
10269 Another part of the forest
10270 Enter AMIENS JAQUES and OTHERS
10271 SONG
10272 AMIENS Under the greenwood tree
10273 Who loves to lie with me
10274 And turn his merry note
10275 Unto the sweet bird's throat
10276 Come hither come hither come hither
10277 Here shall he see
10278 No enemy
10279 But winter and rough weather
10280 JAQUES More more I prithee more
10281 AMIENS It will make you melancholy Monsieur Jaques
10282 JAQUES I thank it More I prithee more I can suck melancholy
10283 out of a song as a weasel sucks eggs More I prithee more
10284 AMIENS My voice is ragged I know I cannot please you
10285 JAQUES I do not desire you to please me I do desire you to sing
10286 Come more another stanzo Call you 'em stanzos
10287 AMIENS What you will Monsieur Jaques
10288 JAQUES Nay I care not for their names they owe me nothing Will
10289 you sing
10290 AMIENS More at your request than to please myself
10291 JAQUES Well then if ever I thank any man I'll thank you but
10292 that they call compliment is like th encounter of two dogapes
10293 and when a man thanks me heartily methinks have given him a
10294 penny and he renders me the beggarly thanks Come sing and you
10295 that will not hold your tongues
10296 AMIENS Well I'll end the song Sirs cover the while the Duke
10297 will drink under this tree He hath been all this day to look
10298 you
10299 JAQUES And I have been all this day to avoid him He is to
10300 disputable for my company I think of as many matters as he but
10301 I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them Come warble
10302 come
10303 SONG
10304 [All together here]
10305 Who doth ambition shun
10306 And loves to live i th sun
10307 Seeking the food he eats
10308 And pleas'd with what he gets
10309 Come hither come hither come hither
10310 Here shall he see
10311 No enemy
10312 But winter and rough weather
10313 JAQUES I'll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in
10314 despite of my invention
10315 AMIENS And I'll sing it
10316 JAQUES Thus it goes
10317 If it do come to pass
10318 That any man turn ass
10319 Leaving his wealth and ease
10320 A stubborn will to please
10321 Ducdame ducdame ducdame
10322 Here shall he see
10323 Gross fools as he
10324 An if he will come to me
10325 AMIENS What's that 'ducdame'
10326 JAQUES 'Tis a Greek invocation to call fools into a circle I'll
10327 go sleep if I can if I cannot I'll rail against all the
10328 firstborn of Egypt
10329 AMIENS And I'll go seek the Duke his banquet is prepar'd
10330 Exeunt severally
10331 SCENE VI
10332 The forest
10333 Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
10334 ADAM Dear master I can go no further O I die for food Here lie
10335 I down and measure out my grave Farewell kind master
10336 ORLANDO Why how now Adam No greater heart in thee Live a
10337 little comfort a little cheer thyself a little If this uncouth
10338 forest yield anything savage I will either be food for it or
10339 bring it for food to thee Thy conceit is nearer death than thy
10340 powers For my sake be comfortable hold death awhile at the
10341 arm's end I will here be with the presently and if I bring thee
10342 not something to eat I will give thee leave to die but if thou
10343 diest before I come thou art a mocker of my labour Well said
10344 thou look'st cheerly and I'll be with thee quickly Yet thou
10345 liest in the bleak air Come I will bear thee to some shelter
10346 and thou shalt not die for lack of a dinner if there live
10347 anything in this desert Cheerly good Adam Exeunt
10348 SCENE VII
10349 The forest
10350 A table set out Enter DUKE SENIOR AMIENS and LORDS like outlaws
10351 DUKE SENIOR I think he be transform'd into a beast
10352 For I can nowhere find him like a man
10353 FIRST LORD My lord he is but even now gone hence
10354 Here was he merry hearing of a song
10355 DUKE SENIOR If he compact of jars grow musical
10356 We shall have shortly discord in the spheres
10357 Go seek him tell him I would speak with him
10358 Enter JAQUES
10359 FIRST LORD He saves my labour by his own approach
10360 DUKE SENIOR Why how now monsieur what a life is this
10361 That your poor friends must woo your company
10362 What you look merrily
10363 JAQUES A fool a fool I met a fool i th forest
10364 A motley fool A miserable world
10365 As I do live by food I met a fool
10366 Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun
10367 And rail'd on Lady Fortune in good terms
10368 In good set terms and yet a motley fool
10369 'Good morrow fool quoth I 'No sir quoth he
10370 'Call me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortune'
10371 And then he drew a dial from his poke
10372 And looking on it with lacklustre eye
10373 Says very wisely 'It is ten o'clock
10374 Thus we may see quoth he 'how the world wags
10375 'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine
10376 And after one hour more 'twill be eleven
10377 And so from hour to hour we ripe and ripe
10378 And then from hour to hour we rot and rot
10379 And thereby hangs a tale When I did hear
10380 The motley fool thus moral on the time
10381 My lungs began to crow like chanticleer
10382 That fools should be so deep contemplative
10383 And I did laugh sans intermission
10384 An hour by his dial O noble fool
10385 A worthy fool Motley's the only wear
10386 DUKE SENIOR What fool is this
10387 JAQUES O worthy fool One that hath been a courtier
10388 And says if ladies be but young and fair
10389 They have the gift to know it and in his brain
10390 Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit
10391 After a voyage he hath strange places cramm'd
10392 With observation the which he vents
10393 In mangled forms O that I were a fool
10394 I am ambitious for a motley coat
10395 DUKE SENIOR Thou shalt have one
10396 JAQUES It is my only suit
10397 Provided that you weed your better judgments
10398 Of all opinion that grows rank in them
10399 That I am wise I must have liberty
10400 Withal as large a charter as the wind
10401 To blow on whom I please for so fools have
10402 And they that are most galled with my folly
10403 They most must laugh And why sir must they so
10404 The why is plain as way to parish church
10405 He that a fool doth very wisely hit
10406 Doth very foolishly although he smart
10407 Not to seem senseless of the bob if not
10408 The wise man's folly is anatomiz'd
10409 Even by the squand'ring glances of the fool
10410 Invest me in my motley give me leave
10411 To speak my mind and I will through and through
10412 Cleanse the foul body of th infected world
10413 If they will patiently receive my medicine
10414 DUKE SENIOR Fie on thee I can tell what thou wouldst do
10415 JAQUES What for a counter would I do but good
10416 DUKE SENIOR Most Mischievous foul sin in chiding sin
10417 For thou thyself hast been a libertine
10418 As sensual as the brutish sting itself
10419 And all th embossed sores and headed evils
10420 That thou with license of free foot hast caught
10421 Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world
10422 JAQUES Why who cries out on pride
10423 That can therein tax any private party
10424 Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea
10425 Till that the wearer's very means do ebb
10426 What woman in the city do I name
10427 When that I say the citywoman bears
10428 The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders
10429 Who can come in and say that I mean her
10430 When such a one as she such is her neighbour
10431 Or what is he of basest function
10432 That says his bravery is not on my cost
10433 Thinking that I mean him but therein suits
10434 His folly to the mettle of my speech
10435 There then how then what then Let me see wherein
10436 My tongue hath wrong'd him if it do him right
10437 Then he hath wrong'd himself if he be free
10438 Why then my taxing like a wildgoose flies
10439 Unclaim'd of any man But who comes here
10440 Enter ORLANDO with his sword drawn
10441 ORLANDO Forbear and eat no more
10442 JAQUES Why I have eat none yet
10443 ORLANDO Nor shalt not till necessity be serv'd
10444 JAQUES Of what kind should this cock come of
10445 DUKE SENIOR Art thou thus bolden'd man by thy distress
10446 Or else a rude despiser of good manners
10447 That in civility thou seem'st so empty
10448 ORLANDO You touch'd my vein at first the thorny point
10449 Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show
10450 Of smooth civility yet arn I inland bred
10451 And know some nurture But forbear I say
10452 He dies that touches any of this fruit
10453 Till I and my affairs are answered
10454 JAQUES An you will not be answer'd with reason I must die
10455 DUKE SENIOR What would you have Your gentleness shall force
10456 More than your force move us to gentleness
10457 ORLANDO I almost die for food and let me have it
10458 DUKE SENIOR Sit down and feed and welcome to our table
10459 ORLANDO Speak you so gently Pardon me I pray you
10460 I thought that all things had been savage here
10461 And therefore put I on the countenance
10462 Of stern commandment But whate'er you are
10463 That in this desert inaccessible
10464 Under the shade of melancholy boughs
10465 Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time
10466 If ever you have look'd on better days
10467 If ever been where bells have knoll'd to church
10468 If ever sat at any good man's feast
10469 If ever from your eyelids wip'd a tear
10470 And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied
10471 Let gentleness my strong enforcement be
10472 In the which hope I blush and hide my sword
10473 DUKE SENIOR True is it that we have seen better days
10474 And have with holy bell been knoll'd to church
10475 And sat at good men's feasts and wip'd our eyes
10476 Of drops that sacred pity hath engend'red
10477 And therefore sit you down in gentleness
10478 And take upon command what help we have
10479 That to your wanting may be minist'red
10480 ORLANDO Then but forbear your food a little while
10481 Whiles like a doe I go to find my fawn
10482 And give it food There is an old poor man
10483 Who after me hath many a weary step
10484 Limp'd in pure love till he be first suffic'd
10485 Oppress'd with two weak evils age and hunger
10486 I will not touch a bit
10487 DUKE SENIOR Go find him out
10488 And we will nothing waste till you return
10489 ORLANDO I thank ye and be blest for your good comfort
10490 Exit
10491 DUKE SENIOR Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy
10492 This wide and universal theatre
10493 Presents more woeful pageants than the scene
10494 Wherein we play in
10495 JAQUES All the world's a stage
10496 And all the men and women merely players
10497 They have their exits and their entrances
10498 And one man in his time plays many parts
10499 His acts being seven ages At first the infant
10500 Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms
10501 Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel
10502 And shining morning face creeping like snail
10503 Unwillingly to school And then the lover
10504 Sighing like furnace with a woeful ballad
10505 Made to his mistress eyebrow Then a soldier
10506 Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard
10507 Jealous in honour sudden and quick in quarrel
10508 Seeking the bubble reputation
10509 Even in the cannon's mouth And then the justice
10510 In fair round belly with good capon lin'd
10511 With eyes severe and beard of formal cut
10512 Full of wise saws and modern instances
10513 And so he plays his part The sixth age shifts
10514 Into the lean and slipper'd pantaloon
10515 With spectacles on nose and pouch on side
10516 His youthful hose well sav'd a world too wide
10517 For his shrunk shank and his big manly voice
10518 Turning again toward childish treble pipes
10519 And whistles in his sound Last scene of all
10520 That ends this strange eventful history
10521 Is second childishness and mere oblivion
10522 Sans teeth sans eyes sans taste sans every thing
10523 Reenter ORLANDO with ADAM
10524 DUKE SENIOR Welcome Set down your venerable burden
10525 And let him feed
10526 ORLANDO I thank you most for him
10527 ADAM So had you need
10528 I scarce can speak to thank you for myself
10529 DUKE SENIOR Welcome fall to I will not trouble you
10530 As yet to question you about your fortunes
10531 Give us some music and good cousin sing
10532 SONG
10533 Blow blow thou winter wind
10534 Thou art not so unkind
10535 As man's ingratitude
10536 Thy tooth is not so keen
10537 Because thou art not seen
10538 Although thy breath be rude
10539 Heighho sing heighho unto the green holly
10540 Most friendship is feigning most loving mere folly
10541 Then heighho the holly
10542 This life is most jolly
10543 Freeze freeze thou bitter sky
10544 That dost not bite so nigh
10545 As benefits forgot
10546 Though thou the waters warp
10547 Thy sting is not so sharp
10548 As friend rememb'red not
10549 Heighho sing &c
10550 DUKE SENIOR If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son
10551 As you have whisper'd faithfully you were
10552 And as mine eye doth his effigies witness
10553 Most truly limn'd and living in your face
10554 Be truly welcome hither I am the Duke
10555 That lov'd your father The residue of your fortune
10556 Go to my cave and tell me Good old man
10557 Thou art right welcome as thy master is
10558 Support him by the arm Give me your hand
10559 And let me all your fortunes understand Exeunt
10560 ACT III SCENE I
10561 The palace
10562 Enter DUKE FREDERICK OLIVER and LORDS
10563 FREDERICK Not see him since Sir sir that cannot be
10564 But were I not the better part made mercy
10565 I should not seek an absent argument
10566 Of my revenge thou present But look to it
10567 Find out thy brother wheresoe'er he is
10568 Seek him with candle bring him dead or living
10569 Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more
10570 To seek a living in our territory
10571 Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine
10572 Worth seizure do we seize into our hands
10573 Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother's mouth
10574 Of what we think against thee
10575 OLIVER O that your Highness knew my heart in this
10576 I never lov'd my brother in my life
10577 FREDERICK More villain thou Well push him out of doors
10578 And let my officers of such a nature
10579 Make an extent upon his house and lands
10580 Do this expediently and turn him going Exeunt
10581 SCENE II
10582 The forest
10583 Enter ORLANDO with a paper
10584 ORLANDO Hang there my verse in witness of my love
10585 And thou thricecrowned Queen of Night survey
10586 With thy chaste eye from thy pale sphere above
10587 Thy huntress name that my full life doth sway
10588 O Rosalind these trees shall be my books
10589 And in their barks my thoughts I'll character
10590 That every eye which in this forest looks
10591 Shall see thy virtue witness'd every where
10592 Run run Orlando carve on every tree
10593 The fair the chaste and unexpressive she Exit
10594 Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
10595 CORIN And how like you this shepherd's life Master Touchstone
10596 TOUCHSTONE Truly shepherd in respect of itself it is a good
10597 life but in respect that it is a shepherd's life it is nought
10598 In respect that it is solitary I like it very well but in
10599 respect that it is private it is a very vile life Now in
10600 respect it is in the fields it pleaseth me well but in respect
10601 it is not in the court it is tedious As it is a spare life
10602 look you it fits my humour well but as there is no more plenty
10603 in it it goes much against my stomach Hast any philosophy in
10604 thee shepherd
10605 CORIN No more but that I know the more one sickens the worse at
10606 ease he is and that he that wants money means and content is
10607 without three good friends that the property of rain is to wet
10608 and fire to burn that good pasture makes fat sheep and that a
10609 great cause of the night is lack of the sun that he that hath
10610 learned no wit by nature nor art may complain of good breeding
10611 or comes of a very dull kindred
10612 TOUCHSTONE Such a one is a natural philosopher Wast ever in
10613 court shepherd
10614 CORIN No truly
10615 TOUCHSTONE Then thou art damn'd
10616 CORIN Nay I hope
10617 TOUCHSTONE Truly thou art damn'd like an illroasted egg all on
10618 one side
10619 CORIN For not being at court Your reason
10620 TOUCHSTONE Why if thou never wast at court thou never saw'st good
10621 manners if thou never saw'st good manners then thy manners must
10622 be wicked and wickedness is sin and sin is damnation Thou art
10623 in a parlous state shepherd
10624 CORIN Not a whit Touchstone Those that are good manners at the
10625 court are as ridiculous in the country as the behaviour of the
10626 country is most mockable at the court You told me you salute not
10627 at the court but you kiss your hands that courtesy would be
10628 uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds
10629 TOUCHSTONE Instance briefly come instance
10630 CORIN Why we are still handling our ewes and their fells you
10631 know are greasy
10632 TOUCHSTONE Why do not your courtier's hands sweat And is not the
10633 grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man Shallow
10634 shallow A better instance I say come
10635 CORIN Besides our hands are hard
10636 TOUCHSTONE Your lips will feel them the sooner Shallow again A
10637 more sounder instance come
10638 CORIN And they are often tarr'd over with the surgery of our
10639 sheep and would you have us kiss tar The courtier's hands are
10640 perfum'd with civet
10641 TOUCHSTONE Most shallow man thou worm's meat in respect of a good
10642 piece of flesh indeed Learn of the wise and perpend civet is
10643 of a baser birth than tar the very uncleanly flux of a cat Mend
10644 the instance shepherd
10645 CORIN You have too courtly a wit for me I'll rest
10646 TOUCHSTONE Wilt thou rest damn'd God help thee shallow man God
10647 make incision in thee thou art raw
10648 CORIN Sir I am a true labourer I earn that I eat get that I
10649 wear owe no man hate envy no man's happiness glad of other
10650 men's good content with my harm and the greatest of my pride is
10651 to see my ewes graze and my lambs suck
10652 TOUCHSTONE That is another simple sin in you to bring the ewes
10653 and the rams together and to offer to get your living by the
10654 copulation of cattle to be bawd to a bellwether and to betray
10655 a shelamb of a twelvemonth to crookedpated old cuckoldly ram
10656 out of all reasonable match If thou beest not damn'd for this
10657 the devil himself will have no shepherds I cannot see else how
10658 thou shouldst scape
10659 CORIN Here comes young Master Ganymede my new mistress's brother
10660 Enter ROSALIND reading a paper
10661 ROSALIND 'From the east to western Inde
10662 No jewel is like Rosalinde
10663 Her worth being mounted on the wind
10664 Through all the world bears Rosalinde
10665 All the pictures fairest lin'd
10666 Are but black to Rosalinde
10667 Let no face be kept in mind
10668 But the fair of Rosalinde'
10669 TOUCHSTONE I'll rhyme you so eight years together dinners and
10670 suppers and sleeping hours excepted It is the right
10671 butterwomen's rank to market
10672 ROSALIND Out fool
10673 TOUCHSTONE For a taste
10674 If a hart do lack a hind
10675 Let him seek out Rosalinde
10676 If the cat will after kind
10677 So be sure will Rosalinde
10678 Winter garments must be lin'd
10679 So must slender Rosalinde
10680 They that reap must sheaf and bind
10681 Then to cart with Rosalinde
10682 Sweetest nut hath sourest rind
10683 Such a nut is Rosalinde
10684 He that sweetest rose will find
10685 Must find love's prick and Rosalinde
10686 This is the very false gallop of verses why do you infect
10687 yourself with them
10688 ROSALIND Peace you dull fool I found them on a tree
10689 TOUCHSTONE Truly the tree yields bad fruit
10690 ROSALIND I'll graff it with you and then I shall graff it with a
10691 medlar Then it will be the earliest fruit i th country for
10692 you'll be rotten ere you be half ripe and that's the right
10693 virtue of the medlar
10694 TOUCHSTONE You have said but whether wisely or no let the forest
10695 judge
10696 Enter CELIA with a writing
10697 ROSALIND Peace
10698 Here comes my sister reading stand aside
10699 CELIA 'Why should this a desert be
10700 For it is unpeopled No
10701 Tongues I'll hang on every tree
10702 That shall civil sayings show
10703 Some how brief the life of man
10704 Runs his erring pilgrimage
10705 That the streching of a span
10706 Buckles in his sum of age
10707 Some of violated vows
10708 'Twixt the souls of friend and friend
10709 But upon the fairest boughs
10710 Or at every sentence end
10711 Will I Rosalinda write
10712 Teaching all that read to know
10713 The quintessence of every sprite
10714 Heaven would in little show
10715 Therefore heaven Nature charg'd
10716 That one body should be fill'd
10717 With all graces wideenlarg'd
10718 Nature presently distill'd
10719 Helen's cheek but not her heart
10720 Cleopatra's majesty
10721 Atalanta's better part
10722 Sad Lucretia's modesty
10723 Thus Rosalinde of many parts
10724 By heavenly synod was devis'd
10725 Of many faces eyes and hearts
10726 To have the touches dearest priz'd
10727 Heaven would that she these gifts should have
10728 And I to live and die her slave'
10729 ROSALIND O most gentle pulpiter What tedious homily of love have
10730 you wearied your parishioners withal and never cried 'Have
10731 patience good people'
10732 CELIA How now Back friends shepherd go off a little go with
10733 him sirrah
10734 TOUCHSTONE Come shepherd let us make an honourable retreat
10735 though not with bag and baggage yet with scrip and scrippage
10736 Exeunt CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
10737 CELIA Didst thou hear these verses
10738 ROSALIND O yes I heard them all and more too for some of them
10739 had in them more feet than the verses would bear
10740 CELIA That's no matter the feet might bear the verses
10741 ROSALIND Ay but the feet were lame and could not bear themselves
10742 without the verse and therefore stood lamely in the verse
10743 CELIA But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be
10744 hang'd and carved upon these trees
10745 ROSALIND I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder before you
10746 came for look here what I found on a palmtree I was never so
10747 berhym'd since Pythagoras time that I was an Irish rat which I
10748 can hardly remember
10749 CELIA Trow you who hath done this
10750 ROSALIND Is it a man
10751 CELIA And a chain that you once wore about his neck
10752 Change you colour
10753 ROSALIND I prithee who
10754 CELIA O Lord Lord it is a hard matter for friends to meet but
10755 mountains may be remov'd with earthquakes and so encounter
10756 ROSALIND Nay but who is it
10757 CELIA Is it possible
10758 ROSALIND Nay I prithee now with most petitionary vehemence tell
10759 me who it is
10760 CELIA O wonderful wonderful most wonderful wonderful and yet
10761 again wonderful and after that out of all whooping
10762 ROSALIND Good my complexion dost thou think though I am
10763 caparison'd like a man I have a doublet and hose in my
10764 disposition One inch of delay more is a South Sea of discovery
10765 I prithee tell me who is it quickly and speak apace I would
10766 thou could'st stammer that thou mightst pour this conceal'd man
10767 out of thy mouth as wine comes out of narrowmouth'd bottle
10768 either too much at once or none at all I prithee take the cork
10769 out of thy mouth that I may drink thy tidings
10770 CELIA So you may put a man in your belly
10771 ROSALIND Is he of God's making What manner of man
10772 Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard
10773 CELIA Nay he hath but a little beard
10774 ROSALIND Why God will send more if the man will be thankful Let
10775 me stay the growth of his beard if thou delay me not the
10776 knowledge of his chin
10777 CELIA It is young Orlando that tripp'd up the wrestler's heels
10778 and your heart both in an instant
10779 ROSALIND Nay but the devil take mocking Speak sad brow and true
10780 maid
10781 CELIA I faith coz 'tis he
10782 ROSALIND Orlando
10783 CELIA Orlando
10784 ROSALIND Alas the day what shall I do with my doublet and hose
10785 What did he when thou saw'st him What said he How look'd he
10786 Wherein went he What makes he here Did he ask for me Where
10787 remains he How parted he with thee And when shalt thou see him
10788 again Answer me in one word
10789 CELIA You must borrow me Gargantua's mouth first 'tis a word too
10790 great for any mouth of this age's size To say ay and no to these
10791 particulars is more than to answer in a catechism
10792 ROSALIND But doth he know that I am in this forest and in man's
10793 apparel Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled
10794 CELIA It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the
10795 propositions of a lover but take a taste of my finding him and
10796 relish it with good observance I found him under a tree like a
10797 dropp'd acorn
10798 ROSALIND It may well be call'd Jove's tree when it drops forth
10799 such fruit
10800 CELIA Give me audience good madam
10801 ROSALIND Proceed
10802 CELIA There lay he stretch'd along like a wounded knight
10803 ROSALIND Though it be pity to see such a sight it well becomes
10804 the ground
10805 CELIA Cry 'Holla to thy tongue I prithee it curvets
10806 unseasonably He was furnish'd like a hunter
10807 ROSALIND O ominous he comes to kill my heart
10808 CELIA I would sing my song without a burden thou bring'st me out
10809 of tune
10810 ROSALIND Do you not know I am a woman When I think I must speak
10811 Sweet say on
10812 CELIA You bring me out Soft comes he not here
10813 Enter ORLANDO and JAQUES
10814 ROSALIND 'Tis he slink by and note him
10815 JAQUES I thank you for your company but good faith I had as
10816 lief have been myself alone
10817 ORLANDO And so had I but yet for fashion sake I thank you too
10818 for your society
10819 JAQUES God buy you let's meet as little as we can
10820 ORLANDO I do desire we may be better strangers
10821 JAQUES I pray you mar no more trees with writing love songs in
10822 their barks
10823 ORLANDO I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them
10824 illfavouredly
10825 JAQUES Rosalind is your love's name
10826 ORLANDO Yes just
10827 JAQUES I do not like her name
10828 ORLANDO There was no thought of pleasing you when she was
10829 christen'd
10830 JAQUES What stature is she of
10831 ORLANDO Just as high as my heart
10832 JAQUES You are full of pretty answers Have you not been
10833 acquainted with goldsmiths wives and conn'd them out of rings
10834 ORLANDO Not so but I answer you right painted cloth from whence
10835 you have studied your questions
10836 JAQUES You have a nimble wit I think 'twas made of Atalanta's
10837 heels Will you sit down with me and we two will rail against
10838 our mistress the world and all our misery
10839 ORLANDO I will chide no breather in the world but myself against
10840 whom I know most faults
10841 JAQUES The worst fault you have is to be in love
10842 ORLANDO 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue I am
10843 weary of you
10844 JAQUES By my troth I was seeking for a fool when I found you
10845 ORLANDO He is drown'd in the brook look but in and you shall see
10846 him
10847 JAQUES There I shall see mine own figure
10848 ORLANDO Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher
10849 JAQUES I'll tarry no longer with you farewell good Signior Love
10850 ORLANDO I am glad of your departure adieu good Monsieur
10851 Melancholy
10852 Exit JAQUES
10853 ROSALIND [Aside to CELIA] I will speak to him like a saucy lackey
10854 and under that habit play the knave with him Do you hear
10855 forester
10856 ORLANDO Very well what would you
10857 ROSALIND I pray you what is't o'clock
10858 ORLANDO You should ask me what time o day there's no clock in
10859 the forest
10860 ROSALIND Then there is no true lover in the forest else sighing
10861 every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot
10862 of Time as well as a clock
10863 ORLANDO And why not the swift foot of Time Had not that been as
10864 proper
10865 ROSALIND By no means sir Time travels in divers paces with
10866 divers persons I'll tell you who Time ambles withal who Time
10867 trots withal who Time gallops withal and who he stands still
10868 withal
10869 ORLANDO I prithee who doth he trot withal
10870 ROSALIND Marry he trots hard with a young maid between the
10871 contract of her marriage and the day it is solemniz'd if the
10872 interim be but a se'nnight Time's pace is so hard that it seems
10873 the length of seven year
10874 ORLANDO Who ambles Time withal
10875 ROSALIND With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that hath
10876 not the gout for the one sleeps easily because he cannot study
10877 and the other lives merrily because he feels no pain the one
10878 lacking the burden of lean and wasteful learning the other
10879 knowing no burden of heavy tedious penury These Time ambles
10880 withal
10881 ORLANDO Who doth he gallop withal
10882 ROSALIND With a thief to the gallows for though he go as softly
10883 as foot can fall he thinks himself too soon there
10884 ORLANDO Who stays it still withal
10885 ROSALIND With lawyers in the vacation for they sleep between term
10886 and term and then they perceive not how Time moves
10887 ORLANDO Where dwell you pretty youth
10888 ROSALIND With this shepherdess my sister here in the skirts of
10889 the forest like fringe upon a petticoat
10890 ORLANDO Are you native of this place
10891 ROSALIND As the coney that you see dwell where she is kindled
10892 ORLANDO Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in
10893 so removed a dwelling
10894 ROSALIND I have been told so of many but indeed an old religious
10895 uncle of mine taught me to speak who was in his youth an inland
10896 man one that knew courtship too well for there he fell in love
10897 I have heard him read many lectures against it and I thank God I
10898 am not a woman to be touch'd with so many giddy offences as he
10899 hath generally tax'd their whole sex withal
10900 ORLANDO Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid
10901 to the charge of women
10902 ROSALIND There were none principal they were all like one another
10903 as halfpence are every one fault seeming monstrous till his
10904 fellowfault came to match it
10905 ORLANDO I prithee recount some of them
10906 ROSALIND No I will not cast away my physic but on those that are
10907 sick There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young
10908 plants with carving 'Rosalind on their barks hangs odes upon
10909 hawthorns and elegies on brambles all forsooth deifying the
10910 name of Rosalind If I could meet that fancymonger I would give
10911 him some good counsel for he seems to have the quotidian of love
10912 upon him
10913 ORLANDO I am he that is so loveshak'd I pray you tell me your
10914 remedy
10915 ROSALIND There is none of my uncle's marks upon you he taught me
10916 how to know a man in love in which cage of rushes I am sure you
10917 are not prisoner
10918 ORLANDO What were his marks
10919 ROSALIND A lean cheek which you have not a blue eye and sunken
10920 which you have not an unquestionable spirit which you have not
10921 a beard neglected which you have not but I pardon you for that
10922 for simply your having in beard is a younger brother's revenue
10923 Then your hose should be ungarter'd your bonnet unbanded your
10924 sleeve unbutton'd your shoe untied and every thing about you
10925 demonstrating a careless desolation But you are no such man you
10926 are rather pointdevice in your accoutrements as loving yourself
10927 than seeming the lover of any other
10928 ORLANDO Fair youth I would I could make thee believe I love
10929 ROSALIND Me believe it You may as soon make her that you love
10930 believe it which I warrant she is apter to do than to confess
10931 she does That is one of the points in the which women still give
10932 the lie to their consciences But in good sooth are you he that
10933 hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired
10934 ORLANDO I swear to thee youth by the white hand of Rosalind I
10935 am that he that unfortunate he
10936 ROSALIND But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak
10937 ORLANDO Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much
10938 ROSALIND Love is merely a madness and I tell you deserves as
10939 well a dark house and a whip as madmen do and the reason why
10940 they are not so punish'd and cured is that the lunacy is so
10941 ordinary that the whippers are in love too Yet I profess curing
10942 it by counsel
10943 ORLANDO Did you ever cure any so
10944 ROSALIND Yes one and in this manner He was to imagine me his
10945 love his mistress and I set him every day to woo me at which
10946 time would I being but a moonish youth grieve be effeminate
10947 changeable longing and liking proud fantastical apish
10948 shallow inconstant full of tears full of smiles for every
10949 passion something and for no passion truly anything as boys and
10950 women are for the most part cattle of this colour would now like
10951 him now loathe him then entertain him then forswear him now
10952 weep for him then spit at him that I drave my suitor from his
10953 mad humour of love to a living humour of madness which was to
10954 forswear the full stream of the world and to live in a nook
10955 merely monastic And thus I cur'd him and this way will I take
10956 upon me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheep's heart
10957 that there shall not be one spot of love in 't
10958 ORLANDO I would not be cured youth
10959 ROSALIND I would cure you if you would but call me Rosalind and
10960 come every day to my cote and woo me
10961 ORLANDO Now by the faith of my love I will Tell me where it is
10962 ROSALIND Go with me to it and I'll show it you and by the way
10963 you shall tell me where in the forest you live Will you go
10964 ORLANDO With all my heart good youth
10965 ROSALIND Nay you must call me Rosalind Come sister will you
10966 go Exeunt
10967 SCENE III
10968 The forest
10969 Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY JAQUES behind
10970 TOUCHSTONE Come apace good Audrey I will fetch up your goats
10971 Audrey And how Audrey am I the man yet Doth my simple feature
10972 content you
10973 AUDREY Your features Lord warrant us What features
10974 TOUCHSTONE I am here with thee and thy goats as the most
10975 capricious poet honest Ovid was among the Goths
10976 JAQUES [Aside] O knowledge illinhabited worse than Jove in a
10977 thatch'd house
10978 TOUCHSTONE When a man's verses cannot be understood nor a man's
10979 good wit seconded with the forward child understanding it
10980 strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a little room
10981 Truly I would the gods had made thee poetical
10982 AUDREY I do not know what 'poetical is Is it honest in deed and
10983 word Is it a true thing
10984 TOUCHSTONE No truly for the truest poetry is the most feigning
10985 and lovers are given to poetry and what they swear in poetry may
10986 be said as lovers they do feign
10987 AUDREY Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical
10988 TOUCHSTONE I do truly for thou swear'st to me thou art honest
10989 now if thou wert a poet I might have some hope thou didst
10990 feign
10991 AUDREY Would you not have me honest
10992 TOUCHSTONE No truly unless thou wert hardfavour'd for honesty
10993 coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar
10994 JAQUES [Aside] A material fool
10995 AUDREY Well I am not fair and therefore I pray the gods make me
10996 honest
10997 TOUCHSTONE Truly and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut were
10998 to put good meat into an unclean dish
10999 AUDREY I am not a slut though I thank the gods I am foul
11000 TOUCHSTONE Well praised be the gods for thy foulness
11001 sluttishness may come hereafter But be it as it may be I will
11002 marry thee and to that end I have been with Sir Oliver Martext
11003 the vicar of the next village who hath promis'd to meet me in
11004 this place of the forest and to couple us
11005 JAQUES [Aside] I would fain see this meeting
11006 AUDREY Well the gods give us joy
11007 TOUCHSTONE Amen A man may if he were of a fearful heart stagger
11008 in this attempt for here we have no temple but the wood no
11009 assembly but hornbeasts But what though Courage As horns are
11010 odious they are necessary It is said 'Many a man knows no end
11011 of his goods Right Many a man has good horns and knows no end
11012 of them Well that is the dowry of his wife 'tis none of his
11013 own getting Horns Even so Poor men alone No no the noblest
11014 deer hath them as huge as the rascal Is the single man therefore
11015 blessed No as a wall'd town is more worthier than a village so
11016 is the forehead of a married man more honourable than the bare
11017 brow of a bachelor and by how much defence is better than no
11018 skill by so much is horn more precious than to want Here comes
11019 Sir Oliver
11020 Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
11021 Sir Oliver Martext you are well met Will you dispatch us here
11022 under this tree or shall we go with you to your chapel
11023 MARTEXT Is there none here to give the woman
11024 TOUCHSTONE I will not take her on gift of any man
11025 MARTEXT Truly she must be given or the marriage is not lawful
11026 JAQUES [Discovering himself] Proceed proceed I'll give her
11027 TOUCHSTONE Good even good Master Whatyecall't how do you sir
11028 You are very well met Goddild you for your last company I am
11029 very glad to see you Even a toy in hand here sir Nay pray be
11030 cover'd
11031 JAQUES Will you be married motley
11032 TOUCHSTONE As the ox hath his bow sir the horse his curb and
11033 the falcon her bells so man hath his desires and as pigeons
11034 bill so wedlock would be nibbling
11035 JAQUES And will you being a man of your breeding be married
11036 under a bush like a beggar Get you to church and have a good
11037 priest that can tell you what marriage is this fellow will but
11038 join you together as they join wainscot then one of you will
11039 prove a shrunk panel and like green timber warp warp
11040 TOUCHSTONE [Aside] I am not in the mind but I were better to be
11041 married of him than of another for he is not like to marry me
11042 well and not being well married it will be a good excuse for me
11043 hereafter to leave my wife
11044 JAQUES Go thou with me and let me counsel thee
11045 TOUCHSTONE Come sweet Audrey
11046 We must be married or we must live in bawdry
11047 Farewell good Master Oliver Not
11048 O sweet Oliver
11049 O brave Oliver
11050 Leave me not behind thee
11051 But
11052 Wind away
11053 Begone I say
11054 I will not to wedding with thee
11055 Exeunt JAQUES TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
11056 MARTEXT 'Tis no matter ne'er a fantastical knave of them all
11057 shall flout me out of my calling Exit
11058 SCENE IV
11059 The forest
11060 Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
11061 ROSALIND Never talk to me I will weep
11062 CELIA Do I prithee but yet have the grace to consider that tears
11063 do not become a man
11064 ROSALIND But have I not cause to weep
11065 CELIA As good cause as one would desire therefore weep
11066 ROSALIND His very hair is of the dissembling colour
11067 CELIA Something browner than Judas's
11068 Marry his kisses are Judas's own children
11069 ROSALIND I faith his hair is of a good colour
11070 CELIA An excellent colour your chestnut was ever the only colour
11071 ROSALIND And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of
11072 holy bread
11073 CELIA He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana A nun of
11074 winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously the very ice of
11075 chastity is in them
11076 ROSALIND But why did he swear he would come this morning and
11077 comes not
11078 CELIA Nay certainly there is no truth in him
11079 ROSALIND Do you think so
11080 CELIA Yes I think he is not a pickpurse nor a horsestealer but
11081 for his verity in love I do think him as concave as covered
11082 goblet or a wormeaten nut
11083 ROSALIND Not true in love
11084 CELIA Yes when he is in but I think he is not in
11085 ROSALIND You have heard him swear downright he was
11086 CELIA 'Was is not 'is besides the oath of a lover is no
11087 stronger than the word of a tapster they are both the confirmer
11088 of false reckonings He attends here in the forest on the Duke
11089 your father
11090 ROSALIND I met the Duke yesterday and had much question with him
11091 He asked me of what parentage I was I told him of as good as
11092 he so he laugh'd and let me go But what talk we of fathers when
11093 there is such a man as Orlando
11094 CELIA O that's a brave man He writes brave verses speaks brave
11095 words swears brave oaths and breaks them bravely quite
11096 traverse athwart the heart of his lover as a puny tilter that
11097 spurs his horse but on one side breaks his staff like a noble
11098 goose But all's brave that youth mounts and folly guides Who
11099 comes here
11100 Enter CORIN
11101 CORIN Mistress and master you have oft enquired
11102 After the shepherd that complain'd of love
11103 Who you saw sitting by me on the turf
11104 Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess
11105 That was his mistress
11106 CELIA Well and what of him
11107 CORIN If you will see a pageant truly play'd
11108 Between the pale complexion of true love
11109 And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain
11110 Go hence a little and I shall conduct you
11111 If you will mark it
11112 ROSALIND O come let us remove
11113 The sight of lovers feedeth those in love
11114 Bring us to this sight and you shall say
11115 I'll prove a busy actor in their play Exeunt
11116 SCENE V
11117 Another part of the forest
11118 Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE
11119 SILVIUS Sweet Phebe do not scorn me do not Phebe
11120 Say that you love me not but say not so
11121 In bitterness The common executioner
11122 Whose heart th accustom'd sight of death makes hard
11123 Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck
11124 But first begs pardon Will you sterner be
11125 Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops
11126 Enter ROSALIND CELIA and CORIN at a distance
11127 PHEBE I would not be thy executioner
11128 I fly thee for I would not injure thee
11129 Thou tell'st me there is murder in mine eye
11130 'Tis pretty sure and very probable
11131 That eyes that are the frail'st and softest things
11132 Who shut their coward gates on atomies
11133 Should be call'd tyrants butchers murderers
11134 Now I do frown on thee with all my heart
11135 And if mine eyes can wound now let them kill thee
11136 Now counterfeit to swoon why now fall down
11137 Or if thou canst not O for shame for shame
11138 Lie not to say mine eyes are murderers
11139 Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee
11140 Scratch thee but with a pin and there remains
11141 Some scar of it lean upon a rush
11142 The cicatrice and capable impressure
11143 Thy palm some moment keeps but now mine eyes
11144 Which I have darted at thee hurt thee not
11145 Nor I am sure there is not force in eyes
11146 That can do hurt
11147 SILVIUS O dear Phebe
11148 If ever as that ever may be near
11149 You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy
11150 Then shall you know the wounds invisible
11151 That love's keen arrows make
11152 PHEBE But till that time
11153 Come not thou near me and when that time comes
11154 Afflict me with thy mocks pity me not
11155 As till that time I shall not pity thee
11156 ROSALIND [Advancing] And why I pray you Who might be your
11157 mother
11158 That you insult exult and all at once
11159 Over the wretched What though you have no beauty
11160 As by my faith I see no more in you
11161 Than without candle may go dark to bed
11162 Must you be therefore proud and pitiless
11163 Why what means this Why do you look on me
11164 I see no more in you than in the ordinary
11165 Of nature's salework 'Od's my little life
11166 I think she means to tangle my eyes too
11167 No faith proud mistress hope not after it
11168 'Tis not your inky brows your black silk hair
11169 Your bugle eyeballs nor your cheek of cream
11170 That can entame my spirits to your worship
11171 You foolish shepherd wherefore do you follow her
11172 Like foggy south puffing with wind and rain
11173 You are a thousand times a properer man
11174 Than she a woman 'Tis such fools as you
11175 That makes the world full of illfavour'd children
11176 'Tis not her glass but you that flatters her
11177 And out of you she sees herself more proper
11178 Than any of her lineaments can show her
11179 But mistress know yourself Down on your knees
11180 And thank heaven fasting for a good man's love
11181 For I must tell you friendly in your ear
11182 Sell when you can you are not for all markets
11183 Cry the man mercy love him take his offer
11184 Foul is most foul being foul to be a scoffer
11185 So take her to thee shepherd Fare you well
11186 PHEBE Sweet youth I pray you chide a year together
11187 I had rather hear you chide than this man woo
11188 ROSALIND He's fall'n in love with your foulness and she'll fall
11189 in love with my anger If it be so as fast as she answers thee
11190 with frowning looks I'll sauce her with bitter words Why look
11191 you so upon me
11192 PHEBE For no ill will I bear you
11193 ROSALIND I pray you do not fall in love with me
11194 For I am falser than vows made in wine
11195 Besides I like you not If you will know my house
11196 'Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by
11197 Will you go sister Shepherd ply her hard
11198 Come sister Shepherdess look on him better
11199 And be not proud though all the world could see
11200 None could be so abus'd in sight as he
11201 Come to our flock Exeunt ROSALIND CELIA and CORIN
11202 PHEBE Dead shepherd now I find thy saw of might
11203 'Who ever lov'd that lov'd not at first sight'
11204 SILVIUS Sweet Phebe
11205 PHEBE Ha what say'st thou Silvius
11206 SILVIUS Sweet Phebe pity me
11207 PHEBE Why I arn sorry for thee gentle Silvius
11208 SILVIUS Wherever sorrow is relief would be
11209 If you do sorrow at my grief in love
11210 By giving love your sorrow and my grief
11211 Were both extermin'd
11212 PHEBE Thou hast my love is not that neighbourly
11213 SILVIUS I would have you
11214 PHEBE Why that were covetousness
11215 Silvius the time was that I hated thee
11216 And yet it is not that I bear thee love
11217 But since that thou canst talk of love so well
11218 Thy company which erst was irksome to me
11219 I will endure and I'll employ thee too
11220 But do not look for further recompense
11221 Than thine own gladness that thou art employ'd
11222 SILVIUS So holy and so perfect is my love
11223 And I in such a poverty of grace
11224 That I shall think it a most plenteous crop
11225 To glean the broken ears after the man
11226 That the main harvest reaps loose now and then
11227 A scatt'red smile and that I'll live upon
11228 PHEBE Know'st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile
11229 SILVIUS Not very well but I have met him oft
11230 And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds
11231 That the old carlot once was master of
11232 PHEBE Think not I love him though I ask for him
11233 'Tis but a peevish boy yet he talks well
11234 But what care I for words Yet words do well
11235 When he that speaks them pleases those that hear
11236 It is a pretty youth not very pretty
11237 But sure he's proud and yet his pride becomes him
11238 He'll make a proper man The best thing in him
11239 Is his complexion and faster than his tongue
11240 Did make offence his eye did heal it up
11241 He is not very tall yet for his years he's tall
11242 His leg is but soso and yet 'tis well
11243 There was a pretty redness in his lip
11244 A little riper and more lusty red
11245 Than that mix'd in his cheek 'twas just the difference
11246 Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask
11247 There be some women Silvius had they mark'd him
11248 In parcels as I did would have gone near
11249 To fall in love with him but for my part
11250 I love him not nor hate him not and yet
11251 I have more cause to hate him than to love him
11252 For what had he to do to chide at me
11253 He said mine eyes were black and my hair black
11254 And now I am rememb'red scorn'd at me
11255 I marvel why I answer'd not again
11256 But that's all one omittance is no quittance
11257 I'll write to him a very taunting letter
11258 And thou shalt bear it wilt thou Silvius
11259 SILVIUS Phebe with all my heart
11260 PHEBE I'll write it straight
11261 The matter's in my head and in my heart
11262 I will be bitter with him and passing short
11263 Go with me Silvius Exeunt
