11272 ACT IV SCENE I
11273 The forest
11274 Enter ROSALIND CELIA and JAQUES
11275 JAQUES I prithee pretty youth let me be better acquainted with
11276 thee
11277 ROSALIND They say you are a melancholy fellow
11278 JAQUES I am so I do love it better than laughing
11279 ROSALIND Those that are in extremity of either are abominable
11280 fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than
11281 drunkards
11282 JAQUES Why 'tis good to be sad and say nothing
11283 ROSALIND Why then 'tis good to be a post
11284 JAQUES I have neither the scholar's melancholy which is
11285 emulation nor the musician's which is fantastical nor the
11286 courtier's which is proud nor the soldier's which is
11287 ambitious nor the lawyer's which is politic nor the lady's
11288 which is nice nor the lover's which is all these but it is a
11289 melancholy of mine own compounded of many simples extracted
11290 from many objects and indeed the sundry contemplation of my
11291 travels in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous
11292 sadness
11293 ROSALIND A traveller By my faith you have great reason to be
11294 sad I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men's then
11295 to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and
11296 poor hands
11297 JAQUES Yes I have gain'd my experience
11298 Enter ORLANDO
11299 ROSALIND And your experience makes you sad I had rather have a
11300 fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad and to
11301 travel for it too
11302 ORLANDO Good day and happiness dear Rosalind
11303 JAQUES Nay then God buy you an you talk in blank verse
11304 ROSALIND Farewell Monsieur Traveller look you lisp and wear
11305 strange suits disable all the benefits of your own country be
11306 out of love with your nativity and almost chide God for making
11307 you that countenance you are or I will scarce think you have
11308 swam in a gondola [Exit JAQUES] Why how now Orlando where
11309 have you been all this while You a lover An you serve me such
11310 another trick never come in my sight more
11311 ORLANDO My fair Rosalind I come within an hour of my promise
11312 ROSALIND Break an hour's promise in love He that will divide a
11313 minute into a thousand parts and break but a part of the
11314 thousand part of a minute in the affairs of love it may be said
11315 of him that Cupid hath clapp'd him o th shoulder but I'll
11316 warrant him heartwhole
11317 ORLANDO Pardon me dear Rosalind
11318 ROSALIND Nay an you be so tardy come no more in my sight I had
11319 as lief be woo'd of a snail
11320 ORLANDO Of a snail
11321 ROSALIND Ay of a snail for though he comes slowly he carries
11322 his house on his head a better jointure I think than you make
11323 a woman besides he brings his destiny with him
11324 ORLANDO What's that
11325 ROSALIND Why horns which such as you are fain to be beholding to
11326 your wives for but he comes armed in his fortune and prevents
11327 the slander of his wife
11328 ORLANDO Virtue is no hornmaker and my Rosalind is virtuous
11329 ROSALIND And I am your Rosalind
11330 CELIA It pleases him to call you so but he hath a Rosalind of a
11331 better leer than you
11332 ROSALIND Come woo me woo me for now I am in a holiday humour
11333 and like enough to consent What would you say to me now an I
11334 were your very very Rosalind
11335 ORLANDO I would kiss before I spoke
11336 ROSALIND Nay you were better speak first and when you were
11337 gravell'd for lack of matter you might take occasion to kiss
11338 Very good orators when they are out they will spit and for
11339 lovers lacking God warn us matter the cleanliest shift is to
11340 kiss
11341 ORLANDO How if the kiss be denied
11342 ROSALIND Then she puts you to entreaty and there begins new
11343 matter
11344 ORLANDO Who could be out being before his beloved mistress
11345 ROSALIND Marry that should you if I were your mistress or I
11346 should think my honesty ranker than my wit
11347 ORLANDO What of my suit
11348 ROSALIND Not out of your apparel and yet out of your suit
11349 Am not I your Rosalind
11350 ORLANDO I take some joy to say you are because I would be talking
11351 of her
11352 ROSALIND Well in her person I say I will not have you
11353 ORLANDO Then in mine own person I die
11354 ROSALIND No faith die by attorney The poor world is almost six
11355 thousand years old and in all this time there was not any man
11356 died in his own person videlicet in a lovecause Troilus had
11357 his brains dash'd out with a Grecian club yet he did what he
11358 could to die before and he is one of the patterns of love
11359 Leander he would have liv'd many a fair year though Hero had
11360 turn'd nun if it had not been for a hot midsummer night for
11361 good youth he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont and
11362 being taken with the cramp was drown'd and the foolish
11363 chroniclers of that age found it was Hero of Sestos But these
11364 are all lies men have died from time to time and worms have
11365 eaten them but not for love
11366 ORLANDO I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind for I
11367 protest her frown might kill me
11368 ROSALIND By this hand it will not kill a fly But come now I
11369 will be your Rosalind in a more comingon disposition and ask me
11370 what you will I will grant it
11371 ORLANDO Then love me Rosalind
11372 ROSALIND Yes faith will I Fridays and Saturdays and all
11373 ORLANDO And wilt thou have me
11374 ROSALIND Ay and twenty such
11375 ORLANDO What sayest thou
11376 ROSALIND Are you not good
11377 ORLANDO I hope so
11378 ROSALIND Why then can one desire too much of a good thing Come
11379 sister you shall be the priest and marry us Give me your hand
11380 Orlando What do you say sister
11381 ORLANDO Pray thee marry us
11382 CELIA I cannot say the words
11383 ROSALIND You must begin 'Will you Orlando'
11384 CELIA Go to Will you Orlando have to wife this Rosalind
11385 ORLANDO I will
11386 ROSALIND Ay but when
11387 ORLANDO Why now as fast as she can marry us
11388 ROSALIND Then you must say 'I take thee Rosalind for wife'
11389 ORLANDO I take thee Rosalind for wife
11390 ROSALIND I might ask you for your commission but I do take thee
11391 Orlando for my husband There's a girl goes before the priest
11392 and certainly a woman's thought runs before her actions
11393 ORLANDO So do all thoughts they are wing'd
11394 ROSALIND Now tell me how long you would have her after you have
11395 possess'd her
11396 ORLANDO For ever and a day
11397 ROSALIND Say 'a day without the 'ever No no Orlando men are
11398 April when they woo December when they wed maids are May when
11399 they are maids but the sky changes when they are wives I will
11400 be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cockpigeon over his hen
11401 more clamorous than a parrot against rain more newfangled than
11402 an ape more giddy in my desires than a monkey I will weep for
11403 nothing like Diana in the fountain and I will do that when you
11404 are dispos'd to be merry I will laugh like a hyen and that when
11405 thou are inclin'd to sleep
11406 ORLANDO But will my Rosalind do so
11407 ROSALIND By my life she will do as I do
11408 ORLANDO O but she is wise
11409 ROSALIND Or else she could not have the wit to do this The wiser
11410 the waywarder Make the doors upon a woman's wit and it will out
11411 at the casement shut that and 'twill out at the keyhole stop
11412 that 'twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney
11413 ORLANDO A man that had a wife with such a wit he might say 'Wit
11414 whither wilt ROSALIND Nay you might keep that check for it till you met your
11415 wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed
11416 ORLANDO And what wit could wit have to excuse that
11417 ROSALIND Marry to say she came to seek you there You shall never
11418 take her without her answer unless you take her without her
11419 tongue O that woman that cannot make her fault her husband's
11420 occasion let her never nurse her child herself for she will
11421 breed it like a fool
11422 ORLANDO For these two hours Rosalind I will leave thee
11423 ROSALIND Alas dear love I cannot lack thee two hours
11424 ORLANDO I must attend the Duke at dinner by two o'clock I will be
11425 with thee again
11426 ROSALIND Ay go your ways go your ways I knew what you would
11427 prove my friends told me as much and I thought no less That
11428 flattering tongue of yours won me 'Tis but one cast away and
11429 so come death Two o'clock is your hour
11430 ORLANDO Ay sweet Rosalind
11431 ROSALIND By my troth and in good earnest and so God mend me and
11432 by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous if you break one jot
11433 of your promise or come one minute behind your hour I will
11434 think you the most pathetical breakpromise and the most hollow
11435 lover and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind that may
11436 be chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful Therefore
11437 beware my censure and keep your promise
11438 ORLANDO With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my
11439 Rosalind so adieu
11440 ROSALIND Well Time is the old justice that examines all such
11441 offenders and let Time try Adieu Exit ORLANDO
11442 CELIA You have simply misus'd our sex in your loveprate We must
11443 have your doublet and hose pluck'd over your head and show the
11444 world what the bird hath done to her own nest
11445 ROSALIND O coz coz coz my pretty little coz that thou didst
11446 know how many fathom deep I am in love But it cannot be sounded
11447 my affection hath an unknown bottom like the Bay of Portugal
11448 CELIA Or rather bottomless that as fast as you pour affection
11449 in it runs out
11450 ROSALIND No that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of
11451 thought conceiv'd of spleen and born of madness that blind
11452 rascally boy that abuses every one's eyes because his own are
11453 out let him be judge how deep I am in love I'll tell thee
11454 Aliena I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando I'll go find a
11455 shadow and sigh till he come
11456 CELIA And I'll sleep Exeunt
11457 SCENE II
11458 The forest
11459 Enter JAQUES and LORDS in the habit of foresters
11460 JAQUES Which is he that killed the deer
11461 LORD Sir it was I
11462 JAQUES Let's present him to the Duke like a Roman conqueror and
11463 it would do well to set the deer's horns upon his head for a
11464 branch of victory Have you no song forester for this purpose
11465 LORD Yes sir
11466 JAQUES Sing it 'tis no matter how it be in tune so it make noise
11467 enough
11468 SONG
11469 What shall he have that kill'd the deer
11470 His leather skin and horns to wear
11471 [The rest shall hear this burden]
11472 Then sing him home
11473 Take thou no scorn to wear the horn
11474 It was a crest ere thou wast born
11475 Thy father's father wore it
11476 And thy father bore it
11477 The horn the horn the lusty horn
11478 Is not a thing to laugh to scorn Exeunt
11479 SCENE III
11480 The forest
11481 Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
11482 ROSALIND How say you now Is it not past two o'clock
11483 And here much Orlando
11484 CELIA I warrant you with pure love and troubled brain he hath
11485 ta'en his bow and arrows and is gone forth to sleep Look who
11486 comes here
11487 Enter SILVIUS
11488 SILVIUS My errand is to you fair youth
11489 My gentle Phebe did bid me give you this
11490 I know not the contents but as I guess
11491 By the stern brow and waspish action
11492 Which she did use as she was writing of it
11493 It bears an angry tenour Pardon me
11494 I am but as a guiltless messenger
11495 ROSALIND Patience herself would startle at this letter
11496 And play the swaggerer Bear this bear all
11497 She says I am not fair that I lack manners
11498 She calls me proud and that she could not love me
11499 Were man as rare as Phoenix 'Od's my will
11500 Her love is not the hare that I do hunt
11501 Why writes she so to me Well shepherd well
11502 This is a letter of your own device
11503 SILVIUS No I protest I know not the contents
11504 Phebe did write it
11505 ROSALIND Come come you are a fool
11506 And turn'd into the extremity of love
11507 I saw her hand she has a leathern hand
11508 A freestonecolour'd hand I verily did think
11509 That her old gloves were on but 'twas her hands
11510 She has a huswife's hand but that's no matter
11511 I say she never did invent this letter
11512 This is a man's invention and his hand
11513 SILVIUS Sure it is hers
11514 ROSALIND Why 'tis a boisterous and a cruel style
11515 A style for challengers Why she defies me
11516 Like Turk to Christian Women's gentle brain
11517 Could not drop forth such giantrude invention
11518 Such Ethiope words blacker in their effect
11519 Than in their countenance Will you hear the letter
11520 SILVIUS So please you for I never heard it yet
11521 Yet heard too much of Phebe's cruelty
11522 ROSALIND She Phebes me mark how the tyrant writes
11523 [Reads]
11524 'Art thou god to shepherd turn'd
11525 That a maiden's heart hath burn'd'
11526 Can a woman rail thus
11527 SILVIUS Call you this railing
11528 ROSALIND 'Why thy godhead laid apart
11529 Warr'st thou with a woman's heart'
11530 Did you ever hear such railing
11531 'Whiles the eye of man did woo me
11532 That could do no vengeance to me'
11533 Meaning me a beast
11534 'If the scorn of your bright eyne
11535 Have power to raise such love in mine
11536 Alack in me what strange effect
11537 Would they work in mild aspect
11538 Whiles you chid me I did love
11539 How then might your prayers move
11540 He that brings this love to the
11541 Little knows this love in me
11542 And by him seal up thy mind
11543 Whether that thy youth and kind
11544 Will the faithful offer take
11545 Of me and all that I can make
11546 Or else by him my love deny
11547 And then I'll study how to die'
11548 SILVIUS Call you this chiding
11549 CELIA Alas poor shepherd
11550 ROSALIND Do you pity him No he deserves no pity Wilt thou love
11551 such a woman What to make thee an instrument and play false
11552 strains upon thee Not to be endur'd Well go your way to her
11553 for I see love hath made thee tame snake and say this to her
11554 that if she love me I charge her to love thee if she will not
11555 I will never have her unless thou entreat for her If you be a
11556 true lover hence and not a word for here comes more company
11557 Exit SILVIUS
11558 Enter OLIVER
11559 OLIVER Good morrow fair ones pray you if you know
11560 Where in the purlieus of this forest stands
11561 A sheepcote fenc'd about with olive trees
11562 CELIA West of this place down in the neighbour bottom
11563 The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream
11564 Left on your right hand brings you to the place
11565 But at this hour the house doth keep itself
11566 There's none within
11567 OLIVER If that an eye may profit by a tongue
11568 Then should I know you by description
11569 Such garments and such years 'The boy is fair
11570 Of female favour and bestows himself
11571 Like a ripe sister the woman low
11572 And browner than her brother Are not you
11573 The owner of the house I did inquire for
11574 CELIA It is no boast being ask'd to say we are
11575 OLIVER Orlando doth commend him to you both
11576 And to that youth he calls his Rosalind
11577 He sends this bloody napkin Are you he
11578 ROSALIND I am What must we understand by this
11579 OLIVER Some of my shame if you will know of me
11580 What man I am and how and why and where
11581 This handkercher was stain'd
11582 CELIA I pray you tell it
11583 OLIVER When last the young Orlando parted from you
11584 He left a promise to return again
11585 Within an hour and pacing through the forest
11586 Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy
11587 Lo what befell He threw his eye aside
11588 And mark what object did present itself
11589 Under an oak whose boughs were moss'd with age
11590 And high top bald with dry antiquity
11591 A wretched ragged man o'ergrown with hair
11592 Lay sleeping on his back About his neck
11593 A green and gilded snake had wreath'd itself
11594 Who with her head nimble in threats approach'd
11595 The opening of his mouth but suddenly
11596 Seeing Orlando it unlink'd itself
11597 And with indented glides did slip away
11598 Into a bush under which bush's shade
11599 A lioness with udders all drawn dry
11600 Lay couching head on ground with catlike watch
11601 When that the sleeping man should stir for 'tis
11602 The royal disposition of that beast
11603 To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead
11604 This seen Orlando did approach the man
11605 And found it was his brother his elder brother
11606 CELIA O I have heard him speak of that same brother
11607 And he did render him the most unnatural
11608 That liv'd amongst men
11609 OLIVER And well he might so do
11610 For well I know he was unnatural
11611 ROSALIND But to Orlando did he leave him there
11612 Food to the suck'd and hungry lioness
11613 OLIVER Twice did he turn his back and purpos'd so
11614 But kindness nobler ever than revenge
11615 And nature stronger than his just occasion
11616 Made him give battle to the lioness
11617 Who quickly fell before him in which hurtling
11618 From miserable slumber I awak'd
11619 CELIA Are you his brother
11620 ROSALIND Was't you he rescu'd
11621 CELIA Was't you that did so oft contrive to kill him
11622 OLIVER 'Twas I but 'tis not I I do not shame
11623 To tell you what I was since my conversion
11624 So sweetly tastes being the thing I am
11625 ROSALIND But for the bloody napkin
11626 OLIVER By and by
11627 When from the first to last betwixt us two
11628 Tears our recountments had most kindly bath'd
11629 As how I came into that desert place
11630 In brief he led me to the gentle Duke
11631 Who gave me fresh array and entertainment
11632 Committing me unto my brother's love
11633 Who led me instantly unto his cave
11634 There stripp'd himself and here upon his arm
11635 The lioness had torn some flesh away
11636 Which all this while had bled and now he fainted
11637 And cried in fainting upon Rosalind
11638 Brief I recover'd him bound up his wound
11639 And after some small space being strong at heart
11640 He sent me hither stranger as I am
11641 To tell this story that you might excuse
11642 His broken promise and to give this napkin
11643 Dy'd in his blood unto the shepherd youth
11644 That he in sport doth call his Rosalind
11645 [ROSALIND swoons]
11646 CELIA Why how now Ganymede sweet Ganymede
11647 OLIVER Many will swoon when they do look on blood
11648 CELIA There is more in it Cousin Ganymede
11649 OLIVER Look he recovers
11650 ROSALIND I would I were at home
11651 CELIA We'll lead you thither
11652 I pray you will you take him by the arm
11653 OLIVER Be of good cheer youth You a man
11654 You lack a man's heart
11655 ROSALIND I do so I confess it Ah sirrah a body would think
11656 this was well counterfeited I pray you tell your brother how
11657 well I counterfeited Heighho
11658 OLIVER This was not counterfeit there is too great testimony in
11659 your complexion that it was a passion of earnest
11660 ROSALIND Counterfeit I assure you
11661 OLIVER Well then take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man
11662 ROSALIND So I do but i faith I should have been a woman by
11663 right
11664 CELIA Come you look paler and paler pray you draw homewards
11665 Good sir go with us
11666 OLIVER That will I for I must bear answer back
11667 How you excuse my brother Rosalind
11668 ROSALIND I shall devise something but I pray you commend my
11669 counterfeiting to him Will you go Exeunt

11678 ACT V SCENE I
11679 The forest
11680 Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
11681 TOUCHSTONE We shall find a time Audrey patience gentle Audrey
11682 AUDREY Faith the priest was good enough for all the old
11683 gentleman's saying
11684 TOUCHSTONE A most wicked Sir Oliver Audrey a most vile Martext
11685 But Audrey there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to
11686 you
11687 AUDREY Ay I know who 'tis he hath no interest in me in the
11688 world here comes the man you mean
11689 Enter WILLIAM
11690 TOUCHSTONE It is meat and drink to me to see a clown By my troth
11691 we that have good wits have much to answer for we shall be
11692 flouting we cannot hold
11693 WILLIAM Good ev'n Audrey
11694 AUDREY God ye good ev'n William
11695 WILLIAM And good ev'n to you sir
11696 TOUCHSTONE Good ev'n gentle friend Cover thy head cover thy
11697 head nay prithee be cover'd How old are you friend
11698 WILLIAM Five and twenty sir
11699 TOUCHSTONE A ripe age Is thy name William
11700 WILLIAM William sir
11701 TOUCHSTONE A fair name Wast born i th forest here
11702 WILLIAM Ay sir I thank God
11703 TOUCHSTONE 'Thank God A good answer
11704 Art rich
11705 WILLIAM Faith sir so so
11706 TOUCHSTONE 'So so is good very good very excellent good and
11707 yet it is not it is but so so Art thou wise
11708 WILLIAM Ay sir I have a pretty wit
11709 TOUCHSTONE Why thou say'st well I do now remember a saying 'The
11710 fool doth think he is wise but the wise man knows himself to be
11711 a fool The heathen philosopher when he had a desire to eat a
11712 grape would open his lips when he put it into his mouth meaning
11713 thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open You do
11714 love this maid
11715 WILLIAM I do sir
11716 TOUCHSTONE Give me your hand Art thou learned
11717 WILLIAM No sir
11718 TOUCHSTONE Then learn this of me to have is to have for it is a
11719 figure in rhetoric that drink being pour'd out of cup into a
11720 glass by filling the one doth empty the other for all your
11721 writers do consent that ipse is he now you are not ipse for I
11722 am he
11723 WILLIAM Which he sir
11724 TOUCHSTONE He sir that must marry this woman Therefore you
11725 clown abandon which is in the vulgar leave the society which
11726 in the boorish is company of this female which in the common is
11727 woman which together is abandon the society of this female or
11728 clown thou perishest or to thy better understanding diest
11729 or to wit I kill thee make thee away translate thy life into
11730 death thy liberty into bondage I will deal in poison with thee
11731 or in bastinado or in steel I will bandy with thee in faction
11732 will o'errun thee with policy I will kill thee a hundred and
11733 fifty ways therefore tremble and depart
11734 AUDREY Do good William
11735 WILLIAM God rest you merry sir Exit
11736 Enter CORIN
11737 CORIN Our master and mistress seeks you come away away
11738 TOUCHSTONE Trip Audrey trip Audrey I attend I attend
11739 Exeunt
11740 SCENE II
11741 The forest
11742 Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER
11743 ORLANDO Is't possible that on so little acquaintance you should
11744 like her that but seeing you should love her and loving woo
11745 and wooing she should grant and will you persever to enjoy
11746 her
11747 OLIVER Neither call the giddiness of it in question the poverty
11748 of her the small acquaintance my sudden wooing nor her sudden
11749 consenting but say with me I love Aliena say with her that she
11750 loves me consent with both that we may enjoy each other It
11751 shall be to your good for my father's house and all the revenue
11752 that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you and here live
11753 and die a shepherd
11754 ORLANDO You have my consent Let your wedding be tomorrow
11755 Thither will I invite the Duke and all's contented followers Go
11756 you and prepare Aliena for look you here comes my Rosalind
11757 Enter ROSALIND
11758 ROSALIND God save you brother
11759 OLIVER And you fair sister Exit
11760 ROSALIND O my dear Orlando how it grieves me to see thee wear
11761 thy heart in a scarf
11762 ORLANDO It is my arm
11763 ROSALIND I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a
11764 lion
11765 ORLANDO Wounded it is but with the eyes of a lady
11766 ROSALIND Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to swoon
11767 when he show'd me your handkercher
11768 ORLANDO Ay and greater wonders than that
11769 ROSALIND O I know where you are Nay 'tis true There was never
11770 any thing so sudden but the fight of two rams and Caesar's
11771 thrasonical brag of 'I came saw and overcame For your brother
11772 and my sister no sooner met but they look'd no sooner look'd but
11773 they lov'd no sooner lov'd but they sigh'd no sooner sigh'd but
11774 they ask'd one another the reason no sooner knew the reason but
11775 they sought the remedy and in these degrees have they made pair
11776 of stairs to marriage which they will climb incontinent or else
11777 be incontinent before marriage They are in the very wrath of
11778 love and they will together Clubs cannot part them
11779 ORLANDO They shall be married tomorrow and I will bid the Duke
11780 to the nuptial But O how bitter a thing it is to look into
11781 happiness through another man's eyes By so much the more shall I
11782 tomorrow be at the height of heartheaviness by how much I
11783 shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for
11784 ROSALIND Why then tomorrow I cannot serve your turn for
11785 Rosalind
11786 ORLANDO I can live no longer by thinking
11787 ROSALIND I will weary you then no longer with idle talking Know
11788 of me then for now I speak to some purpose that I know you are
11789 a gentleman of good conceit I speak not this that you should
11790 bear a good opinion of my knowledge insomuch I say I know you
11791 are neither do I labour for a greater esteem than may in some
11792 little measure draw a belief from you to do yourself good and
11793 not to grace me Believe then if you please that I can do
11794 strange things I have since I was three year old convers'd
11795 with a magician most profound in his art and yet not damnable
11796 If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries
11797 it out when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her I
11798 know into what straits of fortune she is driven and it is not
11799 impossible to me if it appear not inconvenient to you to set
11800 her before your eyes tomorrow human as she is and without any
11801 danger
11802 ORLANDO Speak'st thou in sober meanings
11803 ROSALIND By my life I do which I tender dearly though I say I
11804 am a magician Therefore put you in your best array bid your
11805 friends for if you will be married tomorrow you shall and to
11806 Rosalind if you will
11807 Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE
11808 Look here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers
11809 PHEBE Youth you have done me much ungentleness
11810 To show the letter that I writ to you
11811 ROSALIND I care not if I have It is my study
11812 To seem despiteful and ungentle to you
11813 You are there follow'd by a faithful shepherd
11814 Look upon him love him he worships you
11815 PHEBE Good shepherd tell this youth what 'tis to love
11816 SILVIUS It is to be all made of sighs and tears
11817 And so am I for Phebe
11818 PHEBE And I for Ganymede
11819 ORLANDO And I for Rosalind
11820 ROSALIND And I for no woman
11821 SILVIUS It is to be all made of faith and service
11822 And so am I for Phebe
11823 PHEBE And I for Ganymede
11824 ORLANDO And I for Rosalind
11825 ROSALIND And I for no woman
11826 SILVIUS It is to be all made of fantasy
11827 All made of passion and all made of wishes
11828 All adoration duty and observance
11829 All humbleness all patience and impatience
11830 All purity all trial all obedience
11831 And so am I for Phebe
11832 PHEBE And so am I for Ganymede
11833 ORLANDO And so am I for Rosalind
11834 ROSALIND And so am I for no woman
11835 PHEBE If this be so why blame you me to love you
11836 SILVIUS If this be so why blame you me to love you
11837 ORLANDO If this be so why blame you me to love you
11838 ROSALIND Why do you speak too 'Why blame you me to love you'
11839 ORLANDO To her that is not here nor doth not hear
11840 ROSALIND Pray you no more of this 'tis like the howling of Irish
11841 wolves against the moon [To SILVIUS] I will help you if I can
11842 [To PHEBE] I would love you if I could Tomorrow meet me all
11843 together [ To PHEBE ] I will marry you if ever I marry woman
11844 and I'll be married tomorrow [To ORLANDO] I will satisfy you if
11845 ever I satisfied man and you shall be married tomorrow [To
11846 Silvius] I will content you if what pleases you contents you and
11847 you shall be married tomorrow [To ORLANDO] As you love
11848 Rosalind meet [To SILVIUS] As you love Phebe meet and as I
11849 love no woman I'll meet So fare you well I have left you
11850 commands
11851 SILVIUS I'll not fail if I live
11852 PHEBE Nor I
11853 ORLANDO Nor I Exeunt
11854 SCENE III
11855 The forest
11856 Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
11857 TOUCHSTONE Tomorrow is the joyful day Audre'y tomorrow will we
11858 be married
11859 AUDREY I do desire it with all my heart and I hope it is no
11860 dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world Here come
11861 two of the banish'd Duke's pages
11862 Enter two PAGES
11863 FIRST PAGE Well met honest gentleman
11864 TOUCHSTONE By my troth well met Come sit sit and a song
11865 SECOND PAGE We are for you sit i th middle
11866 FIRST PAGE Shall we clap into't roundly without hawking or
11867 spitting or saying we are hoarse which are the only prologues
11868 to a bad voice
11869 SECOND PAGE I'faith i'faith and both in a tune like two gipsies
11870 on a horse
11871 SONG
11872 It was a lover and his lass
11873 With a hey and a ho and a hey nonino
11874 That o'er the green cornfield did pass
11875 In the spring time the only pretty ring time
11876 When birds do sing hey ding a ding ding
11877 Sweet lovers love the spring
11878 Between the acres of the rye
11879 With a hey and a ho and a hey nonino
11880 These pretty country folks would lie
11881 In the spring time &c
11882 This carol they began that hour
11883 With a hey and a ho and a hey nonino
11884 How that a life was but a flower
11885 In the spring time &c
11886 And therefore take the present time
11887 With a hey and a ho and a hey nonino
11888 For love is crowned with the prime
11889 In the spring time &c
11890 TOUCHSTONE Truly young gentlemen though there was no great
11891 matter in the ditty yet the note was very untuneable
11892 FIRST PAGE YOU are deceiv'd sir we kept time we lost not our
11893 time
11894 TOUCHSTONE By my troth yes I count it but time lost to hear such
11895 a foolish song God buy you and God mend your voices Come
11896 Audrey Exeunt
11897 SCENE IV
11898 The forest
11899 Enter DUKE SENIOR AMIENS JAQUES ORLANDO OLIVER and CELIA
11900 DUKE SENIOR Dost thou believe Orlando that the boy
11901 Can do all this that he hath promised
11902 ORLANDO I sometimes do believe and sometimes do not
11903 As those that fear they hope and know they fear
11904 Enter ROSALIND SILVIUS and PHEBE
11905 ROSALIND Patience once more whiles our compact is urg'd
11906 You say if I bring in your Rosalind
11907 You will bestow her on Orlando here
11908 DUKE SENIOR That would I had I kingdoms to give with her
11909 ROSALIND And you say you will have her when I bring her
11910 ORLANDO That would I were I of all kingdoms king
11911 ROSALIND You say you'll marry me if I be willing
11912 PHEBE That will I should I die the hour after
11913 ROSALIND But if you do refuse to marry me
11914 You'll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd
11915 PHEBE So is the bargain
11916 ROSALIND You say that you'll have Phebe if she will
11917 SILVIUS Though to have her and death were both one thing
11918 ROSALIND I have promis'd to make all this matter even
11919 Keep you your word O Duke to give your daughter
11920 You yours Orlando to receive his daughter
11921 Keep your word Phebe that you'll marry me
11922 Or else refusing me to wed this shepherd
11923 Keep your word Silvius that you'll marry her
11924 If she refuse me and from hence I go
11925 To make these doubts all even
11926 Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA
11927 DUKE SENIOR I do remember in this shepherd boy
11928 Some lively touches of my daughter's favour
11929 ORLANDO My lord the first time that I ever saw him
11930 Methought he was a brother to your daughter
11931 But my good lord this boy is forestborn
11932 And hath been tutor'd in the rudiments
11933 Of many desperate studies by his uncle
11934 Whom he reports to be a great magician
11935 Obscured in the circle of this forest
11936 Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
11937 JAQUES There is sure another flood toward and these couples are
11938 coming to the ark Here comes a pair of very strange beasts which
11939 in all tongues are call'd fools
11940 TOUCHSTONE Salutation and greeting to you all
11941 JAQUES Good my lord bid him welcome This is the motleyminded
11942 gentleman that I have so often met in the forest He hath been a
11943 courtier he swears
11944 TOUCHSTONE If any man doubt that let him put me to my purgation
11945 I have trod a measure I have flatt'red a lady I have been
11946 politic with my friend smooth with mine enemy I have undone
11947 three tailors I have had four quarrels and like to have fought
11948 one
11949 JAQUES And how was that ta'en up
11950 TOUCHSTONE Faith we met and found the quarrel was upon the
11951 seventh cause
11952 JAQUES How seventh cause Good my lord like this fellow
11953 DUKE SENIOR I like him very well
11954 TOUCHSTONE God 'ild you sir I desire you of the like I press in
11955 here sir amongst the rest of the country copulatives to swear
11956 and to forswear according as marriage binds and blood breaks A
11957 poor virgin sir an illfavour'd thing sir but mine own a
11958 poor humour of mine sir to take that that man else will Rich
11959 honesty dwells like a miser sir in a poor house as your pearl
11960 in your foul oyster
11961 DUKE SENIOR By my faith he is very swift and sententious
11962 TOUCHSTONE According to the fool's bolt sir and such dulcet
11963 diseases
11964 JAQUES But for the seventh cause how did you find the quarrel on
11965 the seventh cause
11966 TOUCHSTONE Upon a lie seven times removed bear your body more
11967 seeming Audrey as thus sir I did dislike the cut of a certain
11968 courtier's beard he sent me word if I said his beard was not
11969 cut well he was in the mind it was This is call'd the Retort
11970 Courteous If I sent him word again it was not well cut he would
11971 send me word he cut it to please himself This is call'd the Quip
11972 Modest If again it was not well cut he disabled my judgment
11973 This is call'd the Reply Churlish If again it was not well cut
11974 he would answer I spake not true This is call'd the Reproof
11975 Valiant If again it was not well cut he would say I lie This
11976 is call'd the Countercheck Quarrelsome And so to the Lie
11977 Circumstantial and the Lie Direct
11978 JAQUES And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut
11979 TOUCHSTONE I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial nor
11980 he durst not give me the Lie Direct and so we measur'd swords
11981 and parted
11982 JAQUES Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie
11983 TOUCHSTONE O sir we quarrel in print by the book as you have
11984 books for good manners I will name you the degrees The first
11985 the Retort Courteous the second the Quip Modest the third the
11986 Reply Churlish the fourth the Reproof Valiant the fifth the
11987 Countercheck Quarrelsome the sixth the Lie with Circumstance
11988 the seventh the Lie Direct All these you may avoid but the Lie
11989 Direct and you may avoid that too with an If I knew when seven
11990 justices could not take up a quarrel but when the parties were
11991 met themselves one of them thought but of an If as 'If you
11992 said so then I said so And they shook hands and swore
11993 brothers Your If is the only peacemaker much virtue in If
11994 JAQUES Is not this a rare fellow my lord
11995 He's as good at any thing and yet a fool
11996 DUKE SENIOR He uses his folly like a stalkinghorse and under the
11997 presentation of that he shoots his wit
11998 Enter HYMEN ROSALIND and CELIA Still MUSIC
11999 HYMEN Then is there mirth in heaven
12000 When earthly things made even
12001 Atone together
12002 Good Duke receive thy daughter
12003 Hymen from heaven brought her
12004 Yea brought her hither
12005 That thou mightst join her hand with his
12006 Whose heart within his bosom is
12007 ROSALIND [To DUKE] To you I give myself for I am yours
12008 [To ORLANDO] To you I give myself for I am yours
12009 DUKE SENIOR If there be truth in sight you are my daughter
12010 ORLANDO If there be truth in sight you are my Rosalind
12011 PHEBE If sight and shape be true
12012 Why then my love adieu
12013 ROSALIND I'll have no father if you be not he
12014 I'll have no husband if you be not he
12015 Nor ne'er wed woman if you be not she
12016 HYMEN Peace ho I bar confusion
12017 'Tis I must make conclusion
12018 Of these most strange events
12019 Here's eight that must take hands
12020 To join in Hymen's bands
12021 If truth holds true contents
12022 You and you no cross shall part
12023 You and you are heart in heart
12024 You to his love must accord
12025 Or have a woman to your lord
12026 You and you are sure together
12027 As the winter to foul weather
12028 Whiles a wedlockhymn we sing
12029 Feed yourselves with questioning
12030 That reason wonder may diminish
12031 How thus we met and these things finish
12032 SONG
12033 Wedding is great Juno's crown
12034 O blessed bond of board and bed
12035 'Tis Hymen peoples every town
12036 High wedlock then be honoured
12037 Honour high honour and renown
12038 To Hymen god of every town
12039 DUKE SENIOR O my dear niece welcome thou art to me
12040 Even daughter welcome in no less degree
12041 PHEBE I will not eat my word now thou art mine
12042 Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine
12043 Enter JAQUES de BOYS
12044 JAQUES de BOYS Let me have audience for a word or two
12045 I am the second son of old Sir Rowland
12046 That bring these tidings to this fair assembly
12047 Duke Frederick hearing how that every day
12048 Men of great worth resorted to this forest
12049 Address'd a mighty power which were on foot
12050 In his own conduct purposely to take
12051 His brother here and put him to the sword
12052 And to the skirts of this wild wood he came
12053 Where meeting with an old religious man
12054 After some question with him was converted
12055 Both from his enterprise and from the world
12056 His crown bequeathing to his banish'd brother
12057 And all their lands restor'd to them again
12058 That were with him exil'd This to be true
12059 I do engage my life
12060 DUKE SENIOR Welcome young man
12061 Thou offer'st fairly to thy brothers wedding
12062 To one his lands withheld and to the other
12063 A land itself at large a potent dukedom
12064 First in this forest let us do those ends
12065 That here were well begun and well begot
12066 And after every of this happy number
12067 That have endur'd shrewd days and nights with us
12068 Shall share the good of our returned fortune
12069 According to the measure of their states
12070 Meantime forget this newfall'n dignity
12071 And fall into our rustic revelry
12072 Play music and you brides and bridegrooms all
12073 With measure heap'd in joy to th measures fall
12074 JAQUES Sir by your patience If I heard you rightly
12075 The Duke hath put on a religious life
12076 And thrown into neglect the pompous court
12077 JAQUES DE BOYS He hath
12078 JAQUES To him will I Out of these convertites
12079 There is much matter to be heard and learn'd
12080 [To DUKE] You to your former honour I bequeath
12081 Your patience and your virtue well deserves it
12082 [To ORLANDO] You to a love that your true faith doth merit
12083 [To OLIVER] You to your land and love and great allies
12084 [To SILVIUS] You to a long and welldeserved bed
12085 [To TOUCHSTONE] And you to wrangling for thy loving voyage
12086 Is but for two months victuall'd So to your pleasures
12087 I am for other than for dancing measures
12088 DUKE SENIOR Stay Jaques stay
12089 JAQUES To see no pastime I What you would have
12090 I'll stay to know at your abandon'd cave Exit
12091 DUKE SENIOR Proceed proceed We will begin these rites
12092 As we do trust they'll end in true delights [A dance] Exeunt
12093 EPILOGUE
12094 EPILOGUE
12095 ROSALIND It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue but
12096 it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord the prologue If it
12097 be true that good wine needs no bush 'tis true that a good play
12098 needs no epilogue Yet to good wine they do use good bushes and
12099 good plays prove the better by the help of good epilogues What a
12100 case am I in then that am neither a good epilogue nor cannot
12101 insinuate with you in the behalf of a good play I am not
12102 furnish'd like a beggar therefore to beg will not become me My
12103 way is to conjure you and I'll begin with the women I charge
12104 you O women for the love you bear to men to like as much of
12105 this play as please you and I charge you O men for the love
12106 you bear to women as I perceive by your simp'ring none of you
12107 hates them that between you and the women the play may please
12108 If I were a woman I would kiss as many of you as had beards that
12109 pleas'd me complexions that lik'd me and breaths that I defied
12110 not and I am sure as many as have good beards or good faces
12111 or sweet breaths will for my kind offer when I make curtsy
12112 bid me farewell
12113 THE END
12114 1593
12115 THE COMEDY OF ERRORS
12116 by William Shakespeare

12125 DRAMATIS PERSONAE
12126 SOLINUS Duke of Ephesus
12127 AEGEON a merchant of Syracuse
12128 ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS twin brothers and sons to
12129 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Aegion and Aemelia
12130 DROMIO OF EPHESUS twin brothers and attendants on
12131 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE the two Antipholuses
12132 BALTHAZAR a merchant
12133 ANGELO a goldsmith
12134 FIRST MERCHANT friend to Antipholus of Syracuse
12135 SECOND MERCHANT to whom Angelo is a debtor
12136 PINCH a schoolmaster
12137 AEMILIA wife to AEgeon an abbess at Ephesus
12138 ADRIANA wife to Antipholus of Ephesus
12139 LUCIANA her sister
12140 LUCE servant to Adriana
12141 A COURTEZAN
12142 Gaoler Officers Attendants
12143 SCENE
12144 Ephesus
12145 <<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM

12153 THE COMEDY OF ERRORS
12154 ACT I SCENE 1
12155 A hall in the DUKE'S palace
12156 Enter the DUKE OF EPHESUS AEGEON the Merchant
12157 of Syracuse GAOLER OFFICERS and other ATTENDANTS
12158 AEGEON Proceed Solinus to procure my fall
12159 And by the doom of death end woes and all
12160 DUKE Merchant of Syracuse plead no more
12161 I am not partial to infringe our laws
12162 The enmity and discord which of late
12163 Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke
12164 To merchants our welldealing countrymen
12165 Who wanting guilders to redeem their lives
12166 Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods
12167 Excludes all pity from our threat'ning looks
12168 For since the mortal and intestine jars
12169 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us
12170 It hath in solemn synods been decreed
12171 Both by the Syracusians and ourselves
12172 To admit no traffic to our adverse towns
12173 Nay more if any born at Ephesus
12174 Be seen at any Syracusian marts and fairs
12175 Again if any Syracusian born
12176 Come to the bay of Ephesushe dies
12177 His goods confiscate to the Duke's dispose
12178 Unless a thousand marks be levied
12179 To quit the penalty and to ransom him
12180 Thy substance valued at the highest rate
12181 Cannot amount unto a hundred marks
12182 Therefore by law thou art condemn'd to die
12183 AEGEON Yet this my comfort when your words are done
12184 My woes end likewise with the evening sun
12185 DUKE Well Syracusian say in brief the cause
12186 Why thou departed'st from thy native home
12187 And for what cause thou cam'st to Ephesus
12188 AEGEON A heavier task could not have been impos'd
12189 Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable
12190 Yet that the world may witness that my end
12191 Was wrought by nature not by vile offence
12192 I'll utter what my sorrow gives me leave
12193 In Syracuse was I born and wed
12194 Unto a woman happy but for me
12195 And by me had not our hap been bad
12196 With her I liv'd in joy our wealth increas'd
12197 By prosperous voyages I often made
12198 To Epidamnum till my factor's death
12199 And the great care of goods at random left
12200 Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse
12201 From whom my absence was not six months old
12202 Before herself almost at fainting under
12203 The pleasing punishment that women bear
12204 Had made provision for her following me
12205 And soon and safe arrived where I was
12206 There had she not been long but she became
12207 A joyful mother of two goodly sons
12208 And which was strange the one so like the other
12209 As could not be disdnguish'd but by names
12210 That very hour and in the selfsame inn
12211 A mean woman was delivered
12212 Of such a burden male twins both alike
12213 Those for their parents were exceeding poor
12214 I bought and brought up to attend my sons
12215 My wife not meanly proud of two such boys
12216 Made daily motions for our home return
12217 Unwilling I agreed Alas too soon
12218 We came aboard
12219 A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd
12220 Before the alwayswindobeying deep
12221 Gave any tragic instance of our harm
12222 But longer did we not retain much hope
12223 For what obscured light the heavens did grant
12224 Did but convey unto our fearful minds
12225 A doubtful warrant of immediate death
12226 Which though myself would gladly have embrac'd
12227 Yet the incessant weepings of my wife
12228 Weeping before for what she saw must come
12229 And piteous plainings of the pretty babes
12230 That mourn'd for fashion ignorant what to fear
12231 Forc'd me to seek delays for them and me
12232 And this it was for other means was none
12233 The sailors sought for safety by our boat
12234 And left the ship then sinkingripe to us
12235 My wife more careful for the latterborn
12236 Had fast'ned him unto a small spare mast
12237 Such as seafaring men provide for storms
12238 To him one of the other twins was bound
12239 Whilst I had been like heedful of the other
12240 The children thus dispos'd my wife and I
12241 Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd
12242 Fast'ned ourselves at either end the mast
12243 And floating straight obedient to the stream
12244 Was carried towards Corinth as we thought
12245 At length the sun gazing upon the earth
12246 Dispers'd those vapours that offended us
12247 And by the benefit of his wished light
12248 The seas wax'd calm and we discovered
12249 Two ships from far making amain to us
12250 Of Corinth that of Epidaurus this
12251 But ere they cameO let me say no more
12252 Gather the sequel by that went before
12253 DUKE Nay forward old man do not break off so
12254 For we may pity though not pardon thee
12255 AEGEON O had the gods done so I had not now
12256 Worthily term'd them merciless to us
12257 For ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues
12258 We were encount'red by a mighty rock
12259 Which being violently borne upon
12260 Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst
12261 So that in this unjust divorce of us
12262 Fortune had left to both of us alike
12263 What to delight in what to sorrow for
12264 Her part poor soul seeming as burdened
12265 With lesser weight but not with lesser woe
12266 Was carried with more speed before the wind
12267 And in our sight they three were taken up
12268 By fishermen of Corinth as we thought
12269 At length another ship had seiz'd on us
12270 And knowing whom it was their hap to save
12271 Gave healthful welcome to their shipwreck'd guests
12272 And would have reft the fishers of their prey
12273 Had not their bark been very slow of sail
12274 And therefore homeward did they bend their course
12275 Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss
12276 That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd
12277 To tell sad stories of my own mishaps
12278 DUKE And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for
12279 Do me the favour to dilate at full
12280 What have befall'n of them and thee till now
12281 AEGEON My youngest boy and yet my eldest care
12282 At eighteen years became inquisitive
12283 After his brother and importun'd me
12284 That his attendantso his case was like
12285 Reft of his brother but retain'd his name
12286 Might bear him company in the quest of him
12287 Whom whilst I laboured of a love to see
12288 I hazarded the loss of whom I lov'd
12289 Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece
12290 Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia
12291 And coasting homeward came to Ephesus
12292 Hopeless to find yet loath to leave unsought
12293 Or that or any place that harbours men
12294 But here must end the story of my life
12295 And happy were I in my timely death
12296 Could all my travels warrant me they live
12297 DUKE Hapless Aegeon whom the fates have mark'd
12298 To bear the extremity of dire mishap
12299 Now trust me were it not against our laws
12300 Against my crown my oath my dignity
12301 Which princes would they may not disannul
12302 My soul should sue as advocate for thee
12303 But though thou art adjudged to the death
12304 And passed sentence may not be recall'd
12305 But to our honour's great disparagement
12306 Yet will I favour thee in what I can
12307 Therefore merchant I'll limit thee this day
12308 To seek thy help by beneficial hap
12309 Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus
12310 Beg thou or borrow to make up the sum
12311 And live if no then thou art doom'd to die
12312 Gaoler take him to thy custody
12313 GAOLER I will my lord
12314 AEGEON Hopeless and helpless doth Aegeon wend
12315 But to procrastinate his lifeless end
12316 <Exeunt
12317 SCENE 2
12318 The mart
12319 Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE DROMIO OF SYRACUSE and FIRST MERCHANT
12320 FIRST MERCHANT Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum
12321 Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate
12322 This very day a Syracusian merchant
12323 Is apprehended for arrival here
12324 And not being able to buy out his life
12325 According to the statute of the town
12326 Dies ere the weary sun set in the west
12327 There is your money that I had to keep
12328 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Go bear it to the Centaur where we host
12329 And stay there Dromio till I come to thee
12330 Within this hour it will be dinnertime
12331 Till that I'll view the manners of the town
12332 Peruse the traders gaze upon the buildings
12333 And then return and sleep within mine inn
12334 For with long travel I am stiff and weary
12335 Get thee away
12336 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Many a man would take you at your word
12337 And go indeed having so good a mean
12338 <Exit
12339 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE A trusty villain sir that very oft
12340 When I am dull with care and melancholy
12341 Lightens my humour with his merry jests
12342 What will you walk with me about the town
12343 And then go to my inn and dine with me
12344 FIRST MERCHANT I am invited sir to certain merchants
12345 Of whom I hope to make much benefit
12346 I crave your pardon Soon at five o'clock
12347 Please you I'll meet with you upon the mart
12348 And afterward consort you till bed time
12349 My present business calls me from you now
12350 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Farewell till then I will go lose myself
12351 And wander up and down to view the city
12352 FIRST MERCHANT Sir I commend you to your own content
12353 <Exit FIRST MERCHANT
12354 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE He that commends me to mine own content
12355 Commends me to the thing I cannot get
12356 I to the world am like a drop of water
12357 That in the ocean seeks another drop
12358 Who falling there to find his fellow forth
12359 Unseen inquisitive confounds himself
12360 So I to find a mother and a brother
12361 In quest of them unhappy lose myself
12362 Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS
12363 Here comes the almanac of my true date
12364 What now How chance thou art return'd so soon
12365 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Return'd so soon rather approach'd too late
12366 The capon burns the pig falls from the spit
12367 The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell
12368 My mistress made it one upon my cheek
12369 She is so hot because the meat is cold
12370 The meat is cold because you come not home
12371 You come not home because you have no stomach
12372 You have no stomach having broke your fast
12373 But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray
12374 Are penitent for your default today
12375 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Stop in your wind sir tell me this I pray
12376 Where have you left the money that I gave you
12377 DROMIO OF EPHESUS OSixpence that I had a Wednesday last
12378 To pay the saddler for my mistress crupper
12379 The saddler had it sir I kept it not
12380 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE I am not in a sportive humour now
12381 Tell me and dally not where is the money
12382 We being strangers here how dar'st thou trust
12383 So great a charge from thine own custody
12384 DROMIO OF EPHESUS I pray you jest sir as you sit at dinner
12385 I from my mistress come to you in post
12386 If I return I shall be post indeed
12387 For she will score your fault upon my pate
12388 Methinks your maw like mine should be your clock
12389 And strike you home without a messenger
12390 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Come Dromio come these jests are out of season
12391 Reserve them till a merrier hour than this
12392 Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee
12393 DROMIO OF EPHESUS To me sir Why you gave no gold to me
12394 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Come on sir knave have done your foolishness
12395 And tell me how thou hast dispos'd thy charge
12396 DROMIO OF EPHESUS My charge was but to fetch you from the mart
12397 Home to your house the Phoenix sir to dinner
12398 My mistress and her sister stays for you
12399 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Now as I am a Christian answer me
12400 In what safe place you have bestow'd my money
12401 Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours
12402 That stands on tricks when I am undispos'd
12403 Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me
12404 DROMIO OF EPHESUS I have some marks of yours upon my pate
12405 Some of my mistress marks upon my shoulders
12406 But not a thousand marks between you both
12407 If I should pay your worship those again
12408 Perchance you will not bear them patiently
12409 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Thy mistress marks What mistress slave hast thou
12410 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Your worship's wife my mistress at the Phoenix
12411 She that doth fast till you come home to dinner
12412 And prays that you will hie you home to dinner
12413 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE What wilt thou flout me thus unto my face
12414 Being forbid There take you that sir knave
12415 [Beats him]
12416 DROMIO OF EPHESUS What mean you sir For God's sake hold your hands
12417 Nay an you will not sir I'll take my heels
12418 <Exit
12419 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Upon my life by some device or other
12420 The villain is o'erraught of all my money
12421 They say this town is full of cozenage
12422 As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye
12423 Darkworking sorcerers that change the mind
12424 Soulkilling witches that deform the body
12425 Disguised cheaters prating mountebanks
12426 And many suchlike liberties of sin
12427 If it prove so I will be gone the sooner
12428 I'll to the Centaur to go seek this slave
12429 I greatly fear my money is not safe
12430 <Exit

12439 ACT Il SCENE 1
12440 The house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
12441 Enter ADRIANA wife to ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS with LUCIANA her sister
12442 ADRIANA Neither my husband nor the slave return'd
12443 That in such haste I sent to seek his master
12444 Sure Luciana it is two o'clock
12445 LUCIANA Perhaps some merchant hath invited him
12446 And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner
12447 Good sister let us dine and never fret
12448 A man is master of his liberty
12449 Time is their master and when they see time
12450 They'll go or come If so be patient sister
12451 ADRIANA Why should their liberty than ours be more
12452 LUCIANA Because their business still lies out o door
12453 ADRIANA Look when I serve him so he takes it ill
12454 LUCIANA O know he is the bridle of your will
12455 ADRIANA There's none but asses will be bridled so
12456 LUCIANA Why headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe
12457 There's nothing situate under heaven's eye
12458 But hath his bound in earth in sea in sky
12459 The beasts the fishes and the winged fowls
12460 Are their males subjects and at their controls
12461 Man more divine the master of all these
12462 Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas
12463 Indu'd with intellectual sense and souls
12464 Of more preeminence than fish and fowls
12465 Are masters to their females and their lords
12466 Then let your will attend on their accords
12467 ADRIANA This servitude makes you to keep unwed
12468 LUCIANA Not this but troubles of the marriagebed
12469 ADRIANA But were you wedded you would bear some sway
12470 LUCIANA Ere I learn love I'll practise to obey
12471 ADRIANA How if your husband start some other where
12472 LUCIANA Till he come home again I would forbear
12473 ADRIANA Patience unmov'd no marvel though she pause
12474 They can be meek that have no other cause
12475 A wretched soul bruis'd with adversity
12476 We bid be quiet when we hear it cry
12477 But were we burd'ned with like weight of pain
12478 As much or more we should ourselves complain
12479 So thou that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee
12480 With urging helpless patience would relieve me
12481 But if thou live to see like right bereft
12482 This foolbegg'd patience in thee will be left
12483 LUCIANA Well I will marry one day but to try
12484 Here comes your man now is your husband nigh
12485 Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS
12486 ADRIANA Say is your tardy master now at hand
12487 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Nay he's at two hands with me and that my two
12488 ears can witness
12489 ADRIANA Say didst thou speak with him Know'st thou his mind
12490 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Ay ay he told his mind upon mine ear
12491 Beshrew his hand I scarce could understand it
12492 LUCIANA Spake he so doubtfully thou could'st not feel his meaning
12493 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Nay he struck so plainly I could to
12494 well feel his blows and withal so doubtfully that I could
12495 scarce understand them
12496 ADRIANA But say I prithee is he coming home
12497 It seems he hath great care to please his wife
12498 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Why mistress sure my master is hornmad
12499 ADRIANA Hornmad thou villain
12500 DROMIO OF EPHESUS I mean not cuckoldmad
12501 But sure he is stark mad
12502 When I desir'd him to come home to dinner
12503 He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold
12504 Tis dinner time quoth I 'My gold quoth he
12505 'Your meat doth burn quoth I 'My gold quoth he
12506 'Will you come home quoth I 'My gold quoth he
12507 'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee villain'
12508 'The pig quoth I 'is burn'd 'My gold quoth he
12509 'My mistress sir quoth I 'Hang up thy mistress
12510 I know not thy mistress out on thy mistress'
12511 LUCIANA Quoth who
12512 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Quoth my master
12513 'I know quoth he 'no house no wife no mistress'
12514 So that my errand due unto my tongue
12515 I thank him I bare home upon my shoulders
12516 For in conclusion he did beat me there
12517 ADRIANA Go back again thou slave and fetch him home
12518 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Go back again and be new beaten home
12519 For God's sake send some other messenger
12520 ADRIANA Back slave or I will break thy pate across
12521 DROMIO OF EPHESUS And he will bless that cross with other beating
12522 Between you I shall have a holy head
12523 ADRIANA Hence prating peasant Fetch thy master home
12524 DROMIO OF EPHESUS Am I so round with you as you with me
12525 That like a football you do spurn me thus
12526 You spurn me hence and he will spurn me hither
12527 If I last in this service you must case me in leather
12528 <Exit
12529 LUCIANA Fie how impatience loureth in your face
12530 ADRIANA His company must do his minions grace
12531 Whilst I at home starve for a merry look
12532 Hath homely age th alluring beauty took
12533 From my poor cheek Then he hath wasted it
12534 Are my discourses dull Barren my wit
12535 If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd
12536 Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard
12537 Do their gay vestments his affections bait
12538 That's not my fault he's master of my state
12539 What ruins are in me that can be found
12540 By him not ruin'd Then is he the ground
12541 Of my defeatures My decayed fair
12542 A sunny look of his would soon repair
12543 But too unruly deer he breaks the pale
12544 And feeds from home poor I am but his stale
12545 LUCIANA Selfharming jealousy fie beat it hence
12546 ADRIANA Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense
12547 I know his eye doth homage otherwhere
12548 Or else what lets it but he would be here
12549 Sister you know he promis'd me a chain
12550 Would that alone a love he would detain
12551 So he would keep fair quarter with his bed
12552 I see the jewel best enamelled
12553 Will lose his beauty yet the gold bides still
12554 That others touch and often touching will
12555 Where gold and no man that hath a name
12556 By falsehood and corruption doth it shame
12557 Since that my beauty cannot please his eye
12558 I'll weep what's left away and weeping die
12559 LUCIANA How many fond fools serve mad jealousy
12560 <Exeunt
12561 SCENE 2
12562 The mart
12563 Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
12564 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up
12565 Safe at the Centaur and the heedful slave
12566 Is wand'red forth in care to seek me out
12567 By computation and mine host's report
12568 I could not speak with Dromio since at first
12569 I sent him from the mart See here he comes
12570 Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
12571 How now sir is your merry humour alter'd
12572 As you love strokes so jest with me again
12573 You know no Centaur You receiv'd no gold
12574 Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner
12575 My house was at the Phoenix Wast thou mad
12576 That thus so madly thou didst answer me
12577 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE What answer sir When spake I such a word
12578 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Even now even here not half an hour since
12579 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE I did not see you since you sent me hence
12580 Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me
12581 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Villain thou didst deny the gold's receipt
12582 And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner
12583 For which I hope thou felt'st I was displeas'd
12584 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE I am glad to see you in this merry vein
12585 What means this jest I pray you master tell me
12586 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Yea dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth
12587 Think'st thou I jest Hold take thou that and that
12588 [Beating him]
12589 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Hold sir for God's sake Now your jest is earnest
12590 Upon what bargain do you give it me
12591 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Because that I familiarly sometimes
12592 Do use you for my fool and chat with you
12593 Your sauciness will jest upon my love
12594 And make a common of my serious hours
12595 When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport
12596 But creep in crannies when he hides his beams
12597 If you will jest with me know my aspect
12598 And fashion your demeanour to my looks
12599 Or I will beat this method in your sconce
12600 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Sconce call you it So you would
12601 leave battering I had rather have it a head An you use
12602 these blows long I must get a sconce for my head and
12603 insconce it too or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders
12604 But I pray sir why am I beaten
12605 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Dost thou not know
12606 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Nothing sir but that I am beaten
12607 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Shall I tell you why
12608 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Ay sir and wherefore for they say
12609 every why hath a wherefore
12610 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Why first for flouting me and then wherefore
12611 For urging it the second time to me
12612 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season
12613 When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason
12614 Well sir I thank you
12615 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Thank me sir for what
12616 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Marry sir for this something that you gave
12617 me for nothing
12618 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE I'll make you amends next to
12619 give you nothing for something But say sir is it dinnertime
12620 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE No sir I think the meat wants that I have
12621 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE In good time sir what's that
12622 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Basting
12623 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Well sir then 'twill be dry
12624 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE If it be sir I pray you eat none of it
12625 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Your reason
12626 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Lest it make you choleric and purchase me
12627 another dry basting
12628 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Well sir learn to jest in good time
12629 there's a time for all things
12630 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE I durst have denied that before you
12631 were so choleric
12632 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE By what rule sir
12633 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Marry sir by a rule as plain as the
12634 plain bald pate of Father Time himself
12635 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Let's hear it
12636 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE There's no time for a man to recover
12637 his hair that grows bald by nature
12638 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE May he not do it by fine and recovery
12639 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Yes to pay a fine for a periwig and
12640 recover the lost hair of another man
12641 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Why is Time such a niggard of
12642 hair being as it is so plentiful an excrement
12643 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Because it is a blessing that he bestows
12644 on beasts and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath
12645 given them in wit
12646 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Why but there's many a man
12647 hath more hair than wit
12648 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Not a man of those but he hath the
12649 wit to lose his hair
12650 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Why thou didst conclude hairy
12651 men plain dealers without wit
12652 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE The plainer dealer the sooner lost
12653 yet he loseth it in a kind of jollity
12654 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE For what reason
12655 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE For two and sound ones too
12656 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Nay not sound I pray you
12657 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Sure ones then
12658 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Nay not sure in a thing falsing
12659 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Certain ones then
12660 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Name them
12661 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE The one to save the money that he spends in
12662 tiring the other that at dinner they should not drop in his
12663 porridge
12664 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE You would all this time have prov'd there
12665 is no time for all things
12666 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Marry and did sir namely no time to recover
12667 hair lost by nature
12668 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE But your reason was not substantial why
12669 there is no time to recover
12670 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Thus I mend it Time himself is bald
12671 and therefore to the world's end will have bald followers
12672 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE I knew 't'would be a bald conclusion But
12673 soft who wafts us yonder
12674 Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA
12675 ADRIANA Ay ay Antipholus look strange and frown
12676 Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects
12677 I am not Adriana nor thy wife
12678 The time was once when thou unurg'd wouldst vow
12679 That never words were music to thine ear
12680 That never object pleasing in thine eye
12681 That never touch well welcome to thy hand
12682 That never meat sweetsavour'd in thy taste
12683 Unless I spake or look'd or touch'd or carv'd to thee
12684 How comes it now my husband O how comes it
12685 That thou art then estranged from thyself
12686 Thyself I call it being strange to me
12687 That undividable incorporate
12688 Am better than thy dear self's better part
12689 Ah do not tear away thyself from me
12690 For know my love as easy mayst thou fall
12691 A drop of water in the breaking gulf
12692 And take unmingled thence that drop again
12693 Without addition or diminishing
12694 As take from me thyself and not me too
12695 How dearly would it touch thee to the quick
12696 Should'st thou but hear I were licentious
12697 And that this body consecrate to thee
12698 By ruffian lust should be contaminate
12699 Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me
12700 And hurl the name of husband in my face
12701 And tear the stain'd skin off my harlotbrow
12702 And from my false hand cut the weddingring
12703 And break it with a deepdivorcing vow
12704 I know thou canst and therefore see thou do it
12705 I am possess'd with an adulterate blot
12706 My blood is mingled with the crime of lust
12707 For if we two be one and thou play false
12708 I do digest the poison of thy flesh
12709 Being strumpeted by thy contagion
12710 Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed
12711 I live disstain'd thou undishonoured
12712 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Plead you to me fair dame I know you not
12713 In Ephesus I am but two hours old
12714 As strange unto your town as to your talk
12715 Who every word by all my wit being scann'd
12716 Wants wit in all one word to understand
12717 LUCIANA Fie brother how the world is chang'd with you
12718 When were you wont to use my sister thus
12719 She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner
12720 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE By Dromio
12721 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE By me
12722 ADRIANA By thee and this thou didst return from him
12723 That he did buffet thee and in his blows
12724 Denied my house for his me for his wife
12725 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Did you converse sir with this gentlewoman
12726 What is the course and drift of your compact
12727 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE I Sir I never saw her till this time
12728 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Villain thou liest for even her very words
12729 Didst thou deliver to me on the mart
12730 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE I never spake with her in all my life
12731 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE How can she thus then call us by our names
12732 Unless it be by inspiration
12733 ADRIANA How ill agrees it with your gravity
12734 To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave
12735 Abetting him to thwart me in my mood
12736 Be it my wrong you are from me exempt
12737 But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt
12738 Come I will fasten on this sleeve of thine
12739 Thou art an elm my husband I a vine
12740 Whose weakness married to thy stronger state
12741 Makes me with thy strength to communicate
12742 If aught possess thee from me it is dross
12743 Usurping ivy brier or idle moss
12744 Who all for want of pruning with intrusion
12745 Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion
12746 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE To me she speaks she moves me for her theme
12747 What was I married to her in my dream
12748 Or sleep I now and think I hear all this
12749 What error drives our eyes and ears amiss
12750 Until I know this sure uncertainty
12751 I'll entertain the offer'd fallacy
12752 LUCIANA Dromio go bid the servants spread for dinner
12753 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE O for my beads I cross me for sinner
12754 This is the fairy land O spite of spites
12755 We talk with goblins owls and sprites
12756 If we obey them not this will ensue
12757 They'll suck our breath or pinch us black and blue
12758 LUCIANA Why prat'st thou to thyself and answer'st not
12759 Dromio thou drone thou snail thou slug thou sot
12760 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE I am transformed master am not I
12761 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE I think thou art in mind and so am I
12762 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Nay master both in mind and in my shape
12763 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Thou hast thine own form
12764 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE No I am an ape
12765 LUCIANA If thou art chang'd to aught 'tis to an ass
12766 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE 'Tis true she rides me and I long for grass
12767 'Tis so I am an ass else it could never be
12768 But I should know her as well as she knows me
12769 ADRIANA Come come no longer will I be a fool
12770 To put the finger in the eye and weep
12771 Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn
12772 Come sir to dinner Dromio keep the gate
12773 Husband I'll dine above with you today
12774 And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks
12775 Sirrah if any ask you for your master
12776 Say he dines forth and let no creature enter
12777 Come sister Dromio play the porter well
12778 ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Am I in earth in heaven or in hell
12779 Sleeping or waking mad or welladvis'd
12780 Known unto these and to myself disguis'd
12781 I'll say as they say and persever so
12782 And in this mist at all adventures go
12783 DROMIO OF SYRACUSE Master shall I be porter at the gate
12784 ADRIANA Ay and let none enter lest I break your pate
12785 LUCIANA Come come Antipholus we dine too late
12786 <Exeunt
