14128 SCENE
14129 Rome and the neighbourhood Corioli and the neighbourhood Antium
14130 ACT I SCENE I
14131 Rome A street
14132 Enter a company of mutinous citizens with staves clubs and other weapons
14133 FIRST CITIZEN Before we proceed any further hear me speak
14134 ALL Speak speak
14135 FIRST CITIZEN YOU are all resolv'd rather to die than to famish
14136 ALL Resolv'd resolv'd
14137 FIRST CITIZEN First you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the
14138 people
14139 ALL We know't we know't
14140 FIRST CITIZEN Let us kill him and we'll have corn at our own
14141 price Is't a verdict
14142 ALL No more talking on't let it be done Away away
14143 SECOND CITIZEN One word good citizens
14144 FIRST CITIZEN We are accounted poor citizens the patricians good
14145 What authority surfeits on would relieve us if they would yield
14146 us but the superfluity while it were wholesome we might guess
14147 they relieved us humanely but they think we are too dear The
14148 leanness that afflicts us the object of our misery is as an
14149 inventory to particularize their abundance our sufferance is a
14150 gain to them Let us revenge this with our pikes ere we become
14151 rakes for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread not in
14152 thirst for revenge
14153 SECOND CITIZEN Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius
14154 FIRST CITIZEN Against him first he's a very dog to the
14155 commonalty
14156 SECOND CITIZEN Consider you what services he has done for his
14157 country
14158 FIRST CITIZEN Very well and could be content to give him good
14159 report for't but that he pays himself with being proud
14160 SECOND CITIZEN Nay but speak not maliciously
14161 FIRST CITIZEN I say unto you what he hath done famously he did it
14162 to that end though softconscienc'd men can be content to say it
14163 was for his country he did it to please his mother and to be
14164 partly proud which he is even to the altitude of his virtue
14165 SECOND CITIZEN What he cannot help in his nature you account a
14166 vice in him You must in no way say he is covetous
14167 FIRST CITIZEN If I must not I need not be barren of accusations
14168 he hath faults with surplus to tire in repetition [Shouts
14169 within] What shouts are these The other side o th city is
14170 risen Why stay we prating here To th Capitol
14171 ALL Come come
14172 FIRST CITIZEN Soft who comes here
14173 Enter MENENIUS AGRIPPA
14174 SECOND CITIZEN Worthy Menenius Agrippa one that hath always lov'd
14175 the people
14176 FIRST CITIZEN He's one honest enough would all the rest were so
14177 MENENIUS What work's my countrymen in hand Where go you
14178 With bats and clubs The matter Speak I pray you
14179 FIRST CITIZEN Our business is not unknown to th Senate they have
14180 had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do which now we'll
14181 show 'em in deeds They say poor suitors have strong breaths
14182 they shall know we have strong arms too
14183 MENENIUS Why masters my good friends mine honest neighbours
14184 Will you undo yourselves
14185 FIRST CITIZEN We cannot sir we are undone already
14186 MENENIUS I tell you friends most charitable care
14187 Have the patricians of you For your wants
14188 Your suffering in this dearth you may as well
14189 Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
14190 Against the Roman state whose course will on
14191 The way it takes cracking ten thousand curbs
14192 Of more strong link asunder than can ever
14193 Appear in your impediment For the dearth
14194 The gods not the patricians make it and
14195 Your knees to them not arms must help Alack
14196 You are transported by calamity
14197 Thither where more attends you and you slander
14198 The helms o th state who care for you like fathers
14199 When you curse them as enemies
14200 FIRST CITIZEN Care for us True indeed They ne'er car'd for us
14201 yet Suffer us to famish and their storehouses cramm'd with
14202 grain make edicts for usury to support usurers repeal daily
14203 any wholesome act established against the rich and provide more
14204 piercing statutes daily to chain up and restrain the poor If the
14205 wars eat us not up they will and there's all the love they bear
14206 us
14207 MENENIUS Either you must
14208 Confess yourselves wondrous malicious
14209 Or be accus'd of folly I shall tell you
14210 A pretty tale It may be you have heard it
14211 But since it serves my purpose I will venture
14212 To stale't a little more
14213 FIRST CITIZEN Well I'll hear it sir yet you must not think to
14214 fob off our disgrace with a tale But an't please you deliver
14215 MENENIUS There was a time when all the body's members
14216 Rebell'd against the belly thus accus'd it
14217 That only like a gulf it did remain
14218 I th midst o th body idle and unactive
14219 Still cupboarding the viand never bearing
14220 Like labour with the rest where th other instruments
14221 Did see and hear devise instruct walk feel
14222 And mutually participate did minister
14223 Unto the appetite and affection common
14224 Of the whole body The belly answer'd
14225 FIRST CITIZEN Well sir what answer made the belly
14226 MENENIUS Sir I shall tell you With a kind of smile
14227 Which ne'er came from the lungs but even thus
14228 For look you I may make the belly smile
14229 As well as speak it tauntingly replied
14230 To th discontented members the mutinous parts
14231 That envied his receipt even so most fitly
14232 As you malign our senators for that
14233 They are not such as you
14234 FIRST CITIZEN Your belly's answer What
14235 The kingly crowned head the vigilant eye
14236 The counsellor heart the arm our soldier
14237 Our steed the leg the tongue our trumpeter
14238 With other muniments and petty helps
14239 Is this our fabric if that they
14240 MENENIUS What then
14241 Fore me this fellow speaks What then What then
14242 FIRST CITIZEN Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd
14243 Who is the sink o th body
14244 MENENIUS Well what then
14245 FIRST CITIZEN The former agents if they did complain
14246 What could the belly answer
14247 MENENIUS I will tell you
14248 If you'll bestow a small of what you have little
14249 Patience awhile you'st hear the belly's answer
14250 FIRST CITIZEN Y'are long about it
14251 MENENIUS Note me this good friend
14252 Your most grave belly was deliberate
14253 Not rash like his accusers and thus answered
14254 'True is it my incorporate friends quoth he
14255 'That I receive the general food at first
14256 Which you do live upon and fit it is
14257 Because I am the storehouse and the shop
14258 Of the whole body But if you do remember
14259 I send it through the rivers of your blood
14260 Even to the court the heart to th seat o th brain
14261 And through the cranks and offices of man
14262 The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
14263 From me receive that natural competency
14264 Whereby they live And though that all at once
14265 You my good friends this says the belly mark me
14266 FIRST CITIZEN Ay sir well well
14267 MENENIUS 'Though all at once cannot
14268 See what I do deliver out to each
14269 Yet I can make my audit up that all
14270 From me do back receive the flour of all
14271 And leave me but the bran What say you to t
14272 FIRST CITIZEN It was an answer How apply you this
14273 MENENIUS The senators of Rome are this good belly
14274 And you the mutinous members for examine
14275 Their counsels and their cares digest things rightly
14276 Touching the weal o th common you shall find
14277 No public benefit which you receive
14278 But it proceeds or comes from them to you
14279 And no way from yourselves What do you think
14280 You the great toe of this assembly
14281 FIRST CITIZEN I the great toe Why the great toe
14282 MENENIUS For that being one o th lowest basest poorest
14283 Of this most wise rebellion thou goest foremost
14284 Thou rascal that art worst in blood to run
14285 Lead'st first to win some vantage
14286 But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs
14287 Rome and her rats are at the point of battle
14288 The one side must have bale
14289 Enter CAIUS MARCIUS
14290 Hail noble Marcius
14291 MARCIUS Thanks What's the matter you dissentious rogues
14292 That rubbing the poor itch of your opinion
14293 Make yourselves scabs
14294 FIRST CITIZEN We have ever your good word
14295 MARCIUS He that will give good words to thee will flatter
14296 Beneath abhorring What would you have you curs
14297 That like nor peace nor war The one affrights you
14298 The other makes you proud He that trusts to you
14299 Where he should find you lions finds you hares
14300 Where foxes geese you are no surer no
14301 Than is the coal of fire upon the ice
14302 Or hailstone in the sun Your virtue is
14303 To make him worthy whose offence subdues him
14304 And curse that justice did it Who deserves greatness
14305 Deserves your hate and your affections are
14306 A sick man's appetite who desires most that
14307 Which would increase his evil He that depends
14308 Upon your favours swims with fins of lead
14309 And hews down oaks with rushes Hang ye Trust ye
14310 With every minute you do change a mind
14311 And call him noble that was now your hate
14312 Him vile that was your garland What's the matter
14313 That in these several places of the city
14314 You cry against the noble Senate who
14315 Under the gods keep you in awe which else
14316 Would feed on one another What's their seeking
14317 MENENIUS For corn at their own rates whereof they say
14318 The city is well stor'd
14319 MARCIUS Hang 'em They say
14320 They'll sit by th fire and presume to know
14321 What's done i th Capitol who's like to rise
14322 Who thrives and who declines side factions and give out
14323 Conjectural marriages making parties strong
14324 And feebling such as stand not in their liking
14325 Below their cobbled shoes They say there's grain enough
14326 Would the nobility lay aside their ruth
14327 And let me use my sword I'd make a quarry
14328 With thousands of these quarter'd slaves as high
14329 As I could pick my lance
14330 MENENIUS Nay these are almost thoroughly persuaded
14331 For though abundantly they lack discretion
14332 Yet are they passing cowardly But I beseech you
14333 What says the other troop
14334 MARCIUS They are dissolv'd Hang 'em
14335 They said they were anhungry sigh'd forth proverbs
14336 That hunger broke stone walls that dogs must eat
14337 That meat was made for mouths that the gods sent not
14338 Corn for the rich men only With these shreds
14339 They vented their complainings which being answer'd
14340 And a petition granted them a strange one
14341 To break the heart of generosity
14342 And make bold power look pale they threw their caps
14343 As they would hang them on the horns o th moon
14344 Shouting their emulation
14345 MENENIUS What is granted them
14346 MARCIUS Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms
14347 Of their own choice One's Junius Brutus
14348 Sicinius Velutus and I know not 'Sdeath
14349 The rabble should have first unroof'd the city
14350 Ere so prevail'd with me it will in time
14351 Win upon power and throw forth greater themes
14352 For insurrection's arguing
14353 MENENIUS This is strange
14354 MARCIUS Go get you home you fragments
14355 Enter a MESSENGER hastily
14356 MESSENGER Where's Caius Marcius
14357 MARCIUS Here What's the matter
14358 MESSENGER The news is sir the Volsces are in arms
14359 MARCIUS I am glad on't then we shall ha means to vent
14360 Our musty superfluity See our best elders
14361 Enter COMINIUS TITUS LARTIUS with other SENATORS
14362 JUNIUS BRUTUS and SICINIUS VELUTUS
14363 FIRST SENATOR Marcius 'tis true that you have lately told us
14364 The Volsces are in arms
14365 MARCIUS They have a leader
14366 Tullus Aufidius that will put you to't
14367 I sin in envying his nobility
14368 And were I anything but what I am
14369 I would wish me only he
14370 COMINIUS You have fought together
14371 MARCIUS Were half to half the world by th ears and he
14372 Upon my party I'd revolt to make
14373 Only my wars with him He is a lion
14374 That I am proud to hunt
14375 FIRST SENATOR Then worthy Marcius
14376 Attend upon Cominius to these wars
14377 COMINIUS It is your former promise
14378 MARCIUS Sir it is
14379 And I am constant Titus Lartius thou
14380 Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus face
14381 What art thou stiff Stand'st out
14382 LARTIUS No Caius Marcius
14383 I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other
14384 Ere stay behind this business
14385 MENENIUS O true bred
14386 FIRST SENATOR Your company to th Capitol where I know
14387 Our greatest friends attend us
14388 LARTIUS [To COMINIUS] Lead you on
14389 [To MARCIUS] Follow Cominius we must follow you
14390 Right worthy you priority
14391 COMINIUS Noble Marcius
14392 FIRST SENATOR [To the Citizens] Hence to your homes be gone
14393 MARCIUS Nay let them follow
14394 The Volsces have much corn take these rats thither
14395 To gnaw their garners Worshipful mutineers
14396 Your valour puts well forth pray follow
14397 Ciitzens steal away Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS
14398 SICINIUS Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius
14399 BRUTUS He has no equal
14400 SICINIUS When we were chosen tribunes for the people
14401 BRUTUS Mark'd you his lip and eyes
14402 SICINIUS Nay but his taunts
14403 BRUTUS Being mov'd he will not spare to gird the gods
14404 SICINIUS Bemock the modest moon
14405 BRUTUS The present wars devour him He is grown
14406 Too proud to be so valiant
14407 SICINIUS Such a nature
14408 Tickled with good success disdains the shadow
14409 Which he treads on at noon But I do wonder
14410 His insolence can brook to be commanded
14411 Under Cominius
14412 BRUTUS Fame at the which he aims
14413 In whom already he is well grac'd cannot
14414 Better be held nor more attain'd than by
14415 A place below the first for what miscarries
14416 Shall be the general's fault though he perform
14417 To th utmost of a man and giddy censure
14418 Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he
14419 Had borne the business'
14420 SICINIUS Besides if things go well
14421 Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall
14422 Of his demerits rob Cominius
14423 BRUTUS Come
14424 Half all Cominius honours are to Marcius
14425 Though Marcius earn'd them not and all his faults
14426 To Marcius shall be honours though indeed
14427 In aught he merit not
14428 SICINIUS Let's hence and hear
14429 How the dispatch is made and in what fashion
14430 More than his singularity he goes
14431 Upon this present action
14432 BRUTUS Let's along Exeunt
14433 SCENE II
14434 Corioli The Senate House
14435 Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS with SENATORS of Corioli
14436 FIRST SENATOR So your opinion is Aufidius
14437 That they of Rome are ent'red in our counsels
14438 And know how we proceed
14439 AUFIDIUS Is it not yours
14440 What ever have been thought on in this state
14441 That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome
14442 Had circumvention 'Tis not four days gone
14443 Since I heard thence these are the words I think
14444 I have the letter hereyes here it is
14445 [Reads] 'They have press'd a power but it is not known
14446 Whether for east or west The dearth is great
14447 The people mutinous and it is rumour'd
14448 Cominius Marcius your old enemy
14449 Who is of Rome worse hated than of you
14450 And Titus Lartius a most valiant Roman
14451 These three lead on this preparation
14452 Whither 'tis bent Most likely 'tis for you
14453 Consider of it'
14454 FIRST SENATOR Our army's in the field
14455 We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
14456 To answer us
14457 AUFIDIUS Nor did you think it folly
14458 To keep your great pretences veil'd till when
14459 They needs must show themselves which in the hatching
14460 It seem'd appear'd to Rome By the discovery
14461 We shall be short'ned in our aim which was
14462 To take in many towns ere almost Rome
14463 Should know we were afoot
14464 SECOND SENATOR Noble Aufidius
14465 Take your commission hie you to your bands
14466 Let us alone to guard Corioli
14467 If they set down before's for the remove
14468 Bring up your army but I think you'll find
14469 Th have not prepar'd for us
14470 AUFIDIUS O doubt not that
14471 I speak from certainties Nay more
14472 Some parcels of their power are forth already
14473 And only hitherward I leave your honours
14474 If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet
14475 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike
14476 Till one can do no more
14477 ALL The gods assist you
14478 AUFIDIUS And keep your honours safe
14479 FIRST SENATOR Farewell
14480 SECOND SENATOR Farewell
14481 ALL Farewell Exeunt
14482 SCENE III
14483 Rome MARCIUS house
14484 Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA mother and wife to MARCIUS
14485 they set them down on two low stools and sew
14486 VOLUMNIA I pray you daughter sing or express yourself in a more
14487 comfortable sort If my son were my husband I should freelier
14488 rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the
14489 embracements of his bed where he would show most love When yet
14490 he was but tenderbodied and the only son of my womb when youth
14491 with comeliness pluck'd all gaze his way when for a day of
14492 kings entreaties a mother should not sell him an hour from her
14493 beholding I considering how honour would become such a person
14494 that it was no better than picturelike to hang by th wall if
14495 renown made it not stir was pleas'd to let him seek danger where
14496 he was to find fame To a cruel war I sent him from whence he
14497 return'd his brows bound with oak I tell thee daughter I
14498 sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a manchild than
14499 now in first seeing he had proved himself a man
14500 VIRGILIA But had he died in the business madam how then
14501 VOLUMNIA Then his good report should have been my son I therein
14502 would have found issue Hear me profess sincerely had I a dozen
14503 sons each in my love alike and none less dear than thine and my
14504 good Marcius I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country
14505 than one voluptuously surfeit out of action
14506 Enter a GENTLEWOMAN
14507 GENTLEWOMAN Madam the Lady Valeria is come to visit you
14508 VIRGILIA Beseech you give me leave to retire myself
14509 VOLUMNIA Indeed you shall not
14510 Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum
14511 See him pluck Aufidius down by th hair
14512 As children from a bear the Volsces shunning him
14513 Methinks I see him stamp thus and call thus
14514 'Come on you cowards You were got in fear
14515 Though you were born in Rome His bloody brow
14516 With his mail'd hand then wiping forth he goes
14517 Like to a harvestman that's task'd to mow
14518 Or all or lose his hire
14519 VIRGILIA His bloody brow O Jupiter no blood
14520 VOLUMNIA Away you fool It more becomes a man
14521 Than gilt his trophy The breasts of Hecuba
14522 When she did suckle Hector look'd not lovelier
14523 Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood
14524 At Grecian sword contemning Tell Valeria
14525 We are fit to bid her welcome Exit GENTLEWOMAN
14526 VIRGILIA Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius
14527 VOLUMNIA He'll beat Aufidius head below his knee
14528 And tread upon his neck
14529 Reenter GENTLEWOMAN With VALERIA and an usher
14530 VALERIA My ladies both good day to you
14531 VOLUMNIA Sweet madam
14532 VIRGILIA I am glad to see your ladyship
14533 VALERIA How do you both You are manifest housekeepers What are
14534 you sewing here A fine spot in good faith How does your little
14535 son
14536 VIRGILIA I thank your ladyship well good madam
14537 VOLUMNIA He had rather see the swords and hear a drum than look
14538 upon his schoolmaster
14539 VALERIA O my word the father's son I'll swear 'tis a very
14540 pretty boy O my troth I look'd upon him a Wednesday half an
14541 hour together has such a confirm'd countenance I saw him run
14542 after a gilded butterfly and when he caught it he let it go
14543 again and after it again and over and over he comes and up
14544 again catch'd it again or whether his fall enrag'd him or how
14545 'twas he did so set his teeth and tear it O I warrant how he
14546 mammock'd it
14547 VOLUMNIA One on's father's moods
14548 VALERIA Indeed la 'tis a noble child
14549 VIRGILIA A crack madam
14550 VALERIA Come lay aside your stitchery I must have you play the
14551 idle huswife with me this afternoon
14552 VIRGILIA No good madam I will not out of doors
14553 VALERIA Not out of doors
14554 VOLUMNIA She shall she shall
14555 VIRGILIA Indeed no by your patience I'll not over the threshold
14556 till my lord return from the wars
14557 VALERIA Fie you confine yourself most unreasonably come you
14558 must go visit the good lady that lies in
14559 VIRGILIA I will wish her speedy strength and visit her with my
14560 prayers but I cannot go thither
14561 VOLUMNIA Why I pray you
14562 VIRGILIA 'Tis not to save labour nor that I want love
14563 VALERIA You would be another Penelope yet they say all the yarn
14564 she spun in Ulysses absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths
14565 Come I would your cambric were sensible as your finger that you
14566 might leave pricking it for pity Come you shall go with us
14567 VIRGILIA No good madam pardon me indeed I will not forth
14568 VALERIA In truth la go with me and I'll tell you excellent news
14569 of your husband
14570 VIRGILIA O good madam there can be none yet
14571 VALERIA Verily I do not jest with you there came news from him
14572 last night
14573 VIRGILIA Indeed madam
14574 VALERIA In earnest it's true I heard a senator speak it Thus it
14575 is the Volsces have an army forth against whom Cominius the
14576 general is gone with one part of our Roman power Your lord and
14577 Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioli they
14578 nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars This is true
14579 on mine honour and so I pray go with us
14580 VIRGILIA Give me excuse good madam I will obey you in everything
14581 hereafter
14582 VOLUMNIA Let her alone lady as she is now she will but disease
14583 our better mirth
14584 VALERIA In troth I think she would Fare you well then Come
14585 good sweet lady Prithee Virgilia turn thy solemness out o'
14586 door and go along with us
14587 VIRGILIA No at a word madam indeed I must not I wish you much
14588 mirth
14589 VALERIA Well then farewell Exeunt
14590 SCENE IV
14591 Before Corioli
14592 Enter MARCIUS TITUS LARTIUS with drum and colours
14593 with CAPTAINS and soldiers To them a MESSENGER
14594 MARCIUS Yonder comes news a wager they have met
14595 LARTIUS My horse to yours no
14596 MARCIUS 'Tis done
14597 LARTIUS Agreed
14598 MARCIUS Say has our general met the enemy
14599 MESSENGER They lie in view but have not spoke as yet
14600 LARTIUS So the good horse is mine
14601 MARCIUS I'll buy him of you
14602 LARTIUS No I'll nor sell nor give him lend you him I will
14603 For half a hundred years Summon the town
14604 MARCIUS How far off lie these armies
14605 MESSENGER Within this mile and half
14606 MARCIUS Then shall we hear their 'larum and they ours
14607 Now Mars I prithee make us quick in work
14608 That we with smoking swords may march from hence
14609 To help our fielded friends Come blow thy blast
14610 They sound a parley Enter two SENATORS with others
14611 on the walls of Corioli
14612 Tullus Aufidius is he within your walls
14613 FIRST SENATOR No nor a man that fears you less than he
14614 That's lesser than a little [Drum afar off] Hark our drums
14615 Are bringing forth our youth We'll break our walls
14616 Rather than they shall pound us up our gates
14617 Which yet seem shut we have but pinn'd with rushes
14618 They'll open of themselves [Alarum far off] Hark you far off
14619 There is Aufidius List what work he makes
14620 Amongst your cloven army
14621 MARCIUS O they are at it
14622 LARTIUS Their noise be our instruction Ladders ho
14623 Enter the army of the Volsces
14624 MARCIUS They fear us not but issue forth their city
14625 Now put your shields before your hearts and fight
14626 With hearts more proof than shields Advance brave Titus
14627 They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts
14628 Which makes me sweat with wrath Come on my fellows
14629 He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce
14630 And he shall feel mine edge
14631 Alarum The Romans are beat back to their trenches
14632 Reenter MARCIUS cursing
14633 MARCIUS All the contagion of the south light on you
14634 You shames of Rome you herd of Boils and plagues
14635 Plaster you o'er that you may be abhorr'd
14636 Farther than seen and one infect another
14637 Against the wind a mile You souls of geese
14638 That bear the shapes of men how have you run
14639 From slaves that apes would beat Pluto and hell
14640 All hurt behind Backs red and faces pale
14641 With flight and agued fear Mend and charge home
14642 Or by the fires of heaven I'll leave the foe
14643 And make my wars on you Look to't Come on
14644 If you'll stand fast we'll beat them to their wives
14645 As they us to our trenches Follow me
14646 Another alarum The Volsces fly and MARCIUS follows
14647 them to the gates
14648 So now the gates are ope now prove good seconds
14649 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them
14650 Not for the fliers Mark me and do the like
14651 [MARCIUS enters the gates]
14652 FIRST SOLDIER Foolhardiness not I
14653 SECOND SOLDIER Not I [MARCIUS is shut in]
14654 FIRST SOLDIER See they have shut him in
14655 ALL To th pot I warrant him [Alarum continues]
14656 Reenter TITUS LARTIUS
14657 LARTIUS What is become of Marcius
14658 ALL Slain sir doubtless
14659 FIRST SOLDIER Following the fliers at the very heels
14660 With them he enters who upon the sudden
14661 Clapp'd to their gates He is himself alone
14662 To answer all the city
14663 LARTIUS O noble fellow
14664 Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword
14665 And when it bows stand'st up Thou art left Marcius
14666 A carbuncle entire as big as thou art
14667 Were not so rich a jewel Thou wast a soldier
14668 Even to Cato's wish not fierce and terrible
14669 Only in strokes but with thy grim looks and
14670 The thunderlike percussion of thy sounds
14671 Thou mad'st thine enemies shake as if the world
14672 Were feverous and did tremble
14673 Reenter MARCIUS bleeding assaulted by the enemy
14674 FIRST SOLDIER Look sir
14675 LARTIUS O 'tis Marcius
14676 Let's fetch him off or make remain alike
14677 [They fight and all enter the city]
14678 SCENE V
14679 Within Corioli A street
14680 Enter certain Romans with spoils
14681 FIRST ROMAN This will I carry to Rome
14682 SECOND ROMAN And I this
14683 THIRD ROMAN A murrain on 't I took this for silver
14684 [Alarum continues still afar off]
14685 Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS With a trumpeter
14686 MARCIUS See here these movers that do prize their hours
14687 At a crack'd drachma Cushions leaden spoons
14688 Irons of a doit doublets that hangmen would
14689 Bury with those that wore them these base slaves
14690 Ere yet the fight be done pack up Down with them
14691 Exeunt pillagers
14692 And hark what noise the general makes To him
14693 There is the man of my soul's hate Aufidius
14694 Piercing our Romans then valiant Titus take
14695 Convenient numbers to make good the city
14696 Whilst I with those that have the spirit will haste
14697 To help Cominius
14698 LARTIUS Worthy sir thou bleed'st
14699 Thy exercise hath been too violent
14700 For a second course of fight
14701 MARCIUS Sir praise me not
14702 My work hath yet not warm'd me Fare you well
14703 The blood I drop is rather physical
14704 Than dangerous to me To Aufidius thus
14705 I will appear and fight
14706 LARTIUS Now the fair goddess Fortune
14707 Fall deep in love with thee and her great charms
14708 Misguide thy opposers swords Bold gentleman
14709 Prosperity be thy page
14710 MARCIUS Thy friend no less
14711 Than those she placeth highest So farewell
14712 LARTIUS Thou worthiest Marcius Exit MARCIUS
14713 Go sound thy trumpet in the marketplace
14714 Call thither all the officers o th town
14715 Where they shall know our mind Away Exeunt
14716 SCENE VI
14717 Near the camp of COMINIUS
14718 Enter COMINIUS as it were in retire with soldiers
14719 COMINIUS Breathe you my friends Well fought we are come off
14720 Like Romans neither foolish in our stands
14721 Nor cowardly in retire Believe me sirs
14722 We shall be charg'd again Whiles we have struck
14723 By interims and conveying gusts we have heard
14724 The charges of our friends The Roman gods
14725 Lead their successes as we wish our own
14726 That both our powers with smiling fronts encount'ring
14727 May give you thankful sacrifice
14728 Enter A MESSENGER
14729 Thy news
14730 MESSENGER The citizens of Corioli have issued
14731 And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle
14732 I saw our party to their trenches driven
14733 And then I came away
14734 COMINIUS Though thou speak'st truth
14735 Methinks thou speak'st not well How long is't since
14736 MESSENGER Above an hour my lord
14737 COMINIUS 'Tis not a mile briefly we heard their drums
14738 How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour
14739 And bring thy news so late
14740 MESSENGER Spies of the Volsces
14741 Held me in chase that I was forc'd to wheel
14742 Three or four miles about else had I sir
14743 Half an hour since brought my report
14744 Enter MARCIUS
14745 COMINIUS Who's yonder
14746 That does appear as he were flay'd O gods
14747 He has the stamp of Marcius and I have
14748 Beforetime seen him thus
14749 MARCIUS Come I too late
14750 COMINIUS The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor
14751 More than I know the sound of Marcius tongue
14752 From every meaner man
14753 MARCIUS Come I too late
14754 COMINIUS Ay if you come not in the blood of others
14755 But mantled in your own
14756 MARCIUS O let me clip ye
14757 In arms as sound as when I woo'd in heart
14758 As merry as when our nuptial day was done
14759 And tapers burn'd to bedward
14760 COMINIUS Flower of warriors
14761 How is't with Titus Lartius
14762 MARCIUS As with a man busied about decrees
14763 Condemning some to death and some to exile
14764 Ransoming him or pitying threat'ning th other
14765 Holding Corioli in the name of Rome
14766 Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash
14767 To let him slip at will
14768 COMINIUS Where is that slave
14769 Which told me they had beat you to your trenches
14770 Where is he Call him hither
14771 MARCIUS Let him alone
14772 He did inform the truth But for our gentlemen
14773 The common file a plague tribunes for them
14774 The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge
14775 From rascals worse than they
14776 COMINIUS But how prevail'd you
14777 MARCIUS Will the time serve to tell I do not think
14778 Where is the enemy Are you lords o th field
14779 If not why cease you till you are so
14780 COMINIUS Marcius
14781 We have at disadvantage fought and did
14782 Retire to win our purpose
14783 MARCIUS How lies their battle Know you on which side
14784 They have plac'd their men of trust
14785 COMINIUS As I guess Marcius
14786 Their bands i th vaward are the Antiates
14787 Of their best trust o'er them Aufidius
14788 Their very heart of hope
14789 MARCIUS I do beseech you
14790 By all the battles wherein we have fought
14791 By th blood we have shed together by th vows
14792 We have made to endure friends that you directly
14793 Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates
14794 And that you not delay the present but
14795 Filling the air with swords advanc'd and darts
14796 We prove this very hour
14797 COMINIUS Though I could wish
14798 You were conducted to a gentle bath
14799 And balms applied to you yet dare I never
14800 Deny your asking take your choice of those
14801 That best can aid your action
14802 MARCIUS Those are they
14803 That most are willing If any such be here
14804 As it were sin to doubt that love this painting
14805 Wherein you see me smear'd if any fear
14806 Lesser his person than an ill report
14807 If any think brave death outweighs bad life
14808 And that his country's dearer than himself
14809 Let him alone or so many so minded
14810 Wave thus to express his disposition
14811 And follow Marcius [They all shout and wave their
14812 swords take him up in their arms and cast up their caps]
14813 O me alone Make you a sword of me
14814 If these shows be not outward which of you
14815 But is four Volsces None of you but is
14816 Able to bear against the great Aufidius
14817 A shield as hard as his A certain number
14818 Though thanks to all must I select from all the rest
14819 Shall bear the business in some other fight
14820 As cause will be obey'd Please you to march
14821 And four shall quickly draw out my command
14822 Which men are best inclin'd
14823 COMINIUS March on my fellows
14824 Make good this ostentation and you shall
14825 Divide in all with us Exeunt
14826 SCENE VII
14827 The gates of Corioli
14828 TITUS LARTIUS having set a guard upon Corioli going with drum and trumpet
14829 toward COMINIUS and CAIUS MARCIUS enters with a LIEUTENANT other soldiers
14830 and a scout
14831 LARTIUS So let the ports be guarded keep your duties
14832 As I have set them down If I do send dispatch
14833 Those centuries to our aid the rest will serve
14834 For a short holding If we lose the field
14835 We cannot keep the town
14836 LIEUTENANT Fear not our care sir
14837 LARTIUS Hence and shut your gates upon's
14838 Our guider come to th Roman camp conduct us Exeunt
14839 SCENE VIII
14840 A field of battle between the Roman and the Volscian camps
14841 Alarum as in battle Enter MARCIUS and AUFIDIUS at several doors
14842 MARCIUS I'll fight with none but thee for I do hate thee
14843 Worse than a promisebreaker
14844 AUFIDIUS We hate alike
14845 Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
14846 More than thy fame and envy Fix thy foot
14847 MARCIUS Let the first budger die the other's slave
14848 And the gods doom him after
14849 AUFIDIUS If I fly Marcius
14850 Halloa me like a hare
14851 MARCIUS Within these three hours Tullus
14852 Alone I fought in your Corioli walls
14853 And made what work I pleas'd 'Tis not my blood
14854 Wherein thou seest me mask'd For thy revenge
14855 Wrench up thy power to th highest
14856 AUFIDIUS Wert thou the Hector
14857 That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny
14858 Thou shouldst not scape me here
14859 Here they fight and certain Volsces come in the aid
14860 of AUFIDIUS MARCIUS fights till they be driven in
14861 breathless
14862 Officious and not valiant you have sham'd me
14863 In your condemned seconds Exeunt
14864 SCENE IX
14865 The Roman camp
14866 Flourish Alarum A retreat is sounded Enter at one door
14867 COMINIUS with the Romans at another door MARCIUS with his arm in a scarf
14868 COMINIUS If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work
14869 Thou't not believe thy deeds but I'll report it
14870 Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles
14871 Where great patricians shall attend and shrug
14872 I th end admire where ladies shall be frighted
14873 And gladly quak'd hear more where the dull tribunes
14874 That with the fusty plebeians hate thine honours
14875 Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods
14876 Our Rome hath such a soldier'
14877 Yet cam'st thou to a morsel of this feast
14878 Having fully din'd before
14879 Enter TITUS LARTIUS with his power from the pursuit
14880 LARTIUS O General
14881 Here is the steed we the caparison
14882 Hadst thou beheld
14883 MARCIUS Pray now no more my mother
14884 Who has a charter to extol her blood
14885 When she does praise me grieves me I have done
14886 As you have done that's what I can induc'd
14887 As you have been that's for my country
14888 He that has but effected his good will
14889 Hath overta'en mine act
14890 COMINIUS You shall not be
14891 The grave of your deserving Rome must know
14892 The value of her own 'Twere a concealment
14893 Worse than a theft no less than a traducement
14894 To hide your doings and to silence that
14895 Which to the spire and top of praises vouch'd
14896 Would seem but modest Therefore I beseech you
14897 In sign of what you are not to reward
14898 What you have done before our army hear me
14899 MARCIUS I have some wounds upon me and they smart
14900 To hear themselves rememb'red
14901 COMINIUS Should they not
14902 Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude
14903 And tent themselves with death Of all the horses
14904 Whereof we have ta'en good and good store of all
14905 The treasure in this field achiev'd and city
14906 We render you the tenth to be ta'en forth
14907 Before the common distribution at
14908 Your only choice
14909 MARCIUS I thank you General
14910 But cannot make my heart consent to take
14911 A bribe to pay my sword I do refuse it
14912 And stand upon my common part with those
14913 That have beheld the doing
14914 A long flourish They all cry 'Marcius Marcius'
14915 cast up their caps and lances COMINIUS and LARTIUS stand bare
14916 May these same instruments which you profane
14917 Never sound more When drums and trumpets shall
14918 I th field prove flatterers let courts and cities be
14919 Made all of falsefac'd soothing When steel grows
14920 Soft as the parasite's silk let him be made
14921 An overture for th wars No more I say
14922 For that I have not wash'd my nose that bled
14923 Or foil'd some debile wretch which without note
14924 Here's many else have done you shout me forth
14925 In acclamations hyperbolical
14926 As if I lov'd my little should be dieted
14927 In praises sauc'd with lies
14928 COMINIUS Too modest are you
14929 More cruel to your good report than grateful
14930 To us that give you truly By your patience
14931 If 'gainst yourself you be incens'd we'll put you
14932 Like one that means his proper harm in manacles
14933 Then reason safely with you Therefore be it known
14934 As to us to all the world that Caius Marcius
14935 Wears this war's garland in token of the which
14936 My noble steed known to the camp I give him
14937 With all his trim belonging and from this time
14938 For what he did before Corioli can him
14939 With all th applauseand clamour of the host
14940 Caius Marcius Coriolanus
14941 Bear th addition nobly ever
14942 [Flourish Trumpets sound and drums]
14943 ALL Caius Marcius Coriolanus
14944 CORIOLANUS I will go wash
14945 And when my face is fair you shall perceive
14946 Whether I blush or no Howbeit I thank you
14947 I mean to stride your steed and at all times
14948 To undercrest your good addition
14949 To th fairness of my power
14950 COMINIUS So to our tent
14951 Where ere we do repose us we will write
14952 To Rome of our success You Titus Lartius
14953 Must to Corioli back Send us to Rome
14954 The best with whom we may articulate
14955 For their own good and ours
14956 LARTIUS I shall my lord
14957 CORIOLANUS The gods begin to mock me I that now
14958 Refus'd most princely gifts am bound to beg
14959 Of my Lord General
14960 COMINIUS Take't 'tis yours what is't
14961 CORIOLANUS I sometime lay here in Corioli
14962 At a poor man's house he us'd me kindly
14963 He cried to me I saw him prisoner
14964 But then Aufidius was within my view
14965 And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity I request you
14966 To give my poor host freedom
14967 COMINIUS O well begg'd
14968 Were he the butcher of my son he should
14969 Be free as is the wind Deliver him Titus
14970 LARTIUS Marcius his name
14971 CORIOLANUS By Jupiter forgot
14972 I am weary yea my memory is tir'd
14973 Have we no wine here
14974 COMINIUS Go we to our tent
14975 The blood upon your visage dries 'tis time
14976 It should be look'd to Come Exeunt
14977 SCENE X
14978 The camp of the Volsces
14979 A flourish Cornets Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS bloody with two or three soldiers
14980 AUFIDIUS The town is ta'en
14981 FIRST SOLDIER 'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition
14982 AUFIDIUS Condition
14983 I would I were a Roman for I cannot
14984 Being a Volsce be that I am Condition
14985 What good condition can a treaty find
14986 I th part that is at mercy Five times Marcius
14987 I have fought with thee so often hast thou beat me
14988 And wouldst do so I think should we encounter
14989 As often as we eat By th elements
14990 If e'er again I meet him beard to beard
14991 He's mine or I am his Mine emulation
14992 Hath not that honour in't it had for where
14993 I thought to crush him in an equal force
14994 True sword to sword I'll potch at him some way
14995 Or wrath or craft may get him
14996 FIRST SOLDIER He's the devil
14997 AUFIDIUS Bolder though not so subtle My valour's poison'd
14998 With only suff'ring stain by him for him
14999 Shall fly out of itself Nor sleep nor sanctuary
15000 Being naked sick nor fane nor Capitol
15001 The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice
15002 Embarquements all of fury shall lift up
15003 Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst
15004 My hate to Marcius Where I find him were it
15005 At home upon my brother's guard even there
15006 Against the hospitable canon would I
15007 Wash my fierce hand in's heart Go you to th city
15008 Learn how 'tis held and what they are that must
15009 Be hostages for Rome
15010 FIRST SOLDIER Will not you go
15011 AUFIDIUS I am attended at the cypress grove I pray you
15012 'Tis south the city mills bring me word thither
15013 How the world goes that to the pace of it
15014 I may spur on my journey
15015 FIRST SOLDIER I shall sir Exeunt

15020 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
