26831 ACT II Scene I
26832 Rochester An inn yard
26833 Enter a Carrier with a lantern in his hand
26834 1 Car Heighho an it be not four by the day I'll be hang'd
26835 Charles wain is over the new chimney and yet our horse not
26836 pack'd What ostler
26837 Ost [within] Anon anon
26838 1 Car I prithee Tom beat Cut's saddle put a few flocks in the
26839 point Poor jade is wrung in the withers out of all cess
26840 Enter another Carrier
26841 2 Car Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog and that is the
26842 next way to give poor jades the bots This house is turned upside
26843 down since Robin Ostler died
26844 1 Car Poor fellow never joyed since the price of oats rose It
26845 was the death of him
26846 2 Car I think this be the most villanous house in all London road
26847 for fleas I am stung like a tench
26848 1 Car Like a tench I By the mass there is ne'er a king christen
26849 could be better bit than I have been since the first cock
26850 2 Car Why they will allow us ne'er a jordan and then we leak in
26851 your chimney and your chamberlye breeds fleas like a loach
26852 1 Car What ostler come away and be hang'd come away
26853 2 Car I have a gammon of bacon and two razes of ginger to be
26854 delivered as far as Charing Cross
26855 1 Car God's body the turkeys in my pannier are quite starved
26856 What ostler A plague on thee hast thou never an eye in thy
26857 head Canst not hear An 'twere not as good deed as drink to
26858 break the pate on thee I am a very villain Come and be hang'd
26859 Hast no faith in thee
26860 Enter Gadshill
26861 Gads Good morrow carriers What's o'clock
26862 1 Car I think it be two o'clock
26863 Gads I prithee lend me this lantern to see my gelding in the
26864 stable
26865 1 Car Nay by God soft I know a trick worth two of that
26866 i faith
26867 Gads I pray thee lend me thine
26868 2 Car Ay when canst tell Lend me thy lantern quoth he Marry
26869 I'll see thee hang'd first
26870 Gads Sirrah carrier what time do you mean to come to London
26871 2 Car Time enough to go to bed with a candle I warrant thee
26872 Come neighbour Mugs we'll call up the gentlemen They will
26873 along with company for they have great charge
26874 Exeunt [Carriers]
26875 Gads What ho chamberlain
26876 Enter Chamberlain
26877 Cham At hand quoth pickpurse
26878 Gads That's even as fair as 'at hand quoth the chamberlain for
26879 thou variest no more from picking of purses than giving direction
26880 doth from labouring thou layest the plot how
26881 Cham Good morrow Master Gadshill It holds current that I told
26882 you yesternight There's a franklin in the Wild of Kent hath
26883 brought three hundred marks with him in gold I heard him tell it
26884 to one of his company last night at supper a kind of auditor
26885 one that hath abundance of charge too God knows what They are
26886 up already and call for eggs and butter They will away
26887 presently
26888 Gads Sirrah if they meet not with Saint Nicholas clerks I'll
26889 give thee this neck
26890 Cham No I'll none of it I pray thee keep that for the hangman
26891 for I know thou worshippest Saint Nicholas as truly as a man of
26892 falsehood may
26893 Gads What talkest thou to me of the hangman If I hang I'll make
26894 a fat pair of gallows for if I hang old Sir John hangs with me
26895 and thou knowest he is no starveling Tut there are other
26896 Troyans that thou dream'st not of the which for sport sake are
26897 content to do the profession some grace that would if matters
26898 should be look'd into for their own credit sake make all whole
26899 I am joined with no foot landrakers no longstaff sixpenny
26900 strikers none of these mad mustachio purplehued maltworms but
26901 with nobility and tranquillity burgomasters and great oneyers
26902 such as can hold in such as will strike sooner than speak and
26903 speak sooner than drink and drink sooner than pray and yet
26904 zounds I lie for they pray continually to their saint the
26905 commonwealth or rather not pray to her but prey on her for
26906 they ride up and down on her and make her their boots
26907 Cham What the commonwealth their boots Will she hold out water
26908 in foul way
26909 Gads She will she will Justice hath liquor'd her We steal as in
26910 a castle cocksure We have the receipt of fernseed we walk
26911 invisible
26912 Cham Nay by my faith I think you are more beholding to the night
26913 than to fernseed for your walking invisible
26914 Gads Give me thy hand Thou shalt have a share in our purchase as
26915 I and a true man
26916 Cham Nay rather let me have it as you are a false thief
26917 Gads Go to 'homo is a common name to all men Bid the ostler
26918 bring my gelding out of the stable Farewell you muddy knave
26919 Exeunt
26920 Scene II
26921 The highway near Gadshill
26922 Enter Prince and Poins
26923 Poins Come shelter shelter I have remov'd Falstaff's horse and
26924 he frets like a gumm'd velvet
26925 Prince Stand close [They step aside]
26926 Enter Falstaff
26927 Fal Poins Poins and be hang'd Poins
26928 Prince I comes forward I Peace ye fatkidney'd rascal What a
26929 brawling dost thou keep
26930 Fal Where's Poins Hal
26931 Prince He is walk'd up to the top of the hill I'll go seek him
26932 [Steps aside]
26933 Fal I am accurs'd to rob in that thief's company The rascal hath
26934 removed my horse and tied him I know not where If I travel but
26935 four foot by the squire further afoot I shall break my wind
26936 Well I doubt not but to die a fair death for all this if I
26937 scape hanging for killing that rogue I have forsworn his company
26938 hourly any time this twoandtwenty years and yet I am bewitch'd
26939 with the rogue's company If the rascal have not given me
26940 medicines to make me love him I'll be hang'd It could not be
26941 else I have drunk medicines Poins Hal A plague upon you both
26942 Bardolph Peto I'll starve ere I'll rob a foot further An
26943 'twere not as good a deed as drink to turn true man and to leave
26944 these rogues I am the veriest varlet that ever chewed with a
26945 tooth Eight yards of uneven ground is threescore and ten miles
26946 afoot with me and the stonyhearted villains know it well
26947 enough A plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to
26948 another They whistle Whew A plague upon you all Give me my
26949 horse you rogues give me my horse and be hang'd
26950 Prince [comes forward] Peace ye fatguts Lie down lay thine ear
26951 close to the ground and list if thou canst hear the tread of
26952 travellers
26953 Fal Have you any levers to lift me up again being down 'Sblood
26954 I'll not bear mine own flesh so far afoot again for all the coin
26955 in thy father's exchequer What a plague mean ye to colt me thus
26956 Prince Thou liest thou art not colted thou art uncolted
26957 Fal I prithee good Prince Hal help me to my horse good king's
26958 son
26959 Prince Out ye rogue Shall I be your ostler
26960 Fal Go hang thyself in thine own heirapparent garters If I be
26961 ta'en I'll peach for this An I have not ballads made on you
26962 all and sung to filthy tunes let a cup of sack be my poison
26963 When a jest is so forward and afoot too I hate it
26964 Enter Gadshill [Bardolph and Peto with him]
26965 Gads Stand
26966 Fal So I do against my will
26967 Poins [comes fortward] O 'tis our setter I know his voice
26968 Bardolph what news
26969 Bar Case ye case ye On with your vizards There's money of the
26970 King's coming down the hill 'tis going to the King's exchequer
26971 Fal You lie ye rogue 'Tis going to the King's tavern
26972 Gads There's enough to make us all
26973 Fal To be hang'd
26974 Prince Sirs you four shall front them in the narrow lane Ned
26975 Poins and I will walk lower If they scape from your encounter
26976 then they light on us
26977 Peto How many be there of them
26978 Gads Some eight or ten
26979 Fal Zounds will they not rob us
26980 Prince What a coward Sir John Paunch
26981 Fal Indeed I am not John of Gaunt your grandfather but yet no
26982 coward Hal
26983 Prince Well we leave that to the proof
26984 Poins Sirrah Jack thy horse stands behind the hedge When thou
26985 need'st him there thou shalt find him Farewell and stand fast
26986 Fal Now cannot I strike him if I should be hang'd
26987 Prince [aside to Poins] Ned where are our disguises
26988 Poins [aside to Prince] Here hard by Stand close
26989 [Exeunt Prince and Poins]
26990 Fal Now my masters happy man be his dole say I Every man to
26991 his business
26992 Enter the Travellers
26993 Traveller Come neighbour
26994 The boy shall lead our horses down the hill
26995 We'll walk afoot awhile and ease our legs
26996 Thieves Stand
26997 Traveller Jesus bless us
26998 Fal Strike down with them cut the villains throats Ah
26999 whoreson caterpillars baconfed knaves they hate us youth Down
27000 with them fleece them
27001 Traveller O we are undone both we and ours for ever
27002 Fal Hang ye gorbellied knaves are ye undone No ye fat chuffs
27003 I would your store were here On bacons on What ye knaves
27004 young men must live You are grandjurors are ye We'll jure ye
27005 faith
27006 Here they rob and bind them Exeunt
27007 Enter the Prince and Poins [in buckram suits]
27008 Prince The thieves have bound the true men Now could thou and I
27009 rob the thieves and go merrily to London it would be argument
27010 for a week laughter for a month and a good jest for ever
27011 Poins Stand close I hear them coming
27012 [They stand aside]
27013 Enter the Thieves again
27014 Fal Come my masters let us share and then to horse before day
27015 An the Prince and Poins be not two arrant cowards there's no
27016 equity stirring There's no more valour in that Poins than in a
27017 wild duck
27018 [As they are sharing the Prince and Poins set upon
27019 them THey all run away and Falstaff after a blow or
27020 two runs awasy too leaving the booty behind them]
27021 Prince Your money
27022 Poins Villains
27023 Prince Got with much ease Now merrily to horse
27024 The thieves are scattered and possess'd with fear
27025 So strongly that they dare not meet each other
27026 Each takes his fellow for an officer
27027 Away good Ned Falstaff sweats to death
27028 And lards the lean earth as he walks along
27029 Were't not for laughing I should pity him
27030 Poins How the rogue roar'd Exeunt
27031 Scene III
27032 Warkworth Castle
27033 Enter Hotspur solus reading a letter
27034 Hot 'But for mine own part my lord I could be well contented to
27035 be there in respect of the love I bear your house He could be
27036 contented why is he not then In respect of the love he bears
27037 our house He shows in this he loves his own barn better than he
27038 loves our house Let me see some more 'The purpose you undertake
27039 is dangerous Why that's certain 'Tis dangerous to take a
27040 cold to sleep to drink but I tell you my lord fool out of
27041 this nettle danger we pluck this flower safety 'The purpose
27042 you undertake is dangerous the friends you have named uncertain
27043 the time itself unsorted and your whole plot too light for the
27044 counterpoise of so great an opposition Say you so say you so
27045 I say unto you again you are a shallow cowardly hind and you
27046 lie What a lackbrain is this By the Lord our plot is a good
27047 plot as ever was laid our friends true and constant a good
27048 plot good friends and full of expectation an excellent plot
27049 very good friends What a frostyspirited rogue is this Why my
27050 Lord of York commends the plot and the general course of the
27051 action Zounds an I were now by this rascal I could brain him
27052 with his lady's fan Is there not my father my uncle and
27053 myself Lord Edmund Mortimer my Lord of York and Owen
27054 Glendower Is there not besides the Douglas Have I not all
27055 their letters to meet me in arms by the ninth of the next month
27056 and are they not some of them set forward already What a pagan
27057 rascal is this an infidel Ha you shall see now in very
27058 sincerity of fear and cold heart will he to the King and lay open
27059 all our proceedings O I could divide myself and go to buffets
27060 for moving such a dish of skim milk with so honourable an action
27061 Hang him let him tell the King we are prepared I will set
27062 forward tonight
27063 Enter his Lady
27064 How now Kate I must leave you within these two hours
27065 Lady O my good lord why are you thus alone
27066 For what offence have I this fortnight been
27067 A banish'd woman from my Harry's bed
27068 Tell me sweet lord what is't that takes from thee
27069 Thy stomach pleasure and thy golden sleep
27070 Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth
27071 And start so often when thou sit'st alone
27072 Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks
27073 And given my treasures and my rights of thee
27074 To thickey'd musing and curs'd melancholy
27075 In thy faint slumbers I by thee have watch'd
27076 And heard thee murmur tales of iron wars
27077 Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed
27078 Cry 'Courage to the field And thou hast talk'd
27079 Of sallies and retires of trenches tent
27080 Of palisadoes frontiers parapets
27081 Of basilisks of cannon culverin
27082 Of prisoners ransom and of soldiers slain
27083 And all the currents of a heady fight
27084 Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war
27085 And thus hath so bestirr'd thee in thy sleep
27086 That beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow
27087 Like bubbles ill a latedisturbed stream
27088 And in thy face strange motions have appear'd
27089 Such as we see when men restrain their breath
27090 On some great sudden hest O what portents are these
27091 Some heavy business hath my lord in hand
27092 And I must know it else he loves me not
27093 Hot What ho
27094 [Enter a Servant]
27095 Is Gilliams with the packet gone
27096 Serv He is my lord an hour ago
27097 Hot Hath Butler brought those horses from the sheriff
27098 Serv One horse my lord he brought even now
27099 Hot What horse A roan a cropear is it not
27100 Serv It is my lord
27101 Hot That roan shall be my throne
27102 Well I will back him straight O esperance
27103 Bid Butler lead him forth into the park
27104 [Exit Servant]
27105 Lady But hear you my lord
27106 Hot What say'st thou my lady
27107 Lady What is it carries you away
27108 Hot Why my horse my love my horse
27109 Lady Out you madheaded ape
27110 A weasel hath not such a deal of spleen
27111 As you are toss'd with In faith
27112 I'll know your business Harry that I will
27113 I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir
27114 About his title and hath sent for you
27115 To line his enterprise but if you go
27116 Hot So far afoot I shall be weary love
27117 Lady Come come you paraquito answer me
27118 Directly unto this question that I ask
27119 I'll break thy little finger Harry
27120 An if thou wilt not tell my all things true
27121 Hot Away
27122 Away you trifler Love I love thee not
27123 I care not for thee Kate This is no world
27124 To play with mammets and to tilt with lips
27125 We must have bloody noses and crack'd crowns
27126 And pass them current too Gods me my horse
27127 What say'st thou Kate What wouldst thou have with me
27128 Lady Do you not love me do you not indeed
27129 Well do not then for since you love me not
27130 I will not love myself Do you not love me
27131 Nay tell me if you speak in jest or no
27132 Hot Come wilt thou see me ride
27133 And when I am ahorseback I will swear
27134 I love thee infinitely But hark you Kate
27135 I must not have you henceforth question me
27136 Whither I go nor reason whereabout
27137 Whither I must I must and to conclude
27138 This evening must I leave you gentle Kate
27139 I know you wise but yet no farther wise
27140 Than Harry Percy's wife constant you are
27141 But yet a woman and for secrecy
27142 No lady closer for I well believe
27143 Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know
27144 And so far will I trust thee gentle Kate
27145 Lady How so far
27146 Hot Not an inch further But hark you Kate
27147 Whither I go thither shall you go too
27148 Today will I set forth tomorrow you
27149 Will this content you Kate
27150 Lady It must of force Exeunt
27151 Scene IV
27152 Eastcheap The Boar's Head Tavern
27153 Enter Prince and Poins
27154 Prince Ned prithee come out of that fatroom and lend me thy hand
27155 to laugh a little
27156 Poins Where hast been Hal
27157 Prince With three or four loggerheads amongst three or
27158 fourscore hogsheads I have sounded the very bassstring of
27159 humility Sirrah I am sworn brother to a leash of drawers and
27160 can call them all by their christen names as Tom Dick and
27161 Francis They take it already upon their salvation that though
27162 I be but Prince of Wales yet I am the king of courtesy and tell
27163 me flatly I am no proud Jack like Falstaff but a Corinthian a
27164 lad of mettle a good boy by the Lord so they call me and
27165 when I am King of England I shall command all the good lads
27166 Eastcheap They call drinking deep dying scarlet and when
27167 you breathe in your watering they cry 'hem and bid you play it
27168 off To conclude I am so good a proficient in one quarter of an
27169 hour that I can drink with any tinker in his own language during
27170 my life I tell thee Ned thou hast lost much honour that thou
27171 wert not with me in this action But sweet Ned to sweeten which
27172 name of Ned I give thee this pennyworth of sugar clapp'd even
27173 now into my hand by an underskinker one that never spake other
27174 English in his life than 'Eight shillings and sixpence and 'You
27175 are welcome with this shrill addition 'Anon anon sir Score
27176 a pint of bastard in the Halfmoon or so but Ned to drive
27177 away the time till Falstaff come I prithee do thou stand in some
27178 byroom while I question my puny drawer to what end be gave me
27179 the sugar and do thou never leave calling 'Francis that his
27180 tale to me may be nothing but 'Anon Step aside and I'll show
27181 thee a precedent
27182 Poins Francis
27183 Prince Thou art perfect
27184 Poins Francis [Exit Poins]
27185 Enter [Francis a] Drawer
27186 Fran Anon anon sir Look down into the Pomgarnet Ralph
27187 Prince Come hither Francis
27188 Fran My lord
27189 Prince How long hast thou to serve Francis
27190 Fran Forsooth five years and as much as to
27191 Poins [within] Francis
27192 Fran Anon anon sir
27193 Prince Five year by'r Lady a long lease for the clinking of
27194 Pewter But Francis darest thou be so valiant as to play the
27195 coward with thy indenture and show it a fair pair of heels and
27196 run from it
27197 Fran O Lord sir I'll be sworn upon all the books in England I
27198 could find in my heart
27199 Poins [within] Francis
27200 Fran Anon sir
27201 Prince How old art thou Francis
27202 Fran Let me see About Michaelmas next I shall be
27203 Poins [within] Francis
27204 Fran Anon sir Pray stay a little my lord
27205 Prince Nay but hark you Francis For the sugar thou gavest me
27206 'twas a pennyworth wast not
27207 Fran O Lord I would it had been two
27208 Prince I will give thee for it a thousand pound Ask me when thou
27209 wilt and thou shalt have it
27210 Poins [within] Francis
27211 Fran Anon anon
27212 Prince Anon Francis No Francis but tomorrow Francis or
27213 Francis a Thursday or indeed Francis when thou wilt But
27214 Francis
27215 Fran My lord
27216 Prince Wilt thou rob this leathernjerkin crystalbutton
27217 notpated agatering pukestocking caddisgarter
27218 smoothtongue Spanishpouch
27219 Fran O Lord sir who do you mean
27220 Prince Why then your brown bastard is your only drink for look
27221 you Francis your white canvas doublet will sully In Barbary
27222 sir it cannot come to so much
27223 Fran What sir
27224 Poins [within] Francis
27225 Prince Away you rogue Dost thou not hear them call
27226 Here they both call him The Drawer stands amazed
27227 not knowing which way to go
27228 Enter Vintner
27229 Vint What stand'st thou still and hear'st such a calling Look
27230 to the guests within [Exit Francis] My lord old Sir John with
27231 halfadozen more are at the door Shall I let them in
27232 Prince Let them alone awhile and then open the door
27233 [Exit Vintner]
27234 Poins
27235 Poins [within] Anon anon sir
27236 Enter Poins
27237 Prince Sirrah Falstaff and the rest of the thieves are at the
27238 door Shall we be merry
27239 Poins As merry as crickets my lad But hark ye what cunning
27240 match have you made with this jest of the drawer Come what's
27241 the issue
27242 Prince I am now of all humours that have showed themselves humours
27243 since the old days of goodman Adam to the pupil age of this
27244 present this twelve o'clock at midnight
27245 [Enter Francis]
27246 What's o'clock Francis
27247 Fran Anon anon sir [Exit]
27248 Prince That ever this fellow should have fewer words than a
27249 parrot and yet the son of a woman His industry is upstairs and
27250 downstairs his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning I am not yet
27251 of Percy's mind the Hotspur of the North he that kills me some
27252 six or seven dozen of Scots at a breakfast washes his hands and
27253 says to his wife 'Fie upon this quiet life I want work 'O my
27254 sweet Harry says she 'how many hast thou kill'd today'
27255 'Give my roan horse a drench says he and answers 'Some
27256 fourteen an hour after 'a trifle a trifle I prithee call in
27257 Falstaff I'll play Percy and that damn'd brawn shall play Dame
27258 Mortimer his wife 'Rivo says the drunkard Call in ribs call
27259 in tallow
27260 Enter Falstaff [Gadshill Bardolph and Peto
27261 Francis follows with wine]
27262 Poins Welcome Jack Where hast thou been
27263 Fal A plague of all cowards I say and a vengeance too Marry and
27264 amen Give me a cup of sack boy Ere I lead this life long I'll
27265 sew netherstocks and mend them and foot them too A plague of
27266 all cowards Give me a cup of sack rogue Is there no virtue
27267 extant
27268 He drinketh
27269 Prince Didst thou never see Titan kiss a dish of butter
27270 Pitifulhearted butter that melted at the sweet tale of the sun
27271 If thou didst then behold that compound
27272 Fal You rogue here's lime in this sack too There is nothing but
27273 roguery to be found in villanous man Yet a coward is worse than
27274 a cup of sack with lime in it a villanous coward Go thy ways
27275 old Jack die when thou wilt if manhood good manhood be not
27276 forgot upon the face of the earth then am I a shotten herring
27277 There lives not three good men unhang'd in England and one of
27278 them is fat and grows old God help the while A bad world I
27279 say I would I were a weaver I could sing psalms or anything A
27280 plague of all cowards I say still
27281 Prince How now woolsack What mutter you
27282 Fal A king's son If I do not beat thee out of thy kingdom with a
27283 dagger of lath and drive all thy subjects afore thee like a flock
27284 of wild geese I'll never wear hair on my face more You Prince
27285 of Wales
27286 Prince Why you whoreson round man what's the matter
27287 Fal Are not you a coward Answer me to that and Poins there
27288 Poins Zounds ye fat paunch an ye call me coward by the
27289 Lord I'll stab thee
27290 Fal I call thee coward I'll see thee damn'd ere I call thee
27291 coward but I would give a thousand pound I could run as fast as
27292 thou canst You are straight enough in the shoulders you care
27293 not who sees Your back Call you that backing of your friends A
27294 plague upon such backing Give me them that will face me Give me
27295 a cup of sack I am a rogue if I drunk today
27296 Prince O villain thy lips are scarce wip'd since thou drunk'st
27297 last
27298 Fal All is one for that He drinketh A plague of all cowards
27299 still say I
27300 Prince What's the matter
27301 Fal What's the matter There be four of us here have ta'en a
27302 thousand pound this day morning
27303 Prince Where is it Jack Where is it
27304 Fal Where is it Taken from us it is A hundred upon poor four of
27305 us
27306 Prince What a hundred man
27307 Fal I am a rogue if I were not at halfsword with a dozen of them
27308 two hours together I have scap'd by miracle I am eight times
27309 thrust through the doublet four through the hose my buckler cut
27310 through and through my sword hack'd like a handsaw ecce signum
27311 I never dealt better since I was a man All would not do A
27312 plague of all cowards Let them speak If they speak more or less
27313 than truth they are villains and the sons of darkness
27314 Prince Speak sirs How was it
27315 Gads We four set upon some dozen
27316 Fal Sixteen at least my lord
27317 Gads And bound them
27318 Peto No no they were not bound
27319 Fal You rogue they were bound every man of them or I am a Jew
27320 else an Ebrew Jew
27321 Gads As we were sharing some six or seven fresh men sea upon us
27322 Fal And unbound the rest and then come in the other
27323 Prince What fought you with them all
27324 Fal All I know not what you call all but if I fought not with
27325 fifty of them I am a bunch of radish If there were not two or
27326 three and fifty upon poor old Jack then am I no twolegg'd
27327 creature
27328 Prince Pray God you have not murd'red some of them
27329 Fal Nay that's past praying for I have pepper'd two of them Two
27330 I am sure I have paid two rogues in buckram suits I tell thee
27331 what Hal if I tell thee a lie spit in my face call me horse
27332 Thou knowest my old ward Here I lay and thus I bore my point
27333 Four rogues in buckram let drive at me
27334 Prince What four Thou saidst but two even now
27335 Fal Four Hal I told thee four
27336 Poins Ay ay he said four
27337 Fal These four came all afront and mainly thrust at me I made me
27338 no more ado but took all their seven points in my target thus
27339 Prince Seven Why there were but four even now
27340 Fal In buckram
27341 Poins Ay four in buckram suits
27342 Fal Seven by these hilts or I am a villain else
27343 Prince [aside to Poins] Prithee let him alone We shall have more
27344 anon
27345 Fal Dost thou hear me Hal
27346 Prince Ay and mark thee too Jack
27347 Fal Do so for it is worth the list'ning to These nine in buckram
27348 that I told thee of
27349 Prince So two more already
27350 Fal Their points being broken
27351 Poins Down fell their hose
27352 Fal Began to give me ground but I followed me close came in
27353 foot and hand and with a thought seven of the eleven I paid
27354 Prince O monstrous Eleven buckram men grown out of two
27355 Fal But as the devil would have it three misbegotten knaves in
27356 Kendal green came at my back and let drive at me for it was so
27357 dark Hal that thou couldst not see thy hand
27358 Prince These lies are like their father that begets them gross as
27359 a mountain open palpable Why thou claybrain'd guts thou
27360 knottypated fool thou whoreson obscene greasy tallowcatch
27361 Fal What art thou mad art thou mad Is not the truth the truth
27362 Prince Why how couldst thou know these men in Kendal green when
27363 it was so dark thou couldst not see thy hand Come tell us your
27364 reason What sayest thou to this
27365 Poins Come your reason Jack your reason
27366 Fal What upon compulsion Zounds an I were at the strappado or
27367 all the racks in the world I would not tell you on compulsion
27368 Give you a reason on compulsion If reasons were as plentiful as
27369 blackberries I would give no man a reason upon compulsion I
27370 Prince I'll be no longer guilty of this sin this sanguine
27371 coward this bedpresser this horsebackbreaker this huge hill
27372 of flesh
27373 Fal 'Sblood you starveling you elfskin you dried
27374 neat'stongue you bull's sizzle you stockfish O for breath to
27375 utter what is like thee you tailor's yard you sheath you
27376 bowcase you vile standing tuck
27377 Prince Well breathe awhile and then to it again and when thou
27378 hast tired thyself in base comparisons hear me speak but this
27379 Poins Mark Jack
27380 Prince We two saw you four set on four and bound them and were
27381 masters of their wealth Mark now how a plain tale shall put you
27382 down Then did we two set on you four and with a word outfac'd
27383 you from your prize and have it yea and can show it you here
27384 in the house And Falstaff you carried your guts away as
27385 nimbly with as quick dexterity and roar'd for mercy and still
27386 run and roar'd as ever I heard bullcalf What a slave art thou
27387 to hack thy sword as thou hast done and then say it was in
27388 fight What trick what device what starting hole canst thou now
27389 find out to hide thee from this open and apparent shame
27390 Poins Come let's hear Jack What trick hast thou now
27391 Fal By the Lord I knew ye as well as he that made ye Why hear
27392 you my masters Was it for me to kill the heir apparent Should
27393 I turn upon the true prince Why thou knowest I am as valiant as
27394 Hercules but beware instinct The lion will not touch the true
27395 prince Instinct is a great matter I was now a coward on
27396 instinct I shall think the better of myself and thee during my
27397 life I for a valiant lion and thou for a true prince But by
27398 the Lord lads I am glad you have the money Hostess clap to
27399 the doors Watch tonight pray tomorrow Gallants lads boys
27400 hearts of gold all the titles of good fellowship come to you
27401 What shall we be merry Shall we have a play extempore
27402 Prince Content and the argument shall be thy running away
27403 Fal Ah no more of that Hal an thou lovest me
27404 Enter Hostess
27405 Host O Jesu my lord the Prince
27406 Prince How now my lady the hostess What say'st thou to me
27407 Host Marry my lord there is a nobleman of the court at door
27408 would speak with you He says he comes from your father
27409 Prince Give him as much as will make him a royal man and send him
27410 back again to my mother
27411 Fal What manner of man is he
27412 Host An old man
27413 Fal What doth gravity out of his bed at midnight Shall I give him
27414 his answer
27415 Prince Prithee do Jack
27416 Fal Faith and I'll send him packing
27417 Exit
27418 Prince Now sirs By'r Lady you fought fair so did you Peto so
27419 did you Bardolph You are lions too you ran away upon instinct
27420 you will not touch the true prince no fie
27421 Bard Faith I ran when I saw others run
27422 Prince Tell me now in earnest how came Falstaff's sword so
27423 hack'd
27424 Peto Why he hack'd it with his dagger and said he would swear
27425 truth out of England but he would make you believe it was done in
27426 fight and persuaded us to do the like
27427 Bard Yea and to tickle our noses with speargrass to make them
27428 bleed and then to beslubber our garments with it and swear it
27429 was the blood of true men I did that I did not this seven year
27430 before I blush'd to hear his monstrous devices
27431 Prince O villain thou stolest a cup of sack eighteen years ago
27432 and wert taken with the manner and ever since thou hast blush'd
27433 extempore Thou hadst fire and sword on thy side and yet thou
27434 ran'st away What instinct hadst thou for it
27435 Bard My lord do you see these meteors Do you behold these
27436 exhalations
27437 Prince I do
27438 Bard What think you they portend
27439 Prince Hot livers and cold purses
27440 Bard Choler my lord if rightly taken
27441 Prince No if rightly taken halter
27442 Enter Falstaff
27443 Here comes lean Jack here comes barebone How now my sweet
27444 creature of bombast How long is't ago Jack since thou sawest
27445 thine own knee
27446 Fal My own knee When I was about thy years Hal I was not an
27447 eagle's talent in the waist I could have crept into any
27448 alderman's thumbring A plague of sighing and grief It blows a
27449 man up like a bladder There's villanous news abroad Here was
27450 Sir John Bracy from your father You must to the court in the
27451 morning That same mad fellow of the North Percy and he of
27452 Wales that gave Amamon the bastinado and made Lucifer cuckold
27453 and swore the devil his true liegeman upon the cross of a Welsh
27454 hook what a plague call you him
27455 Poins O Glendower
27456 Fal Owen Owen the same and his soninlaw Mortimer and old
27457 Northumberland and that sprightly Scot of Scots Douglas that
27458 runs ahorseback up a hill perpendicular
27459 Prince He that rides at high speed and with his pistol kills a
27460 sparrow flying
27461 Fal You have hit it
27462 Prince So did he never the sparrow
27463 Fal Well that rascal hath good metal in him he will not run
27464 Prince Why what a rascal art thou then to praise him so for
27465 running
27466 Fal Ahorseback ye cuckoo but afoot he will not budge a foot
27467 Prince Yes Jack upon instinct
27468 Fal I grant ye upon instinct Well he is there too and one
27469 Mordake and a thousand bluecaps more Worcester is stol'n away
27470 tonight thy father's beard is turn'd white with the news you
27471 may buy land now as cheap as stinking mack'rel
27472 Prince Why then it is like if there come a hot June and this
27473 civil buffeting hold we shall buy maidenheads as they buy
27474 hobnails by the hundreds
27475 Fal By the mass lad thou sayest true it is like we shall have
27476 good trading that way But tell me Hal art not thou horrible
27477 afeard Thou being heir apparent could the world pick thee out
27478 three such enemies again as that fiend Douglas that spirit
27479 Percy and that devil Glendower Art thou not horribly afraid
27480 Doth not thy blood thrill at it
27481 Prince Not a whit i faith I lack some of thy instinct
27482 Fal Well thou wilt be horribly chid tomorrow when thou comest to
27483 thy father If thou love file practise an answer
27484 Prince Do thou stand for my father and examine me upon the
27485 particulars of my life
27486 Fal Shall I Content This chair shall be my state this dagger my
27487 sceptre and this cushion my crown
27488 Prince Thy state is taken for a join'dstool thy golden sceptre
27489 for a leaden dagger and thy precious rich crown for a pitiful
27490 bald crown
27491 Fal Well an the fire of grace be not quite out of thee now shalt
27492 thou be moved Give me a cup of sack to make my eyes look red
27493 that it may be thought I have wept for I must speak in passion
27494 and I will do it in King Cambyses vein
27495 Prince Well here is my leg
27496 Fal And here is my speech Stand aside nobility
27497 Host O Jesu this is excellent sport i faith
27498 Fal Weep not sweet queen for trickling tears are vain
27499 Host O the Father how he holds his countenance
27500 Fal For God's sake lords convey my tristful queen
27501 For tears do stop the floodgates of her eyes
27502 Host O Jesu he doth it as like one of these harlotry players as
27503 ever I see
27504 Fal Peace good pintpot Peace good ticklebrain Harry I do
27505 not only marvel where thou spendest thy time but also how thou
27506 art accompanied For though the camomile the more it is trodden
27507 on the faster it grows yet youth the more it is wasted the
27508 sooner it wears That thou art my son I have partly thy mother's
27509 word partly my own opinion but chiefly a villanous trick of
27510 thine eye and a foolish hanging of thy nether lip that doth
27511 warrant me If then thou be son to me here lies the point why
27512 being son to me art thou so pointed at Shall the blessed sun of
27513 heaven prove a micher and eat blackberries A question not to be
27514 ask'd Shall the son of England prove a thief and take purses A
27515 question to be ask'd There is a thing Harry which thou hast
27516 often heard of and it is known to many in our land by the name
27517 of pitch This pitch as ancient writers do report doth defile
27518 so doth the company thou keepest For Harry now I do not speak
27519 to thee in drink but in tears not in pleasure but in passion
27520 not in words only but in woes also and yet there is a virtuous
27521 man whom I have often noted in thy company but I know not his
27522 name
27523 Prince What manner of man an it like your Majesty
27524 Fal A goodly portly man i faith and a corpulent of a cheerful
27525 look a pleasing eye and a most noble carriage and as I think
27526 his age some fifty or by'r Lady inclining to threescore and
27527 now I remember me his name is Falstaff If that man should be
27528 lewdly given he deceiveth me for Harry I see virtue in his
27529 looks If then the tree may be known by the fruit as the fruit
27530 by the tree then peremptorily I speak it there is virtue in
27531 that Falstaff Him keep with the rest banish And tell me now
27532 thou naughty varlet tell me where hast thou been this month
27533 Prince Dost thou speak like a king Do thou stand for me and I'll
27534 play my father
27535 Fal Depose me If thou dost it half so gravely so majestically
27536 both in word and matter hang me up by the heels for a
27537 rabbitsucker or a poulter's hare
27538 Prince Well here I am set
27539 Fal And here I stand Judge my masters
27540 Prince Now Harry whence come you
27541 Fal My noble lord from Eastcheap
27542 Prince The complaints I hear of thee are grievous
27543 Fal 'Sblood my lord they are false Nay I'll tickle ye for a
27544 young prince i faith
27545 Prince Swearest thou ungracious boy Henceforth ne'er look on me
27546 Thou art violently carried away from grace There is a devil
27547 haunts thee in the likeness of an old fat man a tun of man is
27548 thy companion Why dost thou converse with that trunk of humours
27549 that bolting hutch of beastliness that swoll'n parcel of
27550 dropsies that huge bombard of sack that stuff'd cloakbag of
27551 guts that roasted Manningtree ox with the pudding in his belly
27552 that reverend vice that grey iniquity that father ruffian that
27553 vanity in years Wherein is he good but to taste sack and drink
27554 it wherein neat and cleanly but to carve a capon and eat it
27555 wherein cunning but in craft wherein crafty but in villany
27556 wherein villanous but in all things wherein worthy but in
27557 nothing
27558 Fal I would your Grace would take me with you Whom means your
27559 Grace
27560 Prince That villanous abominable misleader of youth Falstaff
27561 that old whitebearded Satan
27562 Fal My lord the man I know
27563 Prince I know thou dost
27564 Fal But to say I know more harm in him than in myself were to say
27565 more than I know That he is old the more the pity his white
27566 hairs do witness it but that he is saving your reverence a
27567 whoremaster that I utterly deny If sack and sugar be a fault
27568 God help the wicked If to be old and merry be a sin then many
27569 an old host that I know is damn'd If to be fat be to be hated
27570 then Pharaoh's lean kine are to be loved No my good lord
27571 Banish Peto banish Bardolph banish Poins but for sweet Jack
27572 Falstaff kind Jack Falstaff true Jack Falstaff valiant Jack
27573 Falstaff and therefore more valiant being as he is old Jack
27574 Falstaff banish not him thy Harry's company banish not him thy
27575 Harry's company Banish plump Jack and banish all the world
27576 Prince I do I will [A knocking heard]
27577 [Exeunt Hostess Francis and Bardolph]
27578 Enter Bardolph running
27579 Bard O my lord my lord the sheriff with a most monstrous watch
27580 is at the door
27581 Fal Out ye rogue Play out the play I have much to say in the
27582 behalf of that Falstaff
27583 Enter the Hostess
27584 Host O Jesu my lord my lord
27585 Prince Heigh heigh the devil rides upon a fiddlestick
27586 What's the matter
27587 Host The sheriff and all the watch are at the door They are come
27588 to search the house Shall I let them in
27589 Fal Dost thou hear Hal Never call a true piece of gold a
27590 counterfeit Thou art essentially mad without seeming so
27591 Prince And thou a natural coward without instinct
27592 Fal I deny your major If you will deny the sheriff so if not
27593 let him enter If I become not a cart as well as another man a
27594 plague on my bringing up I hope I shall as soon be strangled
27595 with a halter as another
27596 Prince Go hide thee behind the arras The rest walk up above
27597 Now my masters for a true face and good conscience
27598 Fal Both which I have had but their date is out and therefore
27599 I'll hide me Exit
27600 Prince Call in the sheriff
27601 [Exeunt Manent the Prince and Peto]
27602 Enter Sheriff and the Carrier
27603 Now Master Sheriff what is your will with me
27604 Sher First pardon me my lord A hue and cry
27605 Hath followed certain men unto this house
27606 Prince What men
27607 Sher One of them is well known my gracious lord
27608 A gross fat man
27609 Carrier As fat as butter
27610 Prince The man I do assure you is not here
27611 For I myself at this time have employ'd him
27612 And sheriff I will engage my word to thee
27613 That I will by tomorrow dinner time
27614 Send him to answer thee or any man
27615 For anything he shall be charg'd withal
27616 And so let me entreat you leave the house
27617 Sher I will my lord There are two gentlemen
27618 Have in this robbery lost three hundred marks
27619 Prince It may be so If he have robb'd these men
27620 He shall be answerable and so farewell
27621 Sher Good night my noble lord
27622 Prince I think it is good morrow is it not
27623 Sher Indeed my lord I think it be two o'clock
27624 Exit [with Carrier]
27625 Prince This oily rascal is known as well as Paul's Go call him
27626 forth
27627 Peto Falstaff Fast asleep behind the arras and snorting like a
27628 horse
27629 Prince Hark how hard he fetches breath Search his pockets
27630 He searcheth his pockets and findeth certain papers
27631 What hast thou found
27632 Peto Nothing but papers my lord
27633 Prince Let's see whit they be Read them
27634 Peto [reads] 'Item A capon ii s ii d
27635 Item Sauce iiii d
27636 Item Sack two gallons v s viii d
27637 Item Anchovies and sack after supper ii s vi d
27638 Item Bread ob'
27639 Prince O monstrous but one halfpennyworth of bread to this
27640 intolerable deal of sack What there is else keep close we'll
27641 read it at more advantage There let him sleep till day I'll to
27642 the court in the morning We must all to the wars and thy place
27643 shall be honourable I'll procure this fat rogue a charge of
27644 foot and I know his death will be a march of twelve score The
27645 money shall be paid back again with advantage Be with me betimes
27646 in the morning and so good morrow Peto
27647 Peto Good morrow good my lord
27648 Exeunt

27650 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
27651 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
27652 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
27653 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS

27657 ACT III Scene I
27658 Bangor The Archdeacon's house
27659 Enter Hotspur Worcester Lord Mortimer Owen Glendower
27660 Mort These promises are fair the parties sure
27661 And our induction full of prosperous hope
27662 Hot Lord Mortimer and cousin Glendower
27663 Will you sit down
27664 And uncle Worcester A plague upon it
27665 I have forgot the map
27666 Glend No here it is
27667 Sit cousin Percy sit good cousin Hotspur
27668 For by that name as oft as Lancaster
27669 Doth speak of you his cheek looks pale and with
27670 A rising sigh he wisheth you in heaven
27671 Hot And you in hell as oft as he hears
27672 Owen Glendower spoke of
27673 Glend I cannot blame him At my nativity
27674 The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes
27675 Of burning cressets and at my birth
27676 The frame and huge foundation of the earth
27677 Shak'd like a coward
27678 Hot Why so it would have done at the same season if your
27679 mother's cat had but kitten'd though yourself had never been
27680 born
27681 Glend I say the earth did shake when I was born
27682 Hot And I say the earth was not of my mind
27683 If you suppose as fearing you it shook
27684 Glend The heavens were all on fire the earth did tremble
27685 Hot O then the earth shook to see the heavens on fire
27686 And not in fear of your nativity
27687 Diseased nature oftentimes breaks forth
27688 In strange eruptions oft the teeming earth
27689 Is with a kind of colic pinch'd and vex'd
27690 By the imprisoning of unruly wind
27691 Within her womb which for enlargement striving
27692 Shakes the old beldame earth and topples down
27693 Steeples and mossgrown towers At your birth
27694 Our grandam earth having this distemp'rature
27695 In passion shook
27696 Glend Cousin of many men
27697 I do not bear these crossings Give me leave
27698 To tell you once again that at my birth
27699 The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes
27700 The goats ran from the mountains and the herds
27701 Were strangely clamorous to the frighted fields
27702 These signs have mark'd me extraordinary
27703 And all the courses of my life do show
27704 I am not in the roll of common men
27705 Where is he living clipp'd in with the sea
27706 That chides the banks of England Scotland Wales
27707 Which calls me pupil or hath read to me
27708 And bring him out that is but woman's son
27709 Can trace me in the tedious ways of art
27710 And hold me pace in deep experiments
27711 Hot I think there's no man speaks better Welsh I'll to dinner
27712 Mort Peace cousin Percy you will make him mad
27713 Glend I can call spirits from the vasty deep
27714 Hot Why so can I or so can any man
27715 But will they come when you do call for them
27716 Glend Why I can teach you cousin to command the devil
27717 Hot And I can teach thee coz to shame the devil
27718 By telling truth Tell truth and shame the devil
27719 If thou have power to raise him bring him hither
27720 And I'll be sworn I have power to shame him hence
27721 O while you live tell truth and shame the devil
27722 Mort Come come no more of this unprofitable chat
27723 Glend Three times hath Henry Bolingbroke made head
27724 Against my power thrice from the banks of Wye
27725 And sandybottom'd Severn have I sent him
27726 Bootless home and weatherbeaten back
27727 Hot Home without boots and in foul weather too
27728 How scapes he agues in the devil's name
27729 Glend Come here's the map Shall we divide our right
27730 According to our threefold order ta'en
27731 Mort The Archdeacon hath divided it
27732 Into three limits very equally
27733 England from Trent and Severn hitherto
27734 By south and east is to my part assign'd
27735 All westward Wales beyond the Severn shore
27736 And all the fertile land within that bound
27737 To Owen Glendower and dear coz to you
27738 The remnant northward lying off from Trent
27739 And our indentures tripartite are drawn
27740 Which being sealed interchangeably
27741 A business that this night may execute
27742 Tomorrow cousin Percy you and I
27743 And my good Lord of Worcester will set forth
27744 To meet your father and the Scottish bower
27745 As is appointed us at Shrewsbury
27746 My father Glendower is not ready yet
27747 Nor shall we need his help these fourteen days
27748 [To Glend] Within that space you may have drawn together
27749 Your tenants friends and neighbouring gentlemen
27750 Glend A shorter time shall send me to you lords
27751 And in my conduct shall your ladies come
27752 From whom you now must steal and take no leave
27753 For there will be a world of water shed
27754 Upon the parting of your wives and you
27755 Hot Methinks my moiety north from Burton here
27756 In quantity equals not one of yours
27757 See how this river comes me cranking in
27758 And cuts me from the best of all my land
27759 A huge halfmoon a monstrous cantle out
27760 I'll have the current ill this place damm'd up
27761 And here the smug and sliver Trent shall run
27762 In a new channel fair and evenly
27763 It shall not wind with such a deep indent
27764 To rob me of so rich a bottom here
27765 Glend Not wind It shall it must You see it doth
27766 Mort Yea but
27767 Mark how he bears his course and runs me up
27768 With like advantage on the other side
27769 Gelding the opposed continent as much
27770 As on the other side it takes from you
27771 Wor Yea but a little charge will trench him here
27772 And on this north side win this cape of land
27773 And then he runs straight and even
27774 Hot I'll have it so A little charge will do it
27775 Glend I will not have it alt'red
27776 Hot Will not you
27777 Glend No nor you shall not
27778 Hot Who shall say me nay
27779 Glend No that will I
27780 Hot Let me not understand you then speak it in Welsh
27781 Glend I can speak English lord as well as you
27782 For I was train'd up in the English court
27783 Where being but young I framed to the harp
27784 Many an English ditty lovely well
27785 And gave the tongue a helpful ornament
27786 A virtue that was never seen in you
27787 Hot Marry
27788 And I am glad of it with all my heart
27789 I had rather be a kitten and cry mew
27790 Than one of these same metre balletmongers
27791 I had rather hear a brazen canstick turn'd
27792 Or a dry wheel grate on the axletree
27793 And that would set my teeth nothing on edge
27794 Nothing so much as mincing poetry
27795 'Tis like the forc'd gait of a shuffling nag
27796 Glend Come you shall have Trent turn'd
27797 Hot I do not care I'll give thrice so much land
27798 To any welldeserving friend
27799 But in the way of bargain mark ye me
27800 I'll cavil on the ninth part of a hair
27801 Are the indentures drawn Shall we be gone
27802 Glend The moon shines fair you may away by night
27803 I'll haste the writer and withal
27804 Break with your wives of your departure hence
27805 I am afraid my daughter will run mad
27806 So much she doteth on her Mortimer Exit
27807 Mort Fie cousin Percy how you cross my father
27808 Hot I cannot choose Sometimes he angers me
27809 With telling me of the moldwarp and the ant
27810 Of the dreamer Merlin and his prophecies
27811 And of a dragon and a finless fish
27812 A clipwing'd griffin and a moulten raven
27813 A couching lion and a ramping cat
27814 And such a deal of skimbleskamble stuff
27815 As puts me from my faith I tell you what
27816 He held me last night at least nine hours
27817 In reckoning up the several devils names
27818 That were his lackeys I cried 'hum and 'Well go to'
27819 But mark'd him not a word O he is as tedious
27820 As a tired horse a railing wife
27821 Worse than a smoky house I had rather live
27822 With cheese and garlic in a windmill far
27823 Than feed on cates and have him talk to me
27824 In any summer house in Christendom
27825 Mort In faith he is a worthy gentleman
27826 Exceedingly well read and profited
27827 In strange concealments valiant as a lion
27828 And wondrous affable and as bountiful
27829 As mines of India Shall I tell you cousin
27830 He holds your temper in a high respect
27831 And curbs himself even of his natural scope
27832 When you come 'cross his humour Faith he does
27833 I warrant you that man is not alive
27834 Might so have tempted him as you have done
27835 Without the taste of danger and reproof
27836 But do not use it oft let me entreat you
27837 Wor In faith my lord you are too wilfulblame
27838 And since your coming hither have done enough
27839 To put him quite besides his patience
27840 You must needs learn lord to amend this fault
27841 Though sometimes it show greatness courage blood
27842 And that's the dearest grace it renders you
27843 Yet oftentimes it doth present harsh rage
27844 Defect of manners want of government
27845 Pride haughtiness opinion and disdain
27846 The least of which haunting a nobleman
27847 Loseth men's hearts and leaves behind a stain
27848 Upon the beauty of all parts besides
27849 Beguiling them of commendation
27850 Hot Well I am school'd Good manners be your speed
27851 Here come our wives and let us take our leave
27852 Enter Glendower with the Ladies
27853 Mort This is the deadly spite that angers me
27854 My wife can speak no English I no Welsh
27855 Glend My daughter weeps she will not part with you
27856 She'll be a soldier too she'll to the wars
27857 Mort Good father tell her that she and my aunt Percy
27858 Shall follow in your conduct speedily
27859 Glendower speaks to her in Welsh and she answers
27860 him in the same
27861 Glend She is desperate here A peevish selfwill'd harlotry
27862 One that no persuasion can do good upon
27863 The Lady speaks in Welsh
27864 Mort I understand thy looks That pretty Welsh
27865 Which thou pourest down from these swelling heavens
27866 I am too perfect in and but for shame
27867 In such a Barley should I answer thee
27868 The Lady again in Welsh
27869 I understand thy kisses and thou mine
27870 And that's a feeling disputation
27871 But I will never be a truant love
27872 Till I have learnt thy language for thy tongue
27873 Makes Welsh as sweet as ditties highly penn'd
27874 Sung by a fair queen in a summer's bow'r
27875 With ravishing division to her lute
27876 Glend Nay if you melt then will she run mad
27877 The Lady speaks again in Welsh
27878 Mort O I am ignorance itself in this
27879 Glend She bids you on the wanton rushes lay you down
27880 And rest your gentle head upon her lap
27881 And she will sing the song that pleaseth you
27882 And on your eyelids crown the god of sleep
27883 Charming your blood with pleasing heaviness
27884 Making such difference 'twixt wake and sleep
27885 As is the difference betwixt day and night
27886 The hour before the heavenlyharness'd team
27887 Begins his golden progress in the East
27888 Mort With all my heart I'll sit and hear her sing
27889 By that time will our book I think be drawn
27890 Glend Do so
27891 And those musicians that shall play to you
27892 Hang in the air a thousand leagues from hence
27893 And straight they shall be here Sit and attend
27894 Hot Come Kate thou art perfect in lying down Come quick
27895 quick that I may lay my head in thy lap
27896 Lady P Go ye giddy goose
27897 The music plays
27898 Hot Now I perceive the devil understands Welsh
27899 And 'tis no marvel be is so humorous
27900 By'r Lady he is a good musician
27901 Lady P Then should you be nothing but musical for you are
27902 altogether govern'd by humours Lie still ye thief and hear the
27903 lady sing in Welsh
27904 Hot I had rather hear Lady my brach howl in Irish
27905 Lady P Wouldst thou have thy head broken
27906 Hot No
27907 Lady P Then be still
27908 Hot Neither 'Tis a woman's fault
27909 Lady P Now God help thee
27910 Hot To the Welsh lady's bed
27911 Lady P What's that
27912 Hot Peace she sings
27913 Here the Lady sings a Welsh song
27914 Come Kate I'll have your song too
27915 Lady P Not mine in good sooth
27916 Hot Not yours in good sooth Heart you swear like a
27917 comfitmaker's wife 'Not you in good sooth and 'as true as I
27918 live and 'as God shall mend me and 'as sure as day'
27919 And givest such sarcenet surety for thy oaths
27920 As if thou ne'er walk'st further than Finsbury
27921 Swear me Kate like a lady as thou art
27922 A good mouthfilling oath and leave 'in sooth'
27923 And such protest of pepper gingerbread
27924 To velvet guards and Sunday citizens Come sing
27925 Lady P I will not sing
27926 Hot 'Tis the next way to turn tailor or be redbreastteacher An
27927 the indentures be drawn I'll away within these two hours and so
27928 come in when ye will Exit
27929 Glend Come come Lord Mortimer You are as slow
27930 As hot Lord Percy is on fire to go
27931 By this our book is drawn we'll but seal
27932 And then to horse immediately
27933 Mort With all my heart
27934 Exeunt
27935 Scene II
27936 London The Palace
27937 Enter the King Prince of Wales and others
27938 King Lords give us leave The Prince of Wales and I
27939 Must have some private conference but be near at hand
27940 For we shall presently have need of you
27941 Exeunt Lords
27942 I know not whether God will have it so
27943 For some displeasing service I have done
27944 That in his secret doom out of my blood
27945 He'll breed revengement and a scourge for me
27946 But thou dost in thy passages of life
27947 Make me believe that thou art only mark'd
27948 For the hot vengeance and the rod of heaven
27949 To punish my mistreadings Tell me else
27950 Could such inordinate and low desires
27951 Such poor such bare such lewd such mean attempts
27952 Such barren pleasures rude society
27953 As thou art match'd withal and grafted to
27954 Accompany the greatness of thy blood
27955 And hold their level with thy princely heart
27956 Prince So please your Majesty I would I could
27957 Quit all offences with as clear excuse
27958 As well as I am doubtless I can purge
27959 Myself of many I am charged withal
27960 Yet such extenuation let me beg
27961 As in reproof of many tales devis'd
27962 Which oft the ear of greatness needs must bear
27963 By smiling pickthanks and base newsmongers
27964 I may for some things true wherein my youth
27965 Hath faulty wand'red and irregular
27966 And pardon on lily true submission
27967 King God pardon thee Yet let me wonder Harry
27968 At thy affections which do hold a wing
27969 Quite from the flight of all thy ancestors
27970 Thy place in Council thou hast rudely lost
27971 Which by thy younger brother is supplied
27972 And art almost an alien to the hearts
27973 Of all the court and princes of my blood
27974 The hope and expectation of thy time
27975 Is ruin'd and the soul of every man
27976 Prophetically do forethink thy fall
27977 Had I so lavish of my presence been
27978 So commonhackney'd in the eyes of men
27979 So stale and cheap to vulgar company
27980 Opinion that did help me to the crown
27981 Had still kept loyal to possession
27982 And left me in reputeless banishment
27983 A fellow of no mark nor likelihood
27984 By being seldom seen I could not stir
27985 But like a comet I Was wond'red at
27986 That men would tell their children 'This is he'
27987 Others would say 'Where Which is Bolingbroke'
27988 And then I stole all courtesy from heaven
27989 And dress'd myself in such humility
27990 That I did pluck allegiance from men's hearts
27991 Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths
27992 Even in the presence of the crowned King
27993 Thus did I keep my person fresh and new
27994 My presence like a robe pontifical
27995 Ne'er seen but wond'red at and so my state
27996 Seldom but sumptuous show'd like a feast
27997 And won by rareness such solemnity
27998 The skipping King he ambled up and down
27999 With shallow jesters and rash bavin wits
28000 Soon kindled and soon burnt carded his state
28001 Mingled his royalty with cap'ring fools
28002 Had his great name profaned with their scorns
28003 And gave his countenance against his name
28004 To laugh at gibing boys and stand the push
28005 Of every beardless vain comparative
28006 Grew a companion to the common streets
28007 Enfeoff'd himself to popularity
28008 That being dally swallowed by men's eyes
28009 They surfeited with honey and began
28010 To loathe the taste of sweetness whereof a little
28011 More than a little is by much too much
28012 So when he had occasion to be seen
28013 He was but as the cuckoo is in June
28014 Heard not regarded seen but with such eyes
28015 As sick and blunted with community
28016 Afford no extraordinary gaze
28017 Such as is bent on unlike majesty
28018 When it shines seldom in admiring eyes
28019 But rather drows'd and hung their eyelids down
28020 Slept in his face and rend'red such aspect
28021 As cloudy men use to their adversaries
28022 Being with his presence glutted gorg'd and full
28023 And in that very line Harry standest thou
28024 For thou hast lost thy princely privilege
28025 With vile participation Not an eye
28026 But is aweary of thy common sight
28027 Save mine which hath desir'd to see thee more
28028 Which now doth that I would not have it do
28029 Make blind itself with foolish tenderness
28030 Prince I shall hereafter my thricegracious lord
28031 Be more myself
28032 King For all the world
28033 As thou art to this hour was Richard then
28034 When I from France set foot at Ravenspurgh
28035 And even as I was then is Percy now
28036 Now by my sceptre and my soul to boot
28037 He hath more worthy interest to the state
28038 Than thou the shadow of succession
28039 For of no right nor colour like to right
28040 He doth fill fields with harness in the realm
28041 Turns head against the lion's armed jaws
28042 And Being no more in debt to years than thou
28043 Leads ancient lords and reverend Bishops on
28044 To bloody battles and to bruising arms
28045 What neverdying honour hath he got
28046 Against renowmed Douglas whose high deeds
28047 Whose hot incursions and great name in arms
28048 Holds from all soldiers chief majority
28049 And military title capital
28050 Through all the kingdoms that acknowledge Christ
28051 Thrice hath this Hotspur Mars in swathling clothes
28052 This infant warrior in his enterprises
28053 Discomfited great Douglas ta'en him once
28054 Enlarged him and made a friend of him
28055 To fill the mouth of deep defiance up
28056 And shake the peace and safety of our throne
28057 And what say you to this Percy Northumberland
28058 The Archbishop's Grace of York Douglas Mortimer
28059 Capitulate against us and are up
28060 But wherefore do I tell these news to thee
28061 Why Harry do I tell thee of my foes
28062 Which art my nearest and dearest enemy'
28063 Thou that art like enough through vassal fear
28064 Base inclination and the start of spleen
28065 To fight against me under Percy's pay
28066 To dog his heels and curtsy at his frowns
28067 To show how much thou art degenerate
28068 Prince Do not think so You shall not find it so
28069 And God forgive them that so much have sway'd
28070 Your Majesty's good thoughts away from me
28071 I will redeem all this on Percy's head
28072 And in the closing of some glorious day
28073 Be bold to tell you that I am your son
28074 When I will wear a garment all of blood
28075 And stain my favours in a bloody mask
28076 Which wash'd away shall scour my shame with it
28077 And that shall be the day whene'er it lights
28078 That this same child of honour and renown
28079 This gallant Hotspur this allpraised knight
28080 And your unthought of Harry chance to meet
28081 For every honour sitting on his helm
28082 Would they were multitudes and on my head
28083 My shames redoubled For the time will come
28084 That I shall make this Northern youth exchange
28085 His glorious deeds for my indignities
28086 Percy is but my factor good my lord
28087 To engross up glorious deeds on my behalf
28088 And I will call hall to so strict account
28089 That he shall render every glory up
28090 Yea even the slightest worship of his time
28091 Or I will tear the reckoning from his heart
28092 This in the name of God I promise here
28093 The which if he be pleas'd I shall perform
28094 I do beseech your Majesty may salve
28095 The longgrown wounds of my intemperance
28096 If not the end of life cancels all bands
28097 And I will die a hundred thousand deaths
28098 Ere break the smallest parcel of this vow
28099 King A hundred thousand rebels die in this
28100 Thou shalt have charge and sovereign trust herein
28101 Enter Blunt
28102 How now good Blunt Thy looks are full of speed
28103 Blunt So hath the business that I come to speak of
28104 Lord Mortimer of Scotland hath sent word
28105 That Douglas and the English rebels met
28106 The eleventh of this month at Shrewsbury
28107 A mighty and a fearful head they are
28108 If promises be kept oil every hand
28109 As ever off'red foul play in a state
28110 King The Earl of Westmoreland set forth today
28111 With him my son Lord John of Lancaster
28112 For this advertisement is five days old
28113 On Wednesday next Harry you shall set forward
28114 On Thursday we ourselves will march Our meeting
28115 Is Bridgenorth and Harry you shall march
28116 Through Gloucestershire by which account
28117 Our business valued some twelve days hence
28118 Our general forces at Bridgenorth shall meet
28119 Our hands are full of business Let's away
28120 Advantage feeds him fat while men delay Exeunt
28121 Scene III
28122 Eastcheap The Boar's Head Tavern
28123 Enter Falstaff and Bardolph
28124 Fal Bardolph am I not fall'n away vilely since this last action
28125 Do I not bate Do I not dwindle Why my skin hangs about me like
28126 an old lady's loose gown I am withered like an old apple John
28127 Well I'll repent and that suddenly while I am in some liking
28128 I shall be out of heart shortly and then I shall have no
28129 strength to repent An I have not forgotten what the inside of a
28130 church is made of I am a peppercorn a brewer's horse The
28131 inside of a church Company villanous company hath been the
28132 spoil of me
28133 Bard Sir John you are so fretful you cannot live long
28134 Fal Why there is it Come sing me a bawdy song make me merry I
28135 was as virtuously given as a gentleman need to be virtuous
28136 enough swore little dic'd not above seven times a week went to
28137 a bawdy house not above once in a quarter of an hour paid money
28138 that I borrowed three or four times lived well and in good
28139 compass and now I live out of all order out of all compass
28140 Bard Why you are so fat Sir John that you must needs be out of
28141 all compass out of all reasonable compass Sir John
28142 Fal Do thou amend thy face and I'll amend my life Thou art our
28143 admiral thou bearest the lantern in the poop but 'tis in the
28144 nose of thee Thou art the Knight of the Burning Lamp
28145 Bard Why Sir John my face does you no harm
28146 Fal No I'll be sworn I make as good use of it as many a man doth
28147 of a death'shead or a memento mori I never see thy face but I
28148 think upon hellfire and Dives that lived in purple for there he
28149 is in his robes burning burning if thou wert any way given to
28150 virtue I would swear by thy face my oath should be 'By this
28151 fire that's God's angel But thou art altogether given over
28152 and wert indeed but for the light in thy face the son of utter
28153 darkness When thou ran'st up Gadshill in the night to catch my
28154 horse if I did not think thou hadst been an ignis fatuus or a
28155 ball of wildfire there's no purchase in money O thou art a
28156 perpetual triumph an everlasting bonfirelight Thou hast saved
28157 me a thousand marks in links and torches walking with thee in
28158 the night betwixt tavern and tavern but the sack that thou hast
28159 drunk me would have bought me lights as good cheap at the dearest
28160 chandler's in Europe I have maintained that salamander of yours
28161 with fire any time this twoandthirty years God reward me for
28162 it
28163 Bard 'Sblood I would my face were in your belly
28164 Fal Godamercy so should I be sure to be heartburn'd
28165 Enter Hostess
28166 How now Dame Partlet the hen Have you enquir'd yet who pick'd
28167 my pocket
28168 Host Why Sir John what do you think Sir John Do you think I
28169 keep thieves in my house I have search'd I have enquired so
28170 has my husband man by man boy by boy servant by servant The
28171 tithe of a hair was never lost in my house before
28172 Fal Ye lie hostess Bardolph was shav'd and lost many a hair and
28173 I'll be sworn my pocket was pick'd Go to you are a woman go
28174 Host Who I No I defy thee God's light I was never call'd so
28175 in mine own house before
28176 Fal Go to I know you well enough
28177 Host No Sir John you do not know me Sir John I know you Sir
28178 John You owe me money Sir John and now you pick a quarrel to
28179 beguile me of it I bought you a dozen of shirts to your back
28180 Fal Dowlas filthy dowlas I have given them away to bakers'
28181 wives they have made bolters of them
28182 Host Now as I am a true woman holland of eight shillings an ell
28183 You owe money here besides Sir John for your diet and
28184 bydrinkings and money lent you fourandtwenty pound
28185 Fal He had his part of it let him pay
28186 Host He Alas he is poor he hath nothing
28187 Fal How Poor Look upon his face What call you rich Let them
28188 coin his nose let them coin his cheeks I'll not pay a denier
28189 What will you make a younker of me Shall I not take mine ease
28190 in mine inn but I shall have my pocket pick'd I have lost a
28191 sealring of my grandfather's worth forty mark
28192 Host O Jesu I have heard the Prince tell him I know not how oft
28193 that that ring was copper
28194 Fal How the Prince is a Jack a sneakcup 'Sblood an he were
28195 here I would cudgel him like a dog if he would say so
28196 Enter the Prince [and Poins] marching and Falstaff meets
28197 them playing upon his truncheon like a fife
28198 How now lad Is the wind in that door i faith Must we all
28199 march
28200 Bard Yea two and two Newgate fashion
28201 Host My lord I pray you hear me
28202 Prince What say'st thou Mistress Quickly How doth thy husband
28203 I love him well he is an honest man
28204 Host Good my lord hear me
28205 Fal Prithee let her alone and list to me
28206 Prince What say'st thou Jack
28207 Fal The other night I fell asleep here behind the arras and had my
28208 pocket pick'd This house is turn'd bawdy house they pick
28209 pockets
28210 Prince What didst thou lose Jack
28211 Fal Wilt thou believe me Hal Three or four bonds of forty pound
28212 apiece and a sealring of my grandfather's
28213 Prince A trifle some eightpenny matter
28214 Host So I told him my lord and I said I heard your Grace say so
28215 and my lord he speaks most vilely of you like a foulmouth'd
28216 man as he is and said he would cudgel you
28217 Prince What he did not
28218 Host There's neither faith truth nor womanhood in me else
28219 Fal There's no more faith in thee than in a stewed prune nor no
28220 more truth in thee than in a drawn fox and for womanhood Maid
28221 Marian may be the deputy's wife of the ward to thee Go you
28222 thing go
28223 Host Say what thing what thing
28224 Fal What thing Why a thing to thank God on
28225 Host I am no thing to thank God on I would thou shouldst know it
28226 I am an honest man's wife and setting thy knighthood aside
28227 thou art a knave to call me so
28228 Fal Setting thy womanhood aside thou art a beast to say
28229 otherwise
28230 Host Say what beast thou knave thou
28231 Fal What beast Why an otter
28232 Prince An otter Sir John Why an otter
28233 Fal Why she's neither fish nor flesh a man knows not where to
28234 have her
28235 Host Thou art an unjust man in saying so Thou or any man knows
28236 where to have me thou knave thou
28237 Prince Thou say'st true hostess and he slanders thee most
28238 grossly
28239 Host So he doth you my lord and said this other day you ought
28240 him a thousand pound
28241 Prince Sirrah do I owe you a thousand pound
28242 Fal A thousand pound Hal A million Thy love is worth a million
28243 thou owest me thy love
28244 Host Nay my lord he call'd you Jack and said he would cudgel
28245 you
28246 Fal Did I Bardolph
28247 Bard Indeed Sir John you said so
28248 Fal Yea if he said my ring was copper
28249 Prince I say 'tis copper Darest thou be as good as thy word now
28250 Fal Why Hal thou knowest as thou art but man I dare but as
28251 thou art Prince I fear thee as I fear the roaring of the lion's
28252 whelp
28253 Prince And why not as the lion
28254 Fal The King himself is to be feared as the lion Dost thou think
28255 I'll fear thee as I fear thy father Nay an I do I pray God my
28256 girdle break
28257 Prince O if it should how would thy guts fall about thy knees
28258 But sirrah there's no room for faith truth nor honesty in
28259 this bosom of thine It is all fill'd up with guts and midriff
28260 Charge an honest woman with picking thy pocket Why thou
28261 whoreson impudent emboss'd rascal if there were anything in
28262 thy pocket but tavern reckonings memorandums of bawdy houses
28263 and one poor pennyworth of sugar candy to make thee longwinded
28264 if thy pocket were enrich'd with any other injuries but these I
28265 am a villain And yet you will stand to it you will not pocket
28266 up wrong Art thou not ashamed
28267 Fal Dost thou hear Hal Thou knowest in the state of innocency
28268 Adam fell and what should poor Jack Falstaff do in the days of
28269 villany Thou seest I have more flesh than another man and
28270 therefore more frailty You confess then you pick'd my pocket
28271 Prince It appears so by the story
28272 Fal Hostess I forgive thee Go make ready breakfast Love thy
28273 husband look to thy servants cherish thy guests Thou shalt
28274 find me tractable to any honest reason Thou seest I am pacified
28275 Still Nay prithee be gone [Exit Hostess] Now Hal to the
28276 news at court For the robbery lad how is that answered
28277 Prince O my sweet beef I must still be good angel to thee
28278 The money is paid back again
28279 Fal O I do not like that paying back 'Tis a double labour
28280 Prince I am good friends with my father and may do anything
28281 Fal Rob me the exchequer the first thing thou doest and do it
28282 with unwash'd hands too
28283 Bard Do my lord
28284 Prince I have procured thee Jack a charge of foot
28285 Fal I would it had been of horse Where shall I find one that can
28286 steal well O for a fine thief of the age of twoandtwenty or
28287 thereabouts I am heinously unprovided Well God be thanked for
28288 these rebels They offend none but the virtuous I laud them I
28289 praise them
28290 Prince Bardolph
28291 Bard My lord
28292 Prince Go bear this letter to Lord John of Lancaster
28293 To my brother John this to my Lord of Westmoreland
28294 [Exit Bardolph]
28295 Go Poins to horse to horse for thou and I
28296 Have thirty miles to ride yet ere dinner time
28297 [Exit Poins]
28298 Jack meet me tomorrow in the Temple Hall
28299 At two o'clock in the afternoon
28300 There shalt thou know thy charge and there receive
28301 Money and order for their furniture
28302 The land is burning Percy stands on high
28303 And either they or we must lower lie [Exit]
28304 Fal Rare words brave world Hostess my breakfast come
28305 O I could wish this tavern were my drum
28306 Exit
