29979 ACT II SCENE I
29980 London A street
29981 Enter HOSTESS with two officers FANG and SNARE
29982 HOSTESS Master Fang have you ent'red the action
29983 FANG It is ent'red
29984 HOSTESS Where's your yeoman Is't a lusty yeoman Will 'a stand
29985 to't
29986 FANG Sirrah where's Snare
29987 HOSTESS O Lord ay good Master Snare
29988 SNARE Here here
29989 FANG Snare we must arrest Sir John Falstaff
29990 HOSTESS Yea good Master Snare I have ent'red him and all
29991 SNARE It may chance cost some of our lives for he will stab
29992 HOSTESS Alas the day take heed of him he stabb'd me in mine own
29993 house and that most beastly In good faith 'a cares not what
29994 mischief he does if his weapon be out he will foin like any
29995 devil he will spare neither man woman nor child
29996 FANG If I can close with him I care not for his thrust
29997 HOSTESS No nor I neither I'll be at your elbow
29998 FANG An I but fist him once an 'a come but within my vice
29999 HOSTESS I am undone by his going I warrant you he's an
30000 infinitive thing upon my score Good Master Fang hold him sure
30001 Good Master Snare let him not scape 'A comes continuantly to
30002 Piecorner saving your manhoods to buy a saddle and he is
30003 indited to dinner to the Lubber's Head in Lumbert Street to
30004 Master Smooth's the silkman I pray you since my exion is
30005 ent'red and my case so openly known to the world let him be
30006 brought in to his answer A hundred mark is a long one for a poor
30007 lone woman to bear and I have borne and borne and borne and
30008 have been fubb'd off and fubb'd off and fubb'd off from this
30009 day to that day that it is a shame to be thought on There is no
30010 honesty in such dealing unless a woman should be made an ass and
30011 a beast to bear every knave's wrong
30012 Enter SIR JOHN FALSTAFF PAGE and BARDOLPH
30013 Yonder he comes and that arrant malmseynose knave Bardolph
30014 with him Do your offices do your offices Master Fang and
30015 Master Snare do me do me do me your offices
30016 FALSTAFF How now whose mare's dead What's the matter
30017 FANG Sir John I arrest you at the suit of Mistress Quickly
30018 FALSTAFF Away varlets Draw Bardolph Cut me off the villian's
30019 head Throw the quean in the channel
30020 HOSTESS Throw me in the channel I'll throw thee in the channel
30021 Wilt thou wilt thou thou bastardly rogue Murder murder Ah
30022 thou honeysuckle villain wilt thou kill God's officers and the
30023 King's Ah thou honeyseed rogue thou art a honeyseed a
30024 manqueller and a womanqueller
30025 FALSTAFF Keep them off Bardolph
30026 FANG A rescue a rescue
30027 HOSTESS Good people bring a rescue or two Thou wot wot thou
30028 thou wot wot ta Do do thou rogue do thou hempseed
30029 PAGE Away you scullion you rampallian you fustilarian
30030 I'll tickle your catastrophe
30031 Enter the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE and his men
30032 CHIEF JUSTICE What is the matter Keep the peace here ho
30033 HOSTESS Good my lord be good to me I beseech you stand to me
30034 CHIEF JUSTICE How now Sir John what are you brawling here
30035 Doth this become your place your time and business
30036 You should have been well on your way to York
30037 Stand from him fellow wherefore hang'st thou upon him
30038 HOSTESS O My most worshipful lord an't please your Grace I am a
30039 poor widow of Eastcheap and he is arrested at my suit
30040 CHIEF JUSTICE For what sum
30041 HOSTESS It is more than for some my lord it is for all all I
30042 have He hath eaten me out of house and home he hath put all my
30043 substance into that fat belly of his But I will have some of it
30044 out again or I will ride thee a nights like a mare
30045 FALSTAFF I think I am as like to ride the mare if I have any
30046 vantage of ground to get up
30047 CHIEF JUSTICE How comes this Sir John Fie What man of good
30048 temper would endure this tempest of exclamation Are you not
30049 ashamed to enforce a poor widow to so rough a course to come by
30050 her own
30051 FALSTAFF What is the gross sum that I owe thee
30052 HOSTESS Marry if thou wert an honest man thyself and the money
30053 too Thou didst swear to me upon a parcelgilt goblet sitting in
30054 my Dolphin chamber at the round table by a seacoal fire upon
30055 Wednesday in Wheeson week when the Prince broke thy head for
30056 liking his father to singingman of Windsor thou didst swear to
30057 me then as I was washing thy wound to marry me and make me my
30058 lady thy wife Canst thou deny it Did not goodwife Keech the
30059 butcher's wife come in then and call me gossip Quickly Coming
30060 in to borrow a mess of vinegar telling us she had a good dish of
30061 prawns whereby thou didst desire to eat some whereby I told
30062 thee they were ill for green wound And didst thou not when she
30063 was gone down stairs desire me to be no more so familiarity with
30064 such poor people saying that ere long they should call me madam
30065 And didst thou not kiss me and bid me fetch the thirty
30066 shillings I put thee now to thy bookoath Deny it if thou
30067 canst
30068 FALSTAFF My lord this is a poor mad soul and she says up and
30069 down the town that her eldest son is like you She hath been in
30070 good case and the truth is poverty hath distracted her But
30071 for these foolish officers I beseech you I may have redress
30072 against them
30073 CHIEF JUSTICE Sir John Sir John I am well acquainted with your
30074 manner of wrenching the true cause the false way It is not a
30075 confident brow nor the throng of words that come with such more
30076 than impudent sauciness from you can thrust me from a level
30077 consideration You have as it appears to me practis'd upon the
30078 easy yielding spirit of this woman and made her serve your uses
30079 both in purse and in person
30080 HOSTESS Yea in truth my lord
30081 CHIEF JUSTICE Pray thee peace Pay her the debt you owe her and
30082 unpay the villainy you have done with her the one you may do
30083 with sterling money and the other with current repentance
30084 FALSTAFF My lord I will not undergo this sneap without reply You
30085 call honourable boldness impudent sauciness if a man will make
30086 curtsy and say nothing he is virtuous No my lord my humble
30087 duty rememb'red I will not be your suitor I say to you I do
30088 desire deliverance from these officers being upon hasty
30089 employment in the King's affairs
30090 CHIEF JUSTICE You speak as having power to do wrong but answer in
30091 th effect of your reputation and satisfy the poor woman
30092 FALSTAFF Come hither hostess
30093 Enter GOWER
30094 CHIEF JUSTICE Now Master Gower what news
30095 GOWER The King my lord and Harry Prince of Wales
30096 Are near at hand The rest the paper tells [Gives a letter]
30097 FALSTAFF As I am a gentleman
30098 HOSTESS Faith you said so before
30099 FALSTAFF As I am a gentleman Come no more words of it
30100 HOSTESS By this heavenly ground I tread on I must be fain to pawn
30101 both my plate and the tapestry of my diningchambers
30102 FALSTAFF Glasses glasses is the only drinking and for thy
30103 walls a pretty slight drollery or the story of the Prodigal or
30104 the German hunting in waterwork is worth a thousand of these
30105 bedhangers and these flybitten tapestries Let it be ten pound
30106 if thou canst Come and 'twere not for thy humours there's not
30107 a better wench in England Go wash thy face and draw the
30108 action Come thou must not be in this humour with me dost not
30109 know me Come come I know thou wast set on to this
30110 HOSTESS Pray thee Sir John let it be but twenty nobles
30111 i faith I am loath to pawn my plate so God save me la
30112 FALSTAFF Let it alone I'll make other shift You'll be a fool
30113 still
30114 HOSTESS Well you shall have it though I pawn my gown
30115 I hope you'll come to supper you'll pay me all together
30116 FALSTAFF Will I live [To BARDOLPH] Go with her with her hook
30117 on hook on
30118 HOSTESS Will you have Doll Tearsheet meet you at supper
30119 FALSTAFF No more words let's have her
30120 Exeunt HOSTESS BARDOLPH and OFFICERS
30121 CHIEF JUSTICE I have heard better news
30122 FALSTAFF What's the news my lord
30123 CHIEF JUSTICE Where lay the King tonight
30124 GOWER At Basingstoke my lord
30125 FALSTAFF I hope my lord all's well What is the news my lord
30126 CHIEF JUSTICE Come all his forces back
30127 GOWER No fifteen hundred foot five hundred horse
30128 Are march'd up to my Lord of Lancaster
30129 Against Northumberland and the Archbishop
30130 FALSTAFF Comes the King back from Wales my noble lord
30131 CHIEF JUSTICE You shall have letters of me presently
30132 Come go along with me good Master Gower
30133 FALSTAFF My lord
30134 CHIEF JUSTICE What's the matter
30135 FALSTAFF Master Gower shall I entreat you with me to dinner
30136 GOWER I must wait upon my good lord here I thank you good Sir
30137 John
30138 CHIEF JUSTICE Sir John you loiter here too long being you are to
30139 take soldiers up in counties as you go
30140 FALSTAFF Will you sup with me Master Gower
30141 CHIEF JUSTICE What foolish master taught you these manners Sir
30142 John
30143 FALSTAFF Master Gower if they become me not he was a fool that
30144 taught them me This is the right fencing grace my lord tap for
30145 tap and so part fair
30146 CHIEF JUSTICE Now the Lord lighten thee Thou art a great fool
30147 Exeunt
30148 SCENE II
30149 London Another street
30150 Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS
30151 PRINCE Before God I am exceeding weary
30152 POINS Is't come to that I had thought weariness durst not have
30153 attach'd one of so high blood
30154 PRINCE Faith it does me though it discolours the complexion of
30155 my greatness to acknowledge it Doth it not show vilely in me to
30156 desire small beer
30157 POINS Why a prince should not be so loosely studied as to
30158 remember so weak a composition
30159 PRINCE Belike then my appetite was notprincely got for by my
30160 troth I do now remember the poor creature small beer But
30161 indeed these humble considerations make me out of love with my
30162 greatness What a disgrace is it to me to remember thy name or
30163 to know thy face tomorrow or to take note how many pair of silk
30164 stockings thou hast viz these and those that were thy
30165 peachcolour'd ones or to bear the inventory of thy shirts as
30166 one for superfluity and another for use But that the
30167 tenniscourtkeeper knows better than I for it is a low ebb of
30168 linen with thee when thou keepest not racket there as thou hast
30169 not done a great while because the rest of thy low countries
30170 have made a shift to eat up thy holland And God knows whether
30171 those that bawl out of the ruins of thy linen shall inherit his
30172 kingdom but the midwives say the children are not in the fault
30173 whereupon the world increases and kindreds are mightily
30174 strengthened
30175 POINS How ill it follows after you have laboured so hard you
30176 should talk so idly Tell me how many good young princes would
30177 do so their fathers being so sick as yours at this time is
30178 PRINCE Shall I tell thee one thing Poins
30179 POINS Yes faith and let it be an excellent good thing
30180 PRINCE It shall serve among wits of no higher breeding than thine
30181 POINS Go to I stand the push of your one thing that you will
30182 tell
30183 PRINCE Marry I tell thee it is not meet that I should be sad now
30184 my father is sick albeit I could tell to thee as to one it
30185 pleases me for fault of a better to call my friend I could be
30186 sad and sad indeed too
30187 POINS Very hardly upon such a subject
30188 PRINCE By this hand thou thinkest me as far in the devil's book
30189 as thou and Falstaff for obduracy and persistency let the end
30190 try the man But I tell thee my heart bleeds inwardly that my
30191 father is so sick and keeping such vile company as thou art hath
30192 in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow
30193 POINS The reason
30194 PRINCE What wouldst thou think of me if I should weep
30195 POINS I would think thee a most princely hypocrite
30196 PRINCE It would be every man's thought and thou art a blessed
30197 fellow to think as every man thinks Never a man's thought in the
30198 world keeps the roadway better than thine Every man would think
30199 me an hypocrite indeed And what accites your most worshipful
30200 thought to think so
30201 POINS Why because you have been so lewd and so much engraffed to
30202 Falstaff
30203 PRINCE And to thee
30204 POINS By this light I am well spoke on I can hear it with mine
30205 own ears The worst that they can say of me is that I am a second
30206 brother and that I am a proper fellow of my hands and those two
30207 things I confess I cannot help By the mass here comes
30208 Bardolph
30209 Enter BARDOLPH and PAGE
30210 PRINCE And the boy that I gave Falstaff 'A had him from me
30211 Christian and look if the fat villain have not transform'd him
30212 ape
30213 BARDOLPH God save your Grace
30214 PRINCE And yours most noble Bardolph
30215 POINS Come you virtuous ass you bashful fool must you be
30216 blushing Wherefore blush you now What a maidenly manatarms
30217 are you become Is't such a matter to get a pottlepot's
30218 maidenhead
30219 PAGE 'A calls me e'en now my lord through a red lattice and I
30220 could discern no part of his face from the window At last I
30221 spied his eyes and methought he had made two holes in the
30222 alewife's new petticoat and so peep'd through
30223 PRINCE Has not the boy profited
30224 BARDOLPH Away you whoreson upright rabbit away
30225 PAGE Away you rascally Althaea's dream away
30226 PRINCE Instruct us boy what dream boy
30227 PAGE Marry my lord Althaea dreamt she was delivered of a
30228 firebrand and therefore I call him her dream
30229 PRINCE A crown's worth of good interpretation There 'tis boy
30230 [Giving a crown]
30231 POINS O that this blossom could be kept from cankers
30232 Well there is sixpence to preserve thee
30233 BARDOLPH An you do not make him be hang'd among you the gallows
30234 shall have wrong
30235 PRINCE And how doth thy master Bardolph
30236 BARDOLPH Well my lord He heard of your Grace's coming to town
30237 There's a letter for you
30238 POINS Deliver'd with good respect And how doth the martlemas
30239 your master
30240 BARDOLPH In bodily health sir
30241 POINS Marry the immortal part needs a physician but that moves
30242 not him Though that be sick it dies not
30243 PRINCE I do allow this well to be as familiar with me as my dog
30244 and he holds his place for look you how he writes
30245 POINS [Reads] 'John Falstaff knight Every man must know that
30246 as oft as he has occasion to name himself even like those that
30247 are kin to the King for they never prick their finger but they
30248 say 'There's some of the King's blood spilt 'How comes that'
30249 says he that takes upon him not to conceive The answer is as
30250 ready as a borrower's cap 'I am the King's poor cousin sir'
30251 PRINCE Nay they will be kin to us or they will fetch it from
30252 Japhet But the letter [Reads] 'Sir John Falstaff knight to
30253 the son of the King nearest his father Harry Prince of Wales
30254 greeting'
30255 POINS Why this is a certificate
30256 PRINCE Peace [Reads] 'I will imitate the honourable Romans in
30257 brevity'
30258 POINS He sure means brevity in breath shortwinded
30259 PRINCE [Reads] 'I commend me to thee I commend thee and I
30260 leave thee Be not too familiar with Poins for he misuses thy
30261 favours so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister Nell
30262 Repent at idle times as thou mayst and so farewell
30263 Thine by yea and no which is as much as to say as
30264 thou usest him JACK FALSTAFF with my familiars
30265 JOHN with my brothers and sisters and SIR JOHN with
30266 all Europe'
30267 POINS My lord I'll steep this letter in sack and make him eat it
30268 PRINCE That's to make him eat twenty of his words But do you use
30269 me thus Ned Must I marry your sister
30270 POINS God send the wench no worse fortune But I never said so
30271 PRINCE Well thus we play the fools with the time and the spirits
30272 of the wise sit in the clouds and mock us Is your master here in
30273 London
30274 BARDOLPH Yea my lord
30275 PRINCE Where sups he Doth the old boar feed in the old frank
30276 BARDOLPH At the old place my lord in Eastcheap
30277 PRINCE What company
30278 PAGE Ephesians my lord of the old church
30279 PRINCE Sup any women with him
30280 PAGE None my lord but old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll
30281 Tearsheet
30282 PRINCE What pagan may that be
30283 PAGE A proper gentlewoman sir and a kinswoman of my master's
30284 PRINCE Even such kin as the parish heifers are to the town bull
30285 Shall we steal upon them Ned at supper
30286 POINS I am your shadow my lord I'll follow you
30287 PRINCE Sirrah you boy and Bardolph no word to your master that
30288 I am yet come to town There's for your silence
30289 BARDOLPH I have no tongue sir
30290 PAGE And for mine sir I will govern it
30291 PRINCE Fare you well go Exeunt BARDOLPH and PAGE
30292 This Doll Tearsheet should be some road
30293 POINS I warrant you as common as the way between Saint Albans and
30294 London
30295 PRINCE How might we see Falstaff bestow himself tonight in his
30296 true colours and not ourselves be seen
30297 POINS Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons and wait upon him at
30298 his table as drawers
30299 PRINCE From a god to a bull A heavy descension It was Jove's
30300 case From a prince to a prentice A low transformation That
30301 shall be mine for in everything the purpose must weigh with the
30302 folly Follow me Ned
30303 Exeunt
30304 SCENE III
30305 Warkworth Before the castle
30306 Enter NORTHUMBERLAND LADY NORTHUMBERLAND and LADY PERCY
30307 NORTHUMBERLAND I pray thee loving wife and gentle daughter
30308 Give even way unto my rough affairs
30309 Put not you on the visage of the times
30310 And be like them to Percy troublesome
30311 LADY NORTHUMBERLAND I have given over I will speak no more
30312 Do what you will your wisdom be your guide
30313 NORTHUMBERLAND Alas sweet wife my honour is at pawn
30314 And but my going nothing can redeem it
30315 LADY PERCY O yet for God's sake go not to these wars
30316 The time was father that you broke your word
30317 When you were more endear'd to it than now
30318 When your own Percy when my heart's dear Harry
30319 Threw many a northward look to see his father
30320 Bring up his powers but he did long in vain
30321 Who then persuaded you to stay at home
30322 There were two honours lost yours and your son's
30323 For yours the God of heaven brighten it
30324 For his it stuck upon him as the sun
30325 In the grey vault of heaven and by his light
30326 Did all the chivalry of England move
30327 To do brave acts He was indeed the glass
30328 Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves
30329 He had no legs that practis'd not his gait
30330 And speaking thick which nature made his blemish
30331 Became the accents of the valiant
30332 For those who could speak low and tardily
30333 Would turn their own perfection to abuse
30334 To seem like him so that in speech in gait
30335 In diet in affections of delight
30336 In military rules humours of blood
30337 He was the mark and glass copy and book
30338 That fashion'd others And him O wondrous him
30339 O miracle of men him did you leave
30340 Second to none unseconded by you
30341 To look upon the hideous god of war
30342 In disadvantage to abide a field
30343 Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur's name
30344 Did seem defensible So you left him
30345 Never O never do his ghost the wrong
30346 To hold your honour more precise and nice
30347 With others than with him Let them alone
30348 The Marshal and the Archbishop are strong
30349 Had my sweet Harry had but half their numbers
30350 Today might I hanging on Hotspur's neck
30351 Have talk'd of Monmouth's grave
30352 NORTHUMBERLAND Beshrew your heart
30353 Fair daughter you do draw my spirits from me
30354 With new lamenting ancient oversights
30355 But I must go and meet with danger there
30356 Or it will seek me in another place
30357 And find me worse provided
30358 LADY NORTHUMBERLAND O fly to Scotland
30359 Till that the nobles and the armed commons
30360 Have of their puissance made a little taste
30361 LADY PERCY If they get ground and vantage of the King
30362 Then join you with them like a rib of steel
30363 To make strength stronger but for all our loves
30364 First let them try themselves So did your son
30365 He was so suff'red so came I a widow
30366 And never shall have length of life enough
30367 To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes
30368 That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven
30369 For recordation to my noble husband
30370 NORTHUMBERLAND Come come go in with me 'Tis with my mind
30371 As with the tide swell'd up unto his height
30372 That makes a stillstand running neither way
30373 Fain would I go to meet the Archbishop
30374 But many thousand reasons hold me back
30375 I will resolve for Scotland There am I
30376 Till time and vantage crave my company Exeunt
30377 SCENE IV
30378 London The Boar's Head Tavern in Eastcheap
30379 Enter FRANCIS and another DRAWER
30380 FRANCIS What the devil hast thou brought thereapplejohns Thou
30381 knowest Sir John cannot endure an applejohn
30382 SECOND DRAWER Mass thou say'st true The Prince once set a dish
30383 of applejohns before him and told him there were five more Sir
30384 Johns and putting off his hat said 'I will now take my leave
30385 of these six dry round old withered knights It ang'red him
30386 to the heart but he hath forgot that
30387 FRANCIS Why then cover and set them down and see if thou canst
30388 find out Sneak's noise Mistress Tearsheet would fain hear some
30389 music
30390 Enter third DRAWER
30391 THIRD DRAWER Dispatch The room where they supp'd is too hot
30392 they'll come in straight
30393 FRANCIS Sirrah here will be the Prince and Master Poins anon and
30394 they will put on two of our jerkins and aprons and Sir John must
30395 not know of it Bardolph hath brought word
30396 THIRD DRAWER By the mass here will be old uds it will be an
30397 excellent stratagem
30398 SECOND DRAWER I'll see if I can find out Sneak
30399 Exeunt second and third DRAWERS
30400 Enter HOSTESS and DOLL TEARSHEET
30401 HOSTESS I faith sweetheart methinks now you are in an excellent
30402 good temperality Your pulsidge beats as extraordinarily as heart
30403 would desire and your colour I warrant you is as red as any
30404 rose in good truth la But i faith you have drunk too much
30405 canaries and that's a marvellous searching wine and it perfumes
30406 the blood ere one can say 'What's this How do you now
30407 DOLL Better than I was hem
30408 HOSTESS Why that's well said a good heart's worth gold
30409 Lo here comes Sir John
30410 Enter FALSTAFF
30411 FALSTAFF [Singing] 'When Arthur first in court Empty the
30412 jordan [Exit FRANCIS] [Singing] 'And was a worthy king How
30413 now Mistress Doll
30414 HOSTESS Sick of a calm yea good faith
30415 FALSTAFF So is all her sect and they be once in a calm they are
30416 sick
30417 DOLL A pox damn you you muddy rascal Is that all the comfort you
30418 give me
30419 FALSTAFF You make fat rascals Mistress Doll
30420 DOLL I make them Gluttony and diseases make them I make them
30421 not
30422 FALSTAFF If the cook help to make the gluttony you help to make
30423 the diseases Doll We catch of you Doll we catch of you grant
30424 that my poor virtue grant that
30425 DOLL Yea joy our chains and our jewels
30426 FALSTAFF 'Your brooches pearls and ouches For to serve bravely
30427 is to come halting off you know to come off the breach with his
30428 pike bent bravely and to surgery bravely to venture upon the
30429 charg'd chambers bravely
30430 DOLL Hang yourself you muddy conger hang yourself
30431 HOSTESS By my troth this is the old fashion you two never meet
30432 but you fall to some discord You are both i good truth as
30433 rheumatic as two dry toasts you cannot one bear with another's
30434 confirmities What the goodyear one must bear and that must be
30435 you You are the weaker vessel as as they say the emptier
30436 vessel
30437 DOLL Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full hogshead
30438 There's a whole merchant's venture of Bourdeaux stuff in him you
30439 have not seen a hulk better stuff'd in the hold Come I'll be
30440 friends with thee Jack Thou art going to the wars and whether
30441 I shall ever see thee again or no there is nobody cares
30442 Reenter FRANCIS
30443 FRANCIS Sir Ancient Pistol's below and would speak with you
30444 DOLL Hang him swaggering rascal Let him not come hither it is
30445 the foulmouth'dst rogue in England
30446 HOSTESS If he swagger let him not come here No by my faith I
30447 must live among my neighbours I'll no swaggerers I am in good
30448 name and fame with the very best Shut the door There comes no
30449 swaggerers here I have not liv'd all this while to have
30450 swaggering now Shut the door I pray you
30451 FALSTAFF Dost thou hear hostess
30452 HOSTESS Pray ye pacify yourself Sir John there comes no
30453 swaggerers here
30454 FALSTAFF Dost thou hear It is mine ancient
30455 HOSTESS Tillyfally Sir John ne'er tell me and your ancient
30456 swagg'rer comes not in my doors I was before Master Tisick the
30457 debuty t other day and as he said to me 'twas no longer ago
30458 than Wednesday last i good faith 'Neighbour Quickly says
30459 he Master Dumbe our minister was by then 'Neighbour Quickly'
30460 says he 'receive those that are civil for said he 'you are in
30461 an ill name Now 'a said so I can tell whereupon 'For says he
30462 'you are an honest woman and well thought on therefore take heed
30463 what guests you receive Receive says he 'no swaggering
30464 companions There comes none here You would bless you to hear
30465 what he said No I'll no swagg'rers
30466 FALSTAFF He's no swagg'rer hostess a tame cheater i faith you
30467 may stroke him as gently as a puppy greyhound He'll not swagger
30468 with a Barbary hen if her feathers turn back in any show of
30469 resistance Call him up drawer
30470 Exit FRANCIS
30471 HOSTESS Cheater call you him I will bar no honest man my house
30472 nor no cheater but I do not love swaggering by my troth I am
30473 the worse when one says 'swagger Feel masters how I shake
30474 look you I warrant you
30475 DOLL So you do hostess
30476 HOSTESS Do I Yea in very truth do I an 'twere an aspen leaf I
30477 cannot abide swagg'rers
30478 Enter PISTOL BARDOLPH and PAGE
30479 PISTOL God save you Sir John
30480 FALSTAFF Welcome Ancient Pistol Here Pistol I charge you with
30481 a cup of sack do you discharge upon mine hostess
30482 PISTOL I will discharge upon her Sir John with two bullets
30483 FALSTAFF She is pistolproof sir you shall not hardly offend
30484 her
30485 HOSTESS Come I'll drink no proofs nor no bullets I'll drink no
30486 more than will do me good for no man's pleasure I
30487 PISTOL Then to you Mistress Dorothy I will charge you
30488 DOLL Charge me I scorn you scurvy companion What you poor
30489 base rascally cheating lacklinen mate Away you mouldy
30490 rogue away I am meat for your master
30491 PISTOL I know you Mistress Dorothy
30492 DOLL Away you cutpurse rascal you filthy bung away By this
30493 wine I'll thrust my knife in your mouldy chaps an you play the
30494 saucy cuttle with me Away you bottleale rascal you
30495 baskethilt stale juggler you Since when I pray you sir
30496 God's light with two points on your shoulder Much
30497 PISTOL God let me not live but I will murder your ruff for this
30498 FALSTAFF No more Pistol I would not have you go off here
30499 Discharge yourself of our company Pistol
30500 HOSTESS No good Captain Pistol not here sweet captain
30501 DOLL Captain Thou abominable damn'd cheater art thou not ashamed
30502 to be called captain An captains were of my mind they would
30503 truncheon you out for taking their names upon you before you
30504 have earn'd them You a captain you slave for what For tearing
30505 a poor whore's ruff in a bawdyhouse He a captain hang him
30506 rogue He lives upon mouldy stew'd prunes and dried cakes A
30507 captain God's light these villains will make the word as odious
30508 as the word 'occupy which was an excellent good word before it
30509 was ill sorted Therefore captains had need look to't
30510 BARDOLPH Pray thee go down good ancient
30511 FALSTAFF Hark thee hither Mistress Doll
30512 PISTOL Not I I tell thee what Corporal Bardolph I could tear
30513 her I'll be reveng'd of her
30514 PAGE Pray thee go down
30515 PISTOL I'll see her damn'd first to Pluto's damn'd lake by this
30516 hand to th infernal deep with Erebus and tortures vile also
30517 Hold hook and line say I Down down dogs down faitors Have
30518 we not Hiren here
30519 HOSTESS Good Captain Peesel be quiet 'tis very late i faith I
30520 beseek you now aggravate your choler
30521 PISTOL These be good humours indeed Shall packhorses
30522 And hollow pamper'd jades of Asia
30523 Which cannot go but thirty mile a day
30524 Compare with Caesars and with Cannibals
30525 And Troiant Greeks Nay rather damn them with
30526 King Cerberus and let the welkin roar
30527 Shall we fall foul for toys
30528 HOSTESS By my troth Captain these are very bitter words
30529 BARDOLPH Be gone good ancient this will grow to a brawl anon
30530 PISTOL Die men like dogs Give crowns like pins Have we not Hiren
30531 here
30532 HOSTESS O my word Captain there's none such here What the
30533 goodyear do you think I would deny her For God's sake be
30534 quiet
30535 PISTOL Then feed and be fat my fair Calipolis
30536 Come give's some sack
30537 'Si fortune me tormente sperato me contento'
30538 Fear we broadsides No let the fiend give fire
30539 Give me some sack and sweetheart lie thou there
30540 [Laying down his sword]
30541 Come we to full points here and are etceteras nothings
30542 FALSTAFF Pistol I would be quiet
30543 PISTOL Sweet knight I kiss thy neaf What we have seen the seven
30544 stars
30545 DOLL For God's sake thrust him down stairs I cannot endure such a
30546 fustian rascal
30547 PISTOL Thrust him down stairs Know we not Galloway nags
30548 FALSTAFF Quoit him down Bardolph like a shovegroat shilling
30549 Nay an 'a do nothing but speak nothing 'a shall be nothing
30550 here
30551 BARDOLPH Come get you down stairs
30552 PISTOL What shall we have incision Shall we imbrue
30553 [Snatching up his sword]
30554 Then death rock me asleep abridge my doleful days
30555 Why then let grievous ghastly gaping wounds
30556 Untwine the Sisters Three Come Atropos I say
30557 HOSTESS Here's goodly stuff toward
30558 FALSTAFF Give me my rapier boy
30559 DOLL I pray thee Jack I pray thee do not draw
30560 FALSTAFF Get you down stairs
30561 [Drawing and driving PISTOL out]
30562 HOSTESS Here's a goodly tumult I'll forswear keeping house afore
30563 I'll be in these tirrits and frights So murder I warrant now
30564 Alas alas put up your naked weapons put up your naked weapons
30565 Exeunt PISTOL and BARDOLPH
30566 DOLL I pray thee Jack be quiet the rascal's gone Ah you
30567 whoreson little valiant villain you
30568 HOSTESS Are you not hurt i th groin Methought 'a made a shrewd
30569 thrust at your belly
30570 Reenter BARDOLPH
30571 FALSTAFF Have you turn'd him out a doors
30572 BARDOLPH Yea sir The rascal's drunk You have hurt him sir i'
30573 th shoulder
30574 FALSTAFF A rascal to brave me
30575 DOLL Ah you sweet little rogue you Alas poor ape how thou
30576 sweat'st Come let me wipe thy face Come on you whoreson
30577 chops Ah rogue i faith I love thee Thou art as valorous as
30578 Hector of Troy worth five of Agamemnon and ten times better
30579 than the Nine Worthies Ah villain
30580 FALSTAFF A rascally slave I will toss the rogue in a blanket
30581 DOLL Do an thou dar'st for thy heart An thou dost I'll canvass
30582 thee between a pair of sheets
30583 Enter musicians
30584 PAGE The music is come sir
30585 FALSTAFF Let them play Play sirs Sit on my knee Don A rascal
30586 bragging slave The rogue fled from me like quicksilver
30587 DOLL I faith and thou follow'dst him like a church Thou
30588 whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boarpig when wilt thou leave
30589 fighting a days and foining a nights and begin to patch up thine
30590 old body for heaven
30591 Enter behind PRINCE HENRY and POINS disguised as drawers
30592 FALSTAFF Peace good Doll Do not speak like a death'shead do
30593 not bid me remember mine end
30594 DOLL Sirrah what humour's the Prince of
30595 FALSTAFF A good shallow young fellow 'A would have made a good
30596 pantler 'a would ha chipp'd bread well
30597 DOLL They say Poins has a good wit
30598 FALSTAFF He a good wit hang him baboon His wit's as thick as
30599 Tewksbury mustard there's no more conceit in him than is in a
30600 mallet
30601 DOLL Why does the Prince love him so then
30602 FALSTAFF Because their legs are both of a bigness and 'a plays at
30603 quoits well and eats conger and fennel and drinks off candles'
30604 ends for flapdragons and rides the wild mare with the boys and
30605 jumps upon join'dstools and swears with a good grace and wears
30606 his boots very smooth like unto the sign of the Leg and breeds
30607 no bate with telling of discreet stories and such other gambol
30608 faculties 'a has that show a weak mind and an able body for the
30609 which the Prince admits him For the Prince himself is such
30610 another the weight of a hair will turn the scales between their
30611 avoirdupois
30612 PRINCE Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut off
30613 POINS Let's beat him before his whore
30614 PRINCE Look whe'er the wither'd elder hath not his poll claw'd
30615 like a parrot
30616 POINS Is it not strange that desire should so many years outlive
30617 performance
30618 FALSTAFF Kiss me Doll
30619 PRINCE Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction What says th'
30620 almanac to that
30621 POINS And look whether the fiery Trigon his man be not lisping
30622 to his master's old tables his notebook his counselkeeper
30623 FALSTAFF Thou dost give me flattering busses
30624 DOLL By my troth I kiss thee with a most constant heart
30625 FALSTAFF I am old I am old
30626 DOLL I love thee better than I love e'er a scurvy young boy of
30627 them all
30628 FALSTAFF What stuff wilt have a kirtle of I shall receive money a
30629 Thursday Shalt have a cap tomorrow A merry song come 'A
30630 grows late we'll to bed Thou't forget me when I am gone
30631 DOLL By my troth thou't set me aweeping an thou say'st so
30632 Prove that ever I dress myself handsome till thy return Well
30633 hearken a th end
30634 FALSTAFF Some sack Francis
30635 PRINCE & POINS Anon anon sir [Advancing]
30636 FALSTAFF Ha a bastard son of the King's And art thou not Poins
30637 his brother
30638 PRINCE Why thou globe of sinful continents what a life dost thou
30639 lead
30640 FALSTAFF A better than thou I am a gentleman thou art a drawer
30641 PRINCE Very true sir and I come to draw you out by the ears
30642 HOSTESS O the Lord preserve thy Grace By my troth welcome to
30643 London Now the Lord bless that sweet face of thine O Jesu are
30644 you come from Wales
30645 FALSTAFF Thou whoreson mad compound of majesty by this light
30646 flesh and corrupt blood thou art welcome
30647 [Leaning his band upon DOLL]
30648 DOLL How you fat fool I scorn you
30649 POINS My lord he will drive you out of your revenge and turn all
30650 to a merriment if you take not the heat
30651 PRINCE YOU whoreson candlemine you how vilely did you speak of
30652 me even now before this honest virtuous civil gentlewoman
30653 HOSTESS God's blessing of your good heart and so she is by my
30654 troth
30655 FALSTAFF Didst thou hear me
30656 PRINCE Yea and you knew me as you did when you ran away by
30657 Gadshill You knew I was at your back and spoke it on purpose to
30658 try my patience
30659 FALSTAFF No no no not so I did not think thou wast within
30660 hearing
30661 PRINCE I shall drive you then to confess the wilful abuse and
30662 then I know how to handle you
30663 FALSTAFF No abuse Hal o mine honour no abuse
30664 PRINCE Not to dispraise me and call me pander and
30665 breadchipper and I know not what
30666 FALSTAFF No abuse Hal
30667 POINS No abuse
30668 FALSTAFF No abuse Ned i th world honest Ned none I
30669 disprais'd him before the wicked that the wicked might not fall
30670 in love with thee in which doing I have done the part of a
30671 careful friend and a true subject and thy father is to give me
30672 thanks for it No abuse Hal none Ned none no faith boys
30673 none
30674 PRINCE See now whether pure fear and entire cowardice doth not
30675 make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to close with us Is
30676 she of the wicked Is thine hostess here of the wicked Or is thy
30677 boy of the wicked Or honest Bardolph whose zeal burns in his
30678 nose of the wicked
30679 POINS Answer thou dead elm answer
30680 FALSTAFF The fiend hath prick'd down Bardolph irrecoverable and
30681 his face is Lucifer's privykitchen where he doth nothing but
30682 roast maltworms For the boy there is a good angel about him
30683 but the devil outbids him too
30684 PRINCE For the women
30685 FALSTAFF For one of them she's in hell already and burns poor
30686 souls For th other I owe her money and whether she be damn'd
30687 for that I know not
30688 HOSTESS No I warrant you
30689 FALSTAFF No I think thou art not I think thou art quit for that
30690 Marry there is another indictment upon thee for suffering flesh
30691 to be eaten in thy house contrary to the law for the which I
30692 think thou wilt howl
30693 HOSTESS All vict'lers do so What's a joint of mutton or two in a
30694 whole Lent
30695 PRINCE You gentlewoman
30696 DOLL What says your Grace
30697 FALSTAFF His Grace says that which his flesh rebels against
30698 [Knocking within]
30699 HOSTESS Who knocks so loud at door Look to th door there
30700 Francis
30701 Enter PETO
30702 PRINCE Peto how now What news
30703 PETO The King your father is at Westminster
30704 And there are twenty weak and wearied posts
30705 Come from the north and as I came along
30706 I met and overtook a dozen captains
30707 Bareheaded sweating knocking at the taverns
30708 And asking every one for Sir John Falstaff
30709 PRINCE By heaven Poins I feel me much to blame
30710 So idly to profane the precious time
30711 When tempest of commotion like the south
30712 Borne with black vapour doth begin to melt
30713 And drop upon our bare unarmed heads
30714 Give me my sword and cloak Falstaff good night
30715 Exeunt PRINCE POINS PETO and BARDOLPH
30716 FALSTAFF Now comes in the sweetest morsel of the night and we
30717 must hence and leave it unpick'd [Knocking within] More
30718 knocking at the door
30719 Reenter BARDOLPH
30720 How now What's the matter
30721 BARDOLPH You must away to court sir presently
30722 A dozen captains stay at door for you
30723 FALSTAFF [To the PAGE] Pay the musicians sirrah Farewell
30724 hostess farewell Doll You see my good wenches how men of
30725 merit are sought after the undeserver may sleep when the man of
30726 action is call'd on Farewell good wenches If I be not sent
30727 away post I will see you again ere I go
30728 DOLL I cannot speak If my heart be not ready to burst
30729 Well sweet Jack have a care of thyself
30730 FALSTAFF Farewell farewell
30731 Exeunt FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH
30732 HOSTESS Well fare thee well I have known thee these twentynine
30733 years come peascodtime but an honester and truerhearted man
30734 well fare thee well
30735 BARDOLPH [ Within] Mistress Tearsheet
30736 HOSTESS What's the matter
30737 BARDOLPH [ Within] Bid Mistress Tearsheet come to my master
30738 HOSTESS O run Doll run run good Come [To BARDOLPH] She
30739 comes blubber'd Yea will you come Doll Exeunt

30741 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
30742 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE

30748 ACT III SCENE I
30749 Westminster The palace
30750 Enter the KING in his nightgown with a page
30751 KING Go call the Earls of Surrey and of Warwick
30752 But ere they come bid them o'erread these letters
30753 And well consider of them Make good speed Exit page
30754 How many thousands of my poorest subjects
30755 Are at this hour asleep O sleep O gentle sleep
30756 Nature's soft nurse how have I frightened thee
30757 That thou no more will weigh my eyelids down
30758 And steep my senses in forgetfulness
30759 Why rather sleep liest thou in smoky cribs
30760 Upon uneasy pallets stretching thee
30761 And hush'd with buzzing nightflies to thy slumber
30762 Than in the perfum'd chambers of the great
30763 Under the canopies of costly state
30764 And lull'd with sound of sweetest melody
30765 O thou dull god why liest thou with the vile
30766 In loathsome beds and leav'st the kingly couch
30767 A watchcase or a common 'larumbell
30768 Wilt thou upon the high and giddy mast
30769 Seal up the shipboy's eyes and rock his brains
30770 In cradle of the rude imperious surge
30771 And in the visitation of the winds
30772 Who take the ruffian billows by the top
30773 Curling their monstrous heads and hanging them
30774 With deafing clamour in the slippery clouds
30775 That with the hurly death itself awakes
30776 Canst thou O partial sleep give thy repose
30777 To the wet seaboy in an hour so rude
30778 And in the calmest and most stillest night
30779 With all appliances and means to boot
30780 Deny it to a king Then happy low lie down
30781 Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown
30782 Enter WARWICK and Surrey
30783 WARWICK Many good morrows to your Majesty
30784 KING Is it good morrow lords
30785 WARWICK 'Tis one o'clock and past
30786 KING Why then good morrow to you all my lords
30787 Have you read o'er the letters that I sent you
30788 WARWICK We have my liege
30789 KING Then you perceive the body of our kingdom
30790 How foul it is what rank diseases grow
30791 And with what danger near the heart of it
30792 WARWICK It is but as a body yet distempered
30793 Which to his former strength may be restored
30794 With good advice and little medicine
30795 My Lord Northumberland will soon be cool'd
30796 KING O God that one might read the book of fate
30797 And see the revolution of the times
30798 Make mountains level and the continent
30799 Weary of solid firmness melt itself
30800 Into the sea and other times to see
30801 The beachy girdle of the ocean
30802 Too wide for Neptune's hips how chances mock
30803 And changes fill the cup of alteration
30804 With divers liquors O if this were seen
30805 The happiest youth viewing his progress through
30806 What perils past what crosses to ensue
30807 Would shut the book and sit him down and die
30808 'Tis not ten years gone
30809 Since Richard and Northumberland great friends
30810 Did feast together and in two years after
30811 Were they at wars It is but eight years since
30812 This Percy was the man nearest my soul
30813 Who like a brother toil'd in my affairs
30814 And laid his love and life under my foot
30815 Yea for my sake even to the eyes of Richard
30816 Gave him defiance But which of you was by
30817 [To WARWICK] You cousin Nevil as I may remember
30818 When Richard with his eye brim full of tears
30819 Then check'd and rated by Northumberland
30820 Did speak these words now prov'd a prophecy
30821 'Northumberland thou ladder by the which
30822 My cousin Bolingbroke ascends my throne'
30823 Though then God knows I had no such intent
30824 But that necessity so bow'd the state
30825 That I and greatness were compell'd to kiss
30826 'The time shall come thus did he follow it
30827 'The time will come that foul sin gathering head
30828 Shall break into corruption so went on
30829 Foretelling this same time's condition
30830 And the division of our amity
30831 WARWICK There is a history in all men's lives
30832 Figuring the natures of the times deceas'd
30833 The which observ'd a man may prophesy
30834 With a near aim of the main chance of things
30835 As yet not come to life who in their seeds
30836 And weak beginning lie intreasured
30837 Such things become the hatch and brood of time
30838 And by the necessary form of this
30839 King Richard might create a perfect guess
30840 That great Northumberland then false to him
30841 Would of that seed grow to a greater falseness
30842 Which should not find a ground to root upon
30843 Unless on you
30844 KING Are these things then necessities
30845 Then let us meet them like necessities
30846 And that same word even now cries out on us
30847 They say the Bishop and Northumberland
30848 Are fifty thousand strong
30849 WARWICK It cannot be my lord
30850 Rumour doth double like the voice and echo
30851 The numbers of the feared Please it your Grace
30852 To go to bed Upon my soul my lord
30853 The powers that you already have sent forth
30854 Shall bring this prize in very easily
30855 To comfort you the more I have receiv'd
30856 A certain instance that Glendower is dead
30857 Your Majesty hath been this fortnight ill
30858 And these unseasoned hours perforce must ad
30859 Unto your sickness
30860 KING I will take your counsel
30861 And were these inward wars once out of hand
30862 We would dear lords unto the Holy Land Exeunt
30863 SCENE II
30864 Gloucestershire Before Justice SHALLOW'S house
30865 Enter SHALLOW and SILENCE meeting MOULDY SHADOW WART FEEBLE BULLCALF
30866 and servants behind
30867 SHALLOW Come on come on come on give me your hand sir give me
30868 your hand sir An early stirrer by the rood And how doth my
30869 good cousin Silence
30870 SILENCE Good morrow good cousin Shallow
30871 SHALLOW And how doth my cousin your bedfellow and your fairest
30872 daughter and mine my goddaughter Ellen
30873 SILENCE Alas a black ousel cousin Shallow
30874 SHALLOW By yea and no sir I dare say my cousin William is become
30875 a good scholar he is at Oxford still is he not
30876 SILENCE Indeed sir to my cost
30877 SHALLOW 'A must then to the Inns o Court shortly I was once of
30878 Clement's Inn where I think they will talk of mad Shallow yet
30879 SILENCE You were call'd 'lusty Shallow then cousin
30880 SHALLOW By the mass I was call'd anything and I would have done
30881 anything indeed too and roundly too There was I and little
30882 John Doit of Staffordshire and black George Barnes and Francis
30883 Pickbone and Will Squele a Cotsole man you had not four such
30884 swingebucklers in all the Inns of Court again And I may say to
30885 you we knew where the bonarobas were and had the best of them
30886 all at commandment Then was Jack Falstaff now Sir John boy
30887 and page to Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norfolk
30888 SILENCE This Sir John cousin that comes hither anon about
30889 soldiers
30890 SHALLOW The same Sir John the very same I see him break
30891 Scoggin's head at the court gate when 'a was a crack not thus
30892 high and the very same day did I fight with one Sampson
30893 Stockfish a fruiterer behind Gray's Inn Jesu Jesu the mad
30894 days that I have spent and to see how many of my old
30895 acquaintance are dead
30896 SILENCE We shall all follow cousin
30897 SHALLOW Certain 'tis certain very sure very sure Death as the
30898 Psalmist saith is certain to all all shall die How a good yoke
30899 of bullocks at Stamford fair
30900 SILENCE By my troth I was not there
30901 SHALLOW Death is certain Is old Double of your town living yet
30902 SILENCE Dead sir
30903 SHALLOW Jesu Jesu dead drew a good bow and dead 'A shot a
30904 fine shoot John a Gaunt loved him well and betted much money on
30905 his head Dead 'A would have clapp'd i th clout at twelve
30906 score and carried you a forehand shaft a fourteen and fourteen
30907 and a half that it would have done a man's heart good to see
30908 How a score of ewes now
30909 SILENCE Thereafter as they be a score of good ewes may be worth
30910 ten pounds
30911 SHALLOW And is old Double dead
30912 Enter BARDOLPH and one with him
30913 SILENCE Here come two of Sir John Falstaffs men as I think
30914 SHALLOW Good morrow honest gentlemen
30915 BARDOLPH I beseech you which is Justice Shallow
30916 SHALLOW I am Robert Shallow sir a poor esquire of this county
30917 and one of the King's justices of the peace What is your good
30918 pleasure with me
30919 BARDOLPH My captain sir commends him to you my captain Sir
30920 John Falstaff a tall gentleman by heaven and a most gallant
30921 leader
30922 SHALLOW He greets me well sir I knew him a good backsword man
30923 How doth the good knight May I ask how my lady his wife doth
30924 BARDOLPH Sir pardon a soldier is better accommodated than with a
30925 wife
30926 SHALLOW It is well said in faith sir and it is well said indeed
30927 too 'Better accommodated It is good yea indeed is it Good
30928 phrases are surely and ever were very commendable
30929 'Accommodated It comes of accommodo Very good a good phrase
30930 BARDOLPH Pardon sir I have heard the word 'Phrase call you it
30931 By this day I know not the phrase but I will maintain the word
30932 with my sword to be a soldierlike word and a word of exceeding
30933 good command by heaven Accommodated that is when a man is as
30934 they say accommodated or when a man is beingwhereby 'a may be
30935 thought to be accommodated which is an excellent thing
30936 Enter FALSTAFF
30937 SHALLOW It is very just Look here comes good Sir John Give me
30938 your good hand give me your worship's good hand By my troth
30939 you like well and bear your years very well Welcome good Sir
30940 John
30941 FALSTAFF I am glad to see you well good Master Robert Shallow
30942 Master Surecard as I think
30943 SHALLOW No Sir John it is my cousin Silence in commission with
30944 me
30945 FALSTAFF Good Master Silence it well befits you should be of the
30946 peace
30947 SILENCE Your good worship is welcome
30948 FALSTAFF Fie this is hot weather Gentlemen have you provided me
30949 here half a dozen sufficient men
30950 SHALLOW Marry have we sir Will you sit
30951 FALSTAFF Let me see them I beseech you
30952 SHALLOW Where's the roll Where's the roll Where's the roll Let
30953 me see let me see let me see So so so so so so yea
30954 marry sir Rafe Mouldy Let them appear as I call let them do
30955 so let them do so Let me see where is Mouldy
30956 MOULDY Here an't please you
30957 SHALLOW What think you Sir John A goodlimb'd fellow young
30958 strong and of good friends
30959 FALSTAFF Is thy name Mouldy
30960 MOULDY Yea an't please you
30961 FALSTAFF 'Tis the more time thou wert us'd
30962 SHALLOW Ha ha ha most excellent i faith Things that are
30963 mouldy lack use Very singular good In faith well said Sir
30964 John very well said
30965 FALSTAFF Prick him
30966 MOULDY I was prick'd well enough before an you could have let me
30967 alone My old dame will be undone now for one to do her husbandry
30968 and her drudgery You need not to have prick'd me there are
30969 other men fitter to go out than I
30970 FALSTAFF Go to peace Mouldy you shall go Mouldy it is time
30971 you were spent
30972 MOULDY Spent
30973 SHALLOW Peace fellow peace stand aside know you where you are
30974 For th other Sir John let me see Simon Shadow
30975 FALSTAFF Yea marry let me have him to sit under He's like to be
30976 a cold soldier
30977 SHALLOW Where's Shadow
30978 SHADOW Here sir
30979 FALSTAFF Shadow whose son art thou
30980 SHADOW My mother's son sir
30981 FALSTAFF Thy mother's son Like enough and thy father's shadow
30982 So the son of the female is the shadow of the male It is often
30983 so indeed but much of the father's substance
30984 SHALLOW Do you like him Sir John
30985 FALSTAFF Shadow will serve for summer Prick him for we have a
30986 number of shadows fill up the musterbook
30987 SHALLOW Thomas Wart
30988 FALSTAFF Where's he
30989 WART Here sir
30990 FALSTAFF Is thy name Wart
30991 WART Yea sir
30992 FALSTAFF Thou art a very ragged wart
30993 SHALLOW Shall I prick him Sir John
30994 FALSTAFF It were superfluous for his apparel is built upon his
30995 back and the whole frame stands upon pins Prick him no more
30996 SHALLOW Ha ha ha You can do it sir you can do it I commend
30997 you well Francis Feeble
30998 FEEBLE Here sir
30999 FALSTAFF What trade art thou Feeble
31000 FEEBLE A woman's tailor sir
31001 SHALLOW Shall I prick him sir
31002 FALSTAFF You may but if he had been a man's tailor he'd ha'
31003 prick'd you Wilt thou make as many holes in an enemy's battle as
31004 thou hast done in a woman's petticoat
31005 FEEBLE I will do my good will sir you can have no more
31006 FALSTAFF Well said good woman's tailor well said courageous
31007 Feeble Thou wilt be as valiant as the wrathful dove or most
31008 magnanimous mouse Prick the woman's tailor well Master
31009 Shallow deep Master Shallow
31010 FEEBLE I would Wart might have gone sir
31011 FALSTAFF I would thou wert a man's tailor that thou mightst mend
31012 him and make him fit to go I cannot put him to a private
31013 soldier that is the leader of so many thousands Let that
31014 suffice most forcible Feeble
31015 FEEBLE It shall suffice sir
31016 FALSTAFF I am bound to thee reverend Feeble Who is next
31017 SHALLOW Peter Bullcalf o th green
31018 FALSTAFF Yea marry let's see Bullcalf
31019 BULLCALF Here sir
31020 FALSTAFF Fore God a likely fellow Come prick me Bullcalf till
31021 he roar again
31022 BULLCALF O Lord good my lord captain
31023 FALSTAFF What dost thou roar before thou art prick'd
31024 BULLCALF O Lord sir I am a diseased man
31025 FALSTAFF What disease hast thou
31026 BULLCALF A whoreson cold sir a cough sir which I caught with
31027 ringing in the King's affairs upon his coronation day sir
31028 FALSTAFF Come thou shalt go to the wars in a gown We will have
31029 away thy cold and I will take such order that thy friends shall
31030 ring for thee Is here all
31031 SHALLOW Here is two more call'd than your number You must have
31032 but four here sir and so I pray you go in with me to dinner
31033 FALSTAFF Come I will go drink with you but I cannot tarry
31034 dinner I am glad to see you by my troth Master Shallow
31035 SHALLOW O Sir John do you remember since we lay all night in the
31036 windmill in Saint George's Field
31037 FALSTAFF No more of that Master Shallow no more of that
31038 SHALLOW Ha 'twas a merry night And is Jane Nightwork alive
31039 FALSTAFF She lives Master Shallow
31040 SHALLOW She never could away with me
31041 FALSTAFF Never never she would always say she could not abide
31042 Master Shallow
31043 SHALLOW By the mass I could anger her to th heart She was then
31044 a bonaroba Doth she hold her own well
31045 FALSTAFF Old old Master Shallow
31046 SHALLOW Nay she must be old she cannot choose but be old
31047 certain she's old and had Robin Nightwork by old Nightwork
31048 before I came to Clement's Inn
31049 SILENCE That's fiftyfive year ago
31050 SHALLOW Ha cousin Silence that thou hadst seen that that this
31051 knight and I have seen Ha Sir John said I well
31052 FALSTAFF We have heard the chimes at midnight Master Shallow
31053 SHALLOW That we have that we have that we have in faith Sir
31054 John we have Our watchword was 'Hem boys Come let's to
31055 dinner come let's to dinner Jesus the days that we have seen
31056 Come come
31057 Exeunt FALSTAFF and the JUSTICES
31058 BULLCALF Good Master Corporate Bardolph stand my friend and
31059 here's four Harry ten shillings in French crowns for you In very
31060 truth sir I had as lief be hang'd sir as go And yet for
31061 mine own part sir I do not care but rather because I am
31062 unwilling and for mine own part have a desire to stay with my
31063 friends else sir I did not care for mine own part so much
31064 BARDOLPH Go to stand aside
31065 MOULDY And good Master Corporal Captain for my old dame's sake
31066 stand my friend She has nobody to do anything about her when I
31067 am gone and she is old and cannot help herself You shall have
31068 forty sir
31069 BARDOLPH Go to stand aside
31070 FEEBLE By my troth I care not a man can die but once we owe God
31071 a death I'll ne'er bear a base mind An't be my destiny so
31072 an't be not so No man's too good to serve 's Prince and let
31073 it go which way it will he that dies this year is quit for the
31074 next
31075 BARDOLPH Well said th'art a good fellow
31076 FEEBLE Faith I'll bear no base mind
31077 Reenter FALSTAFF and the JUSTICES
31078 FALSTAFF Come sir which men shall I have
31079 SHALLOW Four of which you please
31080 BARDOLPH Sir a word with you I have three pound to free Mouldy
31081 and Bullcalf
31082 FALSTAFF Go to well
31083 SHALLOW Come Sir John which four will you have
31084 FALSTAFF Do you choose for me
31085 SHALLOW Marry then Mouldy Bullcalf Feeble and Shadow
31086 FALSTAFF Mouldy and Bullcalf for you Mouldy stay at home till
31087 you are past service and for your part Bullcalf grow you come
31088 unto it I will none of you
31089 SHALLOW Sir John Sir John do not yourself wrong They are your
31090 likeliest men and I would have you serv'd with the best
31091 FALSTAFF Will you tell me Master Shallow how to choose a man
31092 Care I for the limb the thews the stature bulk and big
31093 assemblance of a man Give me the spirit Master Shallow Here's
31094 Wart you see what a ragged appearance it is 'A shall charge you
31095 and discharge you with the motion of a pewterer's hammer come
31096 off and on swifter than he that gibbets on the brewer's bucket
31097 And this same halffac'd fellow Shadow give me this man He
31098 presents no mark to the enemy the foeman may with as great aim
31099 level at the edge of a penknife And for a retreat how swiftly
31100 will this Feeble the woman's tailor run off O give me the
31101 spare men and spare me the great ones Put me a caliver into
31102 Wart's hand Bardolph
31103 BARDOLPH Hold Wart Traverse thus thus thus
31104 FALSTAFF Come manage me your caliver So very well Go to very
31105 good exceeding good O give me always a little lean old
31106 chopt bald shot Well said i faith Wart th'art a good scab
31107 Hold there's a tester for thee
31108 SHALLOW He is not his craft's master he doth not do it right I
31109 remember at Mileend Green when I lay at Clement's Inn I was
31110 then Sir Dagonet in Arthur's show there was a little quiver
31111 fellow and 'a would manage you his piece thus and 'a would
31112 about and about and come you in and come you in 'Rah tah
31113 tah would 'a say 'Bounce would 'a say and away again would
31114 'a go and again would 'a come I shall ne'er see such a fellow
31115 FALSTAFF These fellows will do well Master Shallow God keep you
31116 Master Silence I will not use many words with you Fare you
31117 well Gentlemen both I thank you I must a dozen mile tonight
31118 Bardolph give the soldiers coats
31119 SHALLOW Sir John the Lord bless you God prosper your affairs
31120 God send us peace At your return visit our house let our old
31121 acquaintance be renewed Peradventure I will with ye to the
31122 court
31123 FALSTAFF Fore God would you would
31124 SHALLOW Go to I have spoke at a word God keep you
31125 FALSTAFF Fare you well gentle gentlemen [Exeunt JUSTICES] On
31126 Bardolph lead the men away [Exeunt all but FALSTAFF] As I
31127 return I will fetch off these justices I do see the bottom of
31128 justice Shallow Lord Lord how subject we old men are to this
31129 vice of lying This same starv'd justice hath done nothing but
31130 prate to me of the wildness of his youth and the feats he hath
31131 done about Turnbull Street and every third word a lie duer paid
31132 to the hearer than the Turk's tribute I do remember him at
31133 Clement's Inn like a man made after supper of a cheeseparing
31134 When 'a was naked he was for all the world like a fork'd radish
31135 with a head fantastically carved upon it with a knife 'A was so
31136 forlorn that his dimensions to any thick sight were invisible 'A
31137 was the very genius of famine yet lecherous as a monkey and the
31138 whores call'd him mandrake 'A came ever in the rearward of the
31139 fashion and sung those tunes to the overscutch'd huswifes that
31140 he heard the carmen whistle and sware they were his fancies or
31141 his goodnights And now is this Vice's dagger become a squire
31142 and talks as familiarly of John a Gaunt as if he had been sworn
31143 brother to him and I'll be sworn 'a ne'er saw him but once in
31144 the Tiltyard and then he burst his head for crowding among the
31145 marshal's men I saw it and told John a Gaunt he beat his own
31146 name for you might have thrust him and all his apparel into an
31147 eelskin the case of a treble hautboy was a mansion for him a
31148 court and now has he land and beeves Well I'll be acquainted
31149 with him if I return and 't shall go hard but I'll make him a
31150 philosopher's two stones to me If the young dace be a bait for
31151 the old pike I see no reason in the law of nature but I may snap
31152 at him Let time shape and there an end Exit
