31161 ACT IV SCENE I
31162 Yorkshire Within the Forest of Gaultree
31163 Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK MOWBRAY HASTINGS and others
31164 ARCHBISHOP What is this forest call'd
31165 HASTINGS 'Tis Gaultree Forest an't shall please your Grace
31166 ARCHBISHOP Here stand my lords and send discoverers forth
31167 To know the numbers of our enemies
31168 HASTINGS We have sent forth already
31169 ARCHBISHOP 'Tis well done
31170 My friends and brethren in these great affairs
31171 I must acquaint you that I have receiv'd
31172 Newdated letters from Northumberland
31173 Their cold intent tenour and substance thus
31174 Here doth he wish his person with such powers
31175 As might hold sortance with his quality
31176 The which he could not levy whereupon
31177 He is retir'd to ripe his growing fortunes
31178 To Scotland and concludes in hearty prayers
31179 That your attempts may overlive the hazard
31180 And fearful meeting of their opposite
31181 MOWBRAY Thus do the hopes we have in him touch ground
31182 And dash themselves to pieces
31183 Enter A MESSENGER
31184 HASTINGS Now what news
31185 MESSENGER West of this forest scarcely off a mile
31186 In goodly form comes on the enemy
31187 And by the ground they hide I judge their number
31188 Upon or near the rate of thirty thousand
31189 MOWBRAY The just proportion that we gave them out
31190 Let us sway on and face them in the field
31191 Enter WESTMORELAND
31192 ARCHBISHOP What wellappointed leader fronts us here
31193 MOWBRAY I think it is my Lord of Westmoreland
31194 WESTMORELAND Health and fair greeting from our general
31195 The Prince Lord John and Duke of Lancaster
31196 ARCHBISHOP Say on my Lord of Westmoreland in peace
31197 What doth concern your coming
31198 WESTMORELAND Then my lord
31199 Unto your Grace do I in chief address
31200 The substance of my speech If that rebellion
31201 Came like itself in base and abject routs
31202 Led on by bloody youth guarded with rags
31203 And countenanc'd by boys and beggary
31204 I say if damn'd commotion so appear'd
31205 In his true native and most proper shape
31206 You reverend father and these noble lords
31207 Had not been here to dress the ugly form
31208 Of base and bloody insurrection
31209 With your fair honours You Lord Archbishop
31210 Whose see is by a civil peace maintain'd
31211 Whose beard the silver hand of peace hath touch'd
31212 Whose learning and good letters peace hath tutor'd
31213 Whose white investments figure innocence
31214 The dove and very blessed spirit of peace
31215 Wherefore you do so ill translate yourself
31216 Out of the speech of peace that bears such grace
31217 Into the harsh and boist'rous tongue of war
31218 Turning your books to graves your ink to blood
31219 Your pens to lances and your tongue divine
31220 To a loud trumpet and a point of war
31221 ARCHBISHOP Wherefore do I this So the question stands
31222 Briefly to this end we are all diseas'd
31223 And with our surfeiting and wanton hours
31224 Have brought ourselves into a burning fever
31225 And we must bleed for it of which disease
31226 Our late King Richard being infected died
31227 But my most noble Lord of Westmoreland
31228 I take not on me here as a physician
31229 Nor do I as an enemy to peace
31230 Troop in the throngs of military men
31231 But rather show awhile like fearful war
31232 To diet rank minds sick of happiness
31233 And purge th obstructions which begin to stop
31234 Our very veins of life Hear me more plainly
31235 I have in equal balance justly weigh'd
31236 What wrongs our arms may do what wrongs we suffer
31237 And find our griefs heavier than our offences
31238 We see which way the stream of time doth run
31239 And are enforc'd from our most quiet there
31240 By the rough torrent of occasion
31241 And have the summary of all our griefs
31242 When time shall serve to show in articles
31243 Which long ere this we offer'd to the King
31244 And might by no suit gain our audience
31245 When we are wrong'd and would unfold our griefs
31246 We are denied access unto his person
31247 Even by those men that most have done us wrong
31248 The dangers of the days but newly gone
31249 Whose memory is written on the earth
31250 With yet appearing blood and the examples
31251 Of every minute's instance present now
31252 Hath put us in these illbeseeming arms
31253 Not to break peace or any branch of it
31254 But to establish here a peace indeed
31255 Concurring both in name and quality
31256 WESTMORELAND When ever yet was your appeal denied
31257 Wherein have you been galled by the King
31258 What peer hath been suborn'd to grate on you
31259 That you should seal this lawless bloody book
31260 Of forg'd rebellion with a seal divine
31261 And consecrate commotion's bitter edge
31262 ARCHBISHOP My brother general the commonwealth
31263 To brother horn an household cruelty
31264 I make my quarrel in particular
31265 WESTMORELAND There is no need of any such redress
31266 Or if there were it not belongs to you
31267 MOWBRAY Why not to him in part and to us all
31268 That feel the bruises of the days before
31269 And suffer the condition of these times
31270 To lay a heavy and unequal hand
31271 Upon our honours
31272 WESTMORELAND O my good Lord Mowbray
31273 Construe the times to their necessities
31274 And you shall say indeed it is the time
31275 And not the King that doth you injuries
31276 Yet for your part it not appears to me
31277 Either from the King or in the present time
31278 That you should have an inch of any ground
31279 To build a grief on Were you not restor'd
31280 To all the Duke of Norfolk's signiories
31281 Your noble and right wellrememb'red father's
31282 MOWBRAY What thing in honour had my father lost
31283 That need to be reviv'd and breath'd in me
31284 The King that lov'd him as the state stood then
31285 Was force perforce compell'd to banish him
31286 And then that Henry Bolingbroke and he
31287 Being mounted and both roused in their seats
31288 Their neighing coursers daring of the spur
31289 Their armed staves in charge their beavers down
31290 Their eyes of fire sparkling through sights of steel
31291 And the loud trumpet blowing them together
31292 Then then when there was nothing could have stay'd
31293 My father from the breast of Bolingbroke
31294 O when the King did throw his warder down
31295 His own life hung upon the staff he threw
31296 Then threw he down himself and all their lives
31297 That by indictment and by dint of sword
31298 Have since miscarried under Bolingbroke
31299 WESTMORELAND You speak Lord Mowbray now you know not what
31300 The Earl of Hereford was reputed then
31301 In England the most valiant gentleman
31302 Who knows on whom fortune would then have smil'd
31303 But if your father had been victor there
31304 He ne'er had borne it out of Coventry
31305 For all the country in a general voice
31306 Cried hate upon him and all their prayers and love
31307 Were set on Hereford whom they doted on
31308 And bless'd and grac'd indeed more than the King
31309 But this is mere digression from my purpose
31310 Here come I from our princely general
31311 To know your griefs to tell you from his Grace
31312 That he will give you audience and wherein
31313 It shall appear that your demands are just
31314 You shall enjoy them everything set off
31315 That might so much as think you enemies
31316 MOWBRAY But he hath forc'd us to compel this offer
31317 And it proceeds from policy not love
31318 WESTMORELAND Mowbray you overween to take it so
31319 This offer comes from mercy not from fear
31320 For lo within a ken our army lies
31321 Upon mine honour all too confident
31322 To give admittance to a thought of fear
31323 Our battle is more full of names than yours
31324 Our men more perfect in the use of arms
31325 Our armour all as strong our cause the best
31326 Then reason will our hearts should be as good
31327 Say you not then our offer is compell'd
31328 MOWBRAY Well by my will we shall admit no parley
31329 WESTMORELAND That argues but the shame of your offence
31330 A rotten case abides no handling
31331 HASTINGS Hath the Prince John a full commission
31332 In very ample virtue of his father
31333 To hear and absolutely to determine
31334 Of what conditions we shall stand upon
31335 WESTMORELAND That is intended in the general's name
31336 I muse you make so slight a question
31337 ARCHBISHOP Then take my Lord of Westmoreland this schedule
31338 For this contains our general grievances
31339 Each several article herein redress'd
31340 All members of our cause both here and hence
31341 That are insinewed to this action
31342 Acquitted by a true substantial form
31343 And present execution of our wills
31344 To us and to our purposes confin'd
31345 We come within our awful banks again
31346 And knit our powers to the arm of peace
31347 WESTMORELAND This will I show the general Please you lords
31348 In sight of both our battles we may meet
31349 And either end in peace which God so frame
31350 Or to the place of diff'rence call the swords
31351 Which must decide it
31352 ARCHBISHOP My lord we will do so Exit WESTMORELAND
31353 MOWBRAY There is a thing within my bosom tells me
31354 That no conditions of our peace can stand
31355 HASTINGS Fear you not that if we can make our peace
31356 Upon such large terms and so absolute
31357 As our conditions shall consist upon
31358 Our peace shall stand as firm as rocky mountains
31359 MOWBRAY Yea but our valuation shall be such
31360 That every slight and falsederived cause
31361 Yea every idle nice and wanton reason
31362 Shall to the King taste of this action
31363 That were our royal faiths martyrs in love
31364 We shall be winnow'd with so rough a wind
31365 That even our corn shall seem as light as chaff
31366 And good from bad find no partition
31367 ARCHBISHOP No no my lord Note this the King is weary
31368 Of dainty and such picking grievances
31369 For he hath found to end one doubt by death
31370 Revives two greater in the heirs of life
31371 And therefore will he wipe his tables clean
31372 And keep no telltale to his memory
31373 That may repeat and history his los
31374 To new remembrance For full well he knows
31375 He cannot so precisely weed this land
31376 As his misdoubts present occasion
31377 His foes are so enrooted with his friends
31378 That plucking to unfix an enemy
31379 He doth unfasten so and shake a friend
31380 So that this land like an offensive wife
31381 That hath enrag'd him on to offer strokes
31382 As he is striking holds his infant up
31383 And hangs resolv'd correction in the arm
31384 That was uprear'd to execution
31385 HASTINGS Besides the King hath wasted all his rods
31386 On late offenders that he now doth lack
31387 The very instruments of chastisement
31388 So that his power like to a fangless lion
31389 May offer but not hold
31390 ARCHBISHOP 'Tis very true
31391 And therefore be assur'd my good Lord Marshal
31392 If we do now make our atonement well
31393 Our peace will like a broken limb united
31394 Grow stronger for the breaking
31395 MOWBRAY Be it so
31396 Here is return'd my Lord of Westmoreland
31397 Reenter WESTMORELAND
31398 WESTMORELAND The Prince is here at hand Pleaseth your lordship
31399 To meet his Grace just distance 'tween our armies
31400 MOWBRAY Your Grace of York in God's name then set forward
31401 ARCHBISHOP Before and greet his Grace My lord we come
31402 Exeunt
31403 SCENE II
31404 Another part of the forest
31405 Enter from one side MOWBRAY attended afterwards the ARCHBISHOP
31406 HASTINGS and others from the other side PRINCE JOHN of LANCASTER
31407 WESTMORELAND OFFICERS and others
31408 PRINCE JOHN You are well encount'red here my cousin Mowbray
31409 Good day to you gentle Lord Archbishop
31410 And so to you Lord Hastings and to all
31411 My Lord of York it better show'd with you
31412 When that your flock assembled by the bell
31413 Encircled you to hear with reverence
31414 Your exposition on the holy text
31415 Than now to see you here an iron man
31416 Cheering a rout of rebels with your drum
31417 Turning the word to sword and life to death
31418 That man that sits within a monarch's heart
31419 And ripens in the sunshine of his favour
31420 Would he abuse the countenance of the king
31421 Alack what mischiefs might he set abroach
31422 In shadow of such greatness With you Lord Bishop
31423 It is even so Who hath not heard it spoken
31424 How deep you were within the books of God
31425 To us the speaker in His parliament
31426 To us th imagin'd voice of God himself
31427 The very opener and intelligencer
31428 Between the grace the sanctities of heaven
31429 And our dull workings O who shall believe
31430 But you misuse the reverence of your place
31431 Employ the countenance and grace of heav'n
31432 As a false favourite doth his prince's name
31433 In deeds dishonourable You have ta'en up
31434 Under the counterfeited zeal of God
31435 The subjects of His substitute my father
31436 And both against the peace of heaven and him
31437 Have here upswarm'd them
31438 ARCHBISHOP Good my Lord of Lancaster
31439 I am not here against your father's peace
31440 But as I told my Lord of Westmoreland
31441 The time misord'red doth in common sense
31442 Crowd us and crush us to this monstrous form
31443 To hold our safety up I sent your Grace
31444 The parcels and particulars of our grief
31445 The which hath been with scorn shov'd from the court
31446 Whereon this hydra son of war is born
31447 Whose dangerous eyes may well be charm'd asleep
31448 With grant of our most just and right desires
31449 And true obedience of this madness cur'd
31450 Stoop tamely to the foot of majesty
31451 MOWBRAY If not we ready are to try our fortunes
31452 To the last man
31453 HASTINGS And though we here fall down
31454 We have supplies to second our attempt
31455 If they miscarry theirs shall second them
31456 And so success of mischief shall be born
31457 And heir from heir shall hold this quarrel up
31458 Whiles England shall have generation
31459 PRINCE JOHN YOU are too shallow Hastings much to shallow
31460 To sound the bottom of the aftertimes
31461 WESTMORELAND Pleaseth your Grace to answer them directly
31462 How far forth you do like their articles
31463 PRINCE JOHN I like them all and do allow them well
31464 And swear here by the honour of my blood
31465 My father's purposes have been mistook
31466 And some about him have too lavishly
31467 Wrested his meaning and authority
31468 My lord these griefs shall be with speed redress'd
31469 Upon my soul they shall If this may please you
31470 Discharge your powers unto their several counties
31471 As we will ours and here between the armies
31472 Let's drink together friendly and embrace
31473 That all their eyes may bear those tokens home
31474 Of our restored love and amity
31475 ARCHBISHOP I take your princely word for these redresses
31476 PRINCE JOHN I give it you and will maintain my word
31477 And thereupon I drink unto your Grace
31478 HASTINGS Go Captain and deliver to the army
31479 This news of peace Let them have pay and part
31480 I know it will please them Hie thee Captain
31481 Exit Officer
31482 ARCHBISHOP To you my noble Lord of Westmoreland
31483 WESTMORELAND I pledge your Grace and if you knew what pains
31484 I have bestow'd to breed this present peace
31485 You would drink freely but my love to ye
31486 Shall show itself more openly hereafter
31487 ARCHBISHOP I do not doubt you
31488 WESTMORELAND I am glad of it
31489 Health to my lord and gentle cousin Mowbray
31490 MOWBRAY You wish me health in very happy season
31491 For I am on the sudden something ill
31492 ARCHBISHOP Against ill chances men are ever merry
31493 But heaviness foreruns the good event
31494 WESTMORELAND Therefore be merry coz since sudden sorrow
31495 Serves to say thus 'Some good thing comes tomorrow'
31496 ARCHBISHOP Believe me I am passing light in spirit
31497 MOWBRAY So much the worse if your own rule be true
31498 [Shouts within]
31499 PRINCE JOHN The word of peace is rend'red Hark how they shout
31500 MOWBRAY This had been cheerful after victory
31501 ARCHBISHOP A peace is of the nature of a conquest
31502 For then both parties nobly are subdu'd
31503 And neither party loser
31504 PRINCE JOHN Go my lord
31505 And let our army be discharged too
31506 Exit WESTMORELAND
31507 And good my lord so please you let our trains
31508 March by us that we may peruse the men
31509 We should have cop'd withal
31510 ARCHBISHOP Go good Lord Hastings
31511 And ere they be dismiss'd let them march by
31512 Exit HASTINGS
31513 PRINCE JOHN I trust lords we shall lie tonight together
31514 Reenter WESTMORELAND
31515 Now cousin wherefore stands our army still
31516 WESTMORELAND The leaders having charge from you to stand
31517 Will not go off until they hear you speak
31518 PRINCE JOHN They know their duties
31519 Reenter HASTINGS
31520 HASTINGS My lord our army is dispers'd already
31521 Like youthful steers unyok'd they take their courses
31522 East west north south or like a school broke up
31523 Each hurries toward his home and sportingplace
31524 WESTMORELAND Good tidings my Lord Hastings for the which
31525 I do arrest thee traitor of high treason
31526 And you Lord Archbishop and you Lord Mowbray
31527 Of capital treason I attach you both
31528 MOWBRAY Is this proceeding just and honourable
31529 WESTMORELAND Is your assembly so
31530 ARCHBISHOP Will you thus break your faith
31531 PRINCE JOHN I pawn'd thee none
31532 I promis'd you redress of these same grievances
31533 Whereof you did complain which by mine honour
31534 I will perform with a most Christian care
31535 But for you rebels look to taste the due
31536 Meet for rebellion and such acts as yours
31537 Most shallowly did you these arms commence
31538 Fondly brought here and foolishly sent hence
31539 Strike up our drums pursue the scatt'red stray
31540 God and not we hath safely fought today
31541 Some guard these traitors to the block of death
31542 Treason's true bed and yielderup of breath Exeunt
31543 SCENE III
31544 Another part of the forest
31545 Alarum excursions Enter FALSTAFF and COLVILLE meeting
31546 FALSTAFF What's your name sir Of what condition are you and of
31547 what place I pray
31548 COLVILLE I am a knight sir and my name is Colville of the Dale
31549 FALSTAFF Well then Colville is your name a knight is your
31550 degree and your place the Dale Colville shall still be your
31551 name a traitor your degree and the dungeon your place a place
31552 deep enough so shall you be still Colville of the Dale
31553 COLVILLE Are not you Sir John Falstaff
31554 FALSTAFF As good a man as he sir whoe'er I am Do you yield
31555 sir or shall I sweat for you If I do sweat they are the drops
31556 of thy lovers and they weep for thy death therefore rouse up
31557 fear and trembling and do observance to my mercy
31558 COLVILLE I think you are Sir John Falstaff and in that thought
31559 yield me
31560 FALSTAFF I have a whole school of tongues in this belly of mine
31561 and not a tongue of them all speaks any other word but my name
31562 An I had but a belly of any indifferency I were simply the most
31563 active fellow in Europe My womb my womb my womb undoes me
31564 Here comes our general
31565 Enter PRINCE JOHN OF LANCASTER WESTMORELAND
31566 BLUNT and others
31567 PRINCE JOHN The heat is past follow no further now
31568 Call in the powers good cousin Westmoreland
31569 Exit WESTMORELAND
31570 Now Falstaff where have you been all this while
31571 When everything is ended then you come
31572 These tardy tricks of yours will on my life
31573 One time or other break some gallows back
31574 FALSTAFF I would be sorry my lord but it should be thus I never
31575 knew yet but rebuke and check was the reward of valour Do you
31576 think me a swallow an arrow or a bullet Have I in my poor and
31577 old motion the expedition of thought I have speeded hither with
31578 the very extremest inch of possibility I have found'red nine
31579 score and odd posts and here travel tainted as I am have in
31580 my pure and immaculate valour taken Sir John Colville of the
31581 Dalea most furious knight and valorous enemy But what of that
31582 He saw me and yielded that I may justly say with the hooknos'd
31583 fellow of RomeI came saw and overcame
31584 PRINCE JOHN It was more of his courtesy than your deserving
31585 FALSTAFF I know not Here he is and here I yield him and I
31586 beseech your Grace let it be book'd with the rest of this day's
31587 deeds or by the Lord I will have it in a particular ballad
31588 else with mine own picture on the top on't Colville kissing my
31589 foot to the which course if I be enforc'd if you do not all
31590 show like gilt twopences to me and I in the clear sky of fame
31591 o'ershine you as much as the full moon doth the cinders of the
31592 element which show like pins heads to her believe not the word
31593 of the noble Therefore let me have right and let desert mount
31594 PRINCE JOHN Thine's too heavy to mount
31595 FALSTAFF Let it shine then
31596 PRINCE JOHN Thine's too thick to shine
31597 FALSTAFF Let it do something my good lord that may do me good
31598 and call it what you will
31599 PRINCE JOHN Is thy name Colville
31600 COLVILLE It is my lord
31601 PRINCE JOHN A famous rebel art thou Colville
31602 FALSTAFF And a famous true subject took him
31603 COLVILLE I am my lord but as my betters are
31604 That led me hither Had they been rul'd by me
31605 You should have won them dearer than you have
31606 FALSTAFF I know not how they sold themselves but thou like a
31607 kind fellow gavest thyself away gratis and I thank thee for
31608 thee
31609 Reenter WESTMORELAND
31610 PRINCE JOHN Now have you left pursuit
31611 WESTMORELAND Retreat is made and execution stay'd
31612 PRINCE JOHN Send Colville with his confederates
31613 To York to present execution
31614 Blunt lead him hence and see you guard him sure
31615 Exeunt BLUNT and others
31616 And now dispatch we toward the court my lords
31617 I hear the King my father is sore sick
31618 Our news shall go before us to his Majesty
31619 Which cousin you shall bear to comfort him
31620 And we with sober speed will follow you
31621 FALSTAFF My lord I beseech you give me leave to go through
31622 Gloucestershire and when you come to court stand my good lord
31623 pray in your good report
31624 PRINCE JOHN Fare you well Falstaff I in my condition
31625 Shall better speak of you than you deserve
31626 Exeunt all but FALSTAFF
31627 FALSTAFF I would you had but the wit 'twere better than your
31628 dukedom Good faith this same young soberblooded boy doth not
31629 love me nor a man cannot make him laugh but that's no marvel
31630 he drinks no wine There's never none of these demure boys come
31631 to any proof for thin drink doth so overcool their blood and
31632 making many fishmeals that they fall into a kind of male
31633 greensickness and then when they marry they get wenches They
31634 are generally fools and cowardswhich some of us should be too
31635 but for inflammation A good sherrissack hath a twofold
31636 operation in it It ascends me into the brain dries me there all
31637 the foolish and dull and crudy vapours which environ it makes it
31638 apprehensive quick forgetive full of nimble fiery and
31639 delectable shapes which delivered o'er to the voice the tongue
31640 which is the birth becomes excellent wit The second property of
31641 your excellent sherris is the warming of the blood which before
31642 cold and settled left the liver white and pale which is the
31643 badge of pusillanimity and cowardice but the sherris warms it
31644 and makes it course from the inwards to the parts extremes It
31645 illumineth the face which as a beacon gives warning to all the
31646 rest of this little kingdom man to arm and then the vital
31647 commoners and inland petty spirits muster me all to their
31648 captain the heart who great and puff'd up with this retinue
31649 doth any deed of courage and this valour comes of sherris So
31650 that skill in the weapon is nothing without sack for that sets
31651 it awork and learning a mere hoard of gold kept by a devil
31652 till sack commences it and sets it in act and use Hereof comes
31653 it that Prince Harry is valiant for the cold blood he did
31654 naturally inherit of his father he hath like lean sterile and
31655 bare land manured husbanded and till'd with excellent
31656 endeavour of drinking good and good store of fertile sherris
31657 that he is become very hot and valiant If I had a thousand sons
31658 the first humane principle I would teach them should be to
31659 forswear thin potations and to addict themselves to sack
31660 Enter BARDOLPH
31661 How now Bardolph
31662 BARDOLPH The army is discharged all and gone
31663 FALSTAFF Let them go I'll through Gloucestershire and there will
31664 I visit Master Robert Shallow Esquire I have him already
31665 temp'ring between my finger and my thumb and shortly will I seal
31666 with him Come away Exeunt
31667 SCENE IV
31668 Westminster The Jerusalem Chamber
31669 Enter the KING PRINCE THOMAS OF CLARENCE PRINCE HUMPHREY OF GLOUCESTER
31670 WARWICK and others
31671 KING Now lords if God doth give successful end
31672 To this debate that bleedeth at our doors
31673 We will our youth lead on to higher fields
31674 And draw no swords but what are sanctified
31675 Our navy is address'd our power connected
31676 Our substitutes in absence well invested
31677 And everything lies level to our wish
31678 Only we want a little personal strength
31679 And pause us till these rebels now afoot
31680 Come underneath the yoke of government
31681 WARWICK Both which we doubt not but your Majesty
31682 Shall soon enjoy
31683 KING Humphrey my son of Gloucester
31684 Where is the Prince your brother
31685 PRINCE HUMPHREY I think he's gone to hunt my lord at Windsor
31686 KING And how accompanied
31687 PRINCE HUMPHREY I do not know my lord
31688 KING Is not his brother Thomas of Clarence with him
31689 PRINCE HUMPHREY No my good lord he is in presence here
31690 CLARENCE What would my lord and father
31691 KING Nothing but well to thee Thomas of Clarence
31692 How chance thou art not with the Prince thy brother
31693 He loves thee and thou dost neglect him Thomas
31694 Thou hast a better place in his affection
31695 Than all thy brothers cherish it my boy
31696 And noble offices thou mayst effect
31697 Of mediation after I am dead
31698 Between his greatness and thy other brethren
31699 Therefore omit him not blunt not his love
31700 Nor lose the good advantage of his grace
31701 By seeming cold or careless of his will
31702 For he is gracious if he be observ'd
31703 He hath a tear for pity and a hand
31704 Open as day for melting charity
31705 Yet notwithstanding being incens'd he is flint
31706 As humorous as winter and as sudden
31707 As flaws congealed in the spring of day
31708 His temper therefore must be well observ'd
31709 Chide him for faults and do it reverently
31710 When you perceive his blood inclin'd to mirth
31711 But being moody give him line and scope
31712 Till that his passions like a whale on ground
31713 Confound themselves with working Learn this Thomas
31714 And thou shalt prove a shelter to thy friends
31715 A hoop of gold to bind thy brothers in
31716 That the united vessel of their blood
31717 Mingled with venom of suggestion
31718 As force perforce the age will pour it in
31719 Shall never leak though it do work as strong
31720 As aconitum or rash gunpowder
31721 CLARENCE I shall observe him with all care and love
31722 KING Why art thou not at Windsor with him Thomas
31723 CLARENCE He is not there today he dines in London
31724 KING And how accompanied Canst thou tell that
31725 CLARENCE With Poins and other his continual followers
31726 KING Most subject is the fattest soil to weeds
31727 And he the noble image of my youth
31728 Is overspread with them therefore my grief
31729 Stretches itself beyond the hour of death
31730 The blood weeps from my heart when I do shape
31731 In forms imaginary th'unguided days
31732 And rotten times that you shall look upon
31733 When I am sleeping with my ancestors
31734 For when his headstrong riot hath no curb
31735 When rage and hot blood are his counsellors
31736 When means and lavish manners meet together
31737 O with what wings shall his affections fly
31738 Towards fronting peril and oppos'd decay
31739 WARWICK My gracious lord you look beyond him quite
31740 The Prince but studies his companions
31741 Like a strange tongue wherein to gain the language
31742 'Tis needful that the most immodest word
31743 Be look'd upon and learnt which once attain'd
31744 Your Highness knows comes to no further use
31745 But to be known and hated So like gross terms
31746 The Prince will in the perfectness of time
31747 Cast off his followers and their memory
31748 Shall as a pattern or a measure live
31749 By which his Grace must mete the lives of other
31750 Turning past evils to advantages
31751 KING 'Tis seldom when the bee doth leave her comb
31752 In the dead carrion
31753 Enter WESTMORELAND
31754 Who's here Westmoreland
31755 WESTMORELAND Health to my sovereign and new happiness
31756 Added to that that am to deliver
31757 Prince John your son doth kiss your Grace's hand
31758 Mowbray the Bishop Scroop Hastings and all
31759 Are brought to the correction of your law
31760 There is not now a rebel's sword unsheath'd
31761 But Peace puts forth her olive everywhere
31762 The manner how this action hath been borne
31763 Here at more leisure may your Highness read
31764 With every course in his particular
31765 KING O Westmoreland thou art a summer bird
31766 Which ever in the haunch of winter sings
31767 The lifting up of day
31768 Enter HARCOURT
31769 Look here's more news
31770 HARCOURT From enemies heaven keep your Majesty
31771 And when they stand against you may they fall
31772 As those that I am come to tell you of
31773 The Earl Northumberland and the Lord Bardolph
31774 With a great power of English and of Scots
31775 Are by the shrieve of Yorkshire overthrown
31776 The manner and true order of the fight
31777 This packet please it you contains at large
31778 KING And wherefore should these good news make me sick
31779 Will Fortune never come with both hands full
31780 But write her fair words still in foulest letters
31781 She either gives a stomach and no food
31782 Such are the poor in health or else a feast
31783 And takes away the stomach such are the rich
31784 That have abundance and enjoy it not
31785 I should rejoice now at this happy news
31786 And now my sight fails and my brain is giddy
31787 O me come near me now I am much ill
31788 PRINCE HUMPHREY Comfort your Majesty
31789 CLARENCE O my royal father
31790 WESTMORELAND My sovereign lord cheer up yourself look up
31791 WARWICK Be patient Princes you do know these fits
31792 Are with his Highness very ordinary
31793 Stand from him give him air he'll straight be well
31794 CLARENCE No no he cannot long hold out these pangs
31795 Th incessant care and labour of his mind
31796 Hath wrought the mure that should confine it in
31797 So thin that life looks through and will break out
31798 PRINCE HUMPHREY The people fear me for they do observe
31799 Unfather'd heirs and loathly births of nature
31800 The seasons change their manners as the year
31801 Had found some months asleep and leapt them over
31802 CLARENCE The river hath thrice flow'd no ebb between
31803 And the old folk Time's doting chronicles
31804 Say it did so a little time before
31805 That our great grandsire Edward sick'd and died
31806 WARWICK Speak lower Princes for the King recovers
31807 PRINCE HUMPHREY This apoplexy will certain be his end
31808 KING I pray you take me up and bear me hence
31809 Into some other chamber Softly pray Exeunt
31810 SCENE V
31811 Westminster Another chamber
31812 The KING lying on a bed CLARENCE GLOUCESTER WARWICK
31813 and others in attendance
31814 KING Let there be no noise made my gentle friends
31815 Unless some dull and favourable hand
31816 Will whisper music to my weary spirit
31817 WARWICK Call for the music in the other room
31818 KING Set me the crown upon my pillow here
31819 CLARENCE His eye is hollow and he changes much
31820 WARWICK Less noise less noise
31821 Enter PRINCE HENRY
31822 PRINCE Who saw the Duke of Clarence
31823 CLARENCE I am here brother full of heaviness
31824 PRINCE How now Rain within doors and none abroad
31825 How doth the King
31826 PRINCE HUMPHREY Exceeding ill
31827 PRINCE Heard he the good news yet Tell it him
31828 PRINCE HUMPHREY He alt'red much upon the hearing it
31829 PRINCE If he be sick with joy he'll recover without physic
31830 WARWICK Not so much noise my lords Sweet Prince speak low
31831 The King your father is dispos'd to sleep
31832 CLARENCE Let us withdraw into the other room
31833 WARWICK Will't please your Grace to go along with us
31834 PRINCE No I will sit and watch here by the King
31835 Exeunt all but the PRINCE
31836 Why doth the crown lie there upon his pillow
31837 Being so troublesome a bedfellow
31838 O polish'd perturbation golden care
31839 That keep'st the ports of slumber open wide
31840 To many a watchful night Sleep with it now
31841 Yet not so sound and half so deeply sweet
31842 As he whose brow with homely biggen bound
31843 Snores out the watch of night O majesty
31844 When thou dost pinch thy bearer thou dost sit
31845 Like a rich armour worn in heat of day
31846 That scald'st with safety By his gates of breath
31847 There lies a downy feather which stirs not
31848 Did he suspire that light and weightless down
31849 Perforce must move My gracious lord my father
31850 This sleep is sound indeed this is a sleep
31851 That from this golden rigol hath divorc'd
31852 So many English kings Thy due from me
31853 Is tears and heavy sorrows of the blood
31854 Which nature love and filial tenderness
31855 Shall O dear father pay thee plenteously
31856 My due from thee is this imperial crown
31857 Which as immediate from thy place and blood
31858 Derives itself to me [Putting on the crown] Lo where it sits
31859 Which God shall guard and put the world's whole strength
31860 Into one giant arm it shall not force
31861 This lineal honour from me This from thee
31862 Will I to mine leave as 'tis left to me Exit
31863 KING Warwick Gloucester Clarence
31864 Reenter WARWICK GLOUCESTER CLARENCE
31865 CLARENCE Doth the King call
31866 WARWICK What would your Majesty How fares your Grace
31867 KING Why did you leave me here alone my lords
31868 CLARENCE We left the Prince my brother here my liege
31869 Who undertook to sit and watch by you
31870 KING The Prince of Wales Where is he Let me see him
31871 He is not here
31872 WARWICK This door is open he is gone this way
31873 PRINCE HUMPHREY He came not through the chamber where we stay'd
31874 KING Where is the crown Who took it from my pillow
31875 WARWICK When we withdrew my liege we left it here
31876 KING The Prince hath ta'en it hence Go seek him out
31877 Is he so hasty that he doth suppose
31878 My sleep my death
31879 Find him my lord of Warwick chide him hither
31880 Exit WARWICK
31881 This part of his conjoins with my disease
31882 And helps to end me See sons what things you are
31883 How quickly nature falls into revolt
31884 When gold becomes her object
31885 For this the foolish overcareful fathers
31886 Have broke their sleep with thoughts
31887 Their brains with care their bones with industry
31888 For this they have engrossed and pil'd up
31889 The cank'red heaps of strangeachieved gold
31890 For this they have been thoughtful to invest
31891 Their sons with arts and martial exercises
31892 When like the bee tolling from every flower
31893 The virtuous sweets
31894 Our thighs with wax our mouths with honey pack'd
31895 We bring it to the hive and like the bees
31896 Are murd'red for our pains This bitter taste
31897 Yields his engrossments to the ending father
31898 Reenter WARWICK
31899 Now where is he that will not stay so long
31900 Till his friend sickness hath determin'd me
31901 WARWICK My lord I found the Prince in the next room
31902 Washing with kindly tears his gentle cheeks
31903 With such a deep demeanour in great sorrow
31904 That tyranny which never quaff'd but blood
31905 Would by beholding him have wash'd his knife
31906 With gentle eyedrops He is coming hither
31907 KING But wherefore did he take away the crown
31908 Reenter PRINCE HENRY
31909 Lo where he comes Come hither to me Harry
31910 Depart the chamber leave us here alone
31911 Exeunt all but the KING and the PRINCE
31912 PRINCE I never thought to hear you speak again
31913 KING Thy wish was father Harry to that thought
31914 I stay too long by thee I weary thee
31915 Dost thou so hunger for mine empty chair
31916 That thou wilt needs invest thee with my honours
31917 Before thy hour be ripe O foolish youth
31918 Thou seek'st the greatness that will overwhelm thee
31919 Stay but a little for my cloud of dignity
31920 Is held from falling with so weak a wind
31921 That it will quickly drop my day is dim
31922 Thou hast stol'n that which after some few hours
31923 Were thine without offense and at my death
31924 Thou hast seal'd up my expectation
31925 Thy life did manifest thou lov'dst me not
31926 And thou wilt have me die assur'd of it
31927 Thou hid'st a thousand daggers in thy thoughts
31928 Which thou hast whetted on thy stony heart
31929 To stab at half an hour of my life
31930 What canst thou not forbear me half an hour
31931 Then get thee gone and dig my grave thyself
31932 And bid the merry bells ring to thine ear
31933 That thou art crowned not that I am dead
31934 Let all the tears that should bedew my hearse
31935 Be drops of balm to sanctify thy head
31936 Only compound me with forgotten dust
31937 Give that which gave thee life unto the worms
31938 Pluck down my officers break my decrees
31939 For now a time is come to mock at form
31940 Harry the Fifth is crown'd Up vanity
31941 Down royal state All you sage counsellors hence
31942 And to the English court assemble now
31943 From every region apes of idleness
31944 Now neighbour confines purge you of your scum
31945 Have you a ruffian that will swear drink dance
31946 Revel the night rob murder and commit
31947 The oldest sins the newest kind of ways
31948 Be happy he will trouble you no more
31949 England shall double gild his treble guilt
31950 England shall give him office honour might
31951 For the fifth Harry from curb'd license plucks
31952 The muzzle of restraint and the wild dog
31953 Shall flesh his tooth on every innocent
31954 O my poor kingdom sick with civil blows
31955 When that my care could not withhold thy riots
31956 What wilt thou do when riot is thy care
31957 O thou wilt be a wilderness again
31958 Peopled with wolves thy old inhabitants
31959 PRINCE O pardon me my liege But for my tears
31960 The moist impediments unto my speech
31961 I had forestall'd this dear and deep rebuke
31962 Ere you with grief had spoke and I had heard
31963 The course of it so far There is your crown
31964 And he that wears the crown immortally
31965 Long guard it yours [Kneeling] If I affect it more
31966 Than as your honour and as your renown
31967 Let me no more from this obedience rise
31968 Which my most inward true and duteous spirit
31969 Teacheth this prostrate and exterior bending
31970 God witness with me when I here came in
31971 And found no course of breath within your Majesty
31972 How cold it struck my heart If I do feign
31973 O let me in my present wildness die
31974 And never live to show th incredulous world
31975 The noble change that I have purposed
31976 Coming to look on you thinking you dead
31977 And dead almost my liege to think you were
31978 I spake unto this crown as having sense
31979 And thus upbraided it 'The care on thee depending
31980 Hath fed upon the body of my father
31981 Therefore thou best of gold art worst of gold
31982 Other less fine in carat is more precious
31983 Preserving life in med'cine potable
31984 But thou most fine most honour'd most renown'd
31985 Hast eat thy bearer up Thus my most royal liege
31986 Accusing it I put it on my head
31987 To try with it as with an enemy
31988 That had before my face murd'red my father
31989 The quarrel of a true inheritor
31990 But if it did infect my blood with joy
31991 Or swell my thoughts to any strain of pride
31992 If any rebel or vain spirit of mine
31993 Did with the least affection of a welcome
31994 Give entertainment to the might of it
31995 Let God for ever keep it from my head
31996 And make me as the poorest vassal is
31997 That doth with awe and terror kneel to it
31998 KING O my son
31999 God put it in thy mind to take it hence
32000 That thou mightst win the more thy father's love
32001 Pleading so wisely in excuse of it
32002 Come hither Harry sit thou by my bed
32003 And hear I think the very latest counsel
32004 That ever I shall breathe God knows my son
32005 By what bypaths and indirect crook'd ways
32006 I met this crown and I myself know well
32007 How troublesome it sat upon my head
32008 To thee it shall descend with better quiet
32009 Better opinion better confirmation
32010 For all the soil of the achievement goes
32011 With me into the earth It seem'd in me
32012 But as an honour snatch'd with boist'rous hand
32013 And I had many living to upbraid
32014 My gain of it by their assistances
32015 Which daily grew to quarrel and to bloodshed
32016 Wounding supposed peace All these bold fears
32017 Thou seest with peril I have answered
32018 For all my reign hath been but as a scene
32019 Acting that argument And now my death
32020 Changes the mood for what in me was purchas'd
32021 Falls upon thee in a more fairer sort
32022 So thou the garland wear'st successively
32023 Yet though thou stand'st more sure than I could do
32024 Thou art not firm enough since griefs are green
32025 And all my friends which thou must make thy friends
32026 Have but their stings and teeth newly ta'en out
32027 By whose fell working I was first advanc'd
32028 And by whose power I well might lodge a fear
32029 To be again displac'd which to avoid
32030 I cut them off and had a purpose now
32031 To lead out many to the Holy Land
32032 Lest rest and lying still might make them look
32033 Too near unto my state Therefore my Harry
32034 Be it thy course to busy giddy minds
32035 With foreign quarrels that action hence borne out
32036 May waste the memory of the former days
32037 More would I but my lungs are wasted so
32038 That strength of speech is utterly denied me
32039 How I came by the crown O God forgive
32040 And grant it may with thee in true peace live
32041 PRINCE My gracious liege
32042 You won it wore it kept it gave it me
32043 Then plain and right must my possession be
32044 Which I with more than with a common pain
32045 'Gainst all the world will rightfully maintain
32046 Enter PRINCE JOHN OF LANCASTER WARWICK LORDS and others
32047 KING Look look here comes my John of Lancaster
32048 PRINCE JOHN Health peace and happiness to my royal father
32049 KING Thou bring'st me happiness and peace son John
32050 But health alack with youthful wings is flown
32051 From this bare wither'd trunk Upon thy sight
32052 My worldly business makes a period
32053 Where is my Lord of Warwick
32054 PRINCE My Lord of Warwick
32055 KING Doth any name particular belong
32056 Unto the lodging where I first did swoon
32057 WARWICK 'Tis call'd Jerusalem my noble lord
32058 KING Laud be to God Even there my life must end
32059 It hath been prophesied to me many years
32060 I should not die but in Jerusalem
32061 Which vainly I suppos'd the Holy Land
32062 But bear me to that chamber there I'll lie
32063 In that Jerusalem shall Harry die Exeunt

32072 ACT V SCENE I
32073 Gloucestershire SHALLOW'S house
32074 Enter SHALLOW FALSTAFF BARDOLPH and PAGE
32075 SHALLOW By cock and pie sir you shall not away tonight
32076 What Davy I say
32077 FALSTAFF You must excuse me Master Robert Shallow
32078 SHALLOW I will not excuse you you shall not be excus'd excuses
32079 shall not be admitted there is no excuse shall serve you shall
32080 not be excus'd Why Davy
32081 Enter DAVY
32082 DAVY Here sir
32083 SHALLOW Davy Davy Davy Davy let me see Davy let me see
32084 Davy let me see yea marry William cook bid him come hither
32085 Sir John you shall not be excus'd
32086 DAVY Marry sir thus those precepts cannot be served and
32087 again sir shall we sow the headland with wheat
32088 SHALLOW With red wheat Davy But for William cook are there no
32089 young pigeons
32090 DAVY Yes sir Here is now the smith's note for shoeing and
32091 ploughirons
32092 SHALLOW Let it be cast and paid Sir John you shall not be
32093 excused
32094 DAVY Now sir a new link to the bucket must needs be had and
32095 sir do you mean to stop any of William's wages about the sack he
32096 lost the other day at Hinckley fair
32097 SHALLOW 'A shall answer it Some pigeons Davy a couple of
32098 shortlegg'd hens a joint of mutton and any pretty little tiny
32099 kickshaws tell William cook
32100 DAVY Doth the man of war stay all night sir
32101 SHALLOW Yea Davy I will use him well A friend i th court is
32102 better than a penny in purse Use his men well Davy for they
32103 are arrant knaves and will backbite
32104 DAVY No worse than they are backbitten sir for they have
32105 marvellous foul linen
32106 SHALLOW Well conceited Davy about thy business Davy
32107 DAVY I beseech you sir to countenance William Visor of Woncot
32108 against Clement Perkes o th hill
32109 SHALLOW There is many complaints Davy against that Visor That
32110 Visor is an arrant knave on my knowledge
32111 DAVY I grant your worship that he is a knave sir but yet God
32112 forbid sir but a knave should have some countenance at his
32113 friend's request An honest man sir is able to speak for
32114 himself when a knave is not I have serv'd your worship truly
32115 sir this eight years an I cannot once or twice in a quarter
32116 bear out a knave against an honest man I have but a very little
32117 credit with your worship The knave is mine honest friend sir
32118 therefore I beseech you let him be countenanc'd
32119 SHALLOW Go to I say he shall have no wrong Look about
32120 DAVY [Exit DAVY] Where are you Sir John Come come come off
32121 with your boots Give me your hand Master Bardolph
32122 BARDOLPH I am glad to see your worship
32123 SHALLOW I thank thee with all my heart kind Master Bardolph
32124 [To the PAGE] And welcome my tall fellow Come Sir John
32125 FALSTAFF I'll follow you good Master Robert Shallow
32126 [Exit SHALLOW] Bardolph look to our horses [Exeunt BARDOLPH
32127 and PAGE] If I were sawed into quantities I should make four
32128 dozen of such bearded hermits staves as Master Shallow It is a
32129 wonderful thing to see the semblable coherence of his men's
32130 spirits and his They by observing of him do bear themselves
32131 like foolish justices he by conversing with them is turned
32132 into a justicelike servingman Their spirits are so married in
32133 conjunction with the participation of society that they flock
32134 together in consent like so many wild geese If I had a suit to
32135 Master Shallow I would humour his men with the imputation of
32136 being near their master if to his men I would curry with Master
32137 Shallow that no man could better command his servants It is
32138 certain that either wise bearing or ignorant carriage is caught
32139 as men take diseases one of another therefore let men take heed
32140 of their company I will devise matter enough out of this Shallow
32141 to keep Prince Harry in continual laughter the wearing out of six
32142 fashions which is four terms or two actions and 'a shall laugh
32143 without intervallums O it is much that a lie with a slight
32144 oath and a jest with a sad brow will do with a fellow that never
32145 had the ache in his shoulders O you shall see him laugh till
32146 his face be like a wet cloak ill laid up
32147 SHALLOW [Within] Sir John
32148 FALSTAFF I come Master Shallow I come Master Shallow
32149 Exit
32150 SCENE II
32151 Westminster The palace
32152 Enter severally WARWICK and the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE
32153 WARWICK How now my Lord Chief Justice whither away
32154 CHIEF JUSTICE How doth the King
32155 WARWICK Exceeding well his cares are now all ended
32156 CHIEF JUSTICE I hope not dead
32157 WARWICK He's walk'd the way of nature
32158 And to our purposes he lives no more
32159 CHIEF JUSTICE I would his Majesty had call'd me with him
32160 The service that I truly did his life
32161 Hath left me open to all injuries
32162 WARWICK Indeed I think the young king loves you not
32163 CHIEF JUSTICE I know he doth not and do arm myself
32164 To welcome the condition of the time
32165 Which cannot look more hideously upon me
32166 Than I have drawn it in my fantasy
32167 Enter LANCASTER CLARENCE GLOUCESTER
32168 WESTMORELAND and others
32169 WARWICK Here comes the heavy issue of dead Harry
32170 O that the living Harry had the temper
32171 Of he the worst of these three gentlemen
32172 How many nobles then should hold their places
32173 That must strike sail to spirits of vile sort
32174 CHIEF JUSTICE O God I fear all will be overturn'd
32175 PRINCE JOHN Good morrow cousin Warwick good morrow
32176 GLOUCESTER & CLARENCE Good morrow cousin
32177 PRINCE JOHN We meet like men that had forgot to speak
32178 WARWICK We do remember but our argument
32179 Is all too heavy to admit much talk
32180 PRINCE JOHN Well peace be with him that hath made us heavy
32181 CHIEF JUSTICE Peace be with us lest we be heavier
32182 PRINCE HUMPHREY O good my lord you have lost a friend indeed
32183 And I dare swear you borrow not that face
32184 Of seeming sorrow it is sure your own
32185 PRINCE JOHN Though no man be assur'd what grace to find
32186 You stand in coldest expectation
32187 I am the sorrier would 'twere otherwise
32188 CLARENCE Well you must now speak Sir John Falstaff fair
32189 Which swims against your stream of quality
32190 CHIEF JUSTICE Sweet Princes what I did I did in honour
32191 Led by th impartial conduct of my soul
32192 And never shall you see that I will beg
32193 A ragged and forestall'd remission
32194 If truth and upright innocency fail me
32195 I'll to the King my master that is dead
32196 And tell him who hath sent me after him
32197 WARWICK Here comes the Prince
32198 Enter KING HENRY THE FIFTH attended
32199 CHIEF JUSTICE Good morrow and God save your Majesty
32200 KING This new and gorgeous garment majesty
32201 Sits not so easy on me as you think
32202 Brothers you mix your sadness with some fear
32203 This is the English not the Turkish court
32204 Not Amurath an Amurath succeeds
32205 But Harry Harry Yet be sad good brothers
32206 For by my faith it very well becomes you
32207 Sorrow so royally in you appears
32208 That I will deeply put the fashion on
32209 And wear it in my heart Why then be sad
32210 But entertain no more of it good brothers
32211 Than a joint burden laid upon us all
32212 For me by heaven I bid you be assur'd
32213 I'll be your father and your brother too
32214 Let me but bear your love I'll bear your cares
32215 Yet weep that Harry's dead and so will I
32216 But Harry lives that shall convert those tears
32217 By number into hours of happiness
32218 BROTHERS We hope no otherwise from your Majesty
32219 KING You all look strangely on me and you most
32220 You are I think assur'd I love you not
32221 CHIEF JUSTICE I am assur'd if I be measur'd rightly
32222 Your Majesty hath no just cause to hate me
32223 KING No
32224 How might a prince of my great hopes forget
32225 So great indignities you laid upon me
32226 What rate rebuke and roughly send to prison
32227 Th immediate heir of England Was this easy
32228 May this be wash'd in Lethe and forgotten
32229 CHIEF JUSTICE I then did use the person of your father
32230 The image of his power lay then in me
32231 And in th administration of his law
32232 Whiles I was busy for the commonwealth
32233 Your Highness pleased to forget my place
32234 The majesty and power of law and justice
32235 The image of the King whom I presented
32236 And struck me in my very seat of judgment
32237 Whereon as an offender to your father
32238 I gave bold way to my authority
32239 And did commit you If the deed were ill
32240 Be you contented wearing now the garland
32241 To have a son set your decrees at nought
32242 To pluck down justice from your awful bench
32243 To trip the course of law and blunt the sword
32244 That guards the peace and safety of your person
32245 Nay more to spurn at your most royal image
32246 And mock your workings in a second body
32247 Question your royal thoughts make the case yours
32248 Be now the father and propose a son
32249 Hear your own dignity so much profan'd
32250 See your most dreadful laws so loosely slighted
32251 Behold yourself so by a son disdain'd
32252 And then imagine me taking your part
32253 And in your power soft silencing your son
32254 After this cold considerance sentence me
32255 And as you are a king speak in your state
32256 What I have done that misbecame my place
32257 My person or my liege's sovereignty
32258 KING You are right Justice and you weigh this well
32259 Therefore still bear the balance and the sword
32260 And I do wish your honours may increase
32261 Till you do live to see a son of mine
32262 Offend you and obey you as I did
32263 So shall I live to speak my father's words
32264 'Happy am I that have a man so bold
32265 That dares do justice on my proper son
32266 And not less happy having such a son
32267 That would deliver up his greatness so
32268 Into the hands of justice You did commit me
32269 For which I do commit into your hand
32270 Th unstained sword that you have us'd to bear
32271 With this remembrance that you use the same
32272 With the like bold just and impartial spirit
32273 As you have done 'gainst me There is my hand
32274 You shall be as a father to my youth
32275 My voice shall sound as you do prompt mine ear
32276 And I will stoop and humble my intents
32277 To your wellpractis'd wise directions
32278 And Princes all believe me I beseech you
32279 My father is gone wild into his grave
32280 For in his tomb lie my affections
32281 And with his spirits sadly I survive
32282 To mock the expectation of the world
32283 To frustrate prophecies and to raze out
32284 Rotten opinion who hath writ me down
32285 After my seeming The tide of blood in me
32286 Hath proudly flow'd in vanity till now
32287 Now doth it turn and ebb back to the sea
32288 Where it shall mingle with the state of floods
32289 And flow henceforth in formal majesty
32290 Now call we our high court of parliament
32291 And let us choose such limbs of noble counsel
32292 That the great body of our state may go
32293 In equal rank with the best govern'd nation
32294 That war or peace or both at once may be
32295 As things acquainted and familiar to us
32296 In which you father shall have foremost hand
32297 Our coronation done we will accite
32298 As I before rememb'red all our state
32299 And God consigning to my good intents
32300 No prince nor peer shall have just cause to say
32301 God shorten Harry's happy life one day Exeunt
32302 SCENE III
32303 Gloucestershire SHALLOW'S orchard
32304 Enter FALSTAFF SHALLOW SILENCE BARDOLPH the PAGE and DAVY
32305 SHALLOW Nay you shall see my orchard where in an arbour we
32306 will eat a last year's pippin of mine own graffing with a dish
32307 of caraways and so forth Come cousin Silence And then to bed
32308 FALSTAFF Fore God you have here a goodly dwelling and rich
32309 SHALLOW Barren barren barren beggars all beggars all Sir John
32310 marry good air Spread Davy spread Davy well said Davy
32311 FALSTAFF This Davy serves you for good uses he is your
32312 servingman and your husband
32313 SHALLOW A good varlet a good varlet a very good varlet Sir
32314 John By the mass I have drunk too much sack at supper A good
32315 varlet Now sit down now sit down come cousin
32316 SILENCE Ah sirrah quotha we shall [Singing]
32317 Do nothing but eat and make good cheer
32318 And praise God for the merry year
32319 When flesh is cheap and females dear
32320 And lusty lads roam here and there
32321 So merrily
32322 And ever among so merrily
32323 FALSTAFF There's a merry heart Good Master Silence I'll give you
32324 a health for that anon
32325 SHALLOW Give Master Bardolph some wine Davy
32326 DAVY Sweet sir sit I'll be with you anon most sweet sir sit
32327 Master Page good Master Page sit Proface What you want in
32328 meat we'll have in drink But you must bear the heart's all
32329 Exit
32330 SHALLOW Be merry Master Bardolph and my little soldier there
32331 be merry
32332 SILENCE [Singing]
32333 Be merry be merry my wife has all
32334 For women are shrews both short and tall
32335 'Tis merry in hall when beards wag an
32336 And welcome merry Shrovetide
32337 Be merry be merry
32338 FALSTAFF I did not think Master Silence had been a man of this
32339 mettle
32340 SILENCE Who I I have been merry twice and once ere now
32341 Reenter DAVY
32342 DAVY [To BARDOLPH] There's a dish of leathercoats for you
32343 SHALLOW Davy
32344 DAVY Your worship I'll be with you straight [To BARDOLPH]
32345 A cup of wine sir
32346 SILENCE [Singing]
32347 A cup of wine that's brisk and fine
32348 And drink unto the leman mine
32349 And a merry heart lives longa
32350 FALSTAFF Well said Master Silence
32351 SILENCE An we shall be merry now comes in the sweet o th night
32352 FALSTAFF Health and long life to you Master Silence
32353 SILENCE [Singing]
32354 Fill the cup and let it come
32355 I'll pledge you a mile to th bottom
32356 SHALLOW Honest Bardolph welcome if thou want'st anything and
32357 wilt not call beshrew thy heart Welcome my little tiny thief
32358 and welcome indeed too I'll drink to Master Bardolph and to all
32359 the cabileros about London
32360 DAVY I hope to see London once ere I die
32361 BARDOLPH An I might see you there Davy
32362 SHALLOW By the mass you'R crack a quart together ha will you
32363 not Master Bardolph
32364 BARDOLPH Yea sir in a pottlepot
32365 SHALLOW By God's liggens I thank thee The knave will stick by
32366 thee I can assure thee that 'A will not out 'a 'tis true
32367 bred
32368 BARDOLPH And I'll stick by him sir
32369 SHALLOW Why there spoke a king Lack nothing be merry
32370 [One knocks at door] Look who's at door there ho Who knocks
32371 Exit DAVY
32372 FALSTAFF [To SILENCE who has drunk a bumper] Why now you have
32373 done me right
32374 SILENCE [Singing]
32375 Do me right
32376 And dub me knight
32377 Samingo
32378 Is't not so
32379 FALSTAFF 'Tis so
32380 SILENCE Is't so Why then say an old man can do somewhat
32381 Reenter DAVY
32382 DAVY An't please your worship there's one Pistol come from the
32383 court with news
32384 FALSTAFF From the court Let him come in
32385 Enter PISTOL
32386 How now Pistol
32387 PISTOL Sir John God save you
32388 FALSTAFF What wind blew you hither Pistol
32389 PISTOL Not the ill wind which blows no man to good Sweet knight
32390 thou art now one of the greatest men in this realm
32391 SILENCE By'r lady I think 'a be but goodman Puff of Barson
32392 PISTOL Puff
32393 Puff in thy teeth most recreant coward base
32394 Sir John I am thy Pistol and thy friend
32395 And helterskelter have I rode to thee
32396 And tidings do I bring and lucky joys
32397 And golden times and happy news of price
32398 FALSTAFF I pray thee now deliver them like a man of this world
32399 PISTOL A foutra for the world and worldlings base
32400 I speak of Africa and golden joys
32401 FALSTAFF O base Assyrian knight what is thy news
32402 Let King Cophetua know the truth thereof
32403 SILENCE [Singing] And Robin Hood Scarlet and John
32404 PISTOL Shall dunghill curs confront the Helicons
32405 And shall good news be baffled
32406 Then Pistol lay thy head in Furies lap
32407 SHALLOW Honest gentleman I know not your breeding
32408 PISTOL Why then lament therefore
32409 SHALLOW Give me pardon sir If sir you come with news from the
32410 court I take it there's but two ways either to utter them or
32411 conceal them I am sir under the King in some authority
32412 PISTOL Under which king Bezonian Speak or die
32413 SHALLOW Under King Harry
32414 PISTOL Harry the Fourth or Fifth
32415 SHALLOW Harry the Fourth
32416 PISTOL A foutra for thine office
32417 Sir John thy tender lambkin now is King
32418 Harry the Fifth's the man I speak the truth
32419 When Pistol lies do this and fig me like
32420 The bragging Spaniard
32421 FALSTAFF What is the old king dead
32422 PISTOL As nail in door The things I speak are just
32423 FALSTAFF Away Bardolph saddle my horse Master Robert Shallow
32424 choose what office thou wilt in the land 'tis thine Pistol I
32425 will doublecharge thee with dignities
32426 BARDOLPH O joyful day
32427 I would not take a knighthood for my fortune
32428 PISTOL What I do bring good news
32429 FALSTAFF Carry Master Silence to bed Master Shallow my Lord
32430 Shallow be what thou wilt I am Fortune's steward Get on thy
32431 boots we'll ride all night O sweet Pistol Away Bardolph
32432 [Exit BARDOLPH] Come Pistol utter more to me and withal
32433 devise something to do thyself good Boot boot Master Shallow
32434 I know the young King is sick for me Let us take any man's
32435 horses the laws of England are at my commandment Blessed are
32436 they that have been my friends and woe to my Lord Chief Justice
32437 PISTOL Let vultures vile seize on his lungs also
32438 'Where is the life that late I led say they
32439 Why here it is welcome these pleasant days Exeunt
32440 SCENE IV
32441 London A street
32442 Enter BEADLES dragging in HOSTESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET
32443 HOSTESS No thou arrant knave I would to God that I might die
32444 that I might have thee hang'd Thou hast drawn my shoulder out of
32445 joint
32446 FIRST BEADLE The constables have delivered her over to me and she
32447 shall have whippingcheer enough I warrant her There hath been
32448 a man or two lately kill'd about her
32449 DOLL Nuthook nuthook you lie Come on I'll tell thee what
32450 thou damn'd tripevisag'd rascal an the child I now go with do
32451 miscarry thou wert better thou hadst struck thy mother thou
32452 paperfac'd villain
32453 HOSTESS O the Lord that Sir John were come He would make this a
32454 bloody day to somebody But I pray God the fruit of her womb
32455 miscarry
32456 FIRST BEADLE If it do you shall have a dozen of cushions again
32457 you have but eleven now Come I charge you both go with me for
32458 the man is dead that you and Pistol beat amongst you
32459 DOLL I'll tell you what you thin man in a censer I will have you
32460 as soundly swing'd for this you bluebottle rogue you filthy
32461 famish'd correctioner if you be not swing'd I'll forswear
32462 halfkirtles
32463 FIRST BEADLE Come come you she knighterrant come
32464 HOSTESS O God that right should thus overcome might
32465 Well of sufferance comes ease
32466 DOLL Come you rogue come bring me to a justice
32467 HOSTESS Ay come you starv'd bloodhound
32468 DOLL Goodman death goodman bones
32469 HOSTESS Thou atomy thou
32470 DOLL Come you thin thing come you rascal
32471 FIRST BEADLE Very well Exeunt
32472 SCENE V
32473 Westminster Near the Abbey
32474 Enter GROOMS strewing rushes
32475 FIRST GROOM More rushes more rushes
32476 SECOND GROOM The trumpets have sounded twice
32477 THIRD GROOM 'Twill be two o'clock ere they come from the
32478 coronation Dispatch dispatch Exeunt
32479 Trumpets sound and the KING and his train pass
32480 over the stage After them enter FALSTAFF SHALLOW
32481 PISTOL BARDOLPH and page
32482 FALSTAFF Stand here by me Master Robert Shallow I will make the
32483 King do you grace I will leer upon him as 'a comes by and do
32484 but mark the countenance that he will give me
32485 PISTOL God bless thy lungs good knight
32486 FALSTAFF Come here Pistol stand behind me [To SHALLOW] O if
32487 I had had to have made new liveries I would have bestowed the
32488 thousand pound I borrowed of you But 'tis no matter this poor
32489 show doth better this doth infer the zeal I had to see him
32490 SHALLOW It doth so
32491 FALSTAFF It shows my earnestness of affection
32492 SHALLOW It doth so
32493 FALSTAFF My devotion
32494 SHALLOW It doth it doth it doth
32495 FALSTAFF As it were to ride day and night and not to deliberate
32496 not to remember not to have patience to shift me
32497 SHALLOW It is best certain
32498 FALSTAFF But to stand stained with travel and sweating with
32499 desire to see him thinking of nothing else putting all affairs
32500 else in oblivion as if there were nothing else to be done but to
32501 see him
32502 PISTOL 'Tis 'semper idem for 'obsque hoc nihil est 'Tis all in
32503 every part
32504 SHALLOW 'Tis so indeed
32505 PISTOL My knight I will inflame thy noble liver
32506 And make thee rage
32507 Thy Doll and Helen of thy noble thoughts
32508 Is in base durance and contagious prison
32509 Hal'd thither
32510 By most mechanical and dirty hand
32511 Rouse up revenge from ebon den with fell Alecto's snake
32512 For Doll is in Pistol speaks nought but truth
32513 FALSTAFF I will deliver her
32514 [Shoutswithin and the trumpets sound]
32515 PISTOL There roar'd the sea and trumpetclangor sounds
32516 Enter the KING and his train the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE
32517 among them
32518 FALSTAFF God save thy Grace King Hal my royal Hal
32519 PISTOL The heavens thee guard and keep most royal imp of fame
32520 FALSTAFF God save thee my sweet boy
32521 KING My Lord Chief Justice speak to that vain man
32522 CHIEF JUSTICE Have you your wits Know you what 'tis you speak
32523 FALSTAFF My king my Jove I speak to thee my heart
32524 KING I know thee not old man Fall to thy prayers
32525 How ill white hairs become a fool and jester
32526 I have long dreamt of such a kind of man
32527 So surfeitswell'd so old and so profane
32528 But being awak'd I do despise my dream
32529 Make less thy body hence and more thy grace
32530 Leave gormandizing know the grave doth gape
32531 For thee thrice wider than for other men
32532 Reply not to me with a foolborn jest
32533 Presume not that I am the thing I was
32534 For God doth know so shall the world perceive
32535 That I have turn'd away my former self
32536 So will I those that kept me company
32537 When thou dost hear I am as I have been
32538 Approach me and thou shalt be as thou wast
32539 The tutor and the feeder of my riots
32540 Till then I banish thee on pain of death
32541 As I have done the rest of my misleaders
32542 Not to come near our person by ten mile
32543 For competence of life I will allow you
32544 That lack of means enforce you not to evils
32545 And as we hear you do reform yourselves
32546 We will according to your strengths and qualities
32547 Give you advancement Be it your charge my lord
32548 To see perform'd the tenour of our word
32549 Set on Exeunt the KING and his train
32550 FALSTAFF Master Shallow I owe you a thousand pounds
32551 SHALLOW Yea marry Sir John which I beseech you to let me have
32552 home with me
32553 FALSTAFF That can hardly be Master Shallow Do not you grieve at
32554 this I shall be sent for in private to him Look you he must
32555 seem thus to the world Fear not your advancements I will be the
32556 man yet that shall make you great
32557 SHALLOW I cannot perceive how unless you give me your doublet
32558 and stuff me out with straw I beseech you good Sir John let me
32559 have five hundred of my thousand
32560 FALSTAFF Sir I will be as good as my word This that you heard
32561 was but a colour
32562 SHALLOW A colour that I fear you will die in Sir John
32563 FALSTAFF Fear no colours go with me to dinner Come Lieutenant
32564 Pistol come Bardolph I shall be sent for soon at night
32565 Reenter PRINCE JOHN the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE
32566 with officers
32567 CHIEF JUSTICE Go carry Sir John Falstaff to the Fleet
32568 Take all his company along with him
32569 FALSTAFF My lord my lord
32570 CHIEF JUSTICE I cannot now speak I will hear you soon
32571 Take them away
32572 PISTOL Si fortuna me tormenta spero me contenta
32573 Exeunt all but PRINCE JOHN and the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE
32574 PRINCE JOHN I like this fair proceeding of the King's
32575 He hath intent his wonted followers
32576 Shall all be very well provided for
32577 But all are banish'd till their conversations
32578 Appear more wise and modest to the world
32579 CHIEF JUSTICE And so they are
32580 PRINCE JOHN The King hath call'd his parliament my lord
32581 CHIEF JUSTICE He hath
32582 PRINCE JOHN I will lay odds that ere this year expire
32583 We bear our civil swords and native fire
32584 As far as France I heard a bird so sing
32585 Whose music to my thinking pleas'd the King
32586 Come will you hence Exeunt
32587 EPILOGUE
32588 EPILOGUE
32589 First my fear then my curtsy last my speech My fear is your
32590 displeasure my curtsy my duty and my speech to beg your pardons
32591 If you look for a good speech now you undo me for what I have to say
32592 is of mine own making and what indeed I should say will I doubt
32593 prove mine own marring But to the purpose and so to the venture
32594 Be it known to you as it is very well I was lately here in the end
32595 of a displeasing play to pray your patience for it and to promise you
32596 a better I meant indeed to pay you with this which if like an
32597 ill venture it come unluckily home I break and you my gentle
32598 creditors lose Here I promis'd you I would be and here I commit
32599 my body to your mercies Bate me some and I will pay you some and
32600 as most debtors do promise you infinitely and so I kneel down before
32601 you but indeed to pray for the Queen
32602 If my tongue cannot entreat you to acquit me will you command me to
32603 use my legs And yet that were but light paymentto dance out of
32604 your debt But a good conscience will make any possible
32605 satisfaction and so would I All the gentlewomen here have forgiven
32606 me If the gentlemen will not then the gentlemen do not agree with
32607 the gentlewomen which was never seen before in such an assembly
32608 One word more I beseech you If you be not too much cloy'd with fat
32609 meat our humble author will continue the story with Sir John in
32610 it and make you merry with fair Katherine of France where for
32611 anything I know Falstaff shall die of a sweat unless already 'a be
32612 killed with your hard opinions for Oldcastle died a martyr and this
32613 is not the man My tongue is weary when my legs are too I will bid
32614 you good night
32615 THE END

32668 SCENE
32669 England and France
32670 PROLOGUE
32671 PROLOGUE
32672 Enter CHORUS
32673 CHORUS O for a Muse of fire that would ascend
32674 The brightest heaven of invention
32675 A kingdom for a stage princes to act
32676 And monarchs to behold the swelling scene
32677 Then should the warlike Harry like himself
32678 Assume the port of Mars and at his heels
32679 Leash'd in like hounds should famine sword and fire
32680 Crouch for employment But pardon gentles all
32681 The flat unraised spirits that hath dar'd
32682 On this unworthy scaffold to bring forth
32683 So great an object Can this cockpit hold
32684 The vasty fields of France Or may we cram
32685 Within this wooden O the very casques
32686 That did affright the air at Agincourt
32687 O pardon since a crooked figure may
32688 Attest in little place a million
32689 And let us ciphers to this great accompt
32690 On your imaginary forces work
32691 Suppose within the girdle of these walls
32692 Are now confin'd two mighty monarchies
32693 Whose high upreared and abutting fronts
32694 The perilous narrow ocean parts asunder
32695 Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts
32696 Into a thousand parts divide one man
32697 And make imaginary puissance
32698 Think when we talk of horses that you see them
32699 Printing their proud hoofs i th receiving earth
32700 For 'tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings
32701 Carry them here and there jumping o'er times
32702 Turning th accomplishment of many years
32703 Into an hourglass for the which supply
32704 Admit me Chorus to this history
32705 Who prologuelike your humble patience pray
32706 Gently to hear kindly to judge our play Exit

32708 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
32709 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
32710 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
