33745 ACT III PROLOGUE
33746 Flourish Enter CHORUS
33747 CHORUS Thus with imagin'd wing our swift scene flies
33748 In motion of no less celerity
33749 Than that of thought Suppose that you have seen
33750 The wellappointed King at Hampton pier
33751 Embark his royalty and his brave fleet
33752 With silken streamers the young Phorbus fanning
33753 Play with your fancies and in them behold
33754 Upon the hempen tackle shipboys climbing
33755 Hear the shrill whistle which doth order give
33756 To sounds confus'd behold the threaden sails
33757 Borne with th invisible and creeping wind
33758 Draw the huge bottoms through the furrowed sea
33759 Breasting the lofty surge O do but think
33760 You stand upon the rivage and behold
33761 A city on th inconstant billows dancing
33762 For so appears this fleet majestical
33763 Holding due course to Harfleur Follow follow
33764 Grapple your minds to sternage of this navy
33765 And leave your England as dead midnight still
33766 Guarded with grandsires babies and old women
33767 Either past or not arriv'd to pith and puissance
33768 For who is he whose chin is but enrich'd
33769 With one appearing hair that will not follow
33770 These cull'd and choicedrawn cavaliers to France
33771 Work work your thoughts and therein see a siege
33772 Behold the ordnance on their carriages
33773 With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur
33774 Suppose th ambassador from the French comes back
33775 Tells Harry that the King doth offer him
33776 Katherine his daughter and with her to dowry
33777 Some petty and unprofitable dukedoms
33778 The offer likes not and the nimble gunner
33779 With linstock now the devilish cannon touches
33780 [Alarum and chambers go off]
33781 And down goes an before them Still be kind
33782 And eke out our performance with your mind Exit
33783 <<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
33784 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
33785 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
33786 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
33787 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
33788 PERSONAL USE ONLY AND 2 ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
33789 COMMERCIALLY PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
33790 SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP>>
33791 SCENE I
33792 France Before Harfleur
33793 Alarum Enter the KING EXETER BEDFORD GLOUCESTER
33794 and soldiers with scalingladders
33795 KING Once more unto the breach dear friends once more
33796 Or close the wall up with our English dead
33797 In peace there's nothing so becomes a man
33798 As modest stillness and humility
33799 But when the blast of war blows in our ears
33800 Then imitate the action of the tiger
33801 Stiffen the sinews summon up the blood
33802 Disguise fair nature with hardfavour'd rage
33803 Then lend the eye a terrible aspect
33804 Let it pry through the portage of the head
33805 Like the brass cannon let the brow o'erwhelm it
33806 As fearfully as doth a galled rock
33807 O'erhang and jutty his confounded base
33808 Swill'd with the wild and wasteful ocean
33809 Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide
33810 Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit
33811 To his full height On on you noblest English
33812 Whose blood is fet from fathers of warproof
33813 Fathers that like so many Alexanders
33814 Have in these parts from morn till even fought
33815 And sheath'd their swords for lack of argument
33816 Dishonour not your mothers now attest
33817 That those whom you call'd fathers did beget you
33818 Be copy now to men of grosser blood
33819 And teach them how to war And you good yeomen
33820 Whose limbs were made in England show us here
33821 The mettle of your pasture let us swear
33822 That you are worth your breeding which I doubt not
33823 For there is none of you so mean and base
33824 That hath not noble lustre in your eyes
33825 I see you stand like greyhounds in the slips
33826 Straining upon the start The game's afoot
33827 Follow your spirit and upon this charge
33828 Cry 'God for Harry England and Saint George'
33829 [Exeunt Alarum and chambers go off]
33830 SCENE II
33831 Before Harfleur
33832 Enter NYM BARDOLPH PISTOL and BOY
33833 BARDOLPH On on on on on to the breach to the breach
33834 NYM Pray thee Corporal stay the knocks are too hot and for
33835 mine own part I have not a case of lives The humour of it is too
33836 hot that is the very plainsong of it
33837 PISTOL The plainsong is most just for humours do abound
33838 Knocks go and come God's vassals drop and die
33839 And sword and shield
33840 In bloody field
33841 Doth win immortal fame
33842 BOY Would I were in an alehouse in London I wouid give all my
33843 fame for a pot of ale and safety
33844 PISTOL And I
33845 If wishes would prevail with me
33846 My purpose should not fail with me
33847 But thither would I hie
33848 BOY As duly but not as truly
33849 As bird doth sing on bough
33850 Enter FLUELLEN
33851 FLUELLEN Up to the breach you dogs
33852 Avaunt you cullions [Driving them forward]
33853 PISTOL Be merciful great duke to men of mould
33854 Abate thy rage abate thy manly rage
33855 Abate thy rage great duke
33856 Good bawcock bate thy rage Use lenity sweet chuck
33857 NYM These be good humours Your honour wins bad humours
33858 Exeunt all but BOY
33859 BOY As young as I am I have observ'd these three swashers I am
33860 boy to them all three but all they three though they would
33861 serve me could not be man to me for indeed three such antics do
33862 not amount to a man For Bardolph he is whiteliver'd and
33863 redfac'd by the means whereof 'a faces it out but fights not
33864 For Pistol he hath a killing tongue and a quiet sword by the
33865 means whereof 'a breaks words and keeps whole weapons For Nym
33866 he hath heard that men of few words are the best men and
33867 therefore he scorns to say his prayers lest 'a should be thought
33868 a coward but his few bad words are match'd with as few good
33869 deeds for 'a never broke any man's head but his own and that
33870 was against a post when he was drunk They will steal anything
33871 and call it purchase Bardolph stole a lutecase bore it twelve
33872 leagues and sold it for three halfpence Nym and Bardolph are
33873 sworn brothers in filching and in Calais they stole a
33874 fireshovel I knew by that piece of service the men would carry
33875 coals They would have me as familiar with men's pockets as their
33876 gloves or their handkerchers which makes much against my
33877 manhood if I should take from another's pocket to put into mine
33878 for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs I must leave them and
33879 seek some better service their villainy goes against my weak
33880 stomach and therefore I must cast it up Exit
33881 Reenter FLUELLEN GOWER following
33882 GOWER Captain Fluellen you must come presently to the mines the
33883 Duke of Gloucester would speak with you
33884 FLUELLEN To the mines Tell you the Duke it is not so good to come
33885 to the mines for look you the mines is not according to the
33886 disciplines of the war the concavities of it is not sufficient
33887 For look you th athversary you may discuss unto the Duke
33888 look you is digt himself four yard under the countermines by
33889 Cheshu I think 'a will plow up all if there is not better
33890 directions
33891 GOWER The Duke of Gloucester to whom the order of the siege is
33892 given is altogether directed by an Irishman a very vallant
33893 gentleman i faith
33894 FLUELLEN It is Captain Macmorris is it not
33895 GOWER I think it be
33896 FLUELLEN By Cheshu he is an ass as in the world I will verify
33897 as much in his beard he has no more directions in the true
33898 disciplines of the wars look you of the Roman disciplines than
33899 is a puppydog
33900 Enter MACMORRIS and CAPTAIN JAMY
33901 GOWER Here 'a comes and the Scots captain Captain Jamy with
33902 him
33903 FLUELLEN Captain Jamy is a marvellous falorous gentleman that is
33904 certain and of great expedition and knowledge in th aunchient
33905 wars upon my particular knowledge of his directions By Cheshu
33906 he will maintain his argument as well as any military man in the
33907 world in the disciplines of the pristine wars of the Romans
33908 JAMY I say gud day Captain Fluellen
33909 FLUELLEN Godden to your worship good Captain James
33910 GOWER How now Captain Macmorris Have you quit the mines Have
33911 the pioneers given o'er
33912 MACMORRIS By Chrish la tish ill done The work ish give over
33913 the trompet sound the retreat By my hand I swear and my
33914 father's soul the work ish ill done it ish give over I would
33915 have blowed up the town so Chrish save me la in an hour O
33916 tish ill done tish ill done by my hand tish ill done
33917 FLUELLEN Captain Macmorris I beseech you now will you voutsafe
33918 me look you a few disputations with you as partly touching or
33919 concerning the disciplines of the war the Roman wars in the way
33920 of argument look you and friendly communication partly to
33921 satisfy my opinion and partly for the satisfaction look you of
33922 my mind as touching the direction of the military discipline
33923 that is the point
33924 JAMY It sall be vary gud gud feith gud captains bath and I sall
33925 quit you with gud leve as I may pick occasion that sall I
33926 marry
33927 MACMORRIS It is no time to discourse so Chrish save me The day
33928 is hot and the weather and the wars and the King and the
33929 Dukes it is no time to discourse The town is beseech'd and the
33930 trumpet call us to the breach and we talk and be Chrish do
33931 nothing 'Tis shame for us all so God sa me 'tis shame to
33932 stand still it is shame by my hand and there is throats to be
33933 cut and works to be done and there ish nothing done so Chrish
33934 sa me la
33935 JAMY By the mess ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to
33936 slomber ay'll de gud service or I'll lig i th grund for it
33937 ay or go to death And I'll pay't as valorously as I may that
33938 sall I suerly do that is the breff and the long Marry I wad
33939 full fain heard some question 'tween you tway
33940 FLUELLEN Captain Macmorris I think look you under your
33941 correction there is not many of your nation
33942 MACMORRIS Of my nation What ish my nation Ish a villain and a
33943 bastard and a knave and a rascal What ish my nation Who talks
33944 of my nation
33945 FLUELLEN Look you if you take the matter otherwise than is meant
33946 Captain Macmorris peradventure I shall think you do not use me
33947 with that affability as in discretion you ought to use me look
33948 you being as good a man as yourself both in the disciplines of
33949 war and in the derivation of my birth and in other
33950 particularities
33951 MACMORRIS I do not know you so good a man as myself so
33952 Chrish save me I will cut off your head
33953 GOWER Gentlemen both you will mistake each other
33954 JAMY Ah that's a foul fault [A parley sounded]
33955 GOWER The town sounds a parley
33956 FLUELLEN Captain Macmorris when there is more better opportunity
33957 to be required look you I will be so bold as to tell you I know
33958 the disciplines of war and there is an end Exeunt
33959 SCENE III
33960 Before the gates of Harfleur
33961 Enter the GOVERNOR and some citizens on the walls Enter the KING
33962 and all his train before the gates
33963 KING HENRY How yet resolves the Governor of the town
33964 This is the latest parle we will admit
33965 Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves
33966 Or like to men proud of destruction
33967 Defy us to our worst for as I am a soldier
33968 A name that in my thoughts becomes me best
33969 If I begin the batt'ry once again
33970 I will not leave the halfachieved Harfleur
33971 Till in her ashes she lie buried
33972 The gates of mercy shall be all shut up
33973 And the flesh'd soldier rough and hard of heart
33974 In liberty of bloody hand shall range
33975 With conscience wide as hell mowing like grass
33976 Your fresh fair virgins and your flow'ring infants
33977 What is it then to me if impious war
33978 Array'd in flames like to the prince of fiends
33979 Do with his smirch'd complexion all fell feats
33980 Enlink'd to waste and desolation
33981 What is't to me when you yourselves are cause
33982 If your pure maidens fall into the hand
33983 Of hot and forcing violation
33984 What rein can hold licentious wickednes
33985 When down the hill he holds his fierce career
33986 We may as bootless spend our vain command
33987 Upon th enraged soldiers in their spoil
33988 As send precepts to the Leviathan
33989 To come ashore Therefore you men of Harfleur
33990 Take pity of your town and of your people
33991 Whiles yet my soldiers are in my command
33992 Whiles yet the cool and temperate wind of grace
33993 O'erblows the filthy and contagious clouds
33994 Of heady murder spoil and villainy
33995 If not why in a moment look to see
33996 The blind and bloody with foul hand
33997 Defile the locks of your shrillshrieking daughters
33998 Your fathers taken by the silver beards
33999 And their most reverend heads dash'd to the walls
34000 Your naked infants spitted upon pikes
34001 Whiles the mad mothers with their howls confus'd
34002 Do break the clouds as did the wives of Jewry
34003 At Herod's bloodyhunting slaughtermen
34004 What say you Will you yield and this avoid
34005 Or guilty in defence be thus destroy'd
34006 GOVERNOR Our expectation hath this day an end
34007 The Dauphin whom of succours we entreated
34008 Returns us that his powers are yet not ready
34009 To raise so great a siege Therefore great King
34010 We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy
34011 Enter our gates dispose of us and ours
34012 For we no longer are defensible
34013 KING HENRY Open your gates [Exit GOVERNOR] Come uncle Exeter
34014 Go you and enter Harfleur there remain
34015 And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French
34016 Use mercy to them all For us dear uncle
34017 The winter coming on and sickness growing
34018 Upon our soldiers we will retire to Calais
34019 Tonight in Harfleur will we be your guest
34020 Tomorrow for the march are we addrest
34021 [Flourish The KING and his train enter the town]
34022 SCENE IV
34023 Rouen The FRENCH KING'S palace
34024 Enter KATHERINE and ALICE
34025 KATHERINE Alice tu as ete en Angleterre et tu parles bien le
34026 langage
34027 ALICE Un peu madame
34028 KATHERINE Je te prie m'enseignez il faut que j'apprenne a
34029 parler Comment appelezvous la main en Anglais
34030 ALICE La main Elle est appelee de hand
34031 KATHERINE De hand Et les doigts
34032 ALICE Les doigts Ma foi j'oublie les doigts mais je me
34033 souviendrai Les doigts Je pense qu'ils sont appeles de fingres
34034 oui de fingres
34035 KATHERINE La main de hand les doigts de fingres Je pense que
34036 je suis le bon ecolier j'ai gagne deux mots d'Anglais vitement
34037 Comment appelezvous les ongles
34038 ALICE Les ongles Nous les appelons de nails
34039 KATHERINE De nails Ecoutez ditesmoi si je parle bien de hand
34040 de fingres et de nails
34041 ALICE C'est bien dit madame il est fort bon Anglais
34042 KATHERINE Ditesmoi l'Anglais pour le bras
34043 ALICE De arm madame
34044 KATHERINE Et le coude
34045 ALICE D'elbow
34046 KATHERINE D'elbow Je m'en fais la repetition de tous les mots que
34047 vous m'avez appris des a present
34048 ALICE Il est trop difficile madame comme je pense
34049 KATHERINE Excusezmoi Alice ecoutez d'hand de fingre de
34050 nails d'arma de bilbow
34051 ALICE D'elbow madame
34052 KATHERINE O Seigneur Dieu je m'en oublie D'elbow
34053 Comment appelezvous le col
34054 ALICE De nick madame
34055 KATHERINE De nick Et le menton
34056 ALICE De chin
34057 KATHERINE De sin Le col de nick le menton de sin
34058 ALICE Oui Sauf votre honneur en verite vous prononcez les mots
34059 aussi droit que les natifs d'Angleterre
34060 KATHERINE Je ne doute point d'apprendre par la grace de Dieu et
34061 en peu de temps
34062 ALICE N'avezvous pas deja oublie ce que je vous ai enseigne
34063 KATHERINE Non je reciterai a vous promptement d'hand de fingre
34064 de mails
34065 ALICE De nails madame
34066 KATHERINE De nails de arm de ilbow
34067 ALICE Sauf votre honneur d'elbow
34068 KATHERINE Ainsi disje d'elbow de nick et de sin Comment
34069 appelezvous le pied et la robe
34070 ALICE Le foot madame et le count
34071 KATHERINE Le foot et le count O Seigneur Dieu ils sont mots de
34072 son mauvais corruptible gros et impudique et non pour les
34073 dames d'honneur d'user je ne voudrais prononcer ces mots devant
34074 les seigneurs de France pour tout le monde Foh le foot et le
34075 count Neanmoins je reciterai une autre fois ma lecon ensemble
34076 d'hand de fingre de nails d'arm d'elbow de nick de sin de
34077 foot le count
34078 ALICE Excellent madame
34079 KATHERINE C'est assez pour une fois allonsnous a diner
34080 Exeunt
34081 SCENE V
34082 The FRENCH KING'S palace
34083 Enter the KING OF FRANCE the DAUPHIN DUKE OF BRITAINE
34084 the CONSTABLE OF FRANCE and others
34085 FRENCH KING 'Tis certain he hath pass'd the river Somme
34086 CONSTABLE And if he be not fought withal my lord
34087 Let us not live in France let us quit an
34088 And give our vineyards to a barbarous people
34089 DAUPHIN O Dieu vivant Shall a few sprays of us
34090 The emptying of our fathers luxury
34091 Our scions put in wild and savage stock
34092 Spirt up so suddenly into the clouds
34093 And overlook their grafters
34094 BRITAINE Normans but bastard Normans Norman bastards
34095 Mort Dieu ma vie if they march along
34096 Unfought withal but I will sell my dukedom
34097 To buy a slobb'ry and a dirty farm
34098 In that nookshotten isle of Albion
34099 CONSTABLE Dieu de batailles where have they this mettle
34100 Is not their climate foggy raw and dull
34101 On whom as in despite the sun looks pale
34102 Killing their fruit with frowns Can sodden water
34103 A drench for surrein'd jades their barleybroth
34104 Decoct their cold blood to such valiant heat
34105 And shall our quick blood spirited with wine
34106 Seem frosty O for honour of our land
34107 Let us not hang like roping icicles
34108 Upon our houses thatch whiles a more frosty people
34109 Sweat drops of gallant youth in our rich fields
34110 Poor we call them in their native lords
34111 DAUPHIN By faith and honour
34112 Our madams mock at us and plainly say
34113 Our mettle is bred out and they will give
34114 Their bodies to the lust of English youth
34115 To newstore France with bastard warriors
34116 BRITAINE They bid us to the English dancingschools
34117 And teach lavoltas high and swift corantos
34118 Saying our grace is only in our heels
34119 And that we are most lofty runaways
34120 FRENCH KING Where is Montjoy the herald Speed him hence
34121 Let him greet England with our sharp defiance
34122 Up Princes and with spirit of honour edged
34123 More sharper than your swords hie to the field
34124 Charles Delabreth High Constable of France
34125 You Dukes of Orleans Bourbon and of Berri
34126 Alengon Brabant Bar and Burgundy
34127 Jaques Chatillon Rambures Vaudemont
34128 Beaumont Grandpre Roussi and Fauconbridge
34129 Foix Lestrake Bouciqualt and Charolois
34130 High dukes great princes barons lords and knights
34131 For your great seats now quit you of great shames
34132 Bar Harry England that sweeps through our land
34133 With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur
34134 Rush on his host as doth the melted snow
34135 Upon the valleys whose low vassal seat
34136 The Alps doth spit and void his rheum upon
34137 Go down upon him you have power enough
34138 And in a captive chariot into Rouen
34139 Bring him our prisoner
34140 CONSTABLE This becomes the great
34141 Sorry am I his numbers are so few
34142 His soldiers sick and famish'd in their march
34143 For I am sure when he shall see our army
34144 He'll drop his heart into the sink of fear
34145 And for achievement offer us his ransom
34146 FRENCH KING Therefore Lord Constable haste on Montjoy
34147 And let him say to England that we send
34148 To know what willing ransom he will give
34149 Prince Dauphin you shall stay with us in Rouen
34150 DAUPHIN Not so I do beseech your Majesty
34151 FRENCH KING Be patient for you shall remain with us
34152 Now forth Lord Constable and Princes all
34153 And quickly bring us word of England's fall Exeunt
34154 SCENE VI
34155 The English camp in Picardy
34156 Enter CAPTAINS English and Welsh GOWER and FLUELLEN
34157 GOWER How now Captain Fluellen Come you from the bridge
34158 FLUELLEN I assure you there is very excellent services committed
34159 at the bridge
34160 GOWER Is the Duke of Exeter safe
34161 FLUELLEN The Duke of Exeter is as magnanimous as Agamemnon and a
34162 man that I love and honour with my soul and my heart and my
34163 duty and my live and my living and my uttermost power He is
34164 not God be praised and blessed any hurt in the world but
34165 keeps the bridge most valiantly with excellent discipline There
34166 is an aunchient Lieutenant there at the bridge I think in my
34167 very conscience he is as valiant a man as Mark Antony and he is
34168 man of no estimation in the world but I did see him do as
34169 gallant service
34170 GOWER What do you call him
34171 FLUELLEN He is call'd Aunchient Pistol
34172 GOWER I know him not
34173 Enter PISTOL
34174 FLUELLEN Here is the man
34175 PISTOL Captain I thee beseech to do me favours
34176 The Duke of Exeter doth love thee well
34177 FLUELLEN Ay I praise God and I have merited some love at his
34178 hands
34179 PISTOL Bardolph a soldier firm and sound of heart
34180 And of buxom valour hath by cruel fate
34181 And giddy Fortune's furious fickle wheel
34182 That goddess blind
34183 That stands upon the rolling restless stone
34184 FLUELLEN By your patience Aunchient Pistol Fortune is painted
34185 blind with a muffler afore her eyes to signify to you that
34186 Fortune is blind and she is painted also with a wheel to
34187 signify to you which is the moral of it that she is turning
34188 and inconstant and mutability and variation and her foot look
34189 you is fixed upon a spherical stone which rolls and rolls and
34190 rolls In good truth the poet makes a most excellent description
34191 of it Fortune is an excellent moral
34192 PISTOL Fortune is Bardolph's foe and frowns on him
34193 For he hath stol'n a pax and hanged must 'a be
34194 A damned death
34195 Let gallows gape for dog let man go free
34196 And let not hemp his windpipe suffocate
34197 But Exeter hath given the doom of death
34198 For pax of little price
34199 Therefore go speak the Duke will hear thy voice
34200 And let not Bardolph's vital thread be cut
34201 With edge of penny cord and vile reproach
34202 Speak Captain for his life and I will thee requite
34203 FLUELLEN Aunchient Pistol I do partly understand your meaning
34204 PISTOL Why then rejoice therefore
34205 FLUELLEN Certainly Aunchient it is not a thing to rejoice at
34206 for if look you he were my brother I would desire the Duke to
34207 use his good pleasure and put him to execution for discipline
34208 ought to be used
34209 PISTOL Die and be damn'd and figo for thy friendship
34210 FLUELLEN It is well
34211 PISTOL The fig of Spain Exit
34212 FLUELLEN Very good
34213 GOWER Why this is an arrant counterfeit rascal I remember him
34214 now a bawd a cutpurse
34215 FLUELLEN I'll assure you 'a utt'red as prave words at the pridge
34216 as you shall see in a summer's day But it is very well what he
34217 has spoke to me that is well I warrant you when time is serve
34218 GOWER Why 'tis a gull a fool a rogue that now and then goes to
34219 the wars to grace himself at his return into London under the
34220 form of a soldier And such fellows are perfect in the great
34221 commanders names and they will learn you by rote where services
34222 were done at such and such a sconce at such a breach at such a
34223 convoy who came off bravely who was shot who disgrac'd what
34224 terms the enemy stood on and this they con perfectly in the
34225 phrase of war which they trick up with newtuned oaths and what
34226 a beard of the General's cut and a horrid suit of the camp will
34227 do among foaming bottles and alewash'd wits is wonderful to be
34228 thought on But you must learn to know such slanders of the age
34229 or else you may be marvellously mistook
34230 FLUELLEN I tell you what Captain Gower I do perceive he is not
34231 the man that he would gladly make show to the world he is if I
34232 find a hole in his coat I will tell him my mind [Drum within]
34233 Hark you the King is coming and I must speak with him from the
34234 pridge
34235 Drum and colours Enter the KING and his poor soldiers
34236 and GLOUCESTER
34237 God pless your Majesty
34238 KING HENRY How now Fluellen Cam'st thou from the bridge
34239 FLUELLEN Ay so please your Majesty The Duke of Exeter has very
34240 gallantly maintain'd the pridge the French is gone off look
34241 you and there is gallant and most prave passages Marry th'
34242 athversary was have possession of the pridge but he is enforced
34243 to retire and the Duke of Exeter is master of the pridge I can
34244 tell your Majesty the Duke is a prave man
34245 KING HENRY What men have you lost Fluellen
34246 FLUELLEN The perdition of th athversary hath been very great
34247 reasonable great marry for my part I think the Duke hath lost
34248 never a man but one that is like to be executed for robbing a
34249 church one Bardolph if your Majesty know the man his face is
34250 all bubukles and whelks and knobs and flames o fire and his
34251 lips blows at his nose and it is like a coal of fire sometimes
34252 plue and sometimes red but his nose is executed and his fire's
34253 out
34254 KING HENRY We would have all such offenders so cut off And we
34255 give express charge that in our marches through the country there
34256 be nothing compell'd from the villages nothing taken but paid
34257 for none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful
34258 language for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom the
34259 gentler gamester is the soonest winner
34260 Tucket Enter MONTJOY
34261 MONTJOY You know me by my habit
34262 KING HENRY Well then I know thee what shall I know of thee
34263 MONTJOY My master's mind
34264 KING HENRY Unfold it
34265 MONTJOY Thus says my king Say thou to Harry of England Though we
34266 seem'd dead we did but sleep advantage is a better soldier than
34267 rashness Tell him we could have rebuk'd him at Harfleur but
34268 that we thought not good to bruise an injury till it were full
34269 ripe Now we speak upon our cue and our voice is imperial
34270 England shall repent his folly see his weakness and admire our
34271 sufferance Bid him therefore consider of his ransom which must
34272 proportion the losses we have borne the subjects we have lost
34273 the disgrace we have digested which in weight to reanswer his
34274 pettiness would bow under For our losses his exchequer is too
34275 poor for th effusion of our blood the muster of his kingdom
34276 too faint a number and for our disgrace his own person kneeling
34277 at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction To this add
34278 defiance and tell him for conclusion he hath betrayed his
34279 followers whose condemnation is pronounc'd So far my king and
34280 master so much my office
34281 KING HENRY What is thy name I know thy quality
34282 MONTJOY Montjoy
34283 KING HENRY Thou dost thy office fairly Turn thee back
34284 And tell thy king I do not seek him now
34285 But could be willing to march on to Calais
34286 Without impeachment for to say the sooth
34287 Though 'tis no wisdom to confess so much
34288 Unto an enemy of craft and vantage
34289 My people are with sickness much enfeebled
34290 My numbers lessen'd and those few I have
34291 Almost no better than so many French
34292 Who when they were in health I tell thee herald
34293 I thought upon one pair of English legs
34294 Did march three Frenchmen Yet forgive me God
34295 That I do brag thus this your air of France
34296 Hath blown that vice in me I must repent
34297 Go therefore tell thy master here I am
34298 My ransom is this frail and worthless trunk
34299 My army but a weak and sickly guard
34300 Yet God before tell him we will come on
34301 Though France himself and such another neighbour
34302 Stand in our way There's for thy labour Montjoy
34303 Go bid thy master well advise himself
34304 If we may pass we will if we be hind'red
34305 We shall your tawny ground with your red blood
34306 Discolour and so Montjoy fare you well
34307 The sum of all our answer is but this
34308 We would not seek a battle as we are
34309 Nor as we are we say we will not shun it
34310 So tell your master
34311 MONTJOY I shall deliver so Thanks to your Highness Exit
34312 GLOUCESTER I hope they will not come upon us now
34313 KING HENRY We are in God's hand brother not in theirs
34314 March to the bridge it now draws toward night
34315 Beyond the river we'll encamp ourselves
34316 And on tomorrow bid them march away Exeunt
34317 SCENE VII
34318 The French camp near Agincourt
34319 Enter the CONSTABLE OF FRANCE the LORD RAMBURES the DUKE OF ORLEANS
34320 the DAUPHIN with others
34321 CONSTABLE Tut I have the best armour of the world
34322 Would it were day
34323 ORLEANS You have an excellent armour but let my horse have his
34324 due
34325 CONSTABLE It is the best horse of Europe
34326 ORLEANS Will it never be morning
34327 DAUPHIN My Lord of Orleans and my Lord High Constable you talk of
34328 horse and armour
34329 ORLEANS You are as well provided of both as any prince in the
34330 world
34331 DAUPHIN What a long night is this I will not change my horse with
34332 any that treads but on four pasterns Ca ha he bounds from the
34333 earth as if his entrails were hairs le cheval volant the
34334 Pegasus chez les narines de feu When I bestride him I soar I
34335 am a hawk He trots the air the earth sings when he touches it
34336 the basest horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of
34337 Hermes
34338 ORLEANS He's of the colour of the nutmeg
34339 DAUPHIN And of the heat of the ginger It is a beast for Perseus
34340 he is pure air and fire and the dull elements of earth and water
34341 never appear in him but only in patient stillness while his
34342 rider mounts him he is indeed a horse and all other jades you
34343 may call beasts
34344 CONSTABLE Indeed my lord it is a most absolute and excellent
34345 horse
34346 DAUPHIN It is the prince of palfreys his neigh is like the
34347 bidding of a monarch and his countenance enforces homage
34348 ORLEANS No more cousin
34349 DAUPHIN Nay the man hath no wit that cannot from the rising of
34350 the lark to the lodging of the lamb vary deserved praise on my
34351 palfrey It is a theme as fluent as the sea turn the sands into
34352 eloquent tongues and my horse is argument for them all 'tis a
34353 subject for a sovereign to reason on and for a sovereign's
34354 sovereign to ride on and for the world familiar to us and
34355 unknown to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at
34356 him I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus 'Wonder
34357 of nature'
34358 ORLEANS I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress
34359 DAUPHIN Then did they imitate that which I compos'd to my courser
34360 for my horse is my mistress
34361 ORLEANS Your mistress bears well
34362 DAUPHIN Me well which is the prescript praise and perfection of a
34363 good and particular mistress
34364 CONSTABLE Nay for methought yesterday your mistress shrewdly
34365 shook your back
34366 DAUPHIN So perhaps did yours
34367 CONSTABLE Mine was not bridled
34368 DAUPHIN O then belike she was old and gentle and you rode like a
34369 kern of Ireland your French hose off and in your strait
34370 strossers
34371 CONSTABLE You have good judgment in horsemanship
34372 DAUPHIN Be warn'd by me then they that ride so and ride not
34373 warily fall into foul bogs I had rather have my horse to my
34374 mistress
34375 CONSTABLE I had as lief have my mistress a jade
34376 DAUPHIN I tell thee Constable my mistress wears his own hair
34377 CONSTABLE I could make as true a boast as that if I had a sow to
34378 my mistress
34379 DAUPHIN 'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement et la
34380 truie lavee au bourbier Thou mak'st use of anything
34381 CONSTABLE Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress or any such
34382 proverb so little kin to the purpose
34383 RAMBURES My Lord Constable the armour that I saw in your tent
34384 tonight are those stars or suns upon it
34385 CONSTABLE Stars my lord
34386 DAUPHIN Some of them will fall tomorrow I hope
34387 CONSTABLE And yet my sky shall not want
34388 DAUPHIN That may be for you bear a many superfluously and 'twere
34389 more honour some were away
34390 CONSTABLE Ev'n as your horse bears your praises who would trot as
34391 well were some of your brags dismounted
34392 DAUPHIN Would I were able to load him with his desert Will it
34393 never be day I will trot tomorrow a mile and my way shall be
34394 paved with English faces
34395 CONSTABLE I will not say so for fear I should be fac'd out of my
34396 way but I would it were morning for I would fain be about the
34397 ears of the English
34398 RAMBURES Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners
34399 CONSTABLE You must first go yourself to hazard ere you have them
34400 DAUPHIN 'Tis midnight I'll go arm myself Exit
34401 ORLEANS The Dauphin longs for morning
34402 RAMBURES He longs to eat the English
34403 CONSTABLE I think he will eat all he kills
34404 ORLEANS By the white hand of my lady he's a gallant prince
34405 CONSTABLE Swear by her foot that she may tread out the oath
34406 ORLEANS He is simply the most active gentleman of France
34407 CONSTABLE Doing is activity and he will still be doing
34408 ORLEANS He never did harm that I heard of
34409 CONSTABLE Nor will do none tomorrow he will keep that good name
34410 still
34411 ORLEANS I know him to be valiant
34412 CONSTABLE I was told that by one that knows him better than you
34413 ORLEANS What's he
34414 CONSTABLE Marry he told me so himself and he said he car'd not
34415 who knew it
34416 ORLEANS He needs not it is no hidden virtue in him
34417 CONSTABLE By my faith sir but it is never anybody saw it but
34418 his lackey
34419 'Tis a hooded valour and when it appears it will bate
34420 ORLEANS Illwind never said well
34421 CONSTABLE I will cap that proverb with 'There is flattery in
34422 friendship'
34423 ORLEANS And I will take up that with 'Give the devil his due'
34424 CONSTABLE Well plac'd There stands your friend for the devil
34425 have at the very eye of that proverb with 'A pox of the devil'
34426 ORLEANS You are the better at proverbs by how much 'A fool's bolt
34427 is soon shot'
34428 CONSTABLE You have shot over
34429 ORLEANS 'Tis not the first time you were overshot
34430 Enter a MESSENGER
34431 MESSENGER My Lord High Constable the English lie within fifteen
34432 hundred paces of your tents
34433 CONSTABLE Who hath measur'd the ground
34434 MESSENGER The Lord Grandpre
34435 CONSTABLE A valiant and most expert gentleman Would it were day
34436 Alas poor Harry of England he longs not for the dawning as we
34437 do
34438 ORLEANS What a wretched and peevish fellow is this King of
34439 England to mope with his fatbrain'd followers so far out of his
34440 knowledge
34441 CONSTABLE If the English had any apprehension they would run
34442 away
34443 ORLEANS That they lack for if their heads had any intellectual
34444 armour they could never wear such heavy headpieces
34445 RAMBURES That island of England breeds very valiant creatures
34446 their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage
34447 ORLEANS Foolish curs that run winking into the mouth of a Russian
34448 bear and have their heads crush'd like rotten apples You may as
34449 well say that's a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the
34450 lip of a lion
34451 CONSTABLE Just just and the men do sympathise with the mastiffs
34452 in robustious and rough coming on leaving their wits with their
34453 wives and then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel
34454 they will eat like wolves and fight like devils
34455 ORLEANS Ay but these English are shrewdly out of beef
34456 CONSTABLE Then shall we find tomorrow they have only stomachs to
34457 eat and none to fight Now is it time to arm Come shall we
34458 about it
34459 ORLEANS It is now two o'clock but let me see by ten
34460 We shall have each a hundred Englishmen Exeunt
