34469 ACT IV PROLOGUE
34470 Enter CHORUS
34471 CHORUS Now entertain conjecture of a time
34472 When creeping murmur and the poring dark
34473 Fills the wide vessel of the universe
34474 From camp to camp through the foul womb of night
34475 The hum of either army stilly sounds
34476 That the fix'd sentinels almost receive
34477 The secret whispers of each other's watch
34478 Fire answers fire and through their paly flames
34479 Each battle sees the other's umber'd face
34480 Steed threatens steed in high and boastful neighs
34481 Piercing the night's dull ear and from the tents
34482 The armourers accomplishing the knights
34483 With busy hammers closing rivets up
34484 Give dreadful note of preparation
34485 The country cocks do crow the clocks do ton
34486 And the third hour of drowsy morning name
34487 Proud of their numbers and secure in soul
34488 The confident and overlusty French
34489 Do the lowrated English play at dice
34490 And chide the cripple tardygaited night
34491 Who like a foul and ugly witch doth limp
34492 So tediously away The poor condemned English
34493 Like sacrifices by their watchful fires
34494 Sit patiently and inly ruminate
34495 The morning's danger and their gesture sad
34496 Investing lanklean cheeks and warworn coats
34497 Presenteth them unto the gazing moon
34498 So many horrid ghosts O now who will behold
34499 The royal captain of this ruin'd band
34500 Walking from watch to watch from tent to tent
34501 Let him cry 'Praise and glory on his head'
34502 For forth he goes and visits all his host
34503 Bids them good morrow with a modest smile
34504 And calls them brothers friends and countrymen
34505 Upon his royal face there is no note
34506 How dread an army hath enrounded him
34507 Nor doth he dedicate one jot of colour
34508 Unto the weary and allwatched night
34509 But freshly looks and overbears attaint
34510 With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty
34511 That every wretch pining and pale before
34512 Beholding him plucks comfort from his looks
34513 A largess universal like the sun
34514 His liberal eye doth give to every one
34515 Thawing cold fear that mean and gentle all
34516 Behold as may unworthiness define
34517 A little touch of Harry in the night
34518 And so our scene must to the battle fly
34519 Where O for pity we shall much disgrace
34520 With four or five most vile and ragged foils
34521 Right illdispos'd in brawl ridiculous
34522 The name of Agincourt Yet sit and see
34523 Minding true things by what their mock'ries be Exit
34524 SCENE I
34525 France The English camp at Agincourt
34526 Enter the KING BEDFORD and GLOUCESTER
34527 KING HENRY Gloucester 'tis true that we are in great danger
34528 The greater therefore should our courage be
34529 Good morrow brother Bedford God Almighty
34530 There is some soul of goodness in things evil
34531 Would men observingly distil it out
34532 For our bad neighbour makes us early stirrers
34533 Which is both healthful and good husbandry
34534 Besides they are our outward consciences
34535 And preachers to us all admonishing
34536 That we should dress us fairly for our end
34537 Thus may we gather honey from the weed
34538 And make a moral of the devil himself
34539 Enter ERPINGHAM
34540 Good morrow old Sir Thomas Erpingham
34541 A good soft pillow for that good white head
34542 Were better than a churlish turf of France
34543 ERPINGHAM Not so my liege this lodging likes me better
34544 Since I may say 'Now lie I like a king'
34545 KING HENRY 'Tis good for men to love their present pains
34546 Upon example so the spirit is eased
34547 And when the mind is quick'ned out of doubt
34548 The organs though defunct and dead before
34549 Break up their drowsy grave and newly move
34550 With casted slough and fresh legerity
34551 Lend me thy cloak Sir Thomas Brothers both
34552 Commend me to the princes in our camp
34553 Do my good morrow to them and anon
34554 Desire them all to my pavilion
34555 GLOUCESTER We shall my liege
34556 ERPINGHAM Shall I attend your Grace
34557 KING HENRY No my good knight
34558 Go with my brothers to my lords of England
34559 I and my bosom must debate awhile
34560 And then I would no other company
34561 ERPINGHAM The Lord in heaven bless thee noble Harry
34562 Exeunt all but the KING
34563 KING HENRY Godamercy old heart thou speak'st cheerfully
34564 Enter PISTOL
34565 PISTOL Qui va la
34566 KING HENRY A friend
34567 PISTOL Discuss unto me art thou officer
34568 Or art thou base common and popular
34569 KING HENRY I am a gentleman of a company
34570 PISTOL Trail'st thou the puissant pike
34571 KING HENRY Even so What are you
34572 PISTOL As good a gentleman as the Emperor
34573 KING HENRY Then you are a better than the King
34574 PISTOL The King's a bawcock and a heart of gold
34575 A lad of life an imp of fame
34576 Of parents good of fist most valiant
34577 I kiss his dirty shoe and from heartstring
34578 I love the lovely bully What is thy name
34579 KING HENRY Harry le Roy
34580 PISTOL Le Roy a Cornish name art thou of Cornish crew
34581 KING HENRY No I am a Welshman
34582 PISTOL Know'st thou Fluellen
34583 KING HENRY Yes
34584 PISTOL Tell him I'll knock his leek about his pate
34585 Upon Saint Davy's day
34586 KING HENRY Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day lest
34587 he knock that about yours
34588 PISTOL Art thou his friend
34589 KING HENRY And his kinsman too
34590 PISTOL The figo for thee then
34591 KING HENRY I thank you God be with you
34592 PISTOL My name is Pistol call'd Exit
34593 KING HENRY It sorts well with your fierceness
34594 Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER
34595 GOWER Captain Fluellen
34596 FLUELLEN So in the name of Jesu Christ speak fewer It is the
34597 greatest admiration in the universal world when the true and
34598 aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the wars is not kept if you
34599 would take the pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the Great
34600 you shall find I warrant you that there is no tiddletaddle nor
34601 pibblepabble in Pompey's camp I warrant you you shall find the
34602 ceremonies of the wars and the cares of it and the forms of it
34603 and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to be otherwise
34604 GOWER Why the enemy is loud you hear him all night
34605 FLUELLEN If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating
34606 coxcomb is it meet think you that we should also look you be
34607 an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb In your own
34608 conscience now
34609 GOWER I will speak lower
34610 FLUELLEN I pray you and beseech you that you will
34611 Exeunt GOWER and FLUELLEN
34612 KING HENRY Though it appear a little out of fashion
34613 There is much care and valour in this Welshman
34614 Enter three soldiers JOHN BATES ALEXANDER COURT
34615 and MICHAEL WILLIAMS
34616 COURT Brother John Bates is not that the morning which breaks
34617 yonder
34618 BATES I think it be but we have no great cause to desire the
34619 approach of day
34620 WILLIAMS We see yonder the beginning of the day but I think we
34621 shall never see the end of it Who goes there
34622 KING HENRY A friend
34623 WILLIAMS Under what captain serve you
34624 KING HENRY Under Sir Thomas Erpingham
34625 WILLIAMS A good old commander and a most kind gentleman I pray
34626 you what thinks he of our estate
34627 KING HENRY Even as men wreck'd upon a sand that look to be wash'd
34628 off the next tide
34629 BATES He hath not told his thought to the King
34630 KING HENRY No nor it is not meet he should For though I speak it
34631 to you I think the King is but a man as I am the violet smells
34632 to him as it doth to me the element shows to him as it doth to
34633 me all his senses have but human conditions his ceremonies laid
34634 by in his nakedness he appears but a man and though his
34635 affections are higher mounted than ours yet when they stoop
34636 they stoop with the like wing Therefore when he sees reason of
34637 fears as we do his fears out of doubt be of the same relish
34638 as ours are yet in reason no man should possess him with any
34639 appearance of fear lest he by showing it should dishearten his
34640 army
34641 BATES He may show what outward courage he will but I believe as
34642 cold a night as 'tis he could wish himself in Thames up to the
34643 neck and so I would he were and I by him at all adventures so
34644 we were quit here
34645 KING HENRY By my troth I will speak my conscience of the King I
34646 think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is
34647 BATES Then I would he were here alone so should he be sure to be
34648 ransomed and a many poor men's lives saved
34649 KING HENRY I dare say you love him not so ill to wish him here
34650 alone howsoever you speak this to feel other men's minds
34651 methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the King's
34652 company his cause being just and his quarrel honourable
34653 WILLIAMS That's more than we know
34654 BATES Ay or more than we should seek after for we know enough if
34655 we know we are the King's subjects If his cause be wrong our
34656 obedience to the King wipes the crime of it out of us
34657 WILLIAMS But if the cause be not good the King himself hath a
34658 heavy reckoning to make when all those legs and arms and heads
34659 chopp'd off in a battle shall join together at the latter day
34660 and cry all 'We died at such a place some swearing some crying
34661 for a surgeon some upon their wives left poor behind them some
34662 upon the debts they owe some upon their children rawly left I
34663 am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle for how
34664 can they charitably dispose of anything when blood is their
34665 argument Now if these men do not die well it will be a black
34666 matter for the King that led them to it who to disobey were
34667 against all proportion of subjection
34668 KING HENRY So if a son that is by his father sent about
34669 merchandise do sinfully miscarry upon the sea the imputation of
34670 his wickedness by your rule should be imposed upon his father
34671 that sent him or if a servant under his master's command
34672 transporting a sum of money be assailed by robbers and die in
34673 many irreconcil'd iniquities you may call the business of the
34674 master the author of the servant's damnation But this is not so
34675 the King is not bound to answer the particular endings of his
34676 soldiers the father of his son nor the master of his servant
34677 for they purpose not their death when they purpose their
34678 services Besides there is no king be his cause never so
34679 spotless if it come to the arbitrement of swords can try it out
34680 with all unspotted soldiers some peradventure have on them the
34681 guilt of premeditated and contrived murder some of beguiling
34682 virgins with the broken seals of perjury some making the wars
34683 their bulwark that have before gored the gentle bosom of peace
34684 with pillage and robbery Now if these men have defeated the law
34685 and outrun native punishment though they can outstrip men they
34686 have no wings to fly from God war is His beadle war is His
34687 vengeance so that here men are punish'd for beforebreach of the
34688 King's laws in now the King's quarrel Where they feared the
34689 death they have borne life away and where they would be safe
34690 they perish Then if they die unprovided no more is the King
34691 guilty of their damnation than he was before guilty of those
34692 impieties for the which they are now visited Every subject's
34693 duty is the King's but every subject's soul is his own
34694 Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as every sick man
34695 in his bed wash every mote out of his conscience and dying so
34696 death is to him advantage or not dying the time was blessedly
34697 lost wherein such preparation was gained and in him that escapes
34698 it were not sin to think that making God so free an offer He
34699 let him outlive that day to see His greatness and to teach
34700 others how they should prepare
34701 WILLIAMS 'Tis certain every man that dies ill the ill upon his
34702 own head the King is not to answer for it
34703 BATES I do not desire he should answer for me and yet I determine
34704 to fight lustily for him
34705 KING HENRY I myself heard the King say he would not be ransom'd
34706 WILLIAMS Ay he said so to make us fight cheerfully but when our
34707 throats are cut he may be ransom'd and we ne'er the wiser
34708 KING HENRY If I live to see it I will never trust his word after
34709 WILLIAMS You pay him then That's a perilous shot out of an
34710 eldergun that a poor and a private displeasure can do against a
34711 monarch You may as well go about to turn the sun to ice with
34712 fanning in his face with a peacock's feather You'll never trust
34713 his word after Come 'tis a foolish saying
34714 KING HENRY Your reproof is something too round I should be angry
34715 with you if the time were convenient
34716 WILLIAMS Let it be a quarrel between us if you live
34717 KING HENRY I embrace it
34718 WILLIAMS How shall I know thee again
34719 KING HENRY Give me any gage of thine and I will wear it in my
34720 bonnet then if ever thou dar'st acknowledge it I will make it
34721 my quarrel
34722 WILLIAMS Here's my glove give me another of thine
34723 KING HENRY There
34724 WILLIAMS This will I also wear in my cap if ever thou come to me
34725 and say after tomorrow 'This is my glove by this hand I will
34726 take thee a box on the ear
34727 KING HENRY If ever I live to see it I will challenge it
34728 WILLIAMS Thou dar'st as well be hang'd
34729 KING HENRY Well I will do it though I take thee in the King's
34730 company
34731 WILLIAMS Keep thy word Fare thee well
34732 BATES Be friends you English fools be friends we have
34733 French quarrels enow if you could tell how to reckon
34734 KING HENRY Indeed the French may lay twenty French crowns to one
34735 they will beat us for they bear them on their shoulders but it
34736 is no English treason to cut French crowns and tomorrow the
34737 King himself will be a clipper
34738 Exeunt soldiers
34739 Upon the King Let us our lives our souls
34740 Our debts our careful wives
34741 Our children and our sins lay on the King
34742 We must bear all O hard condition
34743 Twinborn with greatness subject to the breath
34744 Of every fool whose sense no more can feel
34745 But his own wringing What infinite heart's ease
34746 Must kings neglect that private men enjoy
34747 And what have kings that privates have not too
34748 Save ceremony save general ceremony
34749 And what art thou thou idol Ceremony
34750 What kind of god art thou that suffer'st more
34751 Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers
34752 What are thy rents What are thy comingsin
34753 O Ceremony show me but thy worth
34754 What is thy soul of adoration
34755 Art thou aught else but place degree and form
34756 Creating awe and fear in other men
34757 Wherein thou art less happy being fear'd
34758 Than they in fearing
34759 What drink'st thou oft instead of homage sweet
34760 But poison'd flattery O be sick great greatness
34761 And bid thy ceremony give thee cure
34762 Thinks thou the fiery fever will go out
34763 With titles blown from adulation
34764 Will it give place to flexure and low bending
34765 Canst thou when thou command'st the beggar's knee
34766 Command the health of it No thou proud dream
34767 That play'st so subtly with a king's repose
34768 I am a king that find thee and I know
34769 'Tis not the balm the sceptre and the ball
34770 The sword the mace the crown imperial
34771 The intertissued robe of gold and pearl
34772 The farced tide running fore the king
34773 The throne he sits on nor the tide of pomp
34774 That beats upon the high shore of this world
34775 No not all these thrice gorgeous ceremony
34776 Not all these laid in bed majestical
34777 Can sleep so soundly as the wretched slave
34778 Who with a body fill'd and vacant mind
34779 Gets him to rest cramm'd with distressful bread
34780 Never sees horrid night the child of hell
34781 But like a lackey from the rise to set
34782 Sweats in the eye of Pheebus and all night
34783 Sleeps in Elysium next day after dawn
34784 Doth rise and help Hyperion to his horse
34785 And follows so the everrunning year
34786 With profitable labour to his grave
34787 And but for ceremony such a wretch
34788 Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep
34789 Had the forehand and vantage of a king
34790 The slave a member of the country's peace
34791 Enjoys it but in gross brain little wots
34792 What watch the king keeps to maintain the peace
34793 Whose hours the peasant best advantages
34794 Enter ERPINGHAM
34795 ERPINGHAM My lord your nobles jealous of your absence
34796 Seek through your camp to find you
34797 KING Good old knight
34798 Collect them all together at my tent
34799 I'll be before thee
34800 ERPINGHAM I shall do't my lord Exit
34801 KING O God of battles steel my soldiers hearts
34802 Possess them not with fear Take from them now
34803 The sense of reck'ning if th opposed numbers
34804 Pluck their hearts from them Not today O Lord
34805 O not today think not upon the fault
34806 My father made in compassing the crown
34807 I Richard's body have interred new
34808 And on it have bestowed more contrite tears
34809 Than from it issued forced drops of blood
34810 Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay
34811 Who twice a day their wither'd hands hold up
34812 Toward heaven to pardon blood and I have built
34813 Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests
34814 Sing still for Richard's soul More will I do
34815 Though all that I can do is nothing worth
34816 Since that my penitence comes after all
34817 Imploring pardon
34818 Enter GLOUCESTER
34819 GLOUCESTER My liege
34820 KING HENRY My brother Gloucester's voice Ay
34821 I know thy errand I will go with thee
34822 The day my friends and all things stay for me Exeunt
34823 SCENE II
34824 The French camp
34825 Enter the DAUPHIN ORLEANS RAMBURES and others
34826 ORLEANS The sun doth gild our armour up my lords
34827 DAUPHIN Montez a cheval My horse Varlet laquais Ha
34828 ORLEANS O brave spirit
34829 DAUPHIN Via Les eaux et la terre
34830 ORLEANS Rien puis L'air et le feu
34831 DAUPHIN Ciel cousin Orleans
34832 Enter CONSTABLE
34833 Now my Lord Constable
34834 CONSTABLE Hark how our steeds for present service neigh
34835 DAUPHIN Mount them and make incision in their hides
34836 That their hot blood may spin in English eyes
34837 And dout them with superfluous courage ha
34838 RAMBURES What will you have them weep our horses blood
34839 How shall we then behold their natural tears
34840 Enter a MESSENGER
34841 MESSENGER The English are embattl'd you French peers
34842 CONSTABLE To horse you gallant Princes straight to horse
34843 Do but behold yon poor and starved band
34844 And your fair show shall suck away their souls
34845 Leaving them but the shales and husks of men
34846 There is not work enough for all our hands
34847 Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins
34848 To give each naked curtleaxe a stain
34849 That our French gallants shall today draw out
34850 And sheathe for lack of sport Let us but blow on them
34851 The vapour of our valour will o'erturn them
34852 'Tis positive 'gainst all exceptions lords
34853 That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants
34854 Who in unnecessary action swarm
34855 About our squares of battle were enow
34856 To purge this field of such a hilding foe
34857 Though we upon this mountain's basis by
34858 Took stand for idle speculation
34859 But that our honours must not What's to say
34860 A very little little let us do
34861 And all is done Then let the trumpets sound
34862 The tucket sonance and the note to mount
34863 For our approach shall so much dare the field
34864 That England shall couch down in fear and yield
34865 Enter GRANDPRE
34866 GRANDPRE Why do you stay so long my lords of France
34867 Yond island carrions desperate of their bones
34868 Illfavouredly become the morning field
34869 Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose
34870 And our air shakes them passing scornfully
34871 Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggar'd host
34872 And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps
34873 The horsemen sit like fixed candlesticks
34874 With torchstaves in their hand and their poor jades
34875 Lob down their heads dropping the hides and hips
34876 The gum downroping from their paledead eyes
34877 And in their pale dull mouths the gimmal'd bit
34878 Lies foul with chaw'd grass still and motionless
34879 And their executors the knavish crows
34880 Fly o'er them all impatient for their hour
34881 Description cannot suit itself in words
34882 To demonstrate the life of such a battle
34883 In life so lifeless as it shows itself
34884 CONSTABLE They have said their prayers and they stay for death
34885 DAUPHIN Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits
34886 And give their fasting horses provender
34887 And after fight with them
34888 CONSTABLE I stay but for my guidon To the field
34889 I will the banner from a trumpet take
34890 And use it for my haste Come come away
34891 The sun is high and we outwear the day Exeunt
34892 SCENE III
34893 The English camp
34894 Enter GLOUCESTER BEDFORD EXETER ERPINGHAM with all his host
34895 SALISBURY and WESTMORELAND
34896 GLOUCESTER Where is the King
34897 BEDFORD The King himself is rode to view their battle
34898 WESTMORELAND Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand
34899 EXETER There's five to one besides they all are fresh
34900 SALISBURY God's arm strike with us 'tis a fearful odds
34901 God bye you Princes all I'll to my charge
34902 If we no more meet till we meet in heaven
34903 Then joyfully my noble Lord of Bedford
34904 My dear Lord Gloucester and my good Lord Exeter
34905 And my kind kinsman warriors all adieu
34906 BEDFORD Farewell good Salisbury and good luck go with thee
34907 EXETER Farewell kind lord Fight valiantly today
34908 And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it
34909 For thou art fram'd of the firm truth of valour
34910 Exit SALISBURY
34911 BEDFORD He is as full of valour as of kindness
34912 Princely in both
34913 Enter the KING
34914 WESTMORELAND O that we now had here
34915 But one ten thousand of those men in England
34916 That do no work today
34917 KING What's he that wishes so
34918 My cousin Westmoreland No my fair cousin
34919 If we are mark'd to die we are enow
34920 To do our country loss and if to live
34921 The fewer men the greater share of honour
34922 God's will I pray thee wish not one man more
34923 By Jove I am not covetous for gold
34924 Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost
34925 It yearns me not if men my garments wear
34926 Such outward things dwell not in my desires
34927 But if it be a sin to covet honour
34928 I am the most offending soul alive
34929 No faith my coz wish not a man from England
34930 God's peace I would not lose so great an honour
34931 As one man more methinks would share from me
34932 For the best hope I have O do not wish one more
34933 Rather proclaim it Westmoreland through my host
34934 That he which hath no stomach to this fight
34935 Let him depart his passport shall be made
34936 And crowns for convoy put into his purse
34937 We would not die in that man's company
34938 That fears his fellowship to die with us
34939 This day is call'd the feast of Crispian
34940 He that outlives this day and comes safe home
34941 Will stand a tiptoe when this day is nam'd
34942 And rouse him at the name of Crispian
34943 He that shall live this day and see old age
34944 Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbours
34945 And say 'Tomorrow is Saint Crispian'
34946 Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars
34947 And say 'These wounds I had on Crispian's day'
34948 Old men forget yet all shall be forgot
34949 But he'll remember with advantages
34950 What feats he did that day Then shall our names
34951 Familiar in his mouth as household words
34952 Harry the King Bedford and Exeter
34953 Warwick and Talbot Salisbury and Gloucester
34954 Be in their flowing cups freshly rememb'red
34955 This story shall the good man teach his son
34956 And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by
34957 From this day to the ending of the world
34958 But we in it shall be remembered
34959 We few we happy few we band of brothers
34960 For he today that sheds his blood with me
34961 Shall be my brother be he ne'er so vile
34962 This day shall gentle his condition
34963 And gentlemen in England nowabed
34964 Shall think themselves accurs'd they were not here
34965 And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks
34966 That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day
34967 Reenter SALISBURY
34968 SALISBURY My sovereign lord bestow yourself with speed
34969 The French are bravely in their battles set
34970 And will with all expedience charge on us
34971 KING HENRY All things are ready if our minds be so
34972 WESTMORELAND Perish the man whose mind is backward now
34973 KING HENRY Thou dost not wish more help from England coz
34974 WESTMORELAND God's will my liege would you and I alone
34975 Without more help could fight this royal battle
34976 KING HENRY Why now thou hast unwish'd five thousand men
34977 Which likes me better than to wish us one
34978 You know your places God be with you all
34979 Tucket Enter MONTJOY
34980 MONTJOY Once more I come to know of thee King Harry
34981 If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound
34982 Before thy most assured overthrow
34983 For certainly thou art so near the gulf
34984 Thou needs must be englutted Besides in mercy
34985 The constable desires thee thou wilt mind
34986 Thy followers of repentance that their souls
34987 May make a peaceful and a sweet retire
34988 From off these fields where wretches their poor bodies
34989 Must lie and fester
34990 KING HENRY Who hath sent thee now
34991 MONTJOY The Constable of France
34992 KING HENRY I pray thee bear my former answer back
34993 Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones
34994 Good God why should they mock poor fellows thus
34995 The man that once did sell the lion's skin
34996 While the beast liv'd was kill'd with hunting him
34997 A many of our bodies shall no doubt
34998 Find native graves upon the which I trust
34999 Shall witness live in brass of this day's work
35000 And those that leave their valiant bones in France
35001 Dying like men though buried in your dunghills
35002 They shall be fam'd for there the sun shall greet them
35003 And draw their honours reeking up to heaven
35004 Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime
35005 The smell whereof shall breed a plague in France
35006 Mark then abounding valour in our English
35007 That being dead like to the bullet's grazing
35008 Break out into a second course of mischief
35009 Killing in relapse of mortality
35010 Let me speak proudly tell the Constable
35011 We are but warriors for the workingday
35012 Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirch'd
35013 With rainy marching in the painful field
35014 There's not a piece of feather in our host
35015 Good argument I hope we will not fly
35016 And time hath worn us into slovenry
35017 But by the mass our hearts are in the trim
35018 And my poor soldiers tell me yet ere night
35019 They'll be in fresher robes or they will pluck
35020 The gay new coats o'er the French soldiers heads
35021 And turn them out of service If they do this
35022 As if God please they shall my ransom then
35023 Will soon be levied Herald save thou thy labour
35024 Come thou no more for ransom gentle herald
35025 They shall have none I swear but these my joints
35026 Which if they have as I will leave 'em them
35027 Shall yield them little tell the Constable
35028 MONTJOY I shall King Harry And so fare thee well
35029 Thou never shalt hear herald any more Exit
35030 KING HENRY I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom
35031 Enter the DUKE OF YORK
35032 YORK My lord most humbly on my knee I beg
35033 The leading of the vaward
35034 KING HENRY Take it brave York Now soldiers march away
35035 And how thou pleasest God dispose the day Exeunt
35036 SCENE IV
35037 The field of battle
35038 Alarum Excursions Enter FRENCH SOLDIER PISTOL and BOY
35039 PISTOL Yield cur
35040 FRENCH SOLDIER Je pense que vous etes le gentilhomme de bonne
35041 qualite
35042 PISTOL Cality Calen o custure me Art thou a gentleman
35043 What is thy name Discuss
35044 FRENCH SOLDIER O Seigneur Dieu
35045 PISTOL O Signieur Dew should be a gentleman
35046 Perpend my words O Signieur Dew and mark
35047 O Signieur Dew thou diest on point of fox
35048 Except O Signieur thou do give to me
35049 Egregious ransom
35050 FRENCH SOLDIER O prenez misericorde ayez pitie de moi
35051 PISTOL Moy shall not serve I will have forty moys
35052 Or I will fetch thy rim out at thy throat
35053 In drops of crimson blood
35054 FRENCH SOLDIER Estil impossible d'echapper la force de ton bras
35055 PISTOL Brass cur
35056 Thou damned and luxurious mountaingoat
35057 Offer'st me brass
35058 FRENCH SOLDIER O pardonnezmoi
35059 PISTOL Say'st thou me so Is that a ton of moys
35060 Come hither boy ask me this slave in French
35061 What is his name
35062 BOY Ecoutez comment etesvous appele
35063 FRENCH SOLDIER Monsieur le Fer
35064 BOY He says his name is Master Fer
35065 PISTOL Master Fer I'll fer him and firk him and ferret him
35066 discuss the same in French unto him
35067 BOY I do not know the French for fer and ferret and firk
35068 PISTOL Bid him prepare for I will cut his throat
35069 FRENCH SOLDIER Que ditil monsieur
35070 BOY Il me commande a vous dire que vous faites vous pret car ce
35071 soldat ici est dispose tout a cette heure de couper votre gorge
35072 PISTOL Owy cuppele gorge permafoy
35073 Peasant unless thou give me crowns brave crowns
35074 Or mangled shalt thou be by this my sword
35075 FRENCH SOLDIER O je vous supplie pour l'amour de Dieu me
35076 pardonner Je suis gentilhomme de bonne maison Gardez ma vie et
35077 je vous donnerai deux cents ecus
35078 PISTOL What are his words
35079 BOY He prays you to save his life he is a gentleman of a good
35080 house and for his ransom he will give you two hundred crowns
35081 PISTOL Tell him my fury shall abate and I
35082 The crowns will take
35083 FRENCH SOLDIER Petit monsieur que ditil
35084 BOY Encore qu'il est contre son jurement de pardonner aucun
35085 prisonnier neamnoins pour les ecus que vous l'avez promis il
35086 est content a vous donner la liberte le franchisement
35087 FRENCH SOLDIER Sur mes genoux je vous donne mille remercimens et
35088 je m'estime heureux que je suis tombe entre les mains d'un
35089 chevalier je pense le plus brave vaillant et tres distingue
35090 seigneur d'Angleterre
35091 PISTOL Expound unto me boy
35092 BOY He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks and he
35093 esteems himself happy that he hath fall'n into the hands of one
35094 as he thinks the most brave valorous and thriceworthy
35095 signieur of England
35096 PISTOL As I suck blood I will some mercy show
35097 Follow me Exit
35098 BOY Suivezvous le grand capitaine Exit FRENCH SOLDIER
35099 I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart but
35100 the saying is true the empty vessel makes the greatest sound
35101 Bardolph and Nym had ten times more valour than this roaring
35102 devil i th old play that every one may pare his nails with a
35103 wooden dagger and they are both hang'd and so would this be if
35104 he durst steal anything adventurously I must stay with the
35105 lackeys with the luggage of our camp The French might have a
35106 good prey of us if he knew of it for there is none to guard it
35107 but boys Exit
35108 SCENE V
35109 Another part of the field of battle
35110 Enter CONSTABLE ORLEANS BOURBON DAUPHIN and RAMBURES
35111 CONSTABLE O diable
35112 ORLEANS O Seigneur le jour est perdu tout est perdu
35113 DAUPHIN Mort Dieu ma vie all is confounded all
35114 Reproach and everlasting shame
35115 Sits mocking in our plumes [A short alarum]
35116 O mechante fortune Do not run away
35117 CONSTABLE Why an our ranks are broke
35118 DAUPHIN O perdurable shame Let's stab ourselves
35119 Be these the wretches that we play'd at dice for
35120 ORLEANS Is this the king we sent to for his ransom
35121 BOURBON Shame and eternal shame nothing but shame
35122 Let us die in honour once more back again
35123 And he that will not follow Bourbon now
35124 Let him go hence and with his cap in hand
35125 Like a base pander hold the chamberdoor
35126 Whilst by a slave no gender than my dog
35127 His fairest daughter is contaminated
35128 CONSTABLE Disorder that hath spoil'd us friend us now
35129 Let us on heaps go offer up our lives
35130 ORLEANS We are enow yet living in the field
35131 To smother up the English in our throngs
35132 If any order might be thought upon
35133 BOURBON The devil take order now I'll to the throng
35134 Let life be short else shame will be too long Exeunt
35135 SCENE VI
35136 Another part of the field
35137 Alarum Enter the KING and his train with prisoners EXETER and others
35138 KING HENRY Well have we done thricevaliant countrymen
35139 But all's not done yet keep the French the field
35140 EXETER The Duke of York commends him to your Majesty
35141 KING HENRY Lives he good uncle Thrice within this hour
35142 I saw him down thrice up again and fighting
35143 From helmet to the spur all blood he was
35144 EXETER In which array brave soldier doth he lie
35145 Larding the plain and by his bloody side
35146 Yokefellow to his honourowing wounds
35147 The noble Earl of Suffolk also lies
35148 Suffolk first died and York all haggled over
35149 Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped
35150 And takes him by the beard kisses the gashes
35151 That bloodily did yawn upon his face
35152 He cries aloud 'Tarry my cousin Suffolk
35153 My soul shall thine keep company to heaven
35154 Tarry sweet soul for mine then fly abreast
35155 As in this glorious and wellfoughten field
35156 We kept together in our chivalry'
35157 Upon these words I came and cheer'd him up
35158 He smil'd me in the face raught me his hand
35159 And with a feeble grip says 'Dear my lord
35160 Commend my service to my sovereign'
35161 So did he turn and over Suffolk's neck
35162 He threw his wounded arm and kiss'd his lips
35163 And so espous'd to death with blood he seal'd
35164 A testament of nobleending love
35165 The pretty and sweet manner of it forc'd
35166 Those waters from me which I would have stopp'd
35167 But I had not so much of man in me
35168 And all my mother came into mine eyes
35169 And gave me up to tears
35170 KING HENRY I blame you not
35171 For hearing this I must perforce compound
35172 With mistful eyes or they will issue too [Alarum]
35173 But hark what new alarum is this same
35174 The French have reinforc'd their scatter'd men
35175 Then every soldier kill his prisoners
35176 Give the word through Exeunt
35177 SCENE VII
35178 Another part of the field
35179 Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER
35180 FLUELLEN Kill the poys and the luggage 'Tis expressly against the
35181 law of arms 'tis as arrant a piece of knavery mark you now as
35182 can be offert in your conscience now is it not
35183 GOWER 'Tis certain there's not a boy left alive and the cowardly
35184 rascals that ran from the battle ha done this slaughter
35185 besides they have burned and carried away all that was in the
35186 King's tent wherefore the King most worthily hath caus'd every
35187 soldier to cut his prisoner's throat O 'tis a gallant King
35188 FLUELLEN Ay he was porn at Monmouth Captain Gower What call you
35189 the town's name where Alexander the Pig was born
35190 GOWER Alexander the Great
35191 FLUELLEN Why I pray you is not 'pig great The pig or great
35192 or the mighty or the huge or the magnanimous are all one
35193 reckonings save the phrase is a little variations
35194 GOWER I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon his father
35195 was called Philip of Macedon as I take it
35196 FLUELLEN I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn I tell
35197 you Captain if you look in the maps of the 'orld I warrant you
35198 sall find in the comparisons between Macedon and Monmouth that
35199 the situations look you is both alike There is a river in
35200 Macedon and there is also moreover a river at Monmouth it is
35201 call'd Wye at Monmouth but it is out of my prains what is the
35202 name of the other river but 'tis all one 'tis alike as my
35203 fingers is to my fingers and there is salmons in both If you
35204 mark Alexander's life well Harry of Monmouth's life is come
35205 after it indifferent well for there is figures in all things
35206 Alexander God knows and you know in his rages and his furies
35207 and his wraths and his cholers and his moods and his
35208 displeasures and his indignations and also being a little
35209 intoxicates in his prains did in his ales and his angers look
35210 you kill his best friend Cleitus
35211 GOWER Our king is not like him in that he never kill'd any of his
35212 friends
35213 FLUELLEN It is not well done mark you now to take the tales out
35214 of my mouth ere it is made and finished I speak but in the
35215 figures and comparisons of it as Alexander kill'd his friend
35216 Cleitus being in his ales and his cups so also Harry Monmouth
35217 being in his right wits and his good judgments turn'd away the
35218 fat knight with the great belly doublet he was full of jests
35219 and gipes and knaveries and mocks I have forgot his name
35220 GOWER Sir John Falstaff
35221 FLUELLEN That is he I'll tell you there is good men porn at
35222 Monmouth
35223 GOWER Here comes his Majesty
35224 Alarum Enter the KING WARWICK GLOUCESTER
35225 EXETER and others with prisoners Flourish
35226 KING HENRY I was not angry since I came to France
35227 Until this instant Take a trumpet herald
35228 Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hill
35229 If they will fight with us bid them come down
35230 Or void the field they do offend our sight
35231 If they'll do neither we will come to them
35232 And make them skirr away as swift as stones
35233 Enforced from the old Assyrian slings
35234 Besides we'll cut the throats of those we have
35235 And not a man of them that we shall take
35236 Shall taste our mercy Go and tell them so
35237 Enter MONTJOY
35238 EXETER Here comes the herald of the French my liege
35239 GLOUCESTER His eyes are humbler than they us'd to be
35240 KING HENRY How now What means this herald know'st thou not
35241 That I have fin'd these bones of mine for ransom
35242 Com'st thou again for ransom
35243 MONTJOY No great King
35244 I come to thee for charitable licence
35245 That we may wander o'er this bloody field
35246 To book our dead and then to bury them
35247 To sort our nobles from our common men
35248 For many of our princes woe the while
35249 Lie drown'd and soak'd in mercenary blood
35250 So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs
35251 In blood of princes and their wounded steeds
35252 Fret fetlock deep in gore and with wild rage
35253 Yerk out their armed heels at their dead masters
35254 Killing them twice O give us leave great King
35255 To view the field in safety and dispose
35256 Of their dead bodies
35257 KING HENRY I tell thee truly herald
35258 I know not if the day be ours or no
35259 For yet a many of your horsemen peer
35260 And gallop o'er the field
35261 MONTJOY The day is yours
35262 KING HENRY Praised be God and not our strength for it
35263 What is this castle call'd that stands hard by
35264 MONTJOY They call it Agincourt
35265 KING HENRY Then call we this the field of Agincourt
35266 Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus
35267 FLUELLEN Your grandfather of famous memory an't please your
35268 Majesty and your greatuncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales
35269 as I have read in the chronicles fought a most prave pattle here
35270 in France
35271 KING HENRY They did Fluellen
35272 FLUELLEN Your Majesty says very true if your Majesties is
35273 rememb'red of it the Welshmen did good service in garden where
35274 leeks did grow wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps which your
35275 Majesty know to this hour is an honourable badge of the service
35276 and I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek
35277 upon Saint Tavy's day
35278 KING HENRY I wear it for a memorable honour
35279 For I am Welsh you know good countryman
35280 FLUELLEN All the water in Wye cannot wash your Majesty's Welsh
35281 plood out of your pody I can tell you that Got pless it and
35282 preserve it as long as it pleases his Grace and his Majesty too
35283 KING HENRY Thanks good my countryman
35284 FLUELLEN By Jeshu I am your Majesty's countryman care not who
35285 know it I will confess it to all the 'orld I need not be
35286 asham'd of your Majesty praised be Got so long as your Majesty
35287 is an honest man
35288 Enter WILLIAMS
35289 KING HENRY God keep me so Our heralds go with him
35290 Bring me just notice of the numbers dead
35291 On both our parts Call yonder fellow hither
35292 Exeunt heralds with MONTJOY
35293 EXETER Soldier you must come to the King
35294 KING HENRY Soldier why wear'st thou that glove in thy cap
35295 WILLIAMS An't please your Majesty 'tis the gage of one that I
35296 should fight withal if he be alive
35297 KING HENRY An Englishman
35298 WILLIAMS An't please your Majesty a rascal that swagger'd with me
35299 last night who if 'a live and ever dare to challenge this
35300 glove I have sworn to take him a box o th ear or if I can see
35301 my glove in his cap which he swore as he was a soldier he
35302 would wear if alive I will strike it out soundly
35303 KING HENRY What think you Captain Fluellen is it fit this
35304 soldier keep his oath
35305 FLUELLEN He is a craven and a villain else an't please your
35306 Majesty in my conscience
35307 KING HENRY It may be his enemy is a gentlemen of great sort quite
35308 from the answer of his degree
35309 FLUELLEN Though he be as good a gentleman as the Devil is as
35310 Lucifier and Belzebub himself it is necessary look your Grace
35311 that he keep his vow and his oath if he be perjur'd see you
35312 now his reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jacksauce as
35313 ever his black shoe trod upon God's ground and his earth in my
35314 conscience la
35315 KING HENRY Then keep thy vow sirrah when thou meet'st the
35316 fellow
35317 WILLIAMS So I Will my liege as I live
35318 KING HENRY Who serv'st thou under
35319 WILLIAMS Under Captain Gower my liege
35320 FLUELLEN Gower is a good captain and is good knowledge and
35321 literatured in the wars
35322 KING HENRY Call him hither to me soldier
35323 WILLIAMS I will my liege Exit
35324 KING HENRY Here Fluellen wear thou this favour for me and stick
35325 it in thy cap when Alencon and myself were down together I
35326 pluck'd this glove from his helm If any man challenge this he
35327 is a friend to Alencon and an enemy to our person if thou
35328 encounter any such apprehend him an thou dost me love
35329 FLUELLEN Your Grace does me as great honours as can be desir'd in
35330 the hearts of his subjects I would fain see the man that has but
35331 two legs that shall find himself aggrief'd at this glove that is
35332 all but I would fain see it once an please God of his grace
35333 that I might see
35334 KING HENRY Know'st thou Gower
35335 FLUELLEN He is my dear friend an please you
35336 KING HENRY Pray thee go seek him and bring him to my tent
35337 FLUELLEN I will fetch him Exit
35338 KING HENRY My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester
35339 Follow Fluellen closely at the heels
35340 The glove which I have given him for a favour
35341 May haply purchase him a box o th ear
35342 It is the soldier's I by bargain should
35343 Wear it myself Follow good cousin Warwick
35344 If that the soldier strike him as I judge
35345 By his blunt bearing he will keep his word
35346 Some sudden mischief may arise of it
35347 For I do know Fluellen valiant
35348 And touch'd with choler hot as gunpowder
35349 And quickly will return an injury
35350 Follow and see there be no harm between them
35351 Go you with me uncle of Exeter Exeunt
35352 SCENE VIII
35353 Before KING HENRY'S PAVILION
35354 Enter GOWER and WILLIAMS
35355 WILLIAMS I warrant it is to knight you Captain
35356 Enter FLUELLEN
35357 FLUELLEN God's will and his pleasure Captain I beseech you now
35358 come apace to the King there is more good toward you
35359 peradventure than is in your knowledge to dream of
35360 WILLIAMS Sir know you this glove
35361 FLUELLEN Know the glove I know the glove is a glove
35362 WILLIAMS I know this and thus I challenge it [Strikes him]
35363 FLUELLEN 'Sblood an arrant traitor as any's in the universal
35364 world or in France or in England
35365 GOWER How now sir you villain
35366 WILLIAMS Do you think I'll be forsworn
35367 FLUELLEN Stand away Captain Gower I will give treason his
35368 payment into plows I warrant you
35369 WILLIAMS I am no traitor
35370 FLUELLEN That's a lie in thy throat I charge you in his Majesty's
35371 name apprehend him he's a friend of the Duke Alencon's
35372 Enter WARWICK and GLOUCESTER
35373 WARWICK How now how now what's the matter
35374 FLUELLEN My Lord of Warwick here is praised be God for it a
35375 most contagious treason come to light look you as you shall
35376 desire in a summer's day Here is his Majesty
35377 Enter the KING and EXETER
35378 KING HENRY How now what's the matter
35379 FLUELLEN My liege here is a villain and a traitor that look
35380 your Grace has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out
35381 of the helmet of Alencon
35382 WILLIAMS My liege this was my glove here is the fellow of it
35383 and he that I gave it to in change promis'd to wear it in his
35384 cap I promis'd to strike him if he did I met this man with my
35385 glove in his cap and I have been as good as my word
35386 FLUELLEN Your Majesty hear now saving your Majesty's manhood
35387 what an arrant rascally beggarly lousy knave it is I hope
35388 your Majesty is pear me testimony and witness and will
35389 avouchment that this is the glove of Alencon that your Majesty
35390 is give me in your conscience now
35391 KING HENRY Give me thy glove soldier look here is the fellow of
35392 it
35393 'Twas I indeed thou promised'st to strike
35394 And thou hast given me most bitter terms
35395 FLUELLEN An please your Majesty let his neck answer for it if
35396 there is any martial law in the world
35397 KING HENRY How canst thou make me satisfaction
35398 WILLIAMS All offences my lord come from the heart never came
35399 any from mine that might offend your Majesty
35400 KING HENRY It was ourself thou didst abuse
35401 WILLIAMS Your Majesty came not like yourself you appear'd to me
35402 but as a common man witness the night your garments your
35403 lowliness and what your Highness suffer'd under that shape I
35404 beseech you take it for your own fault and not mine for had you
35405 been as I took you for I made no offence therefore I beseech
35406 your Highness pardon me
35407 KING HENRY Here uncle Exeter fill this glove with crowns
35408 And give it to this fellow Keep it fellow
35409 And wear it for an honour in thy cap
35410 Till I do challenge it Give him the crowns
35411 And Captain you must needs be friends with him
35412 FLUELLEN By this day and this light the fellow has mettle enough
35413 in his belly hold there is twelve pence for you and I pray you
35414 to serve God and keep you out of prawls and prabbles and
35415 quarrels and dissensions and I warrant you it is the better
35416 for you
35417 WILLIAMS I will none of your money
35418 FLUELLEN It is with a good will I can tell you it will serve you
35419 to mend your shoes Come wherefore should you be so pashful
35420 Your shoes is not so good 'Tis a good silling I warrant you or
35421 I will change it
35422 Enter an ENGLISH HERALD
35423 KING HENRY Now herald are the dead numb'red
35424 HERALD Here is the number of the slaught'red French
35425 [Gives a paper]
35426 KING HENRY What prisoners of good sort are taken uncle
35427 EXETER Charles Duke of Orleans nephew to the King
35428 John Duke of Bourbon and Lord Bouciqualt
35429 Of other lords and barons knights and squires
35430 Full fifteen hundred besides common men
35431 KING HENRY This note doth tell me of ten thousand French
35432 That in the field lie slain of princes in this number
35433 And nobles bearing banners there lie dead
35434 One hundred twentysix added to these
35435 Of knights esquires and gallant gentlemen
35436 Eight thousand and four hundred of the which
35437 Five hundred were but yesterday dubb'd knights
35438 So that in these ten thousand they have lost
35439 There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries
35440 The rest are princes barons lords knights squires
35441 And gentlemen of blood and quality
35442 The names of those their nobles that lie dead
35443 Charles Delabreth High Constable of France
35444 Jaques of Chatillon Admiral of France
35445 The master of the crossbows Lord Rambures
35446 Great Master of France the brave Sir Guichard Dolphin
35447 John Duke of Alencon Antony Duke of Brabant
35448 The brother to the Duke of Burgundy
35449 And Edward Duke of Bar Of lusty earls
35450 Grandpre and Roussi Fauconbridge and Foix
35451 Beaumont and Marle Vaudemont and Lestrake
35452 Here was a royal fellowship of death
35453 Where is the number of our English dead
35454 [HERALD presents another paper]
35455 Edward the Duke of York the Earl of Suffolk
35456 Sir Richard Kikely Davy Gam Esquire
35457 None else of name and of all other men
35458 But five and twenty O God thy arm was here
35459 And not to us but to thy arm alone
35460 Ascribe we all When without stratagem
35461 But in plain shock and even play of battle
35462 Was ever known so great and little los
35463 On one part and on th other Take it God
35464 For it is none but thine
35465 EXETER 'Tis wonderful
35466 KING HENRY Come go we in procession to the village
35467 And be it death proclaimed through our host
35468 To boast of this or take that praise from God
35469 Which is his only
35470 FLUELLEN Is it not lawful an please your Majesty to tell how
35471 many is kill'd
35472 KING HENRY Yes Captain but with this acknowledgment
35473 That God fought for us
35474 FLUELLEN Yes my conscience he did us great good
35475 KING HENRY Do we all holy rites
35476 Let there be sung 'Non nobis and 'Te Deum'
35477 The dead with charity enclos'd in clay
35478 And then to Calais and to England then
35479 Where ne'er from France arriv'd more happy men Exeunt

35488 ACT V PROLOGUE
35489 Enter CHORUS
35490 CHORUS Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story
35491 That I may prompt them and of such as have
35492 I humbly pray them to admit th excuse
35493 Of time of numbers and due course of things
35494 Which cannot in their huge and proper life
35495 Be here presented Now we bear the King
35496 Toward Calais Grant him there There seen
35497 Heave him away upon your winged thoughts
35498 Athwart the sea Behold the English beach
35499 Pales in the flood with men with wives and boys
35500 Whose shouts and claps outvoice the deepmouth'd sea
35501 Which like a mighty whiffler fore the King
35502 Seems to prepare his way So let him land
35503 And solemnly see him set on to London
35504 So swift a pace hath thought that even now
35505 You may imagine him upon Blackheath
35506 Where that his lords desire him to have borne
35507 His bruised helmet and his bended sword
35508 Before him through the city He forbids it
35509 Being free from vainness and selfglorious pride
35510 Giving full trophy signal and ostent
35511 Quite from himself to God But now behold
35512 In the quick forge and workinghouse of thought
35513 How London doth pour out her citizens
35514 The mayor and all his brethren in best sort
35515 Like to the senators of th antique Rome
35516 With the plebeians swarming at their heels
35517 Go forth and fetch their conqu'ring Caesar in
35518 As by a lower but loving likelihood
35519 Were now the General of our gracious Empress
35520 As in good time he may from Ireland coming
35521 Bringing rebellion broached on his sword
35522 How many would the peaceful city quit
35523 To welcome him Much more and much more cause
35524 Did they this Harry Now in London place him
35525 As yet the lamentation of the French
35526 Invites the King of England's stay at home
35527 The Emperor's coming in behalf of France
35528 To order peace between them and omit
35529 All the occurrences whatever chanc'd
35530 Till Harry's backreturn again to France
35531 There must we bring him and myself have play'd
35532 The interim by rememb'ring you 'tis past
35533 Then brook abridgment and your eyes advance
35534 After your thoughts straight back again to France Exit
35535 SCENE I
35536 France The English camp
35537 Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER
35538 GOWER Nay that's right but why wear you your leek today Saint
35539 Davy's day is past
35540 FLUELLEN There is occasions and causes why and wherefore in all
35541 things I will tell you ass my friend Captain Gower the
35542 rascally scald beggarly lousy pragging knave Pistol which
35543 you and yourself and all the world know to be no petter than a
35544 fellow look you now of no merits he is come to me and prings
35545 me pread and salt yesterday look you and bid me eat my leek it
35546 was in a place where I could not breed no contendon with him but
35547 I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once
35548 again and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires
35549 Enter PISTOL
35550 GOWER Why here he comes swelling like a turkeycock
35551 FLUELLEN 'Tis no matter for his swellings nor his turkeycocks
35552 God pless you Aunchient Pistol you scurvy lousy knave God
35553 pless you
35554 PISTOL Ha art thou bedlam Dost thou thirst base Troyan
35555 To have me fold up Parca's fatal web
35556 Hence I am qualmish at the smell of leek
35557 FLUELLEN I peseech you heartily scurvy lousy knave at my
35558 desires and my requests and my petitions to eat look you
35559 this leek because look you you do not love it nor your
35560 affections and your appetites and your digestions does not
35561 agree with it I would desire you to eat it
35562 PISTOL Not for Cadwallader and all his goats
35563 FLUELLEN There is one goat for you [Strikes him] Will you be so
35564 good scald knave as eat it
35565 PISTOL Base Troyan thou shalt die
35566 FLUELLEN You say very true scald knave when God's will is I
35567 will desire you to live in the meantime and eat your victuals
35568 come there is sauce for it [Striking him again] You call'd me
35569 yesterday mountainsquire but I will make you today a squire of
35570 low degree I pray you fall to if you can mock a leek you can
35571 eat a leek
35572 GOWER Enough Captain you have astonish'd him
35573 FLUELLEN I say I will make him eat some part of my leek or I will
35574 peat his pate four days Bite I pray you it is good for your
35575 green wound and your ploody coxcomb
35576 PISTOL Must I bite
35577 FLUELLEN Yes certainly and out of doubt and out of question
35578 too and ambiguides
35579 PISTOL By this leek I will most horribly revenge I eat and eat
35580 I swear
35581 FLUELLEN Eat I pray you will you have some more sauce to your
35582 leek There is not enough leek to swear by
35583 PISTOL Quiet thy cudgel thou dost see I eat
35584 FLUELLEN Much good do you scald knave heartily Nay pray you
35585 throw none away the skin is good for your broken coxcomb When
35586 you take occasions to see leeks hereafter I pray you mock at
35587 'em that is all
35588 PISTOL Good
35589 FLUELLEN Ay leeks is good Hold you there is a groat to heal
35590 your pate
35591 PISTOL Me a groat
35592 FLUELLEN Yes verily and in truth you shall take it or I have
35593 another leek in my pocket which you shall eat
35594 PISTOL I take thy groat in earnest of revenge
35595 FLUELLEN If I owe you anything I will pay you in cudgels you
35596 shall be a woodmonger and buy nothing of me but cudgels God bye
35597 you and keep you and heal your pate
35598 Exit
35599 PISTOL All hell shall stir for this
35600 GOWER Go go you are a couterfeit cowardly knave Will you mock
35601 at an ancient tradition begun upon an honourable respect and
35602 worn as a memorable trophy of predeceased valour and dare not
35603 avouch in your deeds any of your words I have seen you gleeking
35604 and galling at this gentleman twice or thrice You thought
35605 because he could not speak English in the native garb he could
35606 not therefore handle an English cudgel you find it otherwise
35607 and henceforth let a Welsh correction teach you a good English
35608 condition Fare ye well Exit
35609 PISTOL Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now
35610 News have I that my Nell is dead i th spital
35611 Of malady of France
35612 And there my rendezvous is quite cut off
35613 Old I do wax and from my weary limbs
35614 Honour is cudgell'd Well bawd I'll turn
35615 And something lean to cutpurse of quick hand
35616 To England will I steal and there I'll steal
35617 And patches will I get unto these cudgell'd scars
35618 And swear I got them in the Gallia wars Exit
35619 SCENE II
35620 France The FRENCH KING'S palace
35621 Enter at one door KING HENRY EXETER BEDFORD GLOUCESTER WARWICK
35622 WESTMORELAND and other LORDS at another the FRENCH KING QUEEN ISABEL
35623 the PRINCESS KATHERINE ALICE and other LADIES the DUKE OF BURGUNDY
35624 and his train
35625 KING HENRY Peace to this meeting wherefore we are met
35626 Unto our brother France and to our sister
35627 Health and fair time of day joy and good wishes
35628 To our most fair and princely cousin Katherine
35629 And as a branch and member of this royalty
35630 By whom this great assembly is contriv'd
35631 We do salute you Duke of Burgundy
35632 And princes French and peers health to you all
35633 FRENCH KING Right joyous are we to behold your face
35634 Most worthy brother England fairly met
35635 So are you princes English every one
35636 QUEEN ISABEL So happy be the issue brother England
35637 Of this good day and of this gracious meeting
35638 As we are now glad to behold your eyes
35639 Your eyes which hitherto have home in them
35640 Against the French that met them in their bent
35641 The fatal balls of murdering basilisks
35642 The venom of such looks we fairly hope
35643 Have lost their quality and that this day
35644 Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love
35645 KING HENRY To cry amen to that thus we appear
35646 QUEEN ISABEL You English princes an I do salute you
35647 BURGUNDY My duty to you both on equal love
35648 Great Kings of France and England That I have labour'd
35649 With all my wits my pains and strong endeavours
35650 To bring your most imperial Majesties
35651 Unto this bar and royal interview
35652 Your mightiness on both parts best can witness
35653 Since then my office hath so far prevail'd
35654 That face to face and royal eye to eye
35655 You have congreeted let it not disgrace me
35656 If I demand before this royal view
35657 What rub or what impediment there is
35658 Why that the naked poor and mangled Peace
35659 Dear nurse of arts plenties and joyful births
35660 Should not in this best garden of the world
35661 Our fertile France put up her lovely visage
35662 Alas she hath from France too long been chas'd
35663 And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps
35664 Corrupting in it own fertility
35665 Her vine the merry cheerer of the heart
35666 Unpruned dies her hedges evenpleach'd
35667 Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair
35668 Put forth disorder'd twigs her fallow leas
35669 The darnel hemlock and rank fumitory
35670 Doth root upon while that the coulter rusts
35671 That should deracinate such savagery
35672 The even mead that erst brought sweetly forth
35673 The freckled cowslip burnet and green clover
35674 Wanting the scythe all uncorrected rank
35675 Conceives by idleness and nothing teems
35676 But hateful docks rough thistles kecksies burs
35677 Losing both beauty and utility
35678 And as our vineyards fallows meads and hedges
35679 Defective in their natures grow to wildness
35680 Even so our houses and ourselves and children
35681 Have lost or do not learn for want of time
35682 The sciences that should become our country
35683 But grow like savages as soldiers will
35684 That nothing do but meditate on blood
35685 To swearing and stern looks diffus'd attire
35686 And everything that seems unnatural
35687 Which to reduce into our former favout
35688 You are assembled and my speech entreats
35689 That I may know the let why gentle Peace
35690 Should not expel these inconveniences
35691 And bless us with her former qualities
35692 KING HENRY If Duke of Burgundy you would the peace
35693 Whose want gives growth to th imperfections
35694 Which you have cited you must buy that peace
35695 With full accord to all our just demands
35696 Whose tenours and particular effects
35697 You have enschedul'd briefly in your hands
35698 BURGUNDY The King hath heard them to the which as yet
35699 There is no answer made
35700 KING HENRY Well then the peace
35701 Which you before so urg'd lies in his answer
35702 FRENCH KING I have but with a cursorary eye
35703 O'erglanced the articles pleaseth your Grace
35704 To appoint some of your council presently
35705 To sit with us once more with better heed
35706 To resurvey them we will suddenly
35707 Pass our accept and peremptory answer
35708 KING HENRY Brother we shall Go uncle Exeter
35709 And brother Clarence and you brother Gloucester
35710 Warwick and Huntington go with the King
35711 And take with you free power to ratify
35712 Augment or alter as your wisdoms best
35713 Shall see advantageable for our dignity
35714 Any thing in or out of our demands
35715 And we'll consign thereto Will you fair sister
35716 Go with the princes or stay here with us
35717 QUEEN ISABEL Our gracious brother I will go with them
35718 Haply a woman's voice may do some good
35719 When articles too nicely urg'd be stood on
35720 KING HENRY Yet leave our cousin Katherine here with us
35721 She is our capital demand compris'd
35722 Within the forerank of our articles
35723 QUEEN ISABEL She hath good leave
35724 Exeunt all but the KING KATHERINE and ALICE
35725 KING HENRY Fair Katherine and most fair
35726 Will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms
35727 Such as will enter at a lady's ear
35728 And plead his lovesuit to her gentle heart
35729 KATHERINE Your Majesty shall mock me I cannot speak your England
35730 KING HENRY O fair Katherine if you will love me soundly with your
35731 French heart I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with
35732 your English tongue Do you like me Kate
35733 KATHERINE Pardonnezmoi I cannot tell vat is like me
35734 KING HENRY An angel is like you Kate and you are like an angel
35735 KATHERINE Que ditil que je suis semblable a les anges
35736 ALICE Oui vraiment sauf votre grace ainsi ditil
35737 KING HENRY I said so dear Katherine and I must not blush to
35738 affirm it
35739 KATHERINE O bon Dieu les langues des hommes sont pleines de
35740 tromperies
35741 KING HENRY What says she fair one that the tongues of men are
35742 full of deceits
35743 ALICE Oui dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits dat is
35744 de Princess
35745 KING HENRY The Princess is the better Englishwoman I faith
35746 Kate my wooing is fit for thy understanding I am glad thou
35747 canst speak no better English for if thou couldst thou wouldst
35748 find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I had sold my
35749 farm to buy my crown I know no ways to mince it in love but
35750 directly to say 'I love you Then if you urge me farther than
35751 to say 'Do you in faith I wear out my suit Give me your
35752 answer i faith do and so clap hands and a bargain How say
35753 you lady
35754 KATHERINE Sauf votre honneur me understand well
35755 KING HENRY Marry if you would put me to verses or to dance for
35756 your sake Kate why you undid me for the one I have neither
35757 words nor measure and for the other I have no strength in
35758 measure yet a reasonable measure in strength If I could win a
35759 lady at leapfrog or by vaulting into my saddle with my armour
35760 on my back under the correction of bragging be it spoken I
35761 should quickly leap into wife Or if I might buffet for my love
35762 or bound my horse for her favours I could lay on like a butcher
35763 and sit like a jackanapes never off But before God Kate I
35764 cannot look greenly nor gasp out my cloquence nor I have no
35765 cunning in protestation only downright oaths which I never use
35766 till urg'd nor never break for urging If thou canst love a
35767 fellow of this temper Kate whose face is not worth sunburning
35768 that never looks in his glass for love of anything he sees there
35769 let thine eye be thy cook I speak to thee plain soldier If thou
35770 canst love me for this take me if not to say to thee that I
35771 shall die is true but for thy love by the Lord no yet I love
35772 thee too And while thou liv'st dear Kate take a fellow of
35773 plain and uncoined constancy for he perforce must do thee right
35774 because he hath not the gift to woo in other places for these
35775 fellows of infinite tongue that can rhyme themselves into
35776 ladies favours they do always reason themselves out again
35777 What a speaker is but a prater a rhyme is but a ballad A good
35778 leg will fall a straight back will stoop a black beard will
35779 turn white a curl'd pate will grow bald a fair face will
35780 wither a full eye will wax hollow But a good heart Kate is
35781 the sun and the moon or rather the sun and not the moon for
35782 it shines bright and never changes but keeps his course truly
35783 If thou would have such a one take me and take me take a
35784 soldier take a soldier take a king And what say'st thou then
35785 to my love Speak my fair and fairly I pray thee
35786 KATHERINE Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France
35787 KING HENRY No it is not possible you should love the enemy of
35788 France Kate but in loving me you should love the friend of
35789 France for I love France so well that I will not part with a
35790 village of it I will have it all mine And Kate when France is
35791 mine and I am yours then yours is France and you are mine
35792 KATHERINE I cannot tell vat is dat
35793 KING HENRY No Kate I will tell thee in French which I am sure
35794 will hang upon my tongue like a newmarried wife about her
35795 husband's neck hardly to be shook off Je quand sur le
35796 possession de France et quand vous avez le possession de moi
35797 let me see what then Saint Denis be my speed donc votre est
35798 France et vous etes mienne It is as easy for me Kate to
35799 conquer the kingdom as to speak so much more French I shall
35800 never move thee in French unless it be to laugh at me
35801 KATHERINE Sauf votre honneur le Francais que vous parlez il est
35802 meilleur que l'Anglais lequel je parle
35803 KING HENRY No faith is't not Kate but thy speaking of my
35804 tongue and I thine most truly falsely must needs be granted to
35805 be much at one But Kate dost thou understand thus much
35806 English Canst thou love me
35807 KATHERINE I cannot tell
35808 KING HENRY Can any of your neighbours tell Kate I'll ask them
35809 Come I know thou lovest me and at night when you come into
35810 your closet you'll question this gentlewoman about me and I
35811 know Kate you will to her dispraise those parts in me that you
35812 love with your heart But good Kate mock me mercifully the
35813 rather gentle Princess because I love thee cruelly If ever
35814 thou beest mine Kate as I have a saving faith within me tells
35815 me thou shalt I get thee with scambling and thou must therefore
35816 needs prove a good soldierbreeder Shall not thou and I between
35817 Saint Denis and Saint George compound a boy half French half
35818 English that shall go to Constantinople and take the Turk by the
35819 beard Shall we not What say'st thou my fair flowerdeluce
35820 KATHERINE I do not know dat
35821 KING HENRY No 'tis hereafter to know but now to promise do but
35822 now promise Kate you will endeavour for your French part of
35823 such a boy and for my English moiety take the word of a king and
35824 a bachelor How answer you la plus belle Katherine du monde mon
35825 tres cher et divin deesse
35826 KATHERINE Your Majestee ave fausse French enough to deceive de
35827 most sage damoiselle dat is en France
35828 KING HENRY Now fie upon my false French By mine honour in true
35829 English I love thee Kate by which honour I dare not swear thou
35830 lovest me yet my blood begins to flatter me that thou dost
35831 notwithstanding the poor and untempering effect of my visage Now
35832 beshrew my father's ambition He was thinking of civil wars when
35833 he got me therefore was I created with a stubborn outside with
35834 an aspect of iron that when I come to woo ladies I fright them
35835 But in faith Kate the elder I wax the better I shall appear
35836 my comfort is that old age that in layerup of beauty can do
35837 no more spoil upon my face thou hast me if thou hast me at the
35838 worst and thou shalt wear me if thou wear me better and
35839 better And therefore tell me most fair Katherine will you have
35840 me Put off your maiden blushes avouch the thoughts of your
35841 heart with the looks of an empress take me by the hand and say
35842 'Harry of England I am thine Which word thou shalt no sooner
35843 bless mine ear withal but I will tell thee aloud 'England is
35844 thine Ireland is thine France is thine and Henry Plantagenet
35845 is thine who though I speak it before his face if he be not
35846 fellow with the best king thou shalt find the best king of good
35847 fellows Come your answer in broken music for thy voice is
35848 music and thy English broken therefore Queen of all Katherine
35849 break thy mind to me in broken English wilt thou have me
35850 KATHERINE Dat is as it shall please de roi mon pere
35851 KING HENRY Nay it will please him well Kate it shall please
35852 him Kate
35853 KATHERINE Den it sall also content me
35854 KING HENRY Upon that I kiss your hand and I can you my queen
35855 KATHERINE Laissez mon seigneur laissez laissez Ma foi je ne
35856 veux point que vous abaissiez votre grandeur en baisant la main
35857 d'une notre seigneur indigne serviteur excusezmoi je vous
35858 supplie mon tres puissant seigneur
35859 KING HENRY Then I will kiss your lips Kate
35860 KATHERINE Les dames et demoiselles pour etre baisees devant leur
35861 noces il n'est pas la coutume de France
35862 KING HENRY Madame my interpreter what says she
35863 ALICE Dat it is not be de fashion pour le ladies of France I
35864 cannot tell vat is baiser en Anglish
35865 KING HENRY To kiss
35866 ALICE Your Majestee entendre bettre que moi
35867 KING HENRY It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss
35868 before they are married would she say
35869 ALICE Oui vraiment
35870 KING HENRY O Kate nice customs curtsy to great kings Dear Kate
35871 you and I cannot be confin'd within the weak list of a country's
35872 fashion we are the makers of manners Kate and the liberty that
35873 follows our places stops the mouth of all findfaults as I will
35874 do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in
35875 denying me a kiss therefore patiently and yielding [Kissing
35876 her] You have witchcraft in your lips Kate there is more
35877 eloquence in a sugar touch of them than in the tongues of the
35878 French council and they should sooner persuade Henry of England
35879 than a general petition of monarchs Here comes your father
35880 Enter the FRENCH POWER and the ENGLISH LORDS
35881 BURGUNDY God save your Majesty My royal cousin
35882 Teach you our princess English
35883 KING HENRY I would have her learn my fair cousin how perfectly I
35884 love her and that is good English
35885 BURGUNDY Is she not apt
35886 KING HENRY Our tongue is rough coz and my condition is not
35887 smooth so that having neither the voice nor the heart of
35888 flattery about me I cannot so conjure up the spirit of love in
35889 her that he will appear in his true likeness
35890 BURGUNDY Pardon the frankness of my mirth if I answer you for
35891 that If you would conjure in her you must make a circle if
35892 conjure up love in her in his true likeness he must appear naked
35893 and blind Can you blame her then being a maid yet ros'd over
35894 with the virgin crimson of modesty if she deny the appearance of
35895 a naked blind boy in her naked seeing self It were my lord a
35896 hard condition for a maid to consign to
35897 KING HENRY Yet they do wink and yield as love is blind and
35898 enforces
35899 BURGUNDY They are then excus'd my lord when they see not what
35900 they do
35901 KING HENRY Then good my lord teach your cousin to consent
35902 winking
35903 BURGUNDY I will wink on her to consent my lord if you will teach
35904 her to know my meaning for maids well summer'd and warm kept are
35905 like flies at Bartholomewtide blind though they have their
35906 eyes and then they will endure handling which before would not
35907 abide looking on
35908 KING HENRY This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer and
35909 so I shall catch the fly your cousin in the latter end and she
35910 must be blind too
35911 BURGUNDY As love is my lord before it loves
35912 KING HENRY It is so and you may some of you thank love for my
35913 blindness who cannot see many a fair French city for one fair
35914 French maid that stands in my way
35915 FRENCH KING Yes my lord you see them perspectively the cities
35916 turned into a maid for they are all girdled with maiden walls
35917 that war hath never ent'red
35918 KING HENRY Shall Kate be my wife
35919 FRENCH KING So please you
35920 KING HENRY I am content so the maiden cities you talk of may wait
35921 on her so the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show
35922 me the way to my will
35923 FRENCH KING We have consented to all terms of reason
35924 KING HENRY Is't so my lords of England
35925 WESTMORELAND The king hath granted every article
35926 His daughter first and then in sequel all
35927 According to their firm proposed natures
35928 EXETER Only he hath not yet subscribed this
35929 Where your Majesty demands that the King of France having any
35930 occasion to write for matter of grant shall name your Highness
35931 in this form and with this addition in French Notre tres cher
35932 fils Henri Roi d'Angleterre Heritier de France and thus in
35933 Latin Praeclarissimus filius noster Henricus Rex Angliae et
35934 Haeres Franciae
35935 FRENCH KING Nor this I have not brother so denied
35936 But our request shall make me let it pass
35937 KING HENRY I pray you then in love and dear alliance
35938 Let that one article rank with the rest
35939 And thereupon give me your daughter
35940 FRENCH KING Take her fair son and from her blood raise up
35941 Issue to me that the contending kingdoms
35942 Of France and England whose very shores look pale
35943 With envy of each other's happiness
35944 May cease their hatred and this dear conjunction
35945 Plant neighbourhood and Christianlike accord
35946 In their sweet bosoms that never war advance
35947 His bleeding sword 'twixt England and fair France
35948 LORDS Amen
35949 KING HENRY Now welcome Kate and bear me witness all
35950 That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen [Floulish]
35951 QUEEN ISABEL God the best maker of all marriages
35952 Combine your hearts in one your realms in one
35953 As man and wife being two are one in love
35954 So be there 'twixt your kingdoms such a spousal
35955 That never may ill office or fell jealousy
35956 Which troubles oft the bed of blessed marriage
35957 Thrust in between the paction of these kingdoms
35958 To make divorce of their incorporate league
35959 That English may as French French Englishmen
35960 Receive each other God speak this Amen
35961 ALL Amen
35962 KING HENRY Prepare we for our marriage on which day
35963 My Lord of Burgundy we'll take your oath
35964 And all the peers for surety of our leagues
35965 Then shall I swear to Kate and you to me
35966 And may our oaths well kept and prosp'rous be
35967 Sennet Exeunt
35968 EPILOGUE
35969 EPILOGUE
35970 Enter CHORUS
35971 CHORUS Thus far with rough and allunable pen
35972 Our bending author hath pursu'd the story
35973 In little room confining mighty men
35974 Mangling by starts the full course of their glory
35975 Small time but in that small most greatly lived
35976 This star of England Fortune made his sword
35977 By which the world's best garden he achieved
35978 And of it left his son imperial lord
35979 Henry the Sixth in infant bands crown'd king
35980 Of France and England did this king succeed
35981 Whose state so many had the managing
35982 That they lost France and made his England bleed
35983 Which oft our stage hath shown and for their sake
35984 In your fair minds let this acceptance take Exit
35985 THE END

35999 DUKE OF GLOUCESTER uncle to the King and Protector
36000 DUKE OF BEDFORD uncle to the King and Regent of France
36001 THOMAS BEAUFORT DUKE OF EXETER greatuncle to the king
36002 HENRY BEAUFORT greatuncle to the King BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
36003 and afterwards CARDINAL
36004 JOHN BEAUFORT EARL OF SOMERSET afterwards Duke
36005 RICHARD PLANTAGENET son of Richard late Earl of Cambridge
36006 afterwards DUKE OF YORK
36007 EARL OF WARWICK
36008 EARL OF SALISBURY
36009 EARL OF SUFFOLK
36010 LORD TALBOT afterwards EARL OF SHREWSBURY
