41285 ACT IV SCENE I
41286 The coast of Kent
41287 Alarum Fight at sea Ordnance goes off Enter a LIEUTENANT
41288 a SHIPMASTER and his MATE and WALTER WHITMORE with sailors
41289 SUFFOLK and other GENTLEMEN as prisoners
41290 LIEUTENANT The gaudy blabbing and remorseful day
41291 Is crept into the bosom of the sea
41292 And now loudhowling wolves arouse the jades
41293 That drag the tragic melancholy night
41294 Who with their drowsy slow and flagging wings
41295 Clip dead men's graves and from their misty jaws
41296 Breathe foul contagious darkness in the air
41297 Therefore bring forth the soldiers of our prize
41298 For whilst our pinnace anchors in the Downs
41299 Here shall they make their ransom on the sand
41300 Or with their blood stain this discoloured shore
41301 Master this prisoner freely give I thee
41302 And thou that art his mate make boot of this
41303 The other Walter Whitmore is thy share
41304 FIRST GENTLEMAN What is my ransom master let me know
41305 MASTER A thousand crowns or else lay down your head
41306 MATE And so much shall you give or off goes yours
41307 LIEUTENANT What think you much to pay two thousand crowns
41308 And bear the name and port of gentlemen
41309 Cut both the villains throats for die you shall
41310 The lives of those which we have lost in fight
41311 Be counterpois'd with such a petty sum
41312 FIRST GENTLEMAN I'll give it sir and therefore spare my life
41313 SECOND GENTLEMAN And so will I and write home for it straight
41314 WHITMORE I lost mine eye in laying the prize aboard
41315 [To SUFFOLK] And therefore to revenge it shalt thou die
41316 And so should these if I might have my will
41317 LIEUTENANT Be not so rash take ransom let him live
41318 SUFFOLK Look on my George I am a gentleman
41319 Rate me at what thou wilt thou shalt be paid
41320 WHITMORE And so am I my name is Walter Whitmore
41321 How now Why start'st thou What doth death affright
41322 SUFFOLK Thy name affrights me in whose sound is death
41323 A cunning man did calculate my birth
41324 And told me that by water I should die
41325 Yet let not this make thee be bloodyminded
41326 Thy name is Gualtier being rightly sounded
41327 WHITMORE Gualtier or Walter which it is I care not
41328 Never yet did base dishonour blur our name
41329 But with our sword we wip'd away the blot
41330 Therefore when merchantlike I sell revenge
41331 Broke be my sword my arms torn and defac'd
41332 And I proclaim'd a coward through the world
41333 SUFFOLK Stay Whitmore for thy prisoner is a prince
41334 The Duke of Suffolk William de la Pole
41335 WHITMORE The Duke of Suffolk muffled up in rags
41336 SUFFOLK Ay but these rags are no part of the Duke
41337 Jove sometime went disguis'd and why not I
41338 LIEUTENANT But Jove was never slain as thou shalt be
41339 SUFFOLK Obscure and lowly swain King Henry's blood
41340 The honourable blood of Lancaster
41341 Must not be shed by such a jaded groom
41342 Hast thou not kiss'd thy hand and held my stirrup
41343 Bareheaded plodded by my footcloth mule
41344 And thought thee happy when I shook my head
41345 How often hast thou waited at my cup
41346 Fed from my trencher kneel'd down at the board
41347 When I have feasted with Queen Margaret
41348 Remember it and let it make thee crestfall'n
41349 Ay and allay thus thy abortive pride
41350 How in our voidinglobby hast thou stood
41351 And duly waited for my coming forth
41352 This hand of mine hath writ in thy behalf
41353 And therefore shall it charm thy riotous tongue
41354 WHITMORE Speak Captain shall I stab the forlorn swain
41355 LIEUTENANT First let my words stab him as he hath me
41356 SUFFOLK Base slave thy words are blunt and so art thou
41357 LIEUTENANT Convey him hence and on our longboat's side
41358 Strike off his head
41359 SUFFOLK Thou dar'st not for thy own
41360 LIEUTENANT Poole
41361 SUFFOLK Poole
41362 LIEUTENANT Ay kennel puddle sink whose filth and dirt
41363 Troubles the silver spring where England drinks
41364 Now will I dam up this thy yawning mouth
41365 For swallowing the treasure of the realm
41366 Thy lips that kiss'd the Queen shall sweep the ground
41367 And thou that smil'dst at good Duke Humphrey's death
41368 Against the senseless winds shalt grin in vain
41369 Who in contempt shall hiss at thee again
41370 And wedded be thou to the hags of hell
41371 For daring to affy a mighty lord
41372 Unto the daughter of a worthless king
41373 Having neither subject wealth nor diadem
41374 By devilish policy art thou grown great
41375 And like ambitious Sylla overgorg'd
41376 With gobbets of thy mother's bleeding heart
41377 By thee Anjou and Maine were sold to France
41378 The false revolting Normans thorough thee
41379 Disdain to call us lord and Picardy
41380 Hath slain their governors surpris'd our forts
41381 And sent the ragged soldiers wounded home
41382 The princely Warwick and the Nevils all
41383 Whose dreadful swords were never drawn in vain
41384 As hating thee are rising up in arms
41385 And now the house of York thrust from the crown
41386 By shameful murder of a guiltless king
41387 And lofty proud encroaching tyranny
41388 Burns with revenging fire whose hopeful colours
41389 Advance our halffac'd sun striving to shine
41390 Under the which is writ 'Invitis nubibus'
41391 The commons here in Kent are up in arms
41392 And to conclude reproach and beggary
41393 Is crept into the palace of our King
41394 And all by thee Away convey him hence
41395 SUFFOLK O that I were a god to shoot forth thunder
41396 Upon these paltry servile abject drudges
41397 Small things make base men proud this villain here
41398 Being captain of a pinnace threatens more
41399 Than Bargulus the strong Illyrian pirate
41400 Drones suck not eagles blood but rob beehives
41401 It is impossible that I should die
41402 By such a lowly vassal as thyself
41403 Thy words move rage and not remorse in me
41404 I go of message from the Queen to France
41405 I charge thee waft me safely cross the Channel
41406 LIEUTENANT Walter
41407 WHITMORE Come Suffolk I must waft thee to thy death
41408 SUFFOLK Gelidus timor occupat artus it is thee I fear
41409 WHITMORE Thou shalt have cause to fear before I leave thee
41410 What are ye daunted now Now will ye stoop
41411 FIRST GENTLEMAN My gracious lord entreat him speak him fair
41412 SUFFOLK Suffolk's imperial tongue is stem and rough
41413 Us'd to command untaught to plead for favour
41414 Far be it we should honour such as these
41415 With humble suit no rather let my head
41416 Stoop to the block than these knees bow to any
41417 Save to the God of heaven and to my king
41418 And sooner dance upon a bloody pole
41419 Than stand uncover'd to the vulgar groom
41420 True nobility is exempt from fear
41421 More can I bear than you dare execute
41422 LIEUTENANT Hale him away and let him talk no more
41423 SUFFOLK Come soldiers show what cruelty ye can
41424 That this my death may never be forgot
41425 Great men oft die by vile bezonians
41426 A Roman sworder and banditto slave
41427 Murder'd sweet Tully Brutus bastard hand
41428 Stabb'd Julius Caesar savage islanders
41429 Pompey the Great and Suffolk dies by pirates
41430 Exit WALTER with SUFFOLK
41431 LIEUTENANT And as for these whose ransom we have set
41432 It is our pleasure one of them depart
41433 Therefore come you with us and let him go
41434 Exeunt all but the FIRST GENTLEMAN
41435 Reenter WHITMORE with SUFFOLK'S body
41436 WHITMORE There let his head and lifeless body lie
41437 Until the Queen his mistress bury it Exit
41438 FIRST GENTLEMAN O barbarous and bloody spectacle
41439 His body will I bear unto the King
41440 If he revenge it not yet will his friends
41441 So will the Queen that living held him dear
41442 Exit with the body
41443 SCENE II
41444 Blackheath
41445 Enter GEORGE BEVIS and JOHN HOLLAND
41446 GEORGE Come and get thee a sword though made of a lath they have
41447 been up these two days
41448 JOHN They have the more need to sleep now then
41449 GEORGE I tell thee Jack Cade the clothier means to dress the
41450 commonwealth and turn it and set a new nap upon it
41451 JOHN So he had need for 'tis threadbare Well I say it was never
41452 merry world in England since gentlemen came up
41453 GEORGE O miserable age Virtue is not regarded in handicraftsmen
41454 JOHN The nobility think scorn to go in leather aprons
41455 GEORGE Nay more the King's Council are no good workmen
41456 JOHN True and yet it is said 'Labour in thy vocation which is
41457 as much to say as 'Let the magistrates be labouring men and
41458 therefore should we be magistrates
41459 GEORGE Thou hast hit it for there's no better sign of a brave
41460 mind than a hard hand
41461 JOHN I see them I see them There's Best's son the tanner of
41462 Wingham
41463 GEORGE He shall have the skins of our enemies to make dog's
41464 leather of
41465 JOHN And Dick the butcher
41466 GEORGE Then is sin struck down like an ox and iniquity's throat
41467 cut like a calf
41468 JOHN And Smith the weaver
41469 GEORGE Argo their thread of life is spun
41470 JOHN Come come let's fall in with them
41471 Drum Enter CADE DICK THE BUTCHER SMITH
41472 THE WEAVER and a SAWYER with infinite numbers
41473 CADE We John Cade so term'd of our supposed father
41474 DICK [Aside] Or rather of stealing a cade of herrings
41475 CADE For our enemies shall fall before us inspired with the
41476 spirit of putting down kings and princes command silence
41477 DICK Silence
41478 CADE My father was a Mortimer
41479 DICK [Aside] He was an honest man and a good bricklayer
41480 CADE My mother a Plantagenet
41481 DICK [Aside] I knew her well she was a midwife
41482 CADE My wife descended of the Lacies
41483 DICK [Aside] She was indeed a pedlar's daughter and sold many
41484 laces
41485 SMITH [Aside] But now of late not able to travel with her furr'd
41486 pack she washes bucks here at home
41487 CADE Therefore am I of an honourable house
41488 DICK [Aside] Ay by my faith the field is honourable and there
41489 was he born under a hedge for his father had never a house but
41490 the cage
41491 CADE Valiant I am
41492 SMITH [Aside] 'A must needs for beggary is valiant
41493 CADE I am able to endure much
41494 DICK [Aside] No question of that for I have seen him whipt three
41495 market days together
41496 CADE I fear neither sword nor fire
41497 SMITH [Aside] He need not fear the sword for his coat is of
41498 proof
41499 DICK [Aside] But methinks he should stand in fear of fire being
41500 burnt i th hand for stealing of sheep
41501 CADE Be brave then for your captain is brave and vows
41502 reformation There shall be in England seven halfpenny loaves
41503 sold for a penny the threehoop'd pot shall have ten hoops and
41504 I will make it felony to drink small beer All the realm shall be
41505 in common and in Cheapside shall my palfrey go to grass And
41506 when I am king as king I will be
41507 ALL God save your Majesty
41508 CADE I thank you good people there shall be no money all shall
41509 eat and drink on my score and I will apparel them all in one
41510 livery that they may agree like brothers and worship me their
41511 lord
41512 DICK The first thing we do let's kill all the lawyers
41513 CADE Nay that I mean to do Is not this a lamentable thing that
41514 of the skin of an innocent lamb should be made parchment That
41515 parchment being scribbl'd o'er should undo a man Some say the
41516 bee stings but I say 'tis the bee's wax for I did but seal once
41517 to a thing and I was never mine own man since How now Who's
41518 there
41519 Enter some bringing in the CLERK OF CHATHAM
41520 SMITH The clerk of Chatham He can write and read and cast
41521 accompt
41522 CADE O monstrous
41523 SMITH We took him setting of boys copies
41524 CADE Here's a villain
41525 SMITH Has a book in his pocket with red letters in't
41526 CADE Nay then he is a conjurer
41527 DICK Nay he can make obligations and write courthand
41528 CADE I am sorry for't the man is a proper man of mine honour
41529 unless I find him guilty he shall not die Come hither sirrah
41530 I must examine thee What is thy name
41531 CLERK Emmanuel
41532 DICK They use to write it on the top of letters 'twill go hard
41533 with you
41534 CADE Let me alone Dost thou use to write thy name or hast thou a
41535 mark to thyself like a honest plaindealing man
41536 CLERK Sir I thank God I have been so well brought up that I can
41537 write my name
41538 ALL He hath confess'd Away with him He's a villain and a
41539 traitor
41540 CADE Away with him I say Hang him with his pen and inkhorn about
41541 his neck Exit one with the CLERK
41542 Enter MICHAEL
41543 MICHAEL Where's our General
41544 CADE Here I am thou particular fellow
41545 MICHAEL Fly fly fly Sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother are
41546 hard by with the King's forces
41547 CADE Stand villain stand or I'll fell thee down He shall be
41548 encount'red with a man as good as himself He is but a knight
41549 is 'a
41550 MICHAEL No
41551 CADE To equal him I will make myself a knight presently
41552 [Kneels] Rise up Sir John Mortimer [Rises] Now have at him
41553 Enter SIR HUMPHREY STAFFORD and WILLIAM
41554 his brother with drum and soldiers
41555 STAFFORD Rebellious hinds the filth and scum of Kent
41556 Mark'd for the gallows lay your weapons down
41557 Home to your cottages forsake this groom
41558 The King is merciful if you revolt
41559 WILLIAM STAFFORD But angry wrathful and inclin'd to blood
41560 If you go forward therefore yield or die
41561 CADE As for these silkencoated slaves I pass not
41562 It is to you good people that I speak
41563 O'er whom in time to come I hope to reign
41564 For I am rightful heir unto the crown
41565 STAFFORD Villain thy father was a plasterer
41566 And thou thyself a shearman art thou not
41567 CADE And Adam was a gardener
41568 WILLIAM STAFFORD And what of that
41569 CADE Marry this Edmund Mortimer Earl of March
41570 Married the Duke of Clarence daughter did he not
41571 STAFFORD Ay sir
41572 CADE By her he had two children at one birth
41573 WILLIAM STAFFORD That's false
41574 CADE Ay there's the question but I say 'tis true
41575 The elder of them being put to nurse
41576 Was by a beggarwoman stol'n away
41577 And ignorant of his birth and parentage
41578 Became a bricklayer when he came to age
41579 His son am I deny it if you can
41580 DICK Nay 'tis too true therefore he shall be king
41581 SMITH Sir he made a chimney in my father's house and the bricks
41582 are alive at this day to testify it therefore deny it not
41583 STAFFORD And will you credit this base drudge's words
41584 That speaks he knows not what
41585 ALL Ay marry will we therefore get ye gone
41586 WILLIAM STAFFORD Jack Cade the Duke of York hath taught you this
41587 CADE [Aside] He lies for I invented it myself Go to sirrah
41588 tell the King from me that for his father's sake Henry the
41589 Fifth in whose time boys went to spancounter for French crowns
41590 I am content he shall reign but I'll be Protector over him
41591 DICK And furthermore we'll have the Lord Say's head for selling
41592 the dukedom of Maine
41593 CADE And good reason for thereby is England main'd and fain to go
41594 with a staff but that my puissance holds it up Fellow kings I
41595 tell you that that Lord Say hath gelded the commonwealth and made
41596 it an eunuch and more than that he can speak French and
41597 therefore he is a traitor
41598 STAFFORD O gross and miserable ignorance
41599 CADE Nay answer if you can the Frenchmen are our enemies Go to
41600 then I ask but this can he that speaks with the tongue of an
41601 enemy be a good counsellor or no
41602 ALL No no and therefore we'll have his head
41603 WILLIAM STAFFORD Well seeing gentle words will not prevail
41604 Assail them with the army of the King
41605 STAFFORD Herald away and throughout every town
41606 Proclaim them traitors that are up with Cade
41607 That those which fly before the battle ends
41608 May even in their wives'and children's sight
41609 Be hang'd up for example at their doors
41610 And you that be the King's friends follow me
41611 Exeunt the TWO STAFFORDS and soldiers
41612 CADE And you that love the commons follow me
41613 Now show yourselves men 'tis for liberty
41614 We will not leave one lord one gentleman
41615 Spare none but such as go in clouted shoon
41616 For they are thrifty honest men and such
41617 As would but that they dare not take our parts
41618 DICK They are all in order and march toward us
41619 CADE But then are we in order when we are most out of order Come
41620 march forward Exeunt
41621 SCENE III
41622 Another part of Blackheath
41623 Alarums to the fight wherein both the STAFFORDS are slain
41624 Enter CADE and the rest
41625 CADE Where's Dick the butcher of Ashford
41626 DICK Here sir
41627 CADE They fell before thee like sheep and oxen and thou behavedst
41628 thyself as if thou hadst been in thine own slaughterhouse
41629 therefore thus will I reward thee the Lent shall be as long
41630 again as it is and thou shalt have a licence to kill for a
41631 hundred lacking one
41632 DICK I desire no more
41633 CADE And to speak truth thou deserv'st no less [Putting on SIR
41634 HUMPHREY'S brigandine] This monument of the victory will I bear
41635 and the bodies shall be dragged at my horse heels till I do come
41636 to London where we will have the mayor's sword borne before us
41637 DICK If we mean to thrive and do good break open the gaols and
41638 let out the prisoners
41639 CADE Fear not that I warrant thee Come let's march towards
41640 London Exeunt
41641 SCENE IV
41642 London The palace
41643 Enter the KING with a supplication and the QUEEN with SUFFOLK'S head
41644 the DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM and the LORD SAY
41645 QUEEN Oft have I heard that grief softens the mind
41646 And makes it fearful and degenerate
41647 Think therefore on revenge and cease to weep
41648 But who can cease to weep and look on this
41649 Here may his head lie on my throbbing breast
41650 But where's the body that I should embrace
41651 BUCKINGHAM What answer makes your Grace to the rebels'
41652 supplication
41653 KING HENRY I'll send some holy bishop to entreat
41654 For God forbid so many simple souls
41655 Should perish by the sword And I myself
41656 Rather than bloody war shall cut them short
41657 Will parley with Jack Cade their general
41658 But stay I'll read it over once again
41659 QUEEN Ah barbarous villains Hath this lovely face
41660 Rul'd like a wandering planet over me
41661 And could it not enforce them to relent
41662 That were unworthy to behold the same
41663 KING HENRY Lord Say Jack Cade hath sworn to have thy head
41664 SAY Ay but I hope your Highness shall have his
41665 KING HENRY How now madam
41666 Still lamenting and mourning for Suffolk's death
41667 I fear me love if that I had been dead
41668 Thou wouldst not have mourn'd so much for me
41669 QUEEN No my love I should not mourn but die for thee
41670 Enter A MESSENGER
41671 KING HENRY How now What news Why com'st thou in such haste
41672 MESSENGER The rebels are in Southwark fly my lord
41673 Jack Cade proclaims himself Lord Mortimer
41674 Descended from the Duke of Clarence house
41675 And calls your Grace usurper openly
41676 And vows to crown himself in Westminster
41677 His army is a ragged multitude
41678 Of hinds and peasants rude and merciless
41679 Sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother's death
41680 Hath given them heart and courage to proceed
41681 All scholars lawyers courtiers gentlemen
41682 They call false caterpillars and intend their death
41683 KING HENRY O graceless men they know not what they do
41684 BUCKINGHAM My gracious lord retire to Killingworth
41685 Until a power be rais'd to put them down
41686 QUEEN Ah were the Duke of Suffolk now alive
41687 These Kentish rebels would be soon appeas'd
41688 KING HENRY Lord Say the traitors hate thee
41689 Therefore away with us to Killingworth
41690 SAY So might your Grace's person be in danger
41691 The sight of me is odious in their eyes
41692 And therefore in this city will I stay
41693 And live alone as secret as I may
41694 Enter another MESSENGER
41695 SECOND MESSENGER Jack Cade hath gotten London Bridge
41696 The citizens fly and forsake their houses
41697 The rascal people thirsting after prey
41698 Join with the traitor and they jointly swear
41699 To spoil the city and your royal court
41700 BUCKINGHAM Then linger not my lord away take horse
41701 KING HENRY Come Margaret God our hope will succour us
41702 QUEEN My hope is gone now Suffolk is deceas'd
41703 KING HENRY [To LORD SAY] Farewell my lord trust not the Kentish
41704 rebels
41705 BUCKINGHAM Trust nobody for fear you be betray'd
41706 SAY The trust I have is in mine innocence
41707 And therefore am I bold and resolute Exeunt
41708 SCENE V
41709 London The Tower
41710 Enter LORD SCALES Upon the Tower walking Then enter two or three CITIZENS
41711 below
41712 SCALES How now Is Jack Cade slain
41713 FIRST CITIZEN No my lord nor likely to be slain for they have
41714 won the bridge killing all those that withstand them
41715 The Lord Mayor craves aid of your honour from the
41716 Tower to defend the city from the rebels
41717 SCALES Such aid as I can spare you shall command
41718 But I am troubled here with them myself
41719 The rebels have assay'd to win the Tower
41720 But get you to Smithfield and gather head
41721 And thither I will send you Matthew Goffe
41722 Fight for your King your country and your lives
41723 And so farewell for I must hence again Exeunt
41724 SCENE VI
41725 London Cannon street
41726 Enter JACK CADE and the rest and strikes his staff on London Stone
41727 CADE Now is Mortimer lord of this city And here sitting upon
41728 London Stone I charge and command that of the city's cost the
41729 pissing conduit run nothing but claret wine this first year of
41730 our reign And now henceforward it shall be treason for any that
41731 calls me other than Lord Mortimer
41732 Enter a SOLDIER running
41733 SOLDIER Jack Cade Jack Cade
41734 CADE Knock him down there [They kill him]
41735 SMITH If this fellow be wise he'll never call ye Jack Cade more
41736 I think he hath a very fair warning
41737 DICK My lord there's an army gathered together in Smithfield
41738 CADE Come then let's go fight with them But first go and set
41739 London Bridge on fire and if you can burn down the Tower too
41740 Come let's away Exeunt
41741 SCENE VII
41742 London Smithfield
41743 Alarums MATTHEW GOFFE is slain and all the rest Then enter JACK CADE
41744 with his company
41745 CADE So sirs Now go some and pull down the Savoy others to th'
41746 Inns of Court down with them all
41747 DICK I have a suit unto your lordship
41748 CADE Be it a lordship thou shalt have it for that word
41749 DICK Only that the laws of England may come out of your mouth
41750 JOHN [Aside] Mass 'twill be sore law then for he was thrust in
41751 the mouth with a spear and 'tis not whole yet
41752 SMITH [Aside] Nay John it will be stinking law for his breath
41753 stinks with eating toasted cheese
41754 CADE I have thought upon it it shall be so Away burn all the
41755 records of the realm My mouth shall be the Parliament of
41756 England
41757 JOHN [Aside] Then we are like to have biting statutes unless his
41758 teeth be pull'd out
41759 CADE And henceforward all things shall be in common
41760 Enter a MESSENGER
41761 MESSENGER My lord a prize a prize Here's the Lord Say which
41762 sold the towns in France he that made us pay one and twenty
41763 fifteens and one shining to the pound the last subsidy
41764 Enter GEORGE BEVIS with the LORD SAY
41765 CADE Well he shall be beheaded for it ten times Ah thou say
41766 thou serge nay thou buckram lord Now art thou within point
41767 blank of our jurisdiction regal What canst thou answer to my
41768 Majesty for giving up of Normandy unto Mounsieur Basimecu the
41769 Dauphin of France Be it known unto thee by these presence even
41770 the presence of Lord Mortimer that I am the besom that must
41771 sweep the court clean of such filth as thou art Thou hast most
41772 traitorously corrupted the youth of the realm in erecting a
41773 grammar school and whereas before our forefathers had no other
41774 books but the score and the tally thou hast caused printing to
41775 be us'd and contrary to the King his crown and dignity thou
41776 hast built a papermill It will be proved to thy face that thou
41777 hast men about thee that usually talk of a noun and a verb and
41778 such abominable words as no Christian ear can endure to hear
41779 Thou hast appointed justices of peace to call poor men before
41780 them about matters they were not able to answer Moreover thou
41781 hast put them in prison and because they could not read thou
41782 hast hang'd them when indeed only for that cause they have
41783 been most worthy to live Thou dost ride in a footcloth dost
41784 thou not
41785 SAY What of that
41786 CADE Marry thou ought'st not to let thy horse wear a cloak when
41787 honester men than thou go in their hose and doublets
41788 DICK And work in their shirt too as myself for example that am
41789 a butcher
41790 SAY You men of Kent
41791 DICK What say you of Kent
41792 SAY Nothing but this 'tis 'bona terra mala gens'
41793 CADE Away with him away with him He speaks Latin
41794 SAY Hear me but speak and bear me where you will
41795 Kent in the Commentaries Caesar writ
41796 Is term'd the civil'st place of all this isle
41797 Sweet is the country because full of riches
41798 The people liberal valiant active wealthy
41799 Which makes me hope you are not void of pity
41800 I sold not Maine I lost not Normandy
41801 Yet to recover them would lose my life
41802 Justice with favour have I always done
41803 Pray'rs and tears have mov'd me gifts could never
41804 When have I aught exacted at your hands
41805 But to maintain the King the realm and you
41806 Large gifts have I bestow'd on learned clerks
41807 Because my book preferr'd me to the King
41808 And seeing ignorance is the curse of God
41809 Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven
41810 Unless you be possess'd with devilish spirits
41811 You cannot but forbear to murder me
41812 This tongue hath parley'd unto foreign kings
41813 For your behoof
41814 CADE Tut when struck'st thou one blow in the field
41815 SAY Great men have reaching hands Oft have I struck
41816 Those that I never saw and struck them dead
41817 GEORGE O monstrous coward What to come behind folks
41818 SAY These cheeks are pale for watching for your good
41819 CADE Give him a box o th ear and that will make 'em red again
41820 SAY Long sitting to determine poor men's causes
41821 Hath made me full of sickness and diseases
41822 CADE Ye shall have a hempen caudle then and the help of hatchet
41823 DICK Why dost thou quiver man
41824 SAY The palsy and not fear provokes me
41825 CADE Nay he nods at us as who should say 'I'll be even with
41826 you I'll see if his head will stand steadier on a pole or no
41827 Take him away and behead him
41828 SAY Tell me wherein have I offended most
41829 Have I affected wealth or honour Speak
41830 Are my chests fill'd up with extorted gold
41831 Is my apparel sumptuous to behold
41832 Whom have I injur'd that ye seek my death
41833 These hands are free from guiltless bloodshedding
41834 This breast from harbouring foul deceitful thoughts
41835 O let me live
41836 CADE [Aside] I feel remorse in myself with his words but I'll
41837 bridle it He shall die an it be but for pleading so well for
41838 his life Away with him He has a familiar under his tongue he
41839 speaks not o God's name Go take him away I say and strike
41840 off his head presently and then break into his soninlaw's
41841 house Sir James Cromer and strike off his head and bring them
41842 both upon two poles hither
41843 ALL It shall be done
41844 SAY Ah countrymen if when you make your pray'rs
41845 God should be so obdurate as yourselves
41846 How would it fare with your departed souls
41847 And therefore yet relent and save my life
41848 CADE Away with him and do as I command ye [Exeunt some with
41849 LORD SAY] The proudest peer in the realm shall not wear a head
41850 on his shoulders unless he pay me tribute there shall not a
41851 maid be married but she shall pay to me her maidenhead ere they
41852 have it Men shall hold of me in capite and we charge and
41853 command that their wives be as free as heart can wish or tongue
41854 can tell
41855 DICK My lord when shall we go to Cheapside and take up
41856 commodities upon our bills
41857 CADE Marry presently
41858 ALL O brave
41859 Reenter one with the heads
41860 CADE But is not this braver Let them kiss one another for they
41861 lov'd well when they were alive Now part them again lest they
41862 consult about the giving up of some more towns in France
41863 Soldiers defer the spoil of the city until night for with these
41864 borne before us instead of maces will we ride through the
41865 streets and at every corner have them kiss Away Exeunt
41866 SCENE VIII
41867 Southwark
41868 Alarum and retreat Enter again CADE and all his rabblement
41869 CADE Up Fish Street down Saint Magnus Corner Kill and knock
41870 down Throw them into Thames [Sound a parley]
41871 What noise is this I hear Dare any be so bold to sound retreat
41872 or parley when I command them kill
41873 Enter BUCKINGHAM and old CLIFFORD attended
41874 BUCKINGHAM Ay here they be that dare and will disturb thee
41875 And therefore yet relent and save my life
41876 Know Cade we come ambassadors from the King
41877 Unto the commons whom thou hast misled
41878 And here pronounce free pardon to them all
41879 That will forsake thee and go home in peace
41880 CLIFFORD What say ye countrymen Will ye relent
41881 And yield to mercy whilst 'tis offer'd you
41882 Or let a rebel lead you to your deaths
41883 Who loves the King and will embrace his pardon
41884 Fling up his cap and say 'God save his Majesty'
41885 Who hateth him and honours not his father
41886 Henry the Fifth that made all France to quake
41887 Shake he his weapon at us and pass by
41888 ALL God save the King God save the King
41889 CADE What Buckingham and Clifford are ye so brave
41890 And you base peasants do ye believe him Will you needs be
41891 hang'd with your about your necks Hath my sword therefore broke
41892 through London gates that you should leave me at the White Hart
41893 in Southwark I thought ye would never have given out these arms
41894 till you had recovered your ancient freedom But you are all
41895 recreants and dastards and delight to live in slavery to the
41896 nobility Let them break your backs with burdens take your
41897 houses over your heads ravish your wives and daughters before
41898 your faces For me I will make shift for one and so God's curse
41899 light upon you all
41900 ALL We'll follow Cade we'll follow Cade
41901 CLIFFORD Is Cade the son of Henry the Fifth
41902 That thus you do exclaim you'll go with him
41903 Will he conduct you through the heart of France
41904 And make the meanest of you earls and dukes
41905 Alas he hath no home no place to fly to
41906 Nor knows he how to live but by the spoil
41907 Unless by robbing of your friends and us
41908 Were't not a shame that whilst you live at jar
41909 The fearful French whom you late vanquished
41910 Should make a start o'er seas and vanquish you
41911 Methinks already in this civil broil
41912 I see them lording it in London streets
41913 Crying 'Villiago unto all they meet
41914 Better ten thousand baseborn Cades miscarry
41915 Than you should stoop unto a Frenchman's mercy
41916 To France to France and get what you have lost
41917 Spare England for it is your native coast
41918 Henry hath money you are strong and manly
41919 God on our side doubt not of victory
41920 ALL A Clifford a Clifford We'll follow the King and Clifford
41921 CADE Was ever feather so lightly blown to and fro as this
41922 multitude The name of Henry the Fifth hales them to an hundred
41923 mischiefs and makes them leave me desolate I see them lay their
41924 heads together to surprise me My sword make way for me for here
41925 is no staying In despite of the devils and hell have through
41926 the very middest of you and heavens and honour be witness that
41927 no want of resolution in me but only my followers base and
41928 ignominious treasons makes me betake me to my heels
41929 Exit
41930 BUCKINGHAM What is he fled Go some and follow him
41931 And he that brings his head unto the King
41932 Shall have a thousand crowns for his reward
41933 Exeunt some of them
41934 Follow me soldiers we'll devise a mean
41935 To reconcile you all unto the King Exeunt
41936 SCENE IX
41937 Killing worth Castle
41938 Sound trumpets Enter KING QUEEN and SOMERSET on the terrace
41939 KING HENRY Was ever king that joy'd an earthly throne
41940 And could command no more content than I
41941 No sooner was I crept out of my cradle
41942 But I was made a king at nine months old
41943 Was never subject long'd to be a King
41944 As I do long and wish to be a subject
41945 Enter BUCKINGHAM and old CLIFFORD
41946 BUCKINGHAM Health and glad tidings to your Majesty
41947 KING HENRY Why Buckingham is the traitor Cade surpris'd
41948 Or is he but retir'd to make him strong
41949 Enter below multitudes with halters about their necks
41950 CLIFFORD He is fled my lord and all his powers do yield
41951 And humbly thus with halters on their necks
41952 Expect your Highness doom of life or death
41953 KING HENRY Then heaven set ope thy everlasting gates
41954 To entertain my vows of thanks and praise
41955 Soldiers this day have you redeem'd your lives
41956 And show'd how well you love your Prince and country
41957 Continue still in this so good a mind
41958 And Henry though he be infortunate
41959 Assure yourselves will never be unkind
41960 And so with thanks and pardon to you all
41961 I do dismiss you to your several countries
41962 ALL God save the King God save the King
41963 Enter a MESSENGER
41964 MESSENGER Please it your Grace to be advertised
41965 The Duke of York is newly come from Ireland
41966 And with a puissant and a mighty power
41967 Of gallowglasses and stout kerns
41968 Is marching hitherward in proud array
41969 And still proclaimeth as he comes along
41970 His arms are only to remove from thee
41971 The Duke of Somerset whom he terms a traitor
41972 KING HENRY Thus stands my state 'twixt Cade and York distress'd
41973 Like to a ship that having scap'd a tempest
41974 Is straightway calm'd and boarded with a pirate
41975 But now is Cade driven back his men dispers'd
41976 And now is York in arms to second him
41977 I pray thee Buckingham go and meet him
41978 And ask him what's the reason of these arms
41979 Tell him I'll send Duke Edmund to the Tower
41980 And Somerset we will commit thee thither
41981 Until his army be dismiss'd from him
41982 SOMERSET My lord
41983 I'll yield myself to prison willingly
41984 Or unto death to do my country good
41985 KING HENRY In any case be not too rough in terms
41986 For he is fierce and cannot brook hard language
41987 BUCKINGHAM I will my lord and doubt not so to deal
41988 As all things shall redound unto your good
41989 KING HENRY Come wife let's in and learn to govern better
41990 For yet may England curse my wretched reign
41991 Flourish Exeunt
41992 SCENE X
41993 Kent Iden's garden
41994 Enter CADE
41995 CADE Fie on ambitions Fie on myself that have a sword and yet am
41996 ready to famish These five days have I hid me in these woods and
41997 durst not peep out for all the country is laid for me but now
41998 am I so hungry that if I might have a lease of my life for a
41999 thousand years I could stay no longer Wherefore on a brick
42000 wall have I climb'd into this garden to see if I can eat grass
42001 or pick a sallet another while which is not amiss to cool a
42002 man's stomach this hot weather And I think this word 'sallet'
42003 was born to do me good for many a time but for a sallet my
42004 brainpain had been cleft with a brown bill and many a time
42005 when I have been dry and bravely marching it hath serv'd me
42006 instead of a quartpot to drink in and now the word 'sallet'
42007 must serve me to feed on
42008 Enter IDEN
42009 IDEN Lord who would live turmoiled in the court
42010 And may enjoy such quiet walks as these
42011 This small inheritance my father left me
42012 Contenteth me and worth a monarchy
42013 I seek not to wax great by others waning
42014 Or gather wealth I care not with what envy
42015 Sufficeth that I have maintains my state
42016 And sends the poor well pleased from my gate
42017 CADE Here's the lord of the soil come to seize me for a stray for
42018 entering his feesimple without leave Ah villain thou wilt
42019 betray me and get a thousand crowns of the King by carrying my
42020 head to him but I'll make thee eat iron like an ostrich and
42021 swallow my sword like a great pin ere thou and I part
42022 IDEN Why rude companion whatsoe'er thou be
42023 I know thee not why then should I betray thee
42024 Is't not enough to break into my garden
42025 And like a thief to come to rob my grounds
42026 Climbing my walls in spite of me the owner
42027 But thou wilt brave me with these saucy terms
42028 CADE Brave thee Ay by the best blood that ever was broach'd and
42029 beard thee too Look on me well I have eat no meat these five
42030 days yet come thou and thy five men and if I do not leave you
42031 all as dead as a doornail I pray God I may never eat grass
42032 more
42033 IDEN Nay it shall ne'er be said while England stands
42034 That Alexander Iden an esquire of Kent
42035 Took odds to combat a poor famish'd man
42036 Oppose thy steadfastgazing eyes to mine
42037 See if thou canst outface me with thy looks
42038 Set limb to limb and thou art far the lesser
42039 Thy hand is but a finger to my fist
42040 Thy leg a stick compared with this truncheon
42041 My foot shall fight with all the strength thou hast
42042 And if mine arm be heaved in the air
42043 Thy grave is digg'd already in the earth
42044 As for words whose greatness answers words
42045 Let this my sword report what speech forbears
42046 CADE By my valour the most complete champion that ever I heard
42047 Steel if thou turn the edge or cut not out the burly bon'd
42048 clown in chines of beef ere thou sleep in thy sheath I beseech
42049 God on my knees thou mayst be turn'd to hobnails [Here they
42050 fight CADE falls] O I am slain famine and no other hath slain
42051 me Let ten thousand devils come against me and give me but the
42052 ten meals I have lost and I'd defy them all Wither garden and
42053 be henceforth a burying place to all that do dwell in this house
42054 because the unconquered soul of Cade is fled
42055 IDEN Is't Cade that I have slain that monstrous traitor
42056 Sword I will hallow thee for this thy deed
42057 And hang thee o'er my tomb when I am dead
42058 Ne'er shall this blood be wiped from thy point
42059 But thou shalt wear it as a herald's coat
42060 To emblaze the honour that thy master got
42061 CADE Iden farewell and be proud of thy victory Tell Kent from
42062 me she hath lost her best man and exhort all the world to be
42063 cowards for I that never feared any am vanquished by famine
42064 not by valour [Dies]
42065 IDEN How much thou wrong'st me heaven be my judge
42066 Die damned wretch the curse of her that bare thee
42067 And as I thrust thy body in with my sword
42068 So wish I I might thrust thy soul to hell
42069 Hence will I drag thee headlong by the heels
42070 Unto a dunghill which shall be thy grave
42071 And there cut off thy most ungracious head
42072 Which I will bear in triumph to the King
42073 Leaving thy trunk for crows to feed upon Exit
42074 <<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
42075 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
42076 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
42077 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
42078 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
42079 PERSONAL USE ONLY AND 2 ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
42080 COMMERCIALLY PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
42081 SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP>>
42082 ACT V SCENE I
42083 Fields between Dartford and Blackheath
42084 Enter YORK and his army of Irish with drum and colours
42085 YORK From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right
42086 And pluck the crown from feeble Henry's head
42087 Ring bells aloud burn bonfires clear and bright
42088 To entertain great England's lawful king
42089 Ah sancta majestas who would not buy thee dear
42090 Let them obey that knows not how to rule
42091 This hand was made to handle nought but gold
42092 I cannot give due action to my words
42093 Except a sword or sceptre balance it
42094 A sceptre shall it have have I a soul
42095 On which I'll toss the flowerdeluce of France
42096 Enter BUCKINGHAM
42097 [Aside] Whom have we here Buckingham to disturb me
42098 The King hath sent him sure I must dissemble
42099 BUCKINGHAM York if thou meanest well I greet thee well
42100 YORK Humphrey of Buckingham I accept thy greeting
42101 Art thou a messenger or come of pleasure
42102 BUCKINGHAM A messenger from Henry our dread liege
42103 To know the reason of these arms in peace
42104 Or why thou being a subject as I am
42105 Against thy oath and true allegiance sworn
42106 Should raise so great a power without his leave
42107 Or dare to bring thy force so near the court
42108 YORK [Aside] Scarce can I speak my choler is so great
42109 O I could hew up rocks and fight with flint
42110 I am so angry at these abject terms
42111 And now like Ajax Telamonius
42112 On sheep or oxen could I spend my fury
42113 I am far better born than is the King
42114 More like a king more kingly in my thoughts
42115 But I must make fair weather yet awhile
42116 Till Henry be more weak and I more strong
42117 Buckingham I prithee pardon me
42118 That I have given no answer all this while
42119 My mind was troubled with deep melancholy
42120 The cause why I have brought this army hither
42121 Is to remove proud Somerset from the King
42122 Seditious to his Grace and to the state
42123 BUCKINGHAM That is too much presumption on thy part
42124 But if thy arms be to no other end
42125 The King hath yielded unto thy demand
42126 The Duke of Somerset is in the Tower
42127 YORK Upon thine honour is he prisoner
42128 BUCKINGHAM Upon mine honour he is prisoner
42129 YORK Then Buckingham I do dismiss my pow'rs
42130 Soldiers I thank you all disperse yourselves
42131 Meet me tomorrow in Saint George's field
42132 You shall have pay and everything you wish
42133 And let my sovereign virtuous Henry
42134 Command my eldest son nay all my sons
42135 As pledges of my fealty and love
42136 I'll send them all as willing as I live
42137 Lands goods horse armour anything I have
42138 Is his to use so Somerset may die
42139 BUCKINGHAM York I commend this kind submission
42140 We twain will go into his Highness tent
42141 Enter the KING and attendants
42142 KING HENRY Buckingham doth York intend no harm to us
42143 That thus he marcheth with thee arm in arm
42144 YORK In all submission and humility
42145 York doth present himself unto your Highness
42146 KING HENRY Then what intends these forces thou dost bring
42147 YORK To heave the traitor Somerset from hence
42148 And fight against that monstrous rebel Cade
42149 Who since I heard to be discomfited
42150 Enter IDEN with CADE's head
42151 IDEN If one so rude and of so mean condition
42152 May pass into the presence of a king
42153 Lo I present your Grace a traitor's head
42154 The head of Cade whom I in combat slew
42155 KING HENRY The head of Cade Great God how just art Thou
42156 O let me view his visage being dead
42157 That living wrought me such exceeding trouble
42158 Tell me my friend art thou the man that slew him
42159 IDEN I was an't like your Majesty
42160 KING HENRY How art thou call'd And what is thy degree
42161 IDEN Alexander Iden that's my name
42162 A poor esquire of Kent that loves his king
42163 BUCKINGHAM So please it you my lord 'twere not amiss
42164 He were created knight for his good service
42165 KING HENRY Iden kneel down [He kneels] Rise up a knight
42166 We give thee for reward a thousand marks
42167 And will that thou thenceforth attend on us
42168 IDEN May Iden live to merit such a bounty
42169 And never live but true unto his liege
42170 Enter the QUEEN and SOMERSET
42171 KING HENRY See Buckingham Somerset comes with th Queen
42172 Go bid her hide him quickly from the Duke
42173 QUEEN For thousand Yorks he shall not hide his head
42174 But boldly stand and front him to his face
42175 YORK How now Is Somerset at liberty
42176 Then York unloose thy longimprisoned thoughts
42177 And let thy tongue be equal with thy heart
42178 Shall I endure the sight of Somerset
42179 False king why hast thou broken faith with me
42180 Knowing how hardly I can brook abuse
42181 King did I call thee No thou art not king
42182 Not fit to govern and rule multitudes
42183 Which dar'st not no nor canst not rule a traitor
42184 That head of thine doth not become a crown
42185 Thy hand is made to grasp a palmer's staff
42186 And not to grace an awful princely sceptre
42187 That gold must round engirt these brows of mine
42188 Whose smile and frown like to Achilles spear
42189 Is able with the change to kill and cure
42190 Here is a hand to hold a sceptre up
42191 And with the same to act controlling laws
42192 Give place By heaven thou shalt rule no more
42193 O'er him whom heaven created for thy ruler
42194 SOMERSET O monstrous traitor I arrest thee York
42195 Of capital treason 'gainst the King and crown
42196 Obey audacious traitor kneel for grace
42197 YORK Wouldst have me kneel First let me ask of these
42198 If they can brook I bow a knee to man
42199 Sirrah call in my sons to be my bail Exit attendant
42200 I know ere thy will have me go to ward
42201 They'll pawn their swords for my enfranchisement
42202 QUEEN Call hither Clifford bid him come amain
42203 To say if that the bastard boys of York
42204 Shall be the surety for their traitor father
42205 Exit BUCKINGHAM
42206 YORK O bloodbespotted Neapolitan
42207 Outcast of Naples England's bloody scourge
42208 The sons of York thy betters in their birth
42209 Shall be their father's bail and bane to those
42210 That for my surety will refuse the boys
42211 Enter EDWARD and RICHARD PLANTAGENET
42212 See where they come I'll warrant they'll make it good
42213 Enter CLIFFORD and his SON
42214 QUEEN And here comes Clifford to deny their bail
42215 CLIFFORD Health and all happiness to my lord the King
42216 [Kneels]
42217 YORK I thank thee Clifford Say what news with thee
42218 Nay do not fright us with an angry look
42219 We are thy sovereign Clifford kneel again
42220 For thy mistaking so we pardon thee
42221 CLIFFORD This is my King York I do not mistake
42222 But thou mistakes me much to think I do
42223 To Bedlam with him Is the man grown mad
42224 KING HENRY Ay Clifford a bedlam and ambitious humour
42225 Makes him oppose himself against his king
42226 CLIFFORD He is a traitor let him to the Tower
42227 And chop away that factious pate of his
42228 QUEEN He is arrested but will not obey
42229 His sons he says shall give their words for him
42230 YORK Will you not sons
42231 EDWARD Ay noble father if our words will serve
42232 RICHARD And if words will not then our weapons shall
42233 CLIFFORD Why what a brood of traitors have we here
42234 YORK Look in a glass and call thy image so
42235 I am thy king and thou a falseheart traitor
42236 Call hither to the stake my two brave bears
42237 That with the very shaking of their chains
42238 They may astonish these felllurking curs
42239 Bid Salisbury and Warwick come to me
42240 Enter the EARLS OF WARWICK and SALISBURY
42241 CLIFFORD Are these thy bears We'll bait thy bears to death
42242 And manacle the berard in their chains
42243 If thou dar'st bring them to the baitingplace
42244 RICHARD Oft have I seen a hot o'er weening cur
42245 Run back and bite because he was withheld
42246 Who being suffer'd with the bear's fell paw
42247 Hath clapp'd his tail between his legs and cried
42248 And such a piece of service will you do
42249 If you oppose yourselves to match Lord Warwick
42250 CLIFFORD Hence heap of wrath foul indigested lump
42251 As crooked in thy manners as thy shape
42252 YORK Nay we shall heat you thoroughly anon
42253 CLIFFORD Take heed lest by your heat you burn yourselves
42254 KING HENRY Why Warwick hath thy knee forgot to bow
42255 Old Salisbury shame to thy silver hair
42256 Thou mad misleader of thy brainsick son
42257 What wilt thou on thy deathbed play the ruffian
42258 And seek for sorrow with thy spectacles
42259 O where is faith O where is loyalty
42260 If it be banish'd from the frosty head
42261 Where shall it find a harbour in the earth
42262 Wilt thou go dig a grave to find out war
42263 And shame thine honourable age with blood
42264 Why art thou old and want'st experience
42265 Or wherefore dost abuse it if thou hast it
42266 For shame In duty bend thy knee to me
42267 That bows unto the grave with mickle age
42268 SALISBURY My lord I have considered with myself
42269 The tide of this most renowned duke
42270 And in my conscience do repute his Grace
42271 The rightful heir to England's royal seat
42272 KING HENRY Hast thou not sworn allegiance unto me
42273 SALISBURY I have
42274 KING HENRY Canst thou dispense with heaven for such an oath
42275 SALISBURY It is great sin to swear unto a sin
42276 But greater sin to keep a sinful oath
42277 Who can be bound by any solemn vow
42278 To do a murd'rous deed to rob a man
42279 To force a spotless virgin's chastity
42280 To reave the orphan of his patrimony
42281 To wring the widow from her custom'd right
42282 And have no other reason for this wrong
42283 But that he was bound by a solemn oath
42284 QUEEN A subtle traitor needs no sophister
42285 KING HENRY Call Buckingham and bid him arm himself
42286 YORK Call Buckingham and all the friends thou hast
42287 I am resolv'd for death or dignity
42288 CLIFFORD The first I warrant thee if dreams prove true
42289 WARWICK You were best to go to bed and dream again
42290 To keep thee from the tempest of the field
42291 CLIFFORD I am resolv'd to bear a greater storm
42292 Than any thou canst conjure up today
42293 And that I'll write upon thy burgonet
42294 Might I but know thee by thy household badge
42295 WARWICK Now by my father's badge old Nevil's crest
42296 The rampant bear chain'd to the ragged staff
42297 This day I'll wear aloft my burgonet
42298 As on a mountaintop the cedar shows
42299 That keeps his leaves in spite of any storm
42300 Even to affright thee with the view thereof
42301 CLIFFORD And from thy burgonet I'll rend thy bear
42302 And tread it under foot with all contempt
42303 Despite the berard that protects the bear
42304 YOUNG CLIFFORD And so to arms victorious father
42305 To quell the rebels and their complices
42306 RICHARD Fie charity for shame Speak not in spite
42307 For you shall sup with Jesu Christ tonight
42308 YOUNG CLIFFORD Foul stigmatic that's more than thou canst tell
42309 RICHARD If not in heaven you'll surely sup in hell
42310 Exeunt severally
42311 SCENE II
42312 Saint Albans
42313 Alarums to the battle Enter WARWICK
42314 WARWICK Clifford of Cumberland 'tis Warwick calls
42315 And if thou dost not hide thee from the bear
42316 Now when the angry trumpet sounds alarum
42317 And dead men's cries do fill the empty air
42318 Clifford I say come forth and fight with me
42319 Proud northern lord Clifford of Cumberland
42320 WARWICK is hoarse with calling thee to arms
42321 Enter YORK
42322 How now my noble lord what all afoot
42323 YORK The deadlyhanded Clifford slew my steed
42324 But match to match I have encount'red him
42325 And made a prey for carrion kites and crows
42326 Even of the bonny beast he lov'd so well
42327 Enter OLD CLIFFORD
42328 WARWICK Of one or both of us the time is come
42329 YORK Hold Warwick seek thee out some other chase
42330 For I myself must hunt this deer to death
42331 WARWICK Then nobly York 'tis for a crown thou fight'st
42332 As I intend Clifford to thrive today
42333 It grieves my soul to leave thee unassail'd Exit
42334 CLIFFORD What seest thou in me York Why dost thou pause
42335 YORK With thy brave bearing should I be in love
42336 But that thou art so fast mine enemy
42337 CLIFFORD Nor should thy prowess want praise and esteem
42338 But that 'tis shown ignobly and in treason
42339 YORK So let it help me now against thy sword
42340 As I in justice and true right express it
42341 CLIFFORD My soul and body on the action both
42342 YORK A dreadful lay Address thee instantly
42343 [They fight and CLIFFORD falls]
42344 CLIFFORD La fin couronne les oeuvres [Dies]
42345 YORK Thus war hath given thee peace for thou art still
42346 Peace with his soul heaven if it be thy will Exit
42347 Enter YOUNG CLIFFORD
42348 YOUNG CLIFFORD Shame and confusion All is on the rout
42349 Fear frames disorder and disorder wounds
42350 Where it should guard O war thou son of hell
42351 Whom angry heavens do make their minister
42352 Throw in the frozen bosoms of our part
42353 Hot coals of vengeance Let no soldier fly
42354 He that is truly dedicate to war
42355 Hath no selflove nor he that loves himself
42356 Hath not essentially but by circumstance
42357 The name of valour [Sees his father's body]
42358 O let the vile world end
42359 And the premised flames of the last day
42360 Knit earth and heaven together
42361 Now let the general trumpet blow his blast
42362 Particularities and petty sounds
42363 To cease Wast thou ordain'd dear father
42364 To lose thy youth in peace and to achieve
42365 The silver livery of advised age
42366 And in thy reverence and thy chairdays thus
42367 To die in ruffian battle Even at this sight
42368 My heart is turn'd to stone and while 'tis mine
42369 It shall be stony York not our old men spares
42370 No more will I their babes Tears virginal
42371 Shall be to me even as the dew to fire
42372 And beauty that the tyrant oft reclaims
42373 Shall to my flaming wrath be oil and flax
42374 Henceforth I will not have to do with pity
42375 Meet I an infant of the house of York
42376 Into as many gobbets will I cut it
42377 As wild Medea young Absyrtus did
42378 In cruelty will I seek out my fame
42379 Come thou new ruin of old Clifford's house
42380 As did Aeneas old Anchises bear
42381 So bear I thee upon my manly shoulders
42382 But then Aeneas bare a living load
42383 Nothing so heavy as these woes of mine
42384 Exit with the body
42385 Enter RICHARD and SOMERSET to fight SOMERSET is killed
42386 RICHARD So lie thou there
42387 For underneath an alehouse paltry sign
42388 The Castle in Saint Albans Somerset
42389 Hath made the wizard famous in his death
42390 Sword hold thy temper heart be wrathful still
42391 Priests pray for enemies but princes kill Exit
42392 Fight Excursions Enter KING QUEEN and others
42393 QUEEN Away my lord You are slow for shame away
42394 KING HENRY Can we outrun the heavens Good Margaret stay
42395 QUEEN What are you made of You'll nor fight nor fly
42396 Now is it manhood wisdom and defence
42397 To give the enemy way and to secure us
42398 By what we can which can no more but fly
42399 [Alarum afar off]
42400 If you be ta'en we then should see the bottom
42401 Of all our fortunes but if we haply scape
42402 As well we may if not through your neglect
42403 We shall to London get where you are lov'd
42404 And where this breach now in our fortunes made
42405 May readily be stopp'd
42406 Reenter YOUNG CLIFFORD
42407 YOUNG CLIFFORD But that my heart's on future mischief set
42408 I would speak blasphemy ere bid you fly
42409 But fly you must uncurable discomfit
42410 Reigns in the hearts of all our present parts
42411 Away for your relief and we will live
42412 To see their day and them our fortune give
42413 Away my lord away Exeunt
42414 SCENE III
42415 Fields near Saint Albans
42416 Alarum Retreat Enter YORK RICHARD WARWICK and soldiers
42417 with drum and colours
42418 YORK Of Salisbury who can report of him
42419 That winter lion who in rage forgets
42420 Aged contusions and all brush of time
42421 And like a gallant in the brow of youth
42422 Repairs him with occasion This happy day
42423 Is not itself nor have we won one foot
42424 If Salisbury be lost
42425 RICHARD My noble father
42426 Three times today I holp him to his horse
42427 Three times bestrid him thrice I led him off
42428 Persuaded him from any further act
42429 But still where danger was still there I met him
42430 And like rich hangings in a homely house
42431 So was his will in his old feeble body
42432 But noble as he is look where he comes
42433 Enter SALISBURY
42434 SALISBURY Now by my sword well hast thou fought today
42435 By th mass so did we all I thank you Richard
42436 God knows how long it is I have to live
42437 And it hath pleas'd Him that three times today
42438 You have defended me from imminent death
42439 Well lords we have not got that which we have
42440 'Tis not enough our foes are this time fled
42441 Being opposites of such repairing nature
42442 YORK I know our safety is to follow them
42443 For as I hear the King is fled to London
42444 To call a present court of Parliament
42445 Let us pursue him ere the writs go forth
42446 What says Lord Warwick Shall we after them
42447 WARWICK After them Nay before them if we can
42448 Now by my faith lords 'twas a glorious day
42449 Saint Albans battle won by famous York
42450 Shall be eterniz'd in all age to come
42451 Sound drum and trumpets and to London all
42452 And more such days as these to us befall Exeunt
42453 THE END

42462 1591
42463 THE THIRD PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTH
42464 by William Shakespeare
42465 DRAMATIS PERSONAE
42466 KING HENRY THE SIXTH
42467 EDWARD PRINCE OF WALES his son
42468 LEWIS XI King of France DUKE OF SOMERSET
42469 DUKE OF EXETER EARL OF OXFORD
42470 EARL OF NORTHUMBERLAND EARL OF WESTMORELAND
42471 LORD CLIFFORD
42472 RICHARD PLANTAGENET DUKE OF YORK
42473 EDWARD EARL OF MARCH afterwards KING EDWARD IV his son
42474 EDMUND EARL OF RUTLAND his son
42475 GEORGE afterwards DUKE OF CLARENCE his son
42476 RICHARD afterwards DUKE OF GLOUCESTER his son
42477 DUKE OF NORFOLK MARQUIS OF MONTAGUE
42478 EARL OF WARWICK EARL OF PEMBROKE
42479 LORD HASTINGS LORD STAFFORD
42480 SIR JOHN MORTIMER uncle to the Duke of York
42481 SIR HUGH MORTIMER uncle to the Duke of York
42482 HENRY EARL OF RICHMOND a youth
42483 LORD RIVERS brother to Lady Grey
42484 SIR WILLIAM STANLEY SIR JOHN MONTGOMERY
42485 SIR JOHN SOMERVILLE TUTOR to Rutland
42486 MAYOR OF YORK LIEUTENANT OF THE TOWER
42487 A NOBLEMAN TWO KEEPERS
42488 A HUNTSMAN
42489 A SON that has killed his father
42490 A FATHER that has killed his son
42491 QUEEN MARGARET
42492 LADY GREY afterwards QUEEN to Edward IV
42493 BONA sister to the French Queen
42494 Soldiers Attendants Messengers Watchmen etc

42496 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS

42498 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
42499 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
