43896 SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP>>
43897 ACT III SCENE I
43898 A chase in the north of England
43899 Enter two KEEPERS with crossbows in their hands
43900 FIRST KEEPER Under this thickgrown brake we'll shroud ourselves
43901 For through this laund anon the deer will come
43902 And in this covert will we make our stand
43903 Culling the principal of all the deer
43904 SECOND KEEPER I'll stay above the hill so both may shoot
43905 FIRST KEEPER That cannot be the noise of thy crossbow
43906 Will scare the herd and so my shoot is lost
43907 Here stand we both and aim we at the best
43908 And for the time shall not seem tedious
43909 I'll tell thee what befell me on a day
43910 In this selfplace where now we mean to stand
43911 SECOND KEEPER Here comes a man let's stay till he be past
43912 Enter KING HENRY disguised with a prayerbook
43913 KING HENRY From Scotland am I stol'n even of pure love
43914 To greet mine own land with my wishful sight
43915 No Harry Harry 'tis no land of thine
43916 Thy place is fill'd thy sceptre wrung from thee
43917 Thy balm wash'd off wherewith thou wast anointed
43918 No bending knee will call thee Caesar now
43919 No humble suitors press to speak for right
43920 No not a man comes for redress of thee
43921 For how can I help them and not myself
43922 FIRST KEEPER Ay here's a deer whose skin's a keeper's fee
43923 This is the quondam King let's seize upon him
43924 KING HENRY Let me embrace thee sour adversity
43925 For wise men say it is the wisest course
43926 SECOND KEEPER Why linger we let us lay hands upon him
43927 FIRST KEEPER Forbear awhile we'll hear a little more
43928 KING HENRY My Queen and son are gone to France for aid
43929 And as I hear the great commanding Warwick
43930 Is thither gone to crave the French King's sister
43931 To wife for Edward If this news be true
43932 Poor queen and son your labour is but lost
43933 For Warwick is a subtle orator
43934 And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words
43935 By this account then Margaret may win him
43936 For she's a woman to be pitied much
43937 Her sighs will make a batt'ry in his breast
43938 Her tears will pierce into a marble heart
43939 The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn
43940 And Nero will be tainted with remorse
43941 To hear and see her plaints her brinish tears
43942 Ay but she's come to beg Warwick to give
43943 She on his left side craving aid for Henry
43944 He on his right asking a wife for Edward
43945 She weeps and says her Henry is depos'd
43946 He smiles and says his Edward is install'd
43947 That she poor wretch for grief can speak no more
43948 Whiles Warwick tells his title smooths the wrong
43949 Inferreth arguments of mighty strength
43950 And in conclusion wins the King from her
43951 With promise of his sister and what else
43952 To strengthen and support King Edward's place
43953 O Margaret thus 'twill be and thou poor soul
43954 Art then forsaken as thou went'st forlorn
43955 SECOND KEEPER Say what art thou that talk'st of kings and queens
43956 KING HENRY More than I seem and less than I was born to
43957 A man at least for less I should not be
43958 And men may talk of kings and why not I
43959 SECOND KEEPER Ay but thou talk'st as if thou wert a king
43960 KING HENRY Why so I am in mind and that's enough
43961 SECOND KEEPER But if thou be a king where is thy crown
43962 KING HENRY My crown is in my heart not on my head
43963 Not deck'd with diamonds and Indian stones
43964 Not to be seen My crown is call'd content
43965 A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy
43966 SECOND KEEPER Well if you be a king crown'd with content
43967 Your crown content and you must be contented
43968 To go along with us for as we think
43969 You are the king King Edward hath depos'd
43970 And we his subjects sworn in all allegiance
43971 Will apprehend you as his enemy
43972 KING HENRY But did you never swear and break an oath
43973 SECOND KEEPER No never such an oath nor will not now
43974 KING HENRY Where did you dwell when I was King of England
43975 SECOND KEEPER Here in this country where we now remain
43976 KING HENRY I was anointed king at nine months old
43977 My father and my grandfather were kings
43978 And you were sworn true subjects unto me
43979 And tell me then have you not broke your oaths
43980 FIRST KEEPER No
43981 For we were subjects but while you were king
43982 KING HENRY Why am I dead Do I not breathe a man
43983 Ah simple men you know not what you swear
43984 Look as I blow this feather from my face
43985 And as the air blows it to me again
43986 Obeying with my wind when I do blow
43987 And yielding to another when it blows
43988 Commanded always by the greater gust
43989 Such is the lightness of you common men
43990 But do not break your oaths for of that sin
43991 My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty
43992 Go where you will the King shall be commanded
43993 And be you kings command and I'll obey
43994 FIRST KEEPER We are true subjects to the King King Edward
43995 KING HENRY So would you be again to Henry
43996 If he were seated as King Edward is
43997 FIRST KEEPER We charge you in God's name and the King's
43998 To go with us unto the officers
43999 KING HENRY In God's name lead your King's name be obey'd
44000 And what God will that let your King perform
44001 And what he will I humbly yield unto Exeunt
44002 <<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
44003 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
44004 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
44005 WITH PERMISSION ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
44006 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
44007 PERSONAL USE ONLY AND 2 ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
44008 COMMERCIALLY PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
44009 SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP>>
44010 SCENE II
44011 London The palace
44012 Enter KING EDWARD GLOUCESTER CLARENCE and LADY GREY
44013 KING EDWARD Brother of Gloucester at Saint Albans field
44014 This lady's husband Sir Richard Grey was slain
44015 His land then seiz'd on by the conqueror
44016 Her suit is now to repossess those lands
44017 Which we in justice cannot well deny
44018 Because in quarrel of the house of York
44019 The worthy gentleman did lose his life
44020 GLOUCESTER Your Highness shall do well to grant her suit
44021 It were dishonour to deny it her
44022 KING EDWARD It were no less but yet I'll make a pause
44023 GLOUCESTER [Aside to CLARENCE] Yea is it so
44024 I see the lady hath a thing to grant
44025 Before the King will grant her humble suit
44026 CLARENCE [Aside to GLOUCESTER] He knows the game how true he
44027 keeps the wind
44028 GLOUCESTER [Aside to CLARENCE] Silence
44029 KING EDWARD Widow we will consider of your suit
44030 And come some other time to know our mind
44031 LADY GREY Right gracious lord I cannot brook delay
44032 May it please your Highness to resolve me now
44033 And what your pleasure is shall satisfy me
44034 GLOUCESTER [Aside] Ay widow Then I'll warrant you all your
44035 lands
44036 An if what pleases him shall pleasure you
44037 Fight closer or good faith you'll catch a blow
44038 CLARENCE [Aside to GLOUCESTER] I fear her not unless she chance
44039 to fall
44040 GLOUCESTER [Aside to CLARENCE] God forbid that for he'll take
44041 vantages
44042 KING EDWARD How many children hast thou widow tell me
44043 CLARENCE [Aside to GLOUCESTER] I think he means to beg a child of
44044 her
44045 GLOUCESTER [Aside to CLARENCE] Nay then whip me he'll rather
44046 give her two
44047 LADY GREY Three my most gracious lord
44048 GLOUCESTER [Aside] You shall have four if you'll be rul'd by him
44049 KING EDWARD 'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands
44050 LADY GREY Be pitiful dread lord and grant it then
44051 KING EDWARD Lords give us leave I'll try this widow's wit
44052 GLOUCESTER [Aside] Ay good leave have you for you will have
44053 leave
44054 Till youth take leave and leave you to the crutch
44055 [GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE withdraw]
44056 KING EDWARD Now tell me madam do you love your children
44057 LADY GREY Ay full as dearly as I love myself
44058 KING EDWARD And would you not do much to do them good
44059 LADY GREY To do them good I would sustain some harm
44060 KING EDWARD Then get your husband's lands to do them good
44061 LADY GREY Therefore I came unto your Majesty
44062 KING EDWARD I'll tell you how these lands are to be got
44063 LADY GREY So shall you bind me to your Highness service
44064 KING EDWARD What service wilt thou do me if I give them
44065 LADY GREY What you command that rests in me to do
44066 KING EDWARD But you will take exceptions to my boon
44067 LADY GREY No gracious lord except I cannot do it
44068 KING EDWARD Ay but thou canst do what I mean to ask
44069 LADY GREY Why then I will do what your Grace commands
44070 GLOUCESTER He plies her hard and much rain wears the marble
44071 CLARENCE As red as fire Nay then her wax must melt
44072 LADY GREY Why stops my lord Shall I not hear my task
44073 KING EDWARD An easy task 'tis but to love a king
44074 LADY GREY That's soon perform'd because I am a subject
44075 KING EDWARD Why then thy husband's lands I freely give thee
44076 LADY GREY I take my leave with many thousand thanks
44077 GLOUCESTER The match is made she seals it with a curtsy
44078 KING EDWARD But stay thee 'tis the fruits of love I mean
44079 LADY GREY The fruits of love I mean my loving liege
44080 KING EDWARD Ay but I fear me in another sense
44081 What love thinkst thou I sue so much to get
44082 LADY GREY My love till death my humble thanks my prayers
44083 That love which virtue begs and virtue grants
44084 KING EDWARD No by my troth I did not mean such love
44085 LADY GREY Why then you mean not as I thought you did
44086 KING EDWARD But now you partly may perceive my mind
44087 LADY GREY My mind will never grant what I perceive
44088 Your Highness aims at if I aim aright
44089 KING EDWARD To tell thee plain I aim to lie with thee
44090 LADY GREY To tell you plain I had rather lie in prison
44091 KING EDWARD Why then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands
44092 LADY GREY Why then mine honesty shall be my dower
44093 For by that loss I will not purchase them
44094 KING EDWARD Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily
44095 LADY GREY Herein your Highness wrongs both them and me
44096 But mighty lord this merry inclination
44097 Accords not with the sadness of my suit
44098 Please you dismiss me either with ay or no
44099 KING EDWARD Ay if thou wilt say ay to my request
44100 No if thou dost say no to my demand
44101 LADY GREY Then no my lord My suit is at an end
44102 GLOUCESTER The widow likes him not she knits her brows
44103 CLARENCE He is the bluntest wooer in Christendom
44104 KING EDWARD [Aside] Her looks doth argue her replete with modesty
44105 Her words doth show her wit incomparable
44106 All her perfections challenge sovereignty
44107 One way or other she is for a king
44108 And she shall be my love or else my queen
44109 Say that King Edward take thee for his queen
44110 LADY GREY 'Tis better said than done my gracious lord
44111 I am a subject fit to jest withal
44112 But far unfit to be a sovereign
44113 KING EDWARD Sweet widow by my state I swear to thee
44114 I speak no more than what my soul intends
44115 And that is to enjoy thee for my love
44116 LADY GREY And that is more than I will yield unto
44117 I know I am too mean to be your queen
44118 And yet too good to be your concubine
44119 KING EDWARD You cavil widow I did mean my queen
44120 LADY GREY 'Twill grieve your Grace my sons should call you father
44121 KING EDWARDNo more than when my daughters call thee mother
44122 Thou art a widow and thou hast some children
44123 And by God's Mother I being but a bachelor
44124 Have other some Why 'tis a happy thing
44125 To be the father unto many sons
44126 Answer no more for thou shalt be my queen
44127 GLOUCESTER The ghostly father now hath done his shrift
44128 CLARENCE When he was made a shriver 'twas for shrift
44129 KING EDWARD Brothers you muse what chat we two have had
44130 GLOUCESTER The widow likes it not for she looks very sad
44131 KING EDWARD You'd think it strange if I should marry her
44132 CLARENCE To who my lord
44133 KING EDWARD Why Clarence to myself
44134 GLOUCESTER That would be ten days wonder at the least
44135 CLARENCE That's a day longer than a wonder lasts
44136 GLOUCESTER By so much is the wonder in extremes
44137 KING EDWARD Well jest on brothers I can tell you both
44138 Her suit is granted for her husband's lands
44139 Enter a NOBLEMAN
44140 NOBLEMAN My gracious lord Henry your foe is taken
44141 And brought your prisoner to your palace gate
44142 KING EDWARD See that he be convey'd unto the Tower
44143 And go we brothers to the man that took him
44144 To question of his apprehension
44145 Widow go you along Lords use her honourably
44146 Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER
44147 GLOUCESTER Ay Edward will use women honourably
44148 Would he were wasted marrow bones and all
44149 That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring
44150 To cross me from the golden time I look for
44151 And yet between my soul's desire and me
44152 The lustful Edward's title buried
44153 Is Clarence Henry and his son young Edward
44154 And all the unlook'd for issue of their bodies
44155 To take their rooms ere I can place myself
44156 A cold premeditation for my purpose
44157 Why then I do but dream on sovereignty
44158 Like one that stands upon a promontory
44159 And spies a faroff shore where he would tread
44160 Wishing his foot were equal with his eye
44161 And chides the sea that sunders him from thence
44162 Saying he'll lade it dry to have his way
44163 So do I wish the crown being so far off
44164 And so I chide the means that keeps me from it
44165 And so I say I'll cut the causes off
44166 Flattering me with impossibilities
44167 My eye's too quick my heart o'erweens too much
44168 Unless my hand and strength could equal them
44169 Well say there is no kingdom then for Richard
44170 What other pleasure can the world afford
44171 I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap
44172 And deck my body in gay ornaments
44173 And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks
44174 O miserable thought and more unlikely
44175 Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns
44176 Why love forswore me in my mother's womb
44177 And for I should not deal in her soft laws
44178 She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe
44179 To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub
44180 To make an envious mountain on my back
44181 Where sits deformity to mock my body
44182 To shape my legs of an unequal size
44183 To disproportion me in every part
44184 Like to a chaos or an unlick'd bearwhelp
44185 That carries no impression like the dam
44186 And am I then a man to be belov'd
44187 O monstrous fault to harbour such a thought
44188 Then since this earth affords no joy to me
44189 But to command to check to o'erbear such
44190 As are of better person than myself
44191 I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown
44192 And whiles I live t account this world but hell
44193 Until my misshap'd trunk that bear this head
44194 Be round impaled with a glorious crown
44195 And yet I know not how to get the crown
44196 For many lives stand between me and home
44197 And I like one lost in a thorny wood
44198 That rents the thorns and is rent with the thorns
44199 Seeking a way and straying from the way
44200 Not knowing how to find the open air
44201 But toiling desperately to find it out
44202 Torment myself to catch the English crown
44203 And from that torment I will free myself
44204 Or hew my way out with a bloody axe
44205 Why I can smile and murder whiles I smile
44206 And cry 'Content to that which grieves my heart
44207 And wet my cheeks with artificial tears
44208 And frame my face to all occasions
44209 I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall
44210 I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk
44211 I'll play the orator as well as Nestor
44212 Deceive more slily than Ulysses could
44213 And like a Sinon take another Troy
44214 I can add colours to the chameleon
44215 Change shapes with Protheus for advantages
44216 And set the murderous Machiavel to school
44217 Can I do this and cannot get a crown
44218 Tut were it farther off I'll pluck it down Exit
44219 SCENE III
44220 France The KING'S palace
44221 Flourish Enter LEWIS the French King his sister BONA
44222 his Admiral call'd BOURBON PRINCE EDWARD QUEEN MARGARET
44223 and the EARL of OXFORD LEWIS sits and riseth up again
44224 LEWIS Fair Queen of England worthy Margaret
44225 Sit down with us It ill befits thy state
44226 And birth that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit
44227 QUEEN MARGARET No mighty King of France Now Margaret
44228 Must strike her sail and learn a while to serve
44229 Where kings command I was I must confess
44230 Great Albion's Queen in former golden days
44231 But now mischance hath trod my title down
44232 And with dishonour laid me on the ground
44233 Where I must take like seat unto my fortune
44234 And to my humble seat conform myself
44235 LEWIS Why say fair Queen whence springs this deep despair
44236 QUEEN MARGARET From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
44237 And stops my tongue while heart is drown'd in cares
44238 LEWIS Whate'er it be be thou still like thyself
44239 And sit thee by our side [Seats her by him] Yield not thy neck
44240 To fortune's yoke but let thy dauntless mind
44241 Still ride in triumph over all mischance
44242 Be plain Queen Margaret and tell thy grief
44243 It shall be eas'd if France can yield relief
44244 QUEEN MARGARET Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts
44245 And give my tonguetied sorrows leave to speak
44246 Now therefore be it known to noble Lewis
44247 That Henry sole possessor of my love
44248 Is of a king become a banish'd man
44249 And forc'd to live in Scotland a forlorn
44250 While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York
44251 Usurps the regal title and the seat
44252 Of England's trueanointed lawful King
44253 This is the cause that I poor Margaret
44254 With this my son Prince Edward Henry's heir
44255 Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid
44256 And if thou fail us all our hope is done
44257 Scotland hath will to help but cannot help
44258 Our people and our peers are both misled
44259 Our treasure seiz'd our soldiers put to flight
44260 And as thou seest ourselves in heavy plight
44261 LEWIS Renowned Queen with patience calm the storm
44262 While we bethink a means to break it off
44263 QUEEN MARGARET The more we stay the stronger grows our foe
44264 LEWIS The more I stay the more I'll succour thee
44265 QUEEN MARGARET O but impatience waiteth on true sorrow
44266 And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow
44267 Enter WARWICK
44268 LEWIS What's he approacheth boldly to our presence
44269 QUEEN MARGARET Our Earl of Warwick Edward's greatest friend
44270 LEWIS Welcome brave Warwick What brings thee to France
44271 [He descends She ariseth]
44272 QUEEN MARGARET Ay now begins a second storm to rise
44273 For this is he that moves both wind and tide
44274 WARWICK From worthy Edward King of Albion
44275 My lord and sovereign and thy vowed friend
44276 I come in kindness and unfeigned love
44277 First to do greetings to thy royal person
44278 And then to crave a league of amity
44279 And lastly to confirm that amity
44280 With nuptial knot if thou vouchsafe to grant
44281 That virtuous Lady Bona thy fair sister
44282 To England's King in lawful marriage
44283 QUEEN MARGARET [Aside] If that go forward Henry's hope is done
44284 WARWICK [To BONA] And gracious madam in our king's behalf
44285 I am commanded with your leave and favour
44286 Humbly to kiss your hand and with my tongue
44287 To tell the passion of my sovereign's heart
44288 Where fame late ent'ring at his heedful ears
44289 Hath plac'd thy beauty's image and thy virtue
44290 QUEEN MARGARET King Lewis and Lady Bona hear me speak
44291 Before you answer Warwick His demand
44292 Springs not from Edward's wellmeant honest love
44293 But from deceit bred by necessity
44294 For how can tyrants safely govern home
44295 Unless abroad they purchase great alliance
44296 To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice
44297 That Henry liveth still but were he dead
44298 Yet here Prince Edward stands King Henry's son
44299 Look therefore Lewis that by this league and marriage
44300 Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour
44301 For though usurpers sway the rule a while
44302 Yet heav'ns are just and time suppresseth wrongs
44303 WARWICK Injurious Margaret
44304 PRINCE OF WALES And why not Queen
44305 WARWICK Because thy father Henry did usurp
44306 And thou no more art prince than she is queen
44307 OXFORD Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt
44308 Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain
44309 And after John of Gaunt Henry the Fourth
44310 Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest
44311 And after that wise prince Henry the Fifth
44312 Who by his prowess conquered all France
44313 From these our Henry lineally descends
44314 WARWICK Oxford how haps it in this smooth discourse
44315 You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost
44316 All that which Henry the Fifth had gotten
44317 Methinks these peers of France should smile at that
44318 But for the rest you tell a pedigree
44319 Of threescore and two years a silly time
44320 To make prescription for a kingdom's worth
44321 OXFORD Why Warwick canst thou speak against thy liege
44322 Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years
44323 And not betray thy treason with a blush
44324 WARWICK Can Oxford that did ever fence the right
44325 Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree
44326 For shame Leave Henry and call Edward king
44327 OXFORD Call him my king by whose injurious doom
44328 My elder brother the Lord Aubrey Vere
44329 Was done to death and more than so my father
44330 Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years
44331 When nature brought him to the door of death
44332 No Warwick no while life upholds this arm
44333 This arm upholds the house of Lancaster
44334 WARWICK And I the house of York
44335 LEWIS Queen Margaret Prince Edward and Oxford
44336 Vouchsafe at our request to stand aside
44337 While I use further conference with Warwick
44338 [They stand aloof]
44339 QUEEN MARGARET Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not
44340 LEWIS Now Warwick tell me even upon thy conscience
44341 Is Edward your true king for I were loath
44342 To link with him that were not lawful chosen
44343 WARWICK Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour
44344 LEWIS But is he gracious in the people's eye
44345 WARWICK The more that Henry was unfortunate
44346 LEWIS Then further all dissembling set aside
44347 Tell me for truth the measure of his love
44348 Unto our sister Bona
44349 WARWICK Such it seems
44350 As may beseem a monarch like himself
44351 Myself have often heard him say and swear
44352 That this his love was an eternal plant
44353 Whereof the root was fix'd in virtue's ground
44354 The leaves and fruit maintain'd with beauty's sun
44355 Exempt from envy but not from disdain
44356 Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain
44357 LEWIS Now sister let us hear your firm resolve
44358 BONA Your grant or your denial shall be mine
44359 [To WARWICK] Yet I confess that often ere this day
44360 When I have heard your king's desert recounted
44361 Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire
44362 LEWIS Then Warwick thus our sister shall be Edward's
44363 And now forthwith shall articles be drawn
44364 Touching the jointure that your king must make
44365 Which with her dowry shall be counterpois'd
44366 Draw near Queen Margaret and be a witness
44367 That Bona shall be wife to the English king
44368 PRINCE OF WALES To Edward but not to the English king
44369 QUEEN MARGARET Deceitful Warwick it was thy device
44370 By this alliance to make void my suit
44371 Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend
44372 LEWIS And still is friend to him and Margaret
44373 But if your title to the crown be weak
44374 As may appear by Edward's good success
44375 Then 'tis but reason that I be releas'd
44376 From giving aid which late I promised
44377 Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand
44378 That your estate requires and mine can yield
44379 WARWICK Henry now lives in Scotland at his case
44380 Where having nothing nothing can he lose
44381 And as for you yourself our quondam queen
44382 You have a father able to maintain you
44383 And better 'twere you troubled him than France
44384 QUEEN MARGARET Peace impudent and shameless Warwick
44385 Proud setter up and puller down of kings
44386 I will not hence till with my talk and tears
44387 Both full of truth I make King Lewis behold
44388 Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love
44389 For both of you are birds of selfsame feather
44390 [POST blowing a horn within]
44391 LEWIS Warwick this is some post to us or thee
44392 Enter the POST
44393 POST My lord ambassador these letters are for you
44394 Sent from your brother Marquis Montague
44395 These from our King unto your Majesty
44396 And madam these for you from whom I know not
44397 [They all read their letters]
44398 OXFORD I like it well that our fair Queen and mistress
44399 Smiles at her news while Warwick frowns at his
44400 PRINCE OF WALES Nay mark how Lewis stamps as he were nettled
44401 I hope all's for the best
44402 LEWIS Warwick what are thy news And yours fair Queen
44403 QUEEN MARGARET Mine such as fill my heart with unhop'd joys
44404 WARWICK Mine full of sorrow and heart's discontent
44405 LEWIS What has your king married the Lady Grey
44406 And now to soothe your forgery and his
44407 Sends me a paper to persuade me patience
44408 Is this th alliance that he seeks with France
44409 Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner
44410 QUEEN MARGARET I told your Majesty as much before
44411 This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty
44412 WARWICK King Lewis I here protest in sight of heaven
44413 And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss
44414 That I am clear from this misdeed of Edward's
44415 No more my king for he dishonours me
44416 But most himself if he could see his shame
44417 Did I forget that by the house of York
44418 My father came untimely to his death
44419 Did I let pass th abuse done to my niece
44420 Did I impale him with the regal crown
44421 Did I put Henry from his native right
44422 And am I guerdon'd at the last with shame
44423 Shame on himself for my desert is honour
44424 And to repair my honour lost for him
44425 I here renounce him and return to Henry
44426 My noble Queen let former grudges pass
44427 And henceforth I am thy true servitor
44428 I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona
44429 And replant Henry in his former state
44430 QUEEN MARGARET Warwick these words have turn'd my hate to love
44431 And I forgive and quite forget old faults
44432 And joy that thou becom'st King Henry's friend
44433 WARWICK So much his friend ay his unfeigned friend
44434 That if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us
44435 With some few bands of chosen soldiers
44436 I'll undertake to land them on our coast
44437 And force the tyrant from his seat by war
44438 'Tis not his newmade bride shall succour him
44439 And as for Clarence as my letters tell me
44440 He's very likely now to fall from him
44441 For matching more for wanton lust than honour
44442 Or than for strength and safety of our country
44443 BONA Dear brother how shall Bona be reveng'd
44444 But by thy help to this distressed queen
44445 QUEEN MARGARET Renowned Prince how shall poor Henry live
44446 Unless thou rescue him from foul despair
44447 BONA My quarrel and this English queen's are one
44448 WARWICK And mine fair Lady Bona joins with yours
44449 LEWIS And mine with hers and thine and Margaret's
44450 Therefore at last I firmly am resolv'd
44451 You shall have aid
44452 QUEEN MARGARET Let me give humble thanks for all at once
44453 LEWIS Then England's messenger return in post
44454 And tell false Edward thy supposed king
44455 That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
44456 To revel it with him and his new bride
44457 Thou seest what's past go fear thy king withal
44458 BONA Tell him in hope he'll prove a widower shortly
44459 I'll wear the willowgarland for his sake
44460 QUEEN MARGARET Tell him my mourning weeds are laid aside
44461 And I am ready to put armour on
44462 WARWICK Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong
44463 And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long
44464 There's thy reward be gone Exit POST
44465 LEWIS But Warwick
44466 Thou and Oxford with five thousand men
44467 Shall cross the seas and bid false Edward battle
44468 And as occasion serves this noble Queen
44469 And Prince shall follow with a fresh supply
44470 Yet ere thou go but answer me one doubt
44471 What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty
44472 WARWICK This shall assure my constant loyalty
44473 That if our Queen and this young Prince agree
44474 I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy
44475 To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands
44476 QUEEN MARGARET Yes I agree and thank you for your motion
44477 Son Edward she is fair and virtuous
44478 Therefore delay not give thy hand to Warwick
44479 And with thy hand thy faith irrevocable
44480 That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine
44481 PRINCE OF WALES Yes I accept her for she well deserves it
44482 And here to pledge my vow I give my hand
44483 [He gives his hand to WARWICK]
44484 LEWIS stay we now These soldiers shall be levied
44485 And thou Lord Bourbon our High Admiral
44486 Shall waft them over with our royal fleet
44487 I long till Edward fall by war's mischance
44488 For mocking marriage with a dame of France
44489 Exeunt all but WARWICK
44490 WARWICK I came from Edward as ambassador
44491 But I return his sworn and mortal foe
44492 Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me
44493 But dreadful war shall answer his demand
44494 Had he none else to make a stale but me
44495 Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow
44496 I was the chief that rais'd him to the crown
44497 And I'll be chief to bring him down again
44498 Not that I pity Henry's misery
44499 But seek revenge on Edward's mockery Exit

44501 SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 19901993 BY WORLD LIBRARY INC AND IS
44502 PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE

44504 DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES 1 ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS

44508 ACT IV SCENE I
44509 London The palace
44510 Enter GLOUCESTER CLARENCE SOMERSET and MONTAGUE
44511 GLOUCESTER Now tell me brother Clarence what think you
44512 Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey
44513 Hath not our brother made a worthy choice
44514 CLARENCE Alas you know 'tis far from hence to France
44515 How could he stay till Warwick made return
44516 SOMERSET My lords forbear this talk here comes the King
44517 Flourish Enter KING EDWARD attended LADY
44518 GREY as Queen PEMBROKE STAFFORD HASTINGS
44519 and others Four stand on one side and four on the other
44520 GLOUCESTER And his wellchosen bride
44521 CLARENCE I mind to tell him plainly what I think
44522 KING EDWARD Now brother of Clarence how like you our choice
44523 That you stand pensive as half malcontent
44524 CLARENCE As well as Lewis of France or the Earl of Warwick
44525 Which are so weak of courage and in judgment
44526 That they'll take no offence at our abuse
44527 KING EDWARD Suppose they take offence without a cause
44528 They are but Lewis and Warwick I am Edward
44529 Your King and Warwick's and must have my will
44530 GLOUCESTER And shall have your will because our King
44531 Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well
44532 KING EDWARD Yea brother Richard are you offended too
44533 GLOUCESTER Not I
44534 No God forbid that I should wish them sever'd
44535 Whom God hath join'd together ay and 'twere pity
44536 To sunder them that yoke so well together
44537 KING EDWARD Setting your scorns and your mislike aside
44538 Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey
44539 Should not become my wife and England's Queen
44540 And you too Somerset and Montague
44541 Speak freely what you think
44542 CLARENCE Then this is mine opinion that King Lewis
44543 Becomes your enemy for mocking him
44544 About the marriage of the Lady Bona
44545 GLOUCESTER And Warwick doing what you gave in charge
44546 Is now dishonoured by this new marriage
44547 KING EDWARD What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeas'd
44548 By such invention as I can devise
44549 MONTAGUE Yet to have join'd with France in such alliance
44550 Would more have strength'ned this our commonwealth
44551 'Gainst foreign storms than any homebred marriage
44552 HASTINGS Why knows not Montague that of itself
44553 England is safe if true within itself
44554 MONTAGUE But the safer when 'tis back'd with France
44555 HASTINGS 'Tis better using France than trusting France
44556 Let us be back'd with God and with the seas
44557 Which He hath giv'n for fence impregnable
44558 And with their helps only defend ourselves
44559 In them and in ourselves our safety lies
44560 CLARENCE For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
44561 To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford
44562 KING EDWARD Ay what of that it was my will and grant
44563 And for this once my will shall stand for law
44564 GLOUCESTER And yet methinks your Grace hath not done well
44565 To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales
44566 Unto the brother of your loving bride
44567 She better would have fitted me or Clarence
44568 But in your bride you bury brotherhood
44569 CLARENCE Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir
44570 Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son
44571 And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere
44572 KING EDWARD Alas poor Clarence Is it for a wife
44573 That thou art malcontent I will provide thee
44574 CLARENCE In choosing for yourself you show'd your judgment
44575 Which being shallow you shall give me leave
44576 To play the broker in mine own behalf
44577 And to that end I shortly mind to leave you
44578 KING EDWARD Leave me or tarry Edward will be King
44579 And not be tied unto his brother's will
44580 QUEEN ELIZABETH My lords before it pleas'd his Majesty
44581 To raise my state to title of a queen
44582 Do me but right and you must all confess
44583 That I was not ignoble of descent
44584 And meaner than myself have had like fortune
44585 But as this title honours me and mine
44586 So your dislikes to whom I would be pleasing
44587 Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow
44588 KING EDWARD My love forbear to fawn upon their frowns
44589 What danger or what sorrow can befall thee
44590 So long as Edward is thy constant friend
44591 And their true sovereign whom they must obey
44592 Nay whom they shall obey and love thee too
44593 Unless they seek for hatred at my hands
44594 Which if they do yet will I keep thee safe
44595 And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath
44596 GLOUCESTER [Aside] I hear yet say not much but think the more
44597 Enter a POST
44598 KING EDWARD Now messenger what letters or what news
44599 From France
44600 MESSENGER My sovereign liege no letters and few words
44601 But such as I without your special pardon
44602 Dare not relate
44603 KING EDWARD Go to we pardon thee therefore in brief
44604 Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them
44605 What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters
44606 MESSENGER At my depart these were his very words
44607 'Go tell false Edward the supposed king
44608 That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
44609 To revel it with him and his new bride'
44610 KING EDWARD IS Lewis so brave Belike he thinks me Henry
44611 But what said Lady Bona to my marriage
44612 MESSENGER These were her words utt'red with mild disdain
44613 'Tell him in hope he'll prove a widower shortly
44614 I'll wear the willowgarland for his sake'
44615 KING EDWARD I blame not her she could say little less
44616 She had the wrong But what said Henry's queen
44617 For I have heard that she was there in place
44618 MESSENGER 'Tell him quoth she 'my mourning weeds are done
44619 And I am ready to put armour on'
44620 KING EDWARD Belike she minds to play the Amazon
44621 But what said Warwick to these injuries
44622 MESSENGER He more incens'd against your Majesty
44623 Than all the rest discharg'd me with these words
44624 'Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong
44625 And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long'
44626 KING EDWARD Ha durst the traitor breathe out so proud words
44627 Well I will arm me being thus forewarn'd
44628 They shall have wars and pay for their presumption
44629 But say is Warwick friends with Margaret
44630 MESSENGER Ay gracious sovereign they are so link'd in friendship
44631 That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter
44632 CLARENCE Belike the elder Clarence will have the younger
44633 Now brother king farewell and sit you fast
44634 For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter
44635 That though I want a kingdom yet in marriage
44636 I may not prove inferior to yourself
44637 You that love me and Warwick follow me
44638 Exit and SOMERSET follows
44639 GLOUCESTER [Aside] Not I
44640 My thoughts aim at a further matter I
44641 Stay not for the love of Edward but the crown
44642 KING EDWARD Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick
44643 Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen
44644 And haste is needful in this desp'rate case
44645 Pembroke and Stafford you in our behalf
44646 Go levy men and make prepare for war
44647 They are already or quickly will be landed
44648 Myself in person will straight follow you
44649 Exeunt PEMBROKE and STAFFORD
44650 But ere I go Hastings and Montague
44651 Resolve my doubt You twain of all the rest
44652 Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance
44653 Tell me if you love Warwick more than me
44654 If it be so then both depart to him
44655 I rather wish you foes than hollow friends
44656 But if you mind to hold your true obedience
44657 Give me assurance with some friendly vow
44658 That I may never have you in suspect
44659 MONTAGUE So God help Montague as he proves true
44660 HASTINGS And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause
44661 KING EDWARD Now brother Richard will you stand by us
44662 GLOUCESTER Ay in despite of all that shall withstand you
44663 KING EDWARD Why so then am I sure of victory
44664 Now therefore let us hence and lose no hour
44665 Till we meet Warwick with his foreign pow'r Exeunt
44666 SCENE II
44667 A plain in Warwickshire
44668 Enter WARWICK and OXFORD with French soldiers
44669 WARWICK Trust me my lord all hitherto goes well
44670 The common people by numbers swarm to us
44671 Enter CLARENCE and SOMERSET
44672 But see where Somerset and Clarence comes
44673 Speak suddenly my lords are we all friends
44674 CLARENCE Fear not that my lord
44675 WARWICK Then gentle Clarence welcome unto Warwick
44676 And welcome Somerset I hold it cowardice
44677 To rest mistrustful where a noble heart
44678 Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love
44679 Else might I think that Clarence Edward's brother
44680 Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings
44681 But welcome sweet Clarence my daughter shall be thine
44682 And now what rests but in night's coverture
44683 Thy brother being carelessly encamp'd
44684 His soldiers lurking in the towns about
44685 And but attended by a simple guard
44686 We may surprise and take him at our pleasure
44687 Our scouts have found the adventure very easy
44688 That as Ulysses and stout Diomede
44689 With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus tents
44690 And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds
44691 So we well cover'd with the night's black mantle
44692 At unawares may beat down Edward's guard
44693 And seize himself I say not 'slaughter him'
44694 For I intend but only to surprise him
44695 You that will follow me to this attempt
44696 Applaud the name of Henry with your leader
44697 [They all cry 'Henry']
44698 Why then let's on our way in silent sort
44699 For Warwick and his friends God and Saint George Exeunt
44700 SCENE III
44701 Edward's camp near Warwick
44702 Enter three WATCHMEN to guard the KING'S tent
44703 FIRST WATCHMAN Come on my masters each man take his stand
44704 The King by this is set him down to sleep
44705 SECOND WATCHMAN What will he not to bed
44706 FIRST WATCHMAN Why no for he hath made a solemn vow
44707 Never to lie and take his natural rest
44708 Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd
44709 SECOND WATCHMAN Tomorrow then belike shall be the day
44710 If Warwick be so near as men report
44711 THIRD WATCHMAN But say I pray what nobleman is that
44712 That with the King here resteth in his tent
44713 FIRST WATCHMAN 'Tis the Lord Hastings the King's chiefest friend
44714 THIRD WATCHMAN O is it So But why commands the King
44715 That his chief followers lodge in towns about him
44716 While he himself keeps in the cold field
44717 SECOND WATCHMAN 'Tis the more honour because more dangerous
44718 THIRD WATCHMAN Ay but give me worship and quietness
44719 I like it better than dangerous honour
44720 If Warwick knew in what estate he stands
44721 'Tis to be doubted he would waken him
44722 FIRST WATCHMAN Unless our halberds did shut up his passage
44723 SECOND WATCHMAN Ay wherefore else guard we his royal tent
44724 But to defend his person from nightfoes
44725 Enter WARWICK CLARENCE OXFORD SOMERSET
44726 and French soldiers silent all
44727 WARWICK This is his tent and see where stand his guard
44728 Courage my masters Honour now or never
44729 But follow me and Edward shall be ours
44730 FIRST WATCHMAN Who goes there
44731 SECOND WATCHMAN Stay or thou diest
44732 WARWICK and the rest cry all 'Warwick Warwick and
44733 set upon the guard who fly crying 'Arm Arm WARWICK
44734 and the rest following them
44735 The drum playing and trumpet sounding reenter WARWICK
44736 and the rest bringing the KING out in his gown
44737 sitting in a chair GLOUCESTER and HASTINGS fly over the stage
44738 SOMERSET What are they that fly there
44739 WARWICK Richard and Hastings Let them go here is the Duke
44740 KING EDWARD The Duke Why Warwick when we parted
44741 Thou call'dst me King
44742 WARWICK Ay but the case is alter'd
44743 When you disgrac'd me in my embassade
44744 Then I degraded you from being King
44745 And come now to create you Duke of York
44746 Alas how should you govern any kingdom
44747 That know not how to use ambassadors
44748 Nor how to be contented with one wife
44749 Nor how to use your brothers brotherly
44750 Nor how to study for the people's welfare
44751 Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies
44752 KING EDWARD Yea brother of Clarence art thou here too
44753 Nay then I see that Edward needs must down
44754 Yet Warwick in despite of all mischance
44755 Of thee thyself and all thy complices
44756 Edward will always bear himself as King
44757 Though fortune's malice overthrow my state
44758 My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel
44759 WARWICK Then for his mind be Edward England's king
44760 [Takes off his crown]
44761 But Henry now shall wear the English crown
44762 And be true King indeed thou but the shadow
44763 My Lord of Somerset at my request
44764 See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd
44765 Unto my brother Archbishop of York
44766 When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows
44767 I'll follow you and tell what answer
44768 Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him
44769 Now for a while farewell good Duke of York
44770 KING EDWARD What fates impose that men must needs abide
44771 It boots not to resist both wind and tide
44772 [They lead him out forcibly]
44773 OXFORD What now remains my lords for us to do
44774 But march to London with our soldiers
44775 WARWICK Ay that's the first thing that we have to do
44776 To free King Henry from imprisonment
44777 And see him seated in the regal throne Exeunt
44778 SCENE IV
44779 London The palace
44780 Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and RIVERS
44781 RIVERS Madam what makes you in this sudden change
44782 QUEEN ELIZABETH Why brother Rivers are you yet to learn
44783 What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward
44784 RIVERS What loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick
44785 QUEEN ELIZABETH No but the loss of his own royal person
44786 RIVERS Then is my sovereign slain
44787 QUEEN ELIZABETH Ay almost slain for he is taken prisoner
44788 Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard
44789 Or by his foe surpris'd at unawares
44790 And as I further have to understand
44791 Is new committed to the Bishop of York
44792 Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe
44793 RIVERS These news I must confess are full of grief
44794 Yet gracious madam bear it as you may
44795 Warwick may lose that now hath won the day
44796 QUEEN ELIZABETH Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay
44797 And I the rather wean me from despair
44798 For love of Edward's offspring in my womb
44799 This is it that makes me bridle passion
44800 And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross
44801 Ay ay for this I draw in many a tear
44802 And stop the rising of bloodsucking sighs
44803 Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown
44804 King Edward's fruit true heir to th English crown
44805 RIVERS But madam where is Warwick then become
44806 QUEEN ELIZABETH I am inform'd that he comes towards London
44807 To set the crown once more on Henry's head
44808 Guess thou the rest King Edward's friends must down
44809 But to prevent the tyrant's violence
44810 For trust not him that hath once broken faith
44811 I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary
44812 To save at least the heir of Edward's right
44813 There shall I rest secure from force and fraud
44814 Come therefore let us fly while we may fly
44815 If Warwick take us we are sure to die Exeunt
44816 SCENE V
44817 A park near Middleham Castle in Yorkshire
44818 Enter GLOUCESTER LORD HASTINGS SIR WILLIAM STANLEY and others
44819 GLOUCESTER Now my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley
44820 Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither
44821 Into this chiefest thicket of the park
44822 Thus stands the case you know our King my brother
44823 Is prisoner to the Bishop here at whose hands
44824 He hath good usage and great liberty
44825 And often but attended with weak guard
44826 Comes hunting this way to disport himself
44827 I have advertis'd him by secret means
44828 That if about this hour he make this way
44829 Under the colour of his usual game
44830 He shall here find his friends with horse and men
44831 To set him free from his captivity
44832 Enter KING EDWARD and a HUNTSMAN with him
44833 HUNTSMAN This way my lord for this way lies the game
44834 KING EDWARD Nay this way man See where the huntsmen stand
44835 Now brother of Gloucester Lord Hastings and the rest
44836 Stand you thus close to steal the Bishop's deer
44837 GLOUCESTER Brother the time and case requireth haste
44838 Your horse stands ready at the park corner
44839 KING EDWARD But whither shall we then
44840 HASTINGS To Lynn my lord and shipt from thence to Flanders
44841 GLOUCESTER Well guess'd believe me for that was my meaning
44842 KING EDWARD Stanley I will requite thy forwardness
44843 GLOUCESTER But wherefore stay we 'Tis no time to talk
44844 KING EDWARD Huntsman what say'st thou Wilt thou go along
44845 HUNTSMAN Better do so than tarry and be hang'd
44846 GLOUCESTER Come then away let's ha no more ado
44847 KING EDWARD Bishop farewell Shield thee from Warwick's frown
44848 And pray that I may repossess the crown Exeunt
44849 SCENE VI
44850 London The Tower
44851 Flourish Enter KING HENRY CLARENCE WARWICK SOMERSET young HENRY
44852 EARL OF RICHMOND OXFORD MONTAGUE LIEUTENANT OF THE TOWER and attendants
44853 KING HENRY Master Lieutenant now that God and friends
44854 Have shaken Edward from the regal seat
44855 And turn'd my captive state to liberty
44856 My fear to hope my sorrows unto joys
44857 At our enlargement what are thy due fees
44858 LIEUTENANT Subjects may challenge nothing of their sov'reigns
44859 But if an humble prayer may prevail
44860 I then crave pardon of your Majesty
44861 KING HENRY For what Lieutenant For well using me
44862 Nay be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness
44863 For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure
44864 Ay such a pleasure as incaged birds
44865 Conceive when after many moody thoughts
44866 At last by notes of household harmony
44867 They quite forget their loss of liberty
44868 But Warwick after God thou set'st me free
44869 And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee
44870 He was the author thou the instrument
44871 Therefore that I may conquer fortune's spite
44872 By living low where fortune cannot hurt me
44873 And that the people of this blessed land
44874 May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars
44875 Warwick although my head still wear the crown
44876 I here resign my government to thee
44877 For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds
44878 WARWICK Your Grace hath still been fam'd for virtuous
44879 And now may seem as wise as virtuous
44880 By spying and avoiding fortune's malice
44881 For few men rightly temper with the stars
44882 Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace
44883 For choosing me when Clarence is in place
44884 CLARENCE No Warwick thou art worthy of the sway
44885 To whom the heav'ns in thy nativity
44886 Adjudg'd an olive branch and laurel crown
44887 As likely to be blest in peace and war
44888 And therefore I yield thee my free consent
44889 WARWICK And I choose Clarence only for Protector
44890 KING HENRY Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands
44891 Now join your hands and with your hands your hearts
44892 That no dissension hinder government
44893 I make you both Protectors of this land
44894 While I myself will lead a private life
44895 And in devotion spend my latter days
44896 To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise
44897 WARWICK What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will
44898 CLARENCE That he consents if Warwick yield consent
44899 For on thy fortune I repose myself
44900 WARWICK Why then though loath yet must I be content
44901 We'll yoke together like a double shadow
44902 To Henry's body and supply his place
44903 I mean in bearing weight of government
44904 While he enjoys the honour and his ease
44905 And Clarence now then it is more than needful
44906 Forthwith that Edward be pronounc'd a traitor
44907 And all his lands and goods confiscated
44908 CLARENCE What else And that succession be determin'd
44909 WARWICK Ay therein Clarence shall not want his part
44910 KING HENRY But with the first of all your chief affairs
44911 Let me entreat for I command no more
44912 That Margaret your Queen and my son Edward
44913 Be sent for to return from France with speed
44914 For till I see them here by doubtful fear
44915 My joy of liberty is half eclips'd
44916 CLARENCE It shall be done my sovereign with all speed
44917 KING HENRY My Lord of Somerset what youth is that
44918 Of whom you seem to have so tender care
44919 SOMERSET My liege it is young Henry Earl of Richmond
44920 KING HENRY Come hither England's hope
44921 [Lays his hand on his head]
44922 If secret powers
44923 Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts
44924 This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss
44925 His looks are full of peaceful majesty
44926 His head by nature fram'd to wear a crown
44927 His hand to wield a sceptre and himself
44928 Likely in time to bless a regal throne
44929 Make much of him my lords for this is he
44930 Must help you more than you are hurt by me
44931 Enter a POST
44932 WARWICK What news my friend
44933 POST That Edward is escaped from your brother
44934 And fled as he hears since to Burgundy
44935 WARWICK Unsavoury news But how made he escape
44936 POST He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester
44937 And the Lord Hastings who attended him
44938 In secret ambush on the forest side
44939 And from the Bishop's huntsmen rescu'd him
44940 For hunting was his daily exercise
44941 WARWICK My brother was too careless of his charge
44942 But let us hence my sovereign to provide
44943 A salve for any sore that may betide
44944 Exeunt all but SOMERSET RICHMOND and OXFORD
44945 SOMERSET My lord I like not of this flight of Edward's
44946 For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help
44947 And we shall have more wars befor't be long
44948 As Henry's late presaging prophecy
44949 Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond
44950 So doth my heart misgive me in these conflicts
44951 What may befall him to his harm and ours
44952 Therefore Lord Oxford to prevent the worst
44953 Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany
44954 Till storms be past of civil enmity
44955 OXFORD Ay for if Edward repossess the crown
44956 'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down
44957 SOMERSET It shall be so he shall to Brittany
44958 Come therefore let's about it speedily Exeunt
44959 SCENE VII
44960 Before York
44961 Flourish Enter KING EDWARD GLOUCESTER HASTINGS and soldiers
44962 KING EDWARD Now brother Richard Lord Hastings and the rest
44963 Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends
44964 And says that once more I shall interchange
44965 My waned state for Henry's regal crown
44966 Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas
44967 And brought desired help from Burgundy
44968 What then remains we being thus arriv'd
44969 From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York
44970 But that we enter as into our dukedom
44971 GLOUCESTER The gates made fast Brother I like not this
44972 For many men that stumble at the threshold
44973 Are well foretold that danger lurks within
44974 KING EDWARD Tush man abodements must not now affright us
44975 By fair or foul means we must enter in
44976 For hither will our friends repair to us
44977 HASTINGS My liege I'll knock once more to summon them
44978 Enter on the walls the MAYOR OF YORK and
44979 his BRETHREN
44980 MAYOR My lords we were forewarned of your coming
44981 And shut the gates for safety of ourselves
44982 For now we owe allegiance unto Henry
44983 KING EDWARD But Master Mayor if Henry be your King
44984 Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York
44985 MAYOR True my good lord I know you for no less
44986 KING EDWARD Why and I challenge nothing but my dukedom
44987 As being well content with that alone
44988 GLOUCESTER [Aside] But when the fox hath once got in his nose
44989 He'll soon find means to make the body follow
44990 HASTINGS Why Master Mayor why stand you in a doubt
44991 Open the gates we are King Henry's friends
44992 MAYOR Ay say you so The gates shall then be open'd
44993 [He descends]
44994 GLOUCESTER A wise stout captain and soon persuaded
44995 HASTINGS The good old man would fain that all were well
44996 So 'twere not long of him but being ent'red
44997 I doubt not I but we shall soon persuade
44998 Both him and all his brothers unto reason
44999 Enter below the MAYOR and two ALDERMEN
45000 KING EDWARD So Master Mayor These gates must not be shut
45001 But in the night or in the time of war
45002 What fear not man but yield me up the keys
45003 [Takes his keys]
45004 For Edward will defend the town and thee
45005 And all those friends that deign to follow me
45006 March Enter MONTGOMERY with drum and soldiers
45007 GLOUCESTER Brother this is Sir John Montgomery
45008 Our trusty friend unless I be deceiv'd
45009 KING EDWARD Welcome Sir john But why come you in arms
45010 MONTGOMERY To help King Edward in his time of storm
45011 As every loyal subject ought to do
45012 KING EDWARD Thanks good Montgomery but we now forget
45013 Our title to the crown and only claim
45014 Our dukedom till God please to send the rest
45015 MONTGOMERY Then fare you well for I will hence again
45016 I came to serve a king and not a duke
45017 Drummer strike up and let us march away
45018 [The drum begins to march]
45019 KING EDWARD Nay stay Sir John a while and we'll debate
45020 By what safe means the crown may be recover'd
45021 MONTGOMERY What talk you of debating In few words
45022 If you'll not here proclaim yourself our King
45023 I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone
45024 To keep them back that come to succour you
45025 Why shall we fight if you pretend no title
45026 GLOUCESTER Why brother wherefore stand you on nice points
45027 KING EDWARD When we grow stronger then we'll make our claim
45028 Till then 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning
45029 HASTINGS Away with scrupulous wit Now arms must rule
45030 GLOUCESTER And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns
45031 Brother we will proclaim you out of hand
45032 The bruit thereof will bring you many friends
45033 KING EDWARD Then be it as you will for 'tis my right
45034 And Henry but usurps the diadem
45035 MONTGOMERY Ay now my sovereign speaketh like himself
45036 And now will I be Edward's champion
45037 HASTINGS Sound trumpet Edward shall be here proclaim'd
45038 Come fellow soldier make thou proclamation
45039 [Gives him a paper Flourish]
45040 SOLDIER [Reads] 'Edward the Fourth by the grace of God
45041 King of England and France and Lord of Ireland &c'
45042 MONTGOMERY And whoso'er gainsays King Edward's right
45043 By this I challenge him to single fight
45044 [Throws down gauntlet]
45045 ALL Long live Edward the Fourth
45046 KING EDWARD Thanks brave Montgomery and thanks unto you all
45047 If fortune serve me I'll requite this kindness
45048 Now for this night let's harbour here in York
45049 And when the morning sun shall raise his car
45050 Above the border of this horizon
45051 We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates
45052 For well I wot that Henry is no soldier
45053 Ah froward Clarence how evil it beseems the
45054 To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother
45055 Yet as we may we'll meet both thee and Warwick
45056 Come on brave soldiers doubt not of the day
45057 And that once gotten doubt not of large pay Exeunt
45058 SCENE VIII
45059 London The palace
45060 Flourish Enter KING HENRY WARWICK MONTAGUE CLARENCE OXFORD and EXETER
45061 WARWICK What counsel lords Edward from Belgia
45062 With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders
45063 Hath pass'd in safety through the narrow seas
45064 And with his troops doth march amain to London
45065 And many giddy people flock to him
45066 KING HENRY Let's levy men and beat him back again
45067 CLARENCE A little fire is quickly trodden out
45068 Which being suffer'd rivers cannot quench
45069 WARWICK In Warwickshire I have truehearted friends
45070 Not mutinous in peace yet bold in war
45071 Those will I muster up and thou son Clarence
45072 Shalt stir up in Suffolk Norfolk and in Kent
45073 The knights and gentlemen to come with thee
45074 Thou brother Montague in Buckingham
45075 Northampton and in Leicestershire shalt find
45076 Men well inclin'd to hear what thou command'st
45077 And thou brave Oxford wondrous well belov'd
45078 In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends
45079 My sovereign with the loving citizens
45080 Like to his island girt in with the ocean
45081 Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs
45082 Shall rest in London till we come to him
45083 Fair lords take leave and stand not to reply
45084 Farewell my sovereign
45085 KING HENRY Farewell my Hector and my Troy's true hope
45086 CLARENCE In sign of truth I kiss your Highness hand
45087 KING HENRY Wellminded Clarence be thou fortunate
45088 MONTAGUE Comfort my lord and so I take my leave
45089 OXFORD [Kissing the KING'S band] And thus I seal my truth and bid
45090 adieu
45091 KING HENRY Sweet Oxford and my loving Montague
45092 And all at once once more a happy farewell
45093 WARWICK Farewell sweet lords let's meet at Coventry
45094 Exeunt all but the KING and EXETER
45095 KING HENRY Here at the palace will I rest a while
45096 Cousin of Exeter what thinks your lordship
45097 Methinks the power that Edward hath in field
45098 Should not be able to encounter mine
45099 EXETER The doubt is that he will seduce the rest
45100 KING HENRY That's not my fear my meed hath got me fame
45101 I have not stopp'd mine ears to their demands
45102 Nor posted off their suits with slow delays
45103 My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds
45104 My mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs
45105 My mercy dried their waterflowing tears
45106 I have not been desirous of their wealth
45107 Nor much oppress'd them with great subsidies
45108 Nor forward of revenge though they much err'd
45109 Then why should they love Edward more than me
45110 No Exeter these graces challenge grace
45111 And when the lion fawns upon the lamb
45112 The lamb will never cease to follow him
45113 [Shout within 'A Lancaster A Lancaster']
45114 EXETER Hark hark my lord What shouts are these
45115 Enter KING EDWARD GLOUCESTER and soldiers
45116 KING EDWARD Seize on the shamefac'd Henry bear him hence
45117 And once again proclaim us King of England
45118 You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow
45119 Now stops thy spring my sea shall suck them dry
45120 And swell so much the higher by their ebb
45121 Hence with him to the Tower let him not speak
45122 Exeunt some with KING HENRY
45123 And lords towards Coventry bend we our course
45124 Where peremptory Warwick now remains
45125 The sun shines hot and if we use delay
45126 Cold biting winter mars our hop'dfor hay
45127 GLOUCESTER Away betimes before his forces join
45128 And take the greatgrown traitor unawares
45129 Brave warriors march amain towards Coventry Exeunt
