54925 Scene Britain
54926 ACT I Scene I
54927 [King Lear's Palace]
54928 Enter Kent Gloucester and Edmund [Kent and Glouceste converse
54929 Edmund stands back]
54930 Kent I thought the King had more affected the Duke of Albany than
54931 Cornwall
54932 Glou It did always seem so to us but now in the division of the
54933 kingdom it appears not which of the Dukes he values most for
54934 equalities are so weigh'd that curiosity in neither can make
54935 choice of either's moiety
54936 Kent Is not this your son my lord
54937 Glou His breeding sir hath been at my charge I have so often
54938 blush'd to acknowledge him that now I am braz'd to't
54939 Kent I cannot conceive you
54940 Glou Sir this young fellow's mother could whereupon she grew
54941 roundwomb'd and had indeed sir a son for her cradle ere she
54942 had a husband for her bed Do you smell a fault
54943 Kent I cannot wish the fault undone the issue of it being so
54944 proper
54945 Glou But I have sir a son by order of law some year elder than
54946 this who yet is no dearer in my account Though this knave came
54947 something saucily into the world before he was sent for yet was
54948 his mother fair there was good sport at his making and the
54949 whoreson must be acknowledged Do you know this noble gentleman
54950 Edmund
54951 Edm [comes forward] No my lord
54952 Glou My Lord of Kent Remember him hereafter as my honourable
54953 friend
54954 Edm My services to your lordship
54955 Kent I must love you and sue to know you better
54956 Edm Sir I shall study deserving
54957 Glou He hath been out nine years and away he shall again
54958 Sound a sennet
54959 The King is coming
54960 Enter one bearing a coronet then Lear then the Dukes of
54961 Albany and Cornwall next Goneril Regan Cordelia with
54962 Followers
54963 Lear Attend the lords of France and Burgundy Gloucester
54964 Glou I shall my liege
54965 Exeunt [Gloucester and Edmund]
54966 Lear Meantime we shall express our darker purpose
54967 Give me the map there Know we have divided
54968 In three our kingdom and 'tis our fast intent
54969 To shake all cares and business from our age
54970 Conferring them on younger strengths while we
54971 Unburthen'd crawl toward death Our son of Cornwall
54972 And you our no less loving son of Albany
54973 We have this hour a constant will to publish
54974 Our daughters several dowers that future strife
54975 May be prevented now The princes France and Burgundy
54976 Great rivals in our youngest daughter's love
54977 Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn
54978 And here are to be answer'd Tell me my daughters
54979 Since now we will divest us both of rule
54980 Interest of territory cares of state
54981 Which of you shall we say doth love us most
54982 That we our largest bounty may extend
54983 Where nature doth with merit challenge Goneril
54984 Our eldestborn speak first
54985 Gon Sir I love you more than words can wield the matter
54986 Dearer than eyesight space and liberty
54987 Beyond what can be valued rich or rare
54988 No less than life with grace health beauty honour
54989 As much as child e'er lov'd or father found
54990 A love that makes breath poor and speech unable
54991 Beyond all manner of so much I love you
54992 Cor [aside] What shall Cordelia speak Love and be silent
54993 Lear Of all these bounds even from this line to this
54994 With shadowy forests and with champains rich'd
54995 With plenteous rivers and wideskirted meads
54996 We make thee lady To thine and Albany's issue
54997 Be this perpetual What says our second daughter
54998 Our dearest Regan wife to Cornwall Speak
54999 Reg Sir I am made
55000 Of the selfsame metal that my sister is
55001 And prize me at her worth In my true heart
55002 I find she names my very deed of love
55003 Only she comes too short that I profess
55004 Myself an enemy to all other joys
55005 Which the most precious square of sense possesses
55006 And find I am alone felicitate
55007 In your dear Highness love
55008 Cor [aside] Then poor Cordelia
55009 And yet not so since I am sure my love's
55010 More richer than my tongue
55011 Lear To thee and thine hereditary ever
55012 Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom
55013 No less in space validity and pleasure
55014 Than that conferr'd on Goneril Now our joy
55015 Although the last not least to whose young love
55016 The vines of France and milk of Burgundy
55017 Strive to be interest what can you say to draw
55018 A third more opulent than your sisters Speak
55019 Cor Nothing my lord
55020 Lear Nothing
55021 Cor Nothing
55022 Lear Nothing can come of nothing Speak again
55023 Cor Unhappy that I am I cannot heave
55024 My heart into my mouth I love your Majesty
55025 According to my bond no more nor less
55026 Lear How how Cordelia Mend your speech a little
55027 Lest it may mar your fortunes
55028 Cor Good my lord
55029 You have begot me bred me lov'd me I
55030 Return those duties back as are right fit
55031 Obey you love you and most honour you
55032 Why have my sisters husbands if they say
55033 They love you all Haply when I shall wed
55034 That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry
55035 Half my love with him half my care and duty
55036 Sure I shall never marry like my sisters
55037 To love my father all
55038 Lear But goes thy heart with this
55039 Cor Ay good my lord
55040 Lear So young and so untender
55041 Cor So young my lord and true
55042 Lear Let it be so thy truth then be thy dower
55043 For by the sacred radiance of the sun
55044 The mysteries of Hecate and the night
55045 By all the operation of the orbs
55046 From whom we do exist and cease to be
55047 Here I disclaim all my paternal care
55048 Propinquity and property of blood
55049 And as a stranger to my heart and me
55050 Hold thee from this for ever The barbarous Scythian
55051 Or he that makes his generation messes
55052 To gorge his appetite shall to my bosom
55053 Be as well neighbour'd pitied and reliev'd
55054 As thou my sometime daughter
55055 Kent Good my liege
55056 Lear Peace Kent
55057 Come not between the dragon and his wrath
55058 I lov'd her most and thought to set my rest
55059 On her kind nursery Hence and avoid my sight
55060 So be my grave my peace as here I give
55061 Her father's heart from her Call France Who stirs
55062 Call Burgundy Cornwall and Albany
55063 With my two daughters dowers digest this third
55064 Let pride which she calls plainness marry her
55065 I do invest you jointly in my power
55066 Preeminence and all the large effects
55067 That troop with majesty Ourself by monthly course
55068 With reservation of an hundred knights
55069 By you to be sustain'd shall our abode
55070 Make with you by due turns Only we still retain
55071 The name and all th additions to a king The sway
55072 Revenue execution of the rest
55073 Beloved sons be yours which to confirm
55074 This coronet part betwixt you
55075 Kent Royal Lear
55076 Whom I have ever honour'd as my king
55077 Lov'd as my father as my master follow'd
55078 As my great patron thought on in my prayers
55079 Lear The bow is bent and drawn make from the shaft
55080 Kent Let it fall rather though the fork invade
55081 The region of my heart Be Kent unmannerly
55082 When Lear is mad What wouldst thou do old man
55083 Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak
55084 When power to flattery bows To plainness honour's bound
55085 When majesty falls to folly Reverse thy doom
55086 And in thy best consideration check
55087 This hideous rashness Answer my life my judgment
55088 Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least
55089 Nor are those emptyhearted whose low sound
55090 Reverbs no hollowness
55091 Lear Kent on thy life no more
55092 Kent My life I never held but as a pawn
55093 To wage against thine enemies nor fear to lose it
55094 Thy safety being the motive
55095 Lear Out of my sight
55096 Kent See better Lear and let me still remain
55097 The true blank of thine eye
55098 Lear Now by Apollo
55099 Kent Now by Apollo King
55100 Thou swear'st thy gods in vain
55101 Lear O vassal miscreant
55102 [Lays his hand on his sword]
55103 Alb Corn Dear sir forbear
55104 Kent Do
55105 Kill thy physician and the fee bestow
55106 Upon the foul disease Revoke thy gift
55107 Or whilst I can vent clamour from my throat
55108 I'll tell thee thou dost evil
55109 Lear Hear me recreant
55110 On thine allegiance hear me
55111 Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow
55112 Which we durst never yet and with strain'd pride
55113 To come between our sentence and our power
55114 Which nor our nature nor our place can bear
55115 Our potency made good take thy reward
55116 Five days we do allot thee for provision
55117 To shield thee from diseases of the world
55118 And on the sixth to turn thy hated back
55119 Upon our kingdom If on the tenth day following
55120 Thy banish'd trunk be found in our dominions
55121 The moment is thy death Away By Jupiter
55122 This shall not be revok'd
55123 Kent Fare thee well King Since thus thou wilt appear
55124 Freedom lives hence and banishment is here
55125 [To Cordelia] The gods to their dear shelter take thee maid
55126 That justly think'st and hast most rightly said
55127 [To Regan and Goneril] And your large speeches may your deeds
55128 approve
55129 That good effects may spring from words of love
55130 Thus Kent O princes bids you all adieu
55131 He'll shape his old course in a country new
55132 Exit
55133 Flourish Enter Gloucester with France and Burgundy Attendants
55134 Glou Here's France and Burgundy my noble lord
55135 Lear My Lord of Burgundy
55136 We first address toward you who with this king
55137 Hath rivall'd for our daughter What in the least
55138 Will you require in present dower with her
55139 Or cease your quest of love
55140 Bur Most royal Majesty
55141 I crave no more than hath your Highness offer'd
55142 Nor will you tender less
55143 Lear Right noble Burgundy
55144 When she was dear to us we did hold her so
55145 But now her price is fall'n Sir there she stands
55146 If aught within that little seeming substance
55147 Or all of it with our displeasure piec'd
55148 And nothing more may fitly like your Grace
55149 She's there and she is yours
55150 Bur I know no answer
55151 Lear Will you with those infirmities she owes
55152 Unfriended new adopted to our hate
55153 Dow'r'd with our curse and stranger'd with our oath
55154 Take her or leave her
55155 Bur Pardon me royal sir
55156 Election makes not up on such conditions
55157 Lear Then leave her sir for by the pow'r that made me
55158 I tell you all her wealth [To France] For you great King
55159 I would not from your love make such a stray
55160 To match you where I hate therefore beseech you
55161 T avert your liking a more worthier way
55162 Than on a wretch whom nature is asham'd
55163 Almost t acknowledge hers
55164 France This is most strange
55165 That she that even but now was your best object
55166 The argument of your praise balm of your age
55167 Most best most dearest should in this trice of time
55168 Commit a thing so monstrous to dismantle
55169 So many folds of favour Sure her offence
55170 Must be of such unnatural degree
55171 That monsters it or your forevouch'd affection
55172 Fall'n into taint which to believe of her
55173 Must be a faith that reason without miracle
55174 Should never plant in me
55175 Cor I yet beseech your Majesty
55176 If for I want that glib and oily art
55177 To speak and purpose not since what I well intend
55178 I'll do't before I speak that you make known
55179 It is no vicious blot murther or foulness
55180 No unchaste action or dishonoured step
55181 That hath depriv'd me of your grace and favour
55182 But even for want of that for which I am richer
55183 A stillsoliciting eye and such a tongue
55184 As I am glad I have not though not to have it
55185 Hath lost me in your liking
55186 Lear Better thou
55187 Hadst not been born than not t have pleas'd me better
55188 France Is it but this a tardiness in nature
55189 Which often leaves the history unspoke
55190 That it intends to do My Lord of Burgundy
55191 What say you to the lady Love's not love
55192 When it is mingled with regards that stands
55193 Aloof from th entire point Will you have her
55194 She is herself a dowry
55195 Bur Royal Lear
55196 Give but that portion which yourself propos'd
55197 And here I take Cordelia by the hand
55198 Duchess of Burgundy
55199 Lear Nothing I have sworn I am firm
55200 Bur I am sorry then you have so lost a father
55201 That you must lose a husband
55202 Cor Peace be with Burgundy
55203 Since that respects of fortune are his love
55204 I shall not be his wife
55205 France Fairest Cordelia that art most rich being poor
55206 Most choice forsaken and most lov'd despis'd
55207 Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon
55208 Be it lawful I take up what's cast away
55209 Gods gods 'tis strange that from their cold'st neglect
55210 My love should kindle to inflam'd respect
55211 Thy dow'rless daughter King thrown to my chance
55212 Is queen of us of ours and our fair France
55213 Not all the dukes in wat'rish Burgundy
55214 Can buy this unpriz'd precious maid of me
55215 Bid them farewell Cordelia though unkind
55216 Thou losest here a better where to find
55217 Lear Thou hast her France let her be thine for we
55218 Have no such daughter nor shall ever see
55219 That face of hers again Therefore be gone
55220 Without our grace our love our benison
55221 Come noble Burgundy
55222 Flourish Exeunt Lear Burgundy [Cornwall Albany
55223 Gloucester and Attendants]
55224 France Bid farewell to your sisters
55225 Cor The jewels of our father with wash'd eyes
55226 Cordelia leaves you I know you what you are
55227 And like a sister am most loath to call
55228 Your faults as they are nam'd Use well our father
55229 To your professed bosoms I commit him
55230 But yet alas stood I within his grace
55231 I would prefer him to a better place
55232 So farewell to you both
55233 Gon Prescribe not us our duties
55234 Reg Let your study
55235 Be to content your lord who hath receiv'd you
55236 At fortune's alms You have obedience scanted
55237 And well are worth the want that you have wanted
55238 Cor Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides
55239 Who cover faults at last shame them derides
55240 Well may you prosper
55241 France Come my fair Cordelia
55242 Exeunt France and Cordelia
55243 Gon Sister it is not little I have to say of what most nearly
55244 appertains to us both I think our father will hence tonight
55245 Reg That's most certain and with you next month with us
55246 Gon You see how full of changes his age is The observation we
55247 have made of it hath not been little He always lov'd our
55248 sister most and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her
55249 off appears too grossly
55250 Reg 'Tis the infirmity of his age yet he hath ever but slenderly
55251 known himself
55252 Gon The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash then
55253 must we look to receive from his age not alone the
55254 imperfections of longingraffed condition but therewithal
55255 the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with
55256 them
55257 Reg Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this
55258 of Kent's banishment
55259 Gon There is further compliment of leavetaking between France and
55260 him Pray you let's hit together If our father carry authority
55261 with such dispositions as he bears this last surrender of his
55262 will but offend us
55263 Reg We shall further think on't
55264 Gon We must do something and i th heat
55265 Exeunt
55266 Scene II
55267 The Earl of Gloucester's Castle
55268 Enter [Edmund the] Bastard solus [with a letter]
55269 Edm Thou Nature art my goddess to thy law
55270 My services are bound Wherefore should I
55271 Stand in the plague of custom and permit
55272 The curiosity of nations to deprive me
55273 For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines
55274 Lag of a brother Why bastard wherefore base
55275 When my dimensions are as well compact
55276 My mind as generous and my shape as true
55277 As honest madam's issue Why brand they us
55278 With base with baseness bastardy base base
55279 Who in the lusty stealth of nature take
55280 More composition and fierce quality
55281 Than doth within a dull stale tired bed
55282 Go to th creating a whole tribe of fops
55283 Got 'tween asleep and wake Well then
55284 Legitimate Edgar I must have your land
55285 Our father's love is to the bastard Edmund
55286 As to th legitimate Fine word 'legitimate'
55287 Well my legitimate if this letter speed
55288 And my invention thrive Edmund the base
55289 Shall top th legitimate I grow I prosper
55290 Now gods stand up for bastards
55291 Enter Gloucester
55292 Glou Kent banish'd thus and France in choler parted
55293 And the King gone tonight subscrib'd his pow'r
55294 Confin'd to exhibition All this done
55295 Upon the gad Edmund how now What news
55296 Edm So please your lordship none
55297 [Puts up the letter]
55298 Glou Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter
55299 Edm I know no news my lord
55300 Glou What paper were you reading
55301 Edm Nothing my lord
55302 Glou No What needed then that terrible dispatch of it into your
55303 pocket The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide
55304 itself Let's see Come if it be nothing I shall not need
55305 spectacles
55306 Edm I beseech you sir pardon me It is a letter from my brother
55307 that I have not all o'erread and for so much as I have
55308 perus'd I find it not fit for your o'erlooking
55309 Glou Give me the letter sir
55310 Edm I shall offend either to detain or give it The contents as
55311 in part I understand them are to blame
55312 Glou Let's see let's see
55313 Edm I hope for my brother's justification he wrote this but as
55314 an essay or taste of my virtue
55315 Glou reads 'This policy and reverence of age makes the world
55316 bitter to the best of our times keeps our fortunes from us
55317 till our oldness cannot relish them I begin to find an idle
55318 and fond bondage in the oppression of aged tyranny who sways
55319 not as it hath power but as it is suffer'd Come to me that
55320 of this I may speak more If our father would sleep till I
55321 wak'd him you should enjoy half his revenue for ever and live
55322 the beloved of your brother
55323 'EDGAR'
55324 Hum Conspiracy 'Sleep till I wak'd him you should enjoy half
55325 his revenue My son Edgar Had he a hand to write this a heart
55326 and brain to breed it in When came this to you Who brought it
55327 Edm It was not brought me my lord there's the cunning of it I
55328 found it thrown in at the casement of my closet
55329 Glou You know the character to be your brother's
55330 Edm If the matter were good my lord I durst swear it were his
55331 but in respect of that I would fain think it were not
55332 Glou It is his
55333 Edm It is his hand my lord but I hope his heart is not in the
55334 contents
55335 Glou Hath he never before sounded you in this business
55336 Edm Never my lord But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit
55337 that sons at perfect age and fathers declining the father
55338 should be as ward to the son and the son manage his revenue
55339 Glou O villain villain His very opinion in the letter Abhorred
55340 villain Unnatural detested brutish villain worse than
55341 brutish Go sirrah seek him I'll apprehend him Abominable
55342 villain Where is he
55343 Edm I do not well know my lord If it shall please you to suspend
55344 your indignation against my brother till you can derive from him
55345 better testimony of his intent you should run a certain course
55346 where if you violently proceed against him mistaking his
55347 purpose it would make a great gap in your own honour and shake
55348 in pieces the heart of his obedience I dare pawn down my life
55349 for him that he hath writ this to feel my affection to your
55350 honour and to no other pretence of danger
55351 Glou Think you so
55352 Edm If your honour judge it meet I will place you where you shall
55353 hear us confer of this and by an auricular assurance have your
55354 satisfaction and that without any further delay than this very
55355 evening
55356 Glou He cannot be such a monster
55357 Edm Nor is not sure
55358 Glou To his father that so tenderly and entirely loves him
55359 Heaven and earth Edmund seek him out wind me into him I pray
55360 you frame the business after your own wisdom I would unstate
55361 myself to be in a due resolution
55362 Edm I will seek him sir presently convey the business as I
55363 shall find means and acquaint you withal
55364 Glou These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to
55365 us Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus yet
55366 nature finds itself scourg'd by the sequent effects Love cools
55367 friendship falls off brothers divide In cities mutinies in
55368 countries discord in palaces treason and the bond crack'd
55369 'twixt son and father This villain of mine comes under the
55370 prediction there's son against father the King falls from bias
55371 of nature there's father against child We have seen the best
55372 of our time Machinations hollowness treachery and all
55373 ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves Find out
55374 this villain Edmund it shall lose thee nothing do it
55375 carefully And the noble and truehearted Kent banish'd his
55376 offence honesty 'Tis strange Exit
55377 Edm This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are
55378 sick in fortune often the surfeit of our own behaviour we make
55379 guilty of our disasters the sun the moon and the stars as if
55380 we were villains on necessity fools by heavenly compulsion
55381 knaves thieves and treachers by spherical predominance
55382 drunkards liars and adulterers by an enforc'd obedience of
55383 planetary influence and all that we are evil in by a divine
55384 thrusting on An admirable evasion of whoremaster man to lay
55385 his goatish disposition to the charge of a star My father
55386 compounded with my mother under the Dragon's Tail and my
55387 nativity was under Ursa Major so that it follows I am rough and
55388 lecherous Fut I should have been that I am had the
55389 maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing
55390 Edgar
55391 Enter Edgar
55392 and pat he comes like the catastrophe of the old comedy My
55393 cue is villainous melancholy with a sigh like Tom o Bedlam
55394 O these eclipses do portend these divisions Fa sol la mi
55395 Edg How now brother Edmund What serious contemplation are you
55396 in
55397 Edm I am thinking brother of a prediction I read this other day
55398 what should follow these eclipses
55399 Edg Do you busy yourself with that
55400 Edm I promise you the effects he writes of succeed unhappily as
55401 of unnaturalness between the child and the parent death
55402 dearth dissolutions of ancient amities divisions in state
55403 menaces and maledictions against king and nobles needless
55404 diffidences banishment of friends dissipation of cohorts
55405 nuptial breaches and I know not what
55406 Edg How long have you been a sectary astronomical
55407 Edm Come come When saw you my father last
55408 Edg The night gone by
55409 Edm Spake you with him
55410 Edg Ay two hours together
55411 Edm Parted you in good terms Found you no displeasure in him by
55412 word or countenance
55413 Edg None at all
55414 Edm Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended him and at my
55415 entreaty forbear his presence until some little time hath
55416 qualified the heat of his displeasure which at this instant so
55417 rageth in him that with the mischief of your person it would
55418 scarcely allay
55419 Edg Some villain hath done me wrong
55420 Edm That's my fear I pray you have a continent forbearance till
55421 the speed of his rage goes slower and as I say retire with me
55422 to my lodging from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my
55423 lord speak Pray ye go There's my key If you do stir abroad
55424 go arm'd
55425 Edg Arm'd brother
55426 Edm Brother I advise you to the best Go arm'd I am no honest man
55427 if there be any good meaning toward you I have told you what I
55428 have seen and heard but faintly nothing like the image and
55429 horror of it Pray you away
55430 Edg Shall I hear from you anon
55431 Edm I do serve you in this business
55432 Exit Edgar
55433 A credulous father and a brother noble
55434 Whose nature is so far from doing harms
55435 That he suspects none on whose foolish honesty
55436 My practices ride easy I see the business
55437 Let me if not by birth have lands by wit
55438 All with me's meet that I can fashion fit
55439 Exit
55440 Scene III
55441 The Duke of Albany's Palace
55442 Enter Goneril and [her] Steward [Oswald]
55443 Gon Did my father strike my gentleman for chiding of his fool
55444 Osw Ay madam
55445 Gon By day and night he wrongs me Every hour
55446 He flashes into one gross crime or other
55447 That sets us all at odds I'll not endure it
55448 His knights grow riotous and himself upbraids us
55449 On every trifle When he returns from hunting
55450 I will not speak with him Say I am sick
55451 If you come slack of former services
55452 You shall do well the fault of it I'll answer
55453 [Horns within]
55454 Osw He's coming madam I hear him
55455 Gon Put on what weary negligence you please
55456 You and your fellows I'd have it come to question
55457 If he distaste it let him to our sister
55458 Whose mind and mine I know in that are one
55459 Not to be overrul'd Idle old man
55460 That still would manage those authorities
55461 That he hath given away Now by my life
55462 Old fools are babes again and must be us'd
55463 With checks as flatteries when they are seen abus'd
55464 Remember what I have said
55465 Osw Very well madam
55466 Gon And let his knights have colder looks among you
55467 What grows of it no matter Advise your fellows so
55468 I would breed from hence occasions and I shall
55469 That I may speak I'll write straight to my sister
55470 To hold my very course Prepare for dinner
55471 Exeunt
55472 Scene IV
55473 The Duke of Albany's Palace
55474 Enter Kent [disguised]
55475 Kent If but as well I other accents borrow
55476 That can my speech defuse my good intent
55477 May carry through itself to that full issue
55478 For which I raz'd my likeness Now banish'd Kent
55479 If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemn'd
55480 So may it come thy master whom thou lov'st
55481 Shall find thee full of labours
55482 Horns within Enter Lear [Knights] and Attendants
55483 Lear Let me not stay a jot for dinner go get it ready [Exit
55484 an Attendant] How now What art thou
55485 Kent A man sir
55486 Lear What dost thou profess What wouldst thou with us
55487 Kent I do profess to be no less than I seem to serve him truly
55488 that will put me in trust to love him that is honest to
55489 converse with him that is wise and says little to fear
55490 judgment to fight when I cannot choose and to eat no fish
55491 Lear What art thou
55492 Kent A very honesthearted fellow and as poor as the King
55493 Lear If thou be'st as poor for a subject as he's for a king thou
55494 art poor enough What wouldst thou
55495 Kent Service
55496 Lear Who wouldst thou serve
55497 Kent You
55498 Lear Dost thou know me fellow
55499 Kent No sir but you have that in your countenance which I would
55500 fain call master
55501 Lear What's that
55502 Kent Authority
55503 Lear What services canst thou do
55504 Kent I can keep honest counsel ride run mar a curious tale in
55505 telling it and deliver a plain message bluntly That which
55506 ordinary men are fit for I am qualified in and the best of me
55507 is diligence
55508 Lear How old art thou
55509 Kent Not so young sir to love a woman for singing nor so old to
55510 dote on her for anything I have years on my back fortyeight
55511 Lear Follow me thou shalt serve me If I like thee no worse after
55512 dinner I will not part from thee yet Dinner ho dinner
55513 Where's my knave my fool Go you and call my fool hither
55514 [Exit an attendant]
55515 Enter [Oswald the] Steward
55516 You you sirrah where's my daughter
55517 Osw So please you Exit
55518 Lear What says the fellow there Call the clotpoll back
55519 [Exit a Knight] Where's my fool ho I think the world's
55520 asleep
55521 [Enter Knight]
55522 How now Where's that mongrel
55523 Knight He says my lord your daughter is not well
55524 Lear Why came not the slave back to me when I call'd him
55525 Knight Sir he answered me in the roundest manner he would not
55526 Lear He would not
55527 Knight My lord I know not what the matter is but to my judgment
55528 your Highness is not entertain'd with that ceremonious affection
55529 as you were wont There's a great abatement of kindness appears
55530 as well in the general dependants as in the Duke himself also
55531 and your daughter
55532 Lear Ha say'st thou so
55533 Knight I beseech you pardon me my lord if I be mistaken for
55534 my duty cannot be silent when I think your Highness wrong'd
55535 Lear Thou but rememb'rest me of mine own conception I have
55536 perceived a most faint neglect of late which I have rather
55537 blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretence
55538 and purpose of unkindness I will look further into't But
55539 where's my fool I have not seen him this two days
55540 Knight Since my young lady's going into France sir the fool
55541 hath much pined away
55542 Lear No more of that I have noted it well Go you and tell my
55543 daughter I would speak with her [Exit Knight] Go you call
55544 hither my fool
55545 [Exit an Attendant]
55546 Enter [Oswald the] Steward
55547 O you sir you Come you hither sir Who am I sir
55548 Osw My lady's father
55549 Lear 'My lady's father My lord's knave You whoreson dog you
55550 slave you cur
55551 Osw I am none of these my lord I beseech your pardon
55552 Lear Do you bandy looks with me you rascal
55553 [Strikes him]
55554 Osw I'll not be strucken my lord
55555 Kent Nor tripp'd neither you base football player
55556 [Trips up his heels
55557 Lear I thank thee fellow Thou serv'st me and I'll love thee
55558 Kent Come sir arise away I'll teach you differences Away
55559 away If you will measure your lubber's length again tarry but
55560 away Go to Have you wisdom So
55561 [Pushes him out]
55562 Lear Now my friendly knave I thank thee There's earnest of thy
55563 service [Gives money]
55564 Enter Fool
55565 Fool Let me hire him too Here's my coxcomb
55566 [Offers Kent his cap]
55567 Lear How now my pretty knave How dost thou
55568 Fool Sirrah you were best take my coxcomb
55569 Kent Why fool
55570 Fool Why For taking one's part that's out of favour Nay an thou
55571 canst not smile as the wind sits thou'lt catch cold shortly
55572 There take my coxcomb Why this fellow hath banish'd two on's
55573 daughters and did the third a blessing against his will If
55574 thou follow him thou must needs wear my coxcomb How now
55575 nuncle Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters
55576 Lear Why my boy
55577 Fool If I gave them all my living I'ld keep my coxcombs myself
55578 There's mine beg another of thy daughters
55579 Lear Take heed sirrah the whip
55580 Fool Truth's a dog must to kennel he must be whipp'd out when
55581 Lady the brach may stand by th fire and stink
55582 Lear A pestilent gall to me
55583 Fool Sirrah I'll teach thee a speech
55584 Lear Do
55585 Fool Mark it nuncle
55586 Have more than thou showest
55587 Speak less than thou knowest
55588 Lend less than thou owest
55589 Ride more than thou goest
55590 Learn more than thou trowest
55591 Set less than thou throwest
55592 Leave thy drink and thy whore
55593 And keep inadoor
55594 And thou shalt have more
55595 Than two tens to a score
55596 Kent This is nothing fool
55597 Fool Then 'tis like the breath of an unfeed lawyer you gave me
55598 nothing for't Can you make no use of nothing nuncle
55599 Lear Why no boy Nothing can be made out of nothing
55600 Fool [to Kent] Prithee tell him so much the rent of his land
55601 comes to He will not believe a fool
55602 Lear A bitter fool
55603 Fool Dost thou know the difference my boy between a bitter
55604 fool and a sweet fool
55605 Lear No lad teach me
55606 Fool That lord that counsell'd thee
55607 To give away thy land
55608 Come place him here by me
55609 Do thou for him stand
55610 The sweet and bitter fool
55611 Will presently appear
55612 The one in motley here
55613 The other found out there
55614 Lear Dost thou call me fool boy
55615 Fool All thy other titles thou hast given away that thou wast
55616 born with
55617 Kent This is not altogether fool my lord
55618 Fool No faith lords and great men will not let me If I had a
55619 monopoly out they would have part on't And ladies too they
55620 will not let me have all the fool to myself they'll be
55621 snatching Give me an egg nuncle and I'll give thee two
55622 crowns
55623 Lear What two crowns shall they be
55624 Fool Why after I have cut the egg i th middle and eat up the
55625 meat the two crowns of the egg When thou clovest thy crown i'
55626 th middle and gav'st away both parts thou bor'st thine ass on
55627 thy back o'er the dirt Thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown
55628 when thou gav'st thy golden one away If I speak like myself in
55629 this let him be whipp'd that first finds it so
55630 [Sings] Fools had ne'er less grace in a year
55631 For wise men are grown foppish
55632 They know not how their wits to wear
55633 Their manners are so apish
55634 Lear When were you wont to be so full of songs sirrah
55635 Fool I have us'd it nuncle ever since thou mad'st thy daughters
55636 thy mother for when thou gav'st them the rod and put'st down
55637 thine own breeches
55638 [Sings] Then they for sudden joy did weep
55639 And I for sorrow sung
55640 That such a king should play bopeep
55641 And go the fools among
55642 Prithee nuncle keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to
55643 lie I would fain learn to lie
55644 Lear An you lie sirrah we'll have you whipp'd
55645 Fool I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are They'll have me
55646 whipp'd for speaking true thou'lt have me whipp'd for lying
55647 and sometimes I am whipp'd for holding my peace I had rather be
55648 any kind o thing than a fool And yet I would not be thee
55649 nuncle Thou hast pared thy wit o both sides and left nothing
55650 i th middle Here comes one o the parings
55651 Enter Goneril
55652 Lear How now daughter What makes that frontlet on Methinks you
55653 are too much o late i th frown
55654 Fool Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for
55655 her frowning Now thou art an O without a figure I am better
55656 than thou art now I am a fool thou art nothing
55657 [To Goneril] Yes forsooth I will hold my tongue So your face
55658 bids me though you say nothing Mum mum
55659 He that keeps nor crust nor crum
55660 Weary of all shall want some
55661 [Points at Lear] That's a sheal'd peascod
55662 Gon Not only sir this your alllicens'd fool
55663 But other of your insolent retinue
55664 Do hourly carp and quarrel breaking forth
55665 In rank and nottobeendured riots Sir
55666 I had thought by making this well known unto you
55667 To have found a safe redress but now grow fearful
55668 By what yourself too late have spoke and done
55669 That you protect this course and put it on
55670 By your allowance which if you should the fault
55671 Would not scape censure nor the redresses sleep
55672 Which in the tender of a wholesome weal
55673 Might in their working do you that offence
55674 Which else were shame that then necessity
55675 Must call discreet proceeding
55676 Fool For you know nuncle
55677 The hedgesparrow fed the cuckoo so long
55678 That it had it head bit off by it young
55679 So out went the candle and we were left darkling
55680 Lear Are you our daughter
55681 Gon Come sir
55682 I would you would make use of that good wisdom
55683 Whereof I know you are fraught and put away
55684 These dispositions that of late transform you
55685 From what you rightly are
55686 Fool May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse
55687 Whoop Jug I love thee
55688 Lear Doth any here know me This is not Lear
55689 Doth Lear walk thus speak thus Where are his eyes
55690 Either his notion weakens his discernings
55691 Are lethargied Ha waking 'Tis not so
55692 Who is it that can tell me who I am
55693 Fool Lear's shadow
55694 Lear I would learn that for by the marks of sovereignty
55695 Knowledge and reason I should be false persuaded
55696 I had daughters
55697 Fool Which they will make an obedient father
55698 Lear Your name fair gentlewoman
55699 Gon This admiration sir is much o th savour
55700 Of other your new pranks I do beseech you
55701 To understand my purposes aright
55702 As you are old and reverend you should be wise
55703 Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires
55704 Men so disorder'd so debosh'd and bold
55705 That this our court infected with their manners
55706 Shows like a riotous inn Epicurism and lust
55707 Make it more like a tavern or a brothel
55708 Than a grac'd palace The shame itself doth speak
55709 For instant remedy Be then desir'd
55710 By her that else will take the thing she begs
55711 A little to disquantity your train
55712 And the remainder that shall still depend
55713 To be such men as may besort your age
55714 Which know themselves and you
55715 Lear Darkness and devils
55716 Saddle my horses Call my train together
55717 Degenerate bastard I'll not trouble thee
55718 Yet have I left a daughter
55719 Gon You strike my people and your disorder'd rabble
55720 Make servants of their betters
55721 Enter Albany
55722 Lear Woe that too late repents O sir are you come
55723 Is it your will Speak sir Prepare my horses
55724 Ingratitude thou marblehearted fiend
55725 More hideous when thou show'st thee in a child
55726 Than the seamonster
55727 Alb Pray sir be patient
55728 Lear [to Goneril] Detested kite thou liest
55729 My train are men of choice and rarest parts
55730 That all particulars of duty know
55731 And in the most exact regard support
55732 The worships of their name O most small fault
55733 How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show
55734 Which like an engine wrench'd my frame of nature
55735 From the fix'd place drew from my heart all love
55736 And added to the gall O Lear Lear Lear
55737 Beat at this gate that let thy folly in [Strikes his head]
55738 And thy dear judgment out Go go my people
55739 Alb My lord I am guiltless as I am ignorant
55740 Of what hath mov'd you
55741 Lear It may be so my lord
55742 Hear Nature hear dear goddess hear
55743 Suspend thy purpose if thou didst intend
55744 To make this creature fruitful
55745 Into her womb convey sterility
55746 Dry up in her the organs of increase
55747 And from her derogate body never spring
55748 A babe to honour her If she must teem
55749 Create her child of spleen that it may live
55750 And be a thwart disnatur'd torment to her
55751 Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth
55752 With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks
55753 Turn all her mother's pains and benefits
55754 To laughter and contempt that she may feel
55755 How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is
55756 To have a thankless child Away away Exit
55757 Alb Now gods that we adore whereof comes this
55758 Gon Never afflict yourself to know the cause
55759 But let his disposition have that scope
55760 That dotage gives it
55761 Enter Lear
55762 Lear What fifty of my followers at a clap
55763 Within a fortnight
55764 Alb What's the matter sir
55765 Lear I'll tell thee [To Goneril] Life and death I am asham'd
55766 That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus
55767 That these hot tears which break from me perforce
55768 Should make thee worth them Blasts and fogs upon thee
55769 Th untented woundings of a father's curse
55770 Pierce every sense about thee Old fond eyes
55771 Beweep this cause again I'll pluck ye out
55772 And cast you with the waters that you lose
55773 To temper clay Yea is it come to this
55774 Let it be so Yet have I left a daughter
55775 Who I am sure is kind and comfortable
55776 When she shall hear this of thee with her nails
55777 She'll flay thy wolvish visage Thou shalt find
55778 That I'll resume the shape which thou dost think
55779 I have cast off for ever thou shalt I warrant thee
55780 Exeunt [Lear Kent and Attendants]
55781 Gon Do you mark that my lord
55782 Alb I cannot be so partial Goneril
55783 To the great love I bear you
55784 Gon Pray you content What Oswald ho
55785 [To the Fool] You sir more knave than fool after your master
55786 Fool Nuncle Lear nuncle Lear tarry Take the fool with thee
55787 A fox when one has caught her
55788 And such a daughter
55789 Should sure to the slaughter
55790 If my cap would buy a halter
55791 So the fool follows after Exit
55792 Gon This man hath had good counsel A hundred knights
55793 'Tis politic and safe to let him keep
55794 At point a hundred knights yes that on every dream
55795 Each buzz each fancy each complaint dislike
55796 He may enguard his dotage with their pow'rs
55797 And hold our lives in mercy Oswald I say
55798 Alb Well you may fear too far
55799 Gon Safer than trust too far
55800 Let me still take away the harms I fear
55801 Not fear still to be taken I know his heart
55802 What he hath utter'd I have writ my sister
55803 If she sustain him and his hundred knights
55804 When I have show'd th unfitness
55805 Enter [Oswald the] Steward
55806 How now Oswald
55807 What have you writ that letter to my sister
55808 Osw Yes madam
55809 Gon Take you some company and away to horse
55810 Inform her full of my particular fear
55811 And thereto add such reasons of your own
55812 As may compact it more Get you gone
55813 And hasten your return [Exit Oswald] No no my lord
55814 This milky gentleness and course of yours
55815 Though I condemn it not yet under pardon
55816 You are much more at task for want of wisdom
55817 Than prais'd for harmful mildness
55818 Alb How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell
55819 Striving to better oft we mar what's well
55820 Gon Nay then
55821 Alb Well well th event Exeunt
55822 Scene V
55823 Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
55824 Enter Lear Kent and Fool
55825 Lear Go you before to Gloucester with these letters Acquaint my
55826 daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her
55827 demand out of the letter If your diligence be not speedy I
55828 shall be there afore you
55829 Kent I will not sleep my lord till I have delivered your letter
55830 Exit
55831 Fool If a man's brains were in's heels were't not in danger of
55832 kibes
55833 Lear Ay boy
55834 Fool Then I prithee be merry Thy wit shall ne'er go slipshod
55835 Lear Ha ha ha
55836 Fool Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly for though
55837 she's as like this as a crab's like an apple yet I can tell
55838 what I can tell
55839 Lear What canst tell boy
55840 Fool She'll taste as like this as a crab does to a crab Thou
55841 canst tell why one's nose stands i th middle on's face
55842 Lear No
55843 Fool Why to keep one's eyes of either side's nose that what a
55844 man cannot smell out 'a may spy into
55845 Lear I did her wrong
55846 Fool Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell
55847 Lear No
55848 Fool Nor I neither but I can tell why a snail has a house
55849 Lear Why
55850 Fool Why to put's head in not to give it away to his daughters
55851 and leave his horns without a case
55852 Lear I will forget my nature So kind a father Be my horses
55853 ready
55854 Fool Thy asses are gone about 'em The reason why the seven stars
55855 are no moe than seven is a pretty reason
55856 Lear Because they are not eight
55857 Fool Yes indeed Thou wouldst make a good fool
55858 Lear To tak't again perforce Monster ingratitude
55859 Fool If thou wert my fool nuncle I'ld have thee beaten for being
55860 old before thy time
55861 Lear How's that
55862 Fool Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise
55863 Lear O let me not be mad not mad sweet heaven
55864 Keep me in temper I would not be mad
55865 [Enter a Gentleman]
55866 How now Are the horses ready
55867 Gent Ready my lord
55868 Lear Come boy
55869 Fool She that's a maid now and laughs at my departure
55870 Shall not be a maid long unless things be cut shorter
55871 Exeunt

55880 ACT II Scene I
55881 A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
55882 Enter [Edmund the] Bastard and Curan meeting
55883 Edm Save thee Curan
55884 Cur And you sir I have been with your father and given him
55885 notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his Duchess will be
55886 here with him this night
55887 Edm How comes that
55888 Cur Nay I know not You have heard of the news abroad I mean the
55889 whisper'd ones for they are yet but earkissing arguments
55890 Edm Not I Pray you what are they
55891 Cur Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the two Dukes
55892 of Cornwall and Albany
55893 Edm Not a word
55894 Cur You may do then in time Fare you well sir Exit
55895 Edm The Duke be here tonight The better best
55896 This weaves itself perforce into my business
55897 My father hath set guard to take my brother
55898 And I have one thing of a queasy question
55899 Which I must act Briefness and fortune work
55900 Brother a word Descend Brother I say
55901 Enter Edgar
55902 My father watches O sir fly this place
55903 Intelligence is given where you are hid
55904 You have now the good advantage of the night
55905 Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall
55906 He's coming hither now i th night i th haste
55907 And Regan with him Have you nothing said
55908 Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany
55909 Advise yourself
55910 Edg I am sure on't not a word
55911 Edm I hear my father coming Pardon me
55912 In cunning I must draw my sword upon you
55913 Draw seem to defend yourself now quit you well
55914 Yield Come before my father Light ho here
55915 Fly brother Torches torches So farewell
55916 Exit Edgar
55917 Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion
55918 Of my more fierce endeavour [Stabs his arm] I have seen
55919 drunkards
55920 Do more than this in sport Father father
55921 Stop stop No help
55922 Enter Gloucester and Servants with torches
55923 Glou Now Edmund where's the villain
55924 Edm Here stood he in the dark his sharp sword out
55925 Mumbling of wicked charms conjuring the moon
55926 To stand 's auspicious mistress
55927 Glou But where is he
55928 Edm Look sir I bleed
55929 Glou Where is the villain Edmund
55930 Edm Fled this way sir When by no means he could
55931 Glou Pursue him ho Go after [Exeunt some Servants]
55932 By no means what
55933 Edm Persuade me to the murther of your lordship
55934 But that I told him the revenging gods
55935 'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend
55936 Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond
55937 The child was bound to th father sir in fine
55938 Seeing how loathly opposite I stood
55939 To his unnatural purpose in fell motion
55940 With his prepared sword he charges home
55941 My unprovided body lanch'd mine arm
55942 But when he saw my best alarum'd spirits
55943 Bold in the quarrel's right rous'd to th encounter
55944 Or whether gasted by the noise I made
55945 Full suddenly he fled
55946 Glou Let him fly far
55947 Not in this land shall he remain uncaught
55948 And found dispatch The noble Duke my master
55949 My worthy arch and patron comes tonight
55950 By his authority I will proclaim it
55951 That he which find him shall deserve our thanks
55952 Bringing the murderous caitiff to the stake
55953 He that conceals him death
55954 Edm When I dissuaded him from his intent
55955 And found him pight to do it with curst speech
55956 I threaten'd to discover him He replied
55957 'Thou unpossessing bastard dost thou think
55958 If I would stand against thee would the reposal
55959 Of any trust virtue or worth in thee
55960 Make thy words faith'd No What I should deny
55961 As this I would ay though thou didst produce
55962 My very character I'ld turn it all
55963 To thy suggestion plot and damned practice
55964 And thou must make a dullard of the world
55965 If they not thought the profits of my death
55966 Were very pregnant and potential spurs
55967 To make thee seek it'
55968 Glou Strong and fast'ned villain
55969 Would he deny his letter I never got him
55970 Tucket within
55971 Hark the Duke's trumpets I know not why he comes
55972 All ports I'll bar the villain shall not scape
55973 The Duke must grant me that Besides his picture
55974 I will send far and near that all the kingdom
55975 May have due note of him and of my land
55976 Loyal and natural boy I'll work the means
55977 To make thee capable
55978 Enter Cornwall Regan and Attendants
55979 Corn How now my noble friend Since I came hither
55980 Which I can call but now I have heard strange news
55981 Reg If it be true all vengeance comes too short
55982 Which can pursue th offender How dost my lord
55983 Glou O madam my old heart is crack'd it's crack'd
55984 Reg What did my father's godson seek your life
55985 He whom my father nam'd Your Edgar
55986 Glou O lady lady shame would have it hid
55987 Reg Was he not companion with the riotous knights
55988 That tend upon my father
55989 Glou I know not madam 'Tis too bad too bad
55990 Edm Yes madam he was of that consort
55991 Reg No marvel then though he were ill affected
55992 'Tis they have put him on the old man's death
55993 To have th expense and waste of his revenues
55994 I have this present evening from my sister
55995 Been well inform'd of them and with such cautions
55996 That if they come to sojourn at my house
55997 I'll not be there
55998 Corn Nor I assure thee Regan
55999 Edmund I hear that you have shown your father
56000 A childlike office
56001 Edm 'Twas my duty sir
56002 Glou He did bewray his practice and receiv'd
56003 This hurt you see striving to apprehend him
56004 Corn Is he pursued
56005 Glou Ay my good lord
56006 Corn If he be taken he shall never more
56007 Be fear'd of doing harm Make your own purpose
56008 How in my strength you please For you Edmund
56009 Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant
56010 So much commend itself you shall be ours
56011 Natures of such deep trust we shall much need
56012 You we first seize on
56013 Edm I shall serve you sir
56014 Truly however else
56015 Glou For him I thank your Grace
56016 Corn You know not why we came to visit you
56017 Reg Thus out of season threading darkey'd night
56018 Occasions noble Gloucester of some poise
56019 Wherein we must have use of your advice
56020 Our father he hath writ so hath our sister
56021 Of differences which I best thought it fit
56022 To answer from our home The several messengers
56023 From hence attend dispatch Our good old friend
56024 Lay comforts to your bosom and bestow
56025 Your needful counsel to our business
56026 Which craves the instant use
56027 Glou I serve you madam
56028 Your Graces are right welcome
56029 Exeunt Flourish
56030 Scene II
56031 Before Gloucester's Castle
56032 Enter Kent and [Oswald the] Steward severally
56033 Osw Good dawning to thee friend Art of this house
56034 Kent Ay
56035 Osw Where may we set our horses
56036 Kent I th mire
56037 Osw Prithee if thou lov'st me tell me
56038 Kent I love thee not
56039 Osw Why then I care not for thee
56040 Kent If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold I would make thee care for
56041 me
56042 Osw Why dost thou use me thus I know thee not
56043 Kent Fellow I know thee
56044 Osw What dost thou know me for
56045 Kent A knave a rascal an eater of broken meats a base proud
56046 shallow beggarly threesuited hundredpound filthy
56047 worstedstocking knave a lilyliver'd actiontaking whoreson
56048 glassgazing superserviceable finical rogue
56049 onetrunkinheriting slave one that wouldst be a bawd in way of
56050 good service and art nothing but the composition of a knave
56051 beggar coward pander and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch
56052 one whom I will beat into clamorous whining if thou deny the
56053 least syllable of thy addition
56054 Osw Why what a monstrous fellow art thou thus to rail on one
56055 that's neither known of thee nor knows thee
56056 Kent What a brazenfac'd varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me
56057 Is it two days ago since I beat thee and tripp'd up thy heels
56058 before the King [Draws his sword] Draw you rogue for though
56059 it be night yet the moon shines I'll make a sop o th'
56060 moonshine o you Draw you whoreson cullionly barbermonger
56061 draw
56062 Osw Away I have nothing to do with thee
56063 Kent Draw you rascal You come with letters against the King and
56064 take Vanity the puppet's part against the royalty of her father
56065 Draw you rogue or I'll so carbonado your shanks Draw you
56066 rascal Come your ways
56067 Osw Help ho murther help
56068 Kent Strike you slave Stand rogue Stand you neat slave
56069 Strike [Beats him]
56070 Osw Help ho murther murther
56071 Enter Edmund with his rapier drawn Gloucester Cornwall
56072 Regan Servants
56073 Edm How now What's the matter Parts [them]
56074 Kent With you goodman boy an you please Come I'll flesh ye
56075 Come on young master
56076 Glou Weapons arms What's the matter here
56077 Corn Keep peace upon your lives
56078 He dies that strikes again What is the matter
56079 Reg The messengers from our sister and the King
56080 Corn What is your difference Speak
56081 Osw I am scarce in breath my lord
56082 Kent No marvel you have so bestirr'd your valour You cowardly
56083 rascal nature disclaims in thee a tailor made thee
56084 Corn Thou art a strange fellow A tailor make a man
56085 Kent Ay a tailor sir A stonecutter or a painter could not have
56086 made him so ill though he had been but two hours at the trade
56087 Corn Speak yet how grew your quarrel
56088 Osw This ancient ruffian sir whose life I have spar'd
56089 At suit of his grey beard
56090 Kent Thou whoreson zed thou unnecessary letter My lord if
56091 you'll give me leave I will tread this unbolted villain into
56092 mortar and daub the walls of a jakes with him 'Spare my grey
56093 beard you wagtail
56094 Corn Peace sirrah
56095 You beastly knave know you no reverence
56096 Kent Yes sir but anger hath a privilege
56097 Corn Why art thou angry
56098 Kent That such a slave as this should wear a sword
56099 Who wears no honesty Such smiling rogues as these
56100 Like rats oft bite the holy cords atwain
56101 Which are too intrinse t unloose smooth every passion
56102 That in the natures of their lords rebel
56103 Bring oil to fire snow to their colder moods
56104 Renege affirm and turn their halcyon beaks
56105 With every gale and vary of their masters
56106 Knowing naught like dogs but following
56107 A plague upon your epileptic visage
56108 Smile you my speeches as I were a fool
56109 Goose an I had you upon Sarum Plain
56110 I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot
56111 Corn What art thou mad old fellow
56112 Glou How fell you out Say that
56113 Kent No contraries hold more antipathy
56114 Than I and such a knave
56115 Corn Why dost thou call him knave What is his fault
56116 Kent His countenance likes me not
56117 Corn No more perchance does mine or his or hers
56118 Kent Sir 'tis my occupation to be plain
56119 I have seen better faces in my time
56120 Than stands on any shoulder that I see
56121 Before me at this instant
56122 Corn This is some fellow
56123 Who having been prais'd for bluntness doth affect
56124 A saucy roughness and constrains the garb
56125 Quite from his nature He cannot flatter he
56126 An honest mind and plain he must speak truth
56127 An they will take it so if not he's plain
56128 These kind of knaves I know which in this plainness
56129 Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends
56130 Than twenty sillyducking observants
56131 That stretch their duties nicely
56132 Kent Sir in good faith in sincere verity
56133 Under th allowance of your great aspect
56134 Whose influence like the wreath of radiant fire
56135 On flickering Phoebus front
56136 Corn What mean'st by this
56137 Kent To go out of my dialect which you discommend so much I
56138 know sir I am no flatterer He that beguil'd you in a plain
56139 accent was a plain knave which for my part I will not be
56140 though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to't
56141 Corn What was th offence you gave him
56142 Osw I never gave him any
56143 It pleas'd the King his master very late
56144 To strike at me upon his misconstruction
56145 When he conjunct and flattering his displeasure
56146 Tripp'd me behind being down insulted rail'd
56147 And put upon him such a deal of man
56148 That worthied him got praises of the King
56149 For him attempting who was selfsubdu'd
56150 And in the fleshment of this dread exploit
56151 Drew on me here again
56152 Kent None of these rogues and cowards
56153 But Ajax is their fool
56154 Corn Fetch forth the stocks
56155 You stubborn ancient knave you reverent braggart
56156 We'll teach you
56157 Kent Sir I am too old to learn
56158 Call not your stocks for me I serve the King
56159 On whose employment I was sent to you
56160 You shall do small respect show too bold malice
56161 Against the grace and person of my master
56162 Stocking his messenger
56163 Corn Fetch forth the stocks As I have life and honour
56164 There shall he sit till noon
56165 Reg Till noon Till night my lord and all night too
56166 Kent Why madam if I were your father's dog
56167 You should not use me so
56168 Reg Sir being his knave I will
56169 Corn This is a fellow of the selfsame colour
56170 Our sister speaks of Come bring away the stocks
56171 Stocks brought out
56172 Glou Let me beseech your Grace not to do so
56173 His fault is much and the good King his master
56174 Will check him for't Your purpos'd low correction
56175 Is such as basest and contemn'dest wretches
56176 For pilf'rings and most common trespasses
56177 Are punish'd with The King must take it ill
56178 That he so slightly valued in his messenger
56179 Should have him thus restrain'd
56180 Corn I'll answer that
56181 Reg My sister may receive it much more worse
56182 To have her gentleman abus'd assaulted
56183 For following her affairs Put in his legs
56184 [Kent is put in the stocks]
56185 Come my good lord away
56186 Exeunt [all but Gloucester and Kent]
56187 Glou I am sorry for thee friend 'Tis the Duke's pleasure
56188 Whose disposition all the world well knows
56189 Will not be rubb'd nor stopp'd I'll entreat for thee
56190 Kent Pray do not sir I have watch'd and travell'd hard
56191 Some time I shall sleep out the rest I'll whistle
56192 A good man's fortune may grow out at heels
56193 Give you good morrow
56194 Glou The Duke 's to blame in this 'twill be ill taken
56195 Exit
56196 Kent Good King that must approve the common saw
56197 Thou out of heaven's benediction com'st
56198 To the warm sun
56199 Approach thou beacon to this under globe
56200 That by thy comfortable beams I may
56201 Peruse this letter Nothing almost sees miracles
56202 But misery I know 'tis from Cordelia
56203 Who hath most fortunately been inform'd
56204 Of my obscured course and [reads] 'shall find time
56205 From this enormous state seeking to give
56206 Losses their remedies All weary and o'erwatch'd
56207 Take vantage heavy eyes not to behold
56208 This shameful lodging
56209 Fortune good night smile once more turn thy wheel
56210 Sleeps
56211 Scene III
56212 The open country
56213 Enter Edgar
56214 Edg I heard myself proclaim'd
56215 And by the happy hollow of a tree
56216 Escap'd the hunt No port is free no place
56217 That guard and most unusual vigilance
56218 Does not attend my taking Whiles I may scape
56219 I will preserve myself and am bethought
56220 To take the basest and most poorest shape
56221 That ever penury in contempt of man
56222 Brought near to beast My face I'll grime with filth
56223 Blanket my loins elf all my hair in knots
56224 And with presented nakedness outface
56225 The winds and persecutions of the sky
56226 The country gives me proof and precedent
56227 Of Bedlam beggars who with roaring voices
56228 Strike in their numb'd and mortified bare arms
56229 Pins wooden pricks nails sprigs of rosemary
56230 And with this horrible object from low farms
56231 Poor pelting villages sheepcotes and mills
56232 Sometime with lunatic bans sometime with prayers
56233 Enforce their charity 'Poor Turlygod poor Tom'
56234 That's something yet Edgar I nothing am Exit
56235 Scene IV
56236 Before Gloucester's Castle Kent in the stocks
56237 Enter Lear Fool and Gentleman
56238 Lear 'Tis strange that they should so depart from home
56239 And not send back my messenger
56240 Gent As I learn'd
56241 The night before there was no purpose in them
56242 Of this remove
56243 Kent Hail to thee noble master
56244 Lear Ha
56245 Mak'st thou this shame thy pastime
56246 Kent No my lord
56247 Fool Ha ha look he wears cruel garters Horses are tied by the
56248 head dogs and bears by th neck monkeys by th loins and men
56249 by th legs When a man's overlusty at legs then he wears
56250 wooden netherstocks
56251 Lear What's he that hath so much thy place mistook
56252 To set thee here
56253 Kent It is both he and she
56254 Your son and daughter
56255 Lear No
56256 Kent Yes
56257 Lear No I say
56258 Kent I say yea
56259 Lear No no they would not
56260 Kent Yes they have
56261 Lear By Jupiter I swear no
56262 Kent By Juno I swear ay
56263 Lear They durst not do't
56264 They would not could not do't 'Tis worse than murther
56265 To do upon respect such violent outrage
56266 Resolve me with all modest haste which way
56267 Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage
56268 Coming from us
56269 Kent My lord when at their home
56270 I did commend your Highness letters to them
56271 Ere I was risen from the place that show'd
56272 My duty kneeling came there a reeking post
56273 Stew'd in his haste half breathless panting forth
56274 From Goneril his mistress salutations
56275 Deliver'd letters spite of intermission
56276 Which presently they read on whose contents
56277 They summon'd up their meiny straight took horse
56278 Commanded me to follow and attend
56279 The leisure of their answer gave me cold looks
56280 And meeting here the other messenger
56281 Whose welcome I perceiv'd had poison'd mine
56282 Being the very fellow which of late
56283 Display'd so saucily against your Highness
56284 Having more man than wit about me drew
56285 He rais'd the house with loud and coward cries
56286 Your son and daughter found this trespass worth
56287 The shame which here it suffers
56288 Fool Winter's not gone yet if the wild geese fly that way
56289 Fathers that wear rags
56290 Do make their children blind
56291 But fathers that bear bags
56292 Shall see their children kind
56293 Fortune that arrant whore
56294 Ne'er turns the key to th poor
56295 But for all this thou shalt have as many dolours for thy
56296 daughters as thou canst tell in a year
56297 Lear O how this mother swells up toward my heart
56298 Hysterica passio Down thou climbing sorrow
56299 Thy element's below Where is this daughter
56300 Kent With the Earl sir here within
56301 Lear Follow me not
56302 Stay here Exit
56303 Gent Made you no more offence but what you speak of
56304 Kent None
56305 How chance the King comes with so small a number
56306 Fool An thou hadst been set i th stocks for that question
56307 thou'dst well deserv'd it
56308 Kent Why fool
56309 Fool We'll set thee to school to an ant to teach thee there's no
56310 labouring i th winter All that follow their noses are led by
56311 their eyes but blind men and there's not a nose among twenty
56312 but can smell him that's stinking Let go thy hold when a great
56313 wheel runs down a hill lest it break thy neck with following
56314 it but the great one that goes upward let him draw thee after
56315 When a wise man gives thee better counsel give me mine again I
56316 would have none but knaves follow it since a fool gives it
56317 That sir which serves and seeks for gain
56318 And follows but for form
56319 Will pack when it begins to rain
56320 And leave thee in the storm
56321 But I will tarry the fool will stay
56322 And let the wise man fly
56323 The knave turns fool that runs away
56324 The fool no knave perdy
56325 Kent Where learn'd you this fool
56326 Fool Not i th stocks fool
56327 Enter Lear and Gloucester
56328 Lear Deny to speak with me They are sick they are weary
56329 They have travell'd all the night Mere fetches
56330 The images of revolt and flying off
56331 Fetch me a better answer
56332 Glou My dear lord
56333 You know the fiery quality of the Duke
56334 How unremovable and fix'd he is
56335 In his own course
56336 Lear Vengeance plague death confusion
56337 Fiery What quality Why Gloucester Gloucester
56338 I'ld speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife
56339 Glou Well my good lord I have inform'd them so
56340 Lear Inform'd them Dost thou understand me man
56341 Glou Ay my good lord
56342 Lear The King would speak with Cornwall the dear father
56343 Would with his daughter speak commands her service
56344 Are they inform'd of this My breath and blood
56345 Fiery the fiery Duke Tell the hot Duke that
56346 No but not yet May be he is not well
56347 Infirmity doth still neglect all office
56348 Whereto our health is bound We are not ourselves
56349 When nature being oppress'd commands the mind
56350 To suffer with the body I'll forbear
56351 And am fallen out with my more headier will
56352 To take the indispos'd and sickly fit
56353 For the sound man Death on my state Wherefore
56354 Should be sit here This act persuades me
56355 That this remotion of the Duke and her
56356 Is practice only Give me my servant forth
56357 Go tell the Duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them
56358 Now presently Bid them come forth and hear me
56359 Or at their chamber door I'll beat the drum
56360 Till it cry sleep to death
56361 Glou I would have all well betwixt you Exit
56362 Lear O me my heart my rising heart But down
56363 Fool Cry to it nuncle as the cockney did to the eels when she
56364 put 'em i th paste alive She knapp'd 'em o th coxcombs with
56365 a stick and cried 'Down wantons down 'Twas her brother that
56366 in pure kindness to his horse buttered his hay
56367 Enter Cornwall Regan Gloucester Servants
56368 Lear Good morrow to you both
56369 Corn Hail to your Grace
56370 Kent here set at liberty
56371 Reg I am glad to see your Highness
56372 Lear Regan I think you are I know what reason
56373 I have to think so If thou shouldst not be glad
56374 I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb
56375 Sepulchring an adultress [To Kent] O are you free
56376 Some other time for that Beloved Regan
56377 Thy sister's naught O Regan she hath tied
56378 Sharptooth'd unkindness like a vulture here
56379 [Lays his hand on his heart]
56380 I can scarce speak to thee Thou'lt not believe
56381 With how deprav'd a quality O Regan
56382 Reg I pray you sir take patience I have hope
56383 You less know how to value her desert
56384 Than she to scant her duty
56385 Lear Say how is that
56386 Reg I cannot think my sister in the least
56387 Would fail her obligation If sir perchance
56388 She have restrain'd the riots of your followers
56389 'Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end
56390 As clears her from all blame
56391 Lear My curses on her
56392 Reg O sir you are old
56393 Nature in you stands on the very verge
56394 Of her confine You should be rul'd and led
56395 By some discretion that discerns your state
56396 Better than you yourself Therefore I pray you
56397 That to our sister you do make return
56398 Say you have wrong'd her sir
56399 Lear Ask her forgiveness
56400 Do you but mark how this becomes the house
56401 'Dear daughter I confess that I am old [Kneels]
56402 Age is unnecessary On my knees I beg
56403 That you'll vouchsafe me raiment bed and food'
56404 Reg Good sir no more These are unsightly tricks
56405 Return you to my sister
56406 Lear [rises] Never Regan
56407 She hath abated me of half my train
56408 Look'd black upon me struck me with her tongue
56409 Most serpentlike upon the very heart
56410 All the stor'd vengeances of heaven fall
56411 On her ingrateful top Strike her young bones
56412 You taking airs with lameness
56413 Corn Fie sir fie
56414 Lear You nimble lightnings dart your blinding flames
56415 Into her scornful eyes Infect her beauty
56416 You fensuck'd fogs drawn by the pow'rful sun
56417 To fall and blast her pride
56418 Reg O the blest gods so will you wish on me
56419 When the rash mood is on
56420 Lear No Regan thou shalt never have my curse
56421 Thy tenderhefted nature shall not give
56422 Thee o'er to harshness Her eyes are fierce but thine
56423 Do comfort and not burn 'Tis not in thee
56424 To grudge my pleasures to cut off my train
56425 To bandy hasty words to scant my sizes
56426 And in conclusion to oppose the bolt
56427 Against my coming in Thou better know'st
56428 The offices of nature bond of childhood
56429 Effects of courtesy dues of gratitude
56430 Thy half o th kingdom hast thou not forgot
56431 Wherein I thee endow'd
56432 Reg Good sir to th purpose
56433 Tucket within
56434 Lear Who put my man i th stocks
56435 Corn What trumpet's that
56436 Reg I know't my sister's This approves her letter
56437 That she would soon be here
56438 Enter [Oswald the] Steward
56439 Is your lady come
56440 Lear This is a slave whose easyborrowed pride
56441 Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows
56442 Out varlet from my sight
56443 Corn What means your Grace
56444 Enter Goneril
56445 Lear Who stock'd my servant Regan I have good hope
56446 Thou didst not know on't Who comes here O heavens
56447 If you do love old men if your sweet sway
56448 Allow obedience if yourselves are old
56449 Make it your cause Send down and take my part
56450 [To Goneril] Art not asham'd to look upon this beard
56451 O Regan wilt thou take her by the hand
56452 Gon Why not by th hand sir How have I offended
56453 All's not offence that indiscretion finds
56454 And dotage terms so
56455 Lear O sides you are too tough
56456 Will you yet hold How came my man i th stocks
56457 Corn I set him there sir but his own disorders
56458 Deserv'd much less advancement
56459 Lear You Did you
56460 Reg I pray you father being weak seem so
56461 If till the expiration of your month
56462 You will return and sojourn with my sister
56463 Dismissing half your train come then to me
56464 I am now from home and out of that provision
56465 Which shall be needful for your entertainment
56466 Lear Return to her and fifty men dismiss'd
56467 No rather I abjure all roofs and choose
56468 To wage against the enmity o th air
56469 To be a comrade with the wolf and owl
56470 Necessity's sharp pinch Return with her
56471 Why the hotblooded France that dowerless took
56472 Our youngest born I could as well be brought
56473 To knee his throne and squirelike pension beg
56474 To keep base life afoot Return with her
56475 Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter
56476 To this detested groom [Points at Oswald]
56477 Gon At your choice sir
56478 Lear I prithee daughter do not make me mad
56479 I will not trouble thee my child farewell
56480 We'll no more meet no more see one another
56481 But yet thou art my flesh my blood my daughter
56482 Or rather a disease that's in my flesh
56483 Which I must needs call mine Thou art a boil
56484 A plague sore an embossed carbuncle
56485 In my corrupted blood But I'll not chide thee
56486 Let shame come when it will I do not call it
56487 I do not bid the Thunderbearer shoot
56488 Nor tell tales of thee to highjudging Jove
56489 Mend when thou canst be better at thy leisure
56490 I can be patient I can stay with Regan
56491 I and my hundred knights
56492 Reg Not altogether so
56493 I look'd not for you yet nor am provided
56494 For your fit welcome Give ear sir to my sister
56495 For those that mingle reason with your passion
56496 Must be content to think you old and so
56497 But she knows what she does
56498 Lear Is this well spoken
56499 Reg I dare avouch it sir What fifty followers
56500 Is it not well What should you need of more
56501 Yea or so many sith that both charge and danger
56502 Speak 'gainst so great a number How in one house
56503 Should many people under two commands
56504 Hold amity 'Tis hard almost impossible
56505 Gon Why might not you my lord receive attendance
56506 From those that she calls servants or from mine
56507 Reg Why not my lord If then they chanc'd to slack ye
56508 We could control them If you will come to me
56509 For now I spy a danger I entreat you
56510 To bring but fiveandtwenty To no more
56511 Will I give place or notice
56512 Lear I gave you all
56513 Reg And in good time you gave it
56514 Lear Made you my guardians my depositaries
56515 But kept a reservation to be followed
56516 With such a number What must I come to you
56517 With fiveandtwenty Regan Said you so
56518 Reg And speak't again my lord No more with me
56519 Lear Those wicked creatures yet do look wellfavour'd
56520 When others are more wicked not being the worst
56521 Stands in some rank of praise [To Goneril] I'll go with thee
56522 Thy fifty yet doth double fiveandtwenty
56523 And thou art twice her love
56524 Gon Hear me my lord
56525 What need you fiveandtwenty ten or five
56526 To follow in a house where twice so many
56527 Have a command to tend you
56528 Reg What need one
56529 Lear O reason not the need Our basest beggars
56530 Are in the poorest thing superfluous
56531 Allow not nature more than nature needs
56532 Man's life is cheap as beast's Thou art a lady
56533 If only to go warm were gorgeous
56534 Why nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st
56535 Which scarcely keeps thee warm But for true need
56536 You heavens give me that patience patience I need
56537 You see me here you gods a poor old man
56538 As full of grief as age wretched in both
56539 If it be you that stirs these daughters hearts
56540 Against their father fool me not so much
56541 To bear it tamely touch me with noble anger
56542 And let not women's weapons water drops
56543 Stain my man's cheeks No you unnatural hags
56544 I will have such revenges on you both
56545 That all the world shall I will do such things
56546 What they are yet I know not but they shall be
56547 The terrors of the earth You think I'll weep
56548 No I'll not weep
56549 I have full cause of weeping but this heart
56550 Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws
56551 Or ere I'll weep O fool I shall go mad
56552 Exeunt Lear Gloucester Kent and Fool Storm and
56553 tempest
56554 Corn Let us withdraw 'twill be a storm
56555 Reg This house is little the old man and 's people
56556 Cannot be well bestow'd
56557 Gon 'Tis his own blame hath put himself from rest
56558 And must needs taste his folly
56559 Reg For his particular I'll receive him gladly
56560 But not one follower
56561 Gon So am I purpos'd
56562 Where is my Lord of Gloucester
56563 Corn Followed the old man forth
56564 Enter Gloucester
56565 He is return'd
56566 Glou The King is in high rage
56567 Corn Whither is he going
56568 Glou He calls to horse but will I know not whither
56569 Corn 'Tis best to give him way he leads himself
56570 Gon My lord entreat him by no means to stay
56571 Glou Alack the night comes on and the bleak winds
56572 Do sorely ruffle For many miles about
56573 There's scarce a bush
56574 Reg O sir to wilful men
56575 The injuries that they themselves procure
56576 Must be their schoolmasters Shut up your doors
56577 He is attended with a desperate train
56578 And what they may incense him to being apt
56579 To have his ear abus'd wisdom bids fear
56580 Corn Shut up your doors my lord 'tis a wild night
56581 My Regan counsels well Come out o th storm [Exeunt]
