56590 ACT III Scene I
56591 A heath
56592 Storm still Enter Kent and a Gentleman at several doors
56593 Kent Who's there besides foul weather
56594 Gent One minded like the weather most unquietly
56595 Kent I know you Where's the King
56596 Gent Contending with the fretful elements
56597 Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea
56598 Or swell the curled waters 'bove the main
56599 That things might change or cease tears his white hair
56600 Which the impetuous blasts with eyeless rage
56601 Catch in their fury and make nothing of
56602 Strives in his little world of man to outscorn
56603 The toandfroconflicting wind and rain
56604 This night wherein the cubdrawn bear would couch
56605 The lion and the bellypinched wolf
56606 Keep their fur dry unbonneted he runs
56607 And bids what will take all
56608 Kent But who is with him
56609 Gent None but the fool who labours to outjest
56610 His heartstruck injuries
56611 Kent Sir I do know you
56612 And dare upon the warrant of my note
56613 Commend a dear thing to you There is division
56614 Although as yet the face of it be cover'd
56615 With mutual cunning 'twixt Albany and Cornwall
56616 Who have as who have not that their great stars
56617 Thron'd and set high servants who seem no less
56618 Which are to France the spies and speculations
56619 Intelligent of our state What hath been seen
56620 Either in snuffs and packings of the Dukes
56621 Or the hard rein which both of them have borne
56622 Against the old kind King or something deeper
56623 Whereof perchance these are but furnishings
56624 But true it is from France there comes a power
56625 Into this scattered kingdom who already
56626 Wise in our negligence have secret feet
56627 In some of our best ports and are at point
56628 To show their open banner Now to you
56629 If on my credit you dare build so far
56630 To make your speed to Dover you shall find
56631 Some that will thank you making just report
56632 Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
56633 The King hath cause to plain
56634 I am a gentleman of blood and breeding
56635 And from some knowledge and assurance offer
56636 This office to you
56637 Gent I will talk further with you
56638 Kent No do not
56639 For confirmation that I am much more
56640 Than my outwall open this purse and take
56641 What it contains If you shall see Cordelia
56642 As fear not but you shall show her this ring
56643 And she will tell you who your fellow is
56644 That yet you do not know Fie on this storm
56645 I will go seek the King
56646 Gent Give me your hand Have you no more to say
56647 Kent Few words but to effect more than all yet
56648 That when we have found the King in which your pain
56649 That way I'll this he that first lights on him
56650 Holla the other
56651 Exeunt [severally]
56652 Scene II
56653 Another part of the heath
56654 Storm still Enter Lear and Fool
56655 Lear Blow winds and crack your cheeks rage blow
56656 You cataracts and hurricanoes spout
56657 Till you have drench'd our steeples drown'd the cocks
56658 You sulph'rous and thoughtexecuting fires
56659 Vauntcouriers to oakcleaving thunderbolts
56660 Singe my white head And thou allshaking thunder
56661 Strike flat the thick rotundity o th world
56662 Crack Nature's moulds all germains spill at once
56663 That makes ingrateful man
56664 Fool O nuncle court holy water in a dry house is better than this
56665 rain water out o door Good nuncle in and ask thy daughters
56666 blessing Here's a night pities nether wise men nor fools
56667 Lear Rumble thy bellyful Spit fire spout rain
56668 Nor rain wind thunder fire are my daughters
56669 I tax not you you elements with unkindness
56670 I never gave you kingdom call'd you children
56671 You owe me no subscription Then let fall
56672 Your horrible pleasure Here I stand your slave
56673 A poor infirm weak and despis'd old man
56674 But yet I call you servile ministers
56675 That will with two pernicious daughters join
56676 Your highengender'd battles 'gainst a head
56677 So old and white as this O O 'tis foul
56678 Fool He that has a house to put 's head in has a good headpiece
56679 The codpiece that will house
56680 Before the head has any
56681 The head and he shall louse
56682 So beggars marry many
56683 The man that makes his toe
56684 What he his heart should make
56685 Shall of a corn cry woe
56686 And turn his sleep to wake
56687 For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a
56688 glass
56689 Enter Kent
56690 Lear No I will be the pattern of all patience
56691 I will say nothing
56692 Kent Who's there
56693 Fool Marry here's grace and a codpiece that's a wise man and a
56694 fool
56695 Kent Alas sir are you here Things that love night
56696 Love not such nights as these The wrathful skies
56697 Gallow the very wanderers of the dark
56698 And make them keep their caves Since I was man
56699 Such sheets of fire such bursts of horrid thunder
56700 Such groans of roaring wind and rain I never
56701 Remember to have heard Man's nature cannot carry
56702 Th affliction nor the fear
56703 Lear Let the great gods
56704 That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads
56705 Find out their enemies now Tremble thou wretch
56706 That hast within thee undivulged crimes
56707 Unwhipp'd of justice Hide thee thou bloody hand
56708 Thou perjur'd and thou simular man of virtue
56709 That art incestuous Caitiff in pieces shake
56710 That under covert and convenient seeming
56711 Hast practis'd on man's life Close pentup guilts
56712 Rive your concealing continents and cry
56713 These dreadful summoners grace I am a man
56714 More sinn'd against than sinning
56715 Kent Alack bareheaded
56716 Gracious my lord hard by here is a hovel
56717 Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest
56718 Repose you there whilst I to this hard house
56719 More harder than the stones whereof 'tis rais'd
56720 Which even but now demanding after you
56721 Denied me to come in return and force
56722 Their scanted courtesy
56723 Lear My wits begin to turn
56724 Come on my boy How dost my boy Art cold
56725 I am cold myself Where is this straw my fellow
56726 The art of our necessities is strange
56727 That can make vile things precious Come your hovel
56728 Poor fool and knave I have one part in my heart
56729 That's sorry yet for thee
56730 Fool [sings]
56731 He that has and a little tiny wit
56732 With hey ho the wind and the rain
56733 Must make content with his fortunes fit
56734 For the rain it raineth every day
56735 Lear True my good boy Come bring us to this hovel
56736 Exeunt [Lear and Kent]
56737 Fool This is a brave night to cool a courtesan I'll speak a
56738 prophecy ere I go
56739 When priests are more in word than matter
56740 When brewers mar their malt with water
56741 When nobles are their tailors tutors
56742 No heretics burn'd but wenches suitors
56743 When every case in law is right
56744 No squire in debt nor no poor knight
56745 When slanders do not live in tongues
56746 Nor cutpurses come not to throngs
56747 When usurers tell their gold i th field
56748 And bawds and whores do churches build
56749 Then shall the realm of Albion
56750 Come to great confusion
56751 Then comes the time who lives to see't
56752 That going shall be us'd with feet
56753 This prophecy Merlin shall make for I live before his time
56754 Exit
56755 Scene III
56756 Gloucester's Castle
56757 Enter Gloucester and Edmund
56758 Glou Alack alack Edmund I like not this unnatural dealing When
56759 I desir'd their leave that I might pity him they took from me
56760 the use of mine own house charg'd me on pain of perpetual
56761 displeasure neither to speak of him entreat for him nor any
56762 way sustain him
56763 Edm Most savage and unnatural
56764 Glou Go to say you nothing There is division betwixt the Dukes
56765 and a worse matter than that I have received a letter this
56766 night 'tis dangerous to be spoken I have lock'd the letter in
56767 my closet These injuries the King now bears will be revenged
56768 home there's part of a power already footed we must incline to
56769 the King I will seek him and privily relieve him Go you and
56770 maintain talk with the Duke that my charity be not of him
56771 perceived If he ask for me I am ill and gone to bed Though I
56772 die for't as no less is threat'ned me the King my old master
56773 must be relieved There is some strange thing toward Edmund
56774 Pray you be careful Exit
56775 Edm This courtesy forbid thee shall the Duke
56776 Instantly know and of that letter too
56777 This seems a fair deserving and must draw me
56778 That which my father loses no less than all
56779 The younger rises when the old doth fall Exit
56780 Scene IV
56781 The heath Before a hovel
56782 Storm still Enter Lear Kent and Fool
56783 Kent Here is the place my lord Good my lord enter
56784 The tyranny of the open night 's too rough
56785 For nature to endure
56786 Lear Let me alone
56787 Kent Good my lord enter here
56788 Lear Wilt break my heart
56789 Kent I had rather break mine own Good my lord enter
56790 Lear Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm
56791 Invades us to the skin So 'tis to thee
56792 But where the greater malady is fix'd
56793 The lesser is scarce felt Thou'dst shun a bear
56794 But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea
56795 Thou'dst meet the bear i th mouth When the mind's free
56796 The body's delicate The tempest in my mind
56797 Doth from my senses take all feeling else
56798 Save what beats there Filial ingratitude
56799 Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
56800 For lifting food to't But I will punish home
56801 No I will weep no more In such a night
56802 'To shut me out Pour on I will endure
56803 In such a night as this O Regan Goneril
56804 Your old kind father whose frank heart gave all
56805 O that way madness lies let me shun that
56806 No more of that
56807 Kent Good my lord enter here
56808 Lear Prithee go in thyself seek thine own ease
56809 This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
56810 On things would hurt me more But I'll go in
56811 [To the Fool] In boy go first You houseless poverty
56812 Nay get thee in I'll pray and then I'll sleep
56813 Exit [Fool]
56814 Poor naked wretches wheresoe'er you are
56815 That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm
56816 How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides
56817 Your loop'd and window'd raggedness defend you
56818 From seasons such as these O I have ta'en
56819 Too little care of this Take physic pomp
56820 Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel
56821 That thou mayst shake the superflux to them
56822 And show the heavens more just
56823 Edg [within] Fathom and half fathom and half Poor Tom
56824 Enter Fool [from the hovel]
56825 Fool Come not in here nuncle here's a spirit Help me help me
56826 Kent Give me thy hand Who's there
56827 Fool A spirit a spirit He says his name's poor Tom
56828 Kent What art thou that dost grumble there i th straw
56829 Come forth
56830 Enter Edgar [disguised as a madman]
56831 Edg Away the foul fiend follows me Through the sharp hawthorn
56832 blows the cold wind Humh go to thy cold bed and warm thee
56833 Lear Hast thou given all to thy two daughters and art thou come
56834 to this
56835 Edg Who gives anything to poor Tom whom the foul fiend hath led
56836 through fire and through flame through ford and whirlpool o'er
56837 bog and quagmire that hath laid knives under his pillow and
56838 halters in his pew set ratsbane by his porridge made him proud
56839 of heart to ride on a bay trotting horse over fourinch'd
56840 bridges to course his own shadow for a traitor Bless thy five
56841 wits Tom 's acold O do de do de do de Bless thee from
56842 whirlwinds starblasting and taking Do poor Tom some charity
56843 whom the foul fiend vexes There could I have him now and there
56844 and there again and there
56845 Storm still
56846 Lear What have his daughters brought him to this pass
56847 Couldst thou save nothing Didst thou give 'em all
56848 Fool Nay he reserv'd a blanket else we had been all sham'd
56849 Lear Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air
56850 Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters
56851 Kent He hath no daughters sir
56852 Lear Death traitor nothing could have subdu'd nature
56853 To such a lowness but his unkind daughters
56854 Is it the fashion that discarded fathers
56855 Should have thus little mercy on their flesh
56856 Judicious punishment 'Twas this flesh begot
56857 Those pelican daughters
56858 Edg Pillicock sat on Pillicock's Hill 'Allow 'allow loo loo
56859 Fool This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen
56860 Edg Take heed o th foul fiend obey thy parents keep thy word
56861 justly swear not commit not with man's sworn spouse set not
56862 thy sweet heart on proud array Tom 's acold
56863 Lear What hast thou been
56864 Edg A servingman proud in heart and mind that curl'd my hair
56865 wore gloves in my cap serv'd the lust of my mistress heart and
56866 did the act of darkness with her swore as many oaths as I spake
56867 words and broke them in the sweet face of heaven one that
56868 slept in the contriving of lust and wak'd to do it Wine lov'd
56869 I deeply dice dearly and in woman outparamour'd the Turk
56870 False of heart light of ear bloody of hand hog in sloth fox
56871 in stealth wolf in greediness dog in madness lion in prey
56872 Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray
56873 thy poor heart to woman Keep thy foot out of brothel thy hand
56874 out of placket thy pen from lender's book and defy the foul
56875 fiend Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind says
56876 suum mun hey no nonny Dolphin my boy my boy sessa let
56877 him trot by
56878 Storm still
56879 Lear Why thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy
56880 uncover'd body this extremity of the skies Is man no more than
56881 this Consider him well Thou ow'st the worm no silk the beast
56882 no hide the sheep no wool the cat no perfume Ha Here's three
56883 on's are sophisticated Thou art the thing itself
56884 unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor bare forked
56885 animal as thou art Off off you lendings Come unbutton
56886 here
56887 [Tears at his clothes]
56888 Fool Prithee nuncle be contented 'Tis a naughty night to swim
56889 in Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher's
56890 heart a small spark all the rest on's body cold Look here
56891 comes a walking fire
56892 Enter Gloucester with a torch
56893 Edg This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet He begins at curfew
56894 and walks till the first cock He gives the web and the pin
56895 squints the eye and makes the harelip mildews the white wheat
56896 and hurts the poor creature of earth
56897 Saint Withold footed thrice the 'old
56898 He met the nightmare and her nine fold
56899 Bid her alight
56900 And her troth plight
56901 And aroint thee witch aroint thee
56902 Kent How fares your Grace
56903 Lear What's he
56904 Kent Who's there What is't you seek
56905 Glou What are you there Your names
56906 Edg Poor Tom that eats the swimming frog the toad the todpole
56907 the wallnewt and the water that in the fury of his heart when
56908 the foul fiend rages eats cowdung for sallets swallows the
56909 old rat and the ditchdog drinks the green mantle of the
56910 standing pool who is whipp'd from tithing to tithing and
56911 stockpunish'd and imprison'd who hath had three suits to his
56912 back six shirts to his body horse to ride and weapons to
56913 wear
56914 But mice and rats and such small deer
56915 Have been Tom's food for seven long year
56916 Beware my follower Peace Smulkin peace thou fiend
56917 Glou What hath your Grace no better company
56918 Edg The prince of darkness is a gentleman
56919 Modo he's call'd and Mahu
56920 Glou Our flesh and blood is grown so vile my lord
56921 That it doth hate what gets it
56922 Edg Poor Tom 's acold
56923 Glou Go in with me My duty cannot suffer
56924 T obey in all your daughters hard commands
56925 Though their injunction be to bar my doors
56926 And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you
56927 Yet have I ventur'd to come seek you out
56928 And bring you where both fire and food is ready
56929 Lear First let me talk with this philosopher
56930 What is the cause of thunder
56931 Kent Good my lord take his offer go into th house
56932 Lear I'll talk a word with this same learned Theban
56933 What is your study
56934 Edg How to prevent the fiend and to kill vermin
56935 Lear Let me ask you one word in private
56936 Kent Importune him once more to go my lord
56937 His wits begin t unsettle
56938 Glou Canst thou blame him
56939 Storm still
56940 His daughters seek his death Ah that good Kent
56941 He said it would be thus poor banish'd man
56942 Thou say'st the King grows mad I'll tell thee friend
56943 I am almost mad myself I had a son
56944 Now outlaw'd from my blood He sought my life
56945 But lately very late I lov'd him friend
56946 No father his son dearer True to tell thee
56947 The grief hath craz'd my wits What a night 's this
56948 I do beseech your Grace
56949 Lear O cry you mercy sir
56950 Noble philosopher your company
56951 Edg Tom's acold
56952 Glou In fellow there into th hovel keep thee warm
56953 Lear Come let's in all
56954 Kent This way my lord
56955 Lear With him
56956 I will keep still with my philosopher
56957 Kent Good my lord soothe him let him take the fellow
56958 Glou Take him you on
56959 Kent Sirrah come on go along with us
56960 Lear Come good Athenian
56961 Glou No words no words hush
56962 Edg Child Rowland to the dark tower came
56963 His word was still
56964 Fie foh and fum
56965 I smell the blood of a British man
56966 Exeunt
56967 Scene V
56968 Gloucester's Castle
56969 Enter Cornwall and Edmund
56970 Corn I will have my revenge ere I depart his house
56971 Edm How my lord I may be censured that nature thus gives way to
56972 loyalty something fears me to think of
56973 Corn I now perceive it was not altogether your brother's evil
56974 disposition made him seek his death but a provoking merit set
56975 awork by a reproveable badness in himself
56976 Edm How malicious is my fortune that I must repent to be just
56977 This is the letter he spoke of which approves him an
56978 intelligent party to the advantages of France O heavens that
56979 this treason were not or not I the detector
56980 Corn Go with me to the Duchess
56981 Edm If the matter of this paper be certain you have mighty
56982 business in hand
56983 Corn True or false it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester
56984 Seek out where thy father is that he may be ready for our
56985 apprehension
56986 Edm [aside] If I find him comforting the King it will stuff his
56987 suspicion more fully I will persever in my course of loyalty
56988 though the conflict be sore between that and my blood
56989 Corn I will lay trust upon thee and thou shalt find a dearer
56990 father in my love
56991 Exeunt
56992 Scene VI
56993 A farmhouse near Gloucester's Castle
56994 Enter Gloucester Lear Kent Fool and Edgar
56995 Glou Here is better than the open air take it thankfully I will
56996 piece out the comfort with what addition I can I will not be
56997 long from you
56998 Kent All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience
56999 The gods reward your kindness
57000 Exit [Gloucester]
57001 Edg Frateretto calls me and tells me Nero is an angler in the
57002 lake of darkness Pray innocent and beware the foul fiend
57003 Fool Prithee nuncle tell me whether a madman be a gentleman or a
57004 yeoman
57005 Lear A king a king
57006 Fool No he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son for he's a
57007 mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him
57008 Lear To have a thousand with red burning spits
57009 Come hizzing in upon 'em
57010 Edg The foul fiend bites my back
57011 Fool He's mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf a horse's
57012 health a boy's love or a whore's oath
57013 Lear It shall be done I will arraign them straight
57014 [To Edgar] Come sit thou here most learned justicer
57015 [To the Fool] Thou sapient sir sit here Now you shefoxes
57016 Edg Look where he stands and glares Want'st thou eyes at trial
57017 madam
57018 Come o'er the bourn Bessy to me
57019 Fool Her boat hath a leak
57020 And she must not speak
57021 Why she dares not come over to thee
57022 Edg The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale
57023 Hoppedance cries in Tom's belly for two white herring Croak
57024 not black angel I have no food for thee
57025 Kent How do you sir Stand you not so amaz'd
57026 Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions
57027 Lear I'll see their trial first Bring in their evidence
57028 [To Edgar] Thou robed man of justice take thy place
57029 [To the Fool] And thou his yokefellow of equity
57030 Bench by his side [To Kent] You are o th commission
57031 Sit you too
57032 Edg Let us deal justly
57033 Sleepest or wakest thou jolly shepherd
57034 Thy sheep be in the corn
57035 And for one blast of thy minikin mouth
57036 Thy sheep shall take no harm
57037 Purr the cat is gray
57038 Lear Arraign her first 'Tis Goneril I here take my oath before
57039 this honourable assembly she kicked the poor King her father
57040 Fool Come hither mistress Is your name Goneril
57041 Lear She cannot deny it
57042 Fool Cry you mercy I took you for a jointstool
57043 Lear And here's another whose warp'd looks proclaim
57044 What store her heart is made on Stop her there
57045 Arms arms sword fire Corruption in the place
57046 False justicer why hast thou let her scape
57047 Edg Bless thy five wits
57048 Kent O pity Sir where is the patience now
57049 That you so oft have boasted to retain
57050 Edg [aside] My tears begin to take his part so much
57051 They'll mar my counterfeiting
57052 Lear The little dogs and all
57053 Tray Blanch and Sweetheart see they bark at me
57054 Edg Tom will throw his head at them Avaunt you curs
57055 Be thy mouth or black or white
57056 Tooth that poisons if it bite
57057 Mastiff greyhound mongrel grim
57058 Hound or spaniel brach or lym
57059 Bobtail tyke or trundletall
57060 Tom will make them weep and wail
57061 For with throwing thus my head
57062 Dogs leap the hatch and all are fled
57063 Do de de de Sessa Come march to wakes and fairs and market
57064 towns Poor Tom thy horn is dry
57065 Lear Then let them anatomize Regan See what breeds about her
57066 heart Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard
57067 hearts [To Edgar] You sir I entertain you for one of my
57068 hundred only I do not like the fashion of your garments You'll
57069 say they are Persian attire but let them be chang'd
57070 Kent Now good my lord lie here and rest awhile
57071 Lear Make no noise make no noise draw the curtains
57072 So so so We'll go to supper i th morning So so so
57073 Fool And I'll go to bed at noon
57074 Enter Gloucester
57075 Glou Come hither friend Where is the King my master
57076 Kent Here sir but trouble him not his wits are gone
57077 Glou Good friend I prithee take him in thy arms
57078 I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him
57079 There is a litter ready lay him in't
57080 And drive towards Dover friend where thou shalt meet
57081 Both welcome and protection Take up thy master
57082 If thou shouldst dally half an hour his life
57083 With thine and all that offer to defend him
57084 Stand in assured loss Take up take up
57085 And follow me that will to some provision
57086 Give thee quick conduct
57087 Kent Oppressed nature sleeps
57088 This rest might yet have balm'd thy broken senses
57089 Which if convenience will not allow
57090 Stand in hard cure [To the Fool] Come help to bear thy master
57091 Thou must not stay behind
57092 Glou Come come away
57093 Exeunt [all but Edgar]
57094 Edg When we our betters see bearing our woes
57095 We scarcely think our miseries our foes
57096 Who alone suffers suffers most i th mind
57097 Leaving free things and happy shows behind
57098 But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip
57099 When grief hath mates and bearing fellowship
57100 How light and portable my pain seems now
57101 When that which makes me bend makes the King bow
57102 He childed as I fathered Tom away
57103 Mark the high noises and thyself bewray
57104 When false opinion whose wrong thought defiles thee
57105 In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee
57106 What will hap more tonight safe scape the King
57107 Lurk lurk [Exit]
57108 Scene VII
57109 Gloucester's Castle
57110 Enter Cornwall Regan Goneril [Edmund the] Bastard and Servants
57111 Corn [to Goneril] Post speedily to my lord your husband show him
57112 this letter The army of France is landed Seek out the traitor
57113 Gloucester
57114 [Exeunt some of the Servants]
57115 Reg Hang him instantly
57116 Gon Pluck out his eyes
57117 Corn Leave him to my displeasure Edmund keep you our sister
57118 company The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous
57119 father are not fit for your beholding Advise the Duke where you
57120 are going to a most festinate preparation We are bound to the
57121 like Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us
57122 Farewell dear sister farewell my Lord of Gloucester
57123 Enter [Oswald the] Steward
57124 How now Where's the King
57125 Osw My Lord of Gloucester hath convey'd him hence
57126 Some five or six and thirty of his knights
57127 Hot questrists after him met him at gate
57128 Who with some other of the lord's dependants
57129 Are gone with him towards Dover where they boast
57130 To have wellarmed friends
57131 Corn Get horses for your mistress
57132 Gon Farewell sweet lord and sister
57133 Corn Edmund farewell
57134 Exeunt Goneril [Edmund and Oswald]
57135 Go seek the traitor Gloucester
57136 Pinion him like a thief bring him before us
57137 [Exeunt other Servants]
57138 Though well we may not pass upon his life
57139 Without the form of justice yet our power
57140 Shall do a court'sy to our wrath which men
57141 May blame but not control
57142 Enter Gloucester brought in by two or three
57143 Who's there the traitor
57144 Reg Ingrateful fox 'tis he
57145 Corn Bind fast his corky arms
57146 Glou What mean your Graces Good my friends consider
57147 You are my guests Do me no foul play friends
57148 Corn Bind him I say
57149 [Servants bind him]
57150 Reg Hard hard O filthy traitor
57151 Glou Unmerciful lady as you are I am none
57152 Corn To this chair bind him Villain thou shalt find
57153 [Regan plucks his beard]
57154 Glou By the kind gods 'tis most ignobly done
57155 To pluck me by the beard
57156 Reg So white and such a traitor
57157 Glou Naughty lady
57158 These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin
57159 Will quicken and accuse thee I am your host
57160 With robber's hands my hospitable favours
57161 You should not ruffle thus What will you do
57162 Corn Come sir what letters had you late from France
57163 Reg Be simpleanswer'd for we know the truth
57164 Corn And what confederacy have you with the traitors
57165 Late footed in the kingdom
57166 Reg To whose hands have you sent the lunatic King
57167 Speak
57168 Glou I have a letter guessingly set down
57169 Which came from one that's of a neutral heart
57170 And not from one oppos'd
57171 Corn Cunning
57172 Reg And false
57173 Corn Where hast thou sent the King
57174 Glou To Dover
57175 Reg Wherefore to Dover Wast thou not charg'd at peril
57176 Corn Wherefore to Dover Let him first answer that
57177 Glou I am tied to th stake and I must stand the course
57178 Reg Wherefore to Dover sir
57179 Glou Because I would not see thy cruel nails
57180 Pluck out his poor old eyes nor thy fierce sister
57181 In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs
57182 The sea with such a storm as his bare head
57183 In hellblack night endur'd would have buoy'd up
57184 And quench'd the steeled fires
57185 Yet poor old heart he holp the heavens to rain
57186 If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time
57187 Thou shouldst have said 'Good porter turn the key'
57188 All cruels else subscrib'd But I shall see
57189 The winged vengeance overtake such children
57190 Corn See't shalt thou never Fellows hold the chair
57191 Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot
57192 Glou He that will think to live till he be old
57193 Give me some help O cruel O ye gods
57194 Reg One side will mock another Th other too
57195 Corn If you see vengeance
57196 1 Serv Hold your hand my lord
57197 I have serv'd you ever since I was a child
57198 But better service have I never done you
57199 Than now to bid you hold
57200 Reg How now you dog
57201 1 Serv If you did wear a beard upon your chin
57202 I'ld shake it on this quarrel
57203 Reg What do you mean
57204 Corn My villain Draw and fight
57205 1 Serv Nay then come on and take the chance of anger
57206 Reg Give me thy sword A peasant stand up thus
57207 She takes a sword and runs at him behind
57208 1 Serv O I am slain My lord you have one eye left
57209 To see some mischief on him O He dies
57210 Corn Lest it see more prevent it Out vile jelly
57211 Where is thy lustre now
57212 Glou All dark and comfortless Where's my son Edmund
57213 Edmund enkindle all the sparks of nature
57214 To quit this horrid act
57215 Reg Out treacherous villain
57216 Thou call'st on him that hates thee It was he
57217 That made the overture of thy treasons to us
57218 Who is too good to pity thee
57219 Glou O my follies Then Edgar was abus'd
57220 Kind gods forgive me that and prosper him
57221 Reg Go thrust him out at gates and let him smell
57222 His way to Dover
57223 Exit [one] with Gloucester
57224 How is't my lord How look you
57225 Corn I have receiv'd a hurt Follow me lady
57226 Turn out that eyeless villain Throw this slave
57227 Upon the dunghill Regan I bleed apace
57228 Untimely comes this hurt Give me your arm
57229 Exit [Cornwall led by Regan]
57230 2 Serv I'll never care what wickedness I do
57231 If this man come to good
57232 3 Serv If she live long
57233 And in the end meet the old course of death
57234 Women will all turn monsters
57235 2 Serv Let's follow the old Earl and get the bedlam
57236 To lead him where he would His roguish madness
57237 Allows itself to anything
57238 3 Serv Go thou I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
57239 To apply to his bleeding face Now heaven help him
57240 Exeunt

57249 ACT IV Scene I
57250 The heath
57251 Enter Edgar
57252 Edg Yet better thus and known to be contemn'd
57253 Than still contemn'd and flatter'd To be worst
57254 The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune
57255 Stands still in esperance lives not in fear
57256 The lamentable change is from the best
57257 The worst returns to laughter Welcome then
57258 Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace
57259 The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
57260 Owes nothing to thy blasts
57261 Enter Gloucester led by an Old Man
57262 But who comes here
57263 My father poorly led World world O world
57264 But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee
57265 Life would not yield to age
57266 Old Man O my good lord
57267 I have been your tenant and your father's tenant
57268 These fourscore years
57269 Glou Away get thee away Good friend be gone
57270 Thy comforts can do me no good at all
57271 Thee they may hurt
57272 Old Man You cannot see your way
57273 Glou I have no way and therefore want no eyes
57274 I stumbled when I saw Full oft 'tis seen
57275 Our means secure us and our mere defects
57276 Prove our commodities Ah dear son Edgar
57277 The food of thy abused father's wrath
57278 Might I but live to see thee in my touch
57279 I'ld say I had eyes again
57280 Old Man How now Who's there
57281 Edg [aside] O gods Who is't can say 'I am at the worst'
57282 I am worse than e'er I was
57283 Old Man 'Tis poor mad Tom
57284 Edg [aside] And worse I may be yet The worst is not
57285 So long as we can say 'This is the worst'
57286 Old Man Fellow where goest
57287 Glou Is it a beggarman
57288 Old Man Madman and beggar too
57289 Glou He has some reason else he could not beg
57290 I th last night's storm I such a fellow saw
57291 Which made me think a man a worm My son
57292 Came then into my mind and yet my mind
57293 Was then scarce friends with him I have heard more since
57294 As flies to wanton boys are we to th gods
57295 They kill us for their sport
57296 Edg [aside] How should this be
57297 Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow
57298 Ang'ring itself and others Bless thee master
57299 Glou Is that the naked fellow
57300 Old Man Ay my lord
57301 Glou Then prithee get thee gone If for my sake
57302 Thou wilt o'ertake us hence a mile or twain
57303 I th way toward Dover do it for ancient love
57304 And bring some covering for this naked soul
57305 Who I'll entreat to lead me
57306 Old Man Alack sir he is mad
57307 Glou 'Tis the time's plague when madmen lead the blind
57308 Do as I bid thee or rather do thy pleasure
57309 Above the rest be gone
57310 Old Man I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have
57311 Come on't what will Exit
57312 Glou Sirrah naked fellow
57313 Edg Poor Tom's acold [Aside] I cannot daub it further
57314 Glou Come hither fellow
57315 Edg [aside] And yet I must Bless thy sweet eyes they bleed
57316 Glou Know'st thou the way to Dover
57317 Edg Both stile and gate horseway and footpath Poor Tom hath been
57318 scar'd out of his good wits Bless thee good man's son from
57319 the foul fiend Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once of
57320 lust as Obidicut Hobbididence prince of dumbness Mahu of
57321 stealing Modo of murder Flibbertigibbet of mopping and
57322 mowing who since possesses chambermaids and waiting women So
57323 bless thee master
57324 Glou Here take this Purse thou whom the heavens plagues
57325 Have humbled to all strokes That I am wretched
57326 Makes thee the happier Heavens deal so still
57327 Let the superfluous and lustdieted man
57328 That slaves your ordinance that will not see
57329 Because he does not feel feel your pow'r quickly
57330 So distribution should undo excess
57331 And each man have enough Dost thou know Dover
57332 Edg Ay master
57333 Glou There is a cliff whose high and bending head
57334 Looks fearfully in the confined deep
57335 Bring me but to the very brim of it
57336 And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear
57337 With something rich about me From that place
57338 I shall no leading need
57339 Edg Give me thy arm
57340 Poor Tom shall lead thee
57341 Exeunt
57342 Scene II
57343 Before the Duke of Albany's Palace
57344 Enter Goneril and [Edmund the] Bastard
57345 Gon Welcome my lord I marvel our mild husband
57346 Not met us on the way
57347 Enter [Oswald the] Steward
57348 Now where's your master
57349 Osw Madam within but never man so chang'd
57350 I told him of the army that was landed
57351 He smil'd at it I told him you were coming
57352 His answer was 'The worse Of Gloucester's treachery
57353 And of the loyal service of his son
57354 When I inform'd him then he call'd me sot
57355 And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out
57356 What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him
57357 What like offensive
57358 Gon [to Edmund] Then shall you go no further
57359 It is the cowish terror of his spirit
57360 That dares not undertake He'll not feel wrongs
57361 Which tie him to an answer Our wishes on the way
57362 May prove effects Back Edmund to my brother
57363 Hasten his musters and conduct his pow'rs
57364 I must change arms at home and give the distaff
57365 Into my husband's hands This trusty servant
57366 Shall pass between us Ere long you are like to hear
57367 If you dare venture in your own behalf
57368 A mistress's command Wear this [Gives a favour]
57369 Spare speech
57370 Decline your head This kiss if it durst speak
57371 Would stretch thy spirits up into the air
57372 Conceive and fare thee well
57373 Edm Yours in the ranks of death Exit
57374 Gon My most dear Gloucester
57375 O the difference of man and man
57376 To thee a woman's services are due
57377 My fool usurps my body
57378 Osw Madam here comes my lord Exit
57379 Enter Albany
57380 Gon I have been worth the whistle
57381 Alb O Goneril
57382 You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
57383 Blows in your face I fear your disposition
57384 That nature which contemns it origin
57385 Cannot be bordered certain in itself
57386 She that herself will sliver and disbranch
57387 From her material sap perforce must wither
57388 And come to deadly use
57389 Gon No more The text is foolish
57390 Alb Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile
57391 Filths savour but themselves What have you done
57392 Tigers not daughters what have you perform'd
57393 A father and a gracious aged man
57394 Whose reverence even the headlugg'd bear would lick
57395 Most barbarous most degenerate have you madded
57396 Could my good brother suffer you to do it
57397 A man a prince by him so benefited
57398 If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
57399 Send quickly down to tame these vile offences
57400 It will come
57401 Humanity must perforce prey on itself
57402 Like monsters of the deep
57403 Gon Milkliver'd man
57404 That bear'st a cheek for blows a head for wrongs
57405 Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
57406 Thine honour from thy suffering that not know'st
57407 Fools do those villains pity who are punish'd
57408 Ere they have done their mischief Where's thy drum
57409 France spreads his banners in our noiseless land
57410 With plumed helm thy state begins to threat
57411 Whiles thou a moral fool sit'st still and criest
57412 'Alack why does he so'
57413 Alb See thyself devil
57414 Proper deformity seems not in the fiend
57415 So horrid as in woman
57416 Gon O vain fool
57417 Alb Thou changed and selfcover'd thing for shame
57418 Bemonster not thy feature Were't my fitness
57419 To let these hands obey my blood
57420 They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
57421 Thy flesh and bones Howe'er thou art a fiend
57422 A woman's shape doth shield thee
57423 Gon Marry your manhood mew
57424 Enter a Gentleman
57425 Alb What news
57426 Gent O my good lord the Duke of Cornwall 's dead
57427 Slain by his servant going to put out
57428 The other eye of Gloucester
57429 Alb Gloucester's eyes
57430 Gent A servant that he bred thrill'd with remorse
57431 Oppos'd against the act bending his sword
57432 To his great master who thereat enrag'd
57433 Flew on him and amongst them fell'd him dead
57434 But not without that harmful stroke which since
57435 Hath pluck'd him after
57436 Alb This shows you are above
57437 You justicers that these our nether crimes
57438 So speedily can venge But O poor Gloucester
57439 Lose he his other eye
57440 Gent Both both my lord
57441 This letter madam craves a speedy answer
57442 'Tis from your sister
57443 Gon [aside] One way I like this well
57444 But being widow and my Gloucester with her
57445 May all the building in my fancy pluck
57446 Upon my hateful life Another way
57447 The news is not so tart I'll read and answer
57448 Exit
57449 Alb Where was his son when they did take his eyes
57450 Gent Come with my lady hither
57451 Alb He is not here
57452 Gent No my good lord I met him back again
57453 Alb Knows he the wickedness
57454 Gent Ay my good lord 'Twas he inform'd against him
57455 And quit the house on purpose that their punishment
57456 Might have the freer course
57457 Alb Gloucester I live
57458 To thank thee for the love thou show'dst the King
57459 And to revenge thine eyes Come hither friend
57460 Tell me what more thou know'st
57461 Exeunt
57462 Scene III
57463 The French camp near Dover
57464 Enter Kent and a Gentleman
57465 Kent Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know you the
57466 reason
57467 Gent Something he left imperfect in the state which since his
57468 coming forth is thought of which imports to the kingdom so much
57469 fear and danger that his personal return was most required and
57470 necessary
57471 Kent Who hath he left behind him general
57472 Gent The Marshal of France Monsieur La Far
57473 Kent Did your letters pierce the Queen to any demonstration of
57474 grief
57475 Gent Ay sir She took them read them in my presence
57476 And now and then an ample tear trill'd down
57477 Her delicate cheek It seem'd she was a queen
57478 Over her passion who most rebellike
57479 Sought to be king o'er her
57480 Kent O then it mov'd her
57481 Gent Not to a rage Patience and sorrow strove
57482 Who should express her goodliest You have seen
57483 Sunshine and rain at once her smiles and tears
57484 Were like a better way Those happy smilets
57485 That play'd on her ripe lip seem'd not to know
57486 What guests were in her eyes which parted thence
57487 As pearls from diamonds dropp'd In brief
57488 Sorrow would be a rarity most belov'd
57489 If all could so become it
57490 Kent Made she no verbal question
57491 Gent Faith once or twice she heav'd the name of father
57492 Pantingly forth as if it press'd her heart
57493 Cried 'Sisters sisters Shame of ladies Sisters
57494 Kent father sisters What i th storm i th night
57495 Let pity not be believ'd There she shook
57496 The holy water from her heavenly eyes
57497 And clamour moisten'd Then away she started
57498 To deal with grief alone
57499 Kent It is the stars
57500 The stars above us govern our conditions
57501 Else one self mate and mate could not beget
57502 Such different issues You spoke not with her since
57503 Gent No
57504 Kent Was this before the King return'd
57505 Gent No since
57506 Kent Well sir the poor distressed Lear's i th town
57507 Who sometime in his better tune remembers
57508 What we are come about and by no means
57509 Will yield to see his daughter
57510 Gent Why good sir
57511 Kent A sovereign shame so elbows him his own unkindness
57512 That stripp'd her from his benediction turn'd her
57513 To foreign casualties gave her dear rights
57514 To his doghearted daughters these things sting
57515 His mind so venomously that burning shame
57516 Detains him from Cordelia
57517 Gent Alack poor gentleman
57518 Kent Of Albany's and Cornwall's powers you heard not
57519 Gent 'Tis so they are afoot
57520 Kent Well sir I'll bring you to our master Lear
57521 And leave you to attend him Some dear cause
57522 Will in concealment wrap me up awhile
57523 When I am known aright you shall not grieve
57524 Lending me this acquaintance I pray you go
57525 Along with me Exeunt
57526 Scene IV
57527 The French camp
57528 Enter with Drum and Colours Cordelia Doctor and Soldiers
57529 Cor Alack 'tis he Why he was met even now
57530 As mad as the vex'd sea singing aloud
57531 Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow weeds
57532 With hardocks hemlock nettles cuckoo flow'rs
57533 Darnel and all the idle weeds that grow
57534 In our sustaining corn A century send forth
57535 Search every acre in the highgrown field
57536 And bring him to our eye [Exit an Officer] What can man's
57537 wisdom
57538 In the restoring his bereaved sense
57539 He that helps him take all my outward worth
57540 Doct There is means madam
57541 Our foster nurse of nature is repose
57542 The which he lacks That to provoke in him
57543 Are many simples operative whose power
57544 Will close the eye of anguish
57545 Cor All blest secrets
57546 All you unpublish'd virtues of the earth
57547 Spring with my tears be aidant and remediate
57548 In the good man's distress Seek seek for him
57549 Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life
57550 That wants the means to lead it
57551 Enter Messenger
57552 Mess News madam
57553 The British pow'rs are marching hitherward
57554 Cor 'Tis known before Our preparation stands
57555 In expectation of them O dear father
57556 It is thy business that I go about
57557 Therefore great France
57558 My mourning and important tears hath pitied
57559 No blown ambition doth our arms incite
57560 But love dear love and our ag'd father's right
57561 Soon may I hear and see him
57562 Exeunt
57563 Scene V
57564 Gloucester's Castle
57565 Enter Regan and [Oswald the] Steward
57566 Reg But are my brother's pow'rs set forth
57567 Osw Ay madam
57568 Reg Himself in person there
57569 Osw Madam with much ado
57570 Your sister is the better soldier
57571 Reg Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home
57572 Osw No madam
57573 Reg What might import my sister's letter to him
57574 Osw I know not lady
57575 Reg Faith he is posted hence on serious matter
57576 It was great ignorance Gloucester's eyes being out
57577 To let him live Where he arrives he moves
57578 All hearts against us Edmund I think is gone
57579 In pity of his misery to dispatch
57580 His nighted life moreover to descry
57581 The strength o th enemy
57582 Osw I must needs after him madam with my letter
57583 Reg Our troops set forth tomorrow Stay with us
57584 The ways are dangerous
57585 Osw I may not madam
57586 My lady charg'd my duty in this business
57587 Reg Why should she write to Edmund Might not you
57588 Transport her purposes by word Belike
57589 Something I know not what I'll love thee much
57590 Let me unseal the letter
57591 Osw Madam I had rather
57592 Reg I know your lady does not love her husband
57593 I am sure of that and at her late being here
57594 She gave strange eliads and most speaking looks
57595 To noble Edmund I know you are of her bosom
57596 Osw I madam
57597 Reg I speak in understanding Y'are I know't
57598 Therefore I do advise you take this note
57599 My lord is dead Edmund and I have talk'd
57600 And more convenient is he for my hand
57601 Than for your lady's You may gather more
57602 If you do find him pray you give him this
57603 And when your mistress hears thus much from you
57604 I pray desire her call her wisdom to her
57605 So farewell
57606 If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor
57607 Preferment falls on him that cuts him off
57608 Osw Would I could meet him madam I should show
57609 What party I do follow
57610 Reg Fare thee well Exeunt
57611 Scene VI
57612 The country near Dover
57613 Enter Gloucester and Edgar [like a Peasant]
57614 Glou When shall I come to th top of that same hill
57615 Edg You do climb up it now Look how we labour
57616 Glou Methinks the ground is even
57617 Edg Horrible steep
57618 Hark do you hear the sea
57619 Glou No truly
57620 Edg Why then your other senses grow imperfect
57621 By your eyes anguish
57622 Glou So may it be indeed
57623 Methinks thy voice is alter'd and thou speak'st
57624 In better phrase and matter than thou didst
57625 Edg Y'are much deceiv'd In nothing am I chang'd
57626 But in my garments
57627 Glou Methinks y'are better spoken
57628 Edg Come on sir here's the place Stand still How fearful
57629 And dizzy 'tis to cast one's eyes so low
57630 The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
57631 Show scarce so gross as beetles Halfway down
57632 Hangs one that gathers sampire dreadful trade
57633 Methinks he seems no bigger than his head
57634 The fishermen that walk upon the beach
57635 Appear like mice and yond tall anchoring bark
57636 Diminish'd to her cock her cock a buoy
57637 Almost too small for sight The murmuring surge
57638 That on th unnumb'red idle pebble chafes
57639 Cannot be heard so high I'll look no more
57640 Lest my brain turn and the deficient sight
57641 Topple down headlong
57642 Glou Set me where you stand
57643 Edg Give me your hand You are now within a foot
57644 Of th extreme verge For all beneath the moon
57645 Would I not leap upright
57646 Glou Let go my hand
57647 Here friend is another purse in it a jewel
57648 Well worth a poor man's taking Fairies and gods
57649 Prosper it with thee Go thou further off
57650 Bid me farewell and let me hear thee going
57651 Edg Now fare ye well good sir
57652 Glou With all my heart
57653 Edg [aside] Why I do trifle thus with his despair
57654 Is done to cure it
57655 Glou O you mighty gods He kneels
57656 This world I do renounce and in your sights
57657 Shake patiently my great affliction off
57658 If I could bear it longer and not fall
57659 To quarrel with your great opposeless wills
57660 My snuff and loathed part of nature should
57661 Burn itself out If Edgar live O bless him
57662 Now fellow fare thee well
57663 He falls [forward and swoons]
57664 Edg Gone sir farewell
57665 And yet I know not how conceit may rob
57666 The treasury of life when life itself
57667 Yields to the theft Had he been where he thought
57668 By this had thought been past Alive or dead
57669 Ho you sir friend Hear you sir Speak
57670 Thus might he pass indeed Yet he revives
57671 What are you sir
57672 Glou Away and let me die
57673 Edg Hadst thou been aught but gossamer feathers air
57674 So many fadom down precipitating
57675 Thou'dst shiver'd like an egg but thou dost breathe
57676 Hast heavy substance bleed'st not speak'st art sound
57677 Ten masts at each make not the altitude
57678 Which thou hast perpendicularly fell
57679 Thy life is a miracle Speak yet again
57680 Glou But have I fall'n or no
57681 Edg From the dread summit of this chalky bourn
57682 Look up aheight The shrillgorg'd lark so far
57683 Cannot be seen or heard Do but look up
57684 Glou Alack I have no eyes
57685 Is wretchedness depriv'd that benefit
57686 To end itself by death 'Twas yet some comfort
57687 When misery could beguile the tyrant's rage
57688 And frustrate his proud will
57689 Edg Give me your arm
57690 Up so How is't Feel you your legs You stand
57691 Glou Too well too well
57692 Edg This is above all strangeness
57693 Upon the crown o th cliff what thing was that
57694 Which parted from you
57695 Glou A poor unfortunate beggar
57696 Edg As I stood here below methought his eyes
57697 Were two full moons he had a thousand noses
57698 Horns whelk'd and wav'd like the enridged sea
57699 It was some fiend Therefore thou happy father
57700 Think that the clearest gods who make them honours
57701 Of men's impossibility have preserv'd thee
57702 Glou I do remember now Henceforth I'll bear
57703 Affliction till it do cry out itself
57704 'Enough enough and die That thing you speak of
57705 I took it for a man Often 'twould say
57706 'The fiend the fiend he led me to that place
57707 Edg Bear free and patient thoughts
57708 Enter Lear mad [fantastically dressed with weeds]
57709 But who comes here
57710 The safer sense will ne'er accommodate
57711 His master thus
57712 Lear No they cannot touch me for coming
57713 I am the King himself
57714 Edg O thou sidepiercing sight
57715 Lear Nature 's above art in that respect There's your press
57716 money That fellow handles his bow like a crowkeeper Draw me
57717 a clothier's yard Look look a mouse Peace peace this piece
57718 of toasted cheese will do't There's my gauntlet I'll prove it
57719 on a giant Bring up the brown bills O well flown bird i'
57720 th clout i th clout Hewgh Give the word
57721 Edg Sweet marjoram
57722 Lear Pass
57723 Glou I know that voice
57724 Lear Ha Goneril with a white beard They flatter'd me like a dog
57725 and told me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones
57726 were there To say 'ay and 'no to everything I said 'Ay and
57727 'no too was no good divinity When the rain came to wet me
57728 once and the wind to make me chatter when the thunder would
57729 not peace at my bidding there I found 'em there I smelt 'em
57730 out Go to they are not men o their words They told me I was
57731 everything 'Tis a lie I am not agueproof
57732 Glou The trick of that voice I do well remember
57733 Is't not the King
57734 Lear Ay every inch a king
57735 When I do stare see how the subject quakes
57736 I pardon that man's life What was thy cause
57737 Adultery
57738 Thou shalt not die Die for adultery No
57739 The wren goes to't and the small gilded fly
57740 Does lecher in my sight
57741 Let copulation thrive for Gloucester's bastard son
57742 Was kinder to his father than my daughters
57743 Got 'tween the lawful sheets
57744 To't luxury pellmell for I lack soldiers
57745 Behold yond simp'ring dame
57746 Whose face between her forks presageth snow
57747 That minces virtue and does shake the head
57748 To hear of pleasure's name
57749 The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to't
57750 With a more riotous appetite
57751 Down from the waist they are Centaurs
57752 Though women all above
57753 But to the girdle do the gods inherit
57754 Beneath is all the fiend's
57755 There's hell there's darkness there's the sulphurous pit
57756 burning scalding stench consumption Fie fie fie pah pah
57757 Give me an ounce of civet good apothecary to sweeten my
57758 imagination There's money for thee
57759 Glou O let me kiss that hand
57760 Lear Let me wipe it first it smells of mortality
57761 Glou O ruin'd piece of nature This great world
57762 Sh
